description:
Living around the corner from this place, I literally wake up to the smell of croissants and pastries wafting in. Every time I walk past, I admire and chuckle at the folks in line all wide-eyed and excited to try the notorious cruffin. Super glam IG models pose with their box of Mr. Holmes goodies in front of the sign. All day every day. Reminds me of when I first heard of this place as well.

1) it's a sketchy neighborhood but worth the journey. My car has been broken into 5x in one year but these all happen overnight.
2) IG hype is real. Still two cruffins per person at 9am. However if you're here for anything else, the bakery actually opens earlier.

But okay, being super local and not affected by the hype, let's talk about the actual pastries. Are they good? Yes, yes they are. They're worth it as a treat once in a while as those things are $$$. Their croissants look overdone and burnt but they're definitely in the top 4 croissants in SF in my books. I've heard mixed reviews of their donuts but I actually think their donuts are a LOT better than the rest. Their donuts are deep fried fluffy pillows that leak grease through 5 layers of anything. They are sprinkled with sugar and filled with something. So depending on the day, the flavor may not be your gig, but the actual dough is different than your typical ring shaped donut. 

One of the things I still admire is how they create the flavors so well. Having had more than 10 different cruffins, I can say they are not always consistent. Some are drier than other times. Other times I like the filling more than the pastry itself and other times it's vice verse. I judge based on convenience and not by flavor as it's pretty good every day and I'm not picky about flavors. Get ready to shell out that dough for yummy goodness. This place was a gem to me when I first had it and still is a gem to me to this day.
author: Josie W.

description:
Wanted to visit place so many times and finally made it here today!
It is a tiny shop that has a trendy design. Very cute and modern. They got a good selection of both sweet and savory, and I opted for their sweet choices this time.
Their apple cream donut was very good. Not overly sweet and the apple cream inside was fresh. Finishing it won't make your tastebuds full of sugar, so I liked it.
Got their matcha croissant but have yet tried. I fee that I will like it.
The size was small, and I got both for $8.1. It is on the pricey side, so -1 star overall.
author: Tian G.

description:
I just had to stop by this bakery and try the "cruffin". I best describe this insanely deliciousness as a mix of a croissant and something more delicious. 
Though I arrived at about 9:00am I still waited in line for a few short minutes. The customers waiting just like me, we're all definitely excited to try the "cruffin" also. It's really worth the wait, having a gastronomic orgasm at 9:00am is how every day should start.
I guess being so early the street parking was plentiful. 
The service was awesome with the wait time to match.
This is one bakery that I'll definitely recommend and return to.
author: Enrique O.

description:
Great cruffin place in sf!

After I had cruffin here, now I know why people line up early in the morning to get this cruffin. It's amazing. Pastry is perfectly flaky, crispy and not overly sweet! I waited about 20 minutes before they open to get their cruffin and it was worth it! The flavor I got was blackberry wine flavor. I heard flavors of cruffin change everyday. I'd like to go back and try other flavors! I also got their matcha croissant. Matcha coating wasn't overpowering but it didn't really taste like matcha. It was more like white chocolate coating. It was pretty good but I wouldn't get them next time. 

Their cruffin lives up to the hype!
If you haven't tried cruffin before, their cruffin is a must!
author: Clare L.

description:
This is NOT a sit and dine place, which I thought. I was surprised to see that it was a very tiny location with no name outside.

I guess the long line outside alerted me that I found my place. Line moved fairly quickly.

The three ladies behind the counter were very pleasant, and helpful.

Now, let's talk business. I wanted one of each of the pastries on display. I chose the churro croissant, matcha croissant and the famous cruffin.

I tried the cruffin. It melted in my mouth with its buttery flavor and somewhat crispiness.

The hype was all worth it!
author: Pamela M.

description:
On my most recent visit here I came on a Sunday afternoon and the Cruffins were sold out, but they still had their donuts. Their special donut flavor of the day was speculaas, their version of speculoos. Me and my friend decided to get a Speculaas donut and a Churro Croissant, along with a coffee. 

The donut was filled with Speculaas cream and was good, but nothing I would rave about. The Churro Croissant on the other hand was amazing! Super flakey with the perfect amount of filling and cinnamon sugar! Would definitely get this again! 

I've been to Mr. Holmes before and have waited in line early in the morning to get some Cruffins. The Cruffins are good and they look pretty in pictures. Also, the I Got Baked in San Francisco sign is pretty cool, but good luck taking a nice picture when it gets busy inside!
author: Michael L.

description:
Tiny Instagram-ish place. Sadly we couldn't get an cruffins, they run out soon apparently. Def recommend their spiced pear pastry. The churro croissant was a pleasant surprise too with the cream filled centre. 
Heads up - no seating inside the place.
author: Sai J.

description:
I absolutely adore this bakery!! I had a friend visiting in town from New York City, knowing that I had to show her how we also eat good in the West Coast. 

We got in line about 9-9:30, they say the earlier the better because they make a limited amount of cruffins, which are crossover between muffins and croissants with a flavored cream that is made to PERFECTION. Everyday they have a different filling, such as, matcha, pineapple, apple etc. The bakery also, has other pastries such as chocolate filled croissants, danishes and cookies and of course coffee!! 

The infamous cruffins, are flaky and sugary from the outside, however I was concerned that they might be too sweet, but I was pleasantly surprised by the flavor of the filling especially, it is the perfect level of sweetness!
The goodies range from $3-6 for each or you can get a better deal if you buy half a dozen.

Typically, there's a line outside the bakery to get in, usually about 10-15 minutes. 

Aesthetically, the bakery is trendy! They have a light up sign where people take pictures, it says "I got baked in San Francisco" however space inside is very limited. I give this place a 10/10 based on taste!!
author: Rameesha K.

description:
Had to make a pit-stop at this very cute bakery after seeing their neon "I got baked in San Francisco" sign.. Yes, I will admit that the sign caught my eye but the sweets are also pretty amazing.

I knew their "cruffins" were a must, but the cornflake cookie was my favorite! It had a hint of coffee, the cruffin was also delicious- we had one with a lemon and bay leaf filling. Small bakeshop, I was lucky enough to pop in just in time cause shortly after there was a line. Got my cute photo's as well as a to-go box (which was also very photo worthy) with an assortment of treats.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
San Francisco Work trip means doing the most on our free time.. even if that means ditching a class for some sweets :) 
I grabbed a taxi and went off to find this little bakehouse. 
I loved the pastries I flew on the plane back to San diego and they were still impecable!
For sure a must when in SF! 
Do not let the line intimidate you! 
Love it!
author: Judy A.

description:
We had 1 hour in SF and Mr. Holmes has been on our bucket list thanks to all the beautiful Instagram photos. It's a small shop and just a short line when we went on a Sunday morning shortly after they opened. 

Everything we tried was perfect! Nothing was too too sweet and nothing tasted artificial. This was one of those rare times where we indulged in a bunch of pastries and didn't feel crummy afterwards. HIGHLY RECOMMEND
author: Dave M.

description:
I've woke up early to go to Mr Holmes a few times, and every time the cruffins have been sold out. So eventually I just stopped trying lol - I have tried the cruffins though (from my friends who braved the lines) and they're honestly just alright, so I don't think I'd ever wake up early and wait in line for them anymore. 

On my most recent visit, around noon time on a Sunday, there was no wait and there were still a good amount of pastries left! I ended up choosing the churro crossaint and the chef's choice donut (flavor was speculoos). The crossaint was amazing, it was flaky and custard inside was great, and it was perfectly coated with cinnamon and sugar - highly recommend. The donut though, I could've done without. I couldn't really taste the speculoos flavor and it was just overall meh. I feel that the donuts and cruffins are pretty hyped up, and the other pastries they sell are underrated. I'd definitely get their other items instead of the donuts and cruffins. But if I happened to be there early enough where cruffins are still available, I definitely get one. 

Overall, Mr Holmes is pretty good. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if I'm in the area and it's open and they have stuff available, I'll definitely buy something!
author: Stacey Y.

description: I was in the area, so I decided to try a box of pastries from here. My favorite (or maybe the only pastry I really enjoyed) was their Matcha croissant. I thought most of their other pastries were overly sweet or had too much going on. I knew their churro croissant (visibly coated with cinnamon and sugar) would be sweet, but it was also filled with a sweet cream. I wasn't impressed by their signature cruffin either, which was really just a croissant in the shape of a muffin. Also, way too sweet.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Long line moves pretty quickly. Delicious pastries! 
Least favorite was the matcha... most favorite was the peach. Cookie dough stuffed donut close second. 
My husband and I spent $38 and ate everything within 24 hours. #sorrynotsorry
author: Becky M.

description:
I won't lie, I did it for the 'gram. I don't even remember the first time I saw a photo of the famous "I got baked in San Francisco" sign on Instagram, but I knew I had to try to check it out. (#truemillennial) I won't lie, I didn't even know what I would end up getting since I'm not really into sweet pastries. A Cruffin does not appeal to me at all; a ham and cheese croissant, on the other hand... yeah, I could eat one every day. So when I rolled up super early on a weekday morning I was thrilled to see a pastrami croissant just behind the glass of the counter. You bet I scooped him up right away. I was intrigued by the peaches and cream croissant as well, but I figured one would certainly be enough. I was right, since this was technically my first breakfast. (Calories don't count on vacation, or so I've heard. Or told myself.)

The ladies working the counter were friendly and wonderful even as I stood around taking an appropriate number of Instagram photos before I dug into my treat. It was delicious - like a Reuben crossed with a croissant somehow, without the heft of sauerkraut yet still tangy in some way. Who knows, it was awesome and I devoured it. 

Getting there early is obviously key, especially if you want to get that perfect photo or a cruffin. There were only 2 other people there when I went so it was ideal. Is this the best bakery in the world? Probably not. But I think it's worth the stop at least once.
author: Katy C.

description:
The pastry that they are most known for is their mcruffin which is basically just a croissant in the shape of a muffin. I somehow thought it was suppose to be a crossover of a muffin and a croissant but it was all croissant.
The line was pretty long but it went by pretty fast as everyone just tells the staff what they want and they put it in the box. You have to order a total of 6 pastries to get a box (which I wanted). 

My boyfriend and I got 3 mcruffins, a matcha croissant, a peach croissant, and churro croissant. This was too much for four people. We ended up tossing half of the pastries out since we were only in SF for a week and had other places to eat at :( 

To be honest, amazing pastries but not worth waiting more than... 20 minutes for. All the croissants basically tasted the same. The only difference would be the jam that they put inside. The matcha didn't even have a filling inside.
author: Flora L.

description: 9.7/10 - I honestly didn't know what to expect with this place - but I waited in line for 2 hours outside on a weird San Franciscan street for a bomb a$$ donut. It was well worth it. The best donut I've ever had. The shop is mighty small but you walk in, get your food, take your photo with the neon sign if you can find space and then leave. It was everything I needed it to be and more.
author: Madeline M.

description:
This has been on my go to list for such a long time and they did not disappoint! 

It's such a cute little bakery. There's no sign saying the bakery name, but it's obvious when you see a line out the door and you can't miss the neon pink instagram famous sign "I got baked in San Francisco". I arrived around noon so by then the selection was limited. Many things were sold out already, including their famous cruffin sadly.

It's a grab n' go style bakery since the space is so tiny. You can either grab a couple or a box, which fits 6 or more (~$30). I'm not from the bay area so I grabbed a box to bring back home. I got the matcha croissant, churro croissant, elote danish, spinach artichoke danish, mango guava donut, and a pineapple something crumb cake. I like how they add a nice twist and unique flavors to their pastries which you don't see in other bakeries. Everything tasted delicious, especially the croissants and danishes. They were all super flakey and crispy, with the flavors working well with each other. 

I recommend going early to stand in line, that way you have first pick of all the yummy pastries.
author: Alina H.

description:
We used to come here ALL the time when my husband attended UC Hastings which is super closeby. Sad that we're not in the East Bay and the only time we're in the city is for work and this location is kind of out of the way :(

I feel like there is ALWAYS a line when I go. Once my husband and I were in line, towards the back of the line. We were sooo nervous that they would run out and it would ruin our day. Maybe we looked sad or something, cause a lady that came out of the store stops in front of us and says that they're almost out, and asks if we want a few of hers. 

Not sure where this angel came from!! We were sooo happy but of course, we declined cause those are her cruffins, and we can't possible take them from her. But she really must have been an angel cause she said it's fine, that she would love to give us 2! We asked for her Venmo so we can pay her, but she said that it's ok. 

Honestly, with her act of kindness, the cruffins were even more yummier that day!
author: Alex C.

description:
We decided to explore Chinatown and no visit would be complete without a trip to Mr. Holmes. We stopped through not only for a tasty treat but also for the photo opportunities. The place is super cute and clean. The decor is cute and simple. There are sparkling white tiles on the walls and floors. The boxes are stark white branded boxes with gold lettering. The neon quote against the tiled wall makes for a super cute photo. Everything about the interior screams "cute!" 

The bakery is a short walk from Union Square. We walked from the Starbucks and it took us no more than 12 minutes. I want to say it was 1/7th of a mile. 

When we arrived it was literally 20 mins before closing so there were only a couple of patrons. My friend ordered the pineapple coconut cheesecake bostock and I ordered the mango plum donut. I am not sure if they have a large variety of flavors but there were three for us to choose from. Those 3 included the mango plum donut, pineapple coconut cheesecake bostock, and plum tea danish. 

My friend stated that the cheesecake was really good. I loved the donut. I was initially nervous about the taste because although I love mango anything, it was jelly filled and mixed with plum. The two fruit flavors blended well together. The donut was soft and puffy and the exterior was coated in sugar like a sugar donut. 
 
Mango & plum donut $3.75

Lastly, a bathroom is available inside if needed.
author: Latrunda S.

description:
Huge fan of the donuts which they change the flavor of frequently.

I've had the cruffin and don't understand the hype. Mine wasn't filled with anything but there was some PB&J kind of sitting on top of the cruffin.

I've never had to wait and I probably wouldn't. I wouldn't make the trip just for Mr Holmes either. I usually stop by here for donuts on my way to lunch in the TL.
author: Sophia L.

description:
I absolutely love that there is such a variety of croissants. There is something for your sweet tooth and for those a little bit more daring, there are those goodies with a variety of great fillings. The croissants are always a perfect amount of crispiness on the outside, super delicate and flaky on the inside. They are so popular, you can always expect to see a line out the door and down the sidewalk. On the times that I have visited, usually in the later morning before noon, there have been just a few people inside. That being said, there are lots of things that have already sold out.
My advice is to get up early go stand in the line and take your pick of all the wonderful goodies on the inside!
author: Debbie K.

description: I came solely for the cruffins. FYI- the cruffins are not available until 9am even though the place opens at 7am. Luckily there was no line on the Tuesday I went. The flavor for the day was chocolate earl grey cream. I also opted for I believe a pumpkin cheesecake donut. They typically place the pastries individually in a white parchment like bag but since I wasn't eating them immediately, I asked for a box. The boxes are for when you order at least 6 items but I didn't mind paying extra for a it. I just wanted the ease of transportation and for the cream not to get everywhere. As for the cruffin, the chocolate earl grey cream was delightful. The flavor was literally as it's labeled. The cruffin itself has a sugary coating so eat with caution. That stuff gets everywhere! Overall I feel like it's a little overrated. Yes the bakery is ig worthy but the cruffin was a little dry in my opinion. I didn't get a chance to try the donut since sharing is caring but curious how it would be.
author: Lanha T.

description:
This is a must visit if you're in SF! I came here around lunch (12pm) and there was just a short line. It's a small location so expect a line, which does go by quickly! 

There isn't much room here so when you enter where the counter to purchase the pastries, a small counter to sit and the insta-famous wall that says "I got baked in San Francisco". However, to get all the words in, you need to stand pretty far back... meaning you'll be in the way if there's a line (just a guideline of how small this place is). 

This place does get pricey but it's not like you'll spend this much on pastries every time. It's worth the visit! I recommend the cruffins (croissant muffins) which rotates in flavor depending on availability. I recommend to come early so they don't run out. If they do, the filled donuts and matcha croissants are very tasty as well! 

I got to try the guava cream cheese cruffin which was like nothing I've ever tasted in a GOOD way! It doesn't taste artificial which I was afraid of. I also tried a bite of my boyfriends blueberry filled donut. I don't like donuts with sugar sprinkled on the outside... but other than that, it was very tasty and they didn't skimp on the filling.

It's a grab n' go style bakery because of the limited space. They also serve coffee, lemonade and juice!
author: Winnie L.

description: Was looking for a bakery near Union Square and Yelp told me to come here. Omg. There was a line but waited about 25 minutes on Labor Day Monday. Missed the cruffins but plenty of other tasty items to choose from. A bit on the pricey side but they are huge, original and scrumptious.
author: Mitzi W.

description:
Wow. This place blew me away. I've never done so much for a bakery before, let me say that I went on a saturday morning at 7am, we didn't check their weekend hours and they actually open at 8am, so heads up check the hours and dont be like me. So needless to say we were the first people in line. There are also 2 lines: one for people who want just the baked goods on one side and the other side is for cruffins. 

They dont serve cruffins til an hour after they open so we were waiting a long time for these pastries. While we waited, I got a strawberry creme donut and it was incredible, I was also incredibly full...but there were cruffins on the line I couldn't back down.

So we got a box of cruffins (you're limited to i think 4/pp) and on the way back home we split one and it was also amazing, but at that point it was like 9:30am and I was so full for the entirety of the day from 1 cruffin and 1 donut, so if you have a small stomach be wary, but these pastries are great and a must-see spot!
author: Noor H.

description:
I had to make an easy quick pastry stop before my flight to LA after drooling over the Instagram/yelp pictures!  This place is quite small but cute with an Instagram worthy wall that says "I got baked in San Francisco."

Their pastry options are all displayed and are made fresh daily! My sisters and I shared their green tea croissant, chocolate croissant and donut for a light bite on our flight out. All were scrumptious and every bite delicious! 

You won't regret coming to Mr. Holmes!
author: Blair V.

description: I would upload the pictures of my Cheesecake Creme Brûlée and Mediterranean croissant but I inhaled them both before I could. SO GOOD!
author: Alexandria D.

description:
A super sweet coworker ordered Mr. Holmes for us yesterday. 

Mr Holmes has cronuts, donuts, croissants, and all sorts of other delightful pastries. The place itself is super instagrammable, and is worth going to visit! I think they also have a wonderful take-out experience, since every box comes with the famous slogan in gold-lettering.  "I got baked in San Francisco" 

I had the Try it Croissant which comes with fennel, pumpkin seeds, pastrami, and Manchego cheese. It also has pickled oranges and pickled onions in it, but I wasn't able to taste them. 

I liked the texture quite a bit, and the fennel really made the dish for me. 

Definitely a way to win over your coworkers with a twist on your typical office donuts.
author: Jenée S.

description:
Made a stop here to try there goodies!... they were delectable!... I purchased the Peanut Butter and Raspberry Jelly Cruffin, Creme Bruele Danish, Plum Tea Cream Danish, Rest in Peach Croissant, and Churro Croissant.... and just let me say these little gems were soooo delicious!!... But my favorites were the Plum Tea Creme Danish and the Rest in Peach Croissant, don't get me wrong they were all delicious, but those two were just melt in your mouth delicious! 
If you have a chance to try them I highly recommend you do!
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Totally worth the wait! The filled donuts are my favorite! I love the variety and how it's made fresh that day. Line moves fairly fast but stock up!
author: Bo T.

description: I love this place I discovered it today and bought a box of doughnuts. I was planning to bring the box home but I ate all of them by days end. Try a little of everything there I recommend everything though I only bought six . They were very special
author: anthony v.

description:
Mr. Holmes Bakehouse's east coast counterpart, Supeemoon Bakehouse, is one of my favorite places in NYC, so I knew I had to try this place when I came to San Francisco. I got here 15 minutes after it opened, and there was a line out the door already. Looking in, the aesthetic of the place is really nice and instagrammable. I came here for the cruffin, but I was disappointed when I heard that cruffins didn't come out till 9 am. 
I got a chocolate ganache filled donut, a creme brûlée danish, and a matcha croissant. I thought all 3 items were mediocre and really expensive. For all 3 things and a coffee, I paid $15. I think this is one of those places that you come to just to take pictures, but there are much better pastry shops and bakeries in the area. 
Supermoon Bakehouse is definitely superior to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse. Maybe the cruffins will be better!
author: Angela W.

description:
Fantastic bakery in San Francisco! Must visit for me. 

Visited twice during my time in SF, both times in the morning. Expect long lines, but it moves relatively quickly. They also have a sweet light up sign 'Baked in San Francisco' which is perfect for all the instagrammers. 

Favourites were the coffee danish, matcha croissant, and the corn flakes cookie, but the truth is, everything was good!
author: Lester C.

description:
TLDR; 6 pastries cost $20

lavender donut $3.8 - good and not overly sweet, just lots of lavender mousse 
raspberry donut $3.8 - overly sweet, I'd recommend to skip 
creme brulee danish $4.8 - good, need to try again though because I only got a bite
matcha crossiant $4.3 - good but over time becomes a little sweet
-------------------------------
I really didn't know what to expect so I got there when it opened at 7am on a Wednesday haha 

there were 3 other customers plus me, 1 finishing up an order, 1 waiting for an order and another deciding on what to get. There was no wait at all haha I took some time to scout out everything and I'm a pretty picky eater. 

Right when I arrived, first thing I asked was about their cruffin flavor of the day: guava cheesecake - I didn't get one lol 

I was ecstatic my first time visiting they had my favorite as a donut flavor...LAVENDER! so I got myself two of these, 1 raspberry donut, 2 matcha crossiants, 1 creme brulee danish

lavender donut $3.8 - good and not overly sweet, just lots of lavender mousse 
raspberry donut $3.8 - overly sweet, I'd recommend to skip 
creme brulee danish $4.8 - good, need to try again though because I only got a bite
matcha crossiant $4.3 - good but over time becomes a little sweet

I'll be back to visit!
author: Yeanne L.

description:
Mr. Holmes might be one of my favorite bakeries in SF, but not for the reason you may think!

Everyone sees Mr. Holmes and thinks the cruffins...which are good and great, HOWEVER they are mostly hype for me. If you do come for the cruffins, eat them fresh because the crispy outer shell that they've obviously taken the time to master will get soggy from the filling if you leave it all day long. So eat it fresh and right away if at all possible.

My FAVORITES at Mr. Holmes are the croissants and the donuts. Donuts are filled and really depend on what the flavors for the day are. The croissants are matcha, original, and churro...allll are excellent choices. I mean, how can they perfect the "cr" part of "cruffin" without first perfecting the croissant??! right?? it just makes sense.

Come here, skip the cruffin line, and buy a giant box of every other pastry they have..you won't be disappointed! 

P.S. if you're worried about the crazy line, it isn't nearly as crazy as it was 2 years ago! I got here at 8:50am on a friday and was only 12th in the cruffin line! Probably has to do with them opening up additional locations. :)
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I got up early for Mr. Holmes to see what the hype was. It was a Instagram experience with pretty photo-ops and really nice boxes! 

People rave about the cruffin, but I don't have a sweet tooth, so my favorite was the prosciutto croissant. If I was to go back I'd get all prosciutto croissants and one cruffin.
author: Andrea T.

description:
Popular, hip, trendy, neon-lit, petite bakery, w/ a cool branding identity + cheery & down-to-earth vibes. 

- Came here first-time around 730 am, and there was no line! Every type of pastry neatly stacked! Happy to see the variety of selection. 

- Ordered Matcha croissant (half of the croissant dipped in matcha flavored white chocolate, and no custard filling) & Cruffin. The Matcha croissant tastes very average, nothing too impressive. The covered matcha chocolate didn't really taste like authentic green tea, but rather like white chocolate. Was a bit disappointed that there was no matcha filling in the matcha croissant. (.....Been riding the SF Matcha wave)

- The aesthetics of baked goods, store interiors, packaging (hot pink paper bag w/ a white peace sign like the logo) are all trendy! The branding is perfect. Definitely came in for the neon lights & IG-worthy picture.

- The space is petite, more of a grab-n-go breakfast spot (closes @ 3 pm too). People were standing around. The only bench is below the neon lights. Wish they had more seats! 

- Parking was not easy to find, but early in the morning there are some chances a few blocks down!

- Overall a happy & fun experience!
author: Jess W.

description:
Wonderfully fresh and delicious baked goods!
The bakery is teeny tiny and almost always has a line out the door. It goes by fast, but tons of people take pictures with the 'I got baked in San Francisco' sign which makes it even more cramped. 
My boyfriend and I decided to stop in since the line wasn't too long - we tried the Strawberry Shortcake cruffin and the Matcha croissant. 
Both were incredible! Loved the soft flakiness of the pastries. 
You can purchase a nice box for 87 cents as a great birthday gift (or, we got it for free if you purchase 6+ pastries).
We'll definitely be back!
author: Miranda N.

description:
We came in late and they only had 1 doughnut left, cherry jam. Of course I got it because I had made my girlfriend walk almost 20 minutes. 

I really liked the doughnut. Maybe because it was the first doughnut on my list of spots to hit in 2.5 days or maybe because the service was good or maybe,'just maybe it was because the doughnut was good. The dough was super soft, the jam was a little tart for me but the dough sold me. Also really like the cute interior, only downside is the small space (and lack of options but that's my fault).
author: Wennie H.

description:
I've had this placed bookmarked for so long, but never seem to be able to make it here when it's open or early enough to get a cruffin... at some point I doubted whether or not this place was even worth waiting on a line for (as I saw a lot of other reviewing complaining about.)  Thankfully some lovely friends surprised me at home with their pink lemonade cruffin and creme brulee restes!  The cruffin definitely lived up to my expectation, it had a perfect cross section and I was actually surprised to see that the center was filled all the way to the bottom with filling.  I also ate the cruffin at the end of the day at like 6PM and it held up really well through the whole day.

The reason for the four star review instead of five is that I was disappointed with the creme brulee restes.  It was fine, but I have had better and it definitely did not hold up well to the end of the day.  Also I'm not sure if I would ever come back on my own here because of its proximity to Tenderloin...
author: Jacqueline T.

description:
CRUFFINS, I think they're worth the hype. But for me, my true loves are the donuts & croissants. I appreciate the creativity and complexity of flavors at Mr. Holmes - it's a flavor explosion in your mouth with distinct textures of the pastry & filling. 

Cruffins are available daily at 9 am and flavors are posted on their IG. Come a bit before 9 and you'll find yourself standing in life with fellow cruffin lovers. Don't worry, the line moves fast! If you're not into cruffins, then stop by any time after 7 am. Try to come before noon, because they close as soon as everything sells out (usually around 2 pm). 

You need to buy at least 6 pastries to get a fancy schmancy box. 

Lastly, snap a picture with the neon "I GOT BAKED IN SAN FRANCISCO" sign on the wall :) cuz you just did!
author: Dana Z.

description:
A little bit overhyped in my opinion. Mr Holmes sets itself apart with a very instagram-able aesthetic and pretty pastries, but in terms of actual taste I don't think it's that outstanding. There are a lot of other bakeries in San Francisco where you can get better tasting pastries for 50c-$1 less. 

The best time to go (if you're not trying to get cruffins) is before 9AM b/c you can skip the separate cruffin line and go straight into the bakery. It's a super small place, so definitely grab-n-go. 

I tried almost everything on the menu, and the standouts for me are: 

1. Ramos Fizz Donut (or any flavor donut) ($3): The donut is super light and airy, yet chewy which makes it super fun to eat. Ramos Fizz turned out to basically be a lemon/citrus flavor, which was really good! 

2. Coffee Stout Croissant ($5.8): I can't believe I paid almost $6 for a croissant, but I really really liked this flavor combination. You can really taste both the coffee and the stout,  yet the two bitter flavors don't overpower the croissant at all. 

3. Cheesecake Creme Brulee Danish ($4.8): Cool twist on the typical cheese danish! The creme brulee part on top was delicious. 

I was a little disappointed in the matcha croissant. I thought it would be filled with matcha creme or something on the inside, but it was just dipped in matcha white chocolate (which basically tasted like just white chocolate). The puff pastry at Mr. Holmes also isn't as good as it is at some other places and was more dense and less flakey.
author: Melissa H.

description:
Have you ever gone to a business and had no plans or intentions of going there in the first place??? Well this was that place on a perfectly gorgeous San Francisco morning! Seriously.

We walked about half a mile & I told hubby there probably will be a line. And I was right. There was a line of about ten people in front of us. We made it there a few minutes before 8 AM. In fact another couple walked by & asked why were we standing in line. The gentleman in front of me told them that his sister said one must come here for fabulous baked goodies! That couple instantly decided to stand in line too!

Originally I wanted coffee but that idea fell by the wayside bc I wanted to focus on what baked goodies to order. Their cruffins weren't available until nine. So I chose the churro donut, blueberry cheesecake bostock & a pastrami croissant for hubby (I know right? He saved half for me! LOL)! The sales ladies were very pleasant and helpful if you had questions yet not holding up the line! Be aware the shop is very small. Maybe a few seats for a few people & a small window bar area for two.

Actually we sat against that popular wall for five minutes while I had my amazing churro donut. It was filled with oozing liquidy delicious custard filling that placed me in sweet donut heaven. Omgosh! I rarely eat donuts so I seriously got my fix here! Wished I got three of those donuts & skipped the bostock & pastrami croissant. I realized people were waiting outside for us to leave! To take a pic of that Got Baked wall we were sitting in front of. LOL

One nice tip: there was a bathroom & if you're a customer they will give you the passcode easily.

Why are you still reading my review? Go now!!! And continue to instagram those delicious baked goods & GOT BAKED wall!!! Yup I GOT BAKED in SAN FRANCISCO just recently. And I got the pics to prove it! Hehehehe...
author: Karen K.

description:
Double chocolate vegan cookie is really good.

Matcha croissant is too sweet, normal one is just OK. Order other items.

Ariscault has way better croissants..
author: Ellen H.

description:
We stopped in around 10:00 a.m. on a Sunday and the line wasn't too bad (maybe 5 groups ahead of us) and it moved pretty quickly. Unfortunately, we didn't get to try the famous cruffins but settled on a few items, including the mushroom danish, which was AMAZING. The donut of the day (though pretty presentation) was just ok. I came back again the next day to pick up more treats (before flying back to Seattle) and the mushroom danish was just as good! 

It can be overwhelming to get to the front of the line and see so many options but the staff was friendly, patient, and willing to answer questions regarding some of their top recommendations. As many have mentioned, it's a small place and there really isn't anywhere to enjoy your treats after buying them... Next time we're in San Francisco, we'll definitely be back!
author: Torrie N.

description:
1. GO EARLY!!! They are open until everything is sold which can be before 2:30pm (which is their official closing time). So they can run out of the ones you wanted for the day if you go too late.

2. If you get there and the store is empty, take that opportunity to take a photo with the iconic "I got baked" sign. It's a small bakery and people come in waves, so take every chance you can get. Unless you're one of those people who shamelessly occupy small areas to take pictures or you're ok with having strangers in your pictures.

3. I know everyone gets the cruffin, but my second recommendation would be the blueberries cream cheese toast - not too sweet and heavy.
author: Ellen K.

description:
Every time you see someone go to San Francisco, you see them post their pic by the neon sign at this place. This is definitely a hype foodie spot to visit. I read reviews about the lines on weekends so I decided to go Monday morning. There were a few people there when we arrived looking at all the baked goods but no line. If you come on a Monday morning, I think you will be fine not getting there until 10am like we did.

Everyone had their cameras out. Taking pictures with the neon sign, taking pictures of the cruffins and other baked goods. If you come here, get your photo opp and be respectful of others who would like to take a photo as well.

I had never had a cruffin before and it was soooo good. The one I got had a pink lemonade filling which was not too tart and not to sweet. It was literally the perfect flavor. I also got the matcha croissant which we gave to our roommate and then a bunch of other baked goods. A croissant, a cookie, and some other savory pastries. Each item I got and tried was yummy. I do not think you could go wrong with anything you choose from here.

Worth the hype in my opinion.
author: Emily J.

description:
Has been on my radar for a while now. We had some time to kill in the morning before my husband gets his hair cut at the Public Barber shop in the TL. Unfortunately, we got here around 8:30am so no cruffins for us (starts at 9am) but in the grand scheme of things it was fine because we couldn't eat that much anyways. We got the matcha croissant and the creme brûlée danish along with a double chocolate chip cookie. All was very good and not seen at other bakeries. I don't really enjoy regular pastries so I thought it was nice that they added twists to the originals. The shop itself is pretty small with one unisex restroom and not really anywhere to sit to enjoy your pastries. 

We would probably not make a trip specifically to come here but if we were in the area we would stop by.
author: Sarah C.

description:
The hype isn't real. 

We got there at 9.30am on a Saturday and there was a short line of 3 or 4 people. 

Of course we had to get the cruffin which is a muffin shaped croissant pastry with a cream filling. I believe the type of filling changes daily. We also got a matcha croissant. 

There's nowhere to sit but there is a small ledge where you can presumably stand to eat but we ended up getting our order to go. The whole place is very instagrammable with their window displays and neon sign indoors. 

Unfortunately, their pastries were a let down. The croissant pastry was very mediocre and didn't have the buttery flakiness of a high quality patisserie. We liked the matcha chocolate icing on the matcha croissant a little too much even if a little sweet - never a good sign if the best part of the pastry isn't the pastry itself. 

On the drinks front, there were little to no options. We wanted to get coffee but there was just one option and it was clearly an afterthought. Plus they told the customer behind us they ran out of OJ. Kind of crazy for a Saturday morning. 

Everything would be forgiven if they did the pastries well. Unfortunately this didn't happen and we won't be back.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
Personally, I have mixed feelings about Mr Holmes Bakehouse. I remember waking up extra early on a weekend just to buy their famous Cruffins. Failed numerous times despite waking up before 7 am. Those were the good times, now I don't go as often as I used too. 

Based on my past experiences most of their baked good are delicious. But overall, price wise I' am not too sure if they are worth it.
author: Andrew J.

description:
I want to leave an honest review for Mr. Holmes. This is my second time here and I always want to give this place the benefit of the doubt. The baked goods are just ok in terms of flavor and texture. Maybe because it wasn't fresh out of the oven (we came around 10, cruffins are usually out at 9am), nothing we got felt specular or amazing. 

1. butterscotch cruffin- overwhelmingly sweet, too rich and felt really greasy, got sick of it after 2 bites, too dry 
2. Matcha croissant- favorite so far, flakey and buttery but still kind of dry 
3. Double baked coffee stout croissant- REALLY DRY and the coffee flavor wasn't rich just bitter 
4. Cheese cake creme brulee restes- another good one, the cream cheese filling is delicious but too rich
5. Dulce de leche bomb- imagine a dry donut was no flavors and the little bit of filling made it TOLERABLE.  

Overall, it was just an underwhelming experience. The baked goods taste good but the way overhyped. It really wasn't DELICIOUS or buttery, just alright. If you do go, bring friends so you can share the disappointment with everyone else.
author: Fei S.

description:
CRUFFINS ARE NOT AVAILABLE UNTIL 9AM NO MATTER HOW EARLY THEY OPEN. If you see a line and don't want a cruffin, just walk in and get the items you want. 

We arrived a little before 8:30am on a Wednesday morning and there were 2 other parties that arrived a few min before us. By 9am there was probably only a line about 10 deep so really no need to arrive early for cruffins on a weekday. I will say that we did end up walking by around noon and by just a quick glance they were out of cruffins and half of their baked goods. 

We had a matcha croissant while we were waiting in line and I liked the part of the croissant where the matcha was dipped. It tasted more like white chocolate than matcha. I didn't like how the croissant wasn't warm... but rather stale. So I only ate the matcha part of the croissant. 

Onto the cruffin... it was black seasame and matcha flavored. And I liked it. Both the flavors were subtle so that was nice. The outer shell was delicious with the sugar. It was kind of hard to eat the with the fillings oozing everywhere. I am glad that I had the opportunity to try it but I don't know if it's worth the wait.
author: Maggie W.

description:
Went here with the boo and her friend. Her friend discovered this place via Instagram and wanted to take pics near the neon lights sign.

My advice is to go early. We went a bit later in the afternoon and most of the pastries were gone. I was able to snag a chocolate croissant and a refreshing cold brew. The chocolate croissant was super delicious and just the right amount of chocolate inside. The cold brew was strong and did its job.

For sure will be back in the future at an earlier time. If the croissants tasted that good, I'm sure all the other pastries will be yummy too. Also, it doesn't hurt to have a nice background for a picture.
author: Johnny P.

description:
Been here two times over the period of a few years. All I have to say is that it was just as good as I remember the first time. 

Cruffins are the highlight! The crazy hybrid Croissant-Muffin pastry is worth the wait. The line will start early and they don't start selling them until 9 am. Flavors rotate and you're able to check online which flavor will be available the day you go. Limit 2 per person, glad they do this because I could eat way more. That first bite, holy moly your mouth will not regret that you may have waited a long time.

The shop is earlier so before you wait in line for the Cruffins its advised to go in and buy their other delicious pastries that range are around $4 to $5. Stuff your face while you're waiting for those Cruffins!
author: William T.

description:
Croissants are perfect. No need to say more:) Because how can you mess up on croissants anyway? I am obsessed with Matcha so whatever is dipped in Matcha is 100 times better! 

Don't expect this place to be big! It's tiny! There's always a line because everyone and their mamas wanna take a picture in front of the "I got baked in San Francisco" sign:). 

I haven't tried the cronuts because they didn't have them. Staff is too busy to be nice. They get you in and out though.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Being from Los Angeles where there is a Mr. Holmes Bakehouse, i was still intrigued by the SF bakehouse.

So the parking right in front had a sign: mon-fri no parking from morning to the afternoon....where are we supposed to park??

Because i went on a Monday morning the line was not extremely long, there were about 10 people and most of them were already eating their pastries. When it was my turn i ordered 2 pink lemonade cruffins, 1 matcha croissant, and 1 chocolate croissant ($17!!??). Really fast service but the lady who helped me out was not giving off good hospitality, at all!! I really hate going to trendy places and the staff is rude. 

My mom is a huge chocolate croissant lover so we were surprised when she bit into it and well...i attached photos. You be the judge. Overall, i would not wait in the huge line if there was one. Not worth it, just wait and go during the week or don't go at all! :)
author: Monserrat S.

description:
Mr. Holmes has been known for its baked goods, especially the cruffin. I have had friends' line up and bring them to me before, which I found rather okay only. I happened to be nearby with a friend on a Sunday morning and decided to hop in and check what was in. At 11am, there was only one person ahead of me with a bunch of baked goodies still in stock --how lucky!

I opted for the Matcha Croissant ($4.75) and Proscuitto Croissant ($4.75). Damn, their croissants are bombdiggity here! I loved the half-dripped matcha, which had a strong green tea flavor. It was a nice cross of savory and sweet. My absolute favorite is the prosciutto croissant though. I totally fell in love with this one with the savory flavors of the prosciutto indulged inside the flaky and fluffy croissant. I honestly wish I got another one of these!
author: Cindy Z.

description:
Really happy I finally got to try Mr. Holmes after hearing about all the hype!

I came on a weekday morning (when I was still in college... sigh, when you have all the free time) so they still had cruffins in stock. I bought:
- matcha-dipped croissant
- apple cinnamon monkey bread
- vanilla custard donut
- grapefruit donut
- banana caramel cruffin x2

Tbh I got a little greedy and wanted their iconic box, so I bought a total of 6 items and my total was.... $24. Yes. This place can get pricey, especially if your stomach speaks more to you than your brain. "When your stomach says yes but your brain/wallet say no"

I wish they didn't sell out of baked goods so quickly during the day :( Now that I'm working and living in the south bay, it's so much harder to make the trek up to San Francisco (AND in the Tenderloin where it's kind of sketch) early in the morning for this (I'm talking about getting there at 8AM just to snag their goods)
author: Valerie T.

description:
Um, hello! Why haven't i been here before?! 

Cruffins are my new weakness! I arrived around 11am on a Tuesday and on contrary to reviews, there was still cruffins. I had the match and blackberry or something like that. It's kinda like a churro with a different type of stuffing. Has your mouth watered yet? Good service too! 

#leslieapproved
author: Leslie B.

description:
A hole-in-the-wall bakery shop that sells super tasty, moist, chewy double chocolate cookies. Price-wise, they're around $3 to $4 each, but they're a good size. Also, they sell the usual pastries and some jelly donuts as well.

This is more of a grab n' go type of bakery. There is no table seating except for a couple of benches. They also serve coffee, cold brew, orange juice, and yuzu lemonade.
author: Anna B.

description:
I happened to wake up early, so my friend suggested we check out this bakery for breakfast. We picked the cruffin, croissant, donut and cheesecake pastry. The pastries are good, but I wouldn't wait more than 30 minutes for them. 

Even though I'm not from the bay area, I've heard about the cruffin before. I think the overall flavor/texture lived up to the hype. Even though it was somewhat difficult to eat, I did enjoy every last bite. 

I also think we were overly ambitious to share 4 pastries among the two of us. It was an overload of sweetness in the morning. The next time I'm in town, I'd probably just order a cruffin and grab a coffee from a nearby coffee shop.
author: Karen R.

description:
I came a bit late at around 12pm ish on a Saturday and there was no line.

Parking stinks here, there's metered parking and one way streets everywhere.

There is no seating here, but a table at the window which you can stand & eat, but probably only 2-3 people can fit there. It's a really small shop to grab + go.

The baked goods were SO GOOD. The cookies were delicious and so big! If I ever see one - i'd definitely pick up like three more. I missed out on most of the sweet goods, but luckily I did get to try the coffee/chocolate croissant and it was delicious.

You also have to get at least 6 items in order to get the box, or pay 50 cents for it. I'm definitely going to come back earlier and try the sweet goooooods T_T.
author: Melanie T.

description:
I'm all about dessert and pastries goodies...so BRING IT!!!

1) Get the Cruffin!!! Limit of 2 per person.
2) Better yet, I like the stuffed donuts better. 
3) Get there early, they sell out of the Cruffin quickly. 

Love their pastries even if it's a little overpriced. I just wish they would have more flavors instead of just one per day. Oh well, I still like this place. I hope you give it a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description:
Hellooooooooo this place was so good. I had seen all the insta pics of it and decided to be basic and give it a try when I was in SF. I got there at around 9 on Saturday morning and there was a line out the door of about 15 people, but it didn't take too long to get to the counter. Most importantly, I made it in time to get a cruffin! Keep in mind that they choose a flavor of the day and that's the only one they have for the cruffins. When I was there, it was the white chocolate pistachio rose. It was amazing! I normally am not a huge fan of muffins because they're too dense, but this was a beautiful birthchild of a flaky croissant and a moist muffin - with perfect consistency and lots of flavor. 
I also tried the Japanese Danish, which is a danish with matcha filling and it was also delish. Flaky texture and the matcha wasn't too overpowering.
Keep in mind that this place is tiny so it's not ideal to eat there, there's just enough time to snap a pic with the sign and eat your cruffin on the go.
My brother came here a month after me and the cruffin flavor of the day was pink lemonade. Although this sounds kind of gross at first, he was pleasantly surprised because it wasn't artificial tasting like pink lemonade normally is, and was just a pleasant lemony filling. 
Sometimes you just gotta bite the bullet and be basic, so get the cruffin and you'll regret nothin'.
author: Rita S.

description: I should have learned by know that places with a lot of hype usually disappoint. Yes they have cute, instagrammable neon signs and a few assortment of pastries, but it wasn't really worth the trek. We got the matcha croissant and chocolate chip cookie which were mediocre and a little dry. It seemed pretty standard to me and just a good spot to take a few photos.
author: Jen L.

description:
Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is the place for all your sweet tooth desires. The beauty about being a tourist is that you can come on an off day. You avoid the chaos of the Saturday weekend warriors. The fighting over the last "Cruffin" can be completely avoided. I came on a Thursday at noon.

When I travel I mark all my must-sees and go by neighborhood. The warning I give you is that in San Fran there are hills. Perhaps having two Irish Coffees and then walking up a giant hill was not the best laid plan. But when I arrived my jaw dropped. There was a case stoked full of pastries. There was even some savory concoctions. I had to go for the classic, "The Cruffin", a cross breed between a croissant and a muffin. And today this treat was filled with a coconut custard! Holy Smokes! Sign me up!

Since we live in a social media world the clerk was nice enough to snap a pic of me my new friend the Cruffin under the social media famous sign "I Got Baked In San Francisco".  My heart was happy with my new bakery memory. 

I ended up getting busy right after. And it wasn't until I was at the California Academy of Sciences when I decided to eat my Cruffin. I didn't realize my friend was working in an outside booth and could see me. It's difficult to describe but I ferociously devoured my Cruffin. I mean I might have scared some passer by's. The corners of my mouth filled with croissant flakes and my dress covered in cinnamon and sugar dust. Incredible! Can't wait to return and taste the rest of the menu.

The only down side is there isn't really too much lounging space or bathrooms. This is a grab and go kinda place.
author: Carolina S.

description: So yummy! Tried the special apple toast thing and elote danish. I'm from Texas so if you're gonna give me elote it better be good... and it was! Unique and delicious. Came on a Friday morning so there was no line but would have been worth the wait. Gotta take a gram at the neon sign too while you're there!
author: Nikki T.

description: Cruffin's were sold out at 1pm but thought that would be the case based on other reviews so no points off for that. Curious why they don't make more? Had the apricot/chamomile filled donut which was very good though didn't taste the chamomile. Also had the sticky bun which was small, the perfect size (vs the overly huge size) and it was delish. Service was A+ friendly today, nice young woman
author: Ottis M.

description:
If you get lost, just follow your nose. I wasn't sure if I was walking the right way towards the bakery, but halfway down the street, the scent of butter and baked goods started filling the air.

I was told that this place gets packed, especially in the morning, so I arrived as soon as they opened. At 730AM, there was no line and a full display of pastries to choose from. Because I was taking some to co-workers, I decided to get a little bit of everything, cause sharing is caring. Plus... I wanted to try as much as possible and this was a perfect excuse to do so with less guilt.

Favorites were churro croissant and the donuts. All were still warm and the cream filled insides weren't over the top sweet didn't put me in a sugar coma so early in the day.

Prices are a little on the higher side, but the items are well worth it in my opinion. Will definitely be coming back to try more!
author: Ryan C.

description:
TL;DR short lines on the weekdays at 11AM?!

I arrived on a Tuesday at 11AM. There was no line. Unheard of.

It was epic, I shared a cruffin and matcha croissant. The cruffin was flaky, buttery, complimented by the perfect cream. Very well worth the hype. The matcha croissant was literally a regular croissant with half of it dipped in matcha chocolate. Wish I got another cruffin instead.

Don't forget your cute "I got baked in San Francisco" picture.
author: Sophia L.

description: Finally got around to trying this place thanks to my jetlag. Get her early because there will always be a line. Order the cruffins and get a few extra to go for family and friends. They do rotate out the flavors so you may not get the same thing twice. I tried the passion fruit cruffin which was amazing!! The skin was flaky and crispy which paired perfectly with the passion fruit filling. Just the right amount of sweet and tart. Each cruffin is $4.90 which adds up quickly if you buy several pastries. If you want a box for your pastries you'll have to buy at least six pastries! Be sure to take the obligatory photo with the neon light. If you haven't come here before, the morning wait is worth it!
author: Kristy L.

description:
'I got baked in San Francisco ' .... @mrholmesbakehouse unique #patisserie in #SanFrancisco with most of the Goodies gone by noon. So to catch the best of them have to go there early.. #cruffins #matchacroissant #chocolatecroissant #lavendardonuts #rasberrydonuts.

They #cruffins are available only after 9.00 am and the are gone within no time they close by 2.0 pm
#sanfranciscoeats #sanfranciscotram #sfbay #sf_insta #california #alwayssf #thesanfrancisco #sf_insta #iphoneps #iphone7plus #shotoniphone #shotoniphone7plus #bayareaeats #bayareafoodie #bayarepatisserie #bayareadonuts
author: Vinod A.

description:
Great pastries ! I follow the recommendation from fans. The line was not toot long when I arrived at 9 am 10 people in front of me, it went quick .
I was expecting  to order a Kouign Amann , but not this Friday.
They have seasonal items and it all depends on the day .
I got a chocolate orange cream cruffing ( it was delicious , the chocolate orange cream not cloying in sugar just perfect, a plum tart, the Pastrami croissant . You need to buy a minimum of 6 to get their beautiful box.
Next time I will ask when they have the Kouign Amann. I will aim for  Wednesday when they have the Guava cruffing or a Sunday for the paradise cruffing
author: Lydia H.

description: Not sure what to say, clearly this place is already well received.  We made sure tot he this out based on my sisters recommendation.  We grabbed some pastries before we left.  We were surprised with each one about how good they could be.  We started with the lemon poppy cruffin.  Are they awesome? Yes.  Should all muffins come in that form as someone else here mentioned, unsure but it was great.  Next was the creme brûlée danish, just the right level of sweetness, not overdone at all.  Then came the churro croissant, we don't know what was in there but we were not unhappy, it was delicious followed with more delicious.
author: Yaser R.

description:
Not entirely sure what all the fuss is about with Mr. Holmes. I like the baked goods, but they weren't necessarily better than those I've had at 85% of the bakeries I've been to in my life. 

We came super early to stand in line for the Cruffin of the day (which, btw was different than what they had quotes online #notcool). We were first in line, and when we finally got our hands on the goods, I'll admit they were pretty.... but I wasn't really impressed. The cruffins are hard to eat, have wayyyy too much cream, and honestly weren't that tasty. My friends insist that another cream would make all the difference, but in my opinion you gotta make sure that if you're only offering one flavor a day, it better hit it out of the park EVERY DAY. Ours, for reference, was a toasted hazelnut cream (or something thereabouts). 

We did try a handful of other items. I was really only impressed by their doughnuts, which had a nice doughy texture and a tart raspberry filling. 

I'd say this spot is worth a try if you're in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way or wake up early for it. 

Stay Cheerful ;)
author: Garen A.

description: Yummy!! Unique pastries and baked goods.. Saturday morning around 10am line is not too long. Seems long but only waited about 5 minutes. Nice aesthetic (a lot of people taking pictures). Pretty much no seating area. I got the matcha croissant (croissant with half of it dipped in a matcha cream/frosting). Tasty, nothing too crazy. Maple Malt cruffin- more unique pastry. maple flavoring very light, filled with a maple cream that was delicious. Consistency is a croissant in muffin form. Good balance of flavors, a little too flaky I think for my taste though. Definitely fun to try and get a cute photo.
author: Amanda C.

description: Where do I even start?! We tried every pastry that they had and all of them were heavenly! It's a horrible problem to have when you can't pick just one favorite pastry. It was my first time trying a cruffin and I loved it! I definitely recommend trying more than one item - share with your friends because it's worth it.
author: Danielle D.

description: I would have liked it more except for the aggressive Instagrammers pushing you out of the way so they can take their posed photos often with their cameramen friends who take up the entire shop. It's not something I'd go out of the way for but if you're in the area and need some sweet carb fix, sure. Just don't get in the way of the insta star wannabe
author: John L.

description:
"I got baked in San Francisco" sign is probably how I first even heard of this place.

Arrived at 2pm and all the infamous pastries were gone. Since I was traveled all the way there I got the double chocolate chip gluten free cookie ($5) and it was not very impressive to be quite honest with you. My boyfriend got the ice coffee and when I took a sip the flavor was very subdued and watered down. 
The actual store space is pretty small so don't expect an area where you can sit down to chat; it is more of a grab and go spot.
author: Victoria X.

description: This place is worth the wait! Come for the pink neon sign, stay for the pastries. There are so many beautiful, delicious baked goods to eat - I think their danishes and donuts are particularly good! I know they are known for the cruffin (croissant - muffin hybrid), but I have tried it a few times and wasn't moved. I love the seasonal flavors!! Definitely come check it out, but plan to wait.
author: Alice L.

description:
Went twice, first time at 2pm and they were closed with a sign that said sold out. 

Second time went at 9am on a Wednesday and got there at the perfect time, no line when we got there but a huge one formed minutes after we walked in.

We got two cruffins, a passion fruit donut, this brioche cheesecake thing and a matcha croissant.

The croissant was the star! It tasted like having a matcha frapp with your pastry. It was light, not too sweet and super flavorful! 

The cheesecake was so crazy super good, more of a dessert than breakfast but awesome.

I wasn't a fan of the donut, the filling was great but it was dense and a bit heavy. 

The cruffin was good but I wasn't into the flavor, we got like a mocha coffee type which just isn't really my thing but I'm sure another flavor would have been great.

This place is defenitly insta worthy and the boxes for the pastry's could be saved and used as souvineers.

Will def be back next time I'm in SF.
author: Amanda W.

description: I was afraid for long lines but it was very quick to hop in and get a pastry. It was delicious! I got the matcha croissant and it was great. Will come back and try other ones
author: Esther C.

description: If you ever go to San Francisco, you must try Mr. Holmes! They have a great assortment of baked goods ranging from doughnuts to their famous cruffin. A cruffin is a hybrid between a muffin and croissant that is filled with different flavoured fillings. They have different flavours on different days of the week. Be sure to go early for the cruffin because it is their best seller and will most likely be out of it sooner rather than later. I've been lucky they both times I've been here where there wasn't a line out the door to get these delicious goods. Service was great and the nice nice lady behind the counter explained to me what the different pastries contained in each one. If you want the box, you must order at least 6 items. I would definitely hit up Mr Holmes again in the future when I visit San Francisco.
author: Eddie T.

description: a great find in San Francisco, the cronuts and donuts are so good just the right amount of sweetness not overwhelming but perfect! The dough and fillings are a great ratio and because my husband isn't overly crazy about sweets he really enjoyed the uniqueness of the donuts. The flavors are not what you'd fine at any old donut shop but better they've taken the traditional and made It unique!
author: Michelle S.

description: Sooo good! Loved their white chocolate pastry on a Tuesday! The line is long on an early morning, but it moved really quick. We were probably in line for 10 minutes and got our pastries.
author: Sheryll R.

description: REALLY good everything. Why the one star? Here at 9:23am.... they already ran out of a third of the menu. No more hazelnut pear, no more just try it pastrami. And a few others. And the flavors today did not match what was on the menu online. Fix that. You can't run out of pastries at 9:23am. You're supposed to stay open until 2:30pm?! Come on.
author: Ninah D.

description: We ended up getting here around 12:30 so they were out of the cruffins obviously. My friend and I ended up buying their peach jam croissant and their nectarine donut and a chocolate chip cookie. I don't know why people don't mention their chocolate chip cookie at all. It was a stellar cookie. The peach croissant was ok but I didn't quite get peach flavor out of it and their nectarine donut was light and not greasy at all. We ordered two donuts but one didn't come with any filling at all.... it is a small space and people are constantly trying to get a picture with the wall which really causes some problems getting in and out since you have to stand back quite a ways to get the whole wall in. It was worth trying but I'm not sure I would wait in line for anything. And get the chocolate chip cookie!!
author: Lea B.

description: My boyfriend love their bakery, but the store trigger my allergy reaction even I was just passing by. I can't breath inside or near the store.
author: Hana H.

description:
This place is cute and the pastries are tasty, but I do feel like I was over hyped for this place. I would say that my favorite thing about this place was the cute pink sign. hahaha.... okay and the pastries were decent. 
I got the matcha cruffin and peppermint donut. I liked the matcha on the cruffin. It had a strong matcha flavor and was perfectly sweet. The cruffin was flakey and good. However, I felt like I would have liked it a lot more if there was a cream filling inside of the cruffin. It felt like it was missing something. I actually liked the peppermint donut a lot better. I liked the cream filling inside of the donut. It was creamy and had a subtle peppermint flavor. 
We went early in the morning after Christmas and there was no wait. We literally walked in there and ordered what we wanted. I would recommend this place, but don't have a high expectation.

CHECK OUT MY BLOG POST FOR MORE INFORMATION!! 
http://www.twirlplanejane.com/2018/01/mr-holmes-bakehouse.html
author: Jane P.

description: Their chocolate chunk cookie is to die for. Crunchy yet chewy, you'll never eat a better cookie than this. Trust.
author: Mable J.

description: The people here are angels! I left my purse here and they waited me for picking up after they close. Matcha croissant is my all time fav
author: Qiaqia W.

description:
"I got baked in San Francisco" sign and the cruffin is what this bakery is famous for and the hype revolves upon.

Hazelnut Toffee Cruffin wasn't that tasty at all and was very oily. That was the flavor for the day. Looks better than it tastes. Disappointing to eat for my very first cruffin. Perhaps other flavors are better with everybody raving and all the exclusive hype for their cruffins.

Donuts were too oily too. 

I would prefer the fillings to taste sweeter.

There are two lines. Therefore, if you're searching to obtain the cruffin, be sure to wait in the cruffin line. There is a cruffin purchase limit of 2 only per person. Be sure to arrive by early morning between 7am - 8am. They will start selling cruffins at 9am.  Workers will allow the line moving in at 9am and there was a lady that sold cruffins out in the open while taking payments. She boxes them too.  Afterwards, you may go to the side where they sold other bakery items behind the glass.

On weekends, they open at 8am. So, if you want their other offered bakery items, go into the store directly or wait in their other line. 

When waiting in the cruffin line, you are given a sticker. It is a white piece sign inside a pink circle. The workers outside directed people to where to stand in line. And when they reached their cruffin limit of the day, they informed people who still tried to teeter and wait at the end of the line.

This bakery had no yummy items for what I tasted that day. Doubt I'd return for even another flavor cruffin nor any of their bakery goodies.
author: Andrea S.

description: Best pastries in the city. Cruffins are the best! Savory danish, best cream filled donuts.
author: Keith H.

description: Love everything here, particularly the creative savory items. Came at 11am on a Wednesday morning and there was no line but at least 8 ppl taking selfies.
author: Elaine S.

description:
Features:
-Lucky for me, this place is close by where I reside.  I came here last week on a weekend around 10am and got a box of six pastries-- blood orange cruffin, churro croissant, matcha croissant, espresso donut, kouign amann, and the corn bread pudding with meat.  I can understand why people come here early and wait in that long line--the pastries are delicious.  My favorites were the blood orange cruffin, expresson donut and the kouign amann.  The corn bread tasted a little plain just like the churro croissant and the matcha croissant tasted like a croissant with a sprinkle of sweet green tea glaze.  
-They sell intelligentsia coffee for $2.50 a cup which was pretty cool, too.  
-Just prepare to eat a ton of sugar for breakfast if you decide to come here in the morning to grab pastries.  Everything is sprinkled or made with lots of butter and sugar.  

Improvement:
-The only thing that I did not like was that if you get a box, they ask you to have at least 6 pastries.  There were only two of us so finishing 6 pastries took 2 days.  

Tips:
-Come early!  They can sell out quick!
-Credit cards and cashed accepted.
-Line moves pretty quick.
author: Kristy L.

description:
After hearing all the hype about this famous little bakery in San Francisco I just knew I had to be a part of the hype! My best friend and I waited in line for about 15 minutes and were eager to try the baked goods inside. Inside there was a large selection of tasty treats ranging from plain croissants to matcha croissant's and other delectable baked goods. 

the staff was really friendly and patient with us when they explained everything we asked about and we didn't feel rushed at all. 

Unfortunately the cruffin that they're known for disappointed. But the Dulce de leche croissant was really tasty! Overall the bakery did not live up to the hype though.. I recommend following the bakery with the jane coffee shop down the street
author: Dani F.

description:
JYI - They don't sell cruffin till later in the morning, 8am I think? If you go at 7am, you may buy their other pastries. 

I really want to like Mr. Holmes because we are just a few blocks away, but the taste really felt short. The social media hype really brought this bakery to fame. Yes, the bake goods aren't the best. We ordered two boxes on our first visit; almost everything on the table. We tried the cruffins, the sweet and savory crossiants, and the cheesecake square. 

The pastries aren't the best in texture, it's not flaky like what I expect it to be. I really like the cheesecake square and the only thing I like. 

All in all, I feel like this place is overpriced for what it is, and here's the breakdown for stars.

Pastries: 3 - stars - CHEESECAKE Square for the win! 
Price: 2- stars
Service: 4 stars
author: Maria H.

description:
Their phone message is so helpful!  I'm glad I called before I visited because they were going to be closed on the day I planned to go.  The deal is they have cruffins in the morning at store opening and sell out by 10 am.  They said to anticipate a wait, so I got here ten minutes before they opened to get the cruffin.  There was a small line, but I was able to get one cruffin per person and other baked goodies.  Their matcha stuff is good!

I wasn't blown away by the cruffin because it was so messy to eat.  I admit it was tasty and crispy yet fluffy.  The lady working there was so friendly, which was a great start for my morning.  They don't have seating inside except a small bench against the wall.  Napkins and other condiments are to the left of the register.  I got to take a photo with the "I got baked" sign.  This place is a small establishment and parking is terrible.  I advise walking here.
author: Clara C.

description:
Not the greatest of neighborhoods. However, the incredibly delicious, mouthwatering, and tantalizing delights that come from here are otherworldly. 

My ultimate favorite is the cornflake cookie. This goodie of scrumptiousness is a semi-soft, crunchy, toffee of mouthgasm. It's better than a boyfriend. You can't go wrong with this one.
author: Sana N.

description: This place is kinda over rated. I got the cruffin and it was the peanut butter & jelly one. The mango donut thing (has gin inside) and the elote pastry. The cruffin and elote are flaky like croissants but I thought they were kinda dry and not as buttery soft. The mango donut was a bit better. Def more soft. Saw a few flies hanging around the pastries so I don't know how clean this place is.
author: Chloe K.

description:
"I liked the rain. It made it harder, the harder the better. I didn't see accidents but there are a lot of broken cars out there." 

- John Holmes (legendary porn-star, 1970's)

I honestly have no clue which Mr. Holmes this refers to, but I've been craving something sweet. I've been to many bakeries in San Francisco, but oddly Mr. Holmes wasn't on my did-that, done-that list. So being a renaissance man with a libido that matches I needed some, stat! Mr. Holmes is located on Larkin St. & Post St., it's about a block from the infamous Polk St., so really easy to find. 

"To feel most beautifully alive means to be reading something beautiful, ready always to apprehend in the flow of language the sudden flash of poetry."

- Johnny Holmes (sorta-famous poet, 1940's)

I arrive to a very charming, in a white-picket fence urban sorta way bakery. It's super small therefore I'd suggest ordering to-go, unless you're good with the squatters way of life. I immediately notice the baked scones, muffins, croissants behind the glass and large menu on tiled wall. All the regulars know about the Mr. Holmes C-ruffins, which is basically a cross between a croissant & muffin. However, when I arrived no cruffins were in sight, therefore I ordered a blood orange cherry blossom croissant (name?) and a pear danish (I think? I consumed it so quickly that I failed at figuring what I was eating). I would have ordered more if I was ordering more than just for myself, but on this morning I just needed something amazing for my coffee. 

"I could not help the fact that I was a murderer, no more than the poet can help the inspiration to sing." 
 
- H. H. Holmes (infamous murderer, 1880's)

My verdict? Hmm, well let's knock-out the gal eating behind the counter and the instagram worthy neon sign being out-of-order. Hey, it's all about the pastries and baked goodies here, and Mr. Holmes hit a head-spinning breakdance on my tongue! I can't imagine giving this place anything lower than a wow... now imagine if I had a cruffin?! Lastly, I still have no clue who Mr. Holmes this bakery is named after, and sorry I won't Wikipedia, or ask Mrs. Holmes. Just know I'll be back next time to hopefully snag a cruffin and a kiss from Katie... 

"We all keep dreaming, and luckily, dreams come true."

- Katie Holmes (famous American actress, present)
author: Eric R.

description:
As always, find a bakery in the morning within walking distance of my hotel and bring back some delicious goodness.  Mr. Holmes was a few blocks away and it was a nice early morning walk, however, my sadness on the first visit was because I did not know the cruffin didn't come out until 9.  I didn't even look at the details on their website, just saw the cruffin of the day, grapefruit ginger, and left...LOL!

I ended up taking the Matcha croissant and a chocolate croissant.  Both flaky and soooooo delicious!  The staff is very friendly and told me to come early because a line starts for the cruffins....and they weren't kidding.  I arrived at 8:45 and there was already 15 people ahead of me, and as I waited, at least 15 more behind me.  They only allow two per customer, so if you want more, bring people with you.

Saturday's flavor was chocolate caramel.  I can see why it takes longer for these delicious baked goods!  Crispy at the crown, flaky inside with a wonderful mousse filling.....soooo good and worth the wait.  I will definitely be back the next time I'm up.
author: Mikey H.

description:
Average prices
Long line ups
Good selection of baked items 
Come in the morning for the most fresh items

The most delicious croissant I've ever had in SF! I got the matcha croissant and it was so flaky and had a coating of creamy matcha that didn't overpower the baked item at all.

If you're into Instagram, they also have an instagrammable set up. "I got baked in San Francisco"

I think I'll need to come back for a more well rounded review but so far, so good.
author: Lesley Y.

description:
Over the years, I've been hearing so much hype about Mr Holmes Bakehouse. One morning, I decided to finally wake myself up at 7 AM just to drive all the way to SF to see if it actually does live up to its reputation. Going in, the most talked about item was the "cruffin", so I for sure had to try that out.

Final Verdict: WORTH IT!! Each bite of the cruffin was like pastry heaven. I can't remember the last time I had one that was this creamy. The texture was near flawless too. If I can somehow magically wake myself up early again, I'll for sure be back to try more!

IG: @ravenousfork
author: Tam T.

description: Been here a few times, mostly for their famous cruffins. We waited over an hour before but now it seems like the hype has died down. We came here this past Sunday at 8:45am and the line was fairly short. Once 9am hit, the line started to move fast and were out of there by 9:10am. They used to only limit 2 cruffins per person and handed out stickers prior to 9am to guarantee you'll get one. They don't do that anymore.
