In fact on this trip, we only just got 1 cruffin and other pastries. They open at 8am to buy other pastries but if you want a cruffin they only start selling them at 9am. If you'd like to know what flavors of cruffins or donuts they'll have on a particular day, check out their website. If you want a box, you'll have to buy a minimum of 6 pastries, otherwise they'll serve their pastries in a paper bag. Our last order consisted of, a tropical curd cruffin, a pistachio chocolate donut, a maple malt cream donut, a rest in peach croissant, a plum danish and a blackberry cheesecake bostock. I now prefer their croissants over their cruffins. Their cruffins and donuts are coated with sugar so remember to get napkins or it will be all over your face. They also give a good ratio of filling to pastry.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
Cute little grab and go bakery in Nob Hill with great branding. 

They provide unique pastries that have trendy ingredients (matcha, for example) and are home to the famous 'cruffin.'

I went to try the cruffin on a Saturday afternoon. They did still have them around 2 pm but I did have to wait in a line outside. No seating inside beyond a bench on their Instagram wall. The clerks were helpful but the other customers were honestly just annoying. I had a hard time paying because everyone was taking pictures and waiting in line to take one. It was like no one was even enjoying the pastry, just the photo they got from purchasing in a cruffin. Honestly a weird experience that perhaps I wasn't looking for. 

The two items I purchased were good. Lack of parking or seating paired with odd customers and inside experience didn't exactly make me want to visit again.
author: Abigail M.

description: As a flight attendant, one of the first things I do when going into a city with a long layover is search for local dessert spots. After a few google searches and some Instagram scrolling, I was able to find this little gem in San Francisco. Mr. Holmes Bakehouse was a cute little bakery with unique pastries and an IG worthy wall with a hilarious lighted sign. I got the matcha croissant and donut with coffee flavored filling. Both were incredibly delicious, but if I could change one thing, I'd add a matcha type filling for the croissant. The staff was very nice and was helpful with the customers' questions about what they should try first. The space is small, but it's understandable because you come in, get your pastry, take a pic by the wall, and go on about your day. I can't wait to go back and try the other flavors!
author: Johnny B.

description:
Be here early if you want to try the Cruffin! What is a cruffin? I had no clue until we visited here, it's basically a croissant baked in the muffin tin and stuffed with daily flavors. Wished they offer two flavors a day but I guess that is the hype so you would visit daily to see the flavor of the daily.  Or maybe they just make them during the weekend? Not sure.. Any how we got there around 9am and the line was already long, after about 10min wait a lady came out to give a stickers that guarantees you 2 cruffins. 

What I didn't get was that if you didn't want a cruffin you didn't have to wait, you can just walk in and purchase there other pastries which they have a variety and unique flavors. The cruffin flavor for the day was blood orange which we ordered, as well as the matcha dipped croissant, donut in a cup with chocolate mouse and I think it was chai, and a lemon pear verbena pastry. Just Note: If you want your cruffin in a pastry box you have to order 6 or other pastries to fill the box. Since the cruffin has to be standing up they insisted that if you want the box we had to order additional items. Good thing my friend and I were able to share a box. They should have smaller box options, you can have it in a paper bag but we're site seeing so it was better to have it in a box.

Overall, the flavors was good, the blood orange filling in the cruffin kind of reminded me of orange yogurt, the donuts was the bomb fresh yummy goodness, the matcha croissant is basically a flaky croissant dipped in matcha so as expected, the lemon pear really good. A must when you want pastries!

Also they have a cute lighted sign you can take pictures!
author: Julie Ann I.

description: Got there around 12pm on Saturday and they were closed because they were sold out! Was super bummed but went there again on Monday around 11am and they had a lot of stuff! I didn't get to try the famous cruffins since they were sold out but they had a lot of other assorted baked goods. My favorite was the Nutella filled donuts. Omg I wish I got more of those. Definitely a must try bakery if you're in San Fran!
author: Becky S.

description:
I've probably been here more times than I should.  I just can't help myself.  From the infamous crufin, to their buttery croissants, to savory danishes, and cookies too. Oh and donuts that rotate as well.  Everything here is satisfying and will keep you coming back for more....well at least that's what it does for me. 

So far my favorite things have been their almond stuffed cruffin (the cruffins change quarterly, so do the donuts.) I'm glad I live here because it's nice to stop in during the week.  Even during the week the line can get long.  At 9am is when they start serving cruffins and it's first come first serve.  Once they run out, they run out.  They don't make any more for the day,  so get there around 8:40am if you plan on getting a cruffin.  I can't even imagine what it's like on the weekends.  The have the infamous "I got backed in San Francisco sign." Great photo op after you purchase your goods.  Back to the baked goodness, I love the ham and cheese croissant ($5) , the strawberry jalapeño bear claw -runs about $4.5, and their savory bread pudding ($4).  Definitely worth a try if you are visiting.  Staff are friendly and the line goes by quickly.  Not really any seating inside, except a few stools by the window, so be prepared to stand in the street while you eat your delicious goodies.
author: Adrianna P.

description: I've had a Cronut.  I had to try a Cruffin, especially when I saw they had Guava Cheesecake.  Guava cheese is one of my favorite food combinations.  No way I was passing that up.  I came straight from the airport.  There was a short line.  The people in front of me didn't know what they wanted so let me go ahead.  I got the Guava Cheesecake Cruffin and a Rest In Peach Croissant.  I was disappointed that the small seating area was taken up by a group who had bought several boxes of items, but were just sitting on their phones not eating or taking pictures of any of them.  They were there before I got there and still there when I left.  I didn't see any benches or anywhere I could eat nearby.  I ended up eating on a newspaper rack around the corner.  The Cruffin was my favorite.  The filling is what made it amazing.  The croissant was good but I didn't get any peach flavor which was strange considering the name.
author: Heather N.

description:
Be prepared for a long wait!! Come early to get a sticker, which guarantees you 2 cruffins (only 2 per person, so bring a party if you want more!) These can sell out pretty fast, so I highly recommend coming early in the morning if you want to get your hands on these delicious treats. Also, you can look ahead of time on their website to see if the cruffin flavor is something you'd want. 

In addition to the two cruffins I got, I bought the california croissant, cornflake cookie, two donuts, and a chocolate croissant. To get the box, you must buy 6 items. Everything was pretty worth it, especially the cruffins and cornflake cookie (such an interesting texture and flavor combination!). 

There isn't much seating, so my friend and I brought our pastries to a nearby coffee shop and munched on our pastries while sipping on coffee. 10/10 way to spend your Saturday morning! 

I'm just sad that most of the items are seasonal, so if you try to come back in a year, it's likely some of the menu items are gone (sad reacts).
author: Bradford L.

description:
This bakery came highly recommended by a friend as it was about a two block walk from my apartment.  After reviewing it on Yelp, I was convinced to make it and try a cruffin.  Thank goodness I got two things to try:

Grapefruit Ginger Cruffin
PROS:
- super crispy and yet fluffy croissant dough
- not overly sweet crust
- not overly oily
- good sized portion for the price
CONS:
- way too sweet: I'm not sure if the filling was too sweet or there was just too much filling compared to pastry but I ended up chucking a portion of the dough with a large amount of filling because I felt like I was getting diabetes.

Bacon-Bleu Cheese Pastry
PROS: 
- super light and not oily pastry
- not overly heavy
- not overly flavorful: nice balance between the cheese and bacon and I believe there were onion bits in there
- great savory bite, not overly filling but not too light
CONS:
- none.  This actually was the one saving grace because the cruffin was a big disappointment.

I might have just gotten a bad flavored cruffin.  Perhaps the other flavors are better.  I do plan on going back and trying their other baked goods, especially their croissants.  Hopefully that will change my review and I can update it later.
author: Vera L.

description:
READ ME: If you want a cruffin, they come out at 9AM daily (not when the bakery opens at 7AM). I would start to wait in line at 8:30AM.

My wife likes to tell me I'm all about the hype! Well, Mr Holmes Bakehouse, in my honest opinion, is the epitome of hype! I mean, come on, cruffin? It's 100% playing off the cronut from Dominique Ansel Bakery. Some bakery needs to start making some cragels or cretzels. I get it, it looks good on Instagram/Snapchat. I saw some Asian girl taking pictures with her Mr Holmes Bakehouse box in front of the neon sign while some fat guy with a backpack and SLR was doing a straight 10-minute photoshoot.

To make things worse, the employees there act like they're the hottest bakery and seem pompous because of this. I like hype, but only when the hype leads to something not "too gimmicky" and more importantly delicious, without the snobby girls serving you.

As a consolation, the other baked good are pretty good but no need to wait in line more than 10 minutes for a hype-fail cruffin.
author: Marlon T.

description: Delicious and menu is always changing. Definitely recommend their croissant. Cruffin was pretty good but not something I'd rave about, it's hyped up. Their donuts are kind of dry and the filling is SO sweet, my teeth literally hurt. Lines lines lines.
author: Sharon C.

description:
A Mr Holmes Bakehouse review, in haiku form:

Elusive cruffin.
Why must I always miss you?
Next time...set alarm.
author: Carl M.

description:
You know, I did seen some incredible pictures thru Instagram and Yelp for a while, and it's here at this well populated fan favorite bakery in San Francisco! It's called, "Mr Holmes Bakehouse." Mr Holmes can be a fictional "Sherlock," but he was quite an impressive baker right in my imaginary dream! In real life, Mr Holmes Bakehouse serves the customers of all ages to taste their incredible and devouring baked goods every 365 days a year! The atmosphere is very active and on-going as I welcomed there. The concept is very modern, contemporary and chic inside filled with basic decors along with an interior neon sign across the whole small compact room!

The employees especially the bakers are doing an excellent job for making the customers like me an outstanding service! No cons!

Now onto the treats! When I arrived in San Francisco (coming from Sacramento) at 8:30 am PST on 2/24/2018 and parked at the nearby surface metered street parking, I got in line early before extra people were coming by. Why the line? Oh yes because they were eagerly awaited for the most signature item of all, the cruffins! Cruffin is a muffin in a croissant twist with a touch of seasonal flavors & sprinkled sugars combined right out in the oven. Boy, it was so fresh and clean after it popped out from the oven since 9 am, so I grabbed and ordered two Cruffins (today's arrival: the Custard filling with a white chocolate bark on top) and a Matcha Croissant. As I ate it, these eatable tasted flawless and unbelievably sweet tooth tasty! The cruffins did baked perfectly and eatable to chew which I did feel the sugary taste along with the custard filling too. The Matcha Croissant on the other hand also tasted great! Perfectly baked and flaky especially the half dipped matcha filling too. What a magnificent pastries grub just in time for breakfast!

Parking at Mr Holmes Bakehouse is very challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface metered street parking nor the parking garage if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

All in all, Mr Holmes Bakehouse is the most incredible and amazing bakery that I've ever discovered and visited for the first time! Yes it will get packed before it opens, so get there early for the anticipation hype of all! Perfect for all ages from young to old! A well received! My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description:
I came here for the Cruffin (croissant + muffin) that they are known for. It was better than I expected- it had some cream (not too sweet) inside which added extra moisture. We also got a Cheesecake creme brûlée which was also fantastic. 
The line was not too long for a Saturday. We arrived around 9am and waited for about 15 mins. I would highly recommend this place to anyone who likes donuts/pastries!!
author: Amy L.

description:
Mr. Holmes is another place that ive never had an urge to go because of the long lines and wait.  Since my friend was visiting me, we decided to make a trip out after hiking and wait in line. 

They completely ran out of cruffins by the time we went, but still had plenty of other deliciousness left. I went a little overboard and purchased a pretty large box of pastries. I got the matcha croissant,  regular croissant, cinnamon churro croissant, savory pastry, cornflake cookie, buttersctoch donut, and mocha donut. 

My family demolished the entire box of pastries, so i only had the chance to try the cornflake cookie, matcha croissant, and cinnamon churro croissant.   The cinnamon churro has a nice custard filling. The cornflake cookie is my absolute favorite, its so crispy, chewy, and sweet. I will definitely be coming back for those.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Yes, I was one of the tourists that were in town so I got up early just to be in line to get 2 cruffins.  I was very skeptical because if you're going to name something a CRUFFIN (muffin + croissant = cruffin), you're setting yourself up for VERY high expectations that probably cannot be met, or at least for a fatty like myself.  

If I had to rate this place specifically based on the cruffin alone, I would give it all 5 stars.  Cruffins lived up to and actually exceeded my expectations.  I got 2 and brought them back to my girlfriend.  She was like "OMG WHAT DID YOU BUY 2?!?!?"  A few minutes later, she was like "OMG WHY DID YOU ONLY BUY 2?!?!!?"  

However, their cookies were just average.  Their croissant was also just average.  Their coffee wasn't anything memorable.  But all of this stuff doesn't really matter.  Next time I'm in town, I'll be in line for the cruffins again!
author: Jang N.

description:
In a perfect world, where Mr. Holmes deserves a five-star review, every pastry would be consistent, the donuts would be filled well, the croissants would be equal parts soft and flaky. I love this place, I love the selection, I love the creativity. I would really love if we lived in a perfect world and these things were all true every time I made the trek here.

I've had some of my favorite pastry experiences here (blueberry lemon curd cruffin, kouign amman, chocolate chip cookie). I've also been crazy disappointed by some of the pastries I've purchased here. Just last week, I came two days in a row. On day 1, the kouign amman was excellent, 6/5 stars and one of the best kouign ammans I have ever had. The following day, it was dry, under-baked, and bland - a completely different pastry. On day 1, the donut was dry and under-filled. The following day, it was packed with delicious filling.

This isn't isolated to this location. I've had similar experiences at both of their LA locations. The consistency issues won't stop me from visiting Mr. Holmes because when it's good, it's goooooood. Just be aware - you may not always get their best. If at first you don't succeed...
author: Marissa G.

description:
By jove Sherlock, Holmes has really created that demand!

Who doesn't love a bake shop with lots of hype (hah), extremely photoworthy pastries (yasss, talk about eating with your eyes), rotating flavors (hehe), and hipster flare (har har)??

We moseyed in about 7:30am on a weekday, and d'oh, I didn't scan Yelp in detail enough to gather that cruffins become available only after 9am. The girl informed me too that they often sell out within the hour. The flavor that day was chocolate rye.

Left with a matcha green tea croissant and raspberry kouign amann.  Each was $4.  My first taste of a kouign amann!  It was dense on the outside and flaky on the inside, with a burst of that raspberry jam hidden in there, but there was a lot more granular sugar to the taste than I was expecting.  The croissant was buttery and flaky as a croissant should be, and the coating of green tea was tasty.  That creation was one of the best things I consumed on this vacation. 

Worth a stop in to see what all the fuss is about!  Hope you don't get stuck in line too long!
author: Tricia D.

description: Success! Got to Mr. Holmes at 8ish-9 on a Monday and bagged some goodies! Try their Cruffin at 9 am sharp.
author: Gordon Z.

description: Wow. The cruffins, which are basically croissants cooked in a muffin form, are crispy and soft on the inside yet full of flavor and unique from a regular croissant. The one I had was a chocolate creme with orange flavor and I was glad to have waited in line to get one because it was definitely worth a try on my visit to San Francisco. If you live here or are just visiting make a stop here and get any of their items because all the things I tried were amazing and high quality.
author: Taylor N.

description:
Went at around 9 am and there were still cruffins left! Not too bad of a line around this time (Monday morning). Longest was about 6-8 people. The line goes out the door because the shop is pretty small. 

The cruffins are a more dense version of a croissant shaped into a muffin. Got the pink lemonade cruffin today. Was hoping to have the other flavors. Pink lemonade might be good to some people but I thought it was a weird flavor. Didn't like it very much; but it does have a strong tangy lemon flavor. If you like lemon you might like the pink lemonade cruffin. 

I really like the matcha croissant and the chocolate croissant! Get those for sure! The chocolate croissant has some kind of custard like filling inside. Really good. 

The chocolate brioche bomb has a somewhat bitter mocha filling. Didn't enjoy that one as much; very sticky as well.
author: Mayee L.

description:
4 stars because they were out of cruffins by 12pm (my fault for being late, I know!)

Ended up getting a box of danishes and regular donuts though! 
The poached pear danish & Thai tea donut (pictured) are to-die-for!!!

Be ready to wait in line (separate line and cashier for cruffins) 

Parking: street + nearby garages 
Customer service: 4.5 stars
author: Tushar S.

description:
Personally, I found the cruffins worth waiting for. They were quite delicious without being too sweet, and had the right balance between the chewiness of a muffin and the crispiness of a croissant. The cream filling was a nice added touch. Other items I tried, whether the crème-filled donuts or the kouign amann, were also quite satisfying and quite reasonably sized given the price. 

Is it all as refined and world-class as, say, what B Patisserie has to offer? Perhaps not, but it's all certainly good stuff. I might not wait in line for cruffins every day, but it was certainly worth doing at least once.
author: Vincent L.

description:
This place is a tiny cute and trendy pastry shop. I have three warnings for you:
1. Store is super hot
2. It is really crowded. 
3. They are NOT cheap; be prepared to spend $4 - 6 per pastry

This place is perfect for cute photos and they do have good croissants and cruffins! 
Go early in the morning for cruffins!! Their flavors change frequently,  so don't get upset if you cannot find the flavor you liked from 6 months ago. 

 Menu Recommendation :
1. Matcha Croissants 
2. Seasonal Cruffins 
3. Seasonal donuts
author: Juliana R.

description:
Oh yeah! I could come here every morning and not get sick of it! What a perfect little bakery. My husband and I found Mr. Holmes Bakehouse on Instagram while planning our trip to San Francisco out. We were so excited to try it out. 

We ordered a tart donut, coffee and another sweet pastry (which I can't remember but took a photo of).  All items were superb! My item was quickly engulfed and I got several flakes on me in the midst of it! 

Mr Holmes Bakehouse is a great little place to swing by and pick up a quick breakfast treat!
author: Margaret H.

description:
Why is it I always miss the day there are no cronuts?? Ughh
Anyhoot I cannot complain when I see many other goodies lined up in the display case! 
My eyes dazzled and couldn't decide which baked good did I want??
Secretly my mind told me:
"Get all" lol hmmm I'll take a chocolate chip cookie; matcha crossiant; and uhh powered sugar donuts filled with wha? Calamansi? And plum something haha i can't remember but I'll take that.
Words can't describe the goodies that went down to my tummy, but I hit the gym right after lol

Thanks again Mr. Holmes
author: Kathy V.

description:
I joined the line about 15 minutes before Cruffin Time on a Friday morning.   (Cruffins are not available when the shop first opens).   The smells coming out of the shop are amazing.   The line moved quickly.  I purchased a number of items.  Everything of course is very fresh.  There were some interesting flavor combinations.    My favorite item was the Orange Blossom Cherry Croissant - excellent!  I also enjoyed the Raspberry Hibiscus Kouign Amman.  As for the Cruffin?  I didn't think it had enough filling.

I wish I lived closer so I could visit more often!
author: Diane W.

description:
Mr. Holmes is amazing!!! Went early enough in the am and avoided any lines. 

The matcha croissant is my favorite by far- the croissant is so flaky and perfectly baked with the nice touch of sweet matcha coating. 

I also tried a few stuff cruffins and cannot remember what flavors they were but I don't think anything here could be bad!! 

Tip: if you're visiting, buy more than you think you can eat cause you will be wanting more
author: Marissa R.

description:
I finally got baked at the infamous Mr. Holmes! A couple of friends and I drove into The Bay earlier that morning and arrived here around 8:45am. The line was already out the door. Was I surprised? Absolutely not! Most people were waiting for the cruffins, which begin selling at 9am - we came just in time!
We waited about 20 minutes or so before being able to order, and we definitely didn't hold back! I got a Cruffin (the flavor that day was chocolate buckwheat) ($4.50), Cheesecake Creme Brûlée Restes ($4.50), Banana Almond Chai Danish ($4.50), as well as a Dulce de Leche and Strawberry Rhubarb bread filled with some custard ($4.50/each).
The cruffin is worth the try! It's soft, flaky, sweet, and FILLED with cream! They really don't hold back on the cream filling here. The Restes and Danish were both delicious! They have to be my favorite products on the regular menu. They're both filled with cream and the depth of flavor is truly unforgettable!
The breads were not great. There was barely any cream filling. The majority of the flavor is from the glaze on top. For $4.50, it's not worth it. I wouldn't get those again personally. Mr. Holmes has so many better options!
I'm super glad we got there early enough to try everything we wanted! Now that I've tried them, I'll know what to narrow it down to for next time. I definitely recommend coming early and buy some for later - trust me, you will want more!
author: Aya E.

description:
After my kind of mediocre experience at Supermoon I was a little hesitant to bother with this, but I was up early enough to get a cruffin and figured I might as well try it. I ended up getting a cruffin, a peach-ginger donut, and the almond-banana-chai thing. The donut was my favorite out of all of them. 

The almond flavor of the other pastry was lost behind the heavy banana flavor. It was still delicious, but I looove almond and was hoping the flavor profile would be slanted in the other direction. 

I looked at the website for the cruffin flavors and saw that it was blackberry port today which sounded amazing. I'm a big fan of fruit flavors and not so big on cream or chocolate. When I got there the flavor of the day was cannoli :( I was pretty disappointed but got one anyway. While I was in line I checked their Instagram and I guess they keep that more up to date with flavors than their website. 

I was delightfully surprised when I bit in and it had bits of candied orange peel. They also managed to make the filling actually like a cannoli, light and not too sweet, instead of doing a cannoli flavored pastry cream.
author: Kristyn K.

description:
Their sign "I got baked in San Francisco"  is one of the "must check in" point in San Francisco. 

5 stars for food.
4 stars for the service. (They didn't tell me the soy sauce came with the California croissant)
But I will back to try another items!!!

To get the pretty box, you should buy at least 6 items. I got the matcha croissant, strawberry donut, California croissant, peach croissant and cucumber croissant.

Their  croissants are amazing. To me, I love the matcha croissant the most. Because It tasted not too much sweet, so excited to try this new flavor combo, and it worked quite well. MUST TRY!!!

I also found a small bag of soy sauce in my box. I feel so confused to have it, because it was my first time to visit. HOWEVER, they didn't tell me what does the soy sauce for.  Finally, I  found the answer from Instagram. It came with the California croissant, which was tasted like sushi!!! There were salmon, seaweed, wasabi in it!!!  Soooooooo good!!
author: Anny L.

description: Favorite patties in town. If you're looking to splurge for a Friday morning treat on the way to work, this place is perfect. The selection of pastries are typically the same each day except for the donuts. There is a good amount of sweet and savory. Keep in mind there is basically no seating area, so only take baked items to go. Great place for a quick treat though!
author: Christina L.

description:
Definitely a spot worthy of picture for the gram! 

A friend brought us here and honestly wanted to leave with everything! We ordered the matcha croissant and a cruffin. Let me just say - no regrets! Very delicious pastries.
author: Mellanie P.

description: A short line on a Saturday morning (~10/15 minutes at 9:15am) and well worth it! The bakery is insta worthy and so are their treats. I had a pb&j cruffin and it was amazing! Worth the steepish price tag
author: Melissa B.

description:
Two years later, I finally made it....

Bought 4 different types of croissants, max out on their cruffins, and tried a donut. There were still a bunch of items I have yet to try but that will need to wait on another run.

I had a matcha dipped croissant, a elderberry raspberry croissant, churro croissant, and a california croissant. My favorite was the California croissant just because I'm a savory person. I don't know how I feel about the ginger but it was definitely an interesting concept and part of a complete breakfast. The most disappointing croissant was the matcha one. I didn't quite taste the tea flavor, all I can taste was like a white chocolate type of sweetness. Warning, I don't usually have a sweet tooth, so my tolerance was sweets is low. Unfortunately I ordered too much, so my churro and my elderberry croissants had to sit out and wait, they became soggy :( 

Ok, onward about their cruffins. The flavor I had was passion fruit. Thing was massive and delicious, it had too much filling for me though. Its definitely not something you can eat with complete table manners. The filling would either spill all over your hands or your bite would not have part of the pastry and part of the filling. Just hide and eat it. Onlookers may attempt to steal......
author: Connie C.

description: Every item I got was delicious! If you're craving a fresh homemade treat, sweet or savory, this is your spot. I got there at 9am and there was a small line out the door but once the cruffins arrived it moved pretty fast. I would absolutely go back.
author: Gen T.

description:
I had to see for myself what had the town buzzin' over Mr. Holmes Bakehouse. 

I've been in town a few days and I assumed San Francisco would be a bakery town. Bakeries on every corner baking up sourdough San Francisco treats. Sadly, this is not the case. I used Yelp to make an educated decision on what's baking.

Walking into the store, it's very small. There's a few crazy items for sale and one of them leapt out with black sesame seeds, the California Croissant. 

There are so many yummy baked goods to choose from! I asked, what is a California Croissant? The young man explains inside is seaweed, salmon, ginger and a touch of wasabi. Mmm, sounds funky! (My wife makes a face) 

I'm down for funk, let's go! 

It's exactly how it was described, you take a bite into the flaky croissant. You also bite the seaweed and salmon. It's a nice breakfast on the go.

We finish and see people lining up?? Mr Holmes has a version of the Cronut,  shaped into a muffin. I wish I had more time.

Peace out homies!
author: Bill S.

description: Had the matcha green tea croissant and it exceeded my expectations! The matcha coating was sweet and balanced and the croissant itself was buttery flakey and had an air and delicious taste! The staff are incredibly friendly and gladly will offer you a complimentary water cup with your pastry! Would 10/10 recommend
author: Yurixia A.

description:
Came here while in San Francisco. This place was sad in size compared to the one in LA. To top it off the only thing they serve was coffee and pastries. No barista. Parking is horrible unless you find a spot on the street or parking structure. The wait is close to 45minutes to an hour because all these people are waiting to be basic and take a picture in front of a sign. 

Will not return here but continue visiting the one in LA.
author: Gabriela H.

description:
A small hole in the wall bakery serving up some of the best stuff in SF. Its so small I walked by it twice before I noticed the window, I imagine during prime hours it's hard to miss with the lines. This place is simple and straight to the point, a small display of baked goods, a station to fix your coffee, and of course the wall/sign to take pictures to make everyone you know jealous. 
I came here right as they opened hoping to score one of those coveted cruffins only to find out they come out at 9am, so be warned to time your visit. Also the nice staff was kind enough to let me know they usually sell out pretty quickly. Alas I didn't have enough time to wait so I got a few other things and will have to plan another visit. 
Ended up getting the chocolate coffee stout croissant and the brioche bun. I wanted the elusive cruffins but what I got was plenty delicious. The chocolate croissant was flaky and rich a perfect pairing with my morning coffee. The brioche bun started off meh until I hit the filling which I didn't know it had and boy did it make it amazing, the filling was a creamy fruity explosion of flavor. If their non signature items were that good, I'll definitely go back to try the cruffins.
author: Peter P.

description:
There's a long line here! People line up before they open for their cruffins! For you newcomers, there's 2 different lines, one for everything else and one for anything with cruffins. If you're here for something other than cruffins, then you can bypass the long line! 

It's packed with tourists, that's for sure. They've got the deliciously instagrammable "I got baked in San Francisco" wall! So by default, everyone will pick and choose what they want, pay for it and snap a photo or two! 

I visited Mr. Holmes with 5 other girlfriends. We got cruffins and practically one of every thing they had, lol, yeah we're fatties, don't judge us! The Califronia Roll is probably one favorite other than their cruffins. The cruffins are good, a little sweet, which goes great with black coffee! 

It's definitely worth the wait and lives up to the buzz!
author: Karen L.

description:
Home of the half-croissant and half-muffin hybrid, cruffins! The flavors change quarterly, but you can usually find their flavor updates through Instagram or Facebook. It was perfectly flaky and creamy. The flavor we got to try that day was matcha and prickly pear, which somehow worked well together.

I had the chance to try the earl grey donuts and it was soo good! I've had an obsession with earl grey for so many years now, so if I see it on the menu, I just have to try it! The chocolate brownie and pistachio ones were the other flavors we tried. They also have homemade ube pop tarts!

I recently had it again in Seoul and it was just as delicious as the one in SF. You can also find locations in SoCal!
author: Sherry V.

description:
I've been going here since they opened and have ha don problems until today.  Usually the donuts are pretty balanced out with donut and filling.  Today the donut had maybe 20% filling max.  I checked my friend's and ditto.  I'm hoping this is an exception and not how it's going to be going forward.

Still love the cookies.  Damn best chocolate chip cookies in the city.
author: Jeff W.

description: We were in town for a split second and decided to stop by for the famous cruffin. I was disappointed to hear they already sold out for the day. However, I still wanted to taste their other baked goods and grabbed their pom donut along with some other items. Wow! Hands down the best donut I've tasted and paired so well with a latte. Please open a location in DC!
author: Elly K.

description:
Their "I got baked in San Francisco" sign is easily one of the most Instagrammable spots in San Francisco. You have to be very careful where you stand or else you'll be in the way of someone trying to capture the perfect croissant eating Instagram. 

This place smells AMAZING. Their croissant isn't extremely out of this world - crunchy shell, and really dense and fluffy on the inside. Wasn't overly buttery, but it was good! The sushi one was really spectacular though. You'd think it's a bit weird, but it was delicious! Salmon, dried seaweed and a hit of wasabi. Highly recommend!
author: Ke C.

description: We were very excited to try their pastries but it was hugely disappointing. We had their blackberry donut and it was very average, lacking flavor. It was so overpriced as well. Perhaps other items on their menu might be better to try but won't be coming back anytime soon.
author: Su P.

description: I got a matcha croissant, spinach artichoke danish and a pastrami surprise here. All very good! I would highly, highly recommend the matcha croissant. Get it with a coffee or some tea. I was skeptical of the hype and thought this place would be just average, but I really liked it and would go again.
author: Lanny N.

description:
Those so-called insta-friendly hidden gems in SanFran have been catching lots of attentions from me recently, and among them, Holmes bakehouse was the one that I decided to give a try no matter what. It reminded me getting the cronut from Dominique Ansel in New York, which required some waiting time, if not a lot.

Daily flavors would be released on their Instagram account ahead of time, so one will know which flavor to line up for beforehand. Today I was lucky enough to have tried the prickly pear lime, which was refreshing and lightly sweet. 

Don't forget to give yourself a shot in front of that famous "I got baked in SanFran"; and of course, don't forget to come by earlier before the cruffins are gone for the day.

Limited to two pieces per person, so plan your appetite ahead!
author: Elaine H.

description: My brother and I indulged ourselves by ordering the delicious Creme Brulee which has caramel, cream cheese, and some other goodness.  However, the caramel did aggressively stick to my teeth, but I wouldn't necessarily call that a complaint.  We also ordered the Elote which is more on the savory side and pretty delicious as well.  This place is small inside but you don't need a lot of space or have any reason to stick around when you're enjoying their treats.  Easy to eat on a morning walk.
author: Jamie J.

description:
During my visit to San Francisco, I had to stop by Mr Holmes Bakehouse. It's like "did you even go to San Francisco if you haven't gone to Mr Holmes Bakehouse?" 

They open till they run out so make sure you get there early! I made a mistake of coming during the later times so the next day I made sure I was there an hour or so in when it opened.

The place is relatively small, it can probably fit about 10 people in max. 

They have a counter on the right side with all the goodies displayed in front of you and a name card describing each pastry. We decided to get the matcha croissant and the banana chai pastry. 

I wish I could've gotten a lot more but unfortunately, we wouldn't have enough time to finish it. Also the fact that these pastries were super filling!

The matcha croissant tasted like any croissant dipped in matcha so I wasn't impressed. The banana chai pastry however, was delicious! It was super flaky and had enough cream in it where it wasn't overpowering.

I was also able to snap some pics for the gram!
author: Belle L.

description:
Ughhh!!! Finally I am here but only one flavor of cruffin is available. I was hoping that I can get other flavors but looks like I should be really lucky to get any. I went there on Sunday 8:45. There's a line for sure but wasn't too bad at the time. I also got some other pastries, must also try the donut that filled up with fruity flavors! (peach or raspberry)
Before I visited, I thought the store has seats but the store actually quite small but filled up with lovely pastries!! If you ever come to San Francisco, better get up early and just at least have a cruffin here!!
author: Abbie S.

description: This is obviously one of the hottest bakeries in San Francisco, and rightfully so.  The cruffins are very good, and made just right.  No wonder there is always a line outside its door, at 9:30 AM Sunday morning, and hours later as well.
author: William L.

description:
I had heard the hype about the Cruffin.  
And when a friend from Southern California came to visit for the weekend, I thought I'd brave the warnings of long lines, & reaching the counter only to find they'd run out of the famous Cruffin. 
Anything to make my guests feel welcome. 
I arrived around 10 am. The line was much shorter than I'd expected & everyone in line seemed excited to reach the gold at the end of the rainbow. 
Right before I was about to order, the last 2 Cruffins were sold to someone 2 people ahead. 
I quickly scanned what else I can bring home, so I didn't come back empty handed. 
But much to my surprise, another tray of Cruffins came out.  And in addition to the planned Cruffins, I also purchased my "backup items". 
The workers are friendly, the packaging is nice, the food is delicious (albeit somewhat expensive). 
Would I make the trek here without a special occasion?  Probably not.  Who knows?  I might have a Cruffin-craving!
All in all, the experience was very good!
author: Reed S.

description: Maybe you came in for the instapic but you'd be a fool if you leave without the donuts. The pastries are great, fluffy, crispy and chewy but the donuts are the killer here. Melt in your mouth creamy with amazing fillings- and how cute is it that they stand up?!
author: Zara S.

description:
Came to this place with no expectations. I figured it was some overhyped bakery, just a good place for a photo op. But it turned out to be so good. I didn't want to wake up early on the weekend just to line up for cronuts, so we just went later at around 12:30. Most of their items were gone, but they still had donuts, normal croissants, cookies, blueberry danishes, and savory danishes. 

The donut today was a lemon butterscotch and it was really good. Dusted with sugar on the outside and filled with a lemon butterscotch cream. We also got a blueberry danish to go. I will definitely come back in the future to try their other baked goods!
author: Kelly C.

description: Delicious! We consumed a Rest in Peach Croissant, Tropical Curd Cruffin and a Chocolate Chip Cookie!   Being a sweets enthusiast, I can assure you it is well worth the (10minute) wait. The graphic design is eye popping and perfect for all of your Instagram needs. Only stop and go as there are no seats. The (tiny) Coffee is not worth $3, so skip that and walk down to the next coffee space for that.
author: Brittany L.

description:
YUM. So this is where all those "I got baked in San Francisco" instagram posts and snap stories are from! I totally thought this place was overrated, but I ended up being very impressed and very happy with all my delicious baked goods.

I came here on a Sunday morning around 10am, and we were able to get some blood orange cruffins. They were pretty good, but to be honest, my absolute favorite item which I wish I had gotten more of were the savory sausage creole pastry with gravy. It was delicious and a little bit spicy as well. The hazelnut donut and chocolate croissant were VERY delicious, and we also got a lemon pound cake which was good too.

We didn't have that long of a wait, probably 15 minutes, but I can see how this place sells out quickly.
author: Tiffany J.

description:
Love that there are so many great bakeries in the city.  It's my candy store.  I want one of everything!  I like Mr Holmes because of their creative and interesting flavor combinations and it's always changing. 

Cruffins and donuts are the thing to get here since they're always changing up the flavors.  Follow them or check their IG for flavor updates. Other pastries are not bad at all like their croissants but I'm a classic butter croissant kind of girl and there's still no place like Arsicault bakery for that.  But if you like your croissants with a little flair Mr Holmes definitely has some for you.  

If you really must have the flavor of the day cruffin come early because when they're gone they're gone.  We came an hour after they opened on Saturday and we scored.  Although they started passing stickers out to people in line which entitles you to two cruffins per person which I think is fair. Lines go fairly quickly, unfortunately a requirement at most popular places in the city.  

Before you leave don't forget to take the most IGed photo inside.  If you have to drive, parking is metered and not in the best neighborhood.  Watch out for human feces on the sidewalk. Sad.
author: Naty D.

description:
Insta-worthy & hecka aesthetic place with hecka aesthetic pastries. You come in and they have their pastries lined up and organized and just wow! Makes you want to buy all of them. I ended up choosing the Cherry Blossom Croissant because I love food with a floral fragrant. I loved mine!! The croissant was chewy and soft with a crunch on the outside. Then I hit the filling in the inside and it was an explosion of floral notes and it was just amazing. 

The staff was super friendly and you can kind of see the rest of the people working their magic in the back on these pastries. Hours are kinda limited so stop in as soon as you can!
author: Jenni T.

description:
Mr. Holmes!!
Found out about this place on social media, came to check out the hype.. lived up to it.
We could smell the pastries from a block away!
Ordered the chocolate chip cookie and the mixed berry donut.. both were delicious! 
Service was great.
author: John D.

description:
Food: 4/5     Price: 3.5/5     Service: 4/5    Ambience: 5/5

*** Food Network - Holy Moly Burgers! / PB&J Cruffin *** 

Came here for the cruffins but sadly they ran out!!! The lady told me that you got to stay in line before they open at 8:30 to get them, which are normally available 9-10am. On weekdays you can come around 9 with a reasonable line. 

The wall of "I got baked in San Francisco" was a must - the perfect classy pic for your Instagram! *And the sole purpose of today's visit, minus the cruffins...
 
I ended up getting a Matcha Croissant - surprising flavor combo that worked well! The croissant was fluffy with wholes and beautiful layers, topped with Matcha Pate A Glacer (white chocolate coating). 

Reading all the crazy reviews and talking to the people in line, I think I will be back soon to wait 1hr+ for that infamous cruffin!!

Favorites:
* Matcha Croissant ($4)
author: Victoria L.

description: Stood in line for 45 minutes to try this famous "cruffin".  It's really just a cream filled croissant which is baked in a muffin pan.  The flavor of the day was pink lemonade, which (to me) tasted exactly like lemon meringue pie filling (only pink in color).  To be honest, we were quite underwhelmed by the whole (and expensive) cruffin experience.  I also tried the pastrami croissant, which was disappointing.  Really chewy, fatty pastrami and a surprise spicy kick (which I didn't mind) in a standard (and forgettable) croissant.  The star dish for me was the bourbon papaya donut. If you must, go try and check off your bucket list, but I will continue to go to B Patisserie as my go-to bakery in SF.
author: Brian K.

description:
As you might have read from many other reviews, this is the bakery famous for the Cruffin.  Currently, they do a different flavor cruffin and doughnut everyday for an entire month.  Check out their ig before you go to see if there are any flavors worth it for you.  They come out at 9am even though the bakery opens up earlier.  They will give you a ticket that ensures you will get a cruffin and it was only 2 per customer. I have been here on numerous occasions and tried an assortment of things and this bakery is just not at the top of my list (and I have been to a ton of bakeries!).  There were a couple of cruffin flavors that did I enjoy (believe it was a strawberry cream one) but overall it is just hype and looks good on the gram.  I will say they do a good job on the custard because I do like their doughnuts and I did like a white chocolate blueberry brioche bomb they use to do.  

Croissants were nothing special, was not the flaky (Vive la Tarte has way better ones!).   The idea of a churro croissant filled with dulce de leche custard sounded amazing but the execution of it was disappointing.  FYI the matcha croissant everyone posts about, not filled.  I am all about the filling.  I tried the apple monkey bread and it did not have as much flavor as a I wanted it to be.  I liked the chewy texture but it needed more caramel and more apple to it.  

Overall definitely not worth the wait but I will have to admit that picture of your Mr Holmes box in front of the neo sign, is pretty cool.
author: Lauren S.

description: Some things you really want to say are overrated but this place isn't one of them. Went bright and early and was able to get six different items. Left to right, top row then bottom: Banana almond chai danish, both are donuts and one is a early grey and honey cream but not sure which? Bottom row twice baked coffee stout croissant, pineapple upside down cake cruffin and matcha croissant. All were delicious, croissants were flakey, crispy, lots of layers and flavorful. The cruffin was layers of flake, sugar, yummy fruit filling and the right amount of chewy. The donuts have creamy fillings and tasty icings and glazes. The danish while it was my least favorite out of the six items was still amazing with a crunchy banana chip and great filling.
author: Heather L.

description: There isn't as much options as you'd think, about 10 or so to choose from. Very unique donuts and croissants, but over all very good! There isn't seating inside except for a wall shelve to stand up and eat on, but there was a cute wall that's all white with "I got baked in San Francisco" lit up in pink. Line was out the door but didn't take too long. Definitely worth a visit!
author: Alicia D.

description:
Our hotel was just down the st from this delicious place! 

Ordered: root beer, strawberry, o ache, matcha, churro 

Pros: this trendy and popular place is in the radar for a reason! Their pastries melt in your mouth, they are so good and light! Even though there was a line it was fast service. The decor is cute and light!

Cons: it is not a place to sit and enjoy, it's very tiny.
author: Ceci F.

description:
Got in line at around 0855 on a Wednesday for the cruffins and there were only about 6 people. They are very prompt and begin selling cruffin 0900 on the dot! You'll see some people trickling in but no real wait time for the cruffins.

Cruffin - love the texture, really crispy and flaky. It's coated in sugar but with the cream, the sweetness isn't overwhelming. Not good for keeping long as it'll soften so try to eat as soon as you can!
Limit of 2 cruffins per customer. 
Worth it if there's no line.
Mexican chocolate cruffin - orange zest with lightly spiced chocolate cream. Not too "chocolately" at all!

Got a whole bunch of pastries like the matcha croissant, Gorgonzola shiitake, banana chai, and prickly pear doughnut. 
Absolutely loved everything except the prickly pear - too tart for me and didn't taste the pear.
Gorgonzola shiitake - savory and the cheese wasn't overwhelming.
Banana chai - banana didn't overwhelm the whole pastry. Not exactly a chai flavor but very delicious nevertheless.
author: Shirley L.

description:
---- SWEET ----

Toffee Brown Butter Cookie: 5 stars
Cornflakes, perfect texture, deliciousness.

Creme Filled Doughnut: 5 stars
I tried both the Maple Pecan and Vanilla flavours. Usually I get filled up easily with dense doughnuts, but this felt so light and fluffy I could've eaten several of them and not been slowed down at all! Heavenly.

CCC: 4.5 stars
Chewy, soft yet almost caramelized-crispy dough. One of my favourite cookies in the city!

Banana Chai Danish: 3.5 stars

Churro Bomb:  3.5 stars
Nice cream filling (which tasted like chai tea for some reason), and had a layer of cookie topping on the bun, like Hong Kong bo luo bao.

Bread Pudding: 3 stars
Good, with pulpy berries in it, but not the best thing here. I like my bread puddings wetter and more pudding-y.

Papaya Brioche Bomb: 2 stars
I need to remember that the brioche bombs are NOT the stuffed doughnuts.  The bread is dry, maybe needs to be re-toasted.

Strawberry Jalapeño Brioche Bomb: 2 stars
Mostly bread and pretty dry. Will not buy again.


---- SAVOURY ----

California Croissant: 2.5 stars
Smoked salmon had too salty soy sauce flavour. Croissant was decent but hard crispy texture, Tartine's plain croissant is way better. I gotta try Holmes' plain croissant though.
author: Letitia L.

description:
Wow! Absolutely delicious. We tried the Cruffin (filled with Chai Cream), the Donut (filled with Pumpkin Cream) and the Chocolate Croissant. All were amazing!!

This place is wildly popular with the Instagram crowd, so be prepared to wait in line for food and photo ops! The gals working behind the counter were so nice...very patient with all the tourists.
author: M M.

description: Got here at 8AM and there was no line..  but also no cruffins until 9AM! We made sure to come back and got there a little before 9 and there was surely a line for their famous cruffins. We waited about 25 mins and got the matcha croissant, banana (something), churro brioche, brownie croissant, chocolate chip cookie, and chocolate cruffins all sooooo goood! Their all crispy, fresh, and not overly sweet which I love!
author: Donna K.

description:
TLDR: Each person can purchase a maximum of 2 cruffins per person, and these cruffins are available at 9 AM on Sunday's (not sure about other days). We found street parking nearby, and waited about 15 minutes for cruffins when we arrived a little after 9. Initially we were going to buy 5 pastries, but added another so we could get a box for them. None of the flavors were super strong, so if you don't like overly sweet pastries, this is a place to try. The textures of the pastries were healthy-ish, and didn't have as much butter as most other pastries I've had. I was disappointed because I was hoping for some stronger flavors (not necessarily sweeter).

We got 2 cruffins (flavor of the day: carrot cake), 1 matcha croissant, 1 strawberry elderberry croissant, 1 lemon ricotta donut, and 1 chocolate earl grey donut. Here is my review of them:

Cruffins: The texture was like a cross between a croissant and a cinnamon roll. There is carrot cake flavored filling injected inside the cruffin with a slightly smokey cream cheese frosting on top. Maybe it was the carrot cake flavor, but I wasn't super impressed.

Matcha croissant: My bf thinks this is overrated; he was hoping for matcha filling in addition to the half dipped matcha shell. I thought it was well balanced, kind of like a pocky shell over the croissant. I wished the croissant was more buttery though. 

Lemon ricotta donut: I wished the filling had a stronger lemon flavor and the dough had a more fried texture. This tasted more dough-y.

Chocolate earl grey donut: The filling tasted more creamy than chocolate-y, with a bitter taste finish that resembles the tea. To my disappointment, I couldn't really taste either a bold chocolate or tea flavor.

Strawberry elderberry croissant: This was surprisingly enjoyable, despite the unconventional filling style where strawberry filling was injected on one end and creamy elderberry filling on the other end. I would have been just fine with only the strawberry filling though.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Found myself in Nob Hill, and just had to come to Mr Holmes after hearing all the hype. And to take the obligatory 'I got baked in San Francisco' instagram picture. Unfortunately it was just that. All hype. 

My bf and I got here around 10:30am Saturday and waited approximately 30 mins. 

The shop is small and there wasn't a huge variety of desserts. We went with the plum sake cruffin, green tea croissant, cherry croissant, and the spicy mango and chocolate donuts. 

We paid $24 for 6 pastries, and I just didn't feel like it was worth it. The croissants very very flaky but I didn't feel that WOW feeling I was expecting. Wanted to love the cruffin but it was just ok.
author: Wendy L.

description:
I honestly thought it was just okay such a long line you expect so much more but didn't quite feel this way at first bite.

We tried a cherry blossom and matcha croissant and a grapefruit cruffin. This simply didn't wow me.

The place is cute small you're definitely rushed and the long lines tell you what kind of service you will receive.  It's a one and done place for me.
author: Sylvia Q.

description: I've been coming here for some time now, since Day 1 (holla!) and with most places I grow sick of them over time, but there's something different about this bakehouse. Perhaps it's the luscious (generously filled) brioche donuts, flaky & crunchy amelie amanns, the underrated savory California croissants, or the seemingly never ending different flavors of those beautiful cruffins? Any of which are worth the trip. Brownie points for the staff being super friendly and kind too! Also Ry and Chris are super awesome.
author: Christian R.

description:
Cruffin anybody? I think Mr. Holmes has successfully gotten the name out on social media with its sign and IG posts. It's been years in the making that I would make a trip out here and I went here before having to head into work, so I thought I'd grab a few things for my coworkers before heading off. 

BAKED GOODS: Fortunately, the baked good selection changes frequently, so you can try a bunch of different things. They had unique flavors at the time I visited with passion fruit, matcha, and others. Each baked good I bought (cupcakes, cruffin) were definitely pretty tasty (the price does reflect what you get). Overall, on the sweeter side that I am used to, but the bakes were great and my coworkers agreed. 

SERVICE: Great! 

Overall, Mr. Holmes is a place that I would find myself again if I was in the area, but I would be much pickier for the baked goods I'd get. I would also not opt to wait in those crazy lines I've seen before, but luckily, I hoped in on a Friday morning at 9:30 AM, so I didn't find myself behind a bunch of tourists.
author: Albert H.

description:
Don't leave without a cruffin and/ or a cookie.

The line (always a line) moves super fast and if you're lucky a local eccentric will provide entertainment while you're waiting. 

My suggestion is grab something sweet here and head down 2 blocks to Jane for a sit down with coffee and a savory Jane item since Mr.Holmes is strictly grab and go (no seating).
author: Tara C.

description:
I love Mr.Holmes! Being San Francisco it is a very trendy and touristy spot to visit. Although its location has always been an interesting choice it is well worth the trip!

Arrive early! Unless you do not mind waiting in line to pick your delicious pastries. Of course, you cannot miss out on the opportunity to take that Instagram photo in front of its neon lights. 

The store is extremely small with little seating inside and no seats outside! It isn't a place where you can sit down and eat but it is San Francisco so you can always take a stroll down the street and enjoy the city.

I love their Chai! and I highly recommend! Be ready to shell out a little more than you had expected because their goodies are worth the trip! I have also visited the Los Angeles location!

The employees are also very polite and if you are indecisive they take the time to explain the ingredients.
author: Nathalie M.

description:
These treats were as delicious as they were beautiful. Get some. 

Stopped in to pick up one and wound up with a boxful instead. Worth the hassle of packing them around to fly some home to the family!
author: Vanessa A.

description: What a cute little bakery in SF! We came here for breakfast based on a recommendation from a friend and it was somewhat busy, no long line though. It is not a big place with limited seating areas so it gets crowded. We got a chocolate croissant and a lavender-filled donut and they weren't overly sweet and when paired with milk (they offer that there), it was so delicious! I also love their cute like "I Got Baked in San Francisco" neon sign, makes a good social media photo op. Whenever I am in town or come across other locations, I am definitely trying their other stuff!
author: Anita N.

description:
It's the TENDERLOIN people stop making it seem like its the best place to travel. Tip: Please drive, park illegally and hope there is no line to get whatever they have left. Made the mistake to actually park in a parking lot and walk. Had to bare walking through the homeless and druggies with my 1 year old. 

So they have the neon light up sign where is a big appeal for the instagramers. But I would say overall this place is highly overrated. I see instagram postings of the items people get and they don't tell you that they were there like a hour before opening and waited in a giant line. 

When the bf and I went there was a long line and a field trip of people who are unaware of others. I was very underwhelmed with the choices they had. Everything is mainly their basic croissant dough and glazed fruit. I honestly forced myself to get something since we were there. And it seemed like they were almost of of items and it was like noon. 

The place is very small. In addition, to all the instagramers waiting to take pictures near the exit it's a very annoying experience for those who just want to get a pastry. I rather go to the Fillmore Bakeshop
author: Denice D.

description:
TIP: Check their Instagram for CRUFFIN AND DONUT FLAVORS of the day

I have been wanting to come to Mr Holmes Bakehouse for so long and try their famous cruffins,  and finally, I made it. I was able to get here in time to get those cruffins.

So it was my first time here, but I was lucky enough to be able to purchase a cruffin. I went on a Tuesday and around a little over 10 am. Surprisingly there were quite a few cruffins left, so I was relieved. There was no line, but there were still lots of people. 

The cruffin flavor of the day was Mascarpone Peach, which sounded AMAZING. Also for the donuts, they had Peanut Butter Caramel, Lemon, and Vanilla. I got a Cruffin, Vanilla Donut, Matcha Croissant, Churro Croissant, California Croissant, and a Roasted Tomato Croissant. I got exactly 6 in order to take home these pastries in their beautiful box. 

I have got to tell you, the Mascarpone Peach Cruffin was the best thing ever. LOVED the filling and the crispy outer part of the cruffin. The Churro Croissant also has a filling, not sure if it is vanilla or not, but the whole thing definitely tasted similar to a churro, delicious. For savory, I liked the Roasted Tomato Croissant, it was just the perfect savory croissant for me. The Matcha Croissant and California was a so-so for me. I thought the Matcha Croissant would have a matcha filling, but it didn't, so I was kind of disappointed by that. The California Croissant is a hit or miss, my mom loved it, but for me it was a miss. Not much of a wasabi and ginger person.

They are all priced in the $4-4.50 area, the cruffins are $4.50. Pretty pricey, but worth it.

First time trying cruffins and glad I was able to stop by and try Mr Holmes Bakehouse pastries. Definitely want to come back, definitely recommend!!!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Being a pastry freak, I've been wanting to come to Mr. Holmes for some time now. My delay has been due to their use of pastry cream for their signature pastry, the cruffin. I'm not really a pastry cream kind of guy. In any case, I made my way to Mr. Homes last week. There was a line, but it moved rather quickly. I bought a cruffin, a kouign amann, and a cookie.

For me, the cookie and kouign amann weren't that interesting. The cruffin was interesting. I wasn't that enthusiastic about the pastry cream, but the morning bun itself, which is what the cruffin is less the cream, was quite good. That I really enjoyed. In fact  I was thinking they could sell the morning bun on its own without any filling. I think it would go over well. I also need to mention there wasn't the tiniest lump to be had in the pastry cream. It was smooth as silk.

Now, even though I'm not much of a fan of pastry cream, I do like lemon curd and the folks at Mr. Holmes rotate the flavors for the cruffin. So I'll check in with them, and when they have a lemon flavored cream, I'll be back.
author: Anthony W.

description:
Breaking news: The infamous cruffin is WORTH THE HYPE.

I knew I had to take advantage of my schedule as a student (AKA I still have some weekdays off where I can prioritize going to a bakery over doing real adult things) and try out what Mr. Holmes has to offer! 

My friend and I arrived on a Thursday around 10am, where we were pleased to find absolutely NO LINE and a good supply of cruffins! The cruffin of the day (#COTD?) was pear & elderflower and it was sooo good. The filling consistency reminded me of applesauce (in a good way) and the pear really stuck out.....mainly because I have no idea what an elderflower is supposed to taste like.

The other pastries we tried included the creme-filled donuts & the churro croissant, which is ALSO creme-filled, which was a nice surprise. Both were quite good, but we agreed that the cruffin was definitely the star of the show for us.

My one gripe is that I wish the shop was bigger, but I guess you could say that about any place in SF! 4 stars, I would totally come back if I was in the area and craving a fluffy, crispy treat.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I had heard all about the Cruffins and decided to come by on a week day hoping there would be a little less line. I arrived at 8:50am on a Thursday and found street parking very easily. At 8:50 I was about #10 in line. If you're not buying Cruffins, you can just walk into the store and skip the line. Cruffins start selling at 9am sharp! At 9am the line actually moves quite fast and by 9:05 I was out with my Cruffin! (and made it to work before 9:30) I saw they make a few trays, a pretty rough estimation would be 100-200 Cruffins total at least. Cruffins are $4.50 each.

The Cruffins are really fantastic. It really feels like a muffin-shaped croissant, the outside is perfectly crisp without being dry and the inside is moist. It is filled with a pastry cream, which flavor changes every day. It is just right, thick and not too sweet. The Cruffin is really great, surprising and I'd say even exceeds its hype.

Mr Holmes' Bakehouse also has a bunch of other bakeries, I spotted a matcha-dipped croissant, a smoked salmon savory croissant, monkey bread, donuts and much more that I will definitely try next time!

Also, they sell Cruffin lapel pins at the register for $9.
author: Thomas L.

description: I have to say, the bakery tastes really good. It's a small store, and no place for you to have the bakery tho. The place itself is not located in a good neighborhood, and the place is small, only a wall that is for taking photos for your Instagram.
author: Alexis

description:
As other have noted and I found out:

A) This place closes early/sells out often
B) Cruffins don't come out till 9am 

Everything I tried was excellent just like B patisserie.

I wish they would set aside some cruffins for the morning or simply just make more but that would make too much sense right? I guess what I've heard from other yelpers/people who work in the City is that it's hard to snag a Cruffin if you work in the city during the week.  I've taken more than a few undergrad and grad school business/entrepreneurship classes so I familiar with supply/demand and obviously whatever this bakeshop is doing is working for them and I applaud their efforts to limit the cruffins to two per person so people don't hoard them....but...

To quote the O'Jay's which are from before my time (1975 I believe this song was released) 
"Don't you know that, don't you know you
Got to give the people, give it up
Give the people what they want?
Yeah, yeah, yeah, oh, yeah"


They are pricey as well ( just like B patisserie) and yet I think that's ok since after all it is Sf.
Must gets
- Churro Croissant
-Any donut with filling
-Matcha croissant was delish as well


I like lists what can I say? 

When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. 

Here is a look at how I rank the SF Bakeries I've visited and I indicated what they're known for or a dish I recommend:

Rod's SF Bakery rankings (and what they're known for or what I like). ?) Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places. 
1 Neighbor Bakehouse=cinammon almond bostock
2 B Patisserie=Choco Bannana croissant
3 Zanze's Cheesecake=Regular cheesecake
4 Ariscault =Croissant
5 Yasukochis=Coffee Crunch Cake
6 Chili Pies Baking Co=Pies
7 Dynamo Donuts=donuts
8 Golden Gate Bakery=Egg tart
9 Mr Holmes Bakehouse=Green tea croissant ,Cruffin, 
10 La Luna Cupcakes=cupcakes
11 Three Babes Bakeshop=pies
12 Anthony's Cookies=Cookies
13 New Hollywood Bakery=Egg tart
14 Dianda's Italian American Pastry=Napoleon , Cannoli
15 Mission Pies=Banana Cream Pie
16 Schubert=Swedish Princess cake
17 Yummy Bakery=egg tarts
18 Stella Pastry & Café=Cannoli , Tiramisu
19 Craftsman & Wolves=Rebel within
20 Bob's Donut & Pastry Shop=any donut 
21 Noe Valley Bakery=dipped cupcake
22 Café Greco=Cannoli 
23 Kings Bakery=Tres leches cake
24 Benkyodo Co=mochi
25 Cupcake cove=cupcakes
26 Cups and Cakes Bakery=cupcakes
27 Good Mong Kok Bakery=dim sum
28 Karas cupcake=cupcakes
29 Mission Minis=cupcakes
30 Sift Dessert=cupcakes
31 Tartine Bakery=lemon tart
32 Jane The Bakery=matcha twist , cardamom Lattice Bun
33 Café Madeline=various goods
34 Panaderia La Mexicana=mexican sweet bread
35 Hot cookie=Cookies
36 Les Gourmands Bakery=Croissant
37 Mee Mee Bakery=Cow ears
author: Rod M.

description:
A diamond in the rough part of town... Mr.Holmes' has become a foodie's obsession- starting with that cool neon sign and ending in those decadent, mouthwatering Cruffins! 

Check their IG page for a list of upcoming flavors. Sadly, they're made in limited batches per day, so you have to line up before 9am when they're being made. 

Try a matcha croissant in a photogenic shade of green with the perfect amount of flakiness then grab a cute box to protect your goodies- it's only 80¢

Watch your step and avoid the crack heads. 
I mean that in the nicest way possible, cuz they're my neighbors too.
author: Mitzi G.

description: Make sure you get here early for your choice of delicious-ness! This is a fairly small shop, so they don't have a huge variety of pastries, but all the ones I've tried have been really good. Of course the cruffin is the clear favorite, they do a different flavor every day. Employees are really good at keeping the line moving quickly.
author: Sonya G.

description: Everything is so delicious! My favorite though was the passionfruit filled donut. I still need to try the cruffin. I'm one who will wait for a place to open so I don't have to stand in a line - i have an exact time as to when i will have my delicious treat that way. I'm not one stand in line as there as an uncertainty as to how long I have to wait. Otherwise, they would get five stars. I've eaten here many times yet no cruffin as a result.
author: Danielle S.

description:
The pastrami croissant is where it's at!! 
This 4 stars is strictly for the pastrami croissant.

Honestly don't see the big deal about the cruffin, but that's just my opinion

Paid just about $30 for two coffees and six pasties, tbh, probably won't come back....
author: Christa T.

description:
Mehhh.. I was not impressed with Mr. Holmes Bakehouse.

This bakery has been on my to do list for the long time, especially since they are only open 7am-2:30pm, and I work 9-5... leaving pretty much no time ever to visit. And there's no way I would sacrifice my weekend sleep for a line for pastries.

I decided to take a day off of work and explore parts of SF and try all the things that are only open in the day time. One of them was Mr. Holmes Bakehouse and it was honestly disappointing.

I'm glad there was no line so at least I didn't waste any time. I had the following:

1. The cruffin - it was beer and oats flavored. I loved how the cream had a hint of beer flavor but overall this baked good was WAY too sweet. It was also very difficult and messy to eat. I am glad my friend and I snagged the only standing table inside, or else it would've been impossible to eat. Be prepared for grabbing multiple napkins and dripping the cream onto the floor. Oops. I ended up tossing half of it because it was just too sweet and too much. I think it would've been fine with a dallop of cream on top, and omitting the cream inside.

2. Matcha croissant - this was probably my favorite one out of the 3 things I bought. It is slightly too sweet; the matcha reminds me of a matcha Kit Kat. I think it would've been better if the matcha could be powdered form.

3. Churro croissant - reminds me of a sugar donut... it was okay. But what's worse is it is CREAM FILLED!! Whaaat. Why don't they list that?! Terrible surprise. Tossed half of this too.

Overall, all the items were too sweet to eat the whole thing. I also wish they let customers know that the items were cream filled (yuck!!). I definitely wasted too much money because I bought 2 of the cruffins thinking it wasn't cream filled :(

What's worse is that they charge 87 cents for a box. I'm spending over $20 for 4 items and they're so petty to charge 87 cents! You need to purchase a minimum of 6 items for a free box.... and so I decided to pay 87 cents so I didn't have to carry 4 bags of pastries. Unfortunately, the cream filled cruffin exploded in the box too. sad. 

And WORST of all... the neon light that read "I got baked in San Francisco" was broken!! Man!! So much for the 'gram.

I will not come back. Only delightful part of the experience was the Inteligentsia coffee. I am so glad I did not wait in a long line for this experience.
author: Janet H.

description:
While on vacation with my wife in San Fran she mentioned a bakery that was apparently legendary for their donuts and pastries but also for the LINE around the block! From what I can tell Mr. Holmes Bakehouse has acquired a cult like following and it is solely due to their baking prowess, especially Cruffins!

Needless to say, I was overly impressed by the efficiency of the staff and how amazing everything tasted.

The line is definitely worth the wait.
author: Bennett M.

description:
Mr Holmes - my first thought was Sherlock Holmes, but we are not Baker Street, instead we are at Baker house. 
My relative from Canada actually told me about this place.
We visited on a Tue at 11:30 am.  No lines, no crowds, so nice.
The storefront is unpretentious, hardly any signage, just simple black awnings.  
Located in the mist of Little Saigon in Tenderloin neighborhood.  Sure is humble.
I bought 7 items to sample - croissant heaven for me.  (Croissant dough is very labor intensive, a lot of work, I hear many bakeries outsource their doughs). 
   Cruffin with banana fillings
   California Croissant, with salmon, ginger, wasabi, and seaweed
   Matcha Croissant
   Chocolate Croissant
   Apple pie pull-apart
   Peach Cobbler danish
   Donut with almond poppieseed fillings

Everything was wonderful.  Wish I could visit more often.
author: Connie W.

description:
This place has been on my list for years but I've never wanted to wake up early to brave the line. Since I had jet lag and was up, I decided to go. I just happened  there around 8:40am, which worked out since the cruffin is served at 9. Glad I didn't go even earlier. The line is slow but moves starting at 9, before then it was a standstill. 

Food- 4 stars- Despite the annoying instagramers holding things up, this place lives up to it's reputation. The cruffin was delicious, although there was too much filling. The churro croissant was my favorite. It's just a croissant with cinnamon sugar but it's a very, very good croissant with Vinson sugar. I could have skipped the danish. It was so-so with not enough filling.

Price-3 stars- Hella overpriced. $4.50 for s cruffin, $4 for a croissant. And if you want a box, you better be ready to buy at least 4 items. But truthfully none of my pastries even made it past the door.

Atmosphere- 3 stars- hole in the wall with a tiny counter to eat. They definitely branded well.

Fun to try but I'm not a huge one for lines.
author: Alison B.

description:
We got here late in the day about 1/2 hour before closing. No line, but not much of a selection left either. Get there early for best selection. Duh! 

We were able to secure some scrumptious goodies however!! Love love the raspberry croissant danish? Not sure what it was called but it was super good! Pull apart Apple monkey bread was dense and moist. Peanut butter doughnut looked amazing but I didn't try it. Also grabbed a few chocolate chip cookies. That was about all that was left. Good enough for my group though. 

Next time I come here I'll come earlier and will get the cute box - order of 6 or more and you get a box. We were able to find metered street parking nearby which makes this place easier to access. The lighted sign was out of order but would make a cute pic spot.
author: Juls B.

description:
Where do I start with this place!

So my wife and I came here because we were recommended by friends and other yelpers and who doesn't love pasties/donuts!?

We came here on a Saturday around 9am and they seemed to have a lot of different items in stock still. I think there was only about 10 people in line when we got there. I got a cruffin (root beer float was the flavor of the day) and a matcha croissant; these both were honestly so good! My wife ended up also getting a cruffin with a raspberry donut which she said were excellent! 

The place looks as if it's in a rough part of town but looks pretty cool on the inside. The inside is not big and you are  not able to eat inside, which was fine with us as we were on our way to sight seeing. 

They had a ton of different kinds of donuts, croissants, etc. but I got what seemed to be popular on Yelp which helped when making choices! You have to try to Cruffin when you come here though!!!
author: Dennis G.

description: Carbs are my hot hot sex, so for me, there is nothing not to like about Mr. Holmes. I have never been on the weekend, so can't speak to crowds then, but I try to go right before 9 on weekdays because there is almost always a line, but often most people are just waiting for cruffins, and so you can slide right past them if that's not what you're there for. Cruffins are great, but not worth waiting for when I can get churro croissants, which may actually be mankind's greatest invention. Honestly though, everything here is amazing. Just beware the tourists and Instagrammers taking selfies in front of the neon sign.
author: Josh M.

description:
I literally live above this bakery and smell it every time I leave for work - and let me tell you, it tastes as good as it smells!  This shop is super tiny and they open every morning and close when they sell out of their stock.  Their menu items vary day to day -- so it's always a surprise!  However, there are some items that reoccur pretty frequently --- so no need to fret.  

Although tiny, this spot is super instagramable -- take a photo with the sign that says "I got baked in San Francisco."  The pastries and even the box they come in are gorgeous and totally photo worthy.  

I think some of my favorites include the coconut coffee cream donuts, the California croissant (has salmon/seaweed inside -- NOM), and the savory croissant with bacon and blue cheese.  The staff here is super friendly, but note there's no restroom -- and there's probably a line for the infamous cruffins that start selling at 9:00am but sell out quickly!  (I'm not a fan of waiting, so I've only waited for the cruffins once)

I highly recommend this spot and frequent it pretty often.  I like to buy a box of pastries to surprise my team and they are always so impressed!!  Definitely give this place a try.
author: Michelle S.

description:
The cruffins line starts forming well before this place is serving them up but a while after the place actually opens so if you want cruffins be aware of this!

Honestly not sure why they don't serve their famous cruffins at the same time as everything else.
