The cruffins were not even my favorite pastry out of the 6 I got in a box: too sweet and really messy to eat. There's no seating or tables to enjoy their flaky goods so most people take them to go but if you're exploring the city and walking, you are bound to find your pastries squish and mix with each other when you finally find a place to sit (aka away from the sketchy area this bakery is located in). 
 
Their sweet pastries are too sweet, even for a sweet tooth. Every bite just tasted like sugar and not much else. I really tried to like at least the cruffin (biscotti was the flavor of the day) but not a single flavor really shines through. Maybe heating them up in an oven might make them better but I didn't have an oven on me in SF.

The one savory croissant we got (the Californian? With salmon?) was probably my favorite because you could taste the buttery flakiness of the croissant (it was still cold though).

In short, if you are bent on going to this bakery, do yourself a favor and go buy yourself one of their savory pastries at your own time convenience. If you still go for the cruffins, make sure to check instagram for flavors and consider if it's worth the trek!
author: Annie P.

description: Another sf bakery that I feel like is overhyped. I woke up early and stood in a forever line in order to buy some baked goods from here... however the selection was more limited. I had the furikake and salmon croissant, matcha croissant, and cronut. None of it was that memorable (although the furikake croissant is definitely unique.) Despite living next to Mr. Holmes, after going once I was never motivated to go again.
author: Jocelyn K.

description: Pastry perfection. Baking-class-101 flakiness and creaminess elevated to high art. I normally would never pick a cream filled pastry but the tropical curd is just lovely. It's light and delicate yet there's a complexity to the flavor and feel in your mouth. Perfect dusting of sugar.
author: Marty B.

description: Phenomenal pastries. The cruffin is out of this world. I plan on coming back with my friend after my diet is over. The ultimate cheat day item. The staff is also very cordial and the store looks inviting and modern. There needs to be more seating though. It's practically nothing
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Alright, let me give you the rundown in order to grab yourself one of the infamous "Cruffins"

*** Check their Instagram @mrholmesbakehouse for their flavors of the day (this changes every week)

*** Store Opens at 8AM on the weekend. 
The first time I came here, they had two lines, but the last time they didn't:
1. Cruffin line - They don't bring out the cruffins until 9AM but I suggest waiting in line before since they only sell 150 per day
2. Regular bakery line - Go here if you're here to try their amazing croissants or donuts

*** You need to purchase at least 6 items to get one of their boxes (or pay an additional fee)

Other than that, I would say try as much as you can, you can't really go wrong. My favorite thing on the menu other than the cruffin has got to be the Ferrero Rocher croissant [that they no longer have] or the donuts. Funny enough, I thought I'd never come here again but I'm pretty sure I'm going to stop by every single time I need to be in the city in the AM.
author: Wiseley F.

description:
I'm not a morning person so I didn't wake up in time for the really good stuff but I was able to go around noon on a Weds and get a collection of croissants and donuts. They close at 2:30 pm.

Love the very instagram-worthy decor and packaging. The pastries aren't bad looking either. Pretty tasty. Can't mess up pastries too much though. The donuts are a little on the sweet side especially with the jam filling inside. A little messy to eat as well, but all in all, this is a great place to pick up some wonderful treats. 

Note, there is a lot of construction going on outside the store right now. Parking may be limited due to this. There is usually a line outside as well but I was lucky to get in before a wave of people came in after me.

The coffee is okay. Not very flavorful but definately needed after all the sugar I consumed. 

Can't wait to go back and try many more of their pastries and baked goods.
author: Cicely T.

description: This place is such a wonderful bakery! I came here early to line up for the cruffins that I had heard so much about and they definitely did not disappoint. The flavors change and I am so happy they do because I would love to go back and try a different flavor. I love the ambiance inside and for the Instagram obsessed, it makes for a great picture!
author: Helen z.

description:
As a basic white girl I try out all the trendy places. I was really excited to check out this bakery. They have a great concept going, a cool vibe and unique pastries. 

There's a couple outside factors aside from the actual product that kind of bummed me out. The location, it is in the rough part of the city so it's not like you can just walk around and make your way over to the bakery. The parking in this area isn't great. Also, the shop is so small, it's hard to be on line, deal with the girls taking photos, and the line for photos. Unfortunately to no control of the stores, girls take their sweet time having a photo shoot which stops the flow of traffic coming in and out.
author: Demi K.

description: Disappointed. We got an Uber to the bakery, we went all the way for the famous cruffin and ... sold out. Okay, so let's try the Churros Croissant. The pastry is good, but the filling doesn't even look or taste like the Caramel that they described: white, plain and runny. My husband got the donut and also, nothing special for the price we pay. So, I will not come back.
author: Renata M.

description:
Solid pastries! The croissants, cookies & donuts were amazing. I was a little unsure about it at first but the California croissant with salmon was extreme good! The croissants are some of the best I ever have.
Heads up: the cruffins don't come out until 9 A.M. but can sell out by the afternoon
The ambiance is good but the neighborhood around isn't the nicest.
author: Ece K.

description:
TL/DR: 5 stars for the food, 2 stars for the overall experience.

The Good:
In general, all the baked goods I've had from this place are absolutely amazing. Their donuts are light and perfectly crisp, usually with a custard/cream filling that's not too sweet. Their chocolate chip cookie was very good. I've had one bite of the cruffin, and although it wasn't big enough for me to recommend it, the pastry seemed well made. Their design game is cute -- they did a good job decorating the tiny storefront, and all their packaging is very aesthetically pleasing. 

The Bad:
In general, I don't think this bakery provides a good customer experience. It's very small -- there's no space to eat, and most people just grab and go. It's in a sketchy neighborhood, so there's not really anywhere to sit near by and enjoy your pastry. 

It's also hard to see the full pastry selection as there's usually a line and I often feel rushed/unable to explore options. They don't do a good job of stocking the pastry shelves -- if you're here after 10am on a weekend, they usually don't have much left. To make matters worse, they don't really have a menu online or above the goods to make selection easier. 

The biggest offender is the cruffin though; they only release it at 9AM everyday, despite opening at 7am. I think this is a way to generate demand/keep up appearances. It's hard for people with 9 to 5 jobs to purchase one, and the weekends are too crazy. I interpret it as a shitty PR move by an already popular bakery -- why not just have a constant batch of all your baked goods and keep your shelves stocked? You obviously have enough demand for it.
author: Michelle L.

description: This place is definitely worth a trip. The cruffins and donuts are amazing. Cruffins tend to sell out fast so make sure you get here before 9am. They limit 2 per person.. wish it was more. The donuts are also some of my favorites and they get pretty creative with the flavors that they offer.
author: Iryna P.

description: I really don't understand the Instagram/ Yelp hype of this place... $5 for a mediocre matcha croissant, and ~$5 Chefs choice donut was overly sweet. Would not come back again.
author: Nhi B.

description: Matcha croissant was good but nothing special, just a regular croissant with matcha cream. The tropical donut just tasted like a regular donut with plain filling.
author: Tony P.

description:
After seeing Mr Holmes Bakeshop featured on Insider Dessert, I decided to make a pit stop before heading home from a business trip. I'm very happy I read reviews, because I wouldn't have known that their infamous cruffins don't come out the oven until 9am. I also read on reviews that the line is insanely long, especially on the weekends. So I decided to arrive twenty minutes early to ensure a spot in line (this was a Wednesday). When I arrived, there were only 2 groups of people ahead of me (so much for being early). So, I waited patiently for the cruffins to arrive. 

Exactly at 9am, cruffins came out of the back of the store and right onto the counter. Since I wanted to get a nice decorative box, I knew I had to order at least 6 bakery items. So, I ordered two cruffins (Neapolitan), 2 donuts (Nutella) and 2 croissants (Churro). I must say, I was actually disappointed in the cruffin. While the bread portion was good, I wasn't too keen on the filling. The chocolate was overpowering and took away from the other flavors and it was also kind of bitter. I also tried a croissant, which was absolutely amazing and something I wish I could eat every single day. Unfortunately, I'm not a huge sweets person, so I was unable to take down a donut, but it looked delicious. 

I don't know if I would come back for a cruffin again, it all depends on the filling, but please sign me up for the croissant, any day!
author: Victoria T.

description:
TIP: Must get at least 6 pastries for them to put it in that cool white and gold box - you're going to want that box. So make sure you get 6.

As much as everyone keeps raving about the cruffins (which most times I've missed because they sell out so early in the day)... let's talk about how good the matcha dipped croissant, the thai tea donut, and my ultimate favorite the TOFFEE CORNFLAKE COOKIEs were! SO GOOD! Won't really get heartbroken if I show up here and they're all out of the cruffins as long as they have any of those three left. 

The lady at this location also suggested we try the California croissant - croissant filled with smoked salmon, seaweed (nori), wasabi, and ginger. Strikes me odd when they gave us a soy sauce packet to go along with the croissant. You're supposed to eat it with the soy sauce - hand wrap sushi style. I didn't have the gutsy taste buds to give this one a try but my sushi snob brother did and he enjoyed it. So if your palette is into that kind of stuff - TRY IT! I heard it's good. LOL. 

They recently opened a location closer to home in SoCal. I have yet to visit that location. If you love bread / desserts / donuts  / croissants / carbs / sugar / everything good, this is the place for you. 

You bet - I GOT BAKED IN SAN FRANCISCO and I ain't even mad about it. Yep.
author: Bay M.

description: I'm not a huge fan of sweets let alone pastries but these pastries were to die for. The malt cruffin they offer on Saturday was so soft on the inside/ flaky on the outside. It was perfect! The matcha croissant was good too but there was no filling which I expected there to be :( they also had a peach croissant with filling that was amazing!! 10/10! The blackberry cream filled donut was probably one of the best donuts I've ever had. The lines move fast and I went at around 9:20am on Saturday and everything was still there :) IG:@momo.eatz
author: Ashley A.

description:
"Get rich on Cruffins, or die trying." -CEO of Mr. Holmes Bakehouse, Aaron Caddel

My cousin helped with the opening of Mr. Holmes Bakehouse in Irvine, CA. So this is how I was introduced to the bakery. When I looked further into the business, I came across Caddel's story: he was diagnosed with a potentially malignant brain tumor at 19 years of age. Now read the quote above again and the rest is history!

If you haven't already heard, this place is known for the "Cruffin," which is a hybrid of a Croissant and a Muffin. Unfortunately, we arrived at 11:15am - a little too late to purchase those goodies. But, we ended up with other San Francisco treats!

Not gonna lie....the pastry boxes in the window caught my eye. I really love the design, so classy and chic. A white, solid, cardboard box with gold foil lettering - give me three of them! The minimum order is 6 pastries to get them packed into a box and on average, each pastry is ~$4.00.

Since it was my first visit and probably a long while before visiting again, I chose to order "2 of each" from the display case and a couple of coffees. As soon as we exited, those box flaps flung open and we went to town on the matcha croissant, mushroom danish, grapefruit danish, and chocolate filled donut. Everything was buttery, flakey, a little crunchy, sweet (but not too sweet), just heavenly in every little bite. The gents and I were delighted to have stood patiently in line (~20 mins) for these delicious SF treats!

Hours of operation are 7AM - 2:30PM WEEKDAYS / 8AM - 3:30PM WEEKENDS.

Metered parking is available along the street.
author: Jessica P.

description: The pastries are awesome. Wait for the cruffins. They have a different flavor everyday and they do not serve them until 9am. The elote danish is also excellent. Be sure to get there early because things sell out fast.
author: Bianca D.

description: I had researched Mr Holmes Bakehouse a lot before I stopped by. I was expecting a crazy line (arrived around 10am on a Monday),  but surprisingly walked right in! I tried the following- Cruffin, vanilla doughnut, croissant with peach filling, bostock toast with cheesecake/berries on top and artichoke pastry. I would say all of them are "Ehh". Would I go back? No. It's not that they're bad, but there are better (my opinion) in San Francisco (b. patisserie). They lack the crisp factor when it comes to a croissant or a croissant style pastry. Just not for me. Cute shop though!
author: Erin A.

description: Must get the cruffin! We went here two mornings in a row and they sell out by 9:30. Line forms by 8:30 and they start selling cruffins at 9! Get there early to be garunteed two cruffins per person.
author: Annamarie L.

description: Got one of their famous cruffins and was not disappointed.  They only have one type of cruffin each day.  I wouldn't have chosen the flavor we got, but I did end up enjoying it.  We also got a chocolate croissant.  The pastries are very fresh. The place is small, so don't expect to sit down.  But it has a cool vibe.
author: Bradley L.

description:
Brought a dozen croissants and pastries to a morning meeting.   Rave reviews for the Churro and chocolate croissants.   Perfectly flaky croissant consistency.  Matcha was pretty good though I think Churro was better.  

Get there in the morning as they are best fresh.   If you let these guys sit out for a couple of hours they lose their flakiness.
author: R. G.

description: I came to Mr Holmes Bakehouse during a trip to San Francisco. I ended up going here 2 days back to back as we loved the pastries but also hoped that they'd fix the sign as it was broken when we visited the first time. During my second visit, I got a box to take back on the plane with me and I can honestly say they were some of the BEST pastries I've had. My personal favorites: both of the doughnuts. I wasn't able to wait in like for the cruffins which I hear are amazing. My 2 complaints about the place were the sign was damaged and all 4 days we came here it wasn't on (which yes was another reason why we were visiting it). The second, the fact you have to line up so early for cruffins and they only have a very limited supply. Definitely add this to your list to visit if you're in the San Fran area.
author: Sophia P.

description:
This place was AWESOME. We happened upon it when a guest who was staying at the same hotel as us right around the corner (shout out to the Hotel Carlton) was getting into the elevator with a cool box from Mr Holmes Bakehouse. We walked around the corner to find a small room, with amazing smelling baked goods, and a cheeky neon sign reading "I got baked in San Francisco", great for taking fun insta-pictures here. 

I ordered the sausage cornbread muffin, which comes with a side of gravy (on top or on the side), you really can't go wrong. It was SO SO delicious. The people working there were friendly and had great suggestions. 

We tried going back the next morning and the line was half way down the street, so I guess we lucked out on which day we went!

Atmosphere, super cute and quaint.
Staff, very nice and friendly.
Location, awesome.
Taste, delicious! We'll definitely be back!
author: Heather A.

description:
Hmm did I really just wait 20 minutes and pay $4.50 for a cruffin? Overhyped! It was basically a croissant in the shape of a muffin filled with some pudding cream. The cream is what makes it unique but still nothing to go crazy waiting 1 hour for.. Follow @mrholmesbakehouse on Instagram for updated cruffin and donut flavors. If I ever came back, I'd skip the cruffin line and go for their other pastries.

Cream/jelly filled donuts ($3.50) weren't remarkable but the cream filling is good. Same cream as the cruffin.

They have fancy croissants ($4). I tried the churro and elderberry strawberry ones. I have no idea what an elderberry is so I was surprised when the cream was more tart than sweet. I liked the churro filling which tasted like custard. Overall I'd rather just get a plain croissant, where you can actually taste the buttery flakey texture.

In the end, I'm still a cookie lover at heart. Their toffee cornflake cookie ($3) was surprisingly my favorite! Basically cornflakes cereal in cookie form. Thin and chewy but still had crispy edges! The perfect combination of flavors and texture :D I also tried the chocolate chip with sea salt, and I'm a fan. Yum!

Minimum 6 item order to get a box, which I gladly obliged. Easier to carry the goods in case I need to make a run for it through the Tenderloin :P
author: Betty C.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a long time so when I visited SF, I was sure to come here. We arrived at 10am on a Sunday morning and, unsurprisingly, there was a line out the door. However, it moved relatively fast and we were in the door after 20-30 minutes. The cruffins were already sold out!

We bought a box of 6 pastries. The box is sturdy so the butteriness of the pastries won't leak through. Our selections included a chocolate croissant, a matcha croissant, a butter toffee cookie, a chocolate donut, a bearclaw, and a grapefruit danish. My favorite were definitely the croissants. They're so flakey and buttery -- I was sad when I finished eating them!

The interior of this place is as cute as it looks on instagram. The shop is much smaller than I expected, but it has the pink lights, a small display case of pastries, and a bathroom.

Overall, this is a great bakery for delicious pastries if you're willing to wait a little to get in. If your heart is set on the cruffins, definitely come before opening to ensure you get your hands on some! They only make a certain number every day and you can check the flavor of the day on their instagram account.
author: Ashley D.

description:
After a long stressful day the best part of it was my boyfriend meeting me and treating me to some delicious pastries in the city from Mr Holmes Bakehouse. I've seen photos of the pastries that this place serves and good god it looks delicious and seriously the best type of pastries one can find in the city. I'm not usually a sweets person or a pastries person, but this place can seriously make you change your mind. 

Since this place is so good there can be a line so expect to wait, but seriously it is worth the wait. This place doesn't have a lot of seating so don't really expect to be able to sit down here and dine. Despite having lots of pastries there is not a lot of seating- around 4-5 seats inside. Since this is located in the city, expect either to do street parking or garage parking. Parking can be difficult to find so you might have to uber there or walk if you want. 

My boyfriend and I ended up getting a box filled with pastries, who wouldn't?! We ended up getting a Cruffin, a Strawberry cream donut, Thai tea donut, Raspberry jelly filled croissant, Matcha croissant, and a Matcha cream donut. All these pastries were so delicious especially the Cruffin. This Cruffin had two jellies inside tasting like raspberry and possibly an orange flavor. The downfall is that this place only allows 2 Cruffins per customer and the Cruffins are released at 9:00 am while other pastries are released at around 8:00 am. This makes sense though because the Cruffins are delicious and are usually sold out pretty quickly at this place. Overall, the pastries at this place is so delicious and are cooked to perfection. But if you want to try the Cruffins I highly suggest that you come early because they sell quickly. 

Despite the pastries being a little bit pricey, it is worth both the price and the wait. I would most definitely come back here again if I'm ever in the area to try more of the various pastries that they offer.
author: Nadine Y.

description: Walked all the way down from our hotel (almost two miles) because my son, who is a chef himself, wanted me to bring him home some goodies specifically from this place.  Got there around 2pm, and they were already closed!!!!   Complete disappointment.
author: Traci P.

description:
#willstandinlineforcruffins 

Usually lines and hype let me down. Not this time! And I didn't even get a cruffin! When we got in line there were about 20 left, but by the time we ordered, sold old. Sure I was bummed, but with all the other pretty pastries in the case, I moved on. 

I got a churro croissant and the girl told me it was basically the same thing as a cruffin anyway - same flavors, just different shape. Churro croissant was perfectly flakey and buttery, cinnamon sugar ratio was perfect, and the vanilla custard filling inside was so good! 

We also got a chocolate croissant (so good!), cookie dough bear claw (just okay), and a cherry almond filled donut, which was amazing! The filling wasn't too sweet and the flavors were not at all over powering, which I think often happens with both cherry and almond. 

Line moves pretty quick, so don't let it deter you!
author: Elise H.

description: I didn't get to try this when I was in LA a few weeks back but I was ok since I saw there was one in SF! The place is small but looks hip. Went on a friday afternoon and the line wasn't too long, we got to the front in 5 mins. Most of the pastries were gone so we only had 3 options, the mulled wine danish, dukkah danish, and the chocolate donut. My friend and I ended up getting the mulled wine danish and the dukkah danish, both were good but I like the mulled wine one more! Would come again but want to try other locations.
author: Tam N.

description:
I came 10 minutes prior to closing and had difficulty making up my mind between sweets and savory. Indecision is highly unlike me and seemed to be even more uncomfortable for the girl trying to close up. 

Ergo, she just gave me a giant complimentary bag of both sweet and savory goods that she planned to donate to charity. (I watched her, she didn't lick or otherwise contaminate them before gifting me, don't worry) 

I don't recommend everyone use this trick, but I have to commend the employee for putting us both out of my indecisive misery. 

The savory sausage roll was not my favorite. I'd stick to the sweets here.
author: Spartevan V.

description: Pastry varies during days. Better to come during weekday morning! No line, no wait. I have been there several times, but noticed that the price goes up during the last 6 months. But quality is still good! The only complain is sometimes the color of filling in the pastry is hard to tell... the blackberry filling looks like chocolate, and I accidentally bought that, and the mango lessi flavor criffon offers on Friday is the one I do not like
author: Nina H.

description:
Tasty pastries.

I stopped by on a Monday morning at 8:50, and the line for cruffins was merely 1 person deep, at which point I waited to try some. They were quite delightful, although maybe not worth a 45 minute wait in line. I also had a matcha croissant, which had a nice coating of matcha and was generally well-prepared. I'd definitely stop by to try other pastries if in the area.
author: Dennis J.

description:
Unless you crave their cruffins I suggest you go late morning early afternoon. They have tasty sausage rolls and original donuts such as Thai tea and matcha flavored.

Edit:
We finally get our hands on a cruffin on a rainy Sunday morning, no lines thanks to the rain. It was delicious.
author: Jan Orhun A.

description:
For anyone who wants to know about their other goodies and not just the cruffin, they are really good! Their donuts arent too sweet and i like that whenever i come in i never know what flavors they will have. The cookies are also really good, slightly chewy. I particularly like the double chocolate chip but it is always made topped with sea salt. Solid croissants, crispy and flaky. Coffee flavor croissant has some kind of lightly flavored cream filling. The shiitake mushroom danish they have is a surprisingly delicious savory snack. Definitely going back for more of these.

Nothing here is overly salted or sweetened. I love that all of the emphasis is on good flavor and texture.
author: Wendy F.

description:
I got baked in Los Angeles. 
I got baked in San Francisco. 
Dang, I'm so baked. 

The line for cruffins is no joke. DO line up early if you want them before they run out (around 9am is good). 

I'm okay going without their cruffins because I actually really adore their donuts more. A doughnut gal here ;) 

I always settle for 6 pastries because I like the box and the box is easier to carry around. I'm proud to say that I've tried them all, not all the flavors though. Here's my breakdown from best to least. 

1. Donut 
2. Cruffin 
3. Croissant / Kouign amann
4. Cookie

I love their donuts. It's almost like a malasada. The dough is nice and crispy while the stuffing is a little bit more to give it that nice overflow. The cruffin is also great, too, but not as doughy as I personally prefer pastries. The croissant and kouign amann are also pretty buttery and flaky. Lastly, the cookie is super crunchy and the size of your head! 

In all honestly, my ranking system is wack. All their pastries are at the same level. It just depends on what you're feeling for the day. Bottom line is, don't get upset over no cruffins. There's plenty other "fish" in the sea.
author: Fiona L.

description: The wait on a weekday was not bad at all - I pulled up at 8:45 and found parking on the same block, and was back in my car by 9:05. I got a cruffin (black forest), a donut (coffee hazelnut cream), and a peach croissant. Everything was very visually appealing, but I was expecting much more for the taste - the croissant dough on the cruffin is nicely flakey but kind of flavorless. The donut filling was good, but the donut itself wasn't very tender, and since apparently they filled it with two different holes, the filling all came splooging out on my lap when I tried to eat it. The peach croissant was my favorite, but still not in love. I don't think I'd go back unless I was in the neighborhood - I prefer Arsicault for their absolutely breathtaking croissants, or B. Patisserie for interesting flavor combinations.
author: Alison M.

description: This little bake shop was everything my SF kid said it would be. Options vary daily. Now they have a different cruffin and donut theme daily. They open at 7 but cruffins are sold at 9. Expect a line
author: Mrs T.

description: Updating my review because if you go on a non-weekend, the experience is a lot better and you can have access to all the offerings. Recently went on a Sunday at 10:25 and all the cruffins were already sold out. Went on a Thursday at 10:45 and they had lots of cruffins left as well as all other pastries. If you live in the nabe and have a weekday morning off work, it's worth checking out what they have. The donuts are delicious and I still wish they had a plain version since not all the filling works. Other good bites are the matcha croissants and churro croissants.
author: Semuteh F.

description: One of the most over-exaggerated places. I literally made my husband drive me to see what the hype was about. Beside having to walk down urine infested sidewalks to get to the cramp shop, there were barely any selections. A total of 3 selections to choose from. It was nothing like the Yelp reviews indicated. We bought a croissant. I can buy the same croissant at almost any bakery. Um then there was the apricot filled...hm...I want to say maybe donut? The items did not taste bad, neither were they memorable.
author: Teang K.

description:
Okay a tip:
Get there between 8-9 because they let the cruffins out at 9. In between those times you'll definitely get one. 

Cruffin, donuts and others... you can't go wrong with Mr. Holmes Bakehouse.
author: Kevin L.

description:
10:30a and the limited cruffins are long gone, but so is the long line.  Great business concept of driving demand.  My aunt lives a few blocks away so I drop by for a pastry whenever it's convenient.   :)

If you drive into town, get your companion to line up as you look for parking (longer line is for the 9am cruffin if there is 2 formed, the other one is for non-cruffin specific purchases)

Parking meters start at 9am in the area, and if you circle around you can find 2 hour parking spots too.  Do note the street grid are one-ways here.

Buy 6 and you get an instagrammable brand box.  The churro croissant (has filling) comes close to what the cruffin is, if you got the cruffin then choose another pastry.

Now go drive or take the Geary bus to Arsicault bakery at Arguello and do a comparison!
author: Drew B.

description:
Wow!  Where to start on this place. So dang good. We ordered a variety of things so we could get a good feel for the hype of this bakery.  Let me tell you, the hype is legit. 

The filled donuts were awesome. The cruffins were really, really good. And I LOVED the custard filled churro croissant.  All amazing. Can't wait to go back and get more before we head out of town!!  Gotta try the other flavors since they have different ones every day. 

Line was about 20 people deep at 845 on a Monday morning but the line went by pretty fast. We waited about 20 minutes. Worth the wait, let me tell you!!
author: Erin J.

description:
After hearing so many things about Mr. Homes' infamous cruffins, we finally were able to try them out for ourselves at the original location. I scoured the reviews on Yelp the day before we decided to try, and most people recommended getting there half an hour before the cruffins go on sale at 9 AM to guarantee a cruffin. Sadly we're not morning people, so we got there around 9:15 AM on a weekday. The line was already out the door, but we kept our fingers crossed in the hopes that we would still get a cruffin. So people mentioned that they give you a sticker to guarantee you getting a cruffin that day, and they also mentioned that there were two lines - one for cruffins, one for regular baked goods. Both weren't true the day I went: just 1 single line with no stickers. We just had to wait and see. 

If you want their popular Mr. Homes Bakehouse box, you'll have to buy 6 or more pastries. That's pretty tricky of them, but the boxes are actually really sturdy and well-made. Just make sure your pastries don't tilt or get smushed in the box cause it'll make for oil stains. 

When we got to the front of the line, there were only about 15 cruffins or so left. The flavor of the day that day was Fruity Pebbles - probably not the flavor I would have wanted if I had known ahead of time to check their Instagram. It wasn't bad; I could really taste the Fruity Pebbles in the filling, and the outside of the cruffin was crispy and cinnamon-y while the inside was soft and flaky. Best eaten warm! Once it got cold, it was no longer good. Sadly, the worker who was placing the cruffins in our box accidentally tilted one, so it ended up making a mess. $4.5 per cruffin 

Chocolate croissant: $4 - I expected a croissant that was flaky and crispy and oozing out chocolate upon biting inside. Instead, I got a dry and stale croissant with tiny bits of chocolate pieces inside. Not special at all and definitely not worth the $4. 

Churro croissant: $4 - consists of sugar and Dulce de leche cream. This was amazing! Apparently there was a Dulce de leche cream filling inside of the croissant that I had not been aware of, making it a tad bit sweet, but still so good. The cinnamon on the outside of the croissant definitely made me savor every bite. Flaky and crispy - this made up for the poor chocolate croissant. 

Donuts: $3.5 - I think the donuts were a blood orange and a pistachio cream - we ended up going with the pistachio cream. Nothing too special. After eating all the cinnamon-y desserts, the flavors started to blend together. Not a big fan of the filling, but the donut itself was pretty tasty. Probably wouldn't order this again. 

Apple fruit Danish - $4 I was tempted to order a savory Danish, but at the end, I went for the apple crumble Danish (if I remember correctly). I remember it was one of the best things in that box. Lots of flavor in the filling, not too sweet, but the crumbles and the way the fruit was cooked was a perfect complement to the slightly savory Danish itself. I would order this again - it was good (but not as good as Renaud's) and definitely one of my favorites. 

Ordering is similar to Bottega Louie where you point and fill up your box or bag and pay at the cashier. The storefront is pretty tiny; the outside is unassuming if it's all closed up - it's once you walk inside that you see the bakery in all its goodness. You see all the people taking photos under the "I Got Baked" sign, but you might have to wait a few minutes before you can get your photo; and it's also awkward having other people watch you while you try to get that perfect shot. But no shame, that's why you're visiting Mr. Holmes anyway right? 

tl;dr - Ended up waiting in line for around 30 minutes, trying to take pictures for another 15 minutes before eating our box of goodies in the car and at a park. I'd get the Danish and the churro croissant again, but no longer need the box since I had to toss it out anyway. I can see why this place is so popular and I'm glad I got to visit the original location, but now that I've tried it, I don't think I am eager to revisit anytime soon, unless they have a cruffin of the day that I really want to try - especially since I can go to the location in LA now. They accept credit cards - prices aren't the cheapest and they do add up. Make sure you check their IG before you visit the store!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
After waiting in one of the long lines to enter inside and pick out our pastries, we decided to get a box (the famous white and gold one) of different goodies. There were so many different pastries to choose from!

I'm not one to be a big fan of pastries like this, but my sisters raved about all of them and I must say the chocolate chip cookies were soft, warm, and huge! 

Besides having to wait in the long line with tons of tourists, it's a good spot to grab a pastry or one of their yummy cookies. And you can't beat the cute pink sign inside!
author: Jillian F.

description: Wow!!! Unbelievable flavor. Best croissants I've ever had! Rest in Peach and Elote flavors were my favorite. So glad we made to try this place before I left back to LA. Tried to stop by the other day and they were already sold out! My advice get there early! Yum!!!! Mouthgasmic.
author: Alanna S.

description: Please stay away from here if you are on a diet! The flavors are so fun and delicious. I thought the cornflake cookie was slightly too sweet for my taste, but I still ate two anyway. Check out the menu and you'll see why it is a dangerous place to visit. You will seriously want to grab everything. The banana chai flavors were so delicious (see picture) and the donut was delicious. There was tea flavored cream inside yum! I can't wait to try the matcha croissant. Everything was delicious, but a little too sweet for me.
author: Kosmo Z.

description: Saw Mr Holmes in a YouTube video and wow no joke the line is up the butt! We made several attempts to get our hands on one of those cruffins! Attempt 1, got to Mr Holmes at 2pm and the whole store was sold out on a Sunday. Attempt 2, got there at 8:30 and waited about 45mins and got our hands on some cruffins! They have a limit of two cruffins per person so we got 4 and since it's our first time actually going in the shop we got a little too excited and ended up spending ~$70 on bakery.... sad thing is most of their bakery was crispy so they didn't last very well. Attempt 3, arrived at 11am and very few bakeries were left! I asked the cashier and apparently they serve cruffins at 9am everyday and it runs out 30-45mins past 9am... guys... if you want cruffins get there early! And yes it's worth it!
author: Nina Y.

description: During my trip to San Francisco, I stayed at a hotel nearby so I went here three days in a row for breakfast! I went pretty early (basically at opening time), and I was able to avoid any long waits. FYI, the front of the bakery is quite small that I almost walked past. Also, the prices are a little more expensive for bakery goods, but they're to DIE FOR and totally worth it! If you order 6 pastries/baked goods, you can get a cardboard box, which is super nice. The cookie is amazing as well as any of their croissants. If I had to pick a favorite, it would probably be their crème brûlée retes
author: Han P.

description:
Ok I know I am in minority here for rating this place low. But my review is based on their stupid policy (max 2 cruffin per person) and not the baked goods since I didn't (more accurately wasn't able to) buy cruffin. 

Here it is the issue: not everyone can stand in line. Our elderly family members were waiting in the car. I stood in line but I wasn't able to buy enough for everyone (I wanted 4) when they won't sell me more than 2? That is the most stupid policy I have ever heard!!
Sell me what I want since I am already there don't saved the dam thing for future customers who may or may not show up. Unfortunately I wasn't able to try their cruffin since I couldn't just buy 2 for 4 people!!  
I will not support such a non-sense policy.
author: Paolo D.

description: Have not been to this location but the one in SEOUL , WOW!!!! I would have never known until my friend introduced me to Mr Holmes Bakehouse. I ordered a BRIOCHE DONUT with cookies and creme filing OH YUMMMY! they also had CHURRO CROISSANTS and GREEN TEA CROISSANTS yummy SUGAR RUSH!
author: Michelle M.

description:
Rain or shine, there gon' be a line. 

I don't know about you but I'm a total hater. I was ready to pick apart these baked shits like the chimpanzee that tore that woman's face off but by golly these f*ckers know how to butter that bread. 

I didn't even get a cruffin, but I did get something else with all the cruffin elements that's called something else that I of course can't remember. It was like a croissant/tart. So a Crart... which is easy to remember because it sounds like the best word baby of all time: shart. 

I wasn't even that excited about it and managed to wait over 12 hours to eat it because I was sure it was going to be as basic as those gals who dress tom-boy indie chic with cuffed mom jeans and flat sneakers and solid baseball hats and take selfies in public bathroom mirrors with one leg up on the sink in an interesting crotchy partial crouch position (if you don't know, you clearly haven't been pooting around on insta in the last 2 years). And yes, I am hating some more here. About 90% hating and 10% curious why this has become a thing... and a secret 4% is me wondering if I should start doing it, too. Looks like a good hip flexor stretch.

Aaaaanyway, I ate the not cruffin but very croissant-like square pastry with sticky goop in the center and honest to god had a real 'Come to Jesus' moment. It was not ok how good that thing was. I've never tasted anything like it and the kind of butter they slather that shit in was the bakery equivalent of Spanish Fly.

The line is stupid. 
The yuppies waiting here are the worst. 
The hype is deserving of the most over-exaggerated eye roll ever...
BUT they really are the shit and I'm not embarrassed to say that you will find my yuppie ass in this stupid line waiting for a box of whatever they've got left whenever I'm in the area and I for a short period of time I will shut my hater mouth and just enjoy the moment.
author: Candice G.

description:
An iconic institution in downtown sf....just dont mind its location and inside you will find a world of baked goodness awaiting you. Took me 3 tries just to get in the door. 1-2x, they were closed early. Closing is really 330pm but to be frank, its when they run out of pastry to sell..which is tyoicslly around noon or 1pm...on a good day. People start lining up as early as 7am locals say and the store will be sold out by noon. After that, game over. Store is closed. On my 3rd try got there 10am and sure enough there was a line up on a sat morning. 

I went with a box of 6 and the he most unique of all was the california crossaint. When i asked why the name? Answer: its filled with smoked salmon seaweed ginger and semsame seed. Ahh...such a delectible combo. Had to try it. The rest were  choco and nuttela crossaint, bear claw and churro crossaint...

Couldnt wait to get home so i ordered a coffee and immediately had a bite of the cali crossaint and my oh my...it was classic cali.in my mouth. Smoked salmon was fresh and the seaweed provided a good salty touch to the salmon. The ginger inside wasnt that punget and never affected the flavour but provided a good compliment to the filling. 

The pastries all.looked succelulent and good. Only negative thing i can think of is the crossaints were browned a bit more than normal. And the price.was a bit on the upscale starting at $3.5 for a donut going until $4.5 for the cali one and other varieties...but hey, u only live once and im here so cest la vie!

Happy eating!!
author: Jon L.

description: Maybe I built it up bigger in my head but it wasn't that great. Is it bad that I said that about this place? I thought some of the combos were so strange I didn't even want to try them. We got to try around 5 different things but made sure to get the cruffin and I rather eat other pastries then a cruffin. Pretty greasy and hard. Awkward to eat without the filling fall al over the place.
author: Nettifer W.

description:
We walked about a mile to get here and waited in line for about 15min just based on Yelp reviews. It was well worth the effort. The cruffins were AMAZING! As were the doughnuts and croissants. 

I would highly recommend Mr Holmes to anyone that has a love of fresh baked goods!
author: Erin K.

description:
Who doesn't love Mr Holmes? 
After visiting 5+ times, here are some tips:
I know the sweet options are irresistible, but do try their savory ones too! I like the California Croissant. It's practically sushi rolled in crispy croissant skin! 

Of course, the cruffins are what they are known for! The skin is perfectly crisped, and the filling is generous. Most of the cruffins i tried were a bit too sweet for my taste though. 

Also, the chocolate croissant is more satisfying than the matcha croissant :) It's richer and happier! 

Finally: Buy the regular pastries before cruffins come out, then wait in line for the cruffins with your newly bought pastries. When it's your turn to get cruffins, you can always buy another round off regular pastries ;)
author: Julia C.

description:
Came by to try their baked goods and this hipster bakery was tasty and dare I say a tad better than B Patisserie! Staff were pretty chilled out and wore latex gloves.

Their donut was very light, fluffy, and not too sweet! 

Their cronut croissant was heavenly as this was crispy on the outside, super light on the inside with a not-too-sweet filling! 

Line wasn't too long as it took merely 10 minutes or so to get to the front! 

They take credit cards here too! 

...they are located a couple blocks away from the Tenderloin...so be mindful of your surroundings! ;)
author: Derek S.

description:
Great bakery with delicious goodies..

I wish they would maintain the lines in front I live right next to this place and some mornings I have to Wade through a group of people to get to the bus it's really frustrating
author: Nicholas F.

description: The pastrami croissant was out of this world. I have always wanted to trace to this hot spot in sf. I'm so glad I finally made it, nestled between small shops this little bakery is a gem. The croissants are buttery, with a flaky crust exactly how they should be. The service was superb and I will be hitting this before I leave. The only sad part was they were out of cronuts so I suggest getting there early.
author: Lyndsey W.

description: The Chinese plum tea croissant aaaand the rest in peach croissant were incredible, we missed ot on the cruffins but everything else was amazing
author: Brooke M.

description:
Dude.. this place is ridiculously good. Definitely get the croissants!! They're fresh, flakey and visually appealing. 

By the way, the packaging is super cute if you order to-go. My co-worker surprised our team with a box of these pastries in the morning and we were incredibly thankful. Definitely a great place for breakfast!
author: Jenny H.

description:
My mom and i were on a weekend trip to san fran and decided to check this place out. There are two lines one just for the cruffins and one for remaining pastries. Cruffins are out at 9 am while the bakery opens at 8 am. We arrived around 8:25 with hot coffee in hand to wait for the cruffins. We were one of the first in line and it was great. I stepped out while mom held our place in line to get other pastries such as the asian citrus donut, the churro croissant, and the matcha croissant. The young lady helping me was sooo sweet.  I stepped out of line to get other pastries but I think they let u go and get other pastries after the cruffins too.

 Pastries were beautiful and the sign was cool. Bakery smelled like heaven. The pastries themselves were of good quality but they were soooo sweet for my taste.  Cruffin was good but too sweet for me..  the chocolate flavor was flavor of the day  (if u have a sweet tooth you would love it). If i were to return i would get the plain croissant lol. Matcha croissant was also very good. 

Btw the neighborhood was bad. Several Junkies walking up and down the street trying to get money from you. Make sure to have uber or lyft drop u off by the store.  

Overall really good IF you like sweet breakfast pastries. But i like a more savory pastry so its a two timer for me. I feel like instagram really hyped up this place and you will see all the kiddos taking pics for the gram.
author: Nadia A.

description:
TL;DR: it's pretty tasty and the sign is cool but far from BART and can be expensive! 

Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is a cozy (aka tiny) bakery and there are usually people standing around taking pictures of or with the iconic "I got baked in SF" sign, or taking pictures of their food with the sign. 
I've never gone to line up, but the first time I went they only had one kind of cruffin left (a ginger/grapefruit cruffin) along with a bunch of other non-cruffin pastries. That ginger/grapefruit cruffin was not for me...... however, they had a really great berry pastry that tasted great!

I returned again recently with a friend and there was actually a bunch of cruffins and other pastries left at around 11:30am! Not bad for a Wednesday morning! We both got a matcha croissant each which was really sweet but paired well with coffee. 

I would return again to try their iconic cruffin! And dear Mr. Holmes, please fix your sign. The times I've been there, it has always been broken. Thank you! 

Tip for BART riders wanting to go to Mr. Holmes, it might be best to go from the Civic center stop! It took about 20 minutes to walk there from the Orpheum theater exit and 30 minutes from Union Square and Powell Station!
author: Alison S.

description: Didn't think it would taste amazing but went for the cute pics anyway-- oh was I wrong. The green tea croissant was baked to perfection with the perfect level of sweetness, chew and crunch. I'll be back again!
author: Charmaine L.

description:
Woke up early to go try the esteemed cruffin!

NOTE: I'd recommend getting there by 8:30am so you can get in a reasonable spot in line, but not have to wait too long (or be too far back in line) till they serve cruffins at 9am.

TIP: If you want the box, you need to buy at least 6 pastries. If you want that cruffin, they limit to 2/customer and don't start serving till 9am, regardless of opening time. 

They hand out stickers, and cruffins are limited to 2 per customer. I was set on getting a box of treats, for which you would need to buy 6 pastries minimum. Otherwise, they will serve them to you via the cute pink/white paper bag. 

While we waited in line, my boyfriend went and bought a matcha croissant and a peach pastry for us to nibble on. Yum! Both had a nice balance in flavors, but I preferred the matcha croissant. Nice, flaky, and sweet! 

The cruffin of the day was the peanut butter banana caramel! You can really taste all the flavors of the title! The pastry itself was flaky and perfectly sweet. Each bite was banana-y and you get a peanut butter aftertaste, yum! The filling wasn't too thick and made for an overall yummy treat. It's a bit messy to eat though. Not sure if it's worth the longer wait, but a unique and tasty experience nonetheless. 

We also got the coffee cocoa nib and guava cheesecake donuts, both of which were super yummy! Personally I prefer the donuts over the cruffins (less wait time, fluffier, and easier to eat). 

If you're in the area, give this place a try!
author: Tina T.

description: It's good. My fave was the savory croissant with pastrami. The filled donuts were my second fave. The cruffin was ok. I'm just not a fan of it. The filling was good. The wait was not long and service was good.
author: Melinda L.

description: It was okay! I felt I had to go since I was in the area. I got a hot black coffee and a hazelnut coffee donut. It was good, but probably wouldn't go again. Went at 8:30a and there was no line.
author: Mackenzie K.

description:
My third time eating a cruffin but I'm so exited to finally visit the original bakery in San Francisco! Today's cruffin flavor: Raspberry and Lychee filling and I'm amazed how every day seems to a different cruffin flavor! 

I didn't realize how small the SF store would be compared to the LA location. The location is pretty small and once you get inside the store, it gets pretty crowded since people are trying to get pics with the infamous neon sign 

I got in line around 9 am and there was a decent line already. The bakery opens earlier but the cruffins start selling at 9 am. The line wasn't that bad though, the whole experience took about 20-30 minutes!!

If you get a sticker you are guaranteed a cruffin and each person can only get 2 cruffins. If you don't want a cruffin, you can skip the line!
author: Frances K.

description:
If you've got a sweet tooth & love carbs, you've come to the right place! 

I ordered...

FRUIT DANISH: This baked good is a toast with blackberries/a lot of seasonal fruits, brown butter streusel, & pastry creme. It sounds so simple but that's the reason it's so good! All the flavors mix so well. It's a little too sweet for my liking so I had to share with my boyfriend. He loved it as well. My absolute favorite part of the fruit danish was the crust!! I freakin loved the crust & how crunchy it was! 

Definitely a tourist spot that everyone should hit up! 

TIP: Very small location so it gets crowded & it's a bit hard to take a picture without feeling rushed so come early. They also sell out fast so the earlier you're there the better chance of getting something you want without having to settle.
author: Phuong H.

description:
I'm writing this as a scarf down the heavenly crumbs of what's left of my Fruity Pebbles donut. Wow! That was truly something dream are made of! During my morning haul I also purchased a grapefruit tart and bread pudding. A few things to mention:
1.  If you don't plan on purchasing a cruffin, don't bother waiting in line (learned that the hard way)
2.  Apparently bread pudding has the best chance of keeping fresh until the next day (if properly sealed)

It's encouraged that these goods be eaten immediately because they do not (er, uh, is it donut?) contain preservatives. Score! 

I will SO be going back and can't wait to take out of town guests here-- as long as they can get up in time to jump in line.  Cruffins are usually sold out by 8:00 am on weekends and before 11:00 am during the week.
author: Andrea H.

description:
Since Golden Gate Bakery wasn't open, we headed towards Mr. Holmes Bakehouse, home of the famous cruffin: an amazing filled pastry that is a cross between a croissant and muffin.  The flavor of the day was cranberry mascarpone and they were everything the hype made them out to be.  You definitely need to stop here when in San Francisco.  

Not only do they serve amazing cruffins ($4.50), they offer coffee and other yummy pastries as well.  Here's hoping there's no line when you go!
author: Nadia K.

description:
Pros:  friendly and quick service
           Good pastries 
           

Cons:  street parking
author: Bayarea K.

description:
Sorry this review is kinda later.  Came here on Sunday morning and found street parking right outside.  The line was only 2 shops long and it went pretty quickly.  One of the guys came out n gave stickers to everyone, which allowed them 2 cruffins each.  Seems the cruffins arrive at 9am and sells until they run out.  

As you go in, it seems there are two businesses, one for cruffins and one for baked goods.  First you order your cruffin whilst in line and then you pay for it when you enter, pick up your cruffins and then go to the counter if you want more baked goods, pay for that again and then exit.  Otherwise, if its just cruffins you want, then there is no need to visit the counter for more baked good.

I enjoyed the cruffins.  I only wished they had more than one choice, because chocolate was not really my first choice. So I hope they will consider making more than one choice in the future.  Overall, I enjoyed it.  It had a nice sugary crispy outside.  Will most likely return to try more of their baked goods and hopefully serve cruffins other than chocolate.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I love this place! I think they are one of the best bakeries in SF. 

Get here around 8:30am for the Cruffins! They start serving them at 9am. The only thing I don't like is that they only have one flavor at a time and it can be difficult to figure out what flavor they will have. So you could potentially wait in line for a flavor you don't like or are allergic to.

Every single pastry I've had here is superb! The cruffins, donuts, crossiants, you name it... all good!
author: E C.

description: This place did not disappoint and met all my expectations ! Cruffin!!! That's all I have to say. Stood in line for 40 minutes just to try this amazing dessert per yelp users. The flavor of the day was cannoli filling in the middle and it made my heart melt. This place is a have to if your going to San Fran.
author: Jassmynn R.

description:
Cute place for pastries and coffee! Definitely one of those must-trys if you're into the Instagram-famous cafes.

In my honest opinion, the cruffin is overhyped. It's just a croissant shaped like a muffin and stuffed with orange filling that lacks flavor. The line for this spot can be very long in the mornings, and it's a very tiny space so it's difficult to enjoy your coffee and treat due to no seating. 

Just keep in mind that if you're coming here for the Instagram, you're literally coming here for the Instagram. Looking for a great pastry and coffee? Might not be the place.
author: Hanna J.

description:
Jumped in line to try this epic bakery. We got the cruffins and the flavor of the day, which is a revolving thing, was strawberry milk shake... ow so worth the wait. The outside is supper flaky and sugary so don't eat it in your vehicle or you will be covered in sugar and crumbs as well will your automobile. I warned you!

 We also had the chocolate dipped crosiant, lemon cheesecake doughnut, and the cheese, mushroom pastry. All great choices if your on the fence of what to get.
author: Moses H.

description:
Always a treat, the cruffin is amazing. They make sure to have a delicious and consistent flavor. 
I'm never disappointed with my purchase. 
I look forward to stopping in soon.
author: Tom R.

description:
I had heard that this place is "the new bakery god of San Francisco" and I would say, among all the bakeries we checked out, this was probably the best after Tartine. People compare the two a lot and while Tartine--which is probably the best bakery in America--is better, the comparison itself is unfair since this place is doing its own completely badass and strange thing.

Case in point: The California. Honestly, this is one of the best pastries I have ever had in my life and probably the very best savory pastry I have had period. It is like a smoked salmon sushi roll inside of buttery croissant topped with sesame seeds. It was just exceptional, and daring, and really satisfying.

The cruffin was solid, but I definitely preferred the donuts and croissant-type items. Really good bread pudding, amazing chocolate croissants, siiiiiick white chocolate raspberry cream filled donut. I agree this place is pretty heavy on the hipster/instagram-ready feel, but I wouldn't let that deter you. It is good, one of SF's extremely solid new bakeries and, besides, if you don't like anything at least they serve Intelligentsia coffee.
author: Paul A.

description: One thing that's a must...the CRUFFIN!?! We got really lucky that we arrived around 11 AM on a Saturday thinking that they probably all sold out. But they had a whole tray filled and we must have caught them on a slower weekend morning. Either way I was ecstatic! We also had the green tea croissant and the churro croissant. I think hands down the cruffin was my favorite and definitely something I would come back for! The cruffin was filled with chocolate goodness that was the right amount of sweet and richness. The outside was the many layers of croissant flakiness and crispy parts of the dough was just delicious. The green tea croissant looked too beautiful to eat, but I found the green tea part to not be as strong and I wished I had a little more of that flavor come out. The churro croissant was a nice touch and it did remind me of churros. But, it was filled with dulce de leche filling and it was a nice addition. This tiny shop on the street is definitely worth checking out and this is the place to go in San Francisco to get baked!
author: Christine N.

description:
I drove a little over an hour just to try out this place. And I have to say it was worth it! Spent around $50 cause I wanted to try everything, lol. Everything I got was delicious! I came here early enough to get a spot in line for the famous cruffins. Definitely delicious! I wasn't a big fan of the flavor that day, raspberry and lychee, but it was still good! 
Tip: make sure you read the sign on the door and know which line you're in because there's two different lines for cruffins and other goods.
author: Trinh N.

description: My bf and I love to come here every Sunday morning it's our ritual. We like to come right before 9am when the cruffins come out . I haven't liked any of the flavors so far :( but I'm obsessed with the doughnuts :) They usually have a chocolate filled and some type of fruit filled . We are big fans of the churro and chocolate dipped Croissant. I love the atmosphere it's always so hip and happy .
author: Monica M.

description:
This place is pure love.  If Yelp offered six stars I would only give it five because if the place was bigger I would have the option of eating more pastries.  There is nothing there I am not in love with.  

One thing I wish they did differently...Cruffins before 9am.  If I had a desk job in the city, I would never be able to get a Cruffin.  That 9am rule makes the Cruffin an elite pastry only for medical device sales people, realtors, tourists, financial wholesalers, and others who aren't working or in general don't work very hard. (I was attending a conference that started at 10am so I was not working very hard until 10am - then I was working very hard).  I bet people with high Cruffin consumption at Mr H's also have very nice cuticles and no callouses.  #CruffinsBefore9 :)
author: Sam A.

description: I got came here on a Sunday morning around 8:45 AM hoping to try the cruffin! There was a line out the door already. However, it moves fast. So fast in fact that by the time I got to the counter it was 8:56 and they weren't selling cruffins yet! I didn't want to turn back and wait in line again so I got a Churro Croissant, Matcha Croissant, and the donut of the day which was salted caramel. THE CHURRO CROISSANT WAS DELICIOUS! The donut was good, but not the most amazing donut I've ever had. Was too full to eat the other croissant so I gave it to my friend who liked it. Overall. Great, small place. Definitely time it out perfectly or be prepared to wait in line. Highly recommend!
author: Savannah J.

description: Stopped in for a quick blueberry filled sugar donut. It was good, but I wished I could have tried one of the famous cronuts. Definitely a reason to come back.
author: Alyssa B.

description:
This is a very tiny place, the cruffins are good but it's not wow like I thought. You just have to be careful when you walk in this neighborhood. Some guy told us to be careful because we were downtown. Honestly I don't recommand you this place, the experience doesn't worth it.  

On comprend pourquoi cette pâtisserie est populaire, mais elle est vraiment petite. Faites attention lorsque vous marcher dans le quartier, nous nous sommes fait dire par un résident que c'était une place qui n'était pas un quartier très safe. J'ajoute qu'il était seulement 10h30 du matin.. Essayer cette place durant la semaine, car la fin de semaine, il y a énormément de monde qui font la file.
author: Catherine L.

description:
Today is my birthday. What did I want? 

To watch the sun rise with my family while sipping coffee and eating a cruffin by a large body of water in my hometown, the city of my birth, San Francisco.

I was willing to stand in line for this birthday wish. I know - try not to black out. 

My family and I rolled up, parked right in front, and fell in line at 7:05 AM. There was a line. Said line moved quickly. 

Once inside the bright clean bakery with music bumping made me feel less sleepy. My daughters took advantage of the "aesthetic af" selfie staging area with neon that screams "I got baked in San Francisco" (their slogan) 

I pretty much decided every single baked good behind that glass was to be mine. It's my birthday! 

I pointed at everything I wanted, ordered coffee, and picked up some pins to remember this day. 

We raced to the Pier to watch the sun rise. My daughters and son in law shared their favorite story about me while we ate. It was so sweet. 

We enjoyed: 
strawberry vanilla donut
gingerbread donut
strawberry jalapeño croissant
churro croissant
sea salt chocolate chunk cookies
chocolate monkey bread 
chickpea curry croissant (the only dud for us)
bacon onion and cheese croissant 
apple rum croissant 
persimmon croissant 

Everything was delicious and the technical merit behind each individual pastry really shines. 

Imagine focusing your passion for the culinary arts on one thing: every variant of the initially tricky but so well worth it croissant dough. That is what this bakery is to me. Hyper focused perfection. 

If you've never made croissants at home,  I invite you to. In this, you will have full working knowledge of what you are eating. No really, pick an entire day to bang out 24 croissants. You'll never forget it. 

I applaud the bakers mastery. The business itself is really great with friendly professionals. 

JUST TAKE MY MONEY!!!! 

Wait!! I came for cruffins but saw none behind the glass and now I wonder if I was supposed to ask for it? Wow ok. That's a fail for me. Back to my review. 

PS - my receipt says "Boycott Yelp" but well, so here I am, a seasoned Elite Yelper giving you my high praise. I hope that mess gets worked out. 

I love Yelp and I love Mr Holmes Bakeshop. I hate it when mommy and daddy fight! 

Thank you to everyone on deck today for your part in making my 45th Birthday morning with my family a memorable one.

Take a bow, 5 stars for perfection!
author: Jennifer C P.

description:
Came here again after trying a new brunch place in the area. Since I already tried the cruffins I came back here to try their Intelligista coffee + try new pastries. As usual, the lines were out the door, but service is friendly as always. 

- Coffee- for $2.5 a cup it pairs great with the baked goods. As a medium roast it's pretty light and not as strong so if you're craving coffee to wake you up I'd recommend going somewhere else. 

- Chocolate earl grey donuts- yummm. The filling is a great mix between the savory chocolate flavor and light tea flavor of the earl grey. Definitely one of the lighter donut flavors I've had and it's a new fave. 

- Cornflake/toffee cookie - GET THIS. Anything toffee is usually not a letdown for me and this was another case. The stickiness of the toffee mixed in with the crunchy corn flakes and chewy cookie dough was heaven in my mouth. 

- Chocolate/sea salt cookie - classic. Can't really go wrong with this one. They have tons of chocolate chunks and don't skimp out on the sea salt.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
It's surely tasty but what's up with the lines around the corner and all the hype?!

This stuff will cost you arm and the leg and in certain instances mewborn ;)

Yummy cronuts tho.. ;-)
author: Andy M.

description: Took a $19 Lyft ride over to take pictures to represent Mr. Holmes down in LA. Upon arrival the sign read "all sold out" and doors were closed and locked. It's 2p and hours of operation are until 3:30. I'm not upset that you guys are sold out... that's awesome and honestly saves me from the intake of unnecessary carbs, however a coffee... the picture.. a high five..? Nothing. Over a phone call I told the girl working I would slip my phone through the crack of the door so she could take the picture and still no. Geez. Right behind me there were 3 more groups trying to step foot in just to take a picture as well. It's disappointing. 1 star for the lack of hospitality.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Don't make my mistake, cruffins come out at 9am so waiting in line at 6:50am right before opening is pointless

That aside

My favorite pastry out of the six I got was the churro croissant. It had a lovely creamy center topped with a cinnamon sugar dust that complimented the pastry 

Donut was disappointing, texture was soft and did not care for the greasy aftertaste + filling was lacking and not adequately spread out

Savory tart (too salty) and sweet tart was ok but nothing special stood out

The bear claw was a surprise twist with the jalapeno and strawberry cream filling which made me want to go back for more

As for the plain croissant, is it good, yup but is it the best in SF? Nope...I rather have Neighbors bakehouse or Arsicault Bakery 

Overall Thoughts

The cruffin still eludes me but after having a taste of their other goods, the urgency to try again has waned
author: Eddie W.

description: Amazing pastries! Worth the small line and definitely try out the savory treats too! The cruffin lives up to the hype and the lavender vanilla doughnuts were a delicious surprise (not overly floral!).
author: Shruti D.

description: It was my first time going to this place and there was a short line! Their pastries aren't too sweet which is a plus for me, and the workers were so friendly. Although the space is a little cramped, the food was worth it! The matcha croissant was the best but the horchata cruffin was also really good!
author: Alison G.

description:
Great early morning pit stop for small hearty savories! 

I have been here once for pleasure and two other times to order about 40 various pastries for my office for a breakfast event. No matter the cause, it is an amazing, delicious, and unique place to go to! 

When ordering for my office, I always give them a call the morning of about an hour before going in to make sure they would have enough (which they always do) and to just give them a heads up I'll be coming in for the large order. Whomever is the one to answer the phone, they (usually a girl) are always nice and grateful for me to come in.

When I have gone for the order of 40 pastries, Natalia has always been the one to help. Her customer service is exceptional and stated today that she is glad I come in to order from Mr. Holmes. The two times I have gone, there were different pastries offered, which is always a plus because it gives me and my office a variety of tasty treats in the morning. Natalia is always willing to answer any questions and make sure that my selection is just right (with taste, quality, and quantity.) 

In general, I have not ever had to wait in a line, if anything 2 people the most, but I have heard that the regular line can be long so be aware. For their Cruffins, although I have never had one, be sure to get in line early before 8:45am. Supposedly, these are outstanding and one of a kind, but these can only be bought in the store and in person if you're in line by 9am. 

Can't wait to have more of these again!!
author: Michael T.

description:
Meeee
aaaand
Mr!
Mr. Hoooolmes
Mr. Holmes Mr. Holmes Mr. Holmes
We got a thiiiing going' on....

And it's terrible because these frikin cruffins are 5 dollars and I had to line up an hour before 9 am just to get em... Theres a special flavor every day and Each person is only allowed 2 cruffins and they usually run out within the hour. But that's SF for ya! 

Even if they run out of cruffins, their fruit filled donuts and savory baked goods (Parmesan crusted ham croissant is always a keeper) are great options! If you get 6, you can put your goods in an awesome box! Pair their goods with their intelligentsia coffee and beautiful instagram opportunities - Mr. Holmes is the way to go!!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
Finally checked this place out. Love the pastries. 

Friendly reminder: go early because the pastries will be gone fast.
author: Annie L.

description:
Matcha love for Mr Holmes! I had to pick up a treat on my last morning in SF, since I was staying just around the corner.

Green tea flavored desserts aren't usually my first pick in a lineup of goodies, but I was feeling adventurous today and decided to stray from my usual preferences.

BOY, was I pleased!! Maybe it was because I arrived early that my croissant was so fresh and crispy? Either way...

The only reason why I didn't give this place 5 stars is because of the disappointing lemon chocolate banana bread, which failed my taste bud/texture test. I guess I'm not a fan of cocoa nibs and lemon rinds in my banana bread.

4.5 stars- stick to the croissants for starters!
author: Aimee A.

description:
Donuts aren't worth it. Below 3 stars. It's not bad.. but in the end, a basic donut will do.

And if you're not into sweets: no, they won't be for you. My bestie doesn't love overly sweet things and was told by a staff member to avoid the donuts. She tried both of mines and said she could've done the Orange Pilsner which wasn't very sweet for her. I thought the opposite (I'm sensitive to citrus fruits, I'm an anomaly.. I'm also allergic) so I didn't like the Orange Pilsner Curd very much. I found it unbearable sweet, just the scent was strong. 

The chef's choice donut was strawberry lemongrass which I actually liked. Which my friend found too sweet.. and I don't even like strawberry that much. I ate it in one go.
author: Lilian L.

description:
WOW!!! I like be this place! I have been living in SF since August and this was my first time at Mr.Holmes! I had seen it all over Snapchat and instagram so I knew I had to make the trip! I went on a Saturday morning around 930, I would definitely recommend going early!!! When I got there the line was pretty long, I ended up waiting just under 30 min and they still had a good selection left of baked goods! 

I chose the half dipped matcha croissant, one cinnamon almond cruffin (which is a combo of a muffin and a croissant), and a cherry almond donut.   The matcha croissant was my favorite! It was a little sweet but paired perfect with a black coffee! I will definitely return! Their coffee is so so good as well! I payed a little extra to get the cute box that makes the cutest insta! It's the perfect place to take visitors for a true SF experience!
author: Maddy H.

description: How can you NOT come to Mr Holmes!? I've seen lines out the door that never seem to get shorter but we were lucky enough to come on a Monday with a very short wait. Their baked goods are delicious and made fresh and you can tell by the taste! Not to mention the 'I got baked' fluorescent sign that has become synonymous with the bakery. You have to come here just to say you went!
author: Akiko S.

description:
Go on a weekday and there won't be a line. I went on a thursday at like 10am and they still had a bunch of cruffins left! I heard you have to start lining up at 8am on a weekend, fuck that. Unless you have no other options then okay. 

They rotate flavors every day. You can check the flavors for the week on their instagram @mrholmesbakehouse 

The cruffins, EAT THESE FRESH! I think whether you like it or not is highly dependent on the flavor. I've tried the hot chocolate one and the blood orange coconut one, both are really good. I think the cruffin themselves taste more like a croissant than a muffin, I can't really taste any muffin elements in there except for the fact that it's shaped like a muffin. So essentially, you're eating a croissant with fillings. But it's still a high quality croissant. And their fillings are soo sooooo goood!

I've also tried their donuts, I'm personally not a fan of donuts in general but I thought their donuts was pretty unique, the flavors also rotate as well and these doesn't really sell out!
author: Yen P.

description: Little hole in the wall bakery with iconic neon "I got baked in San Francisco" sign...we walked there and almost missed it...we arrived after breakfast/brunch around 11am so most everything was gone, if u want their good stuff arrive before 10am! It was really a cool spot and had a chocolate chip cookie which was great...not much sitting and looks to be more of a touristy spot as well as delivery, def recommend checking it out tho and get ur selfie with the sign!
author: Clinton R.

description:
You might walk right by... if your nose is broken. You can smell the buttery flaky goodness walking down the street. Matcha croissants and creme brulee Danish, you'll be happy whatever you decide. 
Pick up a kitschy pin too.
author: Nicole L.

description:
It's been a long time coming but after keeping tabs on the daily cruffin and donut flavors, and having a day off work, we made the early morning trek to stand in the famous cruffin line.

We arrived early enough to grab some other pastries before getting in line, and boy did the line grow quickly. Luckily, we were toward the front and once 9AM strikes the line steadily moved.

Not sure if I'd made it back for a while, I definitely got caught up in over-ordering..

Chocolate Passion Fruit Cruffin ($4.50): worth the wait, lived up to the hype. MUST eat within a few hours of ordering. I ate half in the morning and half in the evening; the texture of the pastry was dry later in the day. Recommend checking their Instagram account for weekly updates on cruffin and special donut flavors. 

Hot Toddy Donut ($3.50): was described as a whiskey, lemon, and honey flavored filling, but all of those flavors were very faint, the whiskey in particular. good for a donut, but wished the filling was more pronounced. Again, eat the donuts within a few hours of purchase.

White Chocolate Raspberry Donut ($3.50): good raspberry flavor.

Sea Salt Chocolate Chip Cookie ($3): great chocolate chip cookie, and massive. It's crumbly on the outside and chewy on the inside. Someone likened it to Jacques Torres' cookie in NYC, which I would agree to an extent, but I think this is better and thicker.

Churro Croissant ($4): filled with a vanilla bean + some other flavor pastry cream and dusted with cinnamon on sugar on the outside. good, but wouldn't order again.

Monkey Bread ($4.50): incredibly sweet, and smaller than I imagined, but that's good in this case. I didn't eat it fresh, but it was good in small doses.

Some other notes:
- There are two lines: one for cruffins (they come out at 9AM every morning, limit two per person) along the building to the right of the door if facing the store, and one for the other non-cruffin pastries that goes straight out the door. If you're in the cruffin line, you may still order the other pastries when your turn is up.
- If you want a box for your pastries, you must purchase a minimum of six goodies (can include your later cruffin purchase) or buy for ~$1.50.
- They post one daily donut flavor on Instagram, but they also offer two other flavors. Just ask what they are when you get there, even if they look like they're all sold out. They have sheet pans of pastries they use to restock the display case until they're completely out.

Cruffin was hands down the best pastry. If you're in town or in the area, I recommend trying one at least once.
author: Lindsey C.

description:
This is not a review of their food, because when I got there -- as many reviews before me have said -- they were sold out when I got there. This review is of the experience and general policy set forth by this Bakery and Staff.

My girlfriend and I came to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse on a Monday morning (roughly 10:30AM - Which is 4 hours before closing) and were met by bad news. We are from the south bay, and were looking forward to trying some of these pastry things we see on all of those social media sites... but nope.

They were sold out, and the chick behind the counter said before I could speak as I looked down upon a baron display case "Yup, all sold out, we sell out around 9AM, you have to line-up to get one. Shoulda came earlier."
