As they have a full kitchen in plain sight and I could literally see a couple racks of ready-to-eat donut things, I said "so that cabinet full of things isn't being sold today?" Her: "Nope, those are for tomorrow."

Soooo this place was open for an hour and a half and sold their entire "inventory" or met their daily quota, so they just stop selling food? Then why stay 'open' for another 4 and a half hours? Why not make more? Why not sell a fresh donut?

The short, curt answers from the employee with the "you-shoulda-known-we-were-this-popular" air to her & the overall policy that the bakery makes one batch of food the day before for their patrons is why this place gets a 1-star.

Guess I'll never know what a Cruffin tastes like.
author: Shawn B.
Miko B.

description:
Omg, this place is amazing!

They just have a few items, and they do them very well.

Looks like items stay at a core but fillings and ingredients rotate.

Down the block watched not 1, but 2 drug deals go down lol. Would recommend parking close to the shop.
author: Joey H.

description:
Dear Mr Holmes Bakehouse,

Can I call you Mr. Holmes? 

After searching for a donut shop in San Fran, i was so excited to try your Instagram worthy baked goods. Full of hope and glee I took an Uber out of the way to experience what ya had to offer. Donut know why you had to disappoint me, Mr. Holmes. I'll agree your neon sign and gold foil boxes make for a great gram moment, however your products left much to be desired. I spent about $9.50 for watery coffee and two creamed filled donuts that replaced my hope & glee with an upset tummy.
author: Daniella C.

description:
AMAZING! I loved everything I got here! 
My sister and I came here originally for just the cruffins but we ended up getting one of everything because they all just looked so yummy!

However, the line can get really long really fast. I would recommend to start lining up way before they start selling the cruffins. One of the workers will walk down the line to give out stickers and those with the stickers can get two cruffins. This is to make sure that they had enough for the people in line and We got lucky because we couldn't sleep so we decided to go an hour before it opened and we ended up being the last two people getting the stickers to get cruffins. 

Like I said earlier, we ended up getting one of everything and I am so glad we did. (We ended up with $56 worth of pastries haha...)They were all so delicious. Of course my favorite is still the cruffins. What can beat out the Nutella cream inside though! My other favorite is the California Croissant. It has salmon, avocado, and seaweed inside. There were some I didn't try because I ended up giving them away to friends. Those were the Amelie Aaman, Ube puff, and honey apple toast. 

Oh yeah, the cruffin flavor changes daily, so what you will get is random. If I had the chance to stay in SF again, will definitely come again!
author: Helen Z.

description:
**Get there by 10 to get the cruffins**

Finally tried their famous cruffins and croissants!!!! Let's talk about the cruffins first, the daily flavor is chocolate passion fruit fillings. The croissant shell is very buttery and flanky, with the tartness from the passion fruit jam made a well balanced taste. Nothing much I can complain about.
author: Natasha L.

description:
More a 4.5 than a 4, but the long lines and the fact that pastries run out quickly throughout the day takes away from a full 5. Go there early in the morning if you want a full selection, and go before opening if you want a legendary cruffin. 

You have to order 6 pastries in order to get the cute box. My friend and I got the churro croissant, California croissant, blackberry bostock, caramel popcorn donut; pistachio and white chocolate donut, and strawberry and elderflower donut. 

The churro croissant was super flaky on the outside and soft on the inside, and the cinnamon sugar and churro cream inside were a perfect light sweetness. 

The blackberry bostock was amazing - like cheesecake, fruit tart, and pastry rolled into one. 

The donuts were good as well, but not as light and fluffy as expected. I also wish there were a little more cream. 

Overall definitely worth stopping at in San Francisco - if not just for the super cute pic by the "I got baked in San Francisco" sign.
author: Hali M.

description:
Oh Mr. Holmes, you offer such tempting treats that I want to try them all. I'm not much for sweets, but Mr. Holmes totally gets me with that artichoke pastry. I love a savory pastry and this is one of my favorite items here. 

I have not tried the "cruffin" because I don't like scheduling my day around waiting in line and possibly not even get one. My sweet coworker has frequented several times and either arrived too early or too late. I'm not one of those people who have to have it because others do, so maybe someday if the stars align without a line, I'll try it.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Delicious! Their cruffins ARE indeed with the wait (and I'm not the kind of person to wait in lines). I've come here a few times to pick up an assortment of office pastries. The regular crossings and cookies are nothing to rave about - get something different while you're here and you'll enjoy. (The line blows - 30m wait). 

I could see myself going back and waiting in line for a special treat for my colleagues or guests in town.
author: Pam L.

description:
There will be a line, regardless of what day of the week it is or the weather. Come early and be prepared to wait if you want to check out their pastries. Getting there in the morning does not guarantee you anything. They can and will sell out.

With that being said, if you make it through the line and into the store, you'll see what the hype is about. Their tiled floor, infamous "I got baked in San Francisco" sign and of course their display case of delicious pastries will catch your attention.

Not only do their pastries look good, they also have aesthetically appealing boxes. You'll have to buy 6 or more pastries for the box, or you can ask to purchase one... The bags for single pastries are just as cute though.

I, unfortunately, missed out on their cruffins. I did get to enjoy a doughnut though. They were fluffy and soft. The filling was the perfect amount and also delicious. 

Tiny store, long lines, limited pastries, but if you have time to wait and enjoy pastries, you'll want to check Mr Holmes Bakehouse out.
author: Vivian T.

description:
Mr. Holmes cruffins are in a word, delectable!  However even though I'm not really a donut person, their donuts take the cake!!!

This place has been added to my must take friends and visitors to when we need a  happy boost!
author: Frank S.

description: If you'd like to get more than a photo of their Instagram-famous neon sign, (ie. some actual PASTRIES) I'd recommend getting there before 9 am. This is where we unfortunately made our mistake in taking our time to get to the City from Napa. It's a popular place and their items go fast. We were lucky enough to grab the last peach cream filled pastry...it was awesome! Hopefully we can return and have better luck next time.
author: Greta H.

description:
Wanted to see what the hype was all about. 

The system of having two lines for the cruffins seems more organized, compared to the LA location. Cruffins come out at 9AM, same like the LA location. The line started forming around 7:15 AM on a rainy Saturday, opening at 8 AM. I really thought the lines would be wrapped around the block, but maybe it was just an off day because no one wants to stand in the rain. 

Service - 5/5 - Super friendly and helpful staff.

What we ordered - 
1. Le Donut with Mango Cream - 3/5 - The Mango filling was kind of an odd flavor. It tasted like mango, but not sure if that flavor goes well with doughnut and sugar.
2. Monkey Bread - 1/5 - Way too salty and sweet at the same time. Kind of made me nauseous. I would skip this because we threw it away. 
3. Churro Croissant - 5/5 - These are always so good no matter which location you go to. The cinnamon on top of the flaky Croissant make it above the rest. The filling is so smooth and slightly sweet, you can never go wrong with this option. 

Wish we could have gotten the cruffins, but we don't got time to wait until 9 AM, when Brenda's French Soul Food is calling our names. Hahah!
author: Sharon H.

description:
I had the apricot stuffed doughnut and ohhh em gee !! Bomb !! It was sooo rich and had a great balance between the apricot and the rest of the sweet filling . 
Best doughnut I've ever had . 
Definitely recommend others to try this place . 
It's nice and modern inside and the pastries are amazing!!
author: Alina P.

description:
I got the green tea croissant, banana chai danish, and their famous cruffin. The combinations of flavors are interesting and good, but I feel like this place is slightly overhyped. It might not be worth a super long wait.
Also, the inside of the store is SUPER SMALL. People were squeezing by each other and the fact that many people were waiting around to take pictures with the famous neon sign did not help. There is a small area by the window where you can stand and eat, but it will only fit about 3-4 people.
author: Sana M.

description:
I got baked in San Francisco... That phrase "wake and bake..." I've accomplished that by coming to Mr. Holmes. Thanks to Mr. Holmes for satisfying my munchies!

The first morning that I was in SF, I stopped by Mr. Holmes. I managed to get the cruffins that I have been longing to try! We got there at around 9:40am in line for about 20 minutes. I was expecting a longer wait. The day I went, they had chestnut cream filling, perfect for the holidays! I also tried their savory and sweet danishes. You get a box if you order half a dozen of pastries. I thought all of the pastries were delicious. The cruffin isn't too sweet and it is very delicious. I can understand how this is a successful creation! When I took a first bite, I was glad I waited in that line. The other pastries are delicious as well. They aren't too oily or flaky as some croissants could be. 

The one thing I wish could improve is that I thought the servers were not that helpful. They did not give any recommendations or suggestions. They kind of just looked at us and waited for us to place the order, and we felt a little rushed. They also grabbed a box and assumed that we were going to get a bunch of pastries. Maybe I look like someone that could devour all of those pastries behind the counter.

I wish they have Mr. Holmes in Boston too!
author: Mary T.

description:
Being in the Bay Area for college, coming to Mr. Holmes is always a treat.  The variety and concoctions that are created here are some of the tastiest pastries I've ever eaten, rivaling that of only my hometown's staple, Porto's Bakery. 

My partner and I have made the trek to SF for the baked goods on numerous occasions, specifically to try to nab one of their famous Cruffins, yet falling short almost every time. Luckily this forced us to try all their delectable items. For me, the most notable items on their menu has to be their flaky, croissant inspired goods. By far, the flakiness of their savory rolls (filled with assortment of toppings like bacon, cheese, gorgonzola cheese, mushrooms, etc.) sweet croissants, and cruffins (croissant muffins filled with different creams that change every day) is unmatched. It literally is perfection in every bite. 

The only problem I have with this place is that it is NOT BIG ENOUGH and RUNS OUT SO FAST. You literally have to get here within a half hour of 9am when they come out with Cruffins to get these and probably by noon to get anything else. That's how good this place is. Y'all need to come here and try it.
author: Dylan B.

description:
Came on a Saturday before 10 am and there were some cruffins left thankfully!  They did not have donuts since their fryer was broken so that was a bummer since we traveled all the way to SF just to try this place.  Line was long but moved fairly quickly.  The workers were nice but I felt a little rushed when it came to ordering.  Since it was my first time here, I wanted to ask more about the products they had on hand since the donuts were not available.  The girls looked a bit annoyed when I asked for info on the baked goodies so I ended up just choosing whatever I saw first.  I got 4 cruffins, 1 matcha croissant and 1 cookie which came to $25 even.  I would come back to try the donuts and pick up more cruffins.  Pricey but definitely worth trying out!  

Food: 4/5
Service: 3/5
author: Sabrina T.

description: This place has some of the best pastries I have ever had. Try literally anything and it will be amazing. There's always a long line, but it's worth the wait and moves fast. If I want to grab a croissant here in the morning, I make it a point to leave the house early.
author: Madeleine M.

description:
I'm chomping on my fourth donut as I write this review. Blueberry, to be more specific.  That makes 3 donuts in one day and the fourth for breakfast. They're that good. 

My drive from Sacramento took 2.5 hours and entailed some sing along songs to Boys 2 Men, Mariah Carey and a lot of traffic. A sudden need to pee occurred right before I hit the toll for Bay Bridge, just perfect. I called to ask if they had a bathroom and thank the lord they did. 

I consider myself a fairly lucky person, I found close parking and the meter still had plenty of time on it. It was as if the person before me knew I was borderline an explosive bladder. I ran in, did my thing, and happily chose out my pastries. The only unlucky part was that they ran out of cruffins. I was told to come before 10am if I wanted cruffins. Oh well, I'll just have to come back next time. Oh, and also, their famous sign was broken. I still striked a photo with it though!

I got 2 of each donut, chocolate pistachio, blueberry and lemon and 2 California Croissants. The California Croissant was the first one I chowed down because I hadn't had lunch yet. It has seaweed, salmon, ginger and a hint of wasabi!! Definitely something I've never had before. Not bad. The donuts were the winner though. Every flavor was a hit. They've got their proportions down, too. Not too much filling and not too sweet. If their donuts are this good but they're known for their cruffins, I can't wait to finally try one! Will definitely be back, hopefully sooner than later!
author: Yvonne N.

description:
TIP: if you want to try their cruffins, they aren't available until 9am. If you want everything else without the line, try to come before then. 

You can buy individually in little bags or if you want the unique & oversized box for pics, you can fit up to 6 in there! Try their matcha croissant, it's sooooo good!
author: Sarah S.

description: Really beautiful baked goods! Nice simple storefront. Only complaint would be the prices of croissants and such. I mean this stuff is only $1 in France, why is it $4 here?
author: Rob R.

description:
Just as fantastic as all the reviews! We showed up right when they opened so we were first in line. Everything looked so delicious and the items we picked did not disappoint. 

Two things: 1. We were visiting for a few days and stayed nearby. There is usually a line so just be prepared to wait. 2. If you get there early like we did, just know that the girl at the counter told us the Cruffins are not available until 9ish.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
My friend and I decided to check out Mr Holmes for our weekly brunch dates. We went on a weekday morning (9:30ish), so the line wasn't bad at all..probably less than 5 minutes? And we were able to find a parking spot right in front of the bakery. 

We were overwhelmed by all the goods, and planned on splitting a few. Of course, Mr. Holmes, being well known for their famous cruffin, was def on our to-eat list. Their menu on the website is not updated, so was unfortunately misled by the flavor. I thought they were making Chocolate Rye cream, but since it wasn't updated, it was actually Thai Tea flavor. Nonetheless, we still wanted to try the cruffin and ordered that along with the bread pudding and a savory root vegetable danish. The root vegetable danish was okay..nothing exceptional about and would have been nice if it was warmed. My favorite was actually the bread pudding, which had charred lemon and cocoa nib in it. I honestly wasn't super impressed by the cruffin. The croissant portion was def a nice flakiness, but I wasn't the biggest fan of the thai tea flavor. And maybe enjoying the top of a muffin more than the bottom of the muffin made me not enjoy the cruffin as much. In my opinion, the cronut sounds like a tastier option. But the plus side was that there was plenty of thai tea cream in the cruffin. 

A plus is that they have intelligentsia coffee, which made the perfect combo with the pastries. Mr. Holmes is a nice one time experience, but don't think I would go back..esp not if there was an extensive wait.
author: Jackie C.

description: Ok yes I went here because I wanted to see what the hype was all about. And I wanted a picture of that neon sign. So I walked over to the bakery early on a weekday and had the chance to order the highly desired cruffin. Unfortunately, I was not very impressed by this pastry. When you think about it, the cruffin is kind of a weird hybrid that probably shouldn't exist, like the liger or the zonkey. Let's just keep croissants as croissants and muffins as muffins. Amen.
author: Melody L.

description: The workers were a little rude and the matcha croissant gave me a stomachache. Wasn't matcha flavored AT ALL it was just green colored icing. The spinach artichoke pastry was fine. There isn't much seating either.
author: Catherine R.

description: There is only one thing you need to know about Mr. Holmes' Bakehouse. GET. HERE. EARLY. We stopped by just because we were in the area at around 1pm and all they had left, literally, were 8 donuts. We grabbed one because we were there, and the nectarine jam it was filled with was delicious. Soon after we bought our donut a line formed behind us - most of those people were going to walk away with nothing. They said if we wanted to come by and have our pick of pastries, we needed to line up BEFORE opening. Not sure if I'll go through the effort to do that one day, but those matcha croissants do look amazing.
author: Kim B.

description: Loved everything. Organized and easy to order. Wish there was more than one cruffin flavor.
author: Crystal T.

description:
Delicious buttery goodness.  Like walking into a den of caloric sin.  
We were in & out of this place in a matter of about 5 minutes.  
My favorite was the classic croissant, as the filling in my strawberry croissant made it kind of soggy.  Husband tried the donut and wasn't a big fan.  They didn't have cruffins when we went but that's okay.  

Nothing much offered in terms of beverages (just hot coffee).  It was a hot day so we went down the street for an iced coffee :) 

There is also not much of a seating area.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
You have to get there at 8am and wait in line if you don't want to wait tooooo long! My group went right at 8:10 and waited about 15 minutes or so.

If you get six or more pastries, you get a box! (Haha)

I loved the Matcha croissant and the cruffins!!! And the savory danish with the bacon on top- we definitely finished our pastries with just a foot out the door...
author: Juliana P.

description:
I know that the Cruffin craze is what gets people in, but I wouldn't bother with that. They are good but nothing compares to the Sea Salt Chocolate Chip Cookie. 

The only reason to go to this place is that they have the BEST chocolate chip cookies in the entire world. I don't live in San Francisco but I visit a few times per year and I will not leave without getting a dozen of these cookies. I have people back home EXPECTING these cookies when I return.

As a previous bakery owner who was sure that our chocolate chip cookies were the best, I can honestly take the loss and hand that title to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse.

We aren't really sure HOW they do it...but everything comes together so insanely perfect. The base cookie is perfection. The layer of chocolate throughout the middle. The light sea salt on top. I have to stop talking.

If you are near this place and don't get one, you're just not living your best life.
author: Samantha K.

description: Love this place! Has such fun, creative and delicious pastries  best bake house is SF for sure
author: Fabianna J.

description:
Mr. Holmes is always a fun first stop when I make a trip into the city. And I say *first* stop because if you wait too long, you run risk of them selling out of your favorite treats! Mr. Holmes is very popular on social media for their elusive cruffins (the lovechild between a croissant and a muffin). Cruffins are $4.50 and there is a limit of 2 per customer. They come out at 9 am, and may sell out quickly depending on the day. Cruffins and donuts rotate flavors throughout the week. All the other pastries rotate flavors throughout the quarter (all flavor updates can be found on their instagram). My first trip to Mr. Holmes was a bit of a bust, as I came in past 12 on a weekend. The bakery closes at 2:30 every day, so there was a shortage of many pastries already. The cruffins were long gone, but I was able to pick up a donut and a savory danish. Today (a Thursday), I made it in just before 11 and was greeted with a pretty well stocked display case. I was able to get one cruffin and one of each of the day's donut flavors. My boyfriend got a savory danish. Everything I've gotten from Mr. Holmes has been delicious. The pastries are flaky, the creative fillings always work, and the pics are always instagram worthy. That being said, there is definitely a hype to the bakery that some people may not think is deserved. There are plenty of other great bakeries in SF if you don't find yourself in the Mr. Holmes neighborhood. 

The area isn't the nicest of SF neighborhoods. Those coming from outside of the city might not feel comfortable wandering through the streets to find the little bakery. Street parking runs about $2.25/hour in this area, so I would park in front of a nearby busy store and put in enough for about 30 minutes. It's plenty of time to walk up the street to grab your goodies (unless you're coming during a weekend rush hour).
author: Rachel A.

description: No wonder it's the #1 recommendation on YouTube.  No lines at all on a Monday morning at 10am.  Everything we ordered was excellent!  Lemonade Cruffin, double baked chocolate croissant, yummy!
author: Thanh H.

description: Straight to the point why it's not 5 stars, is because my friend and I had to wake up early to get only 2 Cruffins (2 limit rule). But besides that, the cruffin was definitely worth it as it combines the sturdiness of a muffin and the melting effect of a croissant together. The workers were very helpful when ordering and giving recommendations on what to get. I also got a pastrami croissant because I've never heard of that combination, which to my surprise was a new level a croissant tasting in my opinion. For sure will be back again to try more things.
author: Robert V.

description: Well well well isn't this a place of baked sins... let your imagination take you on an adventure of flavors and mixed desserts. The line can be a bit ridiculous BUT if you time it right (like we did) it'll be a short wait for your taste of the forbidden fruit! Convenient location to grab a snack on the go.
author: Michelle F.

description:
I had been meaning to try Mr. Holmes Bakehouse for a while now after hearing about their famous cruffins.  However, the long lines deterred me, and I wasn't sure if I would have the patience to wait for delectable carb goodness.  On a recent weekend, I decided to brave the queue and see what all the fuss was about.

I got there around 9:30 AM on a Saturday, and given the length of the line, I was worried that I would get to the front and all the cruffins would be sold out.  Luckily, I was able to get my hands on one, and overall, I thought it was excellent.  The flaky croissant dough held a raspberry and pistachio cream (the flavors change regularly), and I liked how the mixture of cream flavors gave it a tart and sweet contrast.  Did it blow my mind? No, but I'm happy I can cross the cruffin off of my baked good bucket list.

I also tried their churro croissant, which came with a dulce de leche filling; while I liked it, I was expecting more of a caramel note to the filling, and the crream seemed more vanilla-like to me. 
 During a subsequent visit, I tried a raspberry hibiscus kouign-amann and a matcha dipped croissant, and while I thought both were good, I feel like I've had better kouign-amanns and croissants at other local bakeries.  While the cruffin was definitely a standout, I don't think I would wait on a long line for their other baked goods.  However, if I was in the area and the line was manageable, I'd definitely go back again.
author: Keith H.

description:
The pastries here were good, but I've had better.  I can see why people would be attracted to this place,  but our party won't be returning. 

This place was a little hard to spot from the street and the parking situation was scarce. Lots of sketchy people roaming the streets as well.

Once we got in, it was definitely nicer inside, but TINY! I can see how lines have to form outside, but luckily for us there was only ONE other person there (it was approximately 1pm at the time). Waiting was not a problem at all. The other customer was already leaving so we had the whole place to ourselves! 

Amazingly, they still had pastries and lots of options. One of the workers suggested the cruffin, which we ended up getting, along with a donut. 

Here's where Mr. Holmes failed...
Don't think you can ask for anything beyond getting your food bagged because wow, it apparently is just too much to ask for and too hard to do, even when there's not even anyone else in the shop! There were two girls up front and the one that wasn't even helping us was being incredibly rude and unwilling to show any kind of decent customer service.

Never again.
author: T H.

description: It's only good for take-out; no tables to sit down. Their pastries are great, they are visually satisfying and delicious. Everything seems too sweet and intense flavors for my taste but definitely a must try place.
author: Clara L.

description:
Simple economics strategy- keep the supply low so the demand will remain high. In addition to having the tastiest and most creative stuffed donuts and baked items ever. The demand continues to remain high. 
Well played Mr Holmes.....well played.
author: Linda H.

description: The cruffins and other baked goods are delicious but not out of this world. I would go here again but it wouldn't be the first stop on my list when I visit San Francisco. But it's still a fun place to go to and get "baked" goods.
author: Sarah R.

description: I finally got to try the cruffins! Got there around 10am on a Sunday morning and surprisingly there were only two people ahead of me. They had a blackberry wine flavor cruffin when I went and it was delicious! Flavor itself was good, and the cruffin was so fluffy inside I couldn't stop eating it. Can't wait to get them again.
author: Jeana Y.

description: Got super lucky only waited 5 minutes each line to get a lil bit of everything they had to offer this Presidents' Day weekend. Loved the matcha green tea croissant. I'll be back to get in line soon!
author: Kristin C.

description:
Food: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Atmosphere 5/5

Let me tell you, it is super rare I give any place a 5/5 all around rating -- but this place takes the cake ;) I have literally 0 things to complain about (except potentially that their sign was broken! alas). First of all, everything you eat is going to be delicious, so you have no bad options, but I have to say that my absolute favorite is the green tea matcha croissant. The cruffin flavor of the day was margarita, and it had a nice salty/tart kick to it that balanced out the sugariness of the outside. (Almost no wait at this point, got there at 8:45am for 9am cruffins, were 2nd in line.) The ladies who work the counter are patient and friendly, and make purchasing a breeze. And the shop is small but adorable, and they have some great merch. We also tried the dark chocolate and pistachio donut, and the strawberry croissant. Both delicious as well :) I highly recommend making the trek out to this SF gem.
author: Whitney G.

description:
I swear that when I first walked through the front door of Mr. Holmes, I heard a chorus of angels singing. Why, you ask? Because this place is sugary, caloric heaven on EARTH, my dear-probably non-San-Franciscan friend. Duh.

From their soft and flaky cruffins to their stellar pastries and donuts, this place serves up an SF-foodie's absolute dream. 

With the menu ever-changing and the timing of your visit important, here are some tips on properly getting cruffin-wasted in everyone's favorite pastry paradise: 

****TIP#1:**** Get there 20 minutes before 9am, NOT at 7am, to get dibs on what they're known for: THE CRUFFINS! (Cue angel choir: "Hallelujah!") They begin selling these at 9am, run out within a few hours, and limit 2-per customer. Because I went on a deserted weekday morning and gave them a big ol' smile, they let me buy 4. Tee hee. Major points to them for being friendly and adaptable business folks! Think opposite of the Soup Nazi character from Seinfeld.

****TIP#2:**** Utilize their social media accounts to plan your visit accordingly. They offer 1 flavor of cruffin daily, and list them on Instagram. If you're not into the ingredients for the day (pumpkin/lime/strawberry/hazelnut, etc), you'd be better off visiting when they have your flavor! 

Use the following link to view their flavor, accompanied by some ridiculously sassy Instagram captions: https://www.instagram.com/mrholmesbakehouse/ 

****TIP#3:**** Pick up a couple boxes for your officemates/team/angry estranged friend that you need to make amends with, and they will instantly love you, irrespective of what else is going on in your life. Trust. 

Have fun getting baked, my Holmies!!
author: Stephen D.

description: Very friendly and patient staff. Pastries were delicious. I got the chocolate croissant and would definitely get it again. My husband got the peanut butter pastry and said it was really good. Be sure to get lots of napkins if eating as it can get messy! Haha
author: Ashley W.

description: Nifty place. Super small. The orange blossom cherry croissant caught my eye, but I didn't realize there was filling. There were two separate pockets of orange blossom cream and cherry compote. I wish they'd mixed the two together so the cherry was less tart and I got both flavors at once. Pretty delicious though.
author: Nikita H.

description:
Incredible flakey pastries, adorable signs, and unique flavors make Mr Holmes a destination spot to visit in San Francisco! 

We went at around 9:00 am and surprisingly we managed to get our hands on cronuts, donuts, and the flavored croissants. We didn't know you could just buy a box for 87 cents, so if you don't want to order over 6 pastries, do that. 

The best desserts were the Cronut and the matcha croissant. The cronut was so flavorful, and the pastry was flakey and to die for. It was heaven!

The matcha croissant was also delicious; buttery, sweet, and crunchy. 

The donuts has very unusual flavoring; we had chocolate passion filling and it was a very very strong and unexpected passion flavor. Interesting experience!

The ambience is unbeatable. I love it here!
author: Jessica L.

description:
269. Never bothered to stop by and look into this place cause the long lines were such a turn off. Two years later, my friend bugged me about going and I figured waiting in line with someone was a little more tolerable. 

We lined up around 8:40am on a Friday and waited 15-20 minutes. It wasn't too bad cause my friend and I took turns peeking in to see what they had to offer. I ended up getting two cruffins and a chocolate croissant.

Cruffin flavors change daily and are a hit-or-miss. They sold old-fashioned cruffins that day (think orange whiskey). I didn't like the flavor and the center was too soggy for me. But the cruffin itself was cripsy and fluffy. I'd definitely prefer an original cruffin.

__________
My 2¢:
- They don't start selling cruffins until 9am, so don't go too early. Limit 2 per person.
- If you're looking for non-cruffin items, check if there is a line first. If there is only one line, it's probably the cruffin line. Just go in and get your stuff.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Mr Holmes Bakehouse has a special place in my heart. Thanks to my friend who introduced me to this place. The staff is super friendly/ nice people. 

Everything they have is super delicious and fresh! Every time I go there, I always get the donut and their famous cruffin. Omg! Their cruffins are out of this world!!! Each day, they have a different flavor in their cruffin's custard, and you may want to try every one of them. Writing this review is making me wanna go there and grab a cruffin :D
author: Mona E.

description: LOOOOOOVVVVVVEEEEEEEE. Everything is so fresh!!best croissants I've ever had!! Just plz plz plz plz plz, get there early af. They sell out at like 1030. I went three times before I actually got to try something! Go go go!!!
author: Dayna L.

description:
Yes, I hopped onto this cruffin craze and I don't regret it! Seriously. I am on Thanksgiving break and woke up *even earlier* than I normally would for a workday to get to this bakery around 8:30AM on a Wednesday morning. Ended up 2nd in line to get my hands on the cruffin of the day (birthday cake for their anniversary!). You can check out the week's upcoming cruffin flavors on their Instagram page.

The CRUFFIN is light and flaky, with a good mixture of sugar and cinnamon dusted on the outside. The exterior has a light crunch with a fluffy interior. For the birthday cake flavor, the inside was filled with a subtle and creamy vanilla custard that was mixed with some colorful sprinkles, and topped with a piece of  small birthday blonde brownie. I was pleasantly surprised that this dessert wasn't overly sweet or rich. I would eat again! 

I also grabbed a STRAWBERRY JALAPENO BEARCLAW and loved the combo of sweet and spicy cream cheese on the inside. I would drizzle that sauce over all my pastries!

 For something savory, I got the HAM & CHEESE CROISSANT and ate that later at home. The croissant was amazing after heating it up at 375F for a few minutes. The thyme and pepper provided a nice savory flavor throughout the croissant and the gruyere and ham melted together perfectly. For this specific croissant, I will always get it to go so I can heat it up later.

My friend liked the CHURRO CROISSANT and enjoyed the generous cinnamon and sugar on the outside. She also liked the ORANGE TANG DONUT and that it tasted like a legit french beignet with a subtle and creamy orange curd inside.

Service was very fast and all the workers were happy to explain the flavors to us. 

Overall, my inner Yelper was pretty impressed with this bakery. I would come back the next time I'm in the area, maybe before going to an event at the Asian Art Museum or the orchestra. It's worth the 16min walk from Civic BART station (not too bad, especially in morning time).
author: Bonnie Z.

description: Get there before they start selling the flavor of the day. I always buy as many as I can and bring a friend with me. A must stop on every visit I'm in the city streets before 9 am. I recommend driving or parking close...seedy area (maybe just in am?) ..but hey that's the city for u
author: Alma G.

description: Went on a Sunday at around 10am, short line outside, but was two people away from a cruffin ): decided to get the matcha croissant instead and it was delicious so it made up for the fact that I didn't get what I came for. At least I got the stereotypical pics of this trendy spot!
author: Kimmi S.

description: I went on a Friday at around 11 am and there was no line and there were plenty of cruffins left. I think there is only a 2-cruffin per person policy as I was unable to get more of them for my friends who were waiting in the hotel room. The flavor of the day was chocolate orange cream. It was good, but not amazing mainly due to the flavor. I also ended up getting the blueberry lemonade donuts, which were soooooo good! The cornflake cookie and the danish were 5-Star as well. I would definitely come back on another day to try another flavor cruffin! Go to their website to see what the flavor of the day is before planning a visit!
author: Kim X.

description:
Creme brulee croissant! Essentially a danish with a sweet caramel/ sugar glaze that is reminiscent of a creme brulee. The flavor didn't exactly remind me of a creme brulee but I don't care- it was fire. 

Best pastry I've had in some time and although they have other tasty options, all I really need from here are these pastries. Hope to get my hands on some more of these on my next visit.
author: Raymond L.

description: Amazing cheesecake bread - I forgot what it's called because I lost my mind when I ate it. Who cares? The goodies here are delectably out of this world good!
author: Londa S.

description: The cruffins are amazing. Perfectly flaky, moist but not gooey, and not overly sweet. Flavors are unique but not trying too hard. Location is tiny and adorable. Can't wait to go back.
author: Jen D.

description:
It was our last day in SF, so I was determined to get baked! Even though this bakery just opened up another location in LA during the same weekend I was here, I decided to wait in line for the one in SF since I was already in the area. The cruffins are ready at 9am, so we came just in time because there weren't that many people waiting here on a weekday. 

If you want to buy any of the other pastries that they offer, you can skip the line. Even though the donuts, cookies, and other desserts looked enticing, I wasn't in the mood for anything else LOL. I noticed some cute tile decor and neon signage that makes for a cute backdrop for photos. We snapped a few photos before getting back in line, which moved fairly quickly. 

There is only one flavor made per day for the cruffins and if they sell out, you miss out! I needed 4 caramel praline cruffins, but I didn't know that there was a limit of 2 per person. I was disappointed and must have looked really sad because the lady behind the counter was nice enough to give me the amount I wanted anyway. Yay! 

I didn't eat one until I was back home, so I had to reheat it. I thought the filling was going to be sweet, but it was sooo delicious and creamy. The muffin part was nothing like I've tasted before. I'm really glad that they created this unique hybrid and can't wait to get baked again!!
author: Dung N.

description: I walked by here one morning and was surprised to see no line, which was quite good.  I've heard about this place and wanted to try it for years.  I tried a kougn amann, which is a round crispy cake that is loaded with butter and sugar and it was excellent. I also tried a churro croissant, which was as expected - super sweet and delicious.  I did not get a chance to try the famous cruffin (not out of the oven yet).  The prices were a bit on the high side, but what do you expect for delicious hand crafted pastries such as this?  Spend a little. . .live a little.  Your stomach will thank you.
author: David Z.

description:
Important: CRUFFINS DO NOT GO ON SALE UNTIL 0900!
Stayed in SF for two nights and had this placed booked marked here on Yelp!  I may or may not have based the location of the hotel I planned to stay at according to the distance it would be from Mr. Holmes Bakehouse.  My SIL and I visited on a Thursday morning at 0810.  We walked a short 15 mins from our hotel in Union Square.  To my surprise there was no line!  Why? Oh, because the cruffins don't come out until 0900!  We had clothes to pack, a room to check out of, a train to catch and a plane to board so we were unable to wait around until the cruffins made their debut!
Picked up a couple churro croissants, two cheesecake filled donuts and one cornflake cookie.
Churro croissants:
Very good!  Soft, flakey croissants that are filled with this absolutely amazing ( I want to call it custard ) filling!  The outside is dusted with cinnamon and sugar.  
Cheesecake filled donuts:
Also, very good!  These remind me of malasadas (Leonard's from Hawai'i). Donut dough is very good, and the filling inside is even better!
Cornflake cookie:
OMG where has this cookie been all my life!  This cookie is seriously so good.  It is crunchy, yet chewy, with bits of sugar in every bite.  
Overall, I would recommend Mr. Holmes Bakehouse.  A bit pricey for baked goods but justified because you cannot find these items just anywhere.
author: Leilani R.

description: Fantastic pastries and the people are really nice. The area is a bit sketchy so don't be wondering round too much.
author: Andy H.

description:
We got in line at 8:20am. Make sure you are in the cruffin line. There are two lines, one for cruffins and one for other bakery treats. Around 8:40, the worker came out and gave everyone stickers in line to make sure you get got a cruffin. There is a 2 cruffin per person limit. The one flavor of the day was Apple pie.

The cruffins were good and I'm glad I got to try it but I wouldn't wait in line again for them. It is a one time thing. I think the donuts are better than the cruffins.

I think the cruffins are more of a croissant in a muffin shape. I don't taste much muffin.
author: Yvonne L.

description: Pretty good bakery, I ordered the Kouign Amann ($4) with raspberry inside and I'd have to say that was pretty good, a little Krispy on the outside. I also had the sake plum doughnut ($3.50), it was average for me, the filling had a sort of a bitter taste to me. It was a cute shop. They do have a restroom and a stand up bar, no seating but some old milk cartons. There is street parking.
author: Sarah S.

description:
They have the most delicious croissants I have ever tried. It is a very small store, and the line wasn't as bad as I expected (10 min wait on a Saturday Morning). 

We grabbed a matcha croissant, a chocolate cruffin, a chocolate croissant, and other pastry that I can't remember haha. 

There is no place to sit down and eat the pastries, you have to take them with you and devour them walking down the beautiful streets of San Francisco like we did!
author: Dianita C.

description:
It's so good!!!! I got here as soon as it opened to see that there was no line just to find out that the cruffins don't come out until 9. If you are there for cruffins GET THERE BEFORE 9 to line up! I bought a bunch of stuff before getting back in line for cruffins. My favorites were the donuts and the churro croissant. I usually hate donuts but their donuts are just absolutely amazing.

Luckily when I went back to line up for the cruffins the line was pretty short. They come out with stickers for everyone on line and theres a max of 2 cruffins per person. Every day they have a different flavor. I think mine was pecan honey (a couple of other ingredients) and it was pretty good. There's a lot of hype around the cruffins and they are pretty good but I think some of their regular pastries are actually better. Definitely worth the visit!

Also you have to buy 6 items to get a box.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Overrated.. Small overpriced coffee, no cronuts or cruffins and we arrive at 9:30 am. Come on get your act together if you want to be known for these then provide them people, simple business model here.
Had the German chocolate donut which had no coconut or true GC flavor to it. More like instant chocolate pudding added  to the inside. I do love me some donuts and I threw half of it away. I put it on the level with a day old donut from Safeway.

Let's be honest you all are coming for the get baked in SF sign or are tourists in the city.
author: Morgan S.

description:
Got the black sesame strawberry jelly donut - the donut was the right amount of fluffy and sugary, and the jelly was delicious, but I wasn't impressed with the black sesame. The black sesame cream didn't pair well with the rest of the jam donut, so I ate the jelly half first, then the black sesame side. 

The decor is really cute, and the paper bags that your pastries come in are really quite fancy and artsy! 

I'd be down to come back and try their other donut / cruffin flavors.
author: Inga C.

description:
YUMMY pastries!! I did the whole wait in line thing for cruffins as well - I don't understand why the shop opens at 8 am but the cruffins only come out at 9 am!! So I got there around 8 am and bought some other pastries while waiting for the cruffins. 

Honestly, I thought the other pastries (like the ube berry puff) might have even been better than the cruffin. Be aware they only have one cruffin flavor a day! I got the root beer float flavor which was not my favorite. Overall, cute adorable yummy bakery!
author: Caley Z.

description: Didn't come early enough for the cruffins, but I also didn't have to deal with any wait time. Every pastry I had at Mr. Holmes was soft and delicious, and their flavors can be so creative! I've had various donuts and croissants and I have yet to be disappointed. And the aesthetic sign is a major plus.
author: Vickie N.

description: I heard lots of great reviews about Mr Holmes, so I decided to give it a try. The lemonade and croissant are amazing... the cute decor makes it a great place to take pics
author: Sophia B.

description:
It's hard to say.. as unique as their pastries are I don't think I would wake and line up super early to get a hold of their cruffins. For those who don't know or who still want to check out the cruffin hype, I came on a Sunday morning to try out their stuff. The bakery opens at 8am and the cruffins don't come out til an hour later. They have two lines; one line for their regular baked goods and another for cruffins ONLY. If you time it right and have enough players, you can play it right.

In the regular line: You can get their pastries of the day in that particular flavor(s). They have a variety of sweet & savory goods. I tried a bite of their peanut butter & cocoa nib donut & their savory croissant of the day when I was in line. I got a box of goods for my family that included a churro croissant, strawberry filled donut, monkey bread, and strawberry jalapeno bear claw.

In the cruffin line: People seem to wait here fairly early to get a head start on the cruffin line. By the time it's moving, the line was around the block! Each person gets a sticker for two cruffins each (hack: bring a baby and they can help get two more cruffins as we saw the people in front of us had) and there's only one flavor. When I came they had a cherry cordial flavor with cocoa nib. I actually liked it! But these pastries are heavy for 4.50 a pop and I couldn't eat it in one sitting.

Overall, it's worth trying at least once. You don't have your hands on a cruffin too often and might as well indulge while you have the chance.
author: Kathleen S.

description: A fun spot to take photos and enjoy a pastry. The long line was worth it. I would suggest anything that they offer .
author: Pam W.

description: I wanted to come here so badly and a rainy sunday morning after my first ever spinning class seemed to be the appropriate time. I didn't feel one bit guilty about getting a whole box of those yummy treats. To share, of course. I wouldn't eat all of that myself (actually, I would, but don't tell anyone). They were out of the cruffins, so we got matcha croissants, a couple of donuts, the churro croissants, a cookie and a kouign amman. My favorite one was the churro croissant and the matcha one, since I recently discovered matcha for me (always late to the party). But really, everything was delicious. B Patisserie remains my favorite, but Mr Holmes is close. And again, there was hardly a line, so within a few minutes we were holding one of those beautiful boxes full of the sweetest carbs. It seems like pastries and I are meant to be.
author: Katja S.

description: It was good, but not what I expected. So many people hyped this place up that I expected it to be super different but it was just mediocre. The only thing I liked was the matcha croissant. It was pretty tasty but I got here around 12 so all the pastries were a little cold. Probably going to come earlier next time and give this place another try!
author: Tracey N.

description: I may or may not have taken a trip to San Francisco just to try this place (before the LA store opened). My verdict? It did not disappoint. The bakery itself was super small but nonetheless cute and artsy. The donuts were amazing and the cruffins were out of this world!!!!! I had to get there about and hour and a half before opening to stand in line for one. Am I crazy? Quite possibly, but words cannot accurately describe just how good my tiramisu filled cruffin was. It was worth the wait, and the money, and the trip...
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Our hotel was luckily around the corner from Mr.'s place. We cautiously turned the corner expecting a long line and sure enough!! It goes really fast. 
We tried a little of everything. All were good especially the churro croissant and the heaven filled donuts. The cronut filled with blueberries and lemon goop was also outstanding.
I would gladly wait in line again.
author: JibJib N.

description: I was given their toffee cookie by a friend-- loved it so much I walked from from Union Square to find this place! By the time I arrived (just after 1pm on a Saturday)... I was too late to see the full array of goodies. All that was left was one yummy berry cheesecake pastry, chocolate chip cookies, and matcha croissants. The berry pastry was wonderful, as with the chocolate cookie.  If you try this place, go early in the morning!
author: Helen D.

description:
Didn't get to try the famous cruffin, but picked up a deeeelicious matcha croissant and coffee early Wednesday morning. The croissant was perfectly flaky, and the coffee was the best complement to it - what a great start to my morning. 

No wait at 8:30 am on a Wed morning. Can't wait to come back to try the cruffin and other pastries!
author: Tanisha S.

description:
The first thing I needed to check off on my list during a recent Cali trip was to see what this cruffin craze was all about. You can find out what the flavor of the day is by checking on their Instagram page. As I don't have an IG account, it was a surprise to me that they had Snickers flavor that day. I was slightly disappointed that it wasn't a fruit flavor. In my opinion, the cruffin was a slightly chewier textured croissant in a muffin shape with a custardy/pudding like filling. It was good, don't get me wrong, but you will most likely not find me waiting 1.5 hrs in line for it again.  

The other pastries were delicious! I especially liked the artichoke asiago danish and a pastry that had peaches in it. I wish I could've tried the California croissant. My sister went to the other line as we waited in the cruffin line so she came back with a variety (teamwork!). All in all, I would come back for the regular pastries. It turned out to be a fun adventure and anything involving baked goods makes this girl happy ;-)
author: Hannah N.

description: This place is so amazing!! Now I understand the long line you must stand in to get in (which goes by pretty fast). An hour and a half just to try this place and we were extremely satisfied with everything we tried. My favorite was a brownie like croissant and the ham and cheese croissant had a mandarin wedge in the middle which added a very good flavor to it. I would definitely come back here to try all their other desserts!
author: Berenice O.

description: This is one of the best bakeries in San Francisco. Their croissants were soft rather than crunchy so It depends what type of taste you like. It's worth to try though.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Heard about this place from just about every one on every form of social media at some point this year, so I just had to join the hype and try it for myself. I came here multiple times just to try to get my hands on their renowned cruffins, but my first time there, I found out that, although they open at 8am, they don't bring out the cruffins until 9am. Unfortunately, I had to get back to work and could not wait till 9 - attempt #1 failed. The next 2 times, I went around lunch time to find that they were all sold out already - attempts #2 and 3 failed. Finally, I stopped by this past weekend at 9am sharp and got my hands on one. Attempt #3 - long awaited success! 

The flavor of the day was s'mores (2/5). (You can check their facebook page for their flavors that week, so you don't go on a day they have a flavor you don't want). Since I was already there, I snagged a couple other items as well. I got their strawberry elderberry croissant (4/5), matcha croissant (4/5), churro croissant (5/5), white chocolate cardamom donut (2/5), butterscotch donut (3/5), and the California croissant (5/5). Let me just say, they know how to make a damn good croissant. All the croissants were delicious, buttery, flakey, and not super sweet. My personal favorite was the churro croissant with the caramely filling in the middle. My friend couldn't stop raving about the California croissant, which was filled with flakey salmon and seaweed. For those who prefer savory over sweet, this is the perfect item for you. 

I was sorely disappointed by the cruffin and the donuts that I had heard so many good things about. The cruffin was way too dense. Croissants are supposed to be light and flakey, but because it was jammed into a muffin tin, the croissant dough didn't really get a chance to rise and just clumped all at the bottom. Their chocolate filling was good though, and the toasted marshmallow on top was a nice touch. Their donuts were also too dense for my liking and they were really dry. Both the cruffin and the donuts lacked filling. There was a thin streak through each donut and cruffin, but because of how dense they were, they both needed more. All in all though, I'll definitely be back here to try out their other savory and sweet croissant options!

Cons:
- Cruffins and donuts are dense and overrated 
- Long line so be prepared to wait 
- Tend to run out of cruffins pretty early in the day, so if that's what you're coming here for be sure to get here early
- No seating inside

Pros: 
- Croissants were darn near perfect 
- All their sweet items weren't grossly sweet like a lot of other bakeries
- Pretty reasonably priced in terms of what you get
author: Diana C.

description:
Sorry folks, I think the cruffin is overrated.  It's just an overcooked, way-too-flaky croissant shaped like a muffin and not even the moderately tasty filling redeems it.

So why does this place get a 5-star review from me?  Because of The Other Stuff.

The Other Stuff is phenomenal.  I'm talking about the filled doughnuts (holy shit are they good!).  The cookies (I'm fantasizing as we speak about the cornflake cookie and the chocolate chip).  The chocolate croissant, among the best I've ever had.

So my advice? I'm sure you want to go there and see for yourself, so just do it.  But please, PLEASE don't neglect The Other Stuff.  As long as you are there, go ahead and buy boatloads of other delicious items and share with your friends.  Because they are delicious.
author: Karen r.

description:
My first Cruffin ever and it was magical! Mr Holmes Bakehouse is definitely doing something right because I wouldn't mind coming back at 8:00 AM to endure a 30 minute wait for these amazing pastries! 

Sunday morning, I miraculously woke up at 7:30 AM after running on 3 hours of sleep. Got to Mr Holmes Bakehouse at 8:15 AM and there was already a line for the Cruffins. Luckily my friend was with me and waited patiently in the Cruffin line while I waited in the other line to purchase the other pastries. The Ham & Cheese Croissant, Salmon Roe Croissants, Cherry Almond Donuts, Sea Salt Chocolate Chip Cookies. You seriously can't go wrong with any of the pastries here! I might have over ordered but it was so worth it. There is no such thing as self control when you're here.

As for the Cruffins, the flavor of the day was White Chocolate Mango. And let me tell you, it was seriously AMAZING. I literally wanted to cry after every bite. It was pure perfection and I recommend eating it right away when its still warm. Seriously LOVE AT FIRST BITE.

I definitely would love to come back and hope that there will be a matcha green tea flavored Cruffin next time. If you're looking for a true San Francisco foodie experience, then come to Mr. Holmes!
author: MyTien P.

description: Delicious pastries definitely worth a try -- a bit pricey though.
author: Gia M.

description:
On the day that my friend and I set across to make the trek to San Francisco to get cruffins, I got to Mr. Holmes around 9:30 AM in the morning and juuuust missed out on the cruffins. Sigh.

However, I was still able to try the donuts and the croissants there and those items are what this review is based off!

Note that the donut flavors change daily so make sure to look online to find out what the flavors are for the day if you're looking for a particular one! The donuts available for the day that I went were blueberry lemonade and chocolate. The donuts were a little too sweet for my taste but overall were pretty solid. 

My favorite was definitely the California Croissant. The concept is a little bit weird but it's basically a Japanese themed croissant with baked salmon, ginger, seaweed and sesame seeds in it. It comes with a soy sauce packet for you to drizzle over the whole thing. This was really nicely done! The croissant was flaky and nicely complimented savory bits of fish baked into the croissant.
author: Nancy T.

description: Quick, no line and simple bakery place. Came here for the first time and tried their matcha croissant and cookies. The matcha croissant wasn't anything special, not the best croissant I've ever had but it was decent. It somehow lacked the crisp flakiness that I always crave with a croissant and it was just simply, a croissant dipped in matcha on one side. Their cookies however were much better and surprisingly tasteful. I should have just bought more cookies instead!
author: Alan C.

description: My daughter from San Diego told us about this bakery so we went there to check it out. Wow! What a marvelous surprise! It was wonderful!
author: Parker E.

description:
The beauty about moving to a new city is being able to stumble upon new gems while exploring. I was lured by the interior design and the beautiful white with gold fonted bakery boxes I saw coming out on gleaming faces. 

Then I realized, this was the cruffin place, yes THE CRUFFIN, a croissant shaped like a muffin, filled with orgasmic buttery goodness. There wasn't a line and I knew it was too good to be true. It was about 10:30am and when I walked in, undoubtedly the pastry trays were sparse with only the circular butter rings left behind from the cruffin's morning presence. 

My brother came to town to visit that weekend so this was the perfect motivation to wake up early with the single mission of consuming a warm, flaky cruffin. 

This is the process people: 
- the shop opens at 7am, and yes, lines are already being formed by then
- get a sticker that allows each person to order a max of 2 cruffins 
- cruffin orders officially start at 9am

We showed up at 8:30am on a Sat morning and were lucky enough to receive one of the last few stickers handed out that made us worthy of getting a cruffin. The line up was approx 30 mins before we got to the front where we loaded up on every baked good possible that would fit into the box. 

We got a mix of sweet and savory baked goods: peanut butter chocolate cruffin x2, California croissant (salmon & seaweed), artichoke bacon croissant, mango coconut danish, blueberry french toast, pumpkin cheesecake donut ~ $35. 

Every bite was worth it. My brother even surrendered his detox and derailed his 6 week flow for these orgasmic pastries. 

Eat here!
author: Janice K.

description:
Holmes sweet holmes...this little street-side bakery is super cute! After seeing all the hype surrounding Mr.Holmes and coming across photos all over Instagram, I decided to make the drive down from the east bay to try it out. I woke up at 7 am just to get here so that the line for cruffins wouldn't be too long, that's how badly I wanted to try it haha. 

(Note: Cruffins don't come out until 9 AM, so don't come here as soon as they're open expecting them to be available.)

My boyfriend and I arrived around 9 AM on a saturday and quickly found parking across the street. At that time, the line wasn't too long, so we were able to receive a sticker that signified we would be able to purchase a maximum of two cruffins. The line probably took about 20-30 minutes and we were out of there with a box of six different pastries - 2 lemon cruffins, 2 matcha croissants, and 2 churro croissants. The cruffins were yummy, and my bf loved it specifically for the lemon cream inside. I thought the churro croissants were delicious - the outside was flaky and the inside was fluffy with what tasted like a maple or cinnamon cream?

The store itself is very tiny inside. There were no tables or chairs indoors or outdoors, so be prepared to take your patries to-go or to eat them standing outside. Service is quick and nice. 

Overall, I would say the line is worth it only if you wait about 30 minutes. Any longer than that, and it's a little much.  Other than that, if you really want the nice IG photo with the "I got baked" sign, guess that could be worth it too, lolol.
author: Michelle C.

description: This place is SO GOOD! Totally worth waking up early for. The cruffin is worth the hype. Can't wait to try out the LA location. Do yourself a favor and check this place out, it's worth the calories.
author: Paola G.

description:
I dont like waiting in lines, but I waited at Mr Holmes. When i finally got in, i came out with 3 boxes full of goodies! I tried a little but of everything because i didnt plan on waiting in line ever again. 

The cruffins were delicious. I wish they had more flavors because the day I went, i believe it was peppermint flavor and i dislike peppermint. Surprisingly, it still tasted good but I can only imagine how delicious it wouldve been with a flavor i love!
author: Claire W.

description:
Though there is a Mr Holmes a lot closer to my home (Highland Park) i found myself in San Francisco this week for business.
I was on Larkin. I knew Mr Holmes was close. i could smell him and his as yet un-tasted by me Cruffins. I was close.
Then i saw the line and i knew i was in Cruffin-Ville!
Mr Holmes bakes things other than the earth shaking Cruffins like Cookies, plain and filled Croissants and something they call a Churro Croissant.
Shopping here is like shopping at a post Christmas Sale at Macy's. You know there are people waiting for your place and therefore you move quickly: probably missing several things.
Some of the people in line told me they come 2 or 3 times A DAY to visit Mr Holmes and his stuff.
So i buy some Coffee Caramel Cruffins, Corn Flake Cookies, Churro Croissants and something called a California Cruffin.
First the Cruffins: basically the Sweet Ones are sugared Croissants, baked in a muffin tin. I bought one stuffed with Coffee Flavored Caramel. Though the baking of the croissant was flawless: all flaky and buttery, very much in the French tradition, the filling was too much both in quantity and in sugarocity, Though a bit of this filling would have been enough. whoever was manning the pastry bag got carried away. Weight-wise there was more filling than Croissant. Yet all i did was squeeze most of the filling out and finished it. This cost $4.50: did you think i would dump it?
 Speaking of pricing: most items are 4-5 bucks which is pricey yet what cannot be denied is that these products are carefully and thoughtfully produced and just as beautiful as fine pastries that i have seen in Paris or Vienna.
The Churro Croissant was baked (not fried) and filled with a creamy, smooth, a little lemony Bavarian cream. Yes!
The Corn Flake Cookie was mouth melting-ly good. Very Good. Like Toffee and corn Flakes ground into a luscious, molassesy Cookie.
The California Cruffin was not sugared but it was stuffed with Smoked Salmon, Nori , Wasabi and Ginger. I couldn't have this everyday but for a savory it was pretty delicious.
BTW: my perhaps future business partner, a San Francisco resident had never even heard of Mr Holmes or his wares but he was bowled over, almost literally after trying out all of these Bakery delights.
All in all a good visit to Mr Holmes and now I can scream from the rooftops: I AM A CRUFFINATOR! 
(attached is a You Tube about the Great Cruffin Caper!)
https://youtu.be/l8fuNvLKk6o
author: Michael A.

description: Such a cute place to stop when in San Fran! Because I went around 10am (kind of late for this bakery) most of the pastries were sold out! If you go I recommend going a little earlier to try and beat the LONG line, but still had a delicious chocolate croissant that I defiantly recommend! The store is very small, so little bit of walking room & no room for tables. The worker that helped me was very accommodating for my first time and helped me picked out what pastries to buy. And....They do of course have the beautiful sign that is Instagram worthy! Can't wait to go back!
author: Tristen B.

description:
Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is so popular! We went around 10:30 am on a Thursday, and most of the baked goods were already gone. The line was also out the door when we got there. 

I ordered a spinach and mushroom croissant and the bacon one as well. I really enjoyed the bacon pastry because I thought it had more filling than the spinach one. But, both were delicious.

There's street parking, which can be dangerous because the streets are super cramped in SF. But it shouldn't take too long to get your pastry, so you can just set the meter for 30 minutes. The bakery isn't meant for people to sit at, so you basically go in to grab the pastries and head out right afterwards.
author: Melody S.

description: They had some unique treats here! We were told to check out the donuts at this place, but we stayed and enjoyed the croissants instead - they really piqued our interests! I had the special sushi croissant which was mind-blowing. Who knew the classic salmon sushi flavors would go well inside a croissant?!? The chocolate croissant was perfectly flaky as well. The plan originally was to enjoy a pastry and head over to lunch, but two croissants did me in - I was done. The cold brew was a lovely pair to my sweet and savory pastries. Awesome job!
author: RJ S.

description: I went on a Saturday at about 1pm and the line was pretty short (only about 5 minutes). I got the matcha croissant and it was nice and flaky. It also had a strong matcha flavor, which I like. This place has been hyped up a lot because of its sign. The pastry was pretty good, but I don't like it's worth all the hype it gets.
author: Jamie N.

description:
I'm surprised I hadn't​ come across this place after living here for 3 years. I was pleasantly surprised by the options and the small cute bakery seems to be a popular place with tourists who take pictures with the "I got baked in SF" sign.

We went there on a Saturday morning around 10 and the line was not too bad then, we were the second set of people there. But the line was almost around the block by the time we left. We ordered the hibiscus cruffin(obvs) and some savory​ danishes and it was very tasty and not too cloying(which is what I love best about the parties here). In my opinion, ​Mr Homes is better than Tartine for their puff pastries.
author: Sherin T.

description:
Got 2 honey lavender cruffins to go ($4.50 each). The lavender, cream filling was okay but my favorite part was the cruffin itself (flaky and good). The powdered sugar made it a bit messy to consume in the office. Overall, it's pretty good. Follow their IG, they posts flavors they're making that week.

I experienced no wait/line on a Tuesday. Wish the staff was a bit friendlier.
author: Ida H.

description:
Mr Holmes bakehouse is a San Francisco tourist attraction that you HAVE to visit at least once. This bakery is known for making the elusive *Cruffin- cross between a croissant and a muffin. To keep the demand high and the suspense their the bakery only makes a limited number of cruffins per day and  you must go super early and get in line to get one. If you are not in line early your chances of trying the famous cruffins will be slim to none. Personally I enjoyed the donuts and other pastries more but you need to try them at least once. A little pricey but worth the stop as a special treat. Check their Instagram every Sunday for a list of the daily donut and cruffin flavors.
Oh and don't forget to take a picture inside the bakery with their famous..."I got baked in SAN Francisco" sign
author: Ali M.

description:
One of the staple SF experiences, here's the down low: yes there's an early morning line, they're famous for their cruffins amongst other products, and there is most definitely talent in front and especially in the back where the magic happens!

Stood in line around 8:30AM on a Saturday morning after reading that they open shop at 8AM. We could tell where the shop was by the line and the bright pink neon signage. A very sweet and brave Holmes worker came out to the street to let us know that the people waiting in line where we were do not have the guarantee of receiving any cruffins. However, that is in case people before us didn't get their allowed quota of 2 cruffins for the day. We were not too far from the "guaranteed" customers, so we stuck through and actually were able to get cruffins which were a delicious cream-filled cruffin with a mini brownie on top! YUM. We had to get in another line and start over to pick other donuts...so come to Mr. Holmes expecting a wait.

We were helped both times by the wonderful and spirited Jeremy. Cheers to you ya breath of fresh winterfresh air!! He made the experience fun and positive so early in the morning, and even though some customers didn't respond well to it we were cheering for you and your personality all the way! A paper box fits 6 donuts basically, but you can stuff more in it if you're a baked goods savant. We also got two chocolate cream filled sugar donuts, which were alright compared to the other pastries. I loved their crispy flaky kougin aman and blackberry/cheesecake brioche bread! UM yes, I could eat that forever. The ube puff we just had to get because of that interesting bright pink prickly pear frosting on top! Hello audacity!

They also serve hot coffee with their signature bright pink peace sign imprinted. I also noticed lots of merch in the form of bags and water for self-service too. Not a lot of room inside or out for sitting, so most people just buy and take their treasures home. In terms of how long to keep them, we were able to eat them even 2 nights after and they were just as delicious and fresh with a quick pop in the oven. Nothing was overly sweet or crazily mixed with flavors. That's what I loved about Mr. Holmes. I will be back no matter the line! I've waited longer for SF brunch, so this is a piece of heavenly cruffin flake to me :)
author: Jodi H.

description:
Don't get me wrong, the pastries were fabulous, but I do not plan on traveling to SF and waiting in line before the shop opens again for these baked goods.

Food ordered:
- Matcha cruffin: 4/5
The matcha cruffin was the special of the day and it was great! My mother, who is not a fan of super sweet pastries also found this to be delectable. It was not overwhelmingly buttery at all.

- Croissant: 2/5
I ordered the plain croissant to see if they got the basics right, and they do. But, in my opinion, it just tastes like your average croissant, but maybe slightly less heavy on the stomach than regular croissants.

I may be back for more cruffins and to try the donuts, but I do not plan on returning to this specific location (I've been to the Tustin location in Southern CA and it was much less crowded). It was a fun adventure but also considering the price of each of the pastries and the fact you need to buy at least 6 pastries to "earn" the Holmes box, it may be a while before I am back. It's a cute tourist spot though.
author: Alice W.

description: The savory baked goods were okay but a bit overpriced with fillings that were a bit less in quantity than expected. Will need to go back at an earlier time to try their more popular selections.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
TBH I was nervous before stepping foot into this bakery because I've heard WAY too many stories about 2-hour lines and cruffins running out. But thankfully, we got here in the morning about 15 minutes after they opened on a weekday and there was NO LINE AT ALL. *yay*

After a few minutes of scanning through the plethora of pastries they had, we got the Matcha croissant and the cruffin (I believe they change up the flavors every month and the flavor we got was lychee and something sour?). The matcha croissant was BOMB. The perfect kind of flakiness you would ever want in a croissant, not like one of these soft and soggy croissants but actually crunchy flakes fall out whenever you take a bite. The cruffin on the other hand, was also crunchy and flaky, but it was a bit hard to chew on. Perhaps the shape of it made it a weird size to grab a bite but I found myself getting the bits of sugar all over my mouth and my clothes. The filling inside the cruffin was okay. I wasn't as much of a fan of it as I was of the matcha croissant. 

Definitely would come back again to try other pastries or go to the LA location.
author: Amy T.

description:
Finally came here to get something. Usually, I don't like going to places with long lines. Today, I woke up early and couldn't go back to sleep, so I decided to come try this place out. It's Thursday at 8am that I arrived. I saw a lot of croissants, but no crofins. A little sad. I think somebody asked about it and was told 9am. So, beware!
So, I got a matcha and roasted tomatoes croissants. They are both good, crispy, and flakey. The roasted tomatoes one is not that special though. I like the matcha one better.
author: Ervi L.

description:
Don't be deterred by the line if you see 5-10 people out the door. Inside is pretty small as it is (hence, there being a line) but it goes fairly quick. They're known for their cruffins with a limit of 2 per person and their stuffed donuts are to die for. If you EVER see their green tea dipped croissants- "git it, git it!" 

Today: Coffee cruffins

Tip: Try getting there early as possible (rainy days are much better) + park on Hemlock street where it is a one way alley between Larkin & Polk. You'll thank me later
author: Jillian V.

description:
Mr Holmes' branding is very trendy/millennial-y so aka good for the Instagram. But does it deliver on product? I thought so...until I went to Tartine. Compared to Tartine, Mr Holmes really pales in comparison. 

We ordered SO many pastries - luckily there was no line because we went early on a weekday. 

*Cruffin - Their hybrid between a croissant & muffin. I believe ours was german chocolate. I don't love german chocolate but this was okay. Is it worth standing in line forever for? Nah. 
*Kougin Amann - It was like their cruffin but...without filling. I thought this was decent (a little too hard? maybe overbaked?) until I went to Crumble & Flake in Seattle
*Ube Puff - Don't know why they slathered the top with some pepto bismo lookin' icing (the website states that it's a prickly pear icing) but the ube insides were great. 
*Chocolate Chip Cookie - hard. Maybe it was stale? Either way, don't get this 
*Savory Dish of some sort - probably my favorite! Good amount of filling to pastry goodness.

Mr Holmes is coming down to Highland Park in SoCal and that's where I think it'll shine because there are really no awesome bakeries (IMO) in that area. Thus, I'll probably visit that location
author: Tiffany H.

description: When did the staff start being nice to customers? I'm so confused. I used to enjoy lining up early, waiting in a line wrapped around the block, just for the mere chance to spend $6 on a cruffin, limit 2 per customer. I loved receiving looks of disdain for asking what each flavor was, and then having my pastry thrust angrily across the counter. Now I can't even get a passive aggressive comment. They say thank you when you tip them. This place has changed, way too nice...what happened? Was it the Broad City spoof that made you change your ways?
author: Ange R.

description:
This has been the best discovery out of all my trips to San Francisco. I have heard from friends about this place before but the personal experience of trying these pastries was amazing. If you like croissant, donuts, and danish, this is your place! I didn't realize how popular this place was until I saw a relatively long line around 11am on a Sunday and pastries were disappearing because most people ordered in boxes.

I missed out on their cruffin. They start selling their cruffins at 8am until sold out or 10am. Since I'm not from the city, it may be difficult to try one of these cruffins but I am determined to  get here early one day!

I ordered the Blue Cheese Bacon Danish, California Croissant, Elderberry Strawberry Croissant, Earl Grey Chocolate Donut, Regular Croissant, and 2 more donuts (I can't exactly remember the flavor being) for a total ~ $30. Slightly pricey but definitely worth it. No favorites to recommend from here because all pastries are worth a try.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Like the amateur foodie I am, I did not realize that Mr. Holmes infamous cruffins sell out within an hour or so of their opening everyday. So when I arrived around 11 AM, excited to try this miraculous pastry I'd read so much about, I was a little heartbroken. But, fear not - I gave one of their other delectable pastries a try! (I mean, I did drive all the way to SF for this foodie excursion, so why not?!)

I ordered a chocolate peanut butter donut and it did not disappoint. The outside of the donut was delicately coated with cinnamon sugar, while the inside was piped with chocolate peanut butter cream. The donut was light and airy. It satisfied my sweet tooth and my heartbreak over the cruffin. But now I know for future reference - come early (before they open) to wait in line for their limited cruffin supply. 

Keep getting baked, San Francisco. Until next time xx
author: Courtney P.

description: This place has really gone down hill since the original bakers and owner have left. I live in the neighborhood and I can't even go anymore.
author: Kara S.

description: I've been to SF so many times but I don't know why we have never been to Mr Holmes! We tried going on a Sunday afternoon but they were already closed since they sold out. We tried again on a Friday morning a few hours after opening and there was plenty of goods left! There was a line out the door as expected since it's a tiny shop but it moved quickly.
