The cruffin was delicious! It was soft and flaky, and I think the custard inside made it even better. The chocolate chip cookie dough croissant was also really good, filled with a cookie dough cream inside too. I can see why this spot is super popular - just wish parking was easier!
author: Ashley C.

description: Delicious pastries. Went here on an early morning to attempt to get ahead of the anticipated long line. We had a bit of a wait until the store opened and then cycle through the people ahead of us when it was finally our turn. The unfortunate part was that they were not prepared with cruffins! After we got over the disappointment of that news, we were greeted with the sight of the items for sale. We made sure to order enough different types to ensure a box! When we took our items with us and were finally able to consume, we were extremely happy with our selection!
author: Crystal S.

description: I've had my eyes on these pastries for a longggg time and couldn't wait to visit. Luckily, they had no line around the block! The croissants are literally to die for. Their drool worthy Instagram pictures live up to the hype!  I know people go crazy over their cruffins they have for a limited time in the morning, but I think everything else is equally worthy!
author: Kacey K.

description: I found this place through facebook. I was lucky that I didn't have to wait at all. If you want to go their without waiting, I highly recommend to go their on weekday instead of weekend. When I went, I got a cruffin, a motcha croissant and a passion fruit donut. My number one to go is their motcha croissant, the motcha flavor really stand out and the croissant was crunchy. Cruffin is my second to go, I felt that I had to order it just by its name. It has really rich flavor.
author: Zichang L.

description:
New to the FIDI. Well at least the Mr Holmes Bakehouse stand. So amazing, made my FRIDAY! They are inside the Workshop Cafe, who would have known? I walk by the cafe everyday to work and today they opened up a nice stand outside. YAY!! Caught my eye right away.

Was on a no sugar diet but can't walk away and not get their donuts. Wish they would add the addition of their famous Cruffins soon. My favorite pastry in the world. The two gentlemen was super nice and friendly. I am welcoming you to the Financial District with open arms. So exciting!

They're there until they sell out. They are all set up already around 730am when I walk by everyday. Not sure about the exact time.
author: Sandy B.

description:
Mr. Holmes is one of the top bakeries in a city bursting with great food. Though they are reknown for their Cruffins - the marriage of croissant dough baked into a deep muffin tin chockablock with delectable, piped-in fillings - I CRAVE their donuts. They have the best filled donuts in all of San Francisco - that I know of (so far). 
Every single item (savory and sweet) I've had from the Bakehouse has been good (kouign amann - go to B Patisserie for theirs) to exquisite (most donuts and cruffins). They have their croissant dough down to a sweet (or savory) science! Most of their flavors are curious and amazing combinations. 
My first trip to MHB was on St. Patrick's Day a couple of years ago. The flavors of that day were Irish Car Bomb cruffins and Whisky Caramel donuts. Since I'm not a huge fan of most alcohols, I was skeptical I'd like either pastry. Oh-Danny-Boy was I wrong! Both flavors were delectable and amazing! The Irish Car Bomb flavor was slightly sweet with the definitive splash of Guinness incorporated into the smoky-ish flavor of the cream filling the light and crispy muffin-shaped croissant. My mother, who is a tee-totaler, even loved the cruffin. 
The Whisky Caramel-filled donut was just as drool-worthy. I'm a sucker for most caramel, but the depth of that whisky-infused caramel was buzz-worthy if only for each enchanting ounce of caramel filling that donut-belly. And the caramel, and all the donut flavors, is encased in some of the most light and lusciously yeasty pastry dough. The MHB elves do a remarkable job in frying each pillowy-goodness to the perfect point of both doughyness and crispiness. The sweetness of the dough is balanced with each flavor they choose to pipe in that day. If I lived closer, I would be a daily customer, the donuts are THAT good. 
MHB changed their flavor rotation to quarterly versus weekly sometime last year (2017), which I'm not a huge fan of since I adore rotating variety, but I know the flavors are well-done and on-point. I agree with others that the Matcha Croissants are okay and should have some piped-in filling, especially since MHB are masters of that skill. I tried most of the original line-up of pastries, including the California croissant (smoked salmon, nori, sesame, and pickled-ginger filled), and all were really good and crave-able. Now I see there are new "standard" items on their menu, I will have to go back to check out their new fascinating and unique flavor combinations encased in their amazing croissant and donut "shells".  
Since I am a holistic person, I will also mention, their marketing acumen is marvelous, too. Their graphics, boxes, signage, and shop are definitely picture-worthy. I got a thing for hot pink, so the "I got baked in SF" neon always gives me a giggly grin each visit. I'm also a bag/container hoarder and do my best to keep my box of treats as pristine as possible, so I might be able to keep my non-pastry collections inside that beautiful white and gold case as a visual reminder of my SF happy foodie adventures/obnoxiousness. ;)
author: AK C.

description:
Epitome of a tourist trap but it was definitely worth the hype and venture to get their amazing pastries, specifically their cruffins. My cousin and I got their "specialty" box of 2 cruffins, one donut, 2 matcha croissants, and one of their churro croissant. You must order at least 6 pastries to get the box, FYI.

On that particular day I went, their specialty flavor for their cruffin was blueberry lemon and for their donut, it was pineapple papaya. Though I'm not a fan of blueberry or papaya in desserts, I still gave it a try. NO REGRETS. The blueberry and lemon worked really well together since the blueberry was sweet and the lemon was more tart, so there was a nice balance of sweetness to counteract each other. The dough of the cruffin itself was very flaky and chewy, which I loved. The pineapple papaya donut had the same effect on me. I didn't think those two flavors would go together especially since I've never heard of that flavor combination before but boy, was I wrong. I was blown away by how good their pastries were. I don't have a favorite from them because I honestly enjoyed everything I got and couldn't pick one for the life of me.
author: Linda C.

description:
I went here to meet up with someone since they suggested donuts and I have been meaning to try this place ever since I've moved out here. On a Sunday afternoon, this place wasn't too busy, but there were people constantly coming in and out. The number of people posing for pictures in front of the "I GOT BAKED IN SAN FRANCISCO" sign was amusing.

I ordered the earl grey donut and my friend ordered the fruit filled one (I'm blanking on which flavor it was now...). Both were delicious and both hit the spot -- what a great lunch :)
author: Leana L.

description:
I used to like it better the last two years, the quality standards lowered up a little and we notice because we live right by the corner so it is our to go place for pastries. 

The cookies are very delicious, try putting them in the oven for 2 min before eating them at home! And the croissants have never disappointed me.
author: Rebecca F.

description:
"Holmes sweet home." Holmes is definitely home. 

I could smell the delicious smell of baked goods and pastries from across the street.

A tip is to line up for the cruffins before 8:30am. My friend and I woke up super early and drove all the way to SF to stand in the freezing cold at 8am. It was an ordinary Tuesday and the line was surprisingly pretty long. Get there early to make sure you get cruffins because they sell out! 

Overall, the cruffins are so so good. It's flaky, like a croissant, and the cream filling is perfectly sweetened. I literally want to try everything. 

The downside is that the area is a little sketchy at times. And it's pretty pricey for some baked goods. Oh well, I'm still addicted to getting baked in San Francisco.
author: Michelle F.

description:
Ummmmm YES. So. Much. Yes.

I'd wanted to stop by Mr. Holmes for the cruffins while in SF but was hesitant when my friend told me we had to get there pretty early to get in line and hope for the best. I'm not a fan of long lines and rarely think 1+ hour waits anywhere for anything is worth it. But man, am I glad we decided to wait. Cruffins are GLORIOUS and "cruffin" is officially my favorite portmanteau. Forget cronuts and whatever other hybrid of croissants x baked good exists. Cruffins are IT.

Fate would have it that the day's flavor was strawberry matcha aka my favorite two flavors of all time!! If you know me you know I love all things matcha/green tea, so when the employee made the announcement prior to handing out the coveted pink stickers that indicate you're guaranteed a cruffin that morning, I was ecstatic. 

We arrived around 8:30AM on a Sunday and there was already a line forming. Needless to say, the wait was long because the shop is TINY and there's only one employee serving the cruffins, but luckily there are several Pokestops within the proximity of Mr. Holmes Bakehouse. Drop a lure and Pokemon & chill until 9AM when the cruffins are ready. Also, unfortunately, if you want to get a box you need 6+ baked goods and each person with a sticker is limited to 2 cruffins. So if you want the pretty gold foil box, you'll need to get in the other line for other pastries. 

Overall the entire ordeal took about 2 hours but the crispy, swirly, fluffy, matcha cream-filled deliciociousness was well worth it. Mission accomplished. And I'd do it again.
author: Emily K.

description:
If you didn't know about Mr. Holmes and/or are too lazy to travel to the Tendernob for some of their brilliant pastries, have no fear! If you're anywhere in FiDi, you can walk over to Workshop Cafe and they have a stand right in front of their doors. Feast on most of their pastries they offer at their brick and mortar location, such as the donuts, kouign amanns, Danishes...

Wait, hold up..."most"?

Yes. Because they don't offer the cruffin here (their unicorn pastry, the one that put Mr. Holmes Bakehouse on the map!). 

Actually, I personally prefer it that way, as I know it's difficult to mass produce in the first place, and there's just way too much demand for them right now. Besides, cruffins are worth going on a quest for anyway! 

However, I question how they are able to keep their pastries warm. Since I work next door, I stopped by for a savory artichoke and feta Danish, and it was quite cold, which took away from its flavor considerably. I guess you must come early to get it, or just toast it when you get to the office. 

Also, instead of Sightglass Coffee, they offer brewed coffee supplied by Workshop. Not a plus or minus on their part, I felt the coffee did its job for me. 

Anyway, I'm also glad they have a presence in the FiDi now! Come on by from 7-1 (or whenever they sell out) during the work week!
author: Viet N.

description: If you live in the Bay Area or you are visiting this is a must go to place for pastries, specifically the Cruffin (croissant and muffin in one)! Beware, there are two different lines, one for cruffins and the other for all other pastries! They do not sale cruffins until an hour after they open, so make sure you are standing in the right line. I highly recommend bringing someone with you, so one can stand in the cruffin line while the other gets pastries to eat while you wait for cruffins. While you are waiting in the cruffin line they will hand out tickets, you can only buy 2 cruffins per person. If they run out of tickets and you do not get one than you are out of luck, so get there early and enjoy the pastries and coffee while you wait in line!
author: Keisha K.

description:
Stopped by before 10am on a Monday morning.

Just 2 peeps ahead of us in line - oh yeah!

Passion fruit filled donut was the bomb! Omg so delicious!  Just wish they provided smaller boxes for 2-3 items.  My donut got a little smashed in the flimsy bag they gave.
author: Jade B.

description: Really small shop with no seating, just a tiny standing area. Baked goods all looked delicious but I am a woman on a mission for the new seasonal flavors of winter 2017. I tried the chestnut creme flavored cruffin. Hands down the best. Not too sweet with a crunchy exterior. Will be back on FRIDAYS :)
author: Jessica L.

description: Bakers and friends: cruffins are not served until 9am and is limited to two per person. Meanwhile, the main bakery opens at 8am. There are two separate queues: one for ONLY cruffins (that opens at 9am) and one for everything else (opens at 8am). My party got there at 8am on a Saturday and there was already a little bit of a line - travels pretty quickly though! We got one of everything. Once we finished buying our pastries, we just moved on to the cruffin line. There was basically no line for the rest of the baked goods at 9 am! The staff is great; they keep the line updated pretty frequently (reminding people what each line is for, when the cruffins will be ready) and give you each a sticker to reserve two cruffins per person. So far, all of the pastries I've tried have been amazing! The pastries are the great because the flavors are bright and interesting and best of all, not too sweet. I really couldn't justify waking up early to wait in line in the cold to get a box of overpriced pastries, but I am definitely glad I was able to try this bakeshop. While $4.50 for a croissant seems a little much, I would recommend anyone in the SF area to come try a little something special!
author: Sydney J.

description:
Overall: I decided to order some breakfast and have it delivered to work. I tried to order using their website, but there was glitches to the order as well as completing it. Later I called and spoke to Bridget on completion. She was great and helped me finalized the order. Unfortunately, you had to wait 3 days for it. The other downside is that you can't place an order for cruffins either. I would have expected since I was placing an order 3 days in advanced, you could order some. Negative 1 star. 

Upon delivery, the delivery guy called me to come down to pick up my order. When I had placed the order, I informed Bridget of my suite number. He said it wasn't given to him and he almost refused to complete his job. I almost refused the order. Negative 0.5 star. 

Food: the food came nicely in presentation. And they tasted great. 

Note on delivery, there is a minimum charge $50 and a delivery charge of $17. I'll be back with another order, hopefully the delivery guy is more professional with his end. 

Thanks for listening.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: Quite the specialty pastry shop!  Everything was delicious, I only wish they had a couple flavors of Cruffins ever day instead of just one.  That's my only negative
author: Ben P.

description:
LOCATION// Tenderloin area. If you're walking here, you'll get to see some colorful characters/scenes. On my 8am walk here, got to witness man taking a #2 outside someone's business (right next to the doors), used needles from someone's last high, and plenty of other human #2s that seeemed to lead the way to the bakery. Not sure if you have to be afraid of being attacked in the day, maybe just offensive and racist obscenities thrown at you (in my case). Just keep walking, no big deal, it'll just add to your day. Definitely don't come at night, though, because if the broken glass on the bakery doors are any indication, maybe things do get a little iffy at certain times of the day.

GOOD TO KNOW// Two lines out the door. One is CRUFFIN ONLY (but you can add coffee), of which sales start at 9am. Two per person (e.g., if you come with a friend, you're allowed 4). You cannot choose your cruffin flavor. There is only one flavor for the day, so check beforehand on the website before lining up if you care what you're lining up for.
The other line is for every other pastry/coffee/etc. No, you cannot order your doughnut in the cruffin line. You must get back out and line up at the other line after you've paid for your cruffin.

VERDICT// Is it hyped? Yes. Is it worth it? I dunno for you, it's just croissant dough pressed into a muffin mold then injected with whatever flavored cream and dusted with sugar crystals. The novelty factor is the shape of the croissant. Did it taste special to me? No. Did it taste good/decent? Yes. Remarkable? Not to me.

I also tried some of the other pastries. I thought the calamansi doughnut was good, but everything else that was made with croissant/flaky pastry dough tasted burnt. You can tell from the photos, that dark browning is charring, not "golden brown." The one sliver of pear on my poached pear and cheese pastry was good, unfortunately it was mostly dough, 90% of which was just so bitter that I had to throw it away. I wouldn't come here again, but some of the flavor profiles are good. The pastry dough is a little dense, though, not enough air between the layers.

STAFF// Yeah, the people at the bakery are smug. But I didn't see them being rude to anyone. Front of house just act a little bemused and self-congratulatory.

They also put pastries inside individual waxed paper bags. I bought 4 pastries, and she just handed me four separate bags. Most other bakeries would either put them all in a larger bag or in a box for you, so that it's easier to carry. Instead, here they seem to save the boxes (sturdy, thick cardboard ones that probably cost more than typical cake boxes) for customers who are also getting cruffins.

TIP// The non-cruffin line actually moves pretty fast. So don't be intimidated if you want to try something else from the bakery. Avoid weekends, and you can avoid long waits for cruffins. Otherwise, come around 8 or 8:30am to guarantee yourself one.
author: Ada L.

description:
Alright, so I know that Mr. Holmes is known for their croissant muffins, known widely as cruffins. And I was prepared for a long line.

But, surprisingly, an hour after opening on a Saturday morning, the line wasn't too bad. It didn't even go down for half a block. But then I realized the line was really for Cruffins, and if you weren't getting any ... you could BYPASS the entire line and just get your other pastries instead. 

The Cruffins were in the last stages of being baked and were going into the display case within the next 10-15 minutes. I had done my research beforehand and realized the flavor of the day--I think it was blackberry--was not one I was super stoked to try. Granted, if it were something chocolaty or cinnamony, I would have waited my turn in that line. But, since I had my eyes on the other pastries and on the chocolate chip cookies, my friend and I breezed past the line and got up close to the bakery display case.

The Mr. Holmes logo is to the left when you enter the store, so you can pause briefly and take your picture before proceeding to check out the treats for the day. I was overwhelmed -- everything smelled delicious and it was hard to narrow down my choices. It was a good thing I had an idea of what I wanted before entering the bakery, so I could attempt to demonstrate some sort of self-control. 

If you have never been there before, Mr. Holmes is definitely worth checking out ... especially if you love bakeries and have a sweet tooth, like me. It'll be hard to stick to your designated list, that's for sure, because everything looks and smells so good! Pastries are about $3-4 each, depending on what you get. My advice would be to get a good assortment if it's your first time - I got a cookie and one of the croissant varieties, and if we were not walking around the city all day, I would have gotten one of the donuts as well.

Here's what I got:

"Salted Chocolate Chip Cookie": This cookie was nothing short of amazing, sporting the perfect balance of salty and sweet. At first, I was afraid that the cookie would be too crunchy for my preference ... but the girl behind the counter reassured me that it was slightly crunchy on the outside, but soft and chewy in the middle. She was totally right and I'm glad I ended up getting two of these cookies. They were chockfull of chocolate chips, which was good news, but the crowning glory was that sea salt on top. I've had salted chocolate chip cookies before, but I think this version had the most salt I've ever tasted on a cookie before. At first bite, it was borderline too salty ... but as I continued to eat the cookie, more and more, I was convinced that the amount of salt worked in the cookie's favor and made it more amazing. The cookie was soft and chewy in texture, but the salt crystals gave it some extra crispiness. Yum! I absolutely dream about these cookies now and would get more if I ever return to Mr. Holmes. There was also a Cornflake Cookie (brown butter toffee and cornflake cereal) that was available, but this cookie is sure to be crunchier because of those cornflakes. I was intrigued and did want to try it (I love the salted oatmeal cornflake from Sprinkles Cupcakes), but decided to save that cookie for a future visit. 

"Bear Claw": I was so busy asking questions about the chocolate chip cookie that I didn't even see this pastry at first. My friend brought it to my attention, saying that I should try it because it contained chocolate chips and the traditional croissant ... but not in the traditional form. I'm not sure if this was a weekend special, but I didn't see it on the Mr. Holmes website before, and I'm so glad I tried it! It was definitely different. This huge bear claw featured layers of croissant dough, but it also appealed to my sweet tooth because it had a chocolate chip cookie dough filling. I didn't taste it with my initial few bites, but once I hit the middle of the bear claw, it felt like it was eating cookie dough, straight up! It was sweet and indulgent--definitely sweeter than the salted chocolate chip cookie I got--but not overly sweet, since the croissant was plain (no glaze). If you like cookie dough or want an unusual treat, I highly recommend this option. 

"Churro Croissant": If my purse had been any bigger, I would have ordered one of these as well. I love churros because of their cinnamon flavor, and this croissant looked absolutely delicious in the display case. It featured dulce de leche cream and cinnamon sugar ... and boy, was it covered in cinnamon sugar. I was curious about the dulce de leche cream but from the outside, this croissant really did remind me of a churro because of the liberal amount of cinnamon sugar on the outside. I definitely want to try it one day - because I know the croissants really are delicious, thanks to the bear claw, I'm sure this cinnamon flavor would hit the spot.
author: Kelli S.

description:
I arrived at 8:40am on a Monday to join the line, waited 20 minutes for the cruffins to come out of the oven, spent $27.50 on a box of pastries without any second thoughts, Instagrammed the "I got baked in San Francisco" (after multiple tries, of course), walked briskly through the sketchy neighborhood (not sure if I was more likely to be robbed of my Mr. Holmes goodies or my wallet), and arrived at my car with one minute left in the meter. I find it moderately alarming that this all seems perfectly normal.... because it is the quintessential way to spend a weekday morning in SF.

[TL;DR] Is it worth it? 
If you are a food enthusiast and/or have lots of free time: yes.
If you are curious but relatively busy: yes, at least once.
If you just want the Instagram: maybe.
Just because: no.

Mr. Holmes has been on my bucket list for awhile, and this is my charmed third time after two unsuccessful pilgrimages. Its cruffins are likely the most elusive, legendary baked goods in the Bay Area! Who would have thought that even weekday morning visits require standing in line. (But then again, start-up workdays beginning at 11am and idle millennials are well known and jested about - sigh - gentrification)

If you do decide to tackle the ordeal, I suggest arriving around 8:30am on a weekday. Weekends are too crazy, and you have to deal with two lines, one just for cruffins and another for everything else! The meter parking fees kick in at 9am, so plan accordingly and bring quarters (I actually saw cops checking). Street parking isn't so bad around that time, though the rate is a hefty $3.25/hr. Also, be sure to check their weekly Instagram updates for cruffin/doughnut flavors--if you're going through all this trouble, you'd better be excited for your cruffin.

(+++) Strawberry lemon cruffin - Mmm as epic as expected. Flakey soft croissant layers filled with fruity custard, coated in sugar like a morning bun (reminiscent of Chinese sugar egg puffs). It boasts a melt-in-your-mouth texture and the filling tastes freshly made of fruit with just the right sweetness. The beautiful shape of the cruffin wins the beauty pageant of pastries, though it could use an additional garnish.

(+++) California croissant - A California roll inside a croissant?! This sourcery of a croissant filed with a small smoked salmon roll, a dash of wasabi, and a sesame coating turned out unexpectedly mind-blowing. The roll was small but I did appreciate the art of airniness in the croissant composition.

(++) Plain croissant - Crisp exterior and silky interior. I liked how there wasn't a caramelized layer like Arsicault and Neighbor, which I find excessive. Really enjoyed Mr. Holmes' simple perfection.

(+) Choux bomb - Tasty with the coffee cream in between buttery cookies with a small chocolate piece; however, I am not a fan of buttercream and I thought this used way too much (which also made it difficult to eat). Too sweet and not as outstanding as the others, but very pretty.

(+/-) Ube pastry - Not as refined in aesthetics (rectangular pastry with a smear of bright magenta frosting) and taste (the sweet ube paste and frosting made it way too sugary, and it had disappointingly little ube flavor). Probably the least remarkable item I tried; like a fancy pop tart.

Tips:
- To get a box, you must buy a minimum of 6 pastries, and it is a darn fine box of thick cardboard and shiny letters
- Max 2 cruffins per customer
- Mentally prepare yourself that the surrounding area smells rancid, but once you walk into the shop you are bathed in the aroma of bakery heaven
- Don't plan to Instagram holding a cruffin in front of the sign; in my opinion this is too messy because the sugar coating. (Plus, there is a line of people judging you)

[THE VERDICT] The hype borders on ridiculous, but Mr. Holmes deserves its fame for the consistently high quality, clever uniqueness, and sheer perfection. While browsing their website, I found that their shift begins at 3am! And in spite of the inelastic demand, they keep their prices reasonable-ish (in SF standards) at ~$3.5-5 for most bakery items, versus Tartine's more exorbitant prices. The value of Mr. Holmes' pastries is indeed evident by the intriguing news of a burglar who stole the cruffin recipe and left the cash register untouched.
author: Edna C.

description: My boyfriend and I were visiting SF from Dallas this past weekend and this bakery was one of our top places to try. It certainly exceeded our expectations! We even went back a second time bc it was just that great. LOVED the cruffins, the matcha crossaint, donuts, and the cajun creole muffin (ask for the dipping gravy). We will definitely return next time we're in town.
author: Brittney K.

description:
Easily my favorite bakery and place to visit in SF!  My gf and I enjoyed mostly everything we bought.

Favorites were blood and orange cruffin (perfect amount of sweet and tanginess), matcha croissant (tasted like a matcha kit kat), sausage creole pastry with gravy, and the toffee and cereal cookie.  All were bomb!!

The box was a very nice addition (felt like I came out the store with a nice pair of shoes haha).  Very well justifies price of having to get 6 items.  And my gf enjoyed the neon lights.  Definitely recommend this place!

Side note but after reading a couple elite posts I don't know why these millennials are smoking thinking why they can't get a box if they order less than 6 or have to pay additional charge if they do want one anyway.  Please get over yourself.
author: Jonathan N.

description: Mr Holmes Bakehouse is one of my favorite bakeries. Honestly, I only went there for the sign. I thought it was cute, it's definitely a fun picture to take and add to your memories in life. BUT, honestly when I tried the pastries, they were also so good. It was an extra treat- a guilty pleasure.
author: Annadean F.

description:
Visited Mr. Holmes on a Friday morning and waited for about 45 minutes in the "Cruffins" line to secure a pair of Cruffins and some other morning pastries.  

The Good:
Taste and selection - there is a wide variety of baked goods and the portions are larger than expected. The signature Cruffins (Croissant + muffin hybrid) have a crunchy crust and good texture; however, there is too much sugar sprinkled on top (unless you're a sugarphile). 

The Bad:
-It's a long wait if you want to buy Cruffins
-Parking around Larkin is a bit sketchy (better taking Muni and walking or Uber).

Recommendations:
Cruffins - they rotate flavors
Choux Bomb
Ube Puff

Tips:
1) Line up early - they open at 8am but start selling the Cruffins at 9am (you will see the line)
2) They limit 2 Cruffins per customer
3) If you want a carry out box, it'll be $1.50 unless you buy 6 pastries and the box is "free."

Overall, I enjoyed getting "baked" in SF.
author: Simon M.

description: I have heard the whispers of this legendary place and I decided to stand in the line to see if they were true.  I'll say that this place is solid, but there isn't anything that crazy about it. The desserts/pastries/donuts look a little better than other places but taste-wise, nothing sets this apart in a large way.  Still loved it. Will go back to try new things. Don't be afraid to be basic and get the chocolate chip cookie!
author: John H.

description:
Truly feels like a tourist hype.. i didn't enjoy the service and culture in the bakery and the 6pastries we tried weren't anything special. 
There is a constant line and they dont have much drink options. I took a pic by their famous pink sign and tasted 6different sweets.. all in all I wont be back to go through this line and tourist trap!
author: Merve C.

description: I am amongst the minority here but I don't understand the "hype"....that's really all it is, HYPE. I've had better baked goods and aesthetically, it's a freaking 4x6 tiled room with some neon lights.  Sorry for keeping it real.
author: Vivian T.

description:
I'm a foodie so I live for food adventures like this one. If you're a foodie, this whole experience is a lot of fun. If you're not a foodie, this whole experience will make you hate the foodie friend who convinced you to participate in this crazy circus that is Mr Holmes Bakehouse.

Things to know before you visit the Bakehouse:
-Cruffins are available at 9am, but stickers to those waiting in line go out about 8:50am
-They make roughly 200 cruffins a day, but some of the 200 won't make the cut due to baking discrepancies and what have you, so it can be more or less depending on the day 
-Each person who receives a sticker can purchase up to 2 cruffins
-The flavor of cruffin served each day changes! The menu is posted on their website/IG
-There are two lines that form in front of the Bakehouse: one line for cruffin purchases ONLY and another line for all other pastries and merchandise.
-The box comes with the purchase of roughly six pastries, any less than that and they might just bag your pastries. A friend asked if she could buy a box but they said no.

Now I know what you really want to know: how early do I have to get there to guarantee myself a cruffin? There is no straight answer to that. Some days are busier than others. I can only share my personal experience. I arrived at 8:35am on a Saturday morning (they open at 8am on weekends) and immediately got in the cruffin line. There were already 30 people ahead of me.

I visited with two other friends. I had one friend hold our spot while my other friend came with me to take the obligatory Instagram pictures inside while it wasn't busy (I recommend this because once the cruffins come out it gets pretty packed in there). At 8:50am we each got a sticker guaranteeing our cruffin and by 9:10ish we had cruffin in hand. This line goes pretty quick because you can only purchase the cruffin in this line. Then we jumped in the other, much shorter line and bought some of the other delicious delicacies inside. I highly recommend the Ube Tart and the Blackberry Bostock.

I enjoyed every minute of this adventure because I was prepared with the help of my fellow Yelpers and I love food. The pastries are delicious. Delicious enough to justify the hype? That depends on who you ask but I think the hype is fun and all the people working at the Bakehouse are really warm and friendly so while the process might seem overly hipster I can assure you that the people working there are not! Good luck & happy eating!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Mr Holmes Bakehouse appears to be one of downtown San Francisco's most popular bakeries. I saw their iconic pastry boxes all around the area. 

My favorite pastries were their lemon curd cream filled doughnut and their cinnamon croissant. I also tried their chocolate cro-ffin which was a croissant in the shape of a muffin; it was certainly unique.
author: Joseph T.

description:
Cruffins are croissant muffins. 

Only 2 cruffins per person. Get in line at 8 am so you can get ready for them to come out at 9 am. They usually sell out between 10 and 1030. Different flavors every day. 

4 cruffins for $18. 
2 pastries for $8. 

They taste good but 1 hour 15 minute wait is not fun. 

They are opening some other locations like in Los Angeles.
author: Keith A.

description:
My sister dragged me here cause she was desperate for a cruffin. And the first time she came, they closed since they ran out of all their pastries! Why can't they just keep making more until it's actually time for them to close? So shady. They know how to run a business. 

We got here around 1130ish and of course, there was already a line outside. We got a strawberry jalapeño brioche bomb, a potato danish, and their le donuts. The donut flavors were vanilla lavender, guava earl grey, and raspberry cream. All were pretty good, but the vanilla lavender had a flowery taste to it, so not really a fan of that. My fave was definitely the potato danish. I really need to try a cruffin though. That's going to happen someday.
author: Tiffany T.

description: Delicious baked goods like the "cruffin" but always extremely crowdered with tourists who are trying to take a photo with/ of their "I got baked in San Francisco" neon sign.  Definitely worth the 5-10 minute wait in line and the chance to be rude to someone from middle America.
author: Ryan J.

description: A bit over hyped but still good. The coco nip bread was surprisingly delicious. The line can be long sometimes so be prepared. Cool Instagram spot.
author: L J.

description:
Everything here is so delicious and beautiful! I came for the cruffins, and arrived around 8:30am (since cruffin distribution starts at 9am). When you're standing in the line, you're so tempted to buy other pastries because they all look so good! The cruffin itself was amazing though and definitely worth the wait. My friend and I originally thought that the flavor that day was going to be chocolate cream, but it turned out, that was one of the donut flavors instead and the actual cruffin flavor was passion fruit. Check Instagram to see what the flavors that week will be! At first we were disappointed, but it was hard to stay disappointed after taking our first bites of the delicious pastry. The tangy passion fruit cream on the inside actually complimented the sweet, flaky croissant on the outside quite well. 

You can also get a nice box of you buy 6+ items, but it costs an additional $1.50 for it. The pastries are all pretty pricey too (and cruffins are $4/each), but they'd make a great gift since everything is presented so nicely. I highly recommend the cruffins as well as the mango cheesecake donuts!
author: Kathy C.

description:
It's a small bakeshop that's pretty easy to miss, but very cute decor inside.
 I liked the cruffin, but I'm sad they only offer one flavor. They had matcha and ube the day I went and I'm not a fan of either. The Cruffin itself was really good, though. Crispy and flaky, nice and messy. Maybe one day they'll consider at least two flavors daily, just in case.
author: Sanela S.

description: Walked past this place on a weekday morning at around 9:00am. There were about 7 or 8 people in front of us, and the line moves pretty quick.  Once you are able to be served, it's so hard to choose what you want because everything looks so good. I went with a cherry cruffin, and it literally exploded with flavor.  That first bite ignited a cherry filling explosion that I'm sure looked horrifying for all by passers as it went on my shirt.  Don't wait too long to eat for it can melt.
author: Max W.

description:
ABSOLUTELY FANTASTIC CROISSANT!!!! DREAMY DONUTS SO SOFT AND FRESH!!! Im not even a donut person, but wow so impressed!

Of so the cruffin. I expected to looooove it. How could you not a croissant and muffin hybrid?! But i found it too sweet personally (and i loooove sweets).   Its a sugar coated croissant texture with cream filling like the donut. Maybe the flavour i had the cream was too sweet? It was just alot with sweet cream and sugar coating and chocolate balls on top. That day the cream was cannoli cream. 

A few days later when i recovered from my sugar coma I tried their croissant and their ubi (probably misspelling) puff which is like a homemade pop tart with sweet plum filling. The ubi was pretty good the frosting was really unique and flavorfull just wish there was more plum filling (it was pretty empty :(  )


So in conclusion amaaaazing coissant, great donuts, ube puff was a nice lil sugary snack and cruffin was good but not as good as its hyped to be.


Something definitely worth mentioning is that they have an instagram account where they do a weekly post of both cruffin flavours and donut flavours.

Definitely going back to this place to try more of their pastries. Also worth mentioning the staff was very friendly and informative.
author: Sara Emily S.

description:
PSA re the lines:  So the way they mange the lines can vary, at least on the weekends, which is when I am there. One day they had merged the 2 lines!  ARGGHHH Since I didn't have much time, I had to leave empty-handed!  I think it was because they didn't have enough staff to run the cruffin-only line that day.

Another day they counted all the cruffins and gave everyone in the cruffin line a pink sticker, which was your guaranteed ticket to 2 cruffins.

Don't be afraid to ask the people in line what is the status of the line :-)  I would say at least half the people are cruffin virgins.

My next endeavor is to try to score some loaves of Tartine bread :-)  Wish me luck!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
AHHHHHH, a foodie's dream come true. I got to try the chocolate croissant and the dark chocolate salted mousse donut. Sadly, I didn't get to try the cruffin, but I will be back to try it. 

The donut is to die for. The dark chocolate and a hint of saltiness makes the mousse everything. The donut almost reminded me of a beignet- so fluffy and nicely sugared on the outside. I can't wait to be back, Mr. Homes Bakehouse
author: Linette F.

description: I've been to SF several times and each trip, I've missed my chance at getting 'baked' (goods) at Mr Holmes Bakehouse because I never made it before it closed. During my last visit, I made it a point to visit Mr Holmes before venturing out and all I can say is, I truly regret not visiting sooner. I ordered a cruffin and a churro croissant. Both were absolutely delicious! I did favor the churro croissant though, only because I love anything churro-like. This croissant was crunchy on the exterior but soft and warm on the inside with the most scrumptious tres leche filling (drool)!  I ended up going back the last day of my trip and getting a box of the churro croissants to bring back home because I knew I'd be craving them. There was a long line, but it goes by pretty quick.
author: Anna P.

description: Unfortunately nothing is gluten free, but I still had the best coffee there. And my non celiac friend really liked the croissant.
author: Laura N.

description:
Everything pretty tasty!! The cookies are greaaaat! I bought a few and a gallon of milk and watched the Matrix for the 20th time:)
Fell into a  tryptophan coma woke up and hammered down a matcha croissant:)
 Seriously, go check this place out.
author: Al T.

description: Follow them on social media to get flavor updates. Today, I was lucky enough to get the last macadamia nut coconut donut. Absolutely my new favorite!! Came here around 1pm on a Saturday since I didn't wake up early enough for their cruffins. No line at all. Thank God they still had donuts left. I'd definitely wait for this flavor again.
author: Gwen M.

description:
I REEEEAAALLLLYY wanted to like this place. My friends always rave about mr holmes and I had to try it. I came on Saturday morning around 9am and waited about 30 mins to get inside. I expected that there would be a wait so thats not the reason for the 2 stars.. My friend and I ordered the Thai tea cruffin, chocolate banana donut, Kahlua something donut, caramel apple bourbon square looking thing (LOL), and a cornflake cookie. Out of those 5 items I only really liked the cornflake cookie! The Thai tea cruffin wasn't very soft and the Thai tea flavoring was meh. I'm not a big fan of anything tasting like alcohol so I guess thats why I didn't like the kahlua donut and bourbon thing. I guess after the cookie I would say the next best thing was the chocolate banana donut. Their donuts remind me of malasadas! So maybe I would like them if I came on a day with a flavor I like.. 

So anyway,we bought six items so we got their cute box for free! The total came out to 23 for six items! A little pricey if you ask me. I'd have to say if I'm going to spend that much I'd rather go to b patisserie. But if I'm ever in the neighborhood and theres no line and theres a donut flavor I like maybe I'll give it a second chance.
author: Kelly S.

description:
The cruffins at Mr Holmes Bakehouse are well known and well photographed. Being a fan of baked goods and sugar, I could not wait to get my hands on a cruffin and get the whole "I got baked in San Francisco" photo experience. 

I came here on a rainy Sunday morning at 11am and, unfortunately, the cruffins were sold out. I should have followed the advice of other reviewers to come early, but the trip was not in the least wasted. I got the blood orange donut ($3.50), matcha croissant ($4), and bacon and onion danish ($4.50). While all of these baked goodies were delicious, the blood orange donut hit home for me. The sweet yet tart filling was oh so good and the flavor was not overwhelming. I definitely recommend the flavor. 

Although I didn't get a cruffin, I was pleased with the pastry selection. It's pricey but sometimes you just have to treat yo self.
author: Katie C.

description:
I"m not a fan of waiting especially in the cold so I decided to forgo the cruffin and sample a few of the different pastries they had. The donut flavors of the day were salted dark chocolate and white chocolate raspberry, i think it was raspberry but i forget. The donuts are soft and delicious and the filling is creamy without being too sugary which is good since the donut itself is covered in sugar. I didn't taste the salt part of the salted dark chocolate but oh well it was still good. The white chocoalte one was really good too but i'm always one to prefer dark to white chocolate. 

Other pastries:
-Cookie Dough bear claw: this one was ok. I wish it had more cookie dough
-Chocolate hazelnut croissant: sooooo good. My second favorite behind the donut.
-Regular Croissant: flaky and buttery. Yummy

I went on a sunday morning at 8:30AM and expected to see a long line for the cruffin but there was only a few people - maybe the cold kept folks away. Parking was super easy that early in the morning.

Price was pretty good. Definitely cheaper than tartine bakery. Coffee was also good.
author: Lisa D.

description: Every time I pass here it's got a crazy line so I just pass by. Today at 8ish no line. I was hyped and the first counter girl was pleased with my enthusiasm. I grabbed the matcha croissant and some shit I can't spell. Anyways the cashier was kinda grumpy after I said no ty to coffee and my total was 8$ for 2 smallish pastries.  Got home pretty tasty a bit on the small side and not nearly soft enough on the inside. Liked the hipster flavors matcha churro and lots of other varieties. Did not appreciate the attitude or the price.
author: nancy w.

description:
We came around 2:15pm and there were only a few pastries left since they closed at 2:30pm. There were sweet danishes (mango and coconut) and savory danishes (artichoke), though I believe they change what's inside them every now and then. I personally went for the Kouign Amann which was described as a caramelized croissant. It was enjoyable but cost $3.50 for a relatively small pastry; however, considering their limited supply and early closing, it makes sense why it's that way. They also sell tote bags among other things there.

I came here for the aesthetic of the "I got baked in San Francisco" sign and the shop was a lot smaller than I expected. It's really easy to walk right pass it too. Though we walked here, parking seemed like a nightmare as it always is around this area. I hear they're building a Los Angeles location which I'm stoked for since I'm super disappointed to not have gotten the change to try their cruffins.
author: Lily L.

description:
I'm actually not usually a pastries person (especially when it comes to breakfast) because I always crave savory food. Mr.Holmes lives up to all of the hype, the expectation, and the anticipation for me and I don't mind the sugar rush after stuffing down a donut and a cruffin in 10 minutes. 

TIP: Check Mr.Holmes' Instagram for weekly flavor updates. Cruffins flavors are as listed. As for donuts , the store tend to have two to three flavors even though there's only 1 listed online. Save yourself the disappointment and check the flavors before just in case you're not a fan of something. 

CRUFFIN PROCEDURES: 
Here's the lowdown for your weekday/weekend cruffin adventure: weekend lines are ridiculous. I would definitely recommend coming here on the weekday if you have time to snatch a cruffin. I've been here around 8:30/8:45 during the weekdays and there are no lines at all. I came here pretty late on a Sunday around 8:45 and the line was almost around the block. Cruffins come out at 9am and is limited to 2 per person (doesn't matter how many stickers they have). The store will give you a sticker as a number count for how many cruffins they made to how people are in line. Don't be discourage if you don't get a sticker! They tend to have leftovers (some people only buy 1 instead of 2 or there's extras) so stick it out until the end (unless you're really really late then yeah, sorry!)

TASTE: 
(+) Cruffin: As for the cruffins themselves, they're worth the wait and the hype in my opinion - even though I do agree with the argument that it's basically just a croissant baked in a muffin form. However, it is crispier than a regular croissant and definitely not as heavy as a muffin so I'm getting the best of both worlds! No complaints here. I've had the passionfruit guava and it's delicious. I prefer the cruffins over the donuts because there's not as much fillings in the cruffins so it doesn't overwhelm the pastry. 

(+) Donut: If you missed the cruffins line, I still recommend trying the donuts! I love how soft and light it is but the filling makes the whole thing pretty heavy for breakfast (& the sugar high!) . The matcha is my favorite but the blueberry jam and the vanilla ( + basically any flavors) will put all other donuts to shame. 

Besides the cruffins and donuts, the other pastries are also not short of expectations. The regular croissants and the bread pudding were spot on. You have to buy 4 things to get a box , or they'll charge you an extra $1.50. Everything is on the pricier side but hey - you gotta do what you gotta do for that Instagram shot!
author: Tram N.

description:
After having lined up early in the morning, I gotta say I have mixed feelings about this place.  First off, the lines are not that bad if you're just looking to get their regular pastries.  In fact the line on a Sunday morning was dead at one point for pastries.  As for the cruffin line, that seems to fill up, but at 9am, it didn't look like they had given out all the stickers which guarantee you 2 cruffins.  

As for what I sampled, some things were great while others were plain or not so great.

Cookies and Cream Cruffin
Loved the cruffin part, hated the filling.  I really didn't care for the flavor, but since I was in SF I had no choice since the flavors change daily and this was what they had that day.  I would pass on this flavor unless you like frosting,  The flavor is spot on, but it's a lot of cream.  The cruffin itself was great, it was like a croissant but on the heavier side.  I would've preferred a plain cruffin over this flavor if they had plain cruffins.  But for the wait, not sure if I would line up again for this.  It wasn't to die for great.

California Croissant
Probably my favorite thing here.  Got it fresh first thing in the morning.  It makes a great on the go breakfast.  The croissant was really light and flaky.  On the drier side.  But the salmon, nori, and ginger inside added some moisture and made the entire thing taste fantastic.  I loved the flavor, and it did remind me of eating sushi.

Ube Puff
Disappointing, I didn't much care for this one.  I thought there would be a stronger ube flavor, but it was pretty light.  It was a cool concept in writing, but the execution wasn't anything I was crazy about.

Raspberry Donut
Great donut, and fantastic filling.  I loved the raspberry filling they had.  The donut was light and tasty.  The filling wasn't too sweet, but there was a ton of filling.  It was almost borderline creamy and really reminded me of raspberry sorbet.  

Apple Honey Bostock
My least favorite thing that I tried.  It looked great, but didn't taste like anything special.  The outer crust portion was pretty hard compared to the rest of it and it tasted sorta burned almost.  There also wasn't too much apple to go with the rest of it.  

Overall, this place is probably worth the visit, if not for the cruffin, then for the California croissant.  The other items are pretty hit or miss.  Choose carefully since they're pretty pricey (most stuff are $4+).  Also if you're coming for the cruffin, check for what flavor is being offered, makes a big difference.
author: Bryson L.

description: I tried a couple of their pastries but the one that i felt that it was completely worth it was the matcha croissant. It was perfect crisp,fresh and although there was only matcha outside it was completly worth the hype. Overall the place is worth it the coffee is pretty good too. A litle overprice but is San Francisco after all.
author: Julia D.

description: Bought a box of pastries for the office and was pretty satisfied. I went for the cruffin but apparently they don't have them ready until 9am.  Also FYI they don't have seating really. I had the lemon hops filled donut. I'm not sure I've tasted hops out of beer before but it reminded me of caraway, a flavor I don't really like. Nonetheless the donut itself was so fresh and soft and delicious. I also had a nibble of the bread pudding loaf. The cacao nibs were a bitter balance but I would have preferred chocolate chips or nothing at all. I also had a little bit of the pear croissant pastry. This also was unique, with a combination of savory stuff with the pear. Bottom line good and very unique things, but if I go back I'll probably stick to basics.
author: Danielle B.

description: Cruffins and croissants were amazing! We didn't have a wait when we went around 10 am on a Saturday, but apparently that is a rarity. They were averaged priced. $30 for a box of 6 and 2 coffees. Four stars out of five because I wish there was a place to sit down and eat.
author: Olivia T.

description:
I have been to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse many times since it opened. I have to admit the cruffin is a rather unique idea (and definitely makes an awesome/hipster picture for Instagram and snapchat). A cruffin is a croissant in the shape of muffin and has cream filling in the inside. Mr. Holmes offers only one flavor each day for the cruffin. The best way to check the flavor of the day is to check their Instagram page. They start selling the cruffin at 9am each day. However, depending on the flavor of the day, the length of the line varies. Today (a Friday), the line for the Matcha Mallow was rather long at 8:30 already. Yet there were times when I didn't see a line until 9....

Aside from the cruffins, they also offer a variety of other pastries including doughnuts, croissants, danishes, cookies (no need to wait in line for these pastries!). If you weren't able to get the cruffin, just get the doughnuts instead. They used the same kind of filling. I suspect they probably reuse the cruffin filling because I have seen the doughnut filling being the same as the cruffin from a few days earlier.

Overall, the cruffin is an interesting idea. The outside is very crunchy and the inside has the same texture as a croissant. Aside from the shape, it is very similar to the cronut from Dominique Ansel in NYC. The rest of the pastries weren't that much of a surprise to me compared to other bakeries in San Francisco.
author: Ida L.

description: This is one of the best fresh Bakehouse in the city!!!!!!! So worth coming in early to skip the hrs of lines lol. But once you get your pastries you forget that you anxieties and have a great snack or desert!!!
author: Garrett P.

description: Yummy !! Croissant and danish are crispy and soft. l love bakeries that are not too sweet. These are totally on point . matcha croissant is delicious, I craved for that some days
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I've tried Mr. Holmes 3 times and each time I've really wanted to like it, but I've decided that it's just hype and I probably won't be back. 

If you are trying to get a cruffin you have to get in a separate cruffin line and they bring them out at 9:00am - not when they open, but at 9:00am. A little frustrating since I work in the area and can be in the bakery at 8:00am, but can't stay for cruffins since I need to be at work by 8:30am.  

This past time I went I really wanted to get one of the gorgeous boxes so I got 6 items (or you pay a certian amount to get the box). I picked out 2 of their donuts (white chocolate mocha and peppermint were the two flavors that day), a bread pudding, churro croissant and two regular croissants. After having a variety of their baked goods I'm not really impressed with anything. The bread pudding was very dry and very bland. The churro croissant was nothing to write home about - literally a croissant with cinnamon sugar on top. Not necessary to add the word "churro" to it. I didn't really enjoy the flavors of the donuts. 

I honestly think that a lot of the appeal of Mr Holmes Bakehouse is their gimmick-y rotation of flavors, the cronut and their aesthetics. Not worth the price point if you ask me! I'd rather go to b patisserie - just further up the street!
author: Samantha G.

description:
Got there at 8:30am on a Monday and we were the 2nd group in line. Waited about half an hour and it was totally worth it! The cruffin literally melted in my mouth and the flavor of the day was white chocolate cardamom. However, I wasn't a huge fan of the strawberry jalapeño brioche bomb. 

Tips: 
- The box comes for free if you order 6 items or you can just buy the box for a dollar more. Obviously we got the box of 6 . 2 cruffin max per person. No seating area in store.
author: Sumana K.

description:
I've dropped by Mr. Holme's Bakehouse several times with and without donuts depending on my luck. Good thing everything they serve here is quite good and everyone who works there are great!

Donuts are always good because every component is good: the dough, the amount of sugar coated, the cream, the cuteness. Every flavor I've tried (Vanilla, Lemon Poppy, Chocolate, Orange Cream, others) has been juicy. Obviously some are better than others depending on preference. What I can tell you is that I would never go for an Orange Cream donut but my friend gave it to me and I ended up really liking this donut 100x more than I thought. 

The Choux Bomb is decadent and kind of annoying to handle because it's fragile and needs to stay cool but it is worth trying. Very sweet and delicious.

Ube Puff Pastry was something I really looked forward to, but I was not interested in the tangy frosting/coating on the top of the pastry (I think it's blueberry?). Everything about the flavor was not familiar to me or what I expected based on what I know of ube (nutty, coconut milky) so I was personally disappointed. However, the puff itself is not bad. 

On the days I don't get to get donuts, I still order everything else.

In terms of savory, I've tried the California Croissant and the Onion Tart. The CA Croissant (California roll in a croissant) was interesting...smoked salmon, wasabi, and other things I don't remember. It was good! Onion tart was DELICIOUS! I would for sure get that one again.

Boisenberry Tart, Blueberry Bostock, and Kouign Amanns were all great. The Bread Pudding was a surprising, delicious surprise as it was juicy. The salted chocolate chip cookies were good, but too salty in my opinion. 

Overall FANTASTIC bakery that is pretty worth the hype, it's just that it's better to avoid the lines if you can. I have yet to try the Cruffins so I will be back FOR SURE.
author: Sofia R.

description:
I'll give it to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse for creating unique, trending pastries. The first time I tried Mr. Holmes was with my girlfriend since we were having lunch nearby and had mentioned to each other that we wanted to try their pastries. It was only around 12pm on a Friday when we walked up to the store only to see the infamous sign, "SOLD OUT." I was devastated. And when things like this happen to me, it only makes me want whatever the hell it is that much more. A nice man from inside Mr. Holmes saw how sad I was and gave us some "defected" croissants from that day, but DAMN THEY WERE SO GOOD. I could not believe these were defected. How? They were buttery, soft, flaky, a little sweet... Unlike anything I have ever tasted. I can only imagine what the non-defected ones taste like haha.

Fast forward to today... (11:30am on a Friday) They were open with pastries in tow and the line was very short. I happily got to try a variety of their Le Donuts, a Strawberry Jalapeño Brioche Bomb, and a Potato Danish. Their Le Donut flavors today were 1) Vanilla Lavender 2) Guava Earl Grey and 3) Raspberry Cream, which were all very delicious. I'm not really a donut fan, but their donuts are light and airy and don't leave you feeling disgusted with yourself! My personal favorite was the Guava Earl Grey since it had a fresh tanginess to it. The Potato Danish was my absolute favorite out of everything we got.

Clearly the place is adorable, the workers are really sweet and the vibe is fun and relaxing. I am dying for a cruffin though. I think those are next on my list. Can't wait to come back for that and to try their new flavors.
author: Debra T.

description:
Awesome bakery for unique baked goods including a sushi-styled croissant! If nothing else, people definitely are willing to make the trip all the way over here just to take a picture with the light up sign on the wall.

Parking around the area is pretty brutal, so I'd definitely recommend walking over or taking some sort of public transport, but this place is worth going to at least once if you're in the city!
author: Andrew T.

description: Sweet and crispy cruffins and croissants. However, these treats are not worth the drive- just if you're in the area
author: Jade L.

description:
I've tried twice prior to my experience yesterday to come to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse, but both times prior, they were closed by the time I arrived. Taking advice from all the other Yelpers, I made sure I was out of the house by 7 to make the hour long drive up to San Francisco. 

My boyfriend and I ended up getting there a couple minutes after the bakery opened on Sunday. Rather than trying to park on the street, we found a small parking garage just around the corner and just parked there ($3 every half hour, if anyone's curious). We stood in line for maybe 15 minutes before we got into the bakery and were able to purchase the regular baked goods. Donuts, croissants, danishes, etc. We filled up a box, which hold at least 6 items. This is super easy to do, and your money will be spent quickly, especially if you tack on some of their other merchandise like I did. 

After we had made our first round of purchases, we went back outside to wait in the line for the elusive ~cruffin~. We waited about half an hour, and we were maybe the 15th people back in line. At about 8:45 (they start selling cruffins at 9), someone from the bakery comes outside and hands out a sticker. If you get a sticker, then you know they have enough cruffins for you. Two per person, but if you're in a group you can pay together. For example, my boyfriend and I each had a sticker, so I just bought 4 at once. The flavors of cruffins change every day, and they post on their Instagram every Sunday for the coming week's flavors, so check there to make plans for a specific day, if you want a certain flavor. 

Everything ran super smooth and everyone was really nice and very helpful! Though the line really did start to build up at 8:40, so I'd definitely advise getting there early. 

In terms of merchandise, I bought a tote bag ($12), a coffee mug ($19), and a pin (I think it was $8?, I'm not 100% sure). They also had aprons that came with a pin ($35), and pre-packaged oatmeal. 

The cruffin was delicious, of course, but my favorite otherwise (of what I've eaten so far), was the churro croissant and my boyfriend *loved* the ferrero rocher croissant! I've got enough pastries left over to last me the rest of this week for breakfast, and I'm looking forward to trying something new every day! I loved my experience at Mr. Holmes and I'll definitely be back!!
author: Samantha V.

description: croissants was literally out of this world. Can't really put it into words. lines are long but very very cute & a must for sf
author: Julia D.

description:
Hey Holmey, how you doin? You see I got baked in San Francisco, but was it worth it? Nah.

I came to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse on a Tuesday and was the first person in line for cruffins! Whoaaaaaaa! Never thought that would've happened in years. Honestly, if I wasn't first in line, it wouldn't have been worth the wait. For one, I thought that there would be more than one cruffin option. NOPE. New flavors daily. That sucks because I'm not a big fan of chocolate and the flavor of the day was Chocolate Rye. Lame, it doesn't even sound appetizing. I was hoping for a green tea cruffin or creme brulee or something neat. The chocolate cruffin honestly was just okay. It wass comparable to pastries elsewhere. This place is just overhyped nonsense in my opinion and I think that The Boulangerie in Dallas/Village Baking is much better. There is such a low cream filling to cruffin ratio, and even though I got the cruffin right out of the oven it was very hard and tasted stale. It was a huge bummer.
I wish that this place met my expectations, but at least I didn't have to wait.
author: Violet H.

description: Well, I must say that I was so excited to know that there's Mr Holmes in my neighborhood. I've visited one in South Korea last Summer, had a very delicious Cronuts. However the Cronuts I found in this place is probably 1/3 smaller than those ones in S Korea. Taste? Mmm I shall say ok. It will probably take a little time for me to come back here.
author: Maki N.

description: Best croissant everrrr! Went on a Saturday morning luckily the crowd went away by the time we arrived. We ordered the matcha dipped croissant and  a raspberry mini croissant. I love the raspberry one! The outside is super crispy and flaky, not too overly sweet just the perfect amount. I would def go back for more baked good!
author: Kelly W.

description: A bit pricey but still very good. Some interesting twists on standards, and for some it's all new. Scotch egg v v good.
author: William M.

description: Worth the hype! Arrive just before 10AM on a weekday to get the last cruffins without waiting in line for more than 10 minutes. Also, wonderful selection of savory pastries!
author: Kimia M.

description:
I've had the cruffins twice. Both times they were just OK. The first flavor I had was fluffernutter and the second flavor was salted caramel. The fluffernuter didn't taste like a fluffernutter and the salted caramel was burned. I don't think I ever need to go back here, especially with the line. I think one cruffin is enough for two people - they have so much filling! The donuts aren't that great either.
I'm glad I went just to try it,  *obviously* had to be one of "those people" and get the pic with the neon sign, but the flavor of the pastries are not as good as the presentation.
author: Emma B.

description:
Ok, so two things I absolutely hate about Mr. Holmes: the absurd hype, and the intentional scarcity.

That's what leads to over 100 people lined up on a Friday morning by 9:10am. Cruffins come out at 9am, but I timed my arrival to 8:15am and I think it was a good choice - I was about 10th in line and was done with my purchase by 9:10. I doubt the people who joined the line after 8:40ish had a chance at a cruffin.

Unlike most places, I definitely blame Mr. Holmes for the hype because they purposefully produce scant quantities of their main item and only bring it out at one time every day... Even if they only want to produce X amount of cruffins each day, I think bringing them out in two batches (as in, one at 9 and one later) would give people more opportunities to get them. As it is, you only have a chance of getting a cruffin if you have the luxury of waiting around for long periods in the morning in the middle of a not-so-great area. So I hate that, and probably won't go back now that I've finally tried a cruffin... unless a friend from out of town is persuasive enough, perhaps.

That said, cruffins are pretty damn good. Very flaky on the outside, soft and fluffy on the inside, and the cream fillings have great texture. I was a little disappointed that the matcha dark chocolate cruffin fillings were mostly dominated by the chocolate cream, so I didn't taste much matcha, but that's not too huge of an issue. 

Their donuts are lovely as well, and they usually have more flavors than what is listed on their weekly Instagram posts. But they sell out almost as quickly as the cruffins! I think that's probably because their other croissants, Danishes, etc. are all items that could be found at other bakeries. 

And finally, their staff are usually great. Very quick and friendly, even when mobbed by the morning rush.

So, although I like to lead with the negative, I think four stars is a good approximation of my opinions toward Mr. Holmes - it could be a great experience if not for the limited quantities and long waits, so one star off for that. But I think it's definitely worth a one-time visit.
author: Delia Z.

description: It smells amazing in here. It smells like bakery heaven inside this small shop. This shop's specialty is its cruffins. The combination of a croissant and a muffin gives you the specialty cruffin! I believe they have a different flavor of cruffin every day. There's always long lines here since the goods are sold out pretty quickly, so it's best to come early to get your hands on the cruffin and any other pastries you're in the mood for. It might get a little crazy having to wake up early and wait in line, but getting to the front of the line, entering the shop and then feasting your senses on all the pastries is totally worth it! There's also a wall with lit neon lights where everyone takes a picture of themselves along with their box of goodies, which makes the experience even more worth it.
author: Brandon D.

description: With this place being one of the top Instagramable locations in CA, I had to make my way to SF! When I walked in, it was a lot smaller than I imagined. It was well maintained and clean. They didn't have a lot of variety when I came in, also because it was past 12PM when I went. I'm guessing the best time to go is close to opening? I ordered their classic donut with a lemon custard filling, that was really good! I also ordered their bread pudding which I was not a fan of, but everyone has different taste interests.
author: Goharik S.

description: Touristy place to get coffee and pastries in SF near city hall. They have a cute sign to take pictures in front of ! The pastries are amazing! There's no where to sit and eat so more of a grab and go type of place. Definitely worth checking out while in the city.
author: Jessica E.

description:
The California croissant was one of the best croissants / breakfast sandwiches I've ever had, and so I was so disappointed to find out it's seasonal! Other than that, the croissants are quite tasty, and the staff is friendly. 

They need to get better lids for their coffee, it was spilling all over my hands as I walked to work.
author: jenica b.

description: The matcha croissant and cruffins are the best!! Lines for the cruffins start early. I arrived at 8:45am on a Friday (15 min before cruffins are served) and there were already 10 people in line ahead of me. You are limited 2 cruffins per person and 1 box per person.
author: Wei P.

description: This place is good but it's $4-5 for a single pastry. Tartine doesn't even charge that much... Overall, it's good and might take visitors here but wouldn't wait in a long line, come often, etc.
author: Sarah M.

description:
So what the heck. This place is the best place ever. Completely lives up to the hype!!! The line took like 15 mins but it was definitely worth it :)) would come back so often if I lived closer! 

I got a chocolate hazelnut cronut and a cherry vanilla filled donut and they are seriously the best things I've ever tried :) idk how something can taste this good wtf. 

If you haven't been yet, GO GO GO!
author: Hayley D.

description: The cruffin (the croissant and muffin's love child) lives up to the hype! Just the thought of the decadent and sweet cream filling is enough to make my mouth water. Also tried the matcha croissant and the raspberry hibiscus kouign amann, which were both very tasty as well. The pastries are quite a bit pricier than I expected (the three came out to be ~$12!!) but all of them were spot on delicious.
author: Velinda L.

description: There was a line before they opened so get there by 7:55 to quickly be in and out. We didn't wait for the cruffins which comes out at 9:00 but low key regret it. Instead we tried the matcha dipped croissant and the pumpkin spice donut. I've never had such tasty matcha before! The croissant was flaky and buttery and the matcha was so creamy and sweet yet true to matcha-taste. The pumpkin spice donuts were also very yummy; the pumpkin spice custard filling was the perfect amount of sweetness, which was a pleasant surprise. I would definitely wait in line next time for the cruffins, but maybe on a warmer day.
author: Judy M.

description:
Bzzz! Bzzz! Bzzz!

That's what it sounds like when my alarm goes off extra early.  And if I'm waking up extra early, I'm probably trying to visit Mr. Holmes Bakehouse on my way to the office.  

Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is inconveniently located on Larkin St., meaning that if you're coming via BART, you need to brace yourself for an interesting walk through the Tenderloin district of SF.  If you're eying one of their precious cruffins, I suggest arriving bright and early.  If you plan on queueing at 9am for cruffins, save yourself the effort and try for an earlier start the next day.  I lined up at 9am once and literally the 2nd person ahead of me in line purchased the last 2 cruffins.  

I only purchase cruffins when I have a special visitor in town and I want to treat them to an exclusive SF treasure.  I've only successfully purchased 2 different types of cruffins. Cookie Dough and Passion Fruit, and I must admit, they're worth the hype.  Flavor and texture are on point. 

The donuts are also the best I've ever had, but I'm also very partial to filled donuts with custard fillings.  I have tried the passion fruit donut, bananas foster, and orange creamsicle donuts.  They should consider changing the name of the orange creamsicle because I was expecting something that tasted overly sweet and artificial and the flavor turned out to be anything but.  It was light, mildly sweet, and rich with the essence of orange zest which cut through the sugar and "dough-y-ness" like a delicious hot knife through equally delicious butter.  Without exaggeration, these are literally my number one favorite donuts in the entire world.

I initially discovered Mr. Holmes Bakehouse by searching for the best croissants in the city on Yelp.  The croissants are fantastic and it is very, very obvious in taste that they are made with high quality real butter.  Rumor has it that the butter is purchased from France.
  
If you're looking to get one of their signature white boxes, plan on purchasing 6 or more pastries, or paying an additional fee.  I'm not waking up early and queueing for anything less than 6 pastries so this has not been an issue for me.

Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is great, but it'd be even better if there were enough cruffins for everyone.  Also, this place is pretty pricey.  Expect to spend $24-$30 on 6 or so pastries.
author: David D.

description: The hype is real! By reading the Yelp reviews, my goal was to get in line by 9am to get a guaranteed Cruffin. Me and my lady got 2 stickers which means 4 Cruffins!!! The texture is unbelievably delicious. So flakey, crunchy and soft all at the same damn time. I believe we had the passionfruit and I think jasmine flavor Cruffin. Boy, was that amazing. We also tried the one with Salmon in it, 2 filled donuts (1 lemon and 1 dark chocolate), a berry croissant and a berry lemon one (YES, we ate it all.) It was our first time there, we might as well order almost everything there. My favorites were the Cruffins and the Salmon one. They start handing "guaranteed Cruffin stickers" at 9 so make sure to get there no later than that if you want a cruffin. 1 sticker = 2 cruffs. Just go check it out. SUPERB!!
author: Maikell B.

description: From out of town, was told by many this place was the spot. Got in early (9am) to take advantage of short lines as well as to get the cruffin of the day. Got the chocolate peppermint donut which really was great. My wife got the churro croissant which was even better! So then had high hopes for the Tai Tea cruffin and it completely fell flat. Maybe it was the flavor that day or maybe it was me being confused of what the true identity of this pastry I was eating, not quite muffin, not quite croissant. Disappointing because this was suppose to be the thing they were known for. However, the donut and churro croissant were delicious so overall, not a bad visit.
author: Ryan H.

description: This place is a must stop for SF visitors. The iconic sign and delicious treats. Expect a line for cruffins that come out at 9, there are limited quantities. Cruffin flavors are posted on their Instagram as well as for their donut. They have more delicious options other than the cruffin!
author: Brielle W.

description: Great pastries and top notch service. They're known for their cruffins but I actually think their other pastries are better. Donut fillings rotate daily and can be interesting. Lines are nuts on weekends so try to stop by on a weekday morning if you can.
author: Justin E.

description:
Finally got to try this place when a friend and I decided on a last minute hike in SF.
We got there fairly late in the day (around 11AM) so no more cruffins or cronuts =[ Didn't bother me too much because my main goal were the matcha cream donuts. And hallelujah they had matcha that day!!!
The donuts were delicious, flight and airy but at the same time chewy (how?!) The cream had a velvet smooth texture and were not too sweet at all. I could definitely use more of the matcha flavor tho.
4 stars because I still think paying $4 for a donut is a lil bit ridiculous, but it is definitely a nice treat!

Maybe we got lucky but parking was super easy (we parked 2 blocks away) and waited around 15 minute before we got our hands on these beauties.

Great spot for those of you who "do it for the 'gram" because they have a cute sign inside on a white bricked wall, and the pastries are definitely a photogenic bunch
author: Rose H.

description: Omg... had the Vegan cookie this morning and it was absolutely yummy!! They're bake goods are definitely the best around. The bakery is always clean and the staff is always welcoming. Definitely something you have to experience for yourself!
author: Delilah D.

description:
After a failed first attempt to come here last Thursday morning, I made three of my buddies wake up at 6am to join me in making the trip from sac allllll the way here. We arrived shortly after 8am. First thing you need to know are that there are two lines! One for their famous cruffins and one for their other baked goods. So make sure you come with at least one other person and make them wait in the cruffin line! They open at 8am but don't start selling cruffins until 9!

The bf and I got in the regular baked goods line while my other two friends waited in the cruffin line. Service was so friendly! They told us that we had to order 6 pastries at least to get the box. So being the basic people that we are, of course we got 6 pastries! Out of the 6, I recommend the chioux bomb (basically a cream puff), coconut cream donut, ube puff pastry, and the chocolate croissant! All the pastries range from 3-5 dollars a pop. My total came out to be 25 dollars. 

We exited the store and returned to our friends who were waiting in the cruffin line and switched places with them so they could line up in the regular baked goods line. It may look pretty long but it moves pretty fast because they got their pastries before the cruffins started selling!
