Out comes one of the workers at 8:50 and she explained that she would hand out one sticker per person to the people waiting in the cruffin line. If you manage to get a sticker, you're guaranteed two cruffins! She made it about three-fourths of the way down the block before she ran out of stickers. So if you come and you're after that point, you aren't guaranteed a cruffin :( 

Fast forward to when we actually got our cruffins. Omg they were amazing. The flavor of the day was "death by chocolate". You can find what flavors they offer for the week on their Facebook page! It was a bit messy to eat because of all the sugar so make sure you get napkins. The cruffin had so many fluffy layers and was filled to the max in the middle with chocolate cream. Delicious! Will I wait in line for an hour again? Probably not. But it's one of those things that you have to try if you're in town and it truly lived up to the hype for sure.
author: Cynthia T.

description:
The hype is pretty real. You really need to get there at least an hour before it opens. There is a line for cruffins and a line for regular pastries. Make sure you bring some cruffin buddies with you because you can only get 2 cruffins per person. Cruffins are served 1 hour after the bakery opens everyday so you're really waiting about 2 hours for these baked goods, but it defiantly is worth at least trying a few times. The wait goes by pretty quickly too if you have people with you or make friends with the people around you in line. 

The cruffins are different every day and they post online what their cruffin flavors are so you can decide if you really want to spend the 2 hours waiting for these delicious treats. The other baked goods are pretty good as well! Everything is super fresh and sweet without being overly sweet. I loved their strawberry jalapeño bombers (has a kick, so maybe not for you if you're not a fan of spice). Defiantly will be back to try the rest of their goodies!
author: Erika C.

description:
The cruffins are good. However, the flavors change too often and the hours and rules are strange to be able to purchase them. I am not too impressed by the other baked good options here. Also, this is a really small space and there is no seating. It's a cute little store though. 

I wish they would make more cruffins each day so that I could try them without waiting in line for an hour each time.
author: Lauren A.

description:
Finally decided to write reviews and I just needed to express my love for Mr. Holmes Bakehouse! All of their pastries are delicious. I have tried their California croissant, Ube Puff, Choux Bomb, and of course their famous cruffins! I went a couple months ago in August and drove an hour to line up at 8:30am. Despite it being a week day, there was already a line. The line doesn't really grow until around 9:30am, but if you're like me and want to have the best spot in line you should come early! 

There are two lines when you get to the bakery.
One for general pastries and the other for cruffins. The bakery opens first for general goods and an hour later for cruffins. Come with a friend so you can get some other pastries while waiting in line for the cruffins.

The California Croissant - delicious. I've never had a   savory croissant like this. If you love salmon and seaweed, this is the best croissant you'll ever have. So buttery and flaky. 10/10

Ube Puff - I got it since I thought the pink glaze was cute. The puff pastry was delicious and the filling was good too. You could taste the ube in the paste which was a good compliment for the glaze. I personally don't really like pies and got it to just try it out. If you like pies/tarts this is for you. 8/10

Choux Bomb - The best thing at Holmes hands down. I always return just for these. So good. The cream filling looks overwhelming but is actually not as rich as one would think. Beautiful and delicious. 10/10

Cruffin - The only day I came for a cruffin the flavor was Buttermilk Toffee. I was excited since the hype and line for cruffins has always been huge. They do look beautiful but taste wise I thought it was okay. The first couple bites are delicious, but then it gets
too sweet and overwhelming for me. Still delicious and I do recommend you try it anyway! I didn't mind the wait in line. 8/10
author: Nancy G.

description: Like most people who come here, I wanted to try the cruffin. Unfortunately, they were sold out. I also wanted to try the choux bomb, but they didn't have that either. The donuts looked too sweet, so I went with savory instead. I ordered the bacon and onion danish. It was crispy and flaky. I also ordered the cookie dough croissant (new item) since there was only one of those left. It was also very flaky and the cream in the middle wasn't too sweet. Both pastries were good, but I wouldn't wait in a line just to have them again. I'll come back to try the cruffins though. If you're here, make sure you take the obligatory picture with the neon sign.
author: Helen H.

description:
Recently tried their kouign-amann, gotta say not bad.. but def still prefer the ones from b patisserie 

The filling is great, light and not too sweet. 

Great green tea croissant, cornflake cookies, omg !
author: Hester D.

description: Unsanitary conditions here. I saw a roach inside the bakery and the staff was too busy to do anything. They said, "we can't chase every bug"!
author: M D.

description: Okay. I went in for 1 cruffin and came out with a whole box of goodies! The cruffin was delicious as expected. BUT, can I just talk about their chocolate chip cookies for a second?!?! AMAZING. By far the best chocolate chip cookie I have ever had. I will definitely be coming back next time I visit San Fran!
author: Krista D.

description:
We cane there during a visit in SF, that place looked amazing on yelp. We came there around 9am on a Sunday. There was a line but according to the pictures on yelp we decided its totally worth the wait. There were only 3 people in front of us and one of the employees stepped out saying they are out of cruffins and it was only 9am.
We decided to grab their donuts and matcha croissants which looked amazing but honestly didn't worth the price paid. All their items cost at least $5(like a plain croissant) and we had way better bakery items from way cheaper bakeries. We got like 2 boxes of stuff and just threw away almost the full second one. 

They had donuts filled with something hazelnut and some cream with lemon and nobody from our family enjoyed those, the lemon ones were not good at all.
The only item that was kinda good was the chocolate croissant and we ate all of it but it is still was super expensive, over $5 a piece.
Now we know...
author: Anna A.

description: The best bakeshop in the city.. everything is sumptuous.. just have to wait for certain time lines are short
author: Nina S.

description:
Baked good are amazing. The line was a bit of a wait. Front end store employees are your typical hipster douche bag variety. 
 
Don't go on the weekends. Kind of a "tourist" spot for people who live in San Francisco.
author: Angelina G.

description:
Oh those cruffins. I never thought the taste could match the hype but they did. They really did. We got to Larkin Street and could see a few blocks away that the line was already formed. We thought we didnt have a chance at the cruffins but luckily we were just ahead of the last folks to be given the stickers that guarantee you 2 cruffins (should you decide to buy that many). 

We also got milk chocolate filled donuts and they were really good. Somewhere between a bomboloni & a stuffed malasada. It's filled to the gills with chocolate cream or whatever filling the decide that day. It was really good. The ferrero rocher choux bomb ($4) was a little disappointing as I love ferrero. It was just too sweet and the texture wasnt for me at all. I would pass on that. It looks great. It just didnt do it for me. The chocolate cream with cacao nibs cruffin on the other hand DID do it for me and it was delicious. The filling was great. The outer croissant vessel that held the cream filling was flaky and sweet. It was really good. I really liked it and I didnt expect to dig it that much.

Line for the cruffin forms to the left if you're facing the doorway. Line to the right is for all the pastries except cruffins. The purpose of the line for the cruffin is that there are only 50 of them made each morning. If you are in line and get a sticker, you are guaranteed 2 cruffins. If people in the line only buy 1 then the ones towards the back get a chance at em. But of course the line has to go through everyone that has a sticker first to see how many cruffins are left, if any, are available for purchase outside those that were guaranteed. Got it?! Good! 

Street parking only. Staff is super cool. Coffee is available. I've gotta get that california croissant next time. Next week, actually... Cant wait. Hope the flavor of the day on cruffins and donuts is a great one. See you on Larkin...
author: Chuck D.

description: I waited for about 40 minutes for something I felt was just hype and felt it to be trendy to want to feel you gotta have it.  Had better not worth the hype in my opinion.
author: Ralph A.

description:
All their croissants or cruffins are delicious and you can't go wrong with either selections. I chose to have the matcha croissant and the chocolate croissant which was very good for breakfast. I would recommend going there very early in the morning (preferably before 11AM) since they sell out pretty fast.

Great for weekend breakfast to go and for gifting to friends from out of town. It's a tough place to park and the neighborhood can be unattractive to out-of-towners.
author: Alan L.

description:
Woke up early to get in line for the cruffin on a Saturday morning. I got there a little after 8 am and I was probably 5th in line. The bakery has two lines and they are clearly marked. The left one is for the cruffin which they don't start selling until 9 am. The right side is for all their other bakery items. 

My bf and I split up in line so we could eat some bakery goods while we waited for the cruffin. If you order 6 items, you get a box. Otherwise you just get your pastries in a little bag. I had the Ube pop tart, two of their donuts and a pastrami Danish. The Ube tart was hands down my favorite. Super flakey with an Ube filling topped with a raspberry glaze! It was so amazing that we went back to get another one. There were two donut flavors that day and they rotate flavor so check their Instagram. We had the cherry almond and a mixed berry. The cherry almond was really good!! Not only is the filling flavorful, the donut itself was fluffy! They had a few savory danishes, but this one was recommended. It was super flaky and the filling was good, but I'm more of a sweets girl. 

Now onto the cruffin...They start handing out stickers in order to know how many people will be able to get one. By 9 am, the line wraps around the block! The flavor was rose champagne and it was beautiful. Literally so pretty, I didn't want to eat it. The filling was delicious and the outside was super buttery and flaky. 

I'd say, try the cruffin at least once but get the Ube tart and donuts! Literally everything else was amazing so you're not missing out either way.
author: Vy T.

description: Great food and service. Every time I come here the employees are always super nice, greeting me and asking me if I need help deciding what to get which is definitely a plus. I always end up getting the cruffins (of course) and the crossaints and they're always super good, even when saving them for later! The cruffin flavors always change but so far I've tried the matcha and black sesame as well as the pink lemonade too and both were amazing! If you aren't a morning person, I definitely suggest coming on a slower day like a Monday or Tuesday. I came both days at around 11-12 and they still had cruffins! A must try :)
author: Cee H.

description:
My girlfriend and I stopped here during our trip to San Francisco because she had heard so much about it and Im never one to turn down a good baked delight. I got their donut of the day, a mint cream donut, and my girlfriend got a churro croissant. The donut itself was great, however I was not a huge fan of the mint filling, just didn't have a great taste to me. The churro croissant was quite good and actually enjoyed it a bit more than my donut. 

It's a nice little place and there was no line for us when we went during the mid morning of a weekday. The staff was nice and had a good presentation of what they had for the day. I would definitely want to try them again and hopefully maybe get a donut better suited to my liking.
author: Peter M.

description:
OH MAN!!! You gotta come stand in line for this baked goodness. I was fortunate to get some cruffins on a Saturday morning. I showed up just after 9 and the line was probably 40 people deep. It took probably about 20 minutes to wait in line, but yes. I also had a chocolate chip cookie and maybe an amelie amann (some name I can't remember, but was great)

I will always make sure to come by this place to get some tasty baked goods whenever in town. Get here maybe 15 minutes before they open to make sure you get what you want (the daily cruffin). Whatever the flavor, I'm sure you'll love it.
author: Justin W.

description: Found this place around the corner from the apt of this guy I was seeing for a short time.  Too bad it was at the end of that. The Bavarian cream croissant donut, not the guy.  The cronut was memorable, guy...not so much.
author: kim t.

description:
Okay, so where do I begin?! I LOVE MR. HOLMES BAKEHOUSE! And yes the line is long all the time and the hours are a bit strange and could be inconvenient, but it's all worth it in the end when you devour your pastries!!!!

It took me two tries to be able to buy cruffins and the second time I went, I arrived at around 9AM to see that there was already a line outside. (I went on a weekend, so the line was to the left, if you're facing the store, but apparently if you go on a weekday, it's to the right). If you get a sticker, that means you're guaranteed to buy cruffins. The limit is 2 per sticker per person and the flavors are posted weekly on their Instagram (@mrholmesbakehouse). 

Do not be bummed if you miss out on the cruffins, because honestly, their other pastries deserve the amount of praise and recognition as the cruffins get! They have the best chocolate chip cookies I've ever had! I love how they add sea salt on top, it gives the perfect balance between sweet and salty. I'm also a fan of their croissants and their California Croissant is a must try! You have to get 6 pastries in order to not get charged for the box.

Their "I Got Baked in San Francisco" is a super cute light up sign that is so Instagram worthy, but it's really difficult to take a picture with it because the bakery is so small and cramped. I can't wait until they open a location in Los Angeles in March (source: eaterLA)!
author: Chanel H.

description:
The experience overall was good. We went around 10:30am on 4th of July so it was nice that the line wasn't too crazy. The place is cute and "Insta-ready". 

I appreciated the vibe, and style, but didn't even try to ask for a cruffin - If you don't stand in line at dawn - forget it, you're not getting one.

Here's the thing - We ordered 4 pastries, and truly liked only 1; their butter croissants. We ordered a couple of butter croissants, 1 prickly pear donut (their only other option was orange pilsner), a chocolate chip cookie, and their butter toffee cookie.

The butter croissants were nice and silky. They're made with french-cultured butter, similar (but not as delicious) to a true Parisian croissant. Thumbs up.

The doughnut - sorry - was gross. Legit milky peptobismol lol - Not even the churro-style donut could recover from that filling. Thumbs down.

The cookies. The butter toffee cookie was nice - Not too sweet, but a bit too snickerdoodle-ish. The chocolate chip cookie had tons of chocolate chunks, which I liked, but! they're way too excited with their salt. They use salt slivers on their cookies, so the first bit tasted like I dipped my beautiful cookie in the ocean. Once I removed them, the cookie was bomb. Thumbs...up?

I'm all for cute cool new spots in the Bay - Totally was expecting a 5-star kind of review and pastries to legit die for, but, I landed at 3.75 stars, aka, 4 stars.
author: Charo F.

description:
We arrived at 9:30 and there was already a line for cruffins. Definitely need to be here around opening time or they'll run out. We ended up getting three cruffins along with a ham and cheese croissant, monkey bread, and a donut. The bakery may be known for its cruffins but we felt as if it ended up being overhyped. They were definitely delicious and unique, but a lot of the other bread was just as good or better. It wasnt as worth for the half hour wait in the cruffin line as the wait for other breads. Would definitely return to try the other types of cruffins though but the highlight of our trip was definitely the croissant. 
The boxes are pretty nice though swag
author: Stephen L.

description: The matcha croissant is amaaaaazinnggggg!!!  Went on a Thursday around 9:30 and there were about 4 people before us... it's didn't take very long and the lines do appear longer since it's a small shop. We got the coffee chocolate croissant, a cruffin, and matcha croissant... They change the cruffin flavors daily so you're always in for a surprise!
author: Dee G.

description: We discovered Mr. Holmes from a friend's ig and have been wanting to try it ever since. We had some time to kill and waited approximately 40 minutes in the 90 degree heat for Mr. Holmes and it was all worth it! We wanted to leave the line a couple times but the aroma from the bakery and the happy faces carrying Mr. Holmes boxes kept us there. We had donuts and croissants and they were pure perfection and are not overly sweet and the flavors are not overwhelming. The matcha croissant was super flakey and buttery and reminded us of pocky sticks. The donuts were soft and spongey. The California croissant was the perfect amount of savory to counter our sweets. However, everything was messy to eat. We ended up getting sugar and croissant flakes everywhere but didn't care because it was so good.
author: Helen L.

description:
Worth the hype! I had a matcha white chocolate croissant and a Parmesan summer squash pastry. The summer squash was my favorite.
I skipped the famous cruffin since I'm not a huge fan of overly sweet things but my roommates got them and loved them!
author: Aly S.

description:
I can't believe this was my first time at Mr. Holmes Bakehouse! this bakery n pastry shop has been featured on numerous food shows. that probably helps in making this an official foodie rest stop! n that also makes it a damn hard place to get the pastries u really want. : / yes, we bought into the hype. 

the shop is really tiny. it's not a sit n enjoy slowly kinda place. there r no tables. no bar area. it's strictly a buy n leave shop. (no wonder the line gets so long in the mornings!)

we didn't get to Mr. Holmes til after lunch so they were already very low on their items. there were only 3 piles of pastries behind glass. it was pretty sad. (for me, not them.) well, since we were already there, we bought anything they had left. (desperation to join the hype.) 

Cranberry Pecan Danish : de-licious! so happy with it. it was crunchy n soft. the layers of pastry was exactly like a croissant which i LOVE. I  should've bought another for tomorrow morning's breakfast. 

Chocolate Chip Cookie : huge n also good. it's the crunchy kind. not the chewy kind. was still pretty fresh.
author: Julie W.

description:
My cruffin experience summed up: so close, yet so far. Couldn't get myself to Mr Holmes Bakehouse until half past 9. Too late! I watched the 2nd person in front of me order the last cruffin of the day. 2 max per person. Separate line for cruffins. All was not lost.. i just hopped into the regular line for other goodies.

Don't miss:
-Donuts: Flavors of the day were orange poppyseed and vanilla. Not too sweet and indulgent thick custard filling. IN LOVE with these. 
-California Croissant: I wasn't sure what to expect. Came with a to go packet of soy sauce. Surprisingly delicious. If you have an adventurous palette, why not!

Ones i'd probably pass on next time:
-Strawberry Jalapeno Brioche Bomb
-Pepper Turkey Pesto Danish
-Artichoke Bechamel Danish
author: Samantha L.

description: This bakehouse was so much simpler than I thought. It was only a small room with the famous neon sign that you see on basic girls instagrams all the time. They only serve pastries and coffee (no espresso drinks), both are worth the trip.
author: Brendan L.

description:
I've honestly never heard of this until the infamous sign blew up all over Instagram. Come to think of it, I've actually never seen photos of their baked goods and pastries on Instagram at all. Just that neon pink sign. Well, might as well give it a try since I'm in the neighborhood, right? 

Oh, there's... A line. Well, alright. It must be good. While waiting in the 30 minute long line - I mean, I had nothing else to do - people were coming out with bags and boxes full of treats. Ok, really now, this place HAS to be amazing. I finally get inside after waiting in the blistering cold to find a pretty decent amount of items to select from. It ranged from cookies to croissants to cruffins (that's a croissant/muffin hybrid, for those of you who were curious). My favorites were the pastries dipped in white chocolate matcha. 

Trying out the food was alright. I wasn't really blown away as much as I would've loved to. I mean, come on, I waited for 30 minutes. But I appreciate how different their pastries are. Who would've thought to mix matcha green tea with white chocolate and dip a croissant in it? Or make a muffin out of a croissant? Genius. But was I impressed? Eh.

TIP: If you want to snag some baked goods and then take your photo under the sign, I highly suggest you take your photo while you're still waiting to be served inside. Taking these photos really just attributes to the ungodly wait for overpriced food.
author: Carl Vincent C.

description:
Amazing customer service.

We had a small mishap with our order. The owner Bridget was so nice in taking care of us once she found out. Great food and great owner!!
author: Jason L.

description:
So the cruffin is a thing -- a deliciously flaky, custard-filled, tasty croissant-muffin thing. We waited in line for about 20 minutes, which is about as much as I would wait for a pastry. 

Service was delightfully friendly, the array of baked treats is simply displayed, and the line moved well. All they do is pastry and brewed coffee, so don't expect anything else, which is fine by me. Pastries include the cruffin of the day (flavors rotate daily; check social media), a filled doughnut and cookies. The biggest delay might be the selfies taken in front of the glowing neon sign that reads "I got baked in San Francisco" -- cheeky, right?

I discovered Mr Holmes Bakeshop via local social media before my San Francisco trip. Whatever they've been doing, it's working.
author: Logan A.

description:
Came here around 730AM on a weekday morning, determined to beat the line. It was only 5 people deep when we joined, but even worse than a wait - they don't start selling cruffins until 9AM. As the salesgirl explained, "we don't sell cruffins before 9AM and that has neeevverrr changed." No, I've never been to Mr Holmes Bakehouse before so how would I have known that, and after that attitude, I'm not coming back.

We still ordered the peach cobble sweet danish and 2x raspberry hibiscus kouign amann. These were both tasty - I thought the flaky layers on the danish were spot on. I've also never had a filled kouign amann, although the hibiscus flavor didn't quite come out. However, both are tiny for the $4 price tag, so expect to be spending more than that.
author: Stella A.

description:
We live in the era of cruffins and cronuts, but do they really live up to their hype?

During my first visit here, I just got regular pastries, such as the different kind of danishes and croissants because they had run out of all the popular items around 11am on a weekend. Enjoyed the savory pastries more than the sweet ones here, but felt like they were pretty overpriced. Did the quality justify the price? It depends on what you get.

Came here for the second time 9am on a Monday, and waited around 15 minutes. This time around I ordered all of the supposed hyped pastries, such as the cruffins, filled donuts and california croissant.

Cruffin: Flavor of the day was Matcha Green Tea. Score. I love matcha green tea flavored stuff, but I have to say I was actually pretty disappointed in the cruffins as it was basically just a croissant overly coated in sugar, filled with custard like fillings, and baked in a muffin mold. The taste could be described as if someone accidentally spilled a pound of sugar on it. Also I have tried the cronut in the east coast, and felt that cronuts were superior to cruffins. I guess I expected to be something mind-blowing, however, the cruffins are definitely aesthetically pleasing and instagram worthy. Would I wait more than 30minutes for these suckers? No. Or at least, not anymore. But if you have a sweet tooth, go for it, tiger. 

Donut: Got the blueberry-cheesecake filled donut. I like this one because I just love custard filled donuts in general... but again, that excessive sugar coating took away from its taste and elegance. The filling reminded me that of Beard Papa's cream puffs. 

California Croissant: Inside the croissant, there is a seaweed wrapped smoked salmon? and more than generous amount wasabi (or similar downed version of wasabi paste). The croissant itself was suuuuperrr flaky and crispy, which me gusta. It surely was an interesting item to try, but I wish there was more of the salmon and less of the wasabi inside.

Overall, I recommend this bakery to try different pastries. Definitely check out their instagram for flavor updates and try to come on a weekday morning to avoid the super long line.

Do it for the insta. hah.
author: Solongo B.

description:
I never waited in line for the cronut so I only find it fit to wait in the cruffin line when visiting SF.

CHECK SOCIAL MEDIA - cruffin and donut flavors updated are posted there.

CRUFFIN - it was disorganized the day we got there. They said there are normally signs. We got there before the bakery opened. Once they opened there is one line for cruffins (and they're sold at 9am so you have to wait in line) and everything else. The everything else line moves quickly. Prompts for selling it efficiently. When it's close to 9am, they start passing out stickers so you'll know if you'll get one for sure. Also, there is a separate process to purchase the cruffins so the lines don't get tangled. You only get a box if you're buying more pastries.

One of us waited in the cruffin line while the other grabbed food in the other. Of the other items, I liked the ube turnover, California croissant (no soy sauce). The other ones were all really similar - different toppings in flakey pastry. I didn't like the chocolate mint cruffin that much - it would've tasted better if there was no sprinkled sugar. The cruffin crunch is incredible. 

Would I stand in line again for the cruffin? Nah.
author: Irene H.

description:
Super cute bakeshop that will always have a short line of people waiting for their cruffins = croissant + muffin. But everything else here is also super delicious. And come on, "I got baked in San Francisco"? best slogan ever. The fillings for their donuts, cruffins, and other pastries change often, so be sure to ask what's being sold day of. 

They start selling their famous cruffins 1 hr after opening each day. There's a limit of 2 per person, so if you're buying for a group, don't just go by yourself. Typically there's are two lines, one for cruffins, and one for other stuff. Show up 30 min early and get in queue. If you have a friend, I recommend buying some other stuff that you can munch on while in line. 

Their stuff is just BEAUTIFUL. From the decor of the shop, to the carryout box (if you buy 6 or more pasteries), to the pastries themselves. Literally had a mini photoshoot after I came home. 

Anyways, what to get:

Strawberry/Jalapeno brioche bomb (5 stars): AMAZING! So moist and filled, no overflowing, with this sweet and spicy jelly and topped with some sugar crumble to give it some crunch. Ate this while in line and was so sad when a clump of jelly fell to the ground. Definitely one of the best.

Choux Bomb (4 stars): I don't know what flavor but this was a great pile of cream on moist shortbread textured scones? cookies?? Honestly, I thought it was going to be hazelnut/chocolate flavored and was disappointed when it wasn't - but still delicious for what it was.

Sugar coated donut (4 stars): Flavors of the day were peanut butter and lavender caramel. These donuts are literally oozing with filling. Forget taking the first bit to only get a mouthful of fluffy dough. The cavity in these is so large that there was too much filling for rest of the donut! The lavender caramel itself was too sweet and heavy for my personal taste though very uniquely flavored. My guess is some people might be turned off by it, but it was certainly different. 

Cruffin (4 stars): Rocky Road was the flavor of the day. much like the donuts, these was stuffed fairly full with whatever filling they have. The rocky road happened to be chocolate pudding with some nut clusters and homemade marshmellows. I wished there was a little more "oomph" to it though, some of the cruffins were filled with almost pure chocolate pudding - nothing too special. The cruffin itself is flaky and coated in sugar. But it doesn't quite have the buttery fluffiness of a croissant since it's baked - comes out more like a danish.

While I wasn't blown away by the cruffin, I definitely think it's worth trying. I also think the filling flavors make a HUGE difference in the eating experience. And don't skip the other stuff too!
author: Liza X.

description:
Ever since my first visit to now world famous Dominique Ansel Bakery in NYC turned my culinary life on its head (http://www.yelp.com/biz/dominique-ansel-bakery-new-york) I've been on a quest to find something that even comes close as a comparison. Having heard that the folks over at Mr. Holmes Bakehouse here in San Francisco had invented a Cruffin, I opted to give it a go, and I'm glad I did. 

Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?

Mr. Holmes has reached that point where you should now expect a lengthy line more or less every single day, but know that it's because the goods here are just that sensational. It's small, it's cramped, and the line is forced outside after no more than five or so people, but the warm and friendly service once you're inside will have you forgetting that you may have just spent 45 minutes of your morning waiting. Star Granted. 

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

$4.50 for a (huge) Cruffin and $3.50 for a (smaller) standard donut. These prices are more than fair considering these are the definition of specialty goods in what is a very expensive city. Star Granted. 

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

Wow. Okay. Let's start with the Cruffin, which was seriously amazing. The flavor of the day this Saturday was Peppermint, which really kicked my holiday spirit into overdrive, and the flaky croissanty exterior blended perfectly with the smooth peppermint custard. Delicious. 

While I didn't think it could get any better, the Salted Caramel Donut very honestly put the Cruffin on the back burner. This would have been a flawless donut if it were empty on the inside, but the salted caramel was sensational, and was the take away of the day as I see it. While the selection isn't near what you find at some of the larger bakeries around the world, the quality was absolute top tier. Dual Stars Granted. 

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

Yes. Dual Stars Granted.
author: Paul V.

description: Came here on a Friday morning around 8:30am. Cruffins were still baking and so I decided to wait in the car. Went back to the store around 9ish am and there was a line. Oh wow. Let's see. Simple decor, lots of pastries to choose from. There was only a young man working and he took time to greet and talk to customers. Yes, every customer and that's about 3-5 or more minutes. No wonder there is a line. Great that they are taking time time chit chat and check in with customers but all I want was to get my pastries. And so, when it was my turn I got two cruffins of course, a matcha tea croissant and two pear danish. Love love the pastries. I only wish the cashier would spend maybe a minute less with each customer and the line could then be faster!!!
author: SevLong L.

description: Always always always show up early (9am) if you want the well known items on their hit list. I learned the hard way. First I showed up too early so they didn't have the cronuts out. Then I came in a bit too late and they were wiped out. But all around bomb place! I love it so much that I always have to get either half a dozen or a full dozen just so I can get the cool box to go with it! Makes the picture look better :)
author: Nick A.

description: BEST CROISSANT EVER! Just the fact that it was dipped in matcha makes it ten times better. It was flaky and crispy and the matcha did not make it soggy and gross. It wasn't too sweet! My friend got the famous cruffin and it was so good too! Don't have that picture but would highly recommend stopping by, it's not over hyped!
author: Vicky L.

description:
we ll today i went to 3 different bakeries in downtown and this was one of those  !!!!
i got a cookie and savory boudin. 
 cookie:  i found it good but not sensational (mediocre)
 savory boudin :  tasted a little greasy maybe because i accidentally bought the savory instead of  the sweet one( which i think could be  less greasy).  i did not like it very much.
but the ingredients that they use i can tell that are decent  quality 
for sure i am going back again to try other pastries !!!!
author: Cecilia C.

description: I don't need to go on and on about how great this is but it is !!!!!! My favorite is this circle banana thing ... I don't remember the name of course because I was in heaven.
author: stephany m.

description:
Bummed cause we went in early at 7 am, and their cruffins don't come out until 9 am. Either way though, great pastries and customer service. It's super small, so expect to be waiting outside. Then it may be difficult to get your picture with the "I got baked in SF" sign lol. Parking is cool early cause meters aren't enforced until 9 am.

We got the vanilla donut, bread pudding, chocolate croissant, and California. The vanilla donut was excellent, light donut and good custard. Bread pudding was really good if you are a bread pudding fan. Chocolate croissant was okay... Pretty basic. I felt the same about the California, which has salmon, nori, etc (like sushi). I was curious if because we came in when they opened, not all of their items were baked fresh. Possibly day old? Either way though I still recommend stopping in, maybe around 9 am when they have all of their pastries ready. Your picture with the sign will look better in the daytime too. Early am is not good lighting for a photo lol.
author: Brandon F.

description:
So, so, so, so good! One of my favorite bakeries in the city, and I've been to several, so that's saying a lot. I got in line at 8am on a Saturday for the famous cruffins, and though that wait in the cold and windy SF air was not the most appealing, the cruffins were absolutely worth the wait.

While in line, I purchased a couple of other pastries to snack on while in line - I had the choux bomb and an ube puff, and both were absolutely amazing. The choux puff was basically like a super huge cream puff filled with a delicious hazelnut cream. Tasted like an oversized Ferrero Rocher truffle in cream puff form. The hazelnut flavor was absolutely wonderful - I could eat that cream by itself everyday if I could.

The ube puff was one of the most unique pastries I've ever tasted, but it was a wonderful party in my mouth. I love yams in general, and the purple yam filling was great because it had the yam taste without being too sweet. The prickly pear icing was sweet and tart and perfect accompaniment to the purple yam.

But the star of the show... the CRUFFINS were the best things I've ever tasted. The flavor of the day was chocolate earl grey, and the filling was so amazing - not too sweet with the perfect hint of tea from the earl grey. The cruffin, somehow, tasted so flaky and crispy and better than any croissant I've ever had. I tried one of the cruffins right after we purchased it, so it was fresh from the oven, but they also taste delicious after putting it in the toaster for a couple of minutes if they go cold. 

Remember that you can only get two cruffins per person per day, and they come out everyday starting at 9am... weekends, people start lines at 8am and weekdays is probably around 8:30am. Regardless, I would say that the cruffins are totally worth waking up and waiting for - they're out of this world.
author: Sheila D.

description: Superb!!! Great bake/color on their beautiful products. The churro croissant is an absolute MUST. You will not be disappointed, but you will need a napkin.
author: JENNIFER D.

description:
Thank you Mr. Holmes for making cruffins. These yummy treats were worth the (short) wait. We got here around 8:45am and received a pink sticker with their peace sign logo shortly after. Each sticker guarantees two cruffins per person. While the bf stayed in line, I wandered into the bake shop to get some of their other good looking pastries. And of course, we dived into them in the 15 minute window before the cruffins come out. 

The Kouign Amann had a great texture. Super crisp and flaky, however, the flavor of pistachio in this pastry was a bit lacking. 

The California croissant was also extremely flaky but a bit softer than the Kouign Amann. What makes this a standout was the filling! This croissant was filled with smoked salmon, seaweed and wasabi. This combination was unique and quite tasty. I just wish they had more of the filling than just one little dollop in the center.The packet of soy sauce on the side was a cute touch. We didn't get a chance to pair with the soy sauce since that would make a mess. 

Finally, the cruffins! The cruffins for the weekend was peppermint. Normally I am not a fan of peppermint, but this was yummy! The peppermint flavor was pleasant and the pastry had just the right sweetness! I love how the cream was filled evenly throughout giving the perfect bite of flaky and creamy each time. 

Wish they reheated the pastries and also maybe leave a trash can outside for those who can't wait to eat them!
author: Eva I.

description: I had been meaning to swing by here for a while. It is as good as people have said. Had the pastrami croissant, which sounds weird but is quite good. Has pastrami, cheddar, onion and what looked like a little pineapple in it. Fantastic for breakfast along with their chocolate cruffin. The only down sides are all of the people who seem to come in just to take selfies and the kind of bitter coffee typical of hipster places.
author: Will L.

description:
Definitely overhyped for me, but it is an Instagram worthy bakery. I mean, who could resists taking a picture of your beautiful croissant under the "I got baked in San Francisco" sign?

I did enjoy their pastries but nothing for me stood out. The pastries are also REALLY good fresh so enjoy them as soon as you can. I didn't get to try their famous cruffins but I did get to try a number of their other pastries. They were all enjoyable. Their croissants had a nice buttery, flaky texture. Their bread was soft and fluffy. Nothing was overly sweet so I really enjoyed that. My favorite that I tried was their strawberry jalapeno danish. It was sweet, creamy, fruity, with a hint of spicy from the jalapeno. It was such a nice blend of sweet and savory.

Make sure you get a box since the box has their signature design on it but you do have to get 6 or more pastries. The shop itself is small. There's enough room to line up and take a picture against the wall with the sign. You can almost miss this shop but all you have to do is look for the store with the neon pink sign inside. Their logo across the door almost looks like graffiti which makes the store blend in even more with all the other stores.

Maybe one of these days, I will wait in line for the cruffins or more likely I would bribe someone to get these for me.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Okay, I was expecting Mr. Holmes to be all hype. There's certainly a lot of hype, but I think it's valid! I dragged myself out of bed early to stand in line for a cruffin...I was disappointed to learn the flavor of the day was white chocolate macadamia nut. Eh. Not my jam. But I waited anyway, and it was totally worth it. A flavor I wasn't crazy about, and this thing still knocked my socks off--impressive!

Don't limit yourself to just the cruffins, though. There's lots of other delicious morsels to be had. The French onion savory danish was freakishly delicious...crispy bits of cheese, caramelized onions, lots of thyme, flaky, gooey. 

Skip the brioche. It wasn't flaky--didn't love the texture, but the blueberries and strawberry crumble were fantastic. 

The fig danish was caramely and featured ripe fig and crunchy walnuts. 

Loved the Amelie Amman--a caramelized croissant. Simple perfection.

Brave the hype, brace yourself for a wait--embrace Mr. Holmes!
author: Dara M.

description:
It's famous bakery place. 
Very tasty and have big lines all the time. 
I lie their pastries a lot. 
It's pricey but it worth it. 
Feels like you are in Paris having tasty pastries. 
Living not far so I can stop by often. 
I don't do that often as I have to be in shape. Lol
author: Natalie D.

description:
Awesome, innovative, adventurous pastry. 

Bar none the best croissant in SF.

You don't have to wait in the cruffin line. Enter from the north side and take the express line to pastry heaven.
author: Adam K.

description: Great pastries and very nice staff. The line was really long when we came here at about 9:30am on a Saturday. They are famous for their cruffins and run out so make sure to come here early if you want to grab one. Their other pastries were really good as well, both sweet and savory.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Love this place visited San Francisco this summer and just have say never heard about a cruffin but it was delicious and I also tried the crossiants and cookies all amazing and fresh definitely a place to checkout when visiting San Francisco
author: Clivia W.

description:
Ya'll the hype surrounding this place is so real. Got here at 9:40 am on Thursday morning and lo and behold, A LINE. Yes, on a random weekday morning, there was still a line. It was pretty timid and we managed to make it in before the cruffins ran out, buuut I'm pretty sure everyone that arrived after us was not as lucky. There's very short optimal time period during which you can seize one of these vessels of flaky, baked goodness. The flavor I had was hot toddy: whiskey and lime. Gotta say it was worth the wait. The pastry was flaky yet soft and just the right amount of chewy. The filling was a lot nicer than I thought it would be since I don't particularly like pastries with alcohol. The bottom of the cruffin was my favorite part of the whole thing. The donuts are solid and they have a good variety of other pastries too. I downed a cruffin here then walked over to Jane on Larkin for a coffee to balance out the sugar rush. You should definitely check this place out if you are in the area.

Things you should know:
- 2 cruffin limit per person.
- Things sell out quickly so get there early.
- Caveat for the prior statement because cruffins are only brought out at 9:00 am.
- The line is relentless on certain days.
author: Lakshmi M.

description:
I came here at 7 a.m. to meet a friend, knowing that I wouldn't get any of their famous cruffins (which only start selling at 9 a.m.).

But since I was in town, I HAD to head over to Mr. Holmes because I've heard only good things about the bakery ever since it opened.

There's a wide selection to choose from, including savory potato and leek tarts, spicy chocolate doughnuts, flaky croissants and much more. I truly, truly wanted to eat everything, but I just couldn't, so I opted for two things to try - their Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb and a California Croissant, two very different types of baked goods.

I started with the Choux Bomb since it looked so good - and its appearance definitely lived up to its taste. In between a fluffy puff pastry sliced in two, the filling - which was luxuriously creamy - captured everything wonderful about a Ferrero Rocher chocolate. The only slight downside of the dessert is the caramel they stuck in the cream - a little too sweet for my liking.

Then there was the California Croissant, filled with smoked salmon, seaweed and sprinkled with toasted sesame seeds. A complete 180 from the Choux Bomb, but just as good - savory and flavorful. 

Oh, Mr. Holmes exceeded my expectations. I hope to pick up more baked goods when I'm not as in a rush in the future.
author: Sara C.

description: Waited about 30 minutes before I was able to order Cruffins (not too bad). However, if you plan on going here to try something else.... SKIP THE LINE! Anyways, I decided to check this place out based on the reviews. I ended up buying a box of: Cruffins, Regular Croissant, California Croissant (MY FAVORITE), Churro Croissant, and a Dark Chocolate Chocolate Chip Cookie. Don't let the price scare you away. Everything was worth every penny!
author: Jadelann J.

description:
You know you have a friend 4 lyfe when she spends her Tuesday morning standing in line to buy the two of you multiple cruffins, realizes that there's a limit of 2 cruffins per person, and has the willpower to not eat your cruffin before your meet-up two days later.

Bless her patient soul.

And, yes, I ate my bakehouse pastries 2 days post-acquirement. But no biggie, that's what 2 minutes in the toaster oven is for.

Earl grey cruffin. The cruffin, at its core, is a solid croissant that maintains its light butteriness, even 2 days old. What elevates the croissant to a cruffin is the cream filling, perfectly imbued with Earl grey flavor, purposefully portioned to occupy a considerable portion of the pastry, and thankfully devoid of that waxiness that leaves your mouth with a film coating. The muffin shape lends to better distribution of cream filling since regular croissants have bottom-heavy fillings and very spacious, lacking tops. The delicate coating in powdered sugar, which makes it seem like a donut, is the icing on the cake. Or the sugar on the cruffin, I should say. Albeit the uneven playing field, the cruffin is much tastier than Paris Baguette's "cronut." This pastry is worth your money.

California croissant. Just like the cruffin, the croissant was solid but not the star of the show. This pastry was elevated by its tiny filling of smoked salmon wrapped in seaweed. The wasabi, though present, wasn't overpowering (and I'm very sensitive to wasabi). Didn't use the soy sauce, didn't think it needed the soy sauce. Would have preferred more salmon, but who wouldn't.

Savory brioche bomb with red Thai pumpkin curry. The taste of the brioche was definitely affected by being "stale" as the dough was a bit tough. The curry flavor was concentrated only in the middle, leaving the remaining 85% of the pastry as an underwhelming, airy cheese bagel.

But, no time to dwell on the past. Bakehouse bucket-list: kouign amann (will it be better than B Patisserie's!?), croissant bread pudding, butternut cheesecake bostock, ube puff, donut, choux bomb, EVERYTHING.

My friend might need another set of hands to help her carry it all.
author: Adele F.

description:
I came around 7:30AM and there were two lines. One is to get cruffins, and the line was hella long already when cruffins come out at 9AM; and the other line is just to get other regular baked goods. My friend waited in the cruffin line and I waited in the other. The regular baked goods line of course is faster and I got a lot cause I just wanted to try everything! After I got my goodie box, I walked over to the other line where my friend was standing. As long as you have a peace sign sticker, you can get a cruffin. I ended up getting two stickers! We waited patiently and ate some of the baked goods as well. 

Cruffins: That day they had chocolate flavor with strawberry on top, but I really wanted to try their matcha flavored ones. I immediately got hooked and I'm obsessed with their cruffins. It's a lovely novel twist/hybrid of croissant and muffin rolled in sugar; so in love that I think they're definitely worth lining up for and waking up early for! The price I believe is $4 or $4.50 for each one, I forgot. The texture of the outside is crunchy and crispy, while the inside was perfectly soft due to the amazingly delicious filling. A perfect baked good to start my day. 

Store: The store is small, but it's a nice environment to take a quick picture with the sign that says "I got baked in San Francisco" after paying for the goods. 

Why four stars? Have to wake up early just to get a cruffin cause they do sell out really fast. Lines can get really long on weekends as well. I believe this place is worth trying once at least.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
I heard about this place from my coworkers.  I was too early for the cruffins the first time I went here.  I got six pastries that included an artichoke danish, bread pudding, and the California croissant.  Not a fan of the California croissant, but I can at least say I tried it.  I fell in love with the artichoke danish.  It looks small, but I was quite full after eating the flaky goodness.

I got cruffins the second time I visited.  I told myself that was all I was going to get, but unsurprisingly, I got a box of six pastries.  I mostly got the savory pastries, and I got a rum doughnut, along with the cruffins.

The flavor that day was salted caramel.  It was pretty good, and really filling.  It came with a pretzel on top.  The cruffin was flaky, and the custard was rich.  I would probably share one next time I get it, because I would be full from eating the artichoke danish.

If you want to get cruffins, you have to be there at least 10 minutes before 9am.  The line can get long.
author: Vira P.

description: This place is famous for its cruffins and while it's pretty good I think its too pricy in my opinion as one cruffin was already 4.5. I only come here when I visit family because it is a few blocks away. I would go more often if they had more cruffins in stock by the time they almost close because that's when there's no line.
author: Erica L.

description:
I have been wanting to try Mr. Holmes Bakehouse for so long after hearing so many people rave about their cruffins on yelp and Instagram. Although they don't start serving cruffins until 9 AM, I wanted to get there early since I heard there would be a long line and a limited number of cruffins.  My boyfriend and I arrived at Mr. Holmes Bakehouse at around 8:10 AM on Sunday morning and there was already a line!! We were far from the front of the line :(  They had two lines.  They have a cruffin line and a line to buy non-cruffin baked goods which was much much shorter than the cruffin line! Before they start serving cruffins, an employee from the bakery gives a sticker to each person in line guaranteeing them a cruffin.  One sticker guarantees two cruffins per person.  

When it was finally 9 AM, they announced that the cruffin flavor of the day which was lemon.  My boyfriend and I ordered a whole bunch of yummy baked goods: 4 lemon cruffins, 2 peanut butter donuts, a peach cobbler sweet danish, blackberry bread, and a ferrero rocher Choux bomb.  The Cruffins were SOOO AMAZING. I still remember the first bite I had! They were so buttery, flaky, fluffy, and light!!  As for the other baked goods, the donuts were pretty good but the rest were alright.  I ended up spending a lot more money at this bakery than expected since it was a bit pricey but definitely worth it. Also, the box is so cute too! make sure to take a picture of their infamous sign :)
author: Kelly C.

description:
Hipster bakery kind of in the middle of nowhere but you'll smell it from a block away and spot it by the line outside the door. 

Note: There's two lines- left is for cruffins and right is for normal pastries. Bakery opens at 7 and cruffins go on sale at 9 so try to get on the cruffin line by 845. They do a sticker system where they start handing out stickers around 850 to guarantee people in line cruffins. Max 2 per person and they only bake a limited amount. You can also purchase normal pastries from the cruffin line but not vice versa. Cruffins are $4.50 each and theres only one flavor per day. Most of the other pastries are about $4 each. They're a little pricey but everything I tried was really yummy, flaky, and buttery!

Is it overhyped? Probably. But there's a reason to the madness. Mr. Holmes definitely makes some really delicious pastries, though for about $4 per pastry, I would be able to get 2 (maybe even 3) pastries from an Asian bakery like 85 degree. Of course, the type of pastry would be completely different but to put things into perspective, Mr. Holmes is not a daily bakery I'd visit but more of a special occasion one I'd recommend to friends :)
author: June Y.

description: Get here early if you can, by the time we got here it was about 10:20am and several things were sold out, there was a line when we arrived as well. We ordered a savory onion, bread pudding piece and a chocolate croissant everything was delicious
author: Jessica M.

description:
Convinced my husband to come on a Saturday morning with me. Got here at 8.45 and at 9 the line started moving.

Cruffin flavor was chocolate and caramel. It was good!! I think everyone should try it at least once. The California croissant was also really good!
author: Zaineb D.

description:
THEIR BAKED GOODS ARE AMAZING!
Cruffins are worth the hype and so are the donuts!

The ones I tried were: 
- Chocolate earl grey cruffin
- California roll
- Peach filled donut
- Chocolate croissant

The cruffin (croissant muffin) was buttery and flaky and the filling was smooth and creamy. Not sure what the other flavors are like but the chocolate earl grey was bomb. The peach filled donut is a good option if you want something fruity. Logistic wise, there are 2 separate lines: one for cruffins (starts at 9 am) and one for other baked goods (much shorter). Definitely recommend waiting for the cruffins - the line moves fairly fast and the wait is definitely worth it!
author: Jenny B.

description:
I live right around the corner from this place, so just keep in mind this is coming from someone who doesn't have to put in much effort to come here unlike some people.

So during the weekends I've noticed the line starts building up around 8. They start selling cruffins at 9. They have separate cruffin / non-cruffin lines on the weekends, but not on the weekdays. They sell out of cruffins within 2-3 hours when they're busy, so just keep that in mind.

I've tried this place a few times now and I gotta say - skip the cruffins. It's the most underwhelming thing they have there taste-wise. They have soo many better things like their doughnuts (flavors change all the time), savory croissants, etc. They even had a "California Sushi Croissant" which was smoked salmon with seaweed and wasabi paste inside of a croissant. It was actually quite delicious.

The cruffin on the other hand is meh. It's messy and isn't that moist because it's mixed with the muffin batter. It's filled with cream on the inside but meh. I'd rather have their doughnut.
author: Sue C.

description: We got there WAY too late for the cruffins and they were nearly out of everything. We ended up buying a Hibiscus Raspberry Kouign Amann and two Blueberry Juniper jelly donuts. Yes, you heard that right. Blueberry JUNIPER, which you could really taste and it was quite good. However, you could really tell that this was end-of-the-day products because the donuts were starting to go a little stale (ie no longer light and fluffy).
author: Loose Seal A.

description:
Although this place opens at 7am, they don't sell cruffins until 9am!! I went on Friday, Dec 30th at 820 am and was the 10-15th person in line! Since it was the holidays, they limit it to 2 cruffins per person.  The line was really long by 9am, but my friends who were at the end still got cruffins!!  The line is well worth for the flaky, buttery cruffin! In each bite, you'll get a good amount of cream.  When I went they only had one flavor, which was chocolate and passionfruit cruffin.  

If you don't want to wait for the cruffin, there's another line for savory pastries and cream filled donuts! It is also very delicious.  We had the bacon and onion danish and the donut of the day.  The donut of the day is a good alternative to the cruffin! It has a sugary exterior and yummy cream on the interior.
author: Jennie Q.

description:
Pros:
Most pastries are not too sweet. 
Not greasy/oily. 

Cons:
Long line!
Pricey
Small portion to price ratio. 
Website doesn't list ingredients. 
Possibly Gmo?

From top left: Apple danish, donut, chocolate cookie, plain croissant, and onion/bacon danish. Very light and not too sweet except the onion and bacon which was a little salty and not too oily/heavy. The cookie was too heavy and too much chocolate.
author: Organic T.

description: Haha no one mentions (in these other reviews) that this place is, literally, a hole in the wall!  By the time I got there, there were only 3 items remaining:  A bunch of cookies, an artichoke savory pastry, and a prosciutto croissant!  Well, you guessed it, I picked their chocolate chip cookie - pretty good cookie, doesn't disappoint on the chocolate chips which are huge and aplenty!  But then, is it that difficult to make a chocolate chippy now that you want to be a 'bakery', I guess not!! It would get 5 stars if at 11:00 am they had a variety of items to choose from instead of just 3!!!  Its a tough crowd out here in SF, you gotta earn those 5 stars, lol
author: Chitra J.

description: DELICIOUS! There is nowhere quite like Holmes Bakehouse. We got there when they opened on a Monday and grabbed a box of goodies and come coffee. No one was there yet. They don't sell the cruffins until 9:00am, so we sampled yummy pastries while we waited. I loved the Ube tart and the California croissant. Around 8:30am we started a line outside for the cruffins. I was first in line! They only allow 2 per person and they are limited! We had bananas foster cruffins. They were DELICIOUS! You can tell they were made with real bananas. I highly recommend coming here at least once. It's worth it to be there early-I haaaaate waiting for food- and from what I've read, the lines get pretty cray. See for yourself and go check them out! Highly recommend!
author: Brittany S.

description: There offering is split between sweet & savory, pastry doughs & donuts. Purchase 6 items, and the box is included. If not, then there is a small charge. I tried the savory pastry square filled with bacon bits and caramelized onions which had a faint taste of garlic oil. The pastry dough is very flaky and crispy, no soggy bits or pockets of unincorporated butter - absolutely delicious and a filling breakfast item. The cruffin filling flavor of the day was a spiced pumpkin puree. The cruffin isn't a novel idea but it's a fun treat. It's a bit tricky to eat without creating a mess of the filling and crumbs but totally worth it. Definitely give it a try if you have a sweet tooth and enjoy flaky pastries.
author: Julia K.

description: Soooooo good!! If youre just visiting SF definitely make your way here and get a box and try one of each.
author: Candice S.

description:
My coworker told me about this place and so glad that I got to try them.. I went with my friend who lives closed by so we just walked here.  

We came a little late so we didn't get the cruffin but we got other goodies and they were all so delicious!!!!

there was a long line, but moved quickly.  my friend and I pretty much picked everything from the display aahah.  we got at least 10 of them.  

we got California croissant, pumpkin thai curry, choux bomb, 2- ube puffs, bread pudding, chocolate chips cookies, strawberry cheesecake bread, chocolate croissant, and pumpkin spice donuts. 

It was so hard to decided which one was my favorite favorite.  but i would have to say the ube puff.  It was flaky and the filling wasn't too sweet and it was perfect.  I should have gotten more ehehhe

service: great.  very patient and informative.  They were really friendly and seem like they are very happy to be working there.  Which is very important. 

atmosphere: very modern and nice. 

overall: everything is just delicious and fresh.  i love their croissant. they are super buttery and flaky.  maybe next time if my friend and i woke up early enough we will line up and get the cruffin.  but i think even without the cruffin, we are still satisfy of what we got and we will try some more.
author: Candice Y.

description: Mr. Holmes is a decent bakery, but too hyped. I find the pastries too sweet. Worth visiting for that awesome neon sign though ;)
author: Isha S.

description: I could go to a bakery every single day (maybe even a couple times a day) and I'd be a happy camper.  My wife had gotten me some goodies from Mr Holmes in the past but I needed to experience it myself.  Since we had July 4th off I went right when it opened.  There was a small line but not too bad.  I was able to order a wide variety of pastries and donuts.  Everything was really delicious and our family finished everything by the end of the day.
author: Blake B.

description:
We picked a good day to come try some cruffins. It was raining, a Sunday after Thanksgiving when folks are either sleeping in, readying to head home or exercising those gained pounds. The line was about 6 persons out the door.  There were over a couple dozen left of the blood orange cruffins. Hubby and I got the max, 4 cruffins and filled our 2 boxes with more to the tune of $57 worth of pastries.  
Everyone liked the cruffins and their plain croissant is really good. Forget about going to Paris, there are good pastries in SF finally. The churro croissant was okay until I got to the center where it oozed with a creamy filling. The mulled wine pastry was interesting but only as a seasonal item. Hubby liked the chocolate croissant but I didn't so much care for the chocolate inside.  He told me it was a once in a lifetime purchase when I balked about paying that much.  What? This isn't a one time visit. I plan to return.
They charge almost 90 cents for lovely boxes but you only need them to impress as a gift. I think with the exception of the cruffins, everything else can go into a bag. They could save money and cost if they went with a thinner version like at other places. It's a tiny store. No where to eat. And after your coronary from all that butter, St. Francis Hospital is just up the block.
author: Ry T.

description: The only good thing about this place is the pastries. Tried a matcha croissant, a cherry blossom croissant, mango jelly donut and a iced coffee. All the pastries were amazing they are unusual flavors but they were so so good! The line was out the door and it has gotten so famous there are tons of people trying to take pics in front of the neon sign. And the place is tiny... The two ladies that helped us kept barking at us to finish ordering so my advice; look at the menu ahead of time and know what to order. All in all the place is so loud and crowded and the employees attitudes are scary BUT the pastries are really darn good. So if you must go to try the famous bake house be prepared and know what you want and be prepared to wait in line.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
So was it worth it?

Yup. The cruffin was. Everything else was just OK.

Per the advice of the employees, arrive before 9am to have your choice of pastries, or before 11 to get a cruffin.

* CRUFFIN - 4.5 STARS:
This was definitely my favorite. I was not a huge fan of the Four Barrel cream filling, but it was pretty good and the croissant was really soft and flaky. 

* SEA SALT CARAMEL BRIOCHE PUFF - 3 stars:
I've tried the coffee, caramel, lychee. The donut is a bit too dry/bready for me, and the fillings are hit or miss. 

* APRICOT / BLUEBERRY DANISH - 3.5 STARS
Pretty good but standard danishes. 

* CHOCOLATE CROISSANT - 3.5 STARS:
Pretty good but standard - not enough chocolate for my taste, too much dough, not enough butter. Favorites still: Tartine and Knead Pattisserie. 

* KOUGIN AMANN - 3.5 STARS: 
B Patisserie is far superior - this one is nice and crunchy but way too sweet.  

* CALIFORNIA CROISSANT - 2.5 STARS:
Unique and unusual - filled with tuna, seaweed, wasabi and served with a side of Kikkoman soy sauce. I personally was not a fan and did not like the tuna, it tasted dry and low quality, but I thought it was a creative idea.
author: Jess C.

description:
Came here today on my lunch break. I knew cruffins would be sold out by noon, but I was in the mood for donuts anyway. The fillings were not enjoyable. I'm disappointed. One had a flavored applesauce type filling and the other was chocolate cream with sour berry notes. They looked gorgeous and the donut dough was decent, a yeast variety, my favorite kind. Bummed about the fillings though. Maybe the pastry chef was trying to do too much? They could use some editorializing on the flavors. 

So, here's the real: You have to brave the tenderloin area to get to the shop by walking from bart. So, be aware of your surroundings. The shop is filled with tourists and scenesters taking selfies. So, be prepared for that too.

Highlight: The pull apart apple pie. Unexpected purchase, but totally made the trek worth it. Next time I'm coming for you, Cruffin.
author: William V.

description:
If I work full time in San Jose, don't live in the city, and have a boyfriend that would prefer to sleep in on weekends, how in the world would I get my hands on these cruffins!?

At last, my prayers were answered... I got called in for jury duty in the city last month and was able to finally try one!

TIP: Closest BART station is Civic Center. It's about a 15 min walk.

I got there at 8:45am on a Monday morning and was about the 20th person in line.

They started serving at 9am and I was in the shop within 10 minutes.

The flavor of the day was Cherry Orange. I walked out with my pastry and lamely took a gazillion pictures of it with different backgrounds. Did it for the insta.

When I was finally satisfied, I dug into the cruffin. Flaky, crispy, sweet, creamy, and messy! I quickly devoured half of my precious treat and was floating on clouds. I saved the other half for after the gym, but it was soggy and not as good, so enjoy immediately!

I want to try all the others flavors so badly...
author: Lincy H.

description:
Summary: cruffins are worse than both cronuts and croissants, not worth the wait. Other baked foods are alright but not stellar

I came here twice on a mission to secure cruffins as a gift for my brother and his fiancée.

The first time, I foolishly came too late in the day and they were sold out. This seemed strange to me since only a few months ago I was at Dominique Ansel in NYC, and there is no longer a wait for cronuts and they were still available at 3 in the afternoon on a weekend. This indicates to me that the supply is artificially limited (as was the case for cronuts a while ago)

To get a pair of cruffins, I showed up at 830 on a Monday morning and was the front of the line. If you think a 30 minute wait doesnt sound too bad, you have not yet been disappointed by a cruffin. It has the vague flavor of a croissant, but without the airiness as the layers are all jammed together to fit a muffin mold (the cronut avoids this problem by proofing and frying without any constraining molds). 

I also sampled a few other goods, which were a bit tasty but not all that unique or memorable. Props to Holmes for some creative attempts, but I'm wary that they are just cashing in on a food trend, and not actually delivering the same kind of creativity you see in all the baked foods at a place like Dominique Ansel, and not executing classic techniques at the level of a place like Tartine.
author: Neal B.

description:
Key point is, get here early. My friends and I got in line at 8:30am - well turns out the cruffin (muffin x croissant) doesn't go on 'sale' until 9am, but whatevs. We got our cruffins at around 9:15am or so.

There's two separate lines - one line for the cruffin and the other line is for all the other pastries. As one very helpful employee told us, the strategy here is that after you get a ticket showing that you are in the cruffin line (2 cruffins per person), have someone in your group go in the other pastry line, which usually has way less people at this point. That way, you'll get everything at the same time!

I only got the cruffin when I went. It was fruity pebbles flavor (flavors change weekly) and it was GREAT. I love croissants and their fluffiness and butteriness and soft layers. It was a bit messy to eat because of all the powdered sugar; next time, I'm gonna shake off a bit before eating it :P Also next time, I want to try some of their other pastries.

And yes, the I GOT BAKED IN SAN FRANCISCO neon sign is one of the most Instagrammed spots in SF, but now there's one in LA!
author: Judith C.

description:
With almost 500 reviews at this point I am unsure how I can differentiate from others. So a quick recap of my experience.

I arrived around 8 AM to a line down the walk, but was lucky enough to receive the last pink sticker that would guarantee me two cruffin's. Later the line grew to behind me around the corner block. This seemed insane, but it was my first time and reviews are strong.

Around 9:30 I got two peanut butter & jelly cruffins served off of a tray. They had enough for some others without stickers, but not much more. Visually they did look great!

The staff was friendly, but really not time to be too friendly during the cruffin madhouse time. I can't recall the price, but it must have not been too outrageous.

I ate one right there on the sidewalk at the suggestion of a friend I made in line. They said you must scarf your first one down, LOL. Well I did just that and jammed the half muffin half croissant in my mouth. I was really delightful, I loved it. So fresh and powerful yum flavors. I had to run back in for napkins, I was a mess! I saved the other one to have with a coffee at the pier later that morning.

I would return, but did not like the long wait in line...who does right.  Those with schedules could not pull this off. Since I was on vacation it worked and I really enjoyed it. A strong 4.5, but rounding down with over an hour wait.
author: J David H.

description:
We didn't get to try the infamous cruffins since we came 45 minutes before closing but there were still other pastries left to try

---fruit bostock: our FAV pastry of the goods we tried! The flaky pastry encrusting the softer center was a good balance
---rocher choux bomb: tasted like a ferrero rocher and peanut butter in one, not bad
---California croissant: I don't think I was too fond of this smoked salmon & seaweed stuffed croissant 

NOTE: there's no seating at this bake shop, just gotta pick up and go
author: Jenny S.

description:
After trying the infamous cruffin a few months ago, I finally got to try some of Mr Holmes' other baked goods. I'm still not convinced that the cruffin is worth the ridiculous wait, but it's worth a visit for some of the other items. Honestly, most things still weren't particularly special in my opinion and Mr Holmes is really 3-3.5 stars to me, but the REUBEN DANISH itself bumps it up to 4 stars. Savory pastries don't appeal to most people like sweet pastries do, but I'm definitely more a fan of their savory items.

* REUBEN DANISH ($4.50) - 5/5
[pastrami, thousand island, house fermented sauerkraut]
Not gonna lie, a pastry with pastrami and bright purple sauerkraut seemed pretty iffy to me at first, but I love savory things so I gave it a try anyway and I'm so glad I did. It may sound disgusting but man it's AMAZING. Super savory and balanced very well. Pastrami's not too salty, sauerkraut's not too strong and there isn't too much thousand island. And the danish part is perfectly flaky and crispy

* KOUIGN AMANN ($3.50) - 4/5
Crispy, buttery and flaky with a nice, not-too-sweet filling

* CROISSANT ($3.50) - 3.5/5
Super buttery and flaky when completely fresh, but the croissants lose their crisp and become softer, kind of like Costco croissants. They're good and big in size, but are they worth $3.50? I don't think I can agree with that.. A Costco croissant will do the trick for much less.

* DONUT ($3.50) - 3.5/5
[pumpkin spice]
As far as donuts go, theirs are pretty good - airy, fluffy and filled with a good amount of filling. For anyone who likes pumpkin flavored things, the pumpkin spice actually tastes like it, and for anyone like me who isn't really into sweet pastries, the pumpkin spice at least isn't overly sweet or rich/creamy (can't say if other flavors are the same)

* SAVORY BRIOCHE BOMB ($4) - 3.5/5
[red thai pumpkin curry]
Basically a soft, fluffy but pretty plain and average brioche bun topped with pumpkin purée and shredded coconut. I liked the pumpkin (had a slight kick to it), but there was too much brioche and not enough pumpkin.

* CRUFFIN - 3.5/5
[smores]
From my original review - I thought a cruffin would actually be some cross between a croissant and muffin in texture, but it's really just a croissant (buttery and flaky like everything else) shaped like a muffin, overly stuffed with a sweet, creamy filling. Too much filling and too little pastry in my opinion
author: Jessie L.

description: Wake up early, put your lose pants on and head to Mr Holmes Bakehouse. Every time I come here I always enjoy something new.  There freshly brewed coffee is the perfect start to the morning. I highly recommend the cruffins (chocolate caramel) and the blueberry juniper donut.
author: Robert V.

description: This place is so cute! I visited Mr Holmes Bakehouse during the Spring and there was a huge line! All the pastries look so delicious. The staff are very friendly, but that might be just because I'm from NYC. I ordered the doughnut with the chocolate icing inside. AND OMG.... SOOO GOOD! It was definitely a bit too sweet for me and very messy. But I would totally eat it again if I ever had the chance to. I highly recommend this place for anyone who has a huge sweet tooth and for people who are looking to eat at a bakery that has very cute and clean aesthetics. Although I did enjoy my doughnut, it honestly does not compare to Dough Doughnuts in NYC ( I have not found a place that tops Dough Doughnut yet). But for those who live in SF, it is a great alternative!
author: Geena K.

description: I went after hearing so much about this place and it was very tiny, I only knew it was the place because of the boxes. I had the chocolate stuffed cruffin which was awesome, I felt so happy eating it. A bit pricey but they are good!
author: Anahi G.

description:
When I get baked AF sometimes I don't give AF about eating "mindfully". Sometimes I just want loads of carbs, sugar and butter. 

This is where Mr. Holmes delivers. They are the dankest pastries in the city. None of that boujie French pastry vibe. They always have that top shelf and the insulin rush I get from eating their doughnuts gives me the sickest pumps in the gym. If you have never eaten doughnuts and then deadlifted right afterwards I suggest you try it out sometime. It might change your life. Basically, Mr. Holmes will get you jacked.

It is a great place to take out of towners. Whenever my family visits SF, we always smoke a huge ass blunt dipped in oil and then get us a big box of Mr. Holmes to eat when the munchies hit hard.

A sunny day in SF is fun on its own - but have you ever done SF while on Mr. Holmes? Try it. Just don't blame me if you get perma-"dough" fried!
author: Travis B.

description: Came in the afternoon and there wasn't much of a wait. The donut had both black sesame and raspberry fillings. I liked both flavors individually, but I don't feel like they went well together. The raspberry masked the taste of the black sesame when it was mixed together, so I would have preferred just having one filling. It almost felt like I was eating two separate donuts. Besides this fact, I really liked the filling.
author: Edward W.

description: Excellent cruffins and donuts! I was recently in NYC and tried cronuts at Dominique Ansel bakery. While good, the cruffins at Mr. Holmes is still a winner in my opinion. The Kouign Amann is not as good as B Pattisserie though. Regardless, so glad we have so many good bakeries to choose from in the city.
author: Anna C.

description: One of the most popular bakeries in San Francisco so I had to give it a try!  Of course I came for what everyone else comes here for: CRUFFINS.  Woke up early and stood in line for a little half an hour before they opened so I could get the cruffins (that day was raspberry) of the day.  I got a box and started filling it with pastries of my choosing.  It was hard to pick because everything looked so good!  The cruffin was so delicious!  I definitely thought it was worth the wait because it was fresh and the filling just oozes out.  It's perfect if you're into sweets!  The employees handed out a sticker while we waited in line and were so nice when they opened the doors to let us in.  I definitely will be coming back wanting to try their other flavors!
author: Mikayla M.

description: Ok. Everybody knows this place is good. Like Real Good. I wanted to recognize the service as being just as amazing. When I was being rung up for my purchase the cashier noticed my frantic pacing to and from the front door. You see I was illegally parked and I must of had that worried expression on my face. The girl in front of me had a massive order that took awhile to tend too so my anxiety build up was palpable. When the cashier took care of me, she was so nice and apologetic which defused any aggravation I might of had. She offered me a coffee for being so patient and I even got to order an extra cruffin....shhhhhhh. What a pleasure. Not only did I leave their with all that deliciousness, I was calmed by the excellent care and treatment by the staff. I'd also like to add that I got an emailed response seconds after I sent my query. Two Thumbs up Mr. Holmes!!!
author: Marcus S.

description: Stood in line for 30 minutes, had a bee almost Sting me, and our puppy kept peeing every step we would take. Other then that well worth the wait, will probably wake up again on Saturday just to wait another 30 minutes for some sweets .great staff, and extremely helpful!
author: Magali H.
