description: Trendy, maybe to a fault. Cleanliness seemed phenomenal though despite the long line. In full disclosure, I did not realize that this bakery was as trendy as it was. My daughter woke up early one morning and I tried to give my wife some extra rest by telling my daughter that we would go grab some donuts. However, when we got there I realized how long the line was and convinced her to wait it out with me. Unfortunately, there is not much there for children outside of chocolate chip cookies, which were delicious, by the way! The monkey bread was OK - too salty. The cruffin we had was chocolate passion fruit and it was very good if you like passion fruit. Not sure it was worth the 20-30 minute wait.
author: Dan E.

description:
lemon. hops. curd.

Let me tell you about the best donut I've ever had. Fluffy, chewy and a layer of sugary goodness. Will be back and will buy several, can't wait to try other flavors next time I'm in SF!

Cruffins were okay, waited in line starting at 8:30 for a Thai tea cream - just didn't like the filling, the cruffin itself wasn't half bad.
author: Cara S.

description:
By 11am on a Friday, it was slim pickings - they had a handful of sweet and savory croissants, 2 plain croissants, and a bunch of donuts, but that was it.  However, there was essentially no wait when I went - just a few tourists taking pictures in front of the signs the say "I got baked in San Francisco.". I'm sure it's busier earlier in the day because most people go for the Cruffins at (?) 9am, but I was actually looking for a croissant anyway.

- Plain croissant: $3.50.  The flavor was ok, but it was too dense for me. I was hoping for something lighter/flakier and more refined
- Bacon blue cheese date savory danish: $4.50.  The filling wasn't bad, but the rest of the pastry was unremarkable

Despite it being a small space, they actually have a very clean and nice bathroom for customers (you need to get the door code from them).  When you order/pay, you can also catch a glimpse of the baking going on in the back.

Make sure you get there early to avoid them selling out.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Ahead of my last visit to see the Mrs., my friend Leti informed me about this place and how they run out quickly, so we should be here extremely early on Sunday morning.

Thanks to her great planning (snacks and coffee she brought) we got ample parking and were only the 8-10 people in line the morning we went.

There are two lines, one specifically for the Cruffins and one for the regular bakery. Once the time get closer for them to release the Cruffins for that day (check their websites daily for flavors), they give you a voucher of sorts that allows each person to purchase 2.

The day we went we had a Strawberry banana Cruffin that was topped off with a homemade Sour Patch kid. 

Just like Cronuts, they were amazingly flaky and tasted just right with the strawberry and banana. It wasn't overly sweet to put me into a diabetic coma. On my next visit(s), I hope I get to try the other flavors.
author: Wes S.

description: Simply delicious and heavenly.  The chocolate chip cookie is spectacular and so is everything else you'll try! If you have an ounce of a sweet tooth you won't be disappointed !
author: Cynthia A.

description:
TBH I came for the matcha cruffins and the California croissant but I didn't read the reviews so by the time I got to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse, they were sold out of specialty cruffins (cries). The line was out the door but it wasn't too bad since the interior is relatively small. No joke this place is really cute on the inside *cue instagram photo op in front of the sign* 

Since my beloved matcha cruffin was out, I got the California croissant (which I wanted) and then just randomly picked a bunch so I can get the box lol. I got a few California croissants, artichoke and mushroom danishes, an almond cruffin, and I forgot the last one. I'll admit that I'm a huge savory person so I LOVED the California croissant and the danishes the most compared to the sweets I purchased. The California croissant stood out to me the most because it was soft, warm, flaky and it has salmon and seaweed on the inside; it also came with some soy sauce. The artichoke and mushroom danishes were delicious as well. The almond cruffin was good but it didn't hit the spot because I wanted the matcha one :|

Even though Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is pretty hyped up, I think that it lives up to the hype. It's fairly different from what I've tried here in SoCal (esp. the California croissants). So if you want the special cruffins of the day, MAKE SURE TO COME EARLY or you'll miss it. All of their other baked goods aren't bad though, so buy a whole box of them. It'll cost ya around $30 for a box.
author: Shannon H.

description: Sped walked to Mr Holmes to get in line for the 9am cruffins on a Tuesday. I arrived right on time--there were only about 8 people in line then. I got 2 of the chocolate coconut cruffins, 1 matcha croissant and 1 churro croissant. Overall, I don't think Mr Holmes lives up to the incredible hype. If I had to pick, I'd say I liked the choc cruffins the most out of the lot, but even then it was lackluster and nothing amazing. Matcha croissant was even more lacking, as the croissant was by no means flaky and the matcha flavor was very subtle.
author: Astrid G.

description:
I've been waiting forever to come out to the city and ridiculously stand in line and now I finally got to try the Cruffin!!! The line for the cruffins doesn't open until 9:00AM and we got there around 8:20AM on a Saturday morning. The actual open time for the rest of the bakery is 8:00AM. When we finally arrived to the front, we got our limit of 2 and then went to the registers to pay. The verdict? Worth the one time standing in line for 40 minutes to try it, but it wasn't anything super impressive. The flavor of the day was a coffee caramel which was pretty good, but the cruffin itself was a sweet pastry covered in more sugar shaped like a muffin. It wasn't anything that super impressed me and I don't know why I wake up early and wait in line for these things. I also got some other pastries and I would have to pass on most of their croissants (matcha green tea croissant, bacon and onion croissant, spinach, mushroom and feta croissant, chocolate chip cookie dough croissant...). I had high expectations since this place is so popular, but the croissants were not as buttery and flaky as I had hoped. I also tried their donut which the flavor was unique (spiced pineapple), but the donut itself was just okay. The cookies on the other hand - OMG - I would come back for that. They are chewy on the inside and just a little crisp on the outside and had great flavors!

Overall, I was a little disappointed to be honest, but I can finally check trying the cruffin off my list.
author: Sophia Y.

description: If you love bread. This is your spot!!! They don't have a lot of variety of bread but just enough to choose from. Delicious bread!
author: Jessica G.

description: I didn't get to try Mr. Holmes Bakehouse the last time I visited SF and had been seeing it all over Instagram for the longest time, so I was excited to finally try it!! I knew that I should've gotten there before it opened, but couldn't, so they were out of cruffins by the time I got there! I was so sad. But I did get a total of 10 bags of treats for myself, family and friends. I got to try the donuts, bacon and onion danish, chocolate and cornflake cookies, and croissant. They were all really good but I guess I expected them to blow my mind good. I still need to go back to try the cruffin!! Finally got baked in San Francisco!!
author: Christine K.

description:
The CRUFFINS. Obviously. On a weekend, people line up for an hour for these babies. And they're so totally worth it. Croissant/muffin fusion with a delicious filling and beautifully presented top. Everyday they release one flavor. Some of the ones I've enjoyed include: hot chocolate, lemon raspberry ginger, and strawberry milkshake. 

While the cruffins might be the main event. Really anything here could be the star of the show! Their donuts are gooey, magic filled, flavor bombs that will turn even the tidiest enthusiast into a messy eater. Many people will get one of these as they wait in line for the cruffin! And it's not something I would ever discourage.
author: Eimanne Z.

description:
I've been hearing about this place for so long, so glad I finally got to try it!

If you go here be ready to wait in line. I think I waited around 30 minutes or so and I went on a Friday morning.

Upon entering, you could smell the butter--my mouth was watering before I even saw any pastries. We ordered about 7 different things, and we all loved what we ordered. I had the strawberry jalapeño brioche and the California croissant. The brioche was delicious--had just enough sweetness and spice and I love love love the topping. The bread itself was also well done-- nice and soft with a slight egg flavor. I wish there was more strawberry jalapeño jelly inside though, that stuff is so yummy. The California croissant was interesting... I don't know if I'd order it again but it was good! The Flavors worked surprisingly well however the textures threw me off a bit... Salmon and croissant... Not typical, but they made it work. 

Definitely want to go again!! And definitely worth the wait.
author: Kaitlyn E.

description: I went the savory route and chose the California Croissant and boy am I ever so excited to go back and try EVERYTHING else that Mr Holmes Bakehouse has to offer! The Croissant was fluffy and light, the salmon was smoky and flavorful, and the nori and sesame topping added a nice little pop in your mouth. This paired nicely with a cup of their coffee, and I am enjoying all of this at Eison Triple Thread. Mr Holmes Bakehouse X Eison Triple Thread. Yee!
author: Christina E.

description: We got there at 8:15am Sunday in the end of January. Very little line but they don't serve the cruffins until after 9. So I had the lemon donut and my husband has the churro croissant. Both good but I was bummed we were able to they the famous cruffins.
author: Karmina R.

description:
Came here the day after Thanksgiving around 11 am and didn't have to wait in line!! Was able to get one of the last few cruffins in an awesome flavor: caramel coffee.

I've tried the OG cronut and some imitations but this by far takes the top spot in my pastry loving heart. It was crispy and soft on the inside, every bite was tasty and there was by far not a lack in filling. 

I also tried a pumpkin Danish which was yummy without being too sweet. I like how they have unconventional pastries like a pear blue cheese danish and an ube puff pastry thing! Definitely looking to come back (hopefully on a matcha cruffin day)
author: Hana S.

description:
Definitely a cute little spot that I would come back to if I were in the area and happened to be hungry. It's much smaller than I anticipated it would be location-wise, so don't let a line out the door deter you - they can only fit about 3 people in line inside the actual store. 

By the time my husband and I arrived at about 11:30 am this past Sunday, there was a short line and a small selection of their offerings left for sale. I don't typically jump at the chance to try trendy hybrid foods, but this time I can admit that I would have liked to have tried one of their proprietary cruffins. I ended up with a donut filled with rhubarb and another fruit I can't recall, and my husband got a slice of savory bread pudding. My major call-out was that the first bite of donut was incredibly sweet (and I can handle even the most sickeningly sweet treats to an extent) though I began to enjoy it more as I continued to eat. My husband commented that he wished his slice could have been warmed, though since the staff didn't offer, I'm not sure if that is something they'll do.

I collect lapel pins like every other basic this side of the Mississip' these days, so I grabbed a peace gesture pin, and my husband's morning coffee rounded out our transaction, which ended up at about $20. Since the space is small, it was amusing to hear the chatter of people around us in line; most of what we heard was that people wanted to take photos of/with the neon sign across from the register that says "I Got Baked in San Francisco" and they were worried about how to do it since it was so cramped at the time. Not gonna lie, I chuckled to myself. You'll get a chance to take your picture - just please snap it fast and move on. Some of us are actually here to just gorge. 

Because of how Instagrammable this spot is, I really have to hand it to whoever does their design work. The boxes, bags, and facade itself are like works of art and it really makes the entire experience enjoyable. Aside from the fact that young people make me bitter because they probably have more time left on this earth than I do and I am prone to rolling my eyes at them, I hope they are the clientele that keeps this place running during the times in between my visits so I can come back and enjoy it too.
author: Emily S.

description: We got the croissant, chocolate croissant, something made in a muffin tin (not the cruffin, they were out), sausage roll, and 2 doughnuts. The best was the buttery pastry muffin tin thing. It was crowded but the line moved quickly. They were all tasty.
author: Jade H.

description:
Oh Mr. Holmes, you are a bad, bad boy. I've always been faithful to Dominique Ansel, but your cruffins were irresistible. Ever since I moved to the West Coast, I no longer had my monthly Cronut fix. It had been a while since I had a sugar-gasm. Then I met Mr. Holmes. His Cruffins were round and elongated, fitting perfectly in your hand with a bit of cream teasing out of the top. The moment I took a bite, I knew there was no turning back. This was the beginning of a sinful affair. I could feel my eyes rolling back as the coffee cream hit my core hard alongside crunchy chocolate chips. I couldn't help but sigh in satisfaction. Oh Mr. Holmes, you sure know how to please a girl's taste buds. With each bite I took, cream squirted everywhere. You're such a messy boy, Mr. Holmes. Better grab some napkins to hide the evidence. We can't let Dominique know. Let's get baked again soon, alright? 

xoxo, secretly yours.
author: Virginia Y.

description: The famous wall in San Francisco where everyone takes their tumblr pictures. This isn't the only thing they're known for, their cruffins are their most well known pastry. The variety is limited since they sell out super quick. I got one cruffin(coconut rum was the flavor of the day), sweet danish(persimmon), and a donut(coffee). The lady that grabbed the pastries was super sweet, she answered my questions and telling me which was most popular. The total for me was $12.00 for three pastries. I think you really get what you pay for because the pastries were so fluffy and crispy. It was still warm too when I took a bite. Next time, I'm getting a whole box of pastries before I leave.
author: Lisa W.

description:
For this SF trip, I made THIS MY MISSION to finally get their famous cruffins. My friends and I came around 8:15 and waited in line. They start passing out a pink sticker guaranteeing you two cruffins. (limit 2 p/person) The cruffins comes out at 9:00 but the bakehouse opened at 8:00 when I went. Thankfully we found parking and it was free Sundays! 

Yesterday's Cruffin flavor was Birthday Cake - celebrating their one year anniversary. Congrats & Happy Birthday btw. I can see why they are doing sooo well!! Honestly, I dont know how I feel about the cruffins. For sure, the presentation is beautiful. They were AMAZING, but at the same time there were some parts there were meh. My first bite was meh but once I reached the center were the cream filling was I was BLOWN AWAY. The filling was rich and creamy. The cake on top was super moist and spongy! Kind of messy to eat, but it's worth it! If you were to ask me Cronut or Cruffin, i'd still choose Cronuts though! I really wish I tried the Matcha Cruffin on Saturday, I think I would've liked that a lot better! I'll be back!

Also, I tried their California Crossaint... It was good until I reached the wasabi...I really wish there weren't any wasabi, because it seriously ruined it all :( but if ya'll love wasabi, salmon, and nori seaweed this would be good.

I heard they're actually coming to LA, soooo I'm pretty excited for that!
author: Michelle Y.

description: I didn't know how basic I could get but I knew I HAD to stop by Mr Holmes whilst in SF. It's basically a must go while here!! I came here on a Friday afternoon after brunch and thank goodness the line wasn't long! I ended up getting one of their pear cruffins and boy was it delicous! The texture of the pastry was the perfect amount of crispiness but it was also soft and warm. I was a little sad they didn't have the Ube cruffins but will definitely try it out next time!
author: Connie Y.

description:
Let's talk in metaphors here. So you're in a bar, and you want to hit the bathroom - but you're a lady, so there's a huge line. But then you look over, and see an opening: it looks like the men's room is unoccupied. Now of course, there's always the possibility that when you come out you'll get the awkward look of disapproval, and ideally you'd use the women's bathroom, but you know what? Sometimes you don't want to wait in line. And there ends one of the worst metaphors I've ever written. 

So at MHB, as the locals probably don't call it, I ate the second best cookie I've ever had. Shout out to Levain in NYC for #1, but this guy really stood its own as a fantastic chocolate chip creation that left me legitimately sad when it ended. And the best part? You only have to wait in the short line, not the insane one for the Croissuffin, as the locals likely don't call it. The line for the Muffsant, as the locals definitely don't refer to it, starts hours before the place starts serving them and typically will cost you an hour that you could otherwise spend climbing random hills around town or designing a new app or whatever people do. 

I'm not proud of comparing the Croissuffant, as the locals undoubtedly do not call it, to the long line for a women's bathroom at a bar. But the other pastries are delightful, and it's definitely worth skipping the hype and going right for the good stuff. 

Get that cookie!
author: Zach W.

description: All I can say is, this was definitely worth the drive and the wait on a Monday morning during the scary traffic! Lol I got here about 9am and waited patiently in line, the wait was about 10 minutes. You can smell the fresh baked goodies outside as well. I ordered there special for the day, it was a pina colada cruffin. If you look on there IG page they reveal the flavors for the week, which was nice to know ahead of time! I also ordered the churro croissants and the vanilla and chocolate filled donuts, sooo good!! I also purchased one of the cute bags they sell, thought it would be a nice souvenir to take back home with me! Can't wait to come back to try a different flavor!
author: Nabella M.

description:
Wonderful selections of delicious and tasty pastries.
I just wished they would stay open longer during the day.
author: Lolo M.

description:
NOTE: Cruffins are sold at 9am, limit 2 per person but the bakery opens at 8am (donuts, ferrero choux bomb, coffee, etc are served)

Pecan Pie cruffins - super good, not too sweet with pecan bits in the filling

Thai Tea donuts- my FAVE from what I tried, the Thai tea taste was really there, the donut itself was fluffy 

Spiced Pineapple - super flavorful, sweet donut with a tart/hint of cinnamon spice that went well together

Ferrero Choux Bomb- I fell in love with the filling on this one, it was creamy & light not too sweet either
author: Precious C.

description:
Well damn. This place is good.

Been meaning to hit up this spot for a while now. Finally got a chance to visit this morning. I feel like there's a lot of hype for this bakery, and I must say, Mr. Holmes totally delivered! So good, so good. Girlfriend and I went pretty hard, copping the max 2 cruffins per person, along with 3 of each type of donut, a caramel sticky bun, chocolate kouign amann, and an ube puff. We were surprised to see that ube puff last minute. Needless to say, instacop. The daily flavor for cruffins was blueberry cheesecake; and donuts were cranberry orange and spiced chocolate. 

You know how sometimes you see pastries that look good, until you take a bite and are disappointed by a dense, stale, flavorless baked mass of dough? None of that business here. Everything we had was delicious. Pastries were light, buttery, and flaky. Fillings were tasty - not too sweet, as my mom and her sisters would say. If you're a fan of pastries, definitely come here. Highly recommended. 

Protip: Cruffin flavors change daily. Peep their website or social media beforehand to see what's on the menu for the day. Also, get there by 9am to queue up for the goodness.
author: Roderick T.

description:
Wow what a bakery. So many different pastries to choose from. Savory to sweet. Cruffins, macha croissant, plain croissant, strawberry thingies, everything I've tried were all really tasty. You really know that they were fresh baked that morning.  

I go in the morning and there is usually a line, but it's short and worth the wait.
author: mike l.

description: The joint was a lot smaller than I had expected with no seating besides 3 stools that people often just use for photo purposes instead of actually sitting down and enjoying the pastries. There is very limited options with only about 10 pastries to choose from such as matcha covered croissants, a peach cobbler pastry, an Apple pie treat, cookies, butterscotch/rhubarb cupcakes, and chocolate-infused croissants. The line was out the door so I had pretty high expectations! I bought 6 pastries for about $24. I surprisingly think the pastries were just average- I think the big hooplah is honestly just about the aesthetics of the place. More about the experience of going and taking an "insta-worthy" pic, rather than a delightful out-of-this-world dessert experience.
author: Amy T.

description:
My first stop here the light was on the wall wasn't working!  But the pastries were amazing!!!!  The line wasn't so bad it was about 8:30 on a weekday.  If you are looking to get cruffins they do not come out til 9am.  

Came back to bring home to Vegas.  The light was working!!!! I didn't get any cruffins because we had to be at the airport.  Line gets long on the weekends before opening but waiting isn't too bad.  The store is so small and selective in items that you basically go in and out.  I realized their donuts selection is different every time.  I got  doughnuts with Thai tea and butterscotch fillings.  And the Apple pie monkey bread filling with bourbon in their caramel sauce!!! Yummmm!!
author: Sharlene E.

description: This bakery has a line for a reason.  The flavors are so unique, and everything offered is incredibly fresh.  The menu changes constantly.  I got a nectarine and thyme doughnut, It was so fluffy, and still warm. I am already craving another.
author: Allie P.

description:
I seriously wanted to make it rain up in that bakery. Well, that was my original intention, but I couldn't because I really wanted to try the famous cruffin ($4.50 a pop). Thus, I was only able to purchase only that particular pastry on the day of my visit. Once you're in the cruffin line, you can't purchase any other of their other pastries. 

There are two long lines: the cruffin line (limit 2 cruffins per person) and misc. pastry line. 

I dragged my trooper of a mister here with me, so that I could get four cruffins, which I inhaled and I subsequently regretted doing so. Ugh, four sugary cruffins to myself, never again. 

+ In order to get the cruffin on a weekend, you have to line up right when this bakery opens at 8 am. Though these bad boys are ready to order at 9 am, don't wait to line closer to 9 am, because they're limited and the lines get long! Once you're in line, you're not even guaranteed to get one. You need to obtain the pink sticker, which is essentially your golden ticket to the damn cruffin. 

+ Cruffin flavors vary each day. I got to try the Chocolate Hazelnut Cruffin, which had a pleasantly golden crisp exterior, a buttery, fluffy center, and an ample amount of chocolate mousse filling. 

Overall, I don't get the cruffin hype. I can't believe we lined up an hour in advance -_- Least I can't say I've never tried one. I'd like to come back to try the other pastries that they offer though. 

I'm totally over the cruffin.
author: Merica S.

description: We wanted to end the year right and so we woke slightly earlier on a Saturday to get in line. We were in luck and website's countdown to the next batch of cruffins was dead wrong. They still had a lot of the passion fruit variety. I made sure my husband and I had 1 each so we don't break up our marriage over it, and I was glad I did! I'd give that cruffin 5 stars. Other things we had: Churro Croissant (4.5 stars), Donut with something coffee-ish (3.5 stars), cornbread stuffing that tasted like pizza for some reason (4 stars). Coffee was more than decent. Service was great!
author: Paulyne R.

description: Get baked at Mr. Holmes. Well worth the visit. They may not have a great location but don't let that foul you. There baked goods are worth the trek.
author: Charles D.

description:
I adore this place. Friendly staff with the absolute best pastries, sea salt chocolate chip cookies, donuts and cruffins you have ever tasted! I seriously die a little with each bite I take. And guess what!? ... 

Uber eats delivers right to your office so you don't even have to leave! Genius. 

I'll take 2 more cruffins to go please.
author: Anna T.

description: This is worth the wait! I had the cruffin and it's so light and fluffy. They put a lot of filling compared to most dessert places that only put the filling at the top and leave the rest just bread. I came on a weekday morning at 10 AM and the wait wasn't too terrible - about a 10-20 minute wait. Cruffins are limited two per person and will run out, so if you want this pastry, you have to come in early! Overall this is a place you have to hit up when you're in SF.
author: Jenny L.

description: Update - finally got my hands on a cruffin (flavor was passionfruit) and it was absolutely delicious!!!! I insta-ed the heck out of it and can't wait to try more flavors. I'm not normally a fan of savory pastries but I also had half of a savory danish topped with bacon and it was to die for!!!
author: Yin H.

description: Hype hype hype. But for good reason. The pastries here are mouth watering - I ordered the matcha croissant and it was super flakey, soft and buttery (I'm pretty sure they overdose in butter and that's how that get you hooked into ordering a whole box). I came here on a Thursday morning at 8 and wanted to come back at noon for more but almost everything was sold out (so I can only imagine how crazy it can get on week ends). I was a little bummed that they're insta-famous sign -"got baked in San Francisco" was out of order, but otherwise, this little hole in the wall is a tucked away gem. Just be sure to come early or you won't get any!
author: Rebecca L.

description:
My only regret is that I didn't get two (but my thighs are thanking me now). I had been plotting my trip to this place to grab one of those infamous cruffins everyone has been raging about. I figured that a Friday would be the perfect day to go: tourists may not be in town/willing to get up that early, and the locals are at work. So I sauntered on down to this place with the doggies a little after 8am, and as luck would have it, there was no line! I was half tempted to run back home, but then I saw several others approaching, so figured I would hold my place. And I'm glad I did. Literally 5 minutes later, the line started to grow (although by no means as bad as on the weekends). 

Now let me get to the good stuff (pun intended). That cruffin! The flavor was chocolate toffee (which they post on their Instagram page, btw. And no, you don't need an Instagram account to see it). It's a croissant in the shape of a muffin, that's dusted with powdered sugar, and then filled with a daily flavor. What I liked most about this treat is that it wasn't too sweet. It was the perfect croissant:cream:sugar ratio. I told myself I would only take a couple bites, but the next thing I know, it's gone! So I guess I ate it. And loved every minute of it!!!

I also couldn't resist the ferrero rocher choux bomb (then again, I can't resist anything ferrero rocher-like). Again, deliciousness!!!! I can't really even tell you what this was or what it consisted of except to say it was just amazing! 

Likes:
-delectable pastry treats -there's something for everyone 
-pet friendly (I thought I would have to lock
My pets to the bike rack, but they let me bring them in
-reasonably priced 
-good quality bakery treats (not to hard or soft, but evenly-textured)

Dislikes:
-only 2 cruffins per person! 
-constant line (be prepared to wait for a minute)
-too close to where I live (which means, my thighs stay in constant anger, but hey, c'est la vie!!)
author: Tracy T.

description: Cruffins and Cronuts galore  get their super early though cause they sell quickly! They have a timer to count down from on their website, which is super creative and helpful! Not to mention, the cute shop and the "I got baked in..." sign
author: Deepshika V.

description: Yummy Cruffins!!!! We had caramelized white chocolate filled ones and they were great!
author: Philip M.

description:
Hands down, THEE BEST Cream/custard-filled Le Donuts!  Get one or two, or hell get all three that come out!  

+ Location: (boarderline) Tenderloin and Nob Hill +
The bakehouse is pretty darn small, so you might miss it along Larkin St.  It is what it is... A room-sized bakery with a glass display of pastries galore.  

++ Gettin' down to business ++
They do open early, but if you arrive at 8:30am, you may notice a long line of people waiting to get their hands on some cruffins.  What are cruffins?  You'll find out.  They start offering them at 9am, but note that you can still bypass the long arse line if you only intend on buying their other goodies.  

+++ Now for MY GOODIES, not yours, MINE +++
~ Maple Almond Bostock ($4.50):  Hmm, this was different!  Kinda like a monkey bread baked in a square shape, and sliced big like a piece of Texas toast only way bigger.  Or better yet, more like an almond croissant threw up on top of sweet bread, mmm!  I ate half (only because I wanted to try all my other pastries), then toaster-oven'd the leftover slice and loved the sugar rush all over again!  It's gotta be the moist buttery almond paste taste with that slightly crisp maple top! 

~ Savory Danishes ($4.50):  
1)  Mushroom danish, first bite... Dude!  I didn't know these were like quickly sauteed and peppered.  One bite and I couldn't stop biting.  Much recommended.  Next...
2)  Grilled onions danish, first bit... Holy sweet Jesus, even better than the mushroom danish!  Really really really recommended!  Engulfed, next...
3)  Artichoke cheese danish, first bite... Mmm, mmm, mmm, I never knew baked artichoke could be so good with some cheese chunks!  And I believe it was feta too, imagine that!
4)  Bacon danish, first bite...  Ah, ok, seems like something I've made before.  Good, but surprisingly not my favorite.  
~~ Now I ate them in this order expecting thinking it was worst to best, only it ended up the other way around.  Can't go wrong with ordering any of these!

++++ CRUFFIN ALERT!!! ++++
~ Green Tea Strawberry Matcha Cruffin ($4.50):  OK, after 35 minutes of waiting, here's what I think....
Crusty, buttery, sugar everywhere, green tea matcha strawberry filling that was nice'n'cool, flakey, and everything you've ever wanted!  I liked it, but sorry, it wasn't worth my time.  Why?  Because the Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb and the cream filled donuts were EVEN BETTER, imo of course!

~~ Lets start with the Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb ($3.50):  HEAVAN! Yes with an "A"!  I was fortunate to grab one of these as they came out.  Not to mention, I was already paying at the register.  If you're an almond lover, caramel lover, cream puff lover, then this is for you!  Words cannot describe this dainty piece of hmm heavan!  Just like a freshly baked Ferrero Rocher itself, only life-sized!  Whatever that's supposed to mean!   

~ And finally, the Cream/custard-filled Le Donuts ($3.50):  Three reasons why they tasted so good!
1)  Tempted to buy all three varieties, I just went with the Peanut Butter-Chocolate which was just oozing with what seamed like a firm chocolate mousse.  Reason number one as to why I think Mr Holmes makes some of the BEST EVER donuts! 
2)  Next, I had the Orange Creamsicle, and DAMN!  Never new life could be so good...  The fact that the custard was cold, and it really taste like an orange ice cream bar justified reason number two.  But my #1 favorite item of everything here.  I can eat a whole box of these!   
3)  No mess as you bite and lick, but both donuts simply had an aroma that makes you wanna devour it in one bite.  The donut itself was crisp and sugary on the outside;  Made that way it should be.  I can smell them now!  

I can only imagine how that passionfruit donut taste and smells... 

+++++ Overall +++++
~ It's been a while since I've written a review this long, that's how good it is.
~ Oh yeah, and service.  No issues as the girls moved quickly and tried to be efficient.
~ Pricing:  eek, I've never spent $50+ on pastries before, but it was worth it!
~ 5-stars!  Eat it!  Try it!  Loved it!  Nuff said!
author: Ron R.

description:
If you are visiting San Francisco, YOU MUST TRY OUT MR HOLMES BAKEHOUSE! I am a huge fan of bakeries and whenever I travel, I try to visit as many as I can ( I love my carbs!) Looking at other reviews on Yelp and blog posts, there was two things I had to be aware of: one, the long line ups and two, the cruffin! I was dedicated to coming early because when I went to Dominique Ansel in New York I missed out on the cronuts by 15 minutes -_-.

I arrived at around 9:15 and there was already a line outside the door! It took me around twenty minutes to go in, but oh boy you can smell the sweet aroma of the pastries outside the door. I would've loved to get a box, but you had to order a minimum of six items. Unfortunately, I was by myself so there was no point of me getting all of that. 

The first thing I saw was rows and rows of beautiful cruffins. That day, the flavour was Reese Peanut Butter, I believe they change up their flavours everyday and they put these on their Instagram page. They looked so flaky and crispy so I definitely snagged one of those. Don't just settle for their cruffins, they have a lot more amazing pastries too! They had donuts, croissants, cookies, and savoury tarts as well! I ordered the Bacon and Leek tart.

The Bacon and Leek Tart was hands down my favourite. It was so flaky and there was a ton of filling inside it too! The chunks of cooked onions and bacon was the perfect combination. I'm not a huge fan of overly sweet items but the cruffin was delicious. You can definitely split it amongst two people because these things were huge! They are quite messy when you eat it, so get those napkins ready. These were just as flaky, and I loved how the filling had a rich peanut butter flavour but was not sweet at all!

Highly recommend, make sure you order as many as you can, and take a cute photo with their sign.
author: Joy P.

description: Visited this bakery a few weeks ago in San Francisco and couldn't wait to go back. I just discovered they opened up a location in highland park. It's a must but you must show up early if you want the best selection..
author: Charles G.

description:
They limit 2 cruffins per person. Cruffins come out at 9am but you want to be there well before then. They will come out and hand stickers to people in line. If you get a sticker you are guaranteed to get a cruffin. If not, then there is a very big chance they will run out before you are up (depending how far back in line you are). 

Also worth noting there are two lines, a cruffin line and a non-cruffin line which is pretty much non-existant. You can just walk up to the counter to get anything else. Got there at 8am and was not one of the people to get a sticker. Luckily I was still able to get one and they were unlike anything I have had before. I do not even have a sweet tooth but can honestly say the cruffins were bomb. 

It might be some time before I wake up early on a weekend to go wait in line for a bakery, but I would say you should definitely try it at least once.
author: Thielson D.

description: This place was great! I got to try two of their items and they both tasted really fresh and unique. The main advice I have is go early. They close at around 2:30, and I went at like 1:30, and most of their stuff was gone. There wasn't much variety left. So if you want to get different flavors of items go in the morning. Also the place is located in a fairly busy area, so it is hard to find parking. Other than that, the cruffins and tarts were delicious! Next time I will go a little bit earlier to try different flavors.
author: I K.

description: They have so many varieties and they change all the time! It gets packed but you get it clear quickly. Bacon and quiches are top tasty. The cookies are delicious. The one with cereal was stunning.
author: Pamela H.

description: Dream pastry heaven!! I want to die and go to Mr. Holmes passion fruit custard heaven!
author: Babs J.

description:
croissant is AMAZING ! BIG LINES worth the wait. A must hit spot.
Get baked @ the Homes Bakehouse. With Every bite you will know why you waited.
author: Kristen P.

description:
5 STARS! 

We came at noon on a Sunday so obviously we weren't expecting to try the legendary cruffins. We were able to get the cherry limeade donut and the blueberry brioche. My favorite was the donut because the donut was sugary in the best way and oozing with cherry limeade goodness. It was an unexpected combination but absolutely delicious. The brioche was nice and creamy but I much preferred the donut. I will come back for donuts and cruffins!!!
author: Jane H.

description:
I know Yelp limits us at 5 stars, but I could not care less! This place is 6. 7 or 8 stars.

I've been here only once but was lucky enough to eat their desserts multiple times. For starters, there are things you need to know before we begin.

Now you might be from NYC and be all like "Oh honey, I really don't know if anything can top a cronut experience bla bla bla." And maybe you are right but we are talking about Cruffin here. That mouth watering layered tower of flavor with pockets of air and butter, coated with sugar. We're talking about different flavors and an incredibly softness that lets you eat the whole thing in 2 bites.

Donuts, unbelieveable! As someone who loves desserts and exploring, I was surprising pleased that Mr Holmes had the best donuts I've ever had. For a long time I thought Bob's donuts was the best, but later that thought was crushed by Dynamo, and yet again it got crushed by Mr Holmes. We're not talking about your average donut though, we're talking about key lime and basil stuff 

There are tons of other flavors that I haven't tried, which is the reason why I smile everytime I walk by and see the huge line. I'd wait (and will for it) too so no judgments. Mr. Holmes please keep being our city's best bakery.

Love,
Ali
author: Ali O.

description:
I did not wait in line for hours on Saturday for the Hello Kitty Bobblehead so I decided instead to wait in line for an hour early Sunday morning for cruffins!  

Tip #1 - Every Sunday evening, they list the anticipated cruffin and donut flavors for the week on Facebook which I did not realize until I heard the person behind me mentioned what the flavors were for the week. They have 1 flavor for the cruffin and 2 flavors for the stuffed donuts each day.  I took a gamble that it wouldn't be coffee and was pleasantly surprised that it was lemon meringue pie that day.  

Tip #2:  If you are facing the storefront, the cruffin line is to the left and the regular pastry line is to the right.  There is a pink sign notating that but when you jump out of the car like I did, I automatically just lined up where I saw the line.  Luckily, 5 minutes later at 8AM, I noticed my line was moving so realized I was in the wrong one and was still able to be near the front of the correct line.  

Tip #3 - If you can come with a second person, one person can get some pastries to munch on while you are waiting for those cruffins.  They start handing out stickers around 10 minutes before 9 so make sure to be back in line before then if you want to maximize the cruffin allocation!

So I got 1 chocolate pistachio donut and a California Croissant to tie us over in line.  I had salmon baklava as an app before during dinner at Saha which coincidentally is pretty close by as well and absolutely love it.  It takes the sweet and savory to a whole new level and I loved it!!  So we decided to take a chance and try the California Croissant which has salmon in it as well.  It is salty enough that it did not require the soy sauce pack that comes with it and was tasty but did not knock my socks off.  I had the chocolate pistachio donut later in the day and the density of it reminded us of a malasada.  I thought I would like it more than I did.  

The cruffins on the other hand, yum and worth that hour wait!!  Each person is allowed 2 so we got the max.  Dusted with sugar on the outside, followed by light flaky layers and then ending with the not overly sweet filling was a perfectly balanced treat any time of the day making it 5 stars!!
author: Joyce Z.

description:
My friend and I came here on a Friday morning around 8AM and there wasn't a line yet. So, we actually ended up being the 1st ones in line for cruffins. 

The cruffins were supposed to come out at 9AM, but they actually took 10-15 mins more to finally be ready. The flavor that day was Almond Joy. 

I ended up getting 2 Almond Joy cruffins, 2 chai donuts, 2 pineapple donuts, 2 Ferrero Rocher choux bombs, and 2 cruffin bread puddings.

It being my first time here, I was most excited about the cruffin of course. Although I'm not the biggest fan of coconut, I'm glad that the Almond Joy cruffin wasn't full of coconut. It was sweet and creamy. It also was hard to finish because of the filling. So, I was only able to eat half of it. 

I thought that the Ferrero Rocher choux bomb was ok. It did have the signature Ferrero chocolate hazelnut taste. But, I felt like it was overly sweet. 

The donuts and cruffin bread pudding were devoured by my family and they really enjoyed them. So, I'll definitely have to get more of those next time. 

Overall, I would say that the cruffins are worth the wait (depending on flavor). I think I would've enjoyed mine more if I was able to try a flavor that I actually liked. But, nonetheless, the concept is great.

I hope to come back and try a better cruffin flavor and a savory Danish because my friend had the artichoke one and said that it was really good!

For all my pastries and the reusable tote bag  that I bought, I spent almost $60.
author: Fallon P.

description: The roasted tomato pastry is everything! Just be careful of those shooting tomato seeds when you bite into it!u
author: Kym P.

description:
_____SERVICE_____
CRUFFINS DON"T GO ON SALE UNTIL 9AM.

I feel like the above need to be in caps for emphasis lol. Nonetheless you gotta get there before 9am because the line gets long. If they run out, that's it for the day.

_____PRICE_____
$4.50 for 1 cruffin. It is a bit expensive but it was for the experience. They also have other kind of sweets for $3-$5 for your accommodation.

_____PRESENTATION_____
Get baked in San Francisco.

_____LOCATION/PARKING_____
There is no free parking if you're trying to go for the cruffins. You'll have to pay in the meters. However there will(should) be lot's of parking spaces you can choose from.

_____MEMORABLE MOMENT_____
The long line behind me...lol.
author: Ivan C.

description: I'm sold on this place! So glad we found it during our Xmas vacation in SF. I only wish there was a location in Orange County!!! We bought a box full of goodies... but my absolute favorites were the donut filled with custard and the sausage roll. I can't wait to find one of the LA locations back home. A+
author: Melissa S.

description: Matcha croissant ftw!  Tried a bite of the chai tea  cronut and was thoroughly disappointed (mostly due to the chai tea filling)
author: Aysha A.

description:
$8.00 lyft ride there
25 Mins waiting in the rain
$6 lyft ride back

And This is probably one of the better bakeries that I've been to. I had the Chocolate stout kruffin, and that was Oooo so Good. I bought an extra one for my mom, and till this day she keeps asking me about it. My friend loved the California croissant, he said it was the best croissant he's ever tasted. 

Even though going here was a pain in the butt, I think i would gladly do it again.
author: Derick F.

description: Ideal for a photo, but not much else. The store was incredibly hot with flies and even a bee buzzing around. We sweated for a picture with the signage and took off as quickly as we could.
author: Lisa D.

description: Everything tasted good. I think this place is overrated! Came all the way from Fremont to try it and: 1) The place was located in the TenderNob (bad area) 2) super tiny place without seats, I had to stand up because it was so crowded! 3) The Asian girl serving was so rude and speaking really loud 4) it's super packed that's so uncomfortable 5) very pricey!
author: Rose M.

description:
this is how to get a cruffin:
They start serving cruffins at 9 but people start lining up at 8. Standing in line 8-9 you will most likely get one. They sell out and you will not be able to get anymore that day. They only sell 2 cruffins per person. 

Now the review. We came around 10/11 and they sold out of cruffins. We get a salted caramel donut - too sweet, Apple scone- really dry crumble, French onion Danish- really sweet didn't like. Cruffin- ridiculously filling. It's like a churro with a lot cream inside. Couldn't finish it. I liked it but can't eat a lot of it. The food is pretty expensive it really adds up. Only the cruffin is worth it to me because it really fills you up.
author: Kristyn G.

description:
This is better than the cronut. 

I went on a Wednesday and there was barely a wait. I also got lucky and they were serving honeycomb that day. Their other pastries are good too. I brought some back to the office and they were devoured within minutes.
author: Andy H.

description:
8:00 a.m. Friday - 2 people

1. Ambiance: This is not a dine in establishment and just a pickup and go service. It is a really cute small bakery with white bricks that gives off a hip and modern look. It has a neon light against the wall that writes, "I GOT BAKED IN SAN FRANCISCO." 

2. Food: We ordered the Chocolate Croissant, Cruffins, and Choux Bomb. Everything was made fresh and an astute person would order everything mentioned and more. I have nothing to scrutinize this bakery as everything was perfectly baked to perfection in all its entirety. 

The Chocolate Croissants were fluffy and buttery with melted chocolate pieces stuffed inside. The cruffins, I had discovered, were fluffy croissants made in a muffin shape with fillers inside. 

Every day, there is a different flavor of cruffins and this particular day was salted caramel & toffee. It was sweet, fluffy and creamy, and definitely worth a try. 

Hands down to the Choux Bomb. I had placed it in the fridge so it was cold and wow, it was amazing. It consists of almond roca cream inside the buttery pastry. It tastes like you're eating delicious cold cream mousse with a buttery crunch. So worth the calories!

3. Service: For the cruffins, there was a line. My friend and I waited in line for 30 minutes starting at 8:00 a.m. and we were the 9th person there. We received a sticker each, which grants us two cruffins per person. There is a separate line for cruffins checkout. Furthermore, if you do decide to to get more pastries that are not cruffins, you can jump to the regular service line and order. Service was fast and friendly. Great group of workers that offered wonderful customer service.

4. Costs: Cruffins are $4.50 a piece. Most of the items are under $5.00. It's worth it and the portions are a good size. 

5. Overall Experience: Besides the long line, which they have no control over, the experience was great. I enjoyed the pastries and they have a nice checkout system, which made the process of paying fast and swiftly. I am grateful that there weren't any inclement weathers that would affect the process of acquiring some delicious baked goods. 

Side Notes: Go early to beat the crowd.
author: Chau P.

description: Came here for the first time yesterday, for the first time there wasn't a long line! I got the cruffin and the donuts, I was so surprise that it wasn't as sweet as I expect it to be which was great! Because usually other bakeries make their pastries really sweet. Was kind of sad that they didnt have the matcha flavor cruffin though. Prices are too bad either, for a donut(3.50), cruffin (4.50) but limited 2 cruffin per person.
author: Christopher G.

description: If you are in the San Francisco area, you gotta try Mr. Holmes. We got 4 of the croissant/muffin hybrid, 2 Cookies, an apple fitter and a normal croissant. The cruffin (I think that's what they call it) is very crispy and fluffy and is what they are known for. If they have the butterscotch cookies, GET IT!! Best cookie I've ever had. When we went there was no wait, but I do know they sell until they are sold out, so go early!
author: Alicia C.

description:
At first I was really excited to try this place, but after trying it I realized it was just all a hype. :( the croissants where not soft and fluffy as I hoped. ( nor were they buttery ) 

Then the customer service was awful. She made me feel horrible that I was asking which was which (even though I got 4 boxes worth of pastries) you would think she would try to be nice. She just made it seem like she didn't not give a rats butt about customer service, she was vey snobby & rude. Customer service is something I really appreciate. Especially for places that are supposed to be well known so when they give bad customer service it's quite disappointing.
author: Khuyen D.

description:
YASSSSSSSSS

This was on top of my must go to places while in San Francisco and it definitely lived up to my expectations. The donuts are delicious and the flavors were on point. You'll definitely have to line up for the cruffins because they are pretty incredible and go out fast. And if there's any, get the ube puff and sweet Danish. Honestly, just try everything. They are all heavenly.
author: Audrey K.

description:
We had JUST missed the last cruffin, but their other baked goods were still delicious! I had the strawberry and creme stuffed donut (not sure what it's actual name is though), and the dough was PERFECT (very airy and melt-in-your-mouth). The filling was also good, and not overly sweet, which was nice when paired with the sugar coating. Now it makes me even more curious about the popular cruffin.

Apparently, the cruffins start selling at 9am, but people already start lining up for them way before then. We got there close to 10am, and a lady in front of us took the last cruffin.. so it does sell out pretty quick! It's also limited to 2 per person. The shop is pretty small, so be prepared to take them to-go to eat!
author: Jennifer F.

description: Love these!! Delicious . I had the matcha chroissant , hortcanta roll and a peach croissant . Get there early because they close at 2:30pm! Great for people who are early birds this shop opens at 7am
author: Russell T.

description:
Went on a Tuesday morning around 10am and they ran out of cruffins (WTF??). Then went around 12:45pm on Saturday and they were closed, with a sign "sold out for the day". They aim to close at 2pm or so.

With that being said, I woke up extra early on a weekday (3rd try) to try their cruffins and other seaweed pastry and it was DELICIOUS. The cruffins was filled with fresh/organic cream custard. And the seaweed pastry was unique, sweet/salty and flaky. I will return, especially - I'm always dreaming about the cream within the cruffins.
author: Yum Y U M.

description: So waking up early in the AM to snag a "cruffin" was out of the question for me. But that's cool, because there are plenty of other delicious goodies at Mr. Holmes. The grapefruit donut is heavenly!!! The fluffy donut is filled with a light, eggy and aromatic custard. Because I ordered the grapefruit, the bitterness of the custard nicely offset the sweetness of the desert. Nom nom nom!  You def need to get one!
author: Chase B.

description:
Came here on an early Saturday morning in hopes of getting a cruffin. The line wrapped around the block and decided it wasn't worth the try. I'd highly suggest going on a weekday. 

There was two lines, I stayed in the non-cruffin line and ordered a spiced pear donut, a persimmon sweet danish, and a churro croissant with filling. All were great but I highly recommend the churro croissant. 

Also ordered a coffee that had a cute little peach sign stamp however the coffee was mediocre, wish it tasted a little better to enjoy with my pastries 

The inside area was VERY tiny and I mean it. People are constantly bumping into each other, people are waiting to take pictures next to the neon sign or of the neon sign. Bakers are trying to rush around to give out cruffins. It felt very hectic inside. I wish they would implement a policy where only a few people at a time were allowed inside and once those people left, then people were welcomed in.
author: Faith C.

description:
*go to the bottom of my review for muy importante information !* 

If it wasn't for yelp, I would have never stumbled upon this place but hey, yelp has helped me numerous times before I found this little, sweet, treasure. :0)

I was anticipating a very long line so my Bestfriend and I headed to the city and got there at 7AM-ish. They open at 7 for their regular, delicious, pastries. 
- California croissant: buttery, flaky, croissant filled with smoked salmon, wasabi, ginger and seaweed. 
- regular croissants. 
- filled donuts. (I bought one flavor each that day which were passion fruit and strawberry).
And other baked goods. 

I originally came here for their "I got baked in San Francisco" totes ($12), but after seeing the filled donuts, I had to grab a box full of goodies. Fill a box with 6 pastries and the box is free, anything less than 6 goodies in a box will automatically be $1.50 charge for the box itself. But hey, the box itself is just too gorgeous to pass up.

Cruffin's make their appearance at 9AM everyday so make sure you get in line beforehand ! We lined up around 8:30ish and the line wasn't bad at all but that's because it's a week day so yay! Lucky us ! It took about only 5ish minutes top to get in and grab the cruffins. 

So just to cut this review short because what really matters is: is this place worth going to? YES. Was this place worth me waking up at 3:30AM to get ready, drive from concord to San Francisco, stop by a Starbucks, kill some time at Jane's, and wait in a line with other eager people waiting for cruffins? Damn right it was worth it ! 

OTHER DEETS:
- parking is street parking so definitely come earlier to find a good spot. It was a Thursday and the meter's start charging at 9AM.
- inside Mr. Holmes is cramp so if you're trying to take a photo, be prepared that it won't come out exactly as you'd want it ! 
- their doors open at 7AM for their regular pastries.
- 9AM Cruffin appearance so line up at 8:30 or even earlier ! 
- $1.50 per Mr. Holmes goodie box. 
- buy 6 pastries and the box is free. 
- $12 "I got baked in San Francisco" tote. 
- they take card and cash.
- sadly, 2 cruffins per customer. 
- cruffin flavors aren't guaranteed to be the same flavor the next day. 
- cruffins: $4.50 a piece.
author: Grace Anne D.

description:
The cruffin is worth the hype. Absolutely insane. 

Staff is super friendly. Rap music bumps. There's a dope neon sign that's ripe for Instagramming. 

It's without question a must visit SF spot.
author: Everett B.

description: Excellent pastries. A tiny venue with tons of Instagramers. Fun and a must visit place in SF.
author: Tom K.

description: I love Mr. Holmes Bakehouse. Their croissants are to die for, especially the churro flavour. They also had one of the best cookies I've ever had. Their donuts are also amazing with flavours changing every day! I highly recommend, but make sure to get there early because they tend to sell out
author: Stewart P.

description:
The home of the infamous "I got baked in San Francisco"  sign and unique cruffins... The star of many social media photos... And the destination following a sometimes lengthy wait...

We showed up around 8:45 AM on a Friday morning and there were already 10-15 people in line. And once it hit 9:00 AM, the line moved really quickly. We got all our stuff and were out the door by approximately 9:15. The nice thing is that there is no wait for pastries besides the cruffins, so you can head on in and skip the line if that's the case. Buuut I can see why there's no line for the pastries. 

FOOD RECOMMENDATIONS
+++ CRUFFINS: Where else are you going to get a cruffin... Nowhere. So yes, the wait is definitely worth it on a WEEKDAY. The lines aren't that crazy so do yourself a favor and come on a weekday. They post the daily flavors for their cruffins and donuts on their Facebook & Instagram, so keep an eye out for that. I thought double cherry would be a weird flavor for a cruffin, but boy was i wrong. Everything about the cruffin is tasty!
+++ CALIFORNIA CROISSANT: I loooove salty/savory breads (from asian bakeries), so this was easily my favorite pastry besides the cruffin. Smoked salmon, ginger, wasabi and nori wrapped in a croissant... Sounds weird, I know. But the flavors worked surprisingly well and the ginger and wasabi was not overpowering at all. 

AND THE NOT SO GOOD ONES... 
- COOKIE: It's a huge cookie for $3. Sea salt and chocolate sound like a good combination, but I just found this cookie to be a little too salty. I like salty and sweet, but this cookie just didn't have the balance between the two down. 
-- DONUTS: Got one of the passionfruit, pear, and flavor of the day: chocolate peanut butter. It's just a standard sugar donut with a little too much of extremely sweet filling. It wasn't terrible but it wasn't amazing.
-- FERRERO ROCHER CHOUX BOMB: Meh... Saw a lot of good reviews for it but it was just okay. A whooole lot of cream but nothing special. A bit too sweet for my liking too
author: Alison Y.

description:
What better way to celebrate national donut day than by getting doughnuts from Mr Holmes! On Friday, May 5th, one of our coworkers made it happen and stood in line at 6am to score us some doughnuts.

*Doughgroni (negroni donut): filled with campari jelly, negroni custard & a negroni syrup filled pipette on top
This was their doughnut to celebrate negroni week. If you like the taste of negroni, you'll love this doughnut. It was soft and airy and the custard was sooo good! I love custard doughnuts and this did not disappoint. The pipette was fun and injected even more flavor.

*Banana donut
I ate this a little later in the day and it was still amazing! The filling had just the right amount of banana flavor and was rich and creamy. Yum!

We also got an assortment of Croissants & Danishes. I didn't try any of them, but everyone loved everything! The croissants looked so buttery and flaky. If I had room, I would have had one too!

Unfortunately, my coworker couldn't get any cruffins, but believe the hype about their doughnuts! Now how to get my hands on one of those amazing looking cruffins!
author: Elena N.

description:
TL;DR - Pricey but delicious! Amazing creative flavors too!

Five stars for the best tasting pastries and living up to the hype.

Only docking points because the wait is insane and there is no announcement when the cruffins are out. So if you're waiting in line, you have no idea if you will even get your paws on a coveted cruffin.

In the unfortunate case that you can't get a cruffin, I'll help ease the shock by putting in my two cents.

Get the california croissant. Savoury and delicious. Yes, there is salmon in there, so if you don't like fish. Don't get it. Their savoury tarts are delicious as well!

Get the donuts.

Get the kounig aman (sp?) Its like...... a croissant with carmelized sugar.

Get the cookies. Delicious. 

The choux bombs are... meh IMO. Too creamy?
The strawberry jalapeno thing was also kinda weird tasting. Not my fave.

Try anything seasonal. They had a salted caramel kounig aman. SO GOOD.
author: Crystal Z.

description: Gary King of King Pool's did an awesome job on my pool! A week short of his proposed completion date, my pool was full of water! Each step was painless from having the hole dug to plastering the pool. I could not be happier with my new pool, the quality of workmanship, and the respect shown to me by Gary King. The people that Gary hired to do each step were considerate, cleaned up after themselves, and did excellent work!
author: Jonyce O.

description:
Beautiful pastries, beautiful boxes and beautiful staff. What's not to love? 

The old-fashioned (like the cocktail) donut was divine. It was worth the wait in the rain.
author: Christopher M.

description:
Visiting the Bay Area again I had to come back here.  This time I brought my sister along before dropping her off at work. We arrived right at 9:30am on a Tuesday and I was nervous that the cruffin a would sell out.  I've noticed that by about 9:45am it will sell out.  I had my sis jump out of the car to jump in line while I circled the block for parking, which I later noticed had a few on Post.  I tried to pull into the loading only zone in front but there were people and a camera crew that just stood there on the streets not moving! Idiots.

It looked like they were filming Mr. Holmes to feature it that day (6/9) featuring 2 female hosts who sounded like complete space cadets out of gawd knows where.  It was just too early to hear a bunch of "Omigawd this looks SO good."  They were really holding up the line cutting customers every 5 min and we have placed to go! The camera backed into me as I was trying to get a lid for my hot coffee and I nearly spilled it!

Anywho here's what he had:

CRUFFIN - CHOCOLATE CHIP MINT - $4.50
There's something different about this mint flavor...it doesn't taste artificial! The mint flavor was pure and it was as if I had it's full leaf mint flavor without the actual leaf! The chocolate flavor was subtle because it's all chocolate chips while the cream filling was still in its perfect custard form.   I appreciate how it wasn't overwhelm fly sweet and as usual, the pastry dough part was sweet, buttery and flakey.  Love it so much! All of it! I think we snagged up the last cruffins of the day.

SAVORY DANISH - MUSHROOM - $4
I never imagined a Danish to have while mushrooms before and I enjoyed it!  There was some cheese and there was some white gravy/sauce embedded under the Rosemary flavored mushrooms.  All this was baked on top of a flaky Danish that reminded me of a really good croissant.  I really enjoyed this one! 

PEAR DANISH - $4
This sweet Danish was pretty straight forward.  There was sweet pear and a bit of custard between the sliced fruit and pastry dough.  It wasn't too sweet and it was full of wonderful pear flavor and fruit! Gosh I love pear.

The staff is alway friendly and I love the gods they serve here.  We just chose a bad day to come where there was a camera crew that hung around to film a bit longer than they should.
author: Tu-Anh N.

description:
I live up the block. Lines are always crazy, and I always just race past it every morning to catch the bus. Stopped one day to pick up some pastries for a friend's birthday because he loves donuts. 

Cruffin of the day was pear and ginger. Meh. I wound up eating around the pudding. The hype is just ridiculous--there were several people taking photos in front of the neon sign indoors. The cashier was surly and looked like she absolutely hated life. Everyone else was super nice though. Prices are a bit...high. $5 for a simple butter croissant. 

If I didn't live up the block, I'd probably be okay with not coming here again.
author: Evelyn C.

description: I can't rave enough about this bakery, I only wish there was room to sit down and hang out - because one item is not enough!
author: Ginny A.

description:
i had tried coming here on a saturday afternoon around 3 .. and of course it was closed cuz its already sold out...
determined ... i woke my ass up early sunday morning around 8 to make it there 15 minutes before 9am for the cruffin blessing.  The cruffin of the day was gingersnap to go w/ the holiday theme.  Here goes my review for the cruffin ... its gigantic! its soo much for just one person to eat and to be honest .. it can get a little bit overwhelming.  The cruffin was good but not GREAT ..

aside from getting cruffins .. we got alot of other pastries .. including chocolate chip cookie ... and to my surprise .. my husband said .. it was ONE OF THE BEST chocolate chip cookie he had ever had... ( first one being ben's cookie from the uk) 

overall ... i think the cruffin is a little bit overhyped... but mr holmes will be my go to chocolate chip cookie spot from now on.
author: Joyce W.

description: I do love this place. My favorites being the salmon savory baked goodness and the churro croissant. I stood in front of the store for an hour one Saturday morning so prepare to wait. On the bright side we were the first ones there. Something to note is they don't serve cruffins until 9 am..... and they open at 8 am. So after waiting an hour for them to open... we weren't going to wait another hour for a cruffin.... So I still have never had a cruffin. =(
author: Azeena H.

description: Reviews were already extremely high and apparently they can get a line out the door. We showed up and there were two people inside but the place smelled delicious. We ordered 4 different items. My favorite being the blackberry pastry and it was to die for. Everything else we ordered was on point as well. Hope to come back next time I'm in town!
author: Andrew R.

description:
It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.

Worst of times:
The Ube Puffs are gone. Mr. Holmes has a seasonal menu, so the Ube Puffs have been removed indefinitely.

Best of times:
Mr. Holmes still has a bunch of killer stuff. We had the Persimmon Sweet Danish and the Apple / Butternut Squash Sweet Danish. Both were really excellent. Both had really nice flavor combinations and, above all, weren't too sweet. We also had the Cookies n' Cream Donut. It was amazingly fluffy with a great creamy filling. People complain about the wait, but it really isn't bad- in and out in 20 minutes.
author: Cameron S.

description:
The cruffin was overhyped for me : ( Overall 4 stars for their baked goods since not everything we tried was that great. I came here on two separate occasions and got different items each time. The first time I stopped by on a Friday around 1:30pm, and there was no line at the time. Of course, they had sold out of the cruffins a few hours ago. The second time I made the mistake of coming on New Year's Eve day, and there was already a super long line at 8:30am (you can start standing in line early but they only start selling the cruffins at 9am each morning). It's a maximum of 2 cruffins/person, so bring more people if you want to purchase more cruffins. Since we were so far back in the line they already sold out of the other cruffin flavor by the time we got to the front. They charge you for a box unless you purchase a minimum of 4-5 items. So far, I've tried:

-Salted Chocolate Chip Cookie ($3.00): FREAKIN' DELICIOUS. This cookie was nice and chewy, and I loved the ratio of chocolate chip to salt- highly recommended!
-From L to R: Salted Caramel Donut ($3.50), Chocolate Kouign Amann ($3.50), Sticky Bun ($4.50) [http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=wZsK1NZzKCSNtyXFhbldPA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg]: The donut was just ok for me since the salted caramel was too sweet. The chocolate kouign amann was good, but nothing special. The sticky bun was my favorite out of the three, and nice and buttery- I would only get this one again.
-Pomegranate Cruffin ($4.50, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qW6NAWfyLDDKqv8NYs-BOg&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Just ok, and not worth the hype, although I think the pomegranate flavor had something to do with my disappointment- it was too tart for me.
-Ube Puff ($4.50) & California Croissant ($5) [http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=zgJD0CEdpkfZiQeEGcjqAQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg]: Just ok; the prickly pear icing on top was too sweet and overpowered the taste of the ube filling. I wasn't a fan of the California Croissant- it was too weird to have salmon and pickled ginger inside of a croissant, in my opinion. I also though the croissant was dry, and not at all flaky.
-Choux Bomb ($4, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=tFHdtVpPp07BBoZcLW1Aig&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum, delicious!! i love the piece of caramel inside, and the custard was creamy and smooth- recommended!
-Donut ($3.50 each): I didn't like the Orange Cream flavor (too orange-y and flowery tasting), but the Earl Gray was good. The jam filled was too tart and I didn't like it. 

I would definitely come back for more cruffins and cross my fingers it wasn't the pomegranate flavor that day, but not sure I would stand in line for a couple hours again to get it. They don't always run out of cruffins right away, and it really depends on the day, so worth it to call ahead and check if you're in the area. I will also be back for the salted chocolate chip cookie (amazing) and to try their other items. Parking in this area can be difficult, but there is street parking available.
author: Amy D.

description:
Definition of a fool : walking here on my 'less-carb' day.
What were I thinking?! Cruffins, apparently.
What was intended to be one cruffin became two cruffins, ferrero rocher roux bomb, california croissant, and pistachio kouign amann.
I'd probably shamelessly fight a grandma for that ferrero rocher roux bomb but the other things were also crazily delicious. Flaky pastry, smooth cream with reasonable sweetness, burnt sugary crisp, hmm...

*Looking at the empty wrappers*
Mr.Holmes :1 VS Willpower : 0
author: Jenny T.

description:
Wow, we stood in line for an hour for cruffins on a Sunday morning. The limit is two per person and the flavor was chocolate passion fruit. If you buy six pastries, they will give you a box. 

My box consisted of: 2 cruffins, raspberry donut, California croissant, strawberry jalapeño brioche, kouign aman, and ube puff. 

My favorite was the California croissant. I loved the smoked salmon with buttery croissant. It was delicious!

The cruffin was OK but I would definitely not wait in line for it. The combination of chocolate and passion fruit was very interesting. 

My least favorite was the ube puff. The thick icing was too overwhelming. Too sweet, too sugary, and too tart. It muted the flavor of the ube filling. 

I came once to check it out and I'm good.
author: Vivian H.

description: This is such an amazing place to go. Cruffins are so amazing and totally worth standing in line for. Got up early in the morning and it totally payed off. So so good! Also recommend the matcha croissant. Super flaky and buttery, coated in sugar, dipped in matcha. I've been here two times and looking forward to coming again! Highly recommend Mr Holmes!!
author: Isabel C.

description:
This place is overhyped. It's really only good for the famous "I got baked in San Francisco" light up sign. The prices here are ridiculous and the pastries aren't that much to rave about. I got one of each flavor for the donuts (mint chocolate, peach, and something mascarpone... I forgot the exact name of the flavor) and a Ube pop tart. Each donut was almost $4 and the pop tart was $4 as well. I wish I could've gotten a cruffin because the day I went they had a brownie flavor. I was also hoping they were gonna have their matcha flavored donut, but that's okay. I think my favorite was the mint chocolate because it had a well balanced mint to chocolate flavor ratio. I was impressed with that flavor. 

The shop was also smaller than I expected and it gets super crowded because everyone wants a picture in front of their famous sign. So you do wanna get here as early as possible to beat the lines, the crowd, and to get the parties you want. Service was good, the cashier lady put on a little convo with my friend and I while we were waiting for our pastries.
author: Danielle Q.

description:
4.5 Stars!

Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is such a ballsy bakery with unique and delicious flavors! Makes me want to quit my job so I can stand in line every morning for cruffins and donuts. Sadly, I need that job to pay for a gym membership so I can work off said cruffins and donuts. A girl can dream, though. Dream about chocolate hazelnut cruffins...rocky road cruffins...chocolate & blood orange cruffins...salted caramel donuts...caramelized banana donuts...mmm! And the Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb really is da bomb! ; )
author: Rose A.

description:
Came on Tuesday, July 5, at around 8:30am.  There were about 10 people already in line.  Cruffins were filled with a coffee creme filling, I believe.  This was SOOOO good.  It was similar to a croissant with a crunchy exterior and a soft, flaky interior.  The creme added a perfect complement to the "croissant/muffin" part of the pastry.  A must try if you can here on a weekday.    

I also tried the kouign amann.  In terms of texture, I thought it was very similar to the cruffin with a crunchy exterior and soft, flaky interior.  The main difference is that this one had a caramelized sugar glaze on the exterior and no creme inside.  Also, it wasn't shaped like a muffin.  This is also a very good pastry, but I did like the cruffin better.  

I'm not sure I'd be willing to come here on a weekend and brave the long lines, but it was definitely worth a visit and well worth your time to see if you think the cruffin lives up to the hype.  (I think it does.)
author: Philbert W.

description:
Cruffins are worth the wait in line. We had the PB&J one and they were out-of-this world delicious and different than anything I've ever had.

Mushroom savory pastry was just that... Savory...and tasty. The puff pastry really can't be outdone here. If you like a good duxelles, get this!

The most surprising thing was the donuts! We had the Strawberry donut that day and omg all 3 of us were beyond impressed. The best donut ever, that actually tasted like REAL strawberries.

This place makes me want to move to SF immediately. You can bypass the line if you don't want Cruffins. Also they limit the number of Cruffins you can buy..2 per person so bring friends if you want to share with others. Highly recommend yet fearing the line will grow longer with all the great reviews.
author: Emily C.

description: So nice to visit the original Mr. Holmes! Their cookies are huge and insane here..... huge and insane. San Francisco doesn't "get" cookies... I have never found good ones.  But they are good here! The Cornflake cookie is sweet, salty and caramelized. The chocolate chip.... forgettaboutit! I still haven't had the Cruffin because I can't order anything other than cookies! Get your belly in here!
author: Ari R.

description:
Mr Holmes has become one of the most IG'd bakeries in SF according to one article I just read. From their sleek white and gold boxes, the pink neon sign against the white subway tiled walls and the black and white tiled floor that reads "Holmes Sweet Holmes", Mr Holmes certainly seems to understand the marketing aspect in this business. 

I've said before that I won't wait up in a long queue for food and will leave that to the tourists but curiosity got the best of me after seeing countless photos of yet another pastry hybrid the cruffin. Like a sucker I eventually caved and had to get my hands on one of these. So we set the alarm clock to stand in line and headed out way too early on a Saturday morning for their much raved about cruffins. 

We arrived at 8:30 as cruffins are served promptly at 9am. Upon arrival it was surprising to see the cruffin queue was already about 70 people deep. The other line had about 30. They make 150 single flavored cruffins a day and a sticker (the golden ticket) allows you to purchase 2 max. We walked out with $50 worth of pastries (we kinda over did it, no?) since we were going to make the time spent waiting here worth it.  

Some notables:

cruffins - I'm sure you're familiar with the cronut that took NYC in a whirlwind a couple years ago but these are croissant dough in a muffin shape (opposed to the donut shape) hence the name cruffin. It was flaky, sweet with a burned caramel type flavoring up top. I personally didn't care for the caramel as it was too sweet for me but it eventually erupted into yet another filling (chocolate custard?) towards the very center of the cruffin. I preferred the filling over the top caramel. 

choux bombs - messy to eat, a tad too much filling but nevertheless they were delicious

Donuts - a "doughgroni" (in celebration of Negroni Week) is a donut that accompanied vial of negroni to inject the pastry. We also had what I initially thought was vanilla custard filled donut but ended up being a citron flavored filling. Perhaps it's because I've been avoiding sugar as much as possible for the last two-three weeks however I found the fillings were much too sweet for my tastes. However the donut itself was perfection and this was for me the clear winner. I may be biased bc I am very partial to donuts. 

You can't help but feel sorry for those who naively arrived later and stood in the cruffin line (particularly those who traveled from outside the city) after the stickers were already distributed. But they later found after overhearing others or checking their phones there is a daily limit on these things. Doing some research beforehand might have helped them avoid their rookie blunder. 

As much as I liked this bakery and they have some very legit pastries the wait is just too much. I might be back but for me, I'll probably just wait in the non-cruffin line.
author: Esther A.

description:
On my first morning in sunny (yet chilly) San Francisco, I found myself off on a morning trek to the famous Mr Holmes Bakehouse. This bakery was recommended by people both on and offline, and upon approaching the venue I knew by the wonderful smells of buttery baked pastries, that I knew I wouldn't be disappointed.

In New York City people are queuing up for Dominique Ansel's cronut, a hybrid between the croissant and the donut. But, over on the west side people are going gaga for Mr Holmes' cruffin, a fusion of a croissant and a muffin.
