At Mr Holmes the cruffins come out at 9am, but be sure to get there early as lines start even before opening and cruffins are limited to two per person. The flavours are posted on Instagram beforehand, so if there is a flavour you're seeking you can check for updates.

That morning the flavour was Passionfruit, which luckily enough would have to be one of my favourite flavours! I did not have an original cronut to compare with, but the cruffin was worth the hype. The filling packed a fruity punch, while the croissant dough was flaky, buttery and slightly sugary.

I also greedily grabbed a box of other goodies, but to be honest I forgot the names of all of them. However, I can tell you one of the standouts was the California Croissant, do yourself a favour and order one, you won't regret it. It's basically a croissant with smoked salmon, pickled ginger, nori and wasabi in the centre. A delicious savoury option topped with sesame seeds and served with a packet of soy sauce.

Definitely put this on your San Francisco list, and don't miss out on the cruffins!
author: Fran L.

description: The wait wasn't that long. The original pastry from them is delicious. I also tried the sausage one which is good to pair with one of their sweet ones
author: Natasha R.

description:
I've been here several times already and am a fan of all their pastries.  I come at 730am on weekdays to avoid the lines.  

Their donuts are my favorite, not overly sweet.
author: Angelica C.

description:
I don't get the hype! I've had the cruffin  - it's messy but good. It's probably the only pastry I liked from here. The jelly donuts were maybe my 2nd favorite, but everything else like the koign amanns, bread pudding, cookie, and the assortment of pastries I bought in a box,...very average! 

I definitely prefer b. patisserie!
author: Joanna S.

description:
*DISCLAIMER*--Waking up early and standing in line is all a part of a great food adventure.
If you are not willing to do what it takes to get your hands on the goods, this might not be your place.
But if you're like me and are always down to jump through hoops for a delicious treat, save this place in your bookmark, set your alarm, and plan your early morning trip, ASAP.
Trust me, well worth it!

I dragged my babies and husband out of bed early on the Labor Day Holiday this weekend, thinking it would be either really crazy busy, or super slow.  We rarely all have the same schedule, so I took advantage of it and crossed my fingers and prayed to the Cruffin Gods for the latter. We passed the shop at about 5 after 8 and saw about 2-3 people in line. (YESS!!) In the no more than 10 min it took to find parking, unload my sleepy family, and walk over, there were about 15 people in line ahead of us.  If you're serious on getting your hands on a Cruffin, plan to get in line between 8-8:15 am.
This morning's flavor was Banana's Fosters.  The chocoholic in me was hoping for something more decadent, but I was still excited to try it out.  We waited it out, keeping the kids busy with iPhones, as the line grew and grew behind us. I can't count how many times I heard people pass by and say, "This line is ridiculous!"  But I knew deep down inside, they were all just kicking themselves for not getting up earlier! Before you knew it the line began moving.  We made it to the counter of the tiny shop and were allowed 2 Cruffins per person.  You better believe we took full advantage and purchased 8 (to share with family of course).  We also somehow managed to fill up 2 additional boxes with other goods, and spent way more than I care to admit.  Here are the takeaways from our purchase:

**Banana Foster's Cruffin-- SOO Yummy!  Did not even remember I was hoping for something chocolate.  Croissant was slightly sweet, with just the right balance of buttery-ness to flakey-ness.  Filling was a deliciously creamy banana custard with real banana fruit pieces hidden in there.
**Ube Puff-- Same well done pastry, filling was true to the Taro Root, and not overly sweetened or processed or "purpled."
**Bread Pudding-- Just okay.  Could have used a yummy sauce to go with it.
**Choux Bomb-- (White Chocolate) My favorite next to the Cruffin.  Decadent and sweet, filled with a white chocolate pastry cream that was stacked to the heavens!  And the cutest piece of salted fudge tucked in there.

I've heard through the grapevine that if you come on a weekday, you can likely show up at 9am and still get some Cruffins, no need to tough out the line.  Strongly considering taking a sick day to test out the theory.  The Yelp community deserves to know!
author: Arcie Marie D.

description:
We waited so long to check this famous place out only to be kinda let down. Service was fast n friendly I just loved the kid working the door this morning ! 

The egg nog donut was good but heavy

The savory bread puddin tasty, rosemary GREAT a Must have!!

Ham cheese croissant average

Heard great things from owner of a coffee bar down the street about Mr H's owner so that is always a good thing... maybe coming back in future to give another try.
author: Lisa S.

description:
Came across mr Holmes bake shop without knowing, until we saw the line out the door.  Peaked inside and there were Bambollini and boxes with the peace sign.  They are popular for their crouffins but when we were there after noon, they already sold out.
We opted for a mango stuffed Bambollini.  It's good.  Airy pillow of fried dough stuffed with mango filling. 
Probably need to try their crouffin one day to judge!
author: Linda T.

description:
I'm a clueless guy from out of town, serious amateur baker, I see this setup walking down a random street and am impressed by the breadth of the kitchen so have to try the product. It's 1:30 in the afternoon so I have no idea, until I go on Yelp, that people line up in the morning for this stuff.

Was my $4 caramel filled donut good? Yes. Was it better than the east coast's mass produced Croissant Donut you don't have to wait in line for at $2.49? No, a tie. Would I wait in line 30 minutes or an hour for a crunwitch or whatever? Very unlikely. 

Sometimes i feel like people in SF are like people in Soviet Russia: you see a line, you have to get in it. (Or as we say in NY, "on" it.) On the other hand, those who say "the lines are too long plus it's too expensive" should probably move to said USSR because they don't know how supply and demand works.
author: Otis M.

description:
Finally got baked. Came here on a Monday morning just before 9:00AM and there were about 15 people ahead of me. The flavor of the day was WHITE CHOCOLATE CARDAMOM.

The good:
+Very generous filling to croissant ratio! 
+I love custard, and the cardamom added a really unique twist to the overall flavor profile. I couldn't really taste the white chocolate, though?
+Good consistency. I was very happy to see all the buttery, flaky layers when I cut into my cruffin
+This is a plus for me, but I would say that a cruffin is more of a croissant than a muffin. The only thing that's muffin is the shape (for people who are expecting a muffin consistency/flavor)

The not so good:
-Excessively dusted with sugar, which was very messy to cut through
-If you buy less than 6 pastries, they put your cruffin in a bag so the cream gets smeared if you don't eat it right away :(
-People traffic, even on early weekdays...
-Pricey

Many have said that a cruffin is a west coast version of a cronut, but I disagree. The croissant is less dense and more substantially piped with custard - definitely the superior of the two. Would definitely come back to sample all of the other flavors!
author: Patricia Z.

description: It's was my first time going to cali San Francisco. I was hungry in the morning. I was looking for breakfast. I got at least 4 cruffins; it was so good
author: Sarah Z.

description:
I worked a part of a team to obtain these Cruffins. 

Player A (myself): drive vehicle without getting a ticket/accident/arrested. 
Drop off Player B to Bakehouse. 
Search for valid and legal parking without getting crushed by a bus or large vehicle. 
Run back to Bakehouse, and join Player B in Cruffin line. 
Allow Player B to stand in non-Cruffin to obtain food to hold yourself over.

We tried California croissant. This is salmon wrapped in nori, wrapped in a croissant, and sprinkled with sesame seeds and furikake! I personally expected this to be salty and very flakey. It was just right amount of salt for me, did not need to add the additional soy sauce. This was a great way to hold me over while standing in line. I would get this again!

When we received the stickers, there was a great sense of relief, and a great number of people started to stare into the window of Cruffin and the drooling and photo taking began.

Finally, it was Lemon Meringue Cruffins and covered in sugar. The cream topping and lemon was excellent, I shared one as we were planning to go out to brunch. My only mistake was eating this in a car which was very messy, but I ate up all the crumbs. I would highly recommend the Cruffins. 

I will have to return to try the other items in the near future.

Repeat process, drive to brunch location, drop off Player B........
author: Brandon W.

description: Came here to try a cruffin to see if it lives up to the hype, and it was not bad! If I could give 3.5 stars, I'd probably do that. The bakery is small and cute and smells amazing. The staff was also very nice and friendly. The cruffin of the day was peanut butter toffee, and it was tasty! The pastry was nice and flaky and the filling tasted peanut buttery. I don't think it's something I'll ever need to try again though. The filling was basically a pudding, which is fine, but I'd prefer something a little lighter. It was a perfectly good treat, but it didn't stand out to me compared to other pastries I've had. Overall, whereas the cronuts from Dominique Ansel in NYC are something I'd dream about having again, the cruffin is a fun novelty, worth trying once to get it out of your system, but nothing to write home about.
author: Rachel D.

description: People totally exaggerate here. When you google where to go in SF most of the websites directs you to visit here for some reason, but I can't see a reason to come here with the eye of a tourist. Yes I bring my friends who come abroad here to take a photo in front of their famous sign "I got baked in SF" because it is cool. But that is it. Their desserts are not adorable or something. I didn't even try for a second time. I just take my coffee since it's just near my apartment.
author: Zeynep D.

description: I found this bakery on my way home from running errands. The smell in itself caught my attention. I walked into a tiny shop with fair priced baked goods. I chose an orange filled sugar donut and chocolate passionfruit cruffin. Both items were AMAZING. I can't wait to go back again to try something new.
author: Madison L.

description: Do you know the cruffinman? I do now and I love him. If you're in San Fran and love bakeries you must stop here. I went twice. FYI First time there was a normal line and we could pick anything, second time there were two lines flowing down both directions of the sidewalk. Turned out one line was for cruffins (and they gave us a sticker guaranteeing 2 cruffins) and the other line was for all other bakery items.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I came here early to get cruffins only to find out they don't bring them out until 9:00 am. I guess I didn't notice that point in one of the reviews. So I bought a few other pastries. They were okay. The matcha croissant just had matcha frosting on it. I would have liked some matcha filling. Also had a
Mexican chocolate donut, raspberry kougin amann, and churro croissant. I've had Dominique Ansel's kougin amann and I thought that one was fantastic. The only pastry that I thought was exceptional was the churro croissant because this one did have a filling.  I'll have to come back for a cruffin.  Also if you want a box they require you to purchase 6 items or they charge you .87.
author: Erin G.

description:
This was really just ok. I didn't get to try their famous cruffin, but I had everything else. The croissant wasn't anyting special, go somewhere else if you want a good one, my sister tried one from here and one from Bouchon or Ariscault and through away this one. 

I did get their savory Bread Pudding and that was excellent, as well as their Monkey Bread. Parking here is tough for out of town people, and the area just seems a tad run down. Overall, i wouldn't come here again unless I was getting a Cruffin.
author: Duncan H.

description:
After months and months of obsessing over all of the pictures posted on social media of decadent, lavish pastries, I finally planned a day with the BF where I put my foot down and said "WE ARE GOING HERE. Wake up at 7am. NO excuses!"
So, as committed as I was, even though we woke up a bit late (30 minutes), we left and made our hour long journey to wait in line for the infamous Cruffin.

Lo and behold, when we got there (btw the area is in the TL if you didn't see that already, so be prepared to dodge poop and pee on the sidewalk), the line was already 20ish people long just for the cruffin--not bad for arriving close to Cruffin time, aka 9am!! While the bf waited in the cruffin line, I entered the storefront to grab some baked goodies ^__^ Once the cruffin line started at 9am, it took us about an hour before we walked out with 4 cruffins and several other baked goods, all in 2 of their recognizable boxes. HOORAY!! 

WHAT WE GOT:

1) Doughnuts: Flavors of the day was nutella and lemon curd--the lemon curd was a lot more sour that I expected!! But it was nice because I think something sweeter would make the doughnut way too sweet. Nutella doughnut was good but not great. I love love love doughnuts, so there are a couple other doughnut shops that reign over these Holmies (I'm so lame ha!). Nonetheless, because of my love for doughnuts I'd probably get them again if/when they are different flavors!

2) Amelie Aman: YES. DROOL. PLEASE. Give me another. One of my favorites actually! It's sweet, crispy, melt in your mouth, everything. Just try it.

3) Blueberry brioche bun: this one was meh. EH. I had my sister try this as well and we weren't too impressed. A one time try was enough for me.

4) California Croissant: If you want something savory, get this! Surprisingly, I enjoyed this one, even without the soy sauce they give with it...and my sister and the bf agreed too. Different, but good. 

5) Almond bostock: hmm this was pretty good! It's this pound-cake like toast thing with almond paste and sliced almonds on top. If you like almonds/almond-tasting things, you'll love this. For me, I felt it to be a bit too sweet--if there was a bit less sugar I'd be a completely happy camper (but maybe the sweetness thing is just me, I don't eat sweets very often so I don't think I'm accustomed to them)

6) Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb: A bit too sweet for me on this one too, I think there was just so much filling--maybe put half of it and it would be perfect. I loved the hazelnut taste in every bite though!

7) THE CRUFFIN: Yes yes, everyone is going crazy over this. Well....it's basically a morning bun, but with an added twist/filling/flavor in the middle. As half croissant, half muffin, the presentation is always on point. I have to admit, I did a photo shoot with one of the cruffins.... ^__^ The cruffin of the day was smores--with a torched marshmallow on top! The bf and I both thoroughly enjoyed eating this, peeling away layers, taking bites, and loving the chocolate filling. Be prepared for sugar EVERYWHERE. This will be messy when you eat it. Just a warning. Limit is 2 per person too!
author: Shannon N.

description:
How To Mr. Holmes Bakehouse:
- 7:30 - Arrive early. Bring a friend to be your partner in cruffiny crime. 
- There are two lines forming :: one for pastries at 8am, the other for cruffins at 9am. 
- Jump into the cruffin line - that pastry line will die down by 8:20, leaving plenty of pastries for your leisurely purchase once the pastry crowd has all filed in behind you in the cruffin line.
- 8:30 - Leave your friend in the cruffin line to go make your/their pastry purchases. To get an awesomely-branded Mr. Holmes box that you'll convince yourself to upcycle to hold useless things on your bookshelf, you have to buy 6 pastries. Take your picture of the "I got baked in San Francisco" sign, because if you don't, were you even really there? Then get back in line to await your sticker.
- 8:45ish - Stickers are handed out. A sticker guarantees you 2 cruffins. No sticker? Don't stomp home angry. Some folks just purchase one cruffin, so there is hope yet!
- 9:00 - Buy your cruffins and go sit in a park or something and get baked, as they say.

Pro Tip: they apparently deliver and accept orders, so you could potentially just avoid all that. Just check out the website for details. (www.mrholmesbakehouse.com)

PS - My favs were the Ube Puff, the Strawberry Jalepeno Brioche and the donuts. God, the donuts.
author: Amanda W.

description: Had to stop by this place to try their cruffins (croissant-muffin)! Came in the early afternoon, but it was very difficult to find parking. After circling the block about 3 times, my boyfriend decided to drop me off to buy some pastries. They have different flavors on the daily, so it's always a little sweet surprise. I got to try the chocolate orange flavored cruffin and it lives up to it's expectations. Perfect amount of filling with just the right amount of sugar on the outside. Would be a perfect pairing with your morning coffee.
author: Michelle S.

description:
I knew I had to check this place out before I fly back to Seattle and so happy I got the chance to! Though I made the mistake of just looking at the photos on Yelp and not reading the reviews...otherwise I would have known to come at 8AM. My friend and I arrived around noon and I was a bit confused when I went in. I only saw a few of the dulce de leche out and thought they were probably going to put out more pastries, so I only bought 2 for me and my friend to try. After paying and everything, I realized those were just what were left for the day and that they were going to be sold out soon. More people swarm in after me and it was sold out in like less than 5mins!

Sighhh so much regret for being stupid and just buying 2. The dulce de leche was SOOO GOOD. I thought it would be overly sweet, but it wasn't...like I could probably eat at least 3 of these one after another. Next time I know to 1. Go early in the morning and 2. Buy as much as I possibly can (meaning bring people who don't really care for pastries with me so I can buy more hehe)
author: Jamie L.

description: Churro croissant worth the line; which moves fast by the way.  We also had the cruffin with quince filling, which was crunchy, flakey and sweet (but not too).  Delicious start to the post Christmas week.
author: Larry H.

description:
What is a Cruffin?

I've seen enough pictures on instagram to know that Mr Holmes Bakehouse was definitely worth waking up early on Saturday morning and lining up.

I arrived there at 8:30 with my boyfriend and immediately noticed two things:
1. There are dozens of people already lined up
2. There are two lines, one for the Cruffins and one for the rest of the baked goods

We didn't know which line was which so my boyfriend got in the first line we reached and I went to go check which was which. It ended up being that my boyfriend lined up in the normal line (to the right of the bakery) and I lined up in the Cruffin line (to the left of the bakery). 

Although the bakery was already open at 8:30, the cruffins aren't for sale until 9am. My boyfriend got to the front of his line fairly quickly; he probably waited around 20 minutes. Tip* If you do split up with your party make sure to look up what regular baked goods you want! Thankfully I had all of the yelp pictures to help me decide what I wanted as I was stuck in the Cruffin line. I asked him to get me a Banana Cream filled Donut, Amelie, 2 of the White Chocolate Rasberry Brioches, and a Ferrero Roche Brioche Bomb. 

Meanwhile, as it neared 9am, someone came out with cute pink stickers to pass out to the line - I think the amount of stickers indicate how many cruffins they have to sell so if you have a sticker, you're good to go. I was also able to get a sticker for my boyfriend too, who shortly after came back with 3 boxes of bake goods lol. 

We got to the front of the line around 9:20am. Each person is limited to 2 cruffins each and on the day I went they were serving a Pecan Brownie Cruffin decorated with Gold Flakes (?). I forget... But, I do know that it was SO GOOD when I actually tasted it. It was nice and flakey, just like a croissant, but had a nice creamy chocolate filling and a sugary coating on the outside that made every bite so delicious! The inside of the bakery is small, but does the job. I also love the lit up sign that says "I Got Baked in San Francisco". 

All in all, we waited about an hour for the Cruffins but it went by so fast that it didn't really feel like it was that long. And anyway, the Cruffins are worth every second that you have to wait so I definitely recommend it. 

I will be back!
author: Michelle C.

description:
I noticed this place on Instagram shortly before I moved here and immediately put it on my list of "musts" for my first week in SF. I love croissants, I love muffins - hey, who am I kidding? I love all pastries! - this place was practically made for me. My roommate and I arrived around 7:30 on a Saturday (I believe it opens at 8) and were met with a mid-sized line (about 15-20 people ahead of us). Luckily, it moved fast and were

The cruffin was everything I would have dreamed it to be. While I'm a huge fan of sweets, I tend to stay away from filled donuts because the filling-to-donut ratio never seems right, and I'm always inundated with all this goo that I don't want. This was not the case with the cruffin (which was filled with some sort of raspberry chocolate mixture). After we took pictures with the iconic "I Got Baked in San Francisco" sign, we went home to devour our goodies - within minutes I was practically licking the plate.

Honestly, I felt this place lived up to hype and I will definitely be going back for more treats soon.
author: Madeline K.

description:
Things you should know about Mr. Holmes Bakehouse:

1. The lines are worth it

2. Make sure you get in the CORRECT line.  There are 2 - 1 for regular stuff (open at 8am on weekends and 7am on weekdays) and the other for cruffins (come out at 9am).  To maximize your time, I highly suggest bringing a friend so that you can split up.  Whomever waits in the regular line can then feed the both of you during your cruffin wait.  

3. Cruffins are the bomb and I am now convinced that every muffin should be morphed into cruffin format.  Flaky goodness with delicious fillings?  Come on, this is a no-brainer.  One other thing?  2 cruffin limit per person

4. Other yummy items: 
    - Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb - tastes like the chocolate, but better
    - Passionfruit anything - I don't even like passionfruit, but I love their passionfruit filling.  It tastes so FRESH 
    - California Croissant - though I was originally hesitant about sushi flavors inside a croissant, I know now that any croissant hybrid is pure awesomeness
author: Sheila C.

description:
Solid 2.5 star.
Place is clean and people were pleasant. Pastries tasted good but was not worth the price. Maybe it's the fancy box the reason they charge that much?

The other reason for not rating them higher is I know I will never be able to taste their "cruffins". They only start selling at certain time in the mornings. A limited number of cruffins is produced daily. There is always a line. They always sell out.

I have a life and a job like most of us. So I believe it is worth waiting hours for a piece of pastry.
author: Ken D.

description:
This place has great pastries!  It gets 4 not 5 stars only because I live a couple doors down and have to put up with the daily Cruffin line and the loud announcements at 9am every morning under my windows.  They sometimes sell out of everything by 11am or noon but otherwise they are open until 3ish.

The line for the Cruffins (croissant dough baked in a muffin tin and filled/topped with some different flavored cream and goodies daily) is usually long and starts around 8:15-8:30.  Cruffins come out at 9am and they only make a limited amount daily.  If you don't want Cruffins and just want other pastries, YOU CAN SKIP THE LINE!  They have two different donuts that are also filled with different things daily.  I think you can check what the daily offerings are via Twitter but I don't tweet so I just peek my head in and ask.

The sweet pastries are better than the savory in my opinion.  They cycle through things by season so you can't always get the same things (I love the Ube Puff and the Stollen, which is dipped in bacon fat and rolled in sugar, but both are now unavailable).  The kouign amann, the bostocks and the Ferrero Rocher hazelnut dipped croissants are favorites.

Most of the people who work there are super nice and friendly and they sell coffee but I've never tried it.  My life's motto is "I don't wait in line to see fish or art" and I would add Cruffins to that list, but if you are a more patient person than I you will be rewarded at Bakehouse.
author: Jon B.

description:
On my SF visit, I decided to walk here at noon mainly to try their famous cruffins, but little did I know, they usually run out within the first hour or so after opening. Why can't they just make more throughout the day? I'm only here once in a while..Nonetheless, I still decided to try their pastries and they definitely did not disappoint.

- Custard Donut: Delicious with a generous amount of filling. Expected the dough to be dry like those in other donut stores, but it was still soft and fluffy. 
- Mushroom Savory Danish: A must-try! Took me by surprise how good it was with the right amount of saltiness.

I believe their pastries were all around $4-5. More expensive than I hoped, but I will definitely come back again just to catch their cruffins!
author: Annie W.

description: super long line all the time unless its pouring cats and dogs. too sweet for me and my family. I feel like its all for the social media (which i am not judging since i did it for the same reason). The savory items are a lot better
author: Jan H.

description:
Saw this place on Instagram, and knew I had to come here... it was the 4th of July, so we called ahead and asked when they closed, and they said as soon as they sold out. We knew we had to get there quick! We got there around 10:45, and they still had the summer squash pastry, two types of cookies, regular croissants, and donuts. I got a cookie and croissant, and my friend got the two different types of donuts they had. The prickly pear donut was SO good - a must-get! I loved how buttery the croissant was, and the chocolate chip cookie had sea salt on top, which really upgraded the flavor. I loved it! 
This shop is very cute and aesthetic, definitely grab some pics while waiting in line.
author: Clare M.

description:
Came here earlier this morning (Friday) around 1030am. Got a box of goodies and gotta say pretty good! Had a croissant cruffin thing and the bacon/ onion and cheddar thing that was pretty hearty. The rest of the items that were in the box were given away. 

The place is easy to find, not in such a busy area so should be able to find parking a block or two away.
author: Rainier V.

description: A bakery from heaven! They have savory and sweet items. The raspberry donut and churro croissant were amazing! I usually don't love sweets but these were out of this world! They sell out of their popular desserts very fast so I recommend you go as soon as they open. Tiny place with no room to sit down but overall great place!
author: Noor S.

description: The donuts are underrated...they are AMAZING! Got in line early in the morning for cruffins since they are limited in amount. If you haven't tried it, it's worth the wait, but I personally liked the filled donuts. This place has great staff and has a wonderful neighborhood bakery feel.  Would definitely be back to try everything else!
author: Jamy P.

description: The whole experience was worth it. The line in the rain, anticipation, meeting other insane tourists who chose to wait for an hour to get a box of carbs.  I am an amateur baker and addicted to sugar therefore prefer to wait for pastries than fine dining anytime! Loved the Cruffin, the Churro croissant was my fave. Next time we are in San Fransisco we will most likely go on a weekday instead of a holiday weekend yet go we will!!!
author: Elizabeth F.

description: I've been to Mr. Holmes in Los Angeles a handful of times. It's more than an IG trend (even though it's great that it's IG worthy), as these pastries are pretty innovative. I don't know any other places that offer such interesting creations in the West Coast (Dominique Ansel, please come to Cali, specifically SF b/c I live here now) so I think it's worth the occasional splurge. I came on a Sunday to grab some treats for a coworker's upcoming birthday. R drove because we were out at dimsum at Mission Bay. Parking can be difficult to find,even though we got super lucky. Walking here can be a bit of a leery task too, since the trek here involves passing through somewhat less than pleasurable circumstances. Since we came in the afternoon, all the cruffins were sold out which was too bad because they had the syringes of port wine that day inserted into the cruffins, which R  was interested in trying. Either ways, I recommend their donuts. I like them more than the cruffins anyways. I ordered the raspberry and lychee. No lie, their lychee infused flavors always blow my mind. I had gotten their Jasmine Milk Tea and Lychee a while back in LA and it was SO GOOD. I got my coworker Chamomile Blueberry and Cardamon Peach Danishes, which she said was good. The thing about the pastries here is that they're not extremely sweet. R does not have a sweet tooth whatsoever but really liked the donuts I bought. The one thing I wish they would do is have a set flavor every day because I like certain flavors more (Jasmine Milk Tea!) and wish I can always purchase them whenever I pay a visit. Expect an average of $4/ pastry, pre-tax. If you buy half a dozen, you get a free box. If you don't want to buy that much, it's a $0.87 extra charge.
author: Michelle R.

description: Woke up early on vacation before my entire family, walked here to get some pastries, saw a line and assumed everyone was waiting for the pastries. After about 10 minutes the line didn't move and finally came to the realization everyone was waiting for cruffins. There was only about 20 minutes until the cruffins were available so I stuck it out and OH MY it was worth it. Got each flavors of the cruffins available, churro croissant, matcha croissant, chocolate croissant, kouin amann and California croissant. Had a bit of each sharing with my family and they were all so good! Although they were all pretty much croissants (crisp on the outside and perfectly soft and flaky within), each was uniquely constructed and flavored. The churro croissant, which was stuffed with dulce de leche cream, was my favorite.
author: Megan K.

description:
Going to Mr Holmes Bakehouse has changed me for forever. I almost feel sorry for the next pastry place I go to. They don't stand a chance. It isn't fair that the next bakery will have to stand up to the awesomeness that was the Cruffin that was stacked and swirled with caramelized banana, peanut butter, and chocolate and topped with crunchy chocolate and peanuts. It isn't fair that the next bakery will also have to find a way to out do the Brioche Bomb that was filled with deliciously sticky sweet blueberry filling.  It also isn't fair that the next bakery will also have to find a way to impress me with their rendition of the kouign amann after having had the Amelie Amann that was flaky, sweet, and just slightly crispy with the caramelized sugary bottom.

It just isn't fair. But hey. As my mom says, "Life isn't fair." 

I mean it when I say that standing in a line early in the morning in the part of the Loin that looks highly unsavory is totally worth it. I came here as a way to kick off my birthday and I honestly couldn't have given myself a better present or start to my day. I'll be back with every intention of buying myself a box (or two) worth of their delightful pastries!
author: Lisa I.

description:
Good but good enough to warrant the line? Hm, I'll have to think about this. I'm leaning towards no.

Love the super cute "I got baked in San Francisco" sign--very nice touch for the small space. No room to enjoy the treats on-site, of course.
author: Yad L.

description:
Went this past holiday Monday to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse to try to get the infamous cruffin. Shop opened at 8am, but cruffins start at 9am. Got there around 8:50am and the line was already about 50 people long down the block. Funny enough though (since there is a separate line for cruffins and cruffins-only), there was no line for the other pastries. So since it's best to roll as a team with someone else, one of us stayed in line and the other went and got a box of the other goodies to take with us, plus a croissant to munch on with our coffee in line.

Cruffin line got going around 9am and probably around 9:15ish, a guy came out and was counting the line and told the lady in front of us, she was probably good, we were shaky and everyone behind us should leave. This is because each person can buy 2 cruffins (and most people do). We decided to stay in line and as it worked out, when we got to the front, the woman in front of us with her kid got only 3 instead of 4 because she was nice and so we got the very last cruffin! (As a side note, I think children shouldn't count as a person to get 2 more cruffins, but I saw a few people pull that one.)

So how was the cruffin? Not as good as the other pastries we got! The flavor (they only have one a day) was raspberry pistachio (I think), and I wasn't that into it. Wish it had been something more appealing to me like toffee or PB banana. The other treats we got were better I thought, and with no line, I'd go back for them instead. 

- Ferrero Rocher choux bomb - did taste just like a ferrero rocher, but too rich for me
- Amelie amann - pretty good! not my favorite, but one of the group's favorite
- Blueberry brioche bomb - good
- Almond something square - the best!! my favorite! 
- Banana creme filled donut - good
- Raspberry creme fille donut - less good
author: MaryKate M.

description:
"Wow! This is the one place that could actually profit off selling the muffin BOTTOMS!" --High praise, from my aunt, while eating the bottom half of a cruffin we split. (We assumed I was getting the better part. Ha!)

Maybe Mr. Holmes deserves five stars for this impressive feat, but let me explain my hesitancy...

I came for the cruffin. And I left with a cruffin. And I now love cruffins. But. I didn't expect my cruffin to have chocolate pudding in it, and it did. What I have to say about that is... I wish it was just the cruffin. I guess I'm sure lots of people lots that pudding. And I'd order it on the side, that's for DAMN sure. But honestly, I felt the flavors of the flaky, buttery pastry were so so mouth watering and delectable, I didn't want to be distracted by any sort of pudding. I just wanted to spend all of my time with that delicious cruffin. 

Maybe I got lucky, and didn't have to wait, but there were...15-20 people in front of us, and that line went FAST (until I got there and slowed things down because I had to talk about everything). But I couldn't have waited more than 15 minutes. So people, take note, hit them up on a weekday. (Unless, do they have a different selection on weekend days???) 

Point is. Their pastry is absolutely phenomenal, and, well... I've eaten a ton of pastry. It's why I'm not so thin. But that's how much I love pastry. And theirs is ACES. People of San Francisco, you are SO lucky you live here and you can come to Mr. Holmes' anytime you want. I'm going to head on home to have some dreams about their sugary baked dough done absolutely right.
author: Tina S.

description: The donuts and pastries are top notch and it is very popular. It would be nice if the service was a bit better.
author: Brandon G.

description: Ignore the neighborhood and definitely stop by. You are greeted with a smile and you feel welcome from the moment you step in. The pastries and all goodies are yummy. The pecan and apple pastry is flaky and not overly sweet. The stuffed donut is surprisingly light and the cream filling is a nice surprise with each bite. They ran out of cruffins which was sad. However, their chocolate chip cookies made things better. It's a cookie done right. The edges are slightly crispy with a nice chewy center. The salt on top gives it that extra something special. They really pay attention to the little things like their packaging. Everything is so adorable. This place is a must!
author: Eve C.

description:
I can't believe I spent $40 on a box of pastries but it was well worth it. Set out to get there in time to try their famous cruffin but we were too late. So I basically ordered everything else they had to offer. Really, there is no going wrong on anything here. The only thing we didn't like was their California Croissant...not our thing. Definitely different.

Chocolate Chip Cookie (4/5)
Chocolate Croissant (4/5)
Salted Caramel filled donut (4/5)
Amelie Amann (5/5) My fave, probably even more so than B. Patisserie!
Banana Cream filled donut (3/5)
California Croissant (2/5)
author: Tiffany L.

description:
It's the early bird that catches the worm.  

Since I didn't arrive until after 10:00, this bird didn't even get within range of, much less catch, the worm (a cruffin).

I did get a bourbon pecan donut.  It was pillowy soft.  It was uber fresh.  It was loaded w creamy filling that had just a hint of bourbon flavor.  The top of the donut is covered w chopped pecans, which of course landed all over my lap in the car.  My fault.  I couldn't wait until I got home (or anywhere, for that matter) to devour it.  The quality is what really came through, more so than flavor, along w the incredible creaminess of the filling.

What came next was the big hit.  The strawberry jalapeño brioche bomb was totally remarkable.  It has a buttery rich crumb topping (which I also, happily, got all over my lap), & a jalapeño spiked strawberry filling that was fantastic.  The pepper notes compliment the strawberry so well.  It's like 2 good friends that you never thought would click, & they end up dating, then get engaged, then get married.  They turn out to be a perfect couple.  

I loved this filling.  I could spread it on so many things.  Pancakes.  Scones.  Croissants.  Biscuits.  Shortbread. Toast.  It'd be great on cheesecake.  The heat from the jalapeño is mild, but it lingers on after you've finished.  Fabulous.  I wished I'd gotten a half dozen of 'em.  

It seems the only way to secure a cruffin is to get here first thing in the morning.  But there are other truly fabulous goodies to be had.  

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
Idk if i'd line up again, but the experience was great! something new that I've never tried

Make sure to be prepared to wait in line for a few hours. Once in line, they'll give you a sticker to guarantee you of the cruffins! each day has different flavors, so cross your fingers you have something delicious !
author: Rachel E.

description:
Thank goodness I work close by to this place. 3-5 minutes by car, so that can be a good or bad thing. My co-worker and I arrived in line by 8:45 (on a Tuesday) and there was about 10-12 people in front of us.
The line moves fast and our total wait time was 30 minutes. (I've been reading other peoples' post and they mention they are 2 lines?? When we arrived, there was just 1. Maybe it's only on the weekends??)

The cruffin flavor of the day was caramel, so I ordered my 2 that was allotted to me and decided to try the passion-fruit filled donut. I could have done more damage to my wallet and figure, but realized I could just come back another day if I really wanted to. ;-)

I have never tasted anything like the cruffin! And whoever thought of it is just amazing!!! Flaky, delicate and crunchy on the outside and then airy and on the inside! It may not be my favorite baked good.
The donut reminded me of malasadas and being in Hawaii especially because of the passion-fruit filling. It was VERY light and fluffy! And none of the creams are overly sweet.
Sadly, the lady in front of us got the last 2 Choux Bombs, so we didn't get to try it. Hopefully next time! 

I was nice enough to bring the other 2 items home to share. They were still in pretty good shape, but don't know how they would hold up overnight. 

3 items at over $12 is definitely not cheap. However, I am still definitely a fan and I'd come again to try another flavored cruffin.
author: Mimie L.

description:
So turns out I was right.  You do have to eat these things fresh.  

In addition to the items I had last time, I also had a savory (ham) croissant, brioche bun (blueberry), chocolate chip cookie, passion fruit donut, and chocolate croissant.  

The chocolate chip cookie reminds me of the Jacques Torres recipe with the chewiness, the flat chocolate pieces, and big salt flakes.  I liked it quite a bit.  

The biggest surprise to me was the passion fruit filled donut.  The filling was delicate in texture and flavor; this made all the difference.  I'm not normally a fan of filled donuts but this isn't like the super tart and crude American version.

Solid bakery but lines might get crazier as the popularity grows. Most of my Instagram feed on the weekends are of this place.
author: Shannon L.

description:
WOW! Just WOW!!

Didn't have to wait in the horrid line. Shout out to my friend Sholtz for bringing the box of goodies over. We sampled a bunch. All were creative, innovative, surprising and delicious! 

Banana caramel cream was my favorite. They're each bomb in there own unique way. The hype delivered! A real treat!

PS. The box is everything. A+ Marketing.
author: Rosalyn W.

description: The times I've come by are around 1PM so I've never seen some of the menu items. Regardless the croissants and other pastries I've had are very buttery and flaky. It's a shame how fast one can go through croissants from this place.
author: Dan C.

description: Giving this delicious confectionery 5 stars because everything I tried was delightful, from the savory tomato egg white danish to the sweet cannoli donuts all the items I got today were so good words truly dont do it justice!
author: Mike S.

description:
*note that cruffins and le donuts have different flavors everyday. Be sure to check their instagram account and website for updates!

*cruffins, although sold at 9am, can only be purchased in person (with a separate line exclusively for the cruffins). And it's apparently limited to 2 cruffins per person.

*although they have official closing times they close early if all the pastries are sold before then

*you can call for pickup or delivery (but they may not always pick up the phone since it's busy). They may also have a $50 minimum from what I saw on their website (best to check yourself as I am not completely sure)

1st visit: 7am on a weekday
20 min wait and I arrived right when it opened . No cruffins(@9am) but still worth the wait. Since I wasn't sure when my next visit would be I decided to try (almost) everything served that day:
.
Strawberry Jalapeno Brioche Bomb .
California Croissant .
Brown Ale Onion Danish.
Apple Honey Bostock.
Ube Puff.
Kaouign Amann.
Bread Pudding .
Strawberry Le Donut.
Artichoke Danish.
Pumpkin Apple Danish.
Caramel Sweet Bun.


*Personal faves: California Croissant, Kaoign Amann, Bread Pudding, Artichoke Danish. My coworkers loved all the sweet pastries too, but I felt that they savory ones and the not-so-sweet ones were what stood out the most. Hands down the best pastries I've ever had (though I'll need to try b patisserie's kaoign amann again to be sure).

2nd visit: Sunday @~12:30
Seeing how fast they tend to sell out I decided to call as I was nearby. Maybe I was lucky but they still had some available at that time, and there was no line! Lots of the pastries were gone but I managed to snag some. Of course, no cruffins left. Or the California croissant. I wouldn't count on being this lucky again- not including Outsidelands, the festivals and county fairs in and out of the city probably kept them away from this bakehouse.

These pastries are now my new guilty pleasure, and snagging a cruffin is now my goal. Wish me luck y'all!
author: Sherry Y.

description: The donuts are pretty delicious and have rotating unique flavors, but don't waste your time getting up extra early to wait in a ridiculously long line down the street for their cruffins that everyone goes nuts about, they're overrated and not worth the wait.
author: Jenna M.

description:
Matcha croissants. 
Is there really anything else to say other than... I might propose to these croissants. Propose what you ask? Anything. Anything.
author: Nnena U.

description:
Skip the cruffin line and buy their donuts and other pastries - they are delicious!

I'm not a huge fan of the cruffin. The time I tried it the flavor was hazelnut, chocolate, raspberry, and pistachio. Too many things going on in a generic chocolate mousse and the flavor did not make any sense to any of my friends. And there was too much filling.

The bakery is clean, the workers are friendly, and the line moves fairly quickly. The shop is very "Instagram" worthy with the pink neon sign & slogan. You'll run into a lot of tourists for sure. 

There are much, much better bakeries in SF than Mr. Holmes Bakehouse, but I think this place lives up to the hype.
author: Nelya T.

description:
i got there around 9:15am on a tuesday, but they still had cruffins til 9:45. minimal (so it'd be kind of stressful if there was people in front of you), but doable.

anyways, i was less impressed this time than i was last time i came. while the exterior of my cruffin was crisp and flaky, i found the middle a little dense. the filling of the day was lychee raspberry curd, but it really just tasted like raspberry yogurt to me. my friend claimed that she could taste the lychee, but i couldn't find any hint of it, even when i ate just the filling.

the california croissant was far more interesting; it had smoked salmon, seaweed, pickled ginger and wasabi. the salmon was a bit salty for me, but it worked when i got a big mouthful of croissant with it. the seaweed was kind of nondescript, but i liked the pickled ginger (i'm the kind of person who steals everyone else's), and the wasabi (a bit of heat, but very mild overall).

2.5-3 stars. it's pretty solid, but i wouldn't wake up exceptionally early for it or take the time to wait if you have limited time in sf.
author: Heather F.

description:
I've found home sweet home with Mr. Holmes Bakehouse. If you haven't heard (you already have) they're famous for their cruffins, the west coast response to the east coast cronut, and yes, they do live up the hype.

Things to note:
- First things first, you need to be able to get up early to even hope of getting your hands on this elusive pastry. They take them out of the oven at 9am, an hour after opening, but you best believe there's a line at least an hour before then so prepare accordingly.
- They post the cruffin flavors a week in advanced (plus the donuts) on Instagram, so you may want to peep that to determine if it's worth the wait.
- They have two lines, one for the cruffins and one for the other pastries (including their filled donuts which rotate flavors each day). If you come early enough, you can usually just go through the regular pastry line and lineup for the cruffins after.
- They limit cruffin purchase to two per person.
- They only offer those beautiful boxes if you buy 6 pastries or more; otherwise they charge.
- It's a teeny shop so prepare to eat it elsewhere (and eat it immediately while the cruffin's still hot, makes such a difference I promise!) And yes, that also means you will struggle to get your neon light insta shot in frame.

As for the things I tried....
- Lemon curd & milk chocolate donut: Loved loved loved the lemon curd donut. It had a lot of tartness but it was nicely balanced by the sugar covered dough. The milk chocolate donut was a more creamy flavor, rather than a ganache, and was pretty tasty as well.
- THE CRUFFIN (strawberry rhubarb): warm beautiful buttery flaky goodness. Seriously, this thing is so messy from its sugar coating but you'll want to eat it right away. It's generously filled so don't worry about them skimping on that. It's also wonderfully crispy on the outside but soft and pillowy on the inside. It's more so a custard filled croissant in the shape of a muffin then anything else, but your perfect conception of it. Definitely worth trying at least once.

I'll definitely be coming back to try their California Croissant (smoke salmon and seaweed in a flaky buttery crust, sign me up), as well as their Ube tart (it's sooooo fat). Now I just need to remember to wake up early enough!
author: Rene B.

description: Love the choices! We had the cream puff and ate it right away on the street! We also had the savory Danish, bread pudding, cookie, chocolate croissant, & pistachio donut! Cute little shop. People were coming here in droves. Wouldn't hesitate to come back when we're in San Francisco!
author: Shelly S.

description:
This review is SOLELY on the hazelnut bomb thing, and my MATCHA CRUFFIN.

So, I've been following Mr. Holmes Bakehouse on instagram. The pictures alone can send me into a diabetic shock. Anyway, I made it a point to come here during my business trip to SF. I mean, one day they had a picture of a matcha cruffin. As a lover of ALL things matcha I was immediately kicking myself for not going that day. As fate would have it, they had it the next day. I walked a MILE to get these babies. Through the pissed stained, cold streets of SF. 

Anyway, the amazingly delicious Matcha Cruffin ended up being the thing dreams are made of. Sweet and flaky on the outside. Injected with Matcha cream in the middle, which was perfectionnnn and not overly sweet.

Hazelnut bomb thing- uhh can you go wrong? It's a ferreo rocher in a pastry form. If I lived near this bakery, you'd have to roll me home.  

I HAVE TO COME BACK. When we meet again SF.
author: Mina C.

description:
We ran all the way here on an early Saturday morning to get in line. We arrived 20 minutes before it opened and the line was, of course, out the door. We still had to wait another 10-20 minutes after they opened to place our order, but it was worth it! Loved the cruffin. Would have liked to try the interesting sushi pastry... 

For the wait, though, I don't know if the cruffin was out of this world. I'm pretty partial to bakeries, though, so it was still pretty awesome.
author: Julianna K.

description:
MY NEW FAVE BAKERY IN SAN FRANCISCO.

With all the delicious and savory bakeries in the city this one is on top. Everything they have here is mind blowing. The cookies, the croissants, the donuts ALL OF IT is heaven on earth. And i'm not even mentioning the CRUFFIN because I haven't even tried it! To be worthy to receive the coveted CRUFFIN one must be willing to withstand time and stand in line at precisely 0900. I hear lines can get up to 90 minutes long....I'm sure its all worth it. Everything here is worth it. Believe all of the hype cause its true. 

The brioche with white chocolate and blueberry is extraordinary and the donuts remind me of Leonard's malasadas (only more divine!!). Even more delicious the day after...
author: Caye Q.

description: Really good and tasty! I got one of the chocolate fill donut and that was honestly heavenly!!!! I also got the cronut (croissant-donut) they are famous for but it was alright:/ I just didn't like the filling. Definitely will be back though for the delicious donut
author: Sarah B.

description:
Cruffin madness!

Honestly, it's worth the (short) wait for one of these beauts. The banana cream-filled one is still lingering in my mind weeks after consumption, and I would happily pay $5 for one again. 

Other pastries are also delish, this version of the Kouign Amann is fantastic. 

Get there around 8:15am on a weekday and you'll be set. Bon a petit!
author: Sarah G.

description:
Made this a destination stop while my friend and I were in town and it was worth it. Ugh. How do they do it? 

We wanted to beat the crowds so we started our morning here, bright and early. To our (sort of) disappointment they don't even start selling cruffins until 9am, so there was no line. No matter...we peeped at their other pastries and knew we wouldn't be leaving empty-handed. Then the convincing lady behind the counter told us we could have a cute pastry box if we bought six. And to hell if we didn't get a box (for what...we were flying back soon... just an excuse to eat 6 pasties, that's what..)! 

I was so glad they had a few savory options. I got the turkey pesto danish for a hit of protein. My friend followed suit and got the potato leek danish. As for sweets, the lady told us about the pastry that was a cross between apple pie, cheesecake and french toast. Uh, excuse me? Throw it in the box! 

We also got a famed choux bomb with vanilla bean pastry cream between two fluffy choux pastries with a hazelnut fudge surprise in the middle. The vanilla cream was...beyond words. These are best eaten right away in a messy, sticky manner. Another popular pastry was the kouign amann, which is a denser version of a croissant. I guess the most disappointing option we got was the chocolate croissant. It was one of the most crisp ones that I've tried, which was unexpected. Don't get me wrong, it was still quite tasty.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Cruffin FTW! Cruffins are made daily and available at 9:00 a.m.  However, the limit is only 2/person. 

My brother's gf bought my parents and I some delicious pastries from Mr. Holmes.  We were lucky to try the following:

Elvis Cruffin -  peanut butter and caramelized banana creme cruffin drizzled with honey.  Although I've seen PB and banana as a healthy snack, I've never actually tried it myself.  I wasn't sure if I'd be a fan, but I was.  It had the right amount of PB and banana where one didn't overpower the other.  The only thing "muffin" about this was the shape.  As far as texture, it's buttery, flaky, and covered in sugar, resembling a cronut.  

Amelie Amann - Mr. Holmes version of the Kouign Amann.  It was flaky and buttery,  but doesn't compare to B. Patisserie's Kouign Amann as it was smaller and more dense. Still yummy though!

California Croissant - This was our least favorite of the bunch.  It's a croissant stuffed sushi filled with smoked salmon, baked seaweed, wasabi and pickled ginger, and topped with furikake.  Although the croissant was flaky, the taste was unpleasant.  It had a muddy taste from all the different ingredient combinations.  I'd say it's definitely an acquired taste.  

Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb - If you're a fan of Ferrero Rocher, you'll LOVE this pastry.  It was absolutely flaky and delicious.  It tasted just like the spherical shaped chocolate, but a bigger version and in croissant form.  
   
I can't wait to visit Mr. Holmes to try their other pastries.
author: Candice H.

description:
Mr. Holmes I presume?

A weekday morning wait?
Any decaf coffee? 
Any room to sit?
NOPE.

In a dodgy area?
An unhelpful bakery gal? 
A "I'm so fancy" to go box? 
YEP.

Are the donuts generously filled but quietly flavored?
Did the pineapple donut taste citrusy?
Did the cherry donut underwhelm with undiscernible flavor?
YES.

Is "cruffin" fun to say?
Was the Chocolate & Coconut Cruffin an overly sweet, reconfigured Mounds bar-ish croissant?
Does the cruffin spawn unsavory prospective mashups like "crookie" (brownie + cookie)?
YUP.

Could the cruffin compete with long time pastry l'amour, Tartine's Morning Bun?
N E V E R.
author: Amy C.

description:
By the time I got to Mr Holmes Bakehouse at 8:30am on a weekday I was already #9 in the line for the oft mentioned cruffins. By the time 9am rolled around the line was so long I couldn't even see the end of it. It must have been 40+ people deep... on a wednesday. This is crazy. And that's coming from someone who just stood in a 1.5 hour wait for state bird.

The pastries were, to their credit, pretty good. I tried a lot of their offerings and some were better than others. 

Poor:
Appled 

Average:
Chocolate chip cookie
Apple hand pie

Good:
Strawberry Citrus Tart
Almond Bostock 
Amelie Amann - I liked the pistachio twist they added to this Kouign Amann.

Great:
Cruffin - The flavor I tried was coffee, and it was great, but not worth waiting 30+ min for, which means only get this on a weekday.
Passion Fruit Doughnut - Great filling, almost like a flavored malasada from back home.

Overall, they hype for this place is unreal, and while "I'm a fan" I do think it is a bit unjustified.
author: Mark O.

description:
Stopped by because mandatory.  Luckily for media purposes, I had spoken with the head chef weeks prior so my order was ready when I got there.  Pastries were fresh and delicious! 

Tip: In order to get the cruffin and some other special goodies, line up early because they sell out fast!
author: Marissa R.

description: These sweets did not disappoint! The line builds early, but worth the wait. The Cruffle was delightful and they have a lot of other great choices, including an amazing chocolate chip salted cookie!! Friendly and helpful staff too!
author: Sarah M.

description: This bakery has been bookmarked for a long time, especially since their neon sign is constantly popping up on my instagram feed. By the time I made it there around noon, they were out of cruffins and the pastries they did have left were just slim pickings - mostly cookies, a bread pudding muffin thing, and some donuts. I guess we arrived way too late and that explains why there was no line at all. And why there were no cruffins left. Since I was there, I got a donut, which ended up being filled with yummy applesauce on the inside, and their bread pudding muffin thing. The donut was good. The bread pudding thing was dense and filled with things like seeds and nuts. The pastries were good but not amazing. I guess I missed out on getting the cruffins. The shop is small and there's one small bench below the neon sign if you want to sit and eat, otherwise it's for to-go. The paper bags that they put our pastries in were cute. Their packaging is cute in general. But I wasn't impressed by the pastries that they did have left - it's not worth the trek for me. And the employees could have been friendlier. I got my picture with the neon sign though lol.
author: Sylvia K.

description: One of the most popular places for breakfast pastries in SF, you will most likely always see a line outside the store in the morning. While all their items are delicious, most people go for the cruffins (think: baby of a croissant and a muffin). Flavours varies from day to day, you can find out on their Instagram. The bakery opens at 8am, and the cruffins come out at 9am, and each person is limited to buy 2 cruffins. So my advice is that if you want to get in on the cruffin action, arrive at the store at 8:30am the latest to line up. Everything is usually sold out by 1pm!
author: Michelle C.

description:
Cute little bakery, woke up extra early to line up for the cruffins.  Was visiting SF from LA and this was another bakery on my list to visit.  Ordered the orange marmalade cruffin, choux bomb, donut, california croissant, strawberry jalapeno brioche bomb and artichoke danish.

I enjoyed everything baked good I ordered but to my surprise my least favorite was the cruffin.  A baker did tell us that day that they had issues with their yeast that day so they had an even more limited amount of cruffins.  

Cannot wait till they open their bakehouse in LA, a must try.
author: Bessy C.

description:
I came here on a Monday morning, hoping to miss the typical weekend rush. It was indeed, much more manageable, and the cute little store-front with pink-neon lights inside is cozy but inviting!

Everything was delicious. I walked home with 2 Coffee-Creme Cruffins (They limit 2/person), the Citrus Tart, The California Croissant, the Salted Caramel donut, the Fererro Rochet Choux, and a cup of SightGlass Coffee. I ended up spending $35 here, which was pretty disturbing for pastries, but oddly, I would easily do it again!

Favorites included the Salted Caramel Donut (I'm obsessed with Donuts and go to Bob's on Polk at least once a month as a treat..but this was easily the best donut of my life!) and the Cruffin - I can't wait to return to try the other flavor of Cruffins.. it was soooo good. It reminded me of a Cronut with flaky layers with a Beard Papa's Cream Puff Center combined - DROOOL!

Side Note: Their Croissants and Cruffins take roughly 3 days to make. While the prices are steep, everything here is labor-intensive and they make each pastry with great care.. no wonder everything is not only delicious, but also drop dead beautiful!

Expect to spend $3-$5 per pastry and to take it to-go. They only have about two seats and a tiny little bar where 1-2 people can eat/drink coffee.
author: Veronica S.

description:
Surprisingly the line wasn't as long as I expected and it moved pretty fast.  We tried several including their famous "Cruffin" which is worth trying.  I couldn't have picked a better day because the vanilla custard filling is my favorite. 

My only disappointment was the clerk who was a little impatient and slightly rude but my interaction with him was limited. Despite the clerk still worth the walk!
author: Cynthia S.

description:
When researching bakeries in SF, I knew I had to stop by this place and it just so happened to be a 10 minute walk from my hotel! We ordered the matcha-cherry cruffin (croissant x muffin hybrid: wherein the texture resembled a croissant and the shape was that of a muffin) and the ube puff pastry. 
The cruffin was delicious. The croissant part was flaky as it should be, but the highlight of the dessert was the filling. It was light yet creamy with the perfect matcha and cherry flavors. When eaten altogether, the flavors and textures complemented one another. The ube puff pastry had a nice flaky, buttery outside as well, however the inside was underwhelming. The ube was downplayed and the custard-like filling was a bit dry and scant. I did love the trendy ambiance and the fast-paced, hassle-free ordering. They offer a variety of other pastries and serve hot coffee and milk. The cruffins are definitely worth a try. Come early to beat the crowd and before they run out of supply! (2 per customer). You can also find the week's menu flavors on their Instagram page (@mrholmesbakehouse).
author: Justine S.

description: The line at this crazy is crazy but worth it. I ordered a box and filled it with one of each item and loved everything! My favorite was the dulce de leche croissant! My mouth waters just thinking about it. Sad that I'm across the country and won't have another one for a long time.
author: Gracie M.

description:
YUMM - was on the top of my SF bakery hit list & finally got to go ^__^ 

The store is super cute tucked into the heart of the Tenderloin, which makes for an interesting morning trip, but super worth it nonetheless. We arrived at around 8:30AM on a Wednesday morning, and we were about 6th in line with no line for the regular pastries, so we easily obtained our long awaited cruffins. 

THE CRUFFINS: ** You can only buy 2 per person so bring friends!! ** 
-- Sooo crisp and flaky. My only complaint was that they have a bit too much filling. Also the flavor of the cruffins and donuts change daily I believe, so you have to check their website for the flavor of the day! 

TIP: If you leave these overnight, they get a bit soggy and don't taste nearly as good :( Consume day of for maximum goodness!

OTHER GOODIES:
+ California Croissant: savory croissant with smoked salmon, ginger, & seaweed - a yummy twist on a bakery classic.
+ Coffee & Rum Donut: Donut itself was really good, but again a bit too much filling for my taste
++ Kouign Amann: SO GOOD - everything great about their puff pastries minus the filling aka nothing but crispy, carby goodness 

Only downside is that everything's a bit pricey, but definitely worth it!
author: Sophie H.

description:
This place is Instagram ready with their quirky 'I got baked in San Francisco' neon sign, the packaging and floor sign. 

I came here on a weekend at 10am expecting a line around the corner but no one was there. Prob because they were out of their cruffins and doughnuts... So I'll have to review when I actually get one of those!

We tried their Amelie amann, fruit custard tarts, chocolate chip cookie and an almond something or other that the girl recommended. 

Everything but the fruit tarts were great! The blueberry/raspberry tart had great flavor, it was really just one of the other tarts that lacked any punch. 

If this is what their other items taste like, I'm excited to go back and try the items I missed out on that they're best known for!
author: Mandi W.

description:
You know I really can't get behind the idea that something is so great it's worth waiting in line for more than 4 or 5 minutes.

I Came On A Friday At 10 and I had To Wait for About 25 To make It complete..

It's good but.....

And I'm sure the coffee they have is fine.

Of course I did not get my cruffin, they sold out before 10.

The ham and cheese croissant offering they have is delicious but it's not worth waiting in line half an hour. if I happen to drive by and saw that there was only a small line, maybe 10 people and there was a parking spot available I might stop again. The hell if I'm going to wait in line for an hour to get a pastry.

I'm sure the cruffin is great, everything else is. All in all what I did have was totally 5 stars I just wish they had a Philz coffee next door.
author: Ben M.

description:
Food 5++   I went there afternoon so of course there was no cruffin.... But all pastries I got brought me heaven! Especially Ferrero Rocher Chou Bomb was heavenly melting in my mouth!
Ambience 5
Package Design 5++ so cute
Service 3 A girl at front looked irritating when I asked some simple questions.
Price 4
author: Tory T.

description:
EDIT: this review was for their FiDi popup, which I think is now gone! :(

FANTASTIC kouign amann here, and slightly cheaper than neighbouring competitors to boot! this counter is a pop-up, so don't expect it to be fully stocked all day (once they sell out, they're dunzo for the day). also, as others have mentioned, since this isn't a primary outpost for them, there aren't cruffins sold here (having lived in NYC for 3 years though, i can tell you the trendy hybrid pastries are really not that great... bleh).

the guy working the counter was warm and friendly, and we joked about how to make the elusive bread pudding an acceptable breakfast item, only to conclude that it's best kept as a guilty pleasure (topped with nutella, of course).
author: Vicki L.

description:
I think this place is way too overhype. And honestly, their pastries aren't anything spectacular. Their cruffins are okay, nothing really special. I think the main reason why people are willing to line up for them and what makes Mr.Holmes unique is that they make a different flavor cruffin everyday. Otherwise, it's not worth waiting in line hella early and finding out that they ran out an hour or two after opening. 

The pastries are eh. I think the only one I actually liked are the donuts and they change the flavors every now and then. But again, are they really worth $3.50 for one donut? Nope. My boyfriend got the croissant. He took one bite of it and was immediately disgusted. He threw it away 'cause it lacked texture and taste. He said he has had better at local coffee shops selling plain croissants. 

Service is practically non-existent. The male worker with the glasses working on Saturday, April 9th needs to quit if he doesn't like his job. My boyfriend and I were waiting in the pastry line and we barely walked through the doors and he was practically yelling at us at what we wanted. Their pastries change so how are we supposed to know what we want right off the bat? Also, they need to add some kind of large menu either by the window so people waiting in line can see what they are selling that day or have a large menu posted on their wall behind the pastry counter. You have to like walk down the entire counter to see your options but you can't even walk 'cause there's always a freakin' line! 

And honestly, the cruffins are basically flavored croissants in my opinion. Nothing fancy. They don't even resemble muffins at all. The name throws you off a bit if you've never heard of the word before. 

I do not see myself coming back here. At least not until they train their employees better, make more cruffins, and implement a menu board somewhere.
author: Phuong T.

description: This place is great! I love it! Beautiful and delicious baked treats. The danishes are works of art and so tasty and also the staff is really sweet!
author: Rachel D.

description:
No exaggeration: the highlight of our San Fran visit!!!!

We had to hike our way to this amazing little bakery on a brisk September morning but it was so unbelievably worth it. We got lucky with no lines and plenty of cruffins left! The flavor was raspberry pistachio and it was heavenly 

We also got the ube puff, which was a unique flavor that I loved! I get cravings for this place weekly and I hope and pray one day we get a Mr. Holmes on the east coast (preferably NYC!!!)
author: Becca C.

description:
Tried the Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb $3.68 with tax $4 - it's crunchy and fat tasting without much flavor in the cream, just like eating whipped cream which I hate.

Chocolate croissant after tax $4 - was on the tray when I saw the girl bringing it out, I go I want a Hot one, the guy said they aren't hot!  Bogus, so I still bought the cold chocolate croissant, ate it next day heated up at home.  It's like eating a store bought croissant, not crunchy at all, just bleh.  Opened it up only 2 small strips of chocolate.

Overpriced & bleh pastries.
author: Ann L.

description: Sad that they have discontinued two favorites; choux bomb and caramel roll. They were excellent but now gone. Cruffins were a great novelty but after trying all those pastry cream flavors I'm done with them. I'm not into donuts so the only thing I go for is the California roll once in awhile. Have not been to Highland Park location but did go to Tustin. Their Kouign Amann is too dense.
author: Robin L.

description:
Wow, I love this place. I've had their chocolate chip cruffin and strawberry japaleno brioche, and both were heavenly! Definitely worth the wait. You can't find cruffins like these anywhere else!

Pro tip: Check their Instagram account (@MrHolmesBakehouse) for weekly updates with cruffin and donut flavors for each day if you want to plan a visit for a specific flavor!
author: Christine T.

description:
Finally got to visit San Francisco when the sun was up!

Like many of the places I try, I always do some research beforehand just to check out the do's and don'ts. So I checked their instagram for their weekly flavors for the cruffins and doughnuts and yelp for tips on what to do! This was one place I had to try!! and y'know get baked!

Mr. Holmes opens at 7AM and the cruffins start selling at 9AM.  From what I saw from other yelpers' reviews, ALWAYS GO EARLY SO THEY DON'T RUN OUT because they make about 200 cruffins a day or so. **They have a limit of 2 cruffins per person!** Arrived about 8:50AM and the line was about 2 doors down (not long at all apparently according to the frequent buyers). 

Took about 15 minutes for us to get to the front of the line, and I'm pretty sure the reason why it takes so long to get the pastries is because everyone stops to take pictures of all the pastries and take pics with the "i got baked in SF" sign because i know i was one of those people. 

My friend and I thought that the box looked aesthetically pleasing so we bought enough cruffins and doughnuts to fill it & yes we still have the box! The daily cruffin flavor was Peach Tea and it was amazing. Right when you take it out of the box/bag, you can feel the crunch and the flakiness just like an actual croissant. I thought it was going to be too sweet but the inside was moist and chewy, filled with a tea creme and a small amount of peach to balance the flavors instead of it overpowering. A little messy to eat because of the sugar on the outside but nothing a little finger licking can't fix!

(It was so good, I was able to get back in line for a second round of orders. YES THATS HOW SHORT THE LINE WAS!)

We also got the Green tea match doughnut and chocolate doughnut as well, and those were like XL doughnuts, so soft and puffy filled with cream! I'm surprised it didn't explode!

The only down side was having to wake up super early to get in line. I like my beauty sleep ):
author: Janise Q.

description: Very unique pastries, this is a must for anyone looking to try baked goods that are delicious and one-of-a-kind! We got a box of six and they varied from donuts with chocolate and fresh mint, to a croissant filled with smoked salmon, nori and wasabi.
author: Christa F.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here around 12. Yes, we know, big mistake since we wanted a cruffin. But no worries! We still got a chance to try a couple of delicious treats! 

We ordered a guava citrus filled donut, and a shortbread mousse dessert thing! 

The guava filled donut was AMAZING. I usually get sick when I eat donuts, and I've had a pretty good amount of donuts to notice, even if they're good quality donuts. But with Mr. Holmes, I was able to have a little more than half without even feeling the tiny bit queasy. I attribute that to the flufiness and lightness of the donut! It has a lot more air than your typical donut, which I liked a lot because it added to the fluff factor. The inside was super delicious too. It was sweet but also with a citrus tang, which was a perfect refreshing break from the sweetness of it all. Especially since there was sugar dusted on the outside too.

The mousse dessert was pretty good too! Too sweet for me to finish by myself. I could only have a bite after having the donut because it was kind of rich with the small cookie/shortbread and also the mousse and fudge on top. It was still really good though. My favorite part was the fudge on top!

If you plan on getting the cruffin, definitely get there early because they sell out fast. But if you don't mind, or you're just lazy getting up like we were, there are still amazing treats to try!
author: Hana B.

description: My friend and I got here at around 9:45 am on a Thursday, and there were still quite a few cruffins left! The cruffin flavor of the day was almond mocha, and it was so good! It was crisp & crunchy on the outside and the filling made it smooth & creamy on the inside! My only complaint is that the filling felt a bit too heavy and sweet for me after eating it for a while, but that's just personal preference. If you're not into cruffins, they also sell other sweet and savory pastries, as well. In addition, the workers are extremely patient & friendly, always willing to answer any questions. Looking forward to trying out the other cruffin flavors in the future!
author: Monica W.

description:
It was a rainy Monday morning, and there's already a line out the door when I arrived at 9:05... So it is like the DMV here, the line starts even before the cruffins is out... Unlike the DMV where you can be there all day waiting till your turn, cruffins don't wait for you. Only early birds get the cruffins.

The flavor of the day was pistachio orange honey, and boy I love them.... The outside was cover in sugar and very flaky. Inside, it was full of the God send gooey and yummy filling (be careful when you bite cuz it could burst and touch your nose )... The paste was right on spot with sweetness for me, and the citrus flavor from the orange make it a perfect combination of sweet and touch of sour...

I got the Chocolate donut and the Passion fruit guava donut. They are also super flavorful... The donuts were soft and puffy... And again, full of fillings inside... I was impressed with the chocolate donut since it has a touch of spicy... So good

They are all worth the wait
author: Zisele N.

description:
Underwhelming. Probably because I had heard so much hype about it. 
Everything is just OK and just OK isn't worth lines or going out of your way to get there when there are several other bakeries in the city which also serve ok pastries or better.
author: Veronica L.

description:
Finally found time to check out what all the hype with the cruffins are about. So I came prepared and ready to wait in line. 

Arrived at 7:45am, for the 8am opening. There were two lines:
1) Cruffins only line (limited 2 per customer - had to wait until 9am for the cruffins to come out)
2) other pastries line (you need to get 6 pastries for one of their very nice boxes!) 

AMBIANCE/SERVICE: very small shop, so you'll be standing outside (in the cold) for most of the time. You don't really get a chance to check out the daily flavors they have until you step into the shop - it would be nice if they had a list posted outside, so people can decide ahead of them what they want once they get in to make the line move faster. 

FOOD: They have rotating flavors for their donuts, danishes and cruffins. Their croissants are delicious and super crunchy. LOVED the double baked croissant, although I wasn't the biggest fan of the custard and raspberry filling inside. I lucked out today because they had matcha cruffins :) I would say cruffin lives up to their hype! The filling inside reminds me of the creme used in Beard Papa's cream puffs, and the outsides is very crispy and flake :) But for $4+ for one and the wait, I probably won't be back anytime soon. This was more like a one time expereince for me, unless the lines are shorter - maybe on a weekday. 

Definitely worth trying at least once! :)
author: Samantha F.

description:
We were warned that this place has a line out the door, but we were up early and willing to check it out. 

The cruffins, the signature item, are NOT ready at opening, but an hour later. And they will sell out by 10:30. Unwilling to wait another hour, we skipped the cruffins and ordered other yummy things.

The croissants are fantastic. The donut was fabulous. The bread pudding - yum! And the sticky bun, yes!!!

Is it worth it, yep. Lines moves quickly. The goods are lovely.
author: Suann G.

description:
I went here on a Friday morning when I was in town around 9:30 am. The line wasn't too bad, just a little out the door, and there were still plenty of cruffins left. The smell of the baked goods was wafting out the door and I was really excited to try some things! 

I picked up a pina colada cruffin and a Mexican hot chocolate donut.
