The pastry itself was quite good and crispy on the cruffin but the fillings on each the cruffin and donut were a bit of a let down. The pastries weren't too sweet, considering they were covered in sugar, but I expected a more bold flavor from the fillings. 

Maybe I'll come back to try a different flavor next time but this time was just meh.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Got the twice baked croissant and it was delicious! One of the best croissants I have had in SF. The croissant had so many different aspects to it-- chocolate, caramel and a doughy almond interior. Super flaky on the outside just like a croissant should be! However, I was a little disappointed by the kouign amann. It didn't taste as fresh as I expected. Overall, would definitely come again to try their other croissants and the infamous cruffin (which was sold out when we came around 11 AM).
author: Rebecca L.

description:
I'm glad I tried it once, but I don't plan on coming back because I've verified that this bakery is just hype. I got in line at about 8:40 on a Friday morning, there were probably about 20 people ahead of me and I was able to order by about 9:20. I got two of the orange earl gray cruffins and a California croissant. The cruffin was a bit dry and had a lot of flavored pudding inside which was a bit overwhelming. If I did it over, I'd only get one, two is just excessive for one person. The California croissant was a unique pastry, with a smoked salmon roll baked into a croissant. It was fun to try, but the combination was a little weird to me. I think I'd prefer to eat the roll and the croissant separately. 
For those planning a visit on a weekday, I wouldn't be overly concerned about getting there early. I think I still would have gotten a cruffin if I had gotten in line just before 9. But it may be because the flavor of the day wasn't as popular.
author: Gloria N.

description:
I was so disappointed when I missed all the cruffins. They sell out so fast T^T I wish they were able to put out more so more people can enjoy them, but I guess that keeps the business running and more people coming back every day, bright and early.

A lot of the pastries were sold out and we weren't left with a lot of choices either. BUT! I did get the famous "I got baked in SF" picture, so I'm happy about that.
author: Jenna Y.

description:
Meh...

The one thing that makes this place unique (the cruffin) is insanely difficult to acquire. I've made three attempts to obtain one of these elusive pastries all to no success. 

Everything else that Mr. Holmes sells can be found at a plethora of other bakeries that are open later and are either on par in terms of quality and deliciousness or are superior. 

Mr. Holmes could really set itself apart from the staggering number of other bakeries by simply focusing on their specialty that makes them unique. 

P.S., if you're reading this Mr. Holmes, know that I gave you 1-star not just because you know what your competition is yet do no better, but that you've decided to rest on your laurels.
author: Mathew R.

description: No line when I went. Got a savory croissant. It was delicious, but would not have been worth a long wait.
author: Shelby R.

description:
I tried the strawberry jalapeno brioche bun and it was amazing! It was perfectly crispy on the outside and the jam was perfectly gooey on the inside -- not to mention the jalapeno flavor was even throughout. 

The counter staff was super helpful in making a recommendation on which pastry to try if they're out of cruffins!
author: Brenae L.

description:
The day has finally come.. I got baked in San Francisco, but I must say that I baked too long and became a tad bit sunburnt! 

Arrived around 9:50am and there was still a ton of cruffins left. The bakeshop opens at 7am, but they starts serving their cruffins at 9am. Most of the time, customers come about 30mins-1hr early and wait in line to get the cruffins. Also, make sure to check their instagram as they update the different flavors weekly. I asked one of the workers there what is the best time to get cruffins and he mentioned Monday-Wednesday will be your best bet. Plus, you won't have to wait in line! 

Now onto the actual baked goods.. 

Cruffin (Chocolate Earl Grey): Super decadent! I think the chocolate was extremely rich, but you can still taste the earl grey. I can't imagine how someone could finish one because it is literally filled with cream & topped with sugar. As for the cruffin itself, it reminds me of a tough croissant shaped like a muffin. Not my favorite, but it looks esthetically pleasing. Depending on the flavor that day.. it could be a hit or miss. 

Doughnut (Coffee Rum): If you are a fan of cream, this is gonna be the one for you. Literally, it was 90% cream & 10% dough. I personally liked the dough, but the coffee rum wasn't my favorite. The rum flavor overpowered the coffee taste and was a bit too much cream for me. Like the cruffin, depending on the flavor.. it's a hit or miss.

Cookie: This cookie was the size of my head! Super big and my favorite frankly. I think what made the chocolate chip cookie so delicious was the sprinkle of sea salt. It allowed it to be this sweet & salty treat that I really liked. 

Ube Puff: Grown-up pop tart filled with ube. Absolutely delicious as well! I liked it a lot cause it was flaky and had a good amount of filling. I remember this was $4.50 though.. so pretty pricey.

In all, I think their well-known pastries don't live up to my expectations! I liked their other pastries, but for a bakery.. it is pretty darn expensive. I think everything ranges in the $3-4.50 range. I don't live in the city, so it is not always an easy commute to get here, but I would still come back to try some of their savory pastries since those looked pretty delicious.
author: Matthew D.

description:
I chose their famous donut and the California croissant. The cream, filled donut was very good. Flaky and sugary in the outside, with perfectly made creme (which was not too sweet) on the inside. It did remind me of a Chinese dim sum donut, but tasted much better. The California croissant was ingenious-- Alaskan salmon perfectly cooked and seaweed inside. Like sushi but with a croissant, not rice. That was very unique and my first time having something of the like. The croissant was very flaky and fell apart with each bite. It was messy to eat, but I liked it a lot. They served it with soy sauce, which I didn't use. It wasn't necessary as there was a bit of a salty taste on the salmon. 

Mr. Holmes, whoever you are, I salute you. I can't wait to come back and try other pastries.
author: Jaime F.

description: The cruffins here are just AMAZING. My friend came in December and got me the peppermint hot cocoa cruffin and I was thoroughly impressed. The outside was fluffy and croissant-like and the inside contained all the filling. I would've preferred a little less filling, but I enjoyed every bite of it. I wish they didn't sell out of them in the morning, so I could come here more often.
author: Catherine S.

description:
What an awesome place to visit!!! :-) A group of us stopped by a little later on a Saturday morning. We didn't make it in time to try their legendary cruffins, but there was such a delicious and unique assortment of other baked goods that no one left disappointed. 

I especially recommend their toffee cookies (the one with the little cereal flakes on top). 

We also ordered some different flavored donuts, croissants, and other pastries (ALL DELICIOUS) -- and then took a picture in front of their classic neon sign.

The staff was EXCELLENT -- despite the masses pouring into the shop, they were friendly, professional, and knowledgeable about each of their menu items! Wonderful experience from start to end!!!

You have to try this!!!!
author: Fiona H.

description:
I would definitely come back for all the goodies from Mr. Holmes! This San Francisco trip is a totally bakery epic...Went to three of the most iconic bakeries in two days! All of them are as perfect as the star rated; they are worth wait.
    Mr. Holmes has been on my Bakery List for so long... Finally, today, I made it! I took the bus 49 and got off at Van Ness and Sutter, then walked a few minutes. When I saw a line, I knew I arrived, and it was only 8:30. There were about 30 people in front of me... While waiting for today's cruffins, I could smell the buttery scent coming from the bakery, how wonderful!
      Here are some tips I've found that are good to know before you go....
Tip1:Cruffins are came out at 9:00 am each day.
Tip2:Limit 2 cruffin per person.
Tip3: Only one flavor for cruffin daily; two flavors for donuts. Check out their Instagram for Everyday flavors.
Tip4: One line for both cruffins and other pastries on weekdays, separated on weekends.
    I got my goodies around 9:30. I bought six pastries ad one cookie.
    Passionfruit Chocolate Cruffin$4.5: I never found a fruit filling that was delightful...  but this one, no kidding, was smooth, harmonious, and fruity. The cruffin itself was flaky, buttery but not greasy.
    Strawberry Jalapeño Bear Claw: Yes, it's jalapeño with strawberry filling!These two flavors were surprisingly matched. Another must get at Mr. Holmes.
   Chef's Choice Donut$3:I didn't know the flavour... but it tasted amazing! It's the best filled donut I've had because I always have plain donuts. But Mr. Holmes gave me a whole new experience. 
    Cornflake Cookies $3: It's pricey but perfect. Even my friend who doesn't like chewy cookies approved this one lol
    I've become a holmie! If you ask me to wait again, I will certainly do that.
author: Jui Han Y.

description:
TL;DR        T  I  P  S:
-There are 2 lines, one for the cruffins, one for pastries
-pastries start selling once the shop opens, cruffins are sold an hour later at 9am
-bring a friend! You need someone to stand in the pastry line while you stand in the cruffin line (or vice versa)
-you also need a friend to pay the meter because metered parking does not start until 9am
-you need a sticker to get a cruffin. 1 sticker=2 cruffins. 2 cruffin limit per person 
-stickers are passed out around 8:50ish
-DO NOT LIMIT YOURSELF TO CRUFFINS. THERE ARE OTHER PASTRIES TO BE LOVED AS WELL (get the ube puff)
-check their instagram for donut and cruffin flavors on certain days 


Dear Mr. Holmes, can I meet you? Can I throw a bread themed all carb party that you can cater? Can you be my personal pastry chef? I was sure that the hype wasn't going to be real, but dammit these pastries got the best of me. After months of yelp-searching, I finally mustered up the craziness to go out and make the drive from SJ to SF at 6 in the morning so I could make it by 7am and be #uno. I came on a saturday, the day after new years day. Don't be left in the dark like me, I assumed that the flavors were something you found out the day of to make it special and fun, but NO. IT IS POSTED ON THEIR INSTAGRAM EACH WEEK. Normally I would like to say that i thoroughly look through things especially when I'm really interested in it, but I do not know why I did not even try in this instance. So because of my lack of research, and because it was after new years, the flavor I got was a Pink Champagne cruffin. 

Okay wait, let me start over. So yes I got to SF at 7am and I was first. I had mixed emotions because I was happy to be first, but I also thought to myself, "man, if there doesn't end up being a long line, I'm going to feel like an idiot doing too much for a pastry." We parked at the metered parking which btw does not start accepting money until 9am. So it's necessary that you probably bring someone so they can hold your place in line while you go pay for the meter. There are two lines, one for normal pastries, one for cruffins, both will be indicated by a sign. The shop opened at 8am for normal pastries. By this time, a line for the cruffins really started to form. Trust me when I say that you definitely should get normal pastries as well. One reason is to hold you over till cruffin time. Second is because I think their pastries are actually phenomenal. The ube puff especially. Oh geez. That is one of the best ube flavored things I have had. The donuts were also delicious (I don't even like donuts). The california croissant would be my 3rd fave, which is a sushi croissant along with a packet of soy sauce. It's very messy, but worth the crumbs and spilled soy sauce! Their savory danishes were also pretty tasty, I think the one we got was a salami one (not completely sure, so just refer to photo). The butternut cheesecake was also yummy, pretty big too. The only pastry I was not fond of was their bread pudding, it was a little too dense and the caramel on top was very very sweet. 

ONTO THE CRUFFIN. It was my fault for not checking the flavor and knowing my luck I ended up with a weird flavor like Pink Champagne. I remember talking to the other people in line like, "Yeah I'm not picky, I really don't think theres any flavor I wouldn't like!" Then the woman came out and announced pink champagne. Once I got my cruffin though...man, maybe it was a good thing that I got a flavor I thought I wouldn't like. Because even though I wasn't a fan of the flavor, I still really liked the cruffin. So I can only imagine how much more amazing it would be if it was a flavor I enjoyed. Which just means I will just have to come back hehe. I loved that the cruffins are so crisp on the outside, but soft on the inside. The filling inside was not overly sweet. I was afraid of a sweetness overkill like reviews have stated, but it was perfect to me! Even a few days later, these were great when I threw them in the toaster oven. Repeat TOASTER OVEN. NOT MICROWAVE. Microwave would just make it soggy and not do it justice. Anyways, I got to talk to one of employees and she told me about how on average they make about 200 cruffins a day, but since they're tricky to make, only about 170 or so end up baking correctly. Aka that's 170 chances for me to get another one, IM COMING BACK.
author: Maleah M.

description:
Well I didn't know getting a cruffin is a serious business that requires research and planning :P So we didn't get any (of course), for future reference: cruffin is out on 9am, 2 per person, different line, sold out usually by 9:20-9:30.

However, I love other pastries! Love how inventive they are, the california croissant (croissant with smoked salmon, nori, etc) is delicious! The regular croissant is also good, vanilla donut is also very good! Love the custard!

The line may look intimidating, but it actually goes pretty fast. Other than the cruffin, most items are well stocked and supplied frequently so no need to panic (?)
author: Ya K.

description:
After weeks of planning when best to get in line and optimize my time, I got to try the infamous cruffin!  

PBJ cruffin 4/5 - The cruffin itself is definitely a novelty item that every San Franciscan would find worth trying, but generally it's just a glorified croissant shaped like a muffin.  Generally, there was a good flaky exterior vs soft bready innards ratio which was unique from the typically shaped croissant.  Perhaps the most distinguishable part of the cruffin was the flavor injection.  The peanut butter and jelly flavor-of-the-day was a bit overwhelming for me; it masked the flaky buttery croissant flavor with an ooze of PBJ. I am sure this is not the case everyday, and other flavors might play better with the pastry flavor. 

Passion fruit donut 4/5 - this unconventional donut had a great doughy texture that I enjoy, and was encrusted in a thin layer of sugar.  There was a bit too much filling, but with a few wipes, I was able to create a good pastry to filling balance, and the filling flavor itself was a really delicious sweet passion fruit flavor without being too sickly sweet or sour or pucker-y like the real fruit.

Negroni donut 4/5 - this donut was a sensory overload.  First, there was a little but strong eyedropper shot of liqueur piercing the top of the pastry, and I injected it into the center of the pastry before eating it.  The distribution of the liqueur was uneven as some bites had really strong alcohol tastes while others had none.  It was an interesting combination to have a really solid pastry mixed with creamy filling and an alcoholic kick.

Important to note, during the week, there is no sticker-ing system for cruffin purchases, it is run with a first come first serve basis and cruffin distribution starts at 9am.  That said, I was able to get in line at 8:45am (cruffins are served starting at 9am), and be served at around 9:20am.  For a Wednesday morning, this was a surprisingly long wait, but nothing compared to the weekend rush for cruffins. Worthwhile wait during the weekdays IMO, but I probably wouldn't fight the eager hordes of people who get there at 7am on the weekends.
author: Kathy T.

description: This shop was right around the corner from my hotel and made for a nice quick breakfast shop before heading off to my Pilates class. The offerings were very nice. I could not say no to the Pastrami croissant, and I am so glad that I complied! Yum and yum again!!! I might stop at this place every morning during this trip! The pricing is a little high, but the quality is quite nice. Wish they had seating.
author: N. S.

description:
This place has achieved cult status, particularly for its cruffins and the "I got baked in San Francisco" decal on the wall, which is pretty much all over instagram.

Go early (~8:40am), wait 20-30 minutes, and get a cruffin. They really are excellent, and a must-try in SF. If you go late and they're out of cruffins, get a matcha croissant. And if they're out of those, then get anything, because everything the place has is wonderful. Try to go before noon though, because they'll often be out of everything by then.

If you're spoilt for choice and want to pick a day to go on, you can go on Instagram where they post the cruffin flavours for the day every week.
author: Tanay J.

description:
I'm not in to this kind of hype place, but i cannot deny how much i enjoyed the strawberry rhubarb cruffin I had. I'm not even in to pastries ! but it was SO GOOD! 
When my girlfriend dragged me to the tenderloin on a cold sunday morning to wait in line I was less than thrilled but after tasting the cruffin and the Turkey Pesto savory pastry my mood improved. 

TIP: DO NOT accidentally call their cruffin a cronut or you will be hit with the sass, from hell.
author: Antonio W.

description: By chance we happened upon Mr. Holmes and decided to stop in for some brunch pre-gaming goodness. There was a line which moved relatively quickly. We heard cruffins typically sell out by 8:30am so we knew we weren't going to get our hands on any (this time!). Not to worry, everything else they sell is damn delicious. We ordered a couple filled donuts (dark chocolate and peach), a churro crossaint and a California croissant (a savory croissant filled with salmon and seaweed). The churro croissant was filled with what tasted like dulce de leche cream. I highly recommend buying one...or three. Peach filled donut was second fav. Flavors vary daily. Wish I lived closer so I could eat Mr. Holmes delicacies to my heart's content
author: Melissa P.

description:
This was my first (and possibly last) visit here. We got here shortly before 8:30am on a sprinkly Saturday morning. (Cruffin distribution begins at 9am). They started handing out "you're guaranteed to get a Cruffin" stickers around 8:50am ... and the girl in front of me got the last one. Although I grew anxious, I stayed positive (cuz that's the way I live my life. And would they REALLY hand out the exact number of stickers?). Anyhow, about 35 minutes later -- we got to the front of the line AND they still had a handful of cruffins left! As you have read/researched, they allow 2 cruffins per person. I ordered 1 because (a) they looked big and sweet and (b) I wanted to give someone else a chance to try a cruffin.

The cruffin itself was good, but a little too sweet for my palette. Is it wrong to say that I threw away some of the filling? Well I did. Sorry, Holmies. Since I woke up at 6:30am to get here and stood outside in the rain, I was expecting a little more. More what? I'm not sure. More all around crispiness? More photo ops??? I really wanted to take a photo of the "I Got Baked in San Francisco" neon sign, but alas, it was off. BOOOO!!! This is worth a visit if you're open to the flavor and willing to standing in a long line, but I would HIGHLY suggest getting in line before 8:20am to guarantee yourself a cruffin.
author: Jane L.

description:
Came in on a rainy Friday in the end of January at around 11am and this place was empty. I could do cartwheels in the room if I wanted to (and I did want to since I FINALLY got to come here). I've been dying to come here for months but considering the location and the reported sell-out times, I never had a chance. But today was my day because there were a TON of cruffins left.

I purchase a big box with 3 cruffins (2 chocolate, 1 banana cream), 1 California Croissant, 1 Choux bomb, and 1 chai tea donut. You have to order 6 items or more to get the box (I coincidentally wanted 6, lucky me!) All the items came down to three things for me 1) the texture/taste of the pastry itself 2) the filling 3) how it came together.

The chocolate orange cruffins were the main cruffins they had today. I got two and kind of regret it. They're very heavy. The orange flavor isn't very distinct and results in a chocolate cream that just tastes a bit "off". The cruffin itself is basically a large portion of the crusty exterior of a croissant. It's buttery and crusty but I prefer the soft inner portions of a croissant the most. Overall it doesn't come together very well for me but it was fun to eat. (3.5/5)

I have very similar feelings for the banana cream cruffin. The banana cream flavor is very strong but something about the cream just didn't sit right with me. I prefer the banana cream at Tartine. It's not bad but it's also nothing very interesting either. (3/5)

The california croissant was a huge disappointment in my opinion. I don't know if they forgot the wasabi or if I grew immune to it or what but all I could taste was the salty salmon and the ginger. All the fillings were smushed into one small roll in the center and I felt like I ate a croissant with a bad california roll in the center. Also since the texture of the croissants here are a bit tougher and the baked salmon was dry, the whole bite was a bit hard to chew. I think it definitely would've tasted better warmed though. (2/5)

The choux bomb and chai tea donut had similarities to them despite being very different desserts. Both of them had the best overall bite (the pastry and the creams actually complemented each other) and the creams were both tasty though a bit too sweet for me. Between the two I prefer the chai tea donut more and if I came back I'd definitely get another one. (3.5/5- choux bomb) (4/5- donut)

Overall, I'm glad I gave Mr. Holmes a try at least once and I'm relieved I didn't spend hours in line just to get it. It's a bit pricy. My 6 pastries were about $27 total. It's worth a try at least once but it wasn't my cup of tea. However I did LOVE taking photos by the sign, especially since their boxes are beautiful. And I was very happy with the helpful service here.
author: Vivian C.

description: I will admit, the wait for these pastries is a but much and a total overkill. It's definitely trendy and instagramable. There is a wide range of pasties available however they are a bit pricey. The matcha croissant was probably my favorite. I wasn't a huge fan of the cruffin flavor they offered that day. All of the pastries had good texture and were light and buttery however not were not out of this world- which I was expecting due to the hype lol. I would stop by if I were in SF again and if there were no line.
author: Anabelle C.

description:
Overall: 3.9/5
-----------------

Food: 2.5/5
1) Chocolate Coconut Cruffin - 2.5/5
2) Hazelnut Doughnut - 2.5/5
3) Chocolate croissant - 2.5/5
4) Ube - 2.5/5
You have to be one of the first people there and wait in line to get a cruffin (its what they are known for). They also change the flavors everyday. However, i dont really think its worth it.

Location:  4/5

Service:  5/5

Cleanliness: 4/5

Experience: 4/5

--------------------
Wait time: 30 mins (morning, weekday)
author: John V.

description:
I'm a fan, and all I had was one cookie! Here's why:

We get to the bakehouse at 9:30am on a Wednesday morning, and the line is out the door. Okay... I get it... everyone else in line is probably a tourist too. There's also plenty of people cutting the line, taking photos of the "I got baked in San Francisco" light, then leaving, which makes the place seem even more packed. 

Minutes after we got in line, one of the workers came out and walked around asking people in line how we were doing, which was really nice. Then, he announced that there were "only 100 pastries left. After we sell the last one, we're closed for the day." I was in shock... they're supposed to close at 2:30pm!!!! It was barely 9:40am! How could this be?

The line moves quickly and I see people carrying boxes of baked goods out of the door, and I'm positive we're not going to make it. As luck would have it, by the time my friend and I got to order, there were two cookies left. That's it. After those two cookies, the line stopped, the lights turned off, and they were done for the day. We felt like we would be sinning if we took both of the last things, so we decided to share one cookie and let the family behind us take the last one. Good karma... right? :) 

The service was wonderful, and the cookie was surprisingly incredible. I could have eaten 4 more! I wish I could have tried the other products they have, but now I know to come right when they open.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Richa A.

description: The childish girl ringing up customers has no respect. A fake yawn, shoving belongings aside as I put them on the counter to pull my credit card out and looking down at me with disdain were enough to ruin my first experience here. Regardless of how the pastries taste, this is one establishment I would not recommend to friends or family to visit.
author: Emily T.

description:
Came out here on a Tuesday Morning rnd 9:30ish (all the way from the flatlands of Fairfield). Thank goodness there was no crazy long line and everything was still available! I was able to snag the last of the ferrero rocher choux bombs. There were plenty of cruffins to go around (I'd say about 10-12 left-- snagged 2 of them), grabbed 2 California sushi croissants and a blueberry brioche bomb. Total came out to under $30 for 7 pastries. Pretty reasonably priced for the city I'd say..

Cali croissant-- crispy outside and soft/ flakey buttery inside with a delicious California sushi roll in the middle. Aw man it was tasty. 'Twas really flavorful and savory. I could eat it for breakfast everyday if I could. 

Peanut butter Cruffin-- crispy sugar coated outside with a surprise filling in the middle. I'm not really a fan of peanut butter but it was 'licious. The peanut butter was very subtle. I believe it was mixed in with marshmallow fluff? It wasn't too sweet which I liked. I enjoyed it so much that I was having second thoughts on whether to eat the one I was saving for a friend..but yeah I had self control...

Ferrero rocher choux bomb-- this was definitely my favorite outta the sweet pastries. It was basically an open cream puff but with their ferrero rocher filling. Oh my yum it was so delish--not too sweet and the flavor was subtle. #nomnation

Blueberry brioche bomb-- I had an opportunity to try it but I was too busy stuffing my face with the Cali croissant and peanut butter Cruffin. My friends devoured it. They said it was nom-worthy 

Not even 10 minutes after we got there they were completely out of cruffins and most of their pastries. We were so lucky that we were able to get what we wanted and we didn't have to wait long for them.

Overall service was great, pastries were on point. I'll be back....on a early weekday morning. I'm not even gonna try to come here on a weekend... Do your research people and plan ahead!!
author: Vicky L.

description:
I dropped by Mr.Holmes on a Monday morning around 8:30 - no line! And no cruffins...(those appear at 9 AM) but still got a box of 6 to share with some friends  (~$25).  Loved the choux bomb, pineapple filled donut, caramel sticky bun, kouign amann, California croissant, and savory potato & leek danish. Everything but the donut was eaten immediately -the donut looked like it would fare the best since it didn't have any flaky layers to worry about. Most everything was greatly enjoyed - 

Unfortunately the California croissant wasn't really enjoyed. It seemed that the smoked salmon was a bit strong, and the way it was wrapped in seaweed made it slippery and messy to eat.

I'd go back again for the caramel sticky bun! It looked a lot like a caramel filled kouign amann - over the top decadence, yes. But go big or go home! The donut was also quite tasty with a perfectly creamy and tart pineapple custard.
author: Lydia N.

description:
Omg - what an amazing bake house. Totally SF style. 
Their pastries are delicious. Must must go. Once you go, you will get hooked. So let's get baked in SF ;)
author: Jenna F.

description:
Hello Cruffin. 
It's me. 
I was wondering after all these years, you'd like to meet. 

I'm so late to this, but I finally got the try the cruffins from this place! I was so excited for this bakery when it first opened, but was a bit put off by the stories of long lines. I was either working so early in the morning or decided to sleep in on the weekend, so I never got around to making the trip here. 

I would say the cruffins are worth the hype and the wait. On the day I went, they had earl grey chocolate! DELICIOUS! Sweet flaky exterior with a velvety smooth earl grey chocolate. Perfect texture and flavor and not overly sweet. Well worth the $4. 

I also bought two of the doughnuts here. One was jalapeno strawberry and the other was lavender caramel. Very creative on the flavors here! I think I enjoyed the cruffin more, but I'm looking to try some other pastries here like the kouign amann. 

Also, just a few tips!
Cruffins come out at 9AM. I got there on a weekday at around 8AM was there was no one there. I recommend getting to the bakery around 8:30AM if its a weekday. The line might have formed, but it wont be too long. They limit the cruffins to 2 per person so, I don't think they'll run out if you get there on time.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
One of the best bakeshops in sf. I've been here twice and I had a good experience both times. 

Must try: cruffins and donuts!

Coconut rum raisin cruffin: 5/5: perfectly crispy, crunchy and sugary exterior. It was the perfect croissant with sugar. The filling was light and tasty. There was a perfect coconut cream with a good splash of rum and raisins sprinkled throughout. 

Caramel banana donut: fluffy exterior and a caramel and banana filling. It wasn't too sweet and the bananas were perfectly ripe. Loved every aspect of this donut.

Definitely love this bakeshop and I can't wait to come back to try other stuff!

Total: $20
author: Stella J.

description:
So I came here again this morning. Today is a Saturday. Last time I gave them 5 stars but this time I came, they switched things up on me. This time, they had 2 lines. One line is CRUFFIN ONLY and the other was the all the other baked goods. This is where there was a problem. So I came around 8am with two other friends. My friend stayed in line while me and my other friend went to the other line to buy some donuts and whatnot. While we were in the other line, the guy came by around 8:45 and gave out these stickers that guaranteed you a cruffin. Because we were in the other line, we did not get the sticker although we were there since 8am! Only one of my friends got it. 

This happened to about 4-5 other people that I know of. Last time I came, we were able to order other goods when we were ordering our cruffin which worked great because there were no issues with stepping out of line. Anyways, the guy was nice enough to give me one cruffin, but I was not allowed 2. Still a great place, but this system needs to be worked out. 

Todays flavor was Orange Creamsicle and it was alright but I really liked the Fluffernutter I had last time! The amelie amann was good again and I tried the salted caramel donut. The salted caramel flavor was better than the vanilla one I got last time. 

I am still a fan of Mr. Holmes but it would be nice to work out a better system! I'll be back, hopefully for a better experience next time!
author: Lydia H.

description:
I'm generally against waiting in line for food, but finding myself a few short blocks from here and with nothing to do on Sunday morning, I wandered over to snag a cruffin (two, actually).

I'm glad I did.  One always has to wonder if these kinds of sensations will live up to the hype, but the cruffin was incredible.  I got a handful of other things too, and of what I've sampled so far everything has been tasty.

This morning, which was Sunday, I arrived at about 8:40 AM and there was a modest line outside for cruffins, but almost no line for everything else.  I took the opportunity to load up on other goods and then stood in line for cruffins.  You can always get cruffins first and other stuff after.

I'd love to come back for just about anything but especially the cruffin - amazing.
author: Brent T.

description:
Sunday Morning, and the cruffins were sold out :/
But there are still a bunch of other amazing looking desserts :)

HOW IT WORKS:
You go in and you tell the people who work there what you want as you move down the selection of baked goods and you pay at the end of the line where you select what you want. And of course stop for a few pics ^_^

PRICING:
To be honest, the pricing is pretty expensive. The average price for each item was about $4-5 dollars. I wish it was a bit cheaper, especially because the wait for the pastries is so long, not to mention parking D':
Rating: 1/5

THE BAKEHOUSE:
The shop is located in the middle of a sketchy place (The Tenderloin, but hey the TL is pretty cool though), but the shop itself is adorable. The shop is pretty small, and there is no seating but there is a small counter and that gorgeous wall that says, "I got baked in San Francisco" (ahh that wall is so beautiful). And yes, it does imply activities that one would do on April 20th. No, I do not engage in such activities. 

Rating: 3/5

SERVICE:
There are a few nice workers, but there are a few workers that have their sass game going strong smh.
Rating: 3/5 

DONUTS:
The donuts are inflated with a thick cream on the inside. The cream seems to be based off of whipped cream and the flavors vary each day. The donut itself is very light and covered in sugar. 
Rating: 4/5 

CROISSANT:
The croissants are absolutely gorgeous and are baked to this golden brown color. They are very crispy and nice and puffed up. The croissant is a little sweet, and overall delicious.
Rating: 5/5

CHOUX BOMB:
This has a lot of filling, which is thick and creamy. The chocolate piece is interesting, it's got this almost nutty taste to it. The ends of the choux were quite small though, which left me with a bunch of cream. The taste was okay, but nothing special.
Rating: 3/5

Overall, I enjoyed this bakery. The pricing, super long wait, and parking makes me cringe, but the pastries themselves will satisfy any foodie. If you're up for the wait and the possible heartbreak of not getting a cruffin, go for it! Even if you don't get a cruffin, there are plenty of other options ^_^
author: Jenny G.

description:
I had heard about this place from a few bloggers that I follow so I was super excited to go and enjoy a morning of pastries and coffee! 

There were so many delicious things to choose from but I finally settled on the studded doughnut and a chocolate chip cookie (to go). Both were fantastic but the coffee was just ok. 

The space is super cool looking but super small. I would recommend it for a grab and go but don't plan on spending too much time there.
author: Tara P.

description:
Pretty good Donuts and pastries. The service sucks, not sure why people in the industry feel it is ok to provide bad service. You are in a "service" industry. I asked what kind of donut? If you don't want to tell me then you should put a sign out. 
Not sure if I would want to come and wait in line. There are lots of better places to come and give my money to.
author: Alison W.

description:
I LOVE PASTRIES. I am a sucker for baked goods. So obviously, I had to try the infamous cruffin! I came here with a friend on Saturday morning exactly at 8 AM (they open at 8). There are two lines, one for cruffins and one for everything else. Thank god my friend agreed to come with me to wait in line. She stood in the cruffin line, which had probably about 10-15 people in front of her at 8 AM!!! And I stood in the other line which had about 5 people. You definitely need to come with a friend if you're planning on getting cruffins and other pastries. 

My line moved fairly quickly, I got 2 boxes of pastries (6 in each box) and was out the door and waiting in the other line with my friend by 8:20ish. The pastries were all ~$3-5 each, so it's a little pricy. If you want a box, you have to get at least 6 pastries, otherwise the box is $1.50. ALSO, that box is HIGH quality LOL. It's some sturdy cardboard box, and very aesthetically pleasing hahhaha. I basically ordered one of every pastry there LOL so yeah I had two boxes. The inside of the bakery is VERY small, and the person at the front was helping each person one at a time, so the line moved slowly but it wasn't too bad at 8 AM. They do take card, but that day their system was glitching so it was taking longer than usual. They give everyone in the cruffin line a sticker to claim their cruffins, 2 cruffins per person (i think ~10 minutes before they start giving the cruffins out at 9 AM). 

SO THE VERDICT ON THE PASTRIES -- DELICIOUS. Ugh. Can anything be more perfect than a pastry????? We ordered a ton of pastries, and literally every single one was delicious. The standouts to me were definitely the matcha donut (flavor varies daily), the artichoke danish, strawberry jalepeno brioche bomb, and the apple honey bostock. The strawberry jalepeno brioche bomb was especially delightful since I was not expecting a slightly spicy pastry at all. And the flavors worked surprisely well together! I wish I had another LOL. I'm in love with danishes, so all of their savory danishes UGH SO MOUTHWATERINGLY TASTY. The cruffin was good as well, but the flavor of the day was chocolate strawberry and I don't really like strawberries or jam and cruffin was topped with a strawberry flavored jam and fresh strawberries...but the chocolate part was great! It's basically a giant croissant shaped like a muffin filled with chocolate pudding. LOL. The insides were amazing. 

There are so many delicious choices. The only downside is the line/waiting and a lil pricy for pastries. But yolo. Come here early. Or midday (skip the morning rush altogether). Get pastries. Stuff your face. Be happy & hello diabetes. LOL
author: Amy T.

description: LOVE. This place is close to where I worked for many years. Love the pastries... And their packaging - what a cool to go box they have! Foil stamped and everything. Makes a great gift when going to a party.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Damn. Holmes is my homie. 

After seeing the buzz on my Instagram, I knew my love for pastries would lead me here soon enough. I thought about braving the #hellastorm but I was like, ehh nevermind. 

I finally made it this past weekend. I love everything about your bakehouse Holmes. Your gold font, your honeycomb patterned floor, your logo, and of course your catchy high times neon sign.  I thought you might possibly be honeydicking us around because of the naysayers, but SCREW THEM! In all honesty, it's "hipster" but fck that cliche mess, I love a good pastry and you definitely deliver on that end.  
Raspberry pistachio brioche bomb, vanilla donut, salted caramel donut and a hazelnut chou. Everything is so damn pretty, but I am sure you know that

My raspberry pistachio brioche bomb had the perfect proportions of jam and cream. DUDE how do you do it!? Skills. Brioche was soft, but the pistachios offered a nice crunch for texture. 

I'll be back for more.


Solid!
author: Susy C.

description:
Man! I made it too late. This place is worth the hype. I did get there a little late, around 12 on a weekday, and the Croissants and Cruffins were all sold out. Be sure to make it there around 9 when they are freshly baked, as they are sold out usually by 11am.

I did however get an expensive $3 cookie. It was completely worth the money.
author: Jack L.

description: As this was one of the recommended places to go, it was a must for me to go. It's about a 10-15 min walk from my hotel Hilton Union Square. Don't expect a big bakery or it to be fancy, we only found it bc of the line of ppl out the door. You pretty much go in and order from a counter of a selection of about 10 different items and they all looked to die for delicious. The cruffin which they're pretty much known for changes monthly I think they said with the flavoring so when we went it was with blackberry. Not the biggest berry fan to begin with but how could I not try it. I also got the matcha croissant, chocolate croissant and apple monkey break with bourbon caramel sauce! Yummmmmm! It even comes in a pretty and sturdy box with the saying "I got naked in San Francisco" how could you not post it on IG. it was perfect for the walking around snack I needed.
author: Grace P.

description: Got here a little after 9:30 and there was NO line out the door. At first I thought all the best sellers were out buuuut nooope! They were full stock on everything! I tried the matcha croissant and apple griffin and both were so yummy and came in a cute box!
author: Shay B.

description:
I love their cruffins and California croissants (a croissant with nori and smoked salmon in the center). 

I've waited three times for cruffins (on the weekends) and have been first in line each time ~7AM. 

Here are the essentials to get a cruffin on a weekend:

- There are two lines. Be in the cruffin line, which is to the left of the bakery by 7:30AM to guarantee a cruffin. Limit 2 per person. Flavors vary every day. 
- Make sure everyone in your cruffin party receives the Mr. Holmes sticker. You'll need the sticker to get a cruffin. 
- Come with a camping chair or happy to chat with other people in line. You've clearly got something in common with all the other crazies in line. Why not joke about it?
- If you intend to buy 4 more pastries from the non-cruffin line, tell them you will and ask for a box. Otherwise, the box will cost you $1.50. You need to buy 6 pastries to get their box.
- Eat your cruffin ASAP if possible. They get a bit soggy after a few hours and don't transport or reheat very well because of the center filling.

Immediately after purchasing cruffins, I always hop into the non-cruffin line to get extra California croissants to eat and to take home and refrigerate. It's great the next day popped in the oven at 400F for 5-8 minutes. I also recommend getting the Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb, if it's available and perhaps their jelly donuts, which remind me of Hawaiian malasadas. 

All the other pastries are good, but I reckon you can find comparable if not better ones at rival bakeries, but you can decide for yourself. You can't go wrong, it's all good if you can stomach it. 

P.S: This is a grab and go bakery. Don't expect to be seated anywhere.
author: Ze Lin X.

description:
Amazing as always, got a cruffin this time and it is worth it!

They open at 8 serving everything except cruffin and cruffin comes out at 9. We arrived around 8:25 on a Sunday morning and line wasn't too bad at all. We were able to get coffee and pastries, so we didn't have to starve in the chilly morning while waiting. This is definitely a plus! By 8:45, one staff came out to announce the flavor of the day and passed out stickers as ticket to buy the cruffins, 2 per person. 

Besides the cruffins that they are known for, the salmon seaweed savory croissant is the BOMB!! The croissant itself is just soooo flaky and it comes with a pack of soy sauce as part of the interesting experience. Don't hesitate to try out other exotic seasonal flavors. I got the strawberry jalapeno bioche this time and the spiciness that kicks in as an after taste is absolutely addictive.

This is definitely a must-go in SF!
author: Ivy F.

description: Yes, the cruffins are worth it and you should wait on the cruffin line if you really want one. But, if you're a general pastry-lover like me, everything else here is equally as amazing. So, if you don't have time to wait or aren't about the hype pastry world, just get in the regular line or come later in the day. Their plain croissants are amazing (light with some crunch, flaky and buttery) and so are their donuts (so satisfying). Mr Holmes is definitely one of my favorite bakeries in the city!
author: Ada C.

description: I go here every other day for breakfast or bread. Having lived in France, now I really miss those French breakfasts. Well, I used to until I discovered this spot! Eclair, pain au chocolat  and croissant! Sometimes, plus lemon tart (if anything left). Love you, guys!
author: Katerina S.

description: I absolutely love how cute the interior is! This place is located in the Tenderloin. Their pastries are to die for! Make sure you go early because they will sell out fast! I tried the orange blossom cherry croissant, it was delicious! I am so sad there isn't a Mr Holmes in Chicago! It's a must try! "get baked in san francisco!"
author: Annie C.

description: This is my second time at Mr. Holmes Bakehouse. First time i went the famous cruffin is not available so we ended up buying their other pastries which are equally as good as the cruffins. But today I'm so happy the cruffin is available to my surprise. I immediately bought two pieces which is actually the maximum allowed per person. I also got four other pastries because I wanted them in a Mr. Holmes box. Today's flavor is raspberry...it's so good. I also got donuts, cruffin pudding and churro croissant.
author: mel m.

description:
Mr. Holmes Bakehouse...

Ambiance:10
Food: 7.5

I think the pastries are sometimes a hit or miss. But the ones that are a hit are definitely pastries to come back for. My experience here is always a delight! I love the people here and the design of the shop. Whitewall, large windows, natural lighting=favorite. I recently tried their cherry malasadas, and wow... I usually hate donut texture pastries but these malasadas changed my life. The cherry filling is not too heavy and over powering. It's light and creamy! 

I also love their savory pastries. We had their turkey and pesto Danish and their potato and leek Danish. Both delicious and filling! 

I recommend trying both savory and sweet items!
author: Frances T.

description:
My fiancé and I had driven from Los Angeles to San Francisco and our first stop was Mr. Holmes Bakehouse. I had seen so many images of their pastries online and I had stalked their yelp account for days prior to our arrival. 

One thing I kept reading was arrive early because lines can be a bit long, that was what I was anticipating for, but as we arrived there was hardly anyone there. I screamed for joy in my mind, my patience was starting to thin after that 5 hour drive. It was 9am and no one in sight, we even found decent parking! We had our fur babies so we went into the bakery one at a time. There were no descriptions of what each pastry was so either you asked each items description or you chose solely on aesthetics alone. From photos online I was able to distinguish the ube puff and ordered it immediately. The only issue I had was while I was ordering I had asked for the iconic box and the associated quickly snapped at me stating that it was only for purchases of 6 items.

I ended up ordering

 a cruffin (croissant muffin hybrid), ube puff pastry, strawberry jalapeño brioche, two cream filled donuts and a choux bomb. I insisted that my fiancé have a try at the strawberry jalapeno brioche and it did not disappoint. Overall I spent $27 on 6 pastries which was pretty standard for a boutique bakery and even after 3 days the pastries were still delicious. The ube puff and the strawberry jalapeño brioche are my favorite. I cannot wait until you all open a location in Los Angeles!
author: Karyn T.

description:
I finally got a chance to stop by on a rainy sunday. there was no line out the door, but also no cruffins to be had. I got the only doughnut of the day - kinda boring (vanilla cream) but tasty.  There were about 14 things to choose from, and man the people in the line are annoying, asking billions of questions about everything - "it is just pastry people, not a life-altering decision - take a friggin chance!"

I DO love their boxes.
author: Amy W.

description:
I heard about this place from a friend who loves pastries and desserts as much as I do. We rounded up a group of friends and showed up at 8:30am Sunday. There was a line, but thanks to good friends who got here at 8:10, we didn't have to wait more than 30 minutes. The great thing is that you don't have to stand in line if you are not getting the cruffins. So some of us got the filled donuts and other goodies, while others waited. Their strawberry smoothie donut ($3.5) is very very good!! Now as for the cruffin, it's amazing. It was stuffed with a generous amount of German chocolate filling, slivers of coconut pieces, and SO crispy on the outside just like a croissant should. The shape is of a muffin, so I guess that's the part it takes on its name. Note that you can only buy two cruffins with each visit.
Overall I had a great morning, all thanks to my visit at Mr Holmes. It is worth visiting at least once.
author: Alice S.

description: There's a line for a reason. Absolutely stellar creative baking happening here. So hard to choose. I went for the corn flake brown butter and toffee cookie. Absolute home run.
author: Bill S.

description:
I'd been wanting to stop by Mr. Holmes for awhile now & finally found the time to one weekend  with my cousins. We all read the reviews and were well-versed in our plan to tackle the hot ass mess that is Mr Holmes, including waking our asses up at 6am!

Here are my tips that'll make the process hopefully easier for you!
1) Split up your group. There are 2 lines, one for cruffins and the other for any other pastries. Send someone to get the other yummy pastries you want, while you stay in the cruffin line for the special sticker. IF by chance you're stopping by alone, go to the other line FIRST, then the cruffin line. The other line moves way faster! 

2) The holy sticker!! Each pink sticker guarantees each person a max of 2 cruffins. I know, sad right?! Stickers are usually distributed between 7am-8:30am, sometimes a little later because cruffins come out at 9am. If you don't get a sticker, don't completely give up! They usually give some leeway to the next 2-3 people after the last person who received the sticker

We got the special 4th of July cruffins they had that day that were filled with passion fruit. What i love about the cruffins is that they aren't overly sweet like you'd expect them to be - for me at least. The cruffin itself has a nice crusty exterior because of the sugar, but it's light and airy at the same time. Hard to explain so you'll just have to try it for yourself! Trust me, it's worth the wait 

Good luck!! Keep calm & cronut on
author: Joelle P.

description: Everyone loves to go here for the Instagram pics and social media uploads! I personally love overloading my self with sugary goodness! I do have to say that the people working on Saturday morning did not want to be there or they were annoyed with the crowd of people, or it could have been because the flavor of month for Cruffins was Matcha Green Tea? All in all, make sure to show up half an hour before opening time to get first dibs on all the yummy pastries!!!
author: Austin D.

description: Came here on a Wednesday around 1:20pm. Got there a bit too late for the cruffin. They were sold out again! So I end up getting one mint donut, blueberry donut, California croissant, and ube tart. My fav were the California croissant and ube tart. The UBe tart wasn't too sweet and super fluffy. Will come back for the cruffin.
author: Tram T.

description:
The choux bomb is amazing and brought me back to Paris. The filling is decadent and rich so don't let the petite size deceive you! 

It was national donut day so what the hell, I ordered a donut. I sort of regretted the decision due to the sugar/fat/carb overload but more importantly, the donut wasn't that impressive. It was very puffy and just felt like eating deep fried puffy bread. The mocha filling could also have had more of the coffee flavor that I felt was lacking. 

I definitely want to go back and try the cruffin! 

TIP: There's no seating and it's close to the Tenderloin. If you're wanting to eat here, prepare for a to-go seating plan.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Yes this is the place known for cruffins, that created the cruffins, but the other items are JUST AS AMAZING! That's right! 

The key to getting a cruffin on the weekend? Be in line by 8:30 a.m. They pass out stickers right before 9am, and cruffins are sold only at 9am. The sticker permits two cruffins per person. The flavor changes daily. The cruffins do not last longer than the day they were made. They are best eaten immediately. No joke.

If standing in line is not your thing, or you missed your opportunity for cruffin, their other baked items are just as good. Everything is delicious. There is a separate line for these items, and the line is non-existent. So you can have one person stand in line for a cruffin, and then someone else to grab other items to snack on!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
This lil' bakery is making me a fat ass but frankly it's so good I don't care. Their filled donuts are probably my favorite items despite the croiffin thing people line up for. What's there to say about sweet, baked goodness but kudos! 
The service us good but I have encountered very slow patrons who create a line when a little foresight would cure it. 
I won't stop coming here until I weigh 300 pounds
author: Tommy W.

description:
I only had their chocolate croissant because cruffins are not available until 9 AM :(

I should have done more research... But I was too excited that getting there at 7:30 means I will be able to get one without having to queue up like crazy! When I got there, there was still a queue, but certainly a small one comparatively.

The chocolate croissant was not bad! Which means it is A-OK. So I'm going to give this place a 3 stars (it's only fair since I haven't tried their famous cruffins). I'll just have to come back at another time for those and give another update once I've tried them!
author: Jade F.

description:
If you're a true San Franciscan, you know we only queue up for three things: brunch, Bi-Rite and Mr Holmes Bakehouse! So if you've woken up in a pleasant mood and can spare some time, line that ass up for some sweets and treats! Trust me, it is ABSOLUTELY worth the wait! 

Try their California Croissant if you're feelin' adventurous; the wasabi, nuri, ginger, and smoked salmon will leave you asking, "Where have you been all my life?!" If you've got more of a sweet tooth, then try their Boysenberry Danish. I swear, it's like an orgasm in your mouth. And who doesn't want that to kick start their day? HA!
author: Flor K.

description:
Everyone comes here for the cruffins, which is a croissant and a muffin combined. They start selling it at 9am but there is always a line an hour or two before that. 

Personally, I don't think I would wake up early to line up for these again. Even if you wait in line, you are not guarantee a cruffin. They pass out stickers to insure you into getting them but they run out of stickers less than half way through the line. The line usually stretches down the block, sometimes even around the corner. I stood inline at around 8:20 & I was able to get 2 cruffins. 

I got the strawberry matcha & I gotta say there wasn't anything special about it. The strawberry was way too over powering & I couldn't taste any of the matcha. But I do like the concept. The bread was fluffy & sweet. Although, it was extremely messy to eat since there is sugar. I was wearing black & the sugar got everywhere on my clothes while I was eating. 

I would definitely come back if the wait wasn't so crazy, but i feel like it's just a hype.
author: Jessica S.

description: Tasty but not sure it was worth waiting an hour in the tender loin before first bake to make sure you get a cruffin. We were getting harassed by a very aggressive homeless man for money for "bread". The staff were absolutely no help in keeping waiting customers feeling safe and secure.
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Excellent service and even better pastries! We snagged the last cruffin they had and it was 10am! My favorite was a jalapeño and strawberry jam thing. It was so good I can't even recall its name! 

A must try SF treat!
author: Natasha H.

description:
This place was good but a newsflash- ALL CROISSANTS ARE GOOD! It was very cute and trendy inside, but the cruffins were nothing special to me. Almost overwhelmingly sweet and sugary (and I usually love sweet and sugary).  

If there is a line and u are in a hurry, I wouldn't bother waiting, but if u have plenty of time on your hands, go check it out I guess, but don't expect anything more than a classic good croissant that you can pick up much more easily at Starbucks :)
author: Tara R.

description: Many people take Uber or Lyft to buy the best croissants! Highly recommend cruffins that let you delightful!
author: Amanda H.

description:
On my quest for cronuts, I stumbled on this place through Yelp! I decided to give this place a shot, so I dragged my boyfriend out of bed on Sunday at 7AM. The line was already forming but was not bad when we arrived. By about 8:30 the line was half way around the block, this place opens at 8:30 on Sunday's but they don't start to sell the cruffins until 9? Why? I don't particularly know. Anyway we finally got our sticker and the features flavor was Lemon Poppy Seed. Of course my bf and I got all 4, since there's a 2 per person minimum. We ended up buying more pasties as we felt we might as well considering we waited for about 1.5 hours. 

The lemon poppy seed wasn't my favorite, too tangy for my taste and I usually love lemon pound cake. You have to eat your cruffin ASAP, I waited till about half way to eat my second one and it was all soggy, no crisp after a few hours. Over all, I'd go back to try the other flavors, but not the lemon poppy seed. They only have one flavor per day. I just feel that if we're going to wait for 1.5 hours in line there should be more of a variety on cruffins.

I also ended up getting the Ube pastry which was amazing!!
author: Marisa B.

description:
Mr Holmes is indeed for the Holmies. I was siked when I realized this bakery was just around the corner from our apartment! Especially for the cruffin being that I love a good croissant. Strawberry milkshake cruffin was sugary and crispy on the outside and filled with baby pink cream. Warning it can get real messy scarfing this treat down. 

The coconut donut was way better than the cruffin though because the filling to dough ratio was more balanced. The apple honey bostock is a solid choice too. Wished we went back everyday so I could try the strawberry jalapeño brioche and the ube puff pastry! 

Also it's a tiny bakery, with only one high top to stand by near the window. Most customers would just buy and go
author: K C.

description:
Disclaimer: review is for not-cruffins.

Rolled in around 10:30 on a Thursday morning with hardly a line or wait.  We missed the cruffin cut-off by half an hour or so (I'm gonna say we did this intentionally), and some other popular items like the choux bomb had run out, but we managed to snag the following pastries:
- Mint chocolate chip donuts: Greedily took the last two remaining donuts of the day because capitalism. I honestly didn't think it would work but the creme had an authentic mint flavor without being overpowering. 
- Artichoke danish: Awesome. Again, was weary of too much artichoke but the balance between the feta/bechamel and the good ole thistle was on point.
- Kouign Amann: Okay but not outstanding, especially if you compare it to the one at b. or Dominique Ansel in NY.
- Chocolate sea salt cookie: Thick with just the right amount of saltiness. Yeah I said it.
- Pumpkin apple danish: to be tried at home but it sure looks good.

Overall, I'm annoyed that I'll have to come back for reals before I can pass final judgment, but after trying a good selection of Mr. Holmes' back catalogue, I have a good feeling about his hit single. Would I return for just these items again? Maybe not before trying other bakeries in SF, but Mr. Holmes is definitely in my rotation for now.
author: Brennan L.

description: Alright, so I live around the corner from this biz. And ya know what? It's not all that it's chalked up to be. The line is really convincing. I returned again and again until I finally came early enough to try the ever-elusive cruffin. It's okay. The dough was flakey-ish. The vanilla filling was good. But it just wasn't "wow". All the things I tried before the final cruffin weren't all that great either. The choco croissant, the mango donut, the squash danish--they were all just okay. I could find better elsewhere if I want to venture a couple blocks. I think the fun of it all roots from the anticipation of standing in line with other excited folks. So, in conclusion, if ya wanna have fun standing in line, go to Holmes!
author: Hannah J.

description: Great pastries. No too sweet. Not too buttery. Nice and flaky / crunchy crush where ots supposed to be. Fillings are usually thought through and balanced. People go there for the cruffins but I think they just nailed the beignets. They're perfect. Tiny place but a real gem in the tenderloin !
author: Jonathan F.

description: I love Mr Holmes because of its aesthetics. Their cruffins are popular for a reason - they are pretty good but always sold out. Their donuts, danishes, and fruit tarts are also not bad (just really sweet). I liked their earl grey donuts a lot. If you get over 6 pastries you can get a box for free.
author: Cate L.

description:
-- 1/100 reviews for 2016 -- Since I am so inconsistent with reviews, I've decided to give this idea a try.

On my last day of my San Francisco trip, I've decided to stop by here before I left. It was one of the best decisions ever!

The cruffins was OUT OF THIS WORLD! I forgot which flavor was sold that day, but I want to say it was the coffee chocolate chip? I normally don't like chocolate but omg, this had me say otherwise. Honestly, I would come here everyday if I lived closer. I have yet to try the other flavor cruffins one day. Can't wait to come back here.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Finally got to try Mr Holmes and their famous cruffins. (Do not mistakenly call them a cronut, lady selling them will give sassy response. Which is fair, but my poor companion was dragged out of bed by me to wait in line in the wee hours of the morning on a weekend)

Two lines: the one on the left (facing the storefront) is for cruffins, the one on the right is everything else. Unfortunately, you can't order other items in the cruffin line, but that makes sense because the store itself is actually super tiny (VS Dominique Ansel in NY that started this whole hype, you can buy additional items to your cronut in the cronut line.)
---Cruffin line started pretty early - we got there around 8:15 on a Sunday morning and there was already a small line (about 10-15 people in front of us, more added as people joined their friends). Stickers come out at 8:40. Unlike one of the yelpers, I do NOT recommend you necessarily split up your group. If you miss the sticker hand out, you will not get a cruffin. Yes, the sticker grants two cruffins per person, but dont you want all two to yourself? I did watch two people leave to join the other line to get other goods and by the time they came back, they had missed the sticker hand out. My alternative: we waited it out in the cruffin line, and immediately after getting our cruffin, the lady will ask "Are you buying anything else?" If yes, you literally hop over to the other side and fill your box with more goodies.  This second line does not always exist and even when it does, it moves pretty quick.

No seats. It's a tiny store that can only accommodate a handful of people. You give them your pink sticker, you get your cruffin, you pay, you GTFO. 

Flavor of that day: Strawberry Rhubarb! My take-away? DELICIOUS. They really do capture that perfect croissant texture - flaky and buttery - and combine it with sugar so that it caramelizes into an almost creme brulee type flavor. I truly enjoy it. Warning - the texture does not carry over into next day, but the flavor is still good. I think the filling softens the cruffin from the inside out, taking away that signature light delicate flakiness of a perfect croissant.

Other verdicts: We ordered a savory danish (Turkey & Pesto) and an Amelie Amann. Savory danish was bomb, and we wished we had ordered more...that ale & onion one looked promising. Amelie Amann was tasty, but nothing to write home about. The signature pistachio and rose paste they put inside was minimal and I barely noticed it. I wish we had ordered a donut, but at this point, with six pastries between two people, we were worried about too many gainzz right before summer ;)

TL;DR: Cruffins are tasty, worth the wait if you're really into pastries. (For us, about an hour. Arrived Sunday Morning at 8:15, out by 9:20). They have really captured the perfect croissant flavor/texture. Best to eat it that day. Other pastries definitely worth a try - especially the  savory danish to balance that sweet. You can just order the other pastries after you pick up your cruffins.
author: Josephine T.

description:
Got there around 8:30am on a weekday (Wednesday) and sure enough there was a long line outside of Mr. Holmes that extended down the slope. I felt like a child again during Christmas, waiting to unravel the surprise. They officially start selling their pastries/cruffins at 9am and with every inch towards Mr. Holmes, my friends and I experienced a tumultuous mix of excitement and apprehension as we saw the elegant white boxes displayed on the window dwindle and sell out. Thankfully they still had cruffins left when we ordered and made waking up early (during break too) worth it. 

The hype for the cruffin is real and I would say the excitement, anticipation, and apprehension were all well worth it. 

Tip: Have someone in line while you explore the different pastries offered for the day. Also, they only sell bottled water.
author: Linda K.

description:
Came here on a Tues 9:15am, was 5th in line, and there were only 8 cruffins left.  They do limit 2 per customer and luckily, the folks ahead of me only got 1 each.

Cruffins were out of this world.
Banana creme donuts were insane.
Choux Bomb = Like a flaky Ferrero Rocher croissant
Amalie Amann - layers and layers of butter, and sugar
author: Margaret W.

description: I've been wanting to visit this bakery for quite some time now and I finally did but I didn't really have much choices to choose from. (Definitely my fault for going 30 min before they close) but my experience was great. We got there and was immediately greeted by an employee and helped. I decided to get a donut and she went ahead and gave me another on the house! So nice! We paid and took a picture of their neon sign and went on with our day. The donuts were amazing! Can't wait to go back at an earlier time to try some of their other goodies!
author: Alejandra M.

description: Just the usual, nothing great about the place for the hype. Beware of flies from the neighbourhood.
author: Vivek P.

description:
I've had excellent baked goods. I've been to the best of the best in many cities. This is one. 

Original kinds of goodies. Great versions of old favorites. Pricey but worth every cent. Long line and worth the wait. Sweet or savory, the goods are perfect. 

The special items go first thing in the morning, line up before they open. Even if you miss the unique items, go. 

Coffee is only average. Everything else is superlative. 

Recommended.
author: Paul W.

description: Friendly and helpful staff even though the line is also out the door the staff still has a smile on their face and they are still happy to help you with any questions. The pastries are amazing sweet or savory. This is a must if you're coming to San Francisco
author: Genesie B.

description:
Oooohhhh my god, i'm so glad i've had the chance to try this place and their wondrous creations! I'm normally not even a pastry loving person, but I had to see what the hype was about with those cruffins and custard filled donuts! The hype is definitely real!!! Unfortunately this also means... the line is real too, ha! I've been on a weekday afternoon (wasn't too much left), but i've also been on a Friday at 8:40 am, and I was around 10th in line for cruffins, which come out at 9:00 am every morning. There's also a line for people who don't want cruffins (in most cases, you can just walk up to the counter and order). I've found that the best time to go is around 9 am Monday - Friday, as for Saturday and Sunday... don't even try! LOL!

What I've gotten to try so far:
- Pumpkin spice cream cruffin: During fall, it's all about the pumpkin spice... This cruffin did not disappoint! I was surprised by the size when I first saw it through the window.. This thing is huge! The outside is crunchy, and the inside is soft like a croissant. The filling inside was perfect--not too sweet, but had a strong pumpkin spice flavoring!
- Blueberry cheesecake donut: I got this for my bf because he loves anything blueberry flavored. Mr Holmes' donut texture was soft and pillowy, not dense at all. Loved the blueberry cheesecake filling! I even ate this one the day after and heated it up in the microwave for a few seconds, and it was still good!
- Matcha donut: I was sooo excited to try this! From the looks of it, I thought the matcha custard filling would be scarce, but it was actually pumped throughout the whole donut! The matcha toned down the sweetness of the sugar coated exterior too. Delish!
- California croissant: I absolutely loved this!! There is smoked salmon, seaweed, ginger, and wasabi rolled inside the middle of a huge croissant. The ginger and wasabi aren't too strong (I don't like either usually). They box it with a little packet of soy sauce, but I didn't use it because the croissant is very flavorful on its own.
- Artichoke danish: The artichoke and the feta blended together and the outcome was amazeballs!!!! Now I want to try all of their savory danishes!! 
- Ferrero Rocher choux bomb: I didn't know what to expect, but I love ferrero rochers so I decided to try this! The inside was a bit too sweet for me. I would share this with someone else in the future because I couldn't finish the whole thing!
- Kouign amann: Super dense layered croissant dough with a glazed, sugar coated outside. I thought this was alright and nothing too special. I think that's my personal preference though because a lot of people enjoy this!

The cute box is free if you buy 6 pastries, but costs $1.50 if you get less than that. A box of six pastries will probably run you around $25! Most items are less than $5.

I will be back soon! The cruffin is game changing, but so are all the other pastries... Be sure to get an assortment to try everything out! :) By the way, cruffin and donut flavors change daily, so be sure to check Mr Holmes' instagram or facebook for flavor updates!
author: Tara A.

description: Pastries are great, but not worth having to dodge all of the tourists taking instagrams in front of the "I Got Baked in San Francisco" sign.
author: Rachel K.

description:
I'm obsessed with their cruffins. Soft, melt in your mouth, with a little bit of something special (I got berry filling) - I will definitely be back as many times as possible. 

Tip: they will only sell you 2 cruffins per person. But, load up on donuts or whatever else you like. 

Worth the hype!
author: Leeyen R.

description:
Came here crack ass in the morning (not really). We got here at 8am when they don't even start serving cruffins until 9am. There were already 2 lines at this time: one for soley cruffins and the other for everything else. I came here with only 1 other person so yes, we each waited  in separate lines alone... liek fat asses. We had to try them all!

Cruffins: The only cruffin they had that day were the s'mores flavor. I thought it was just ok.. not really worth the long wait.

Luckily, we were able to try other things here. Some things worth trying are the ham and cheese, sushi (different), and the banana donuts (MUST TRY!!!)
author: Karen L.

description: Great stuff! We came for the cruffins and stayed for everything else! Worth the wait in line!!
author: Taylor B.

description: Overrated, crunchy, and crowded. Staff did not go out of their way to be polite and the coffee tasted like goat. Cute design but the food was not worth it.
author: Lulu S.

description: The baked goods are always fresh and unparalleled quality. But my real kutos goes to their marketing team. The decor and branding done with this place is nothing short of fabulous. Mr. Holmes is famous not only for its yummy baked goods but because of its iconic "I Got Baked in San Francisco" sign and its trendy merchandise.
author: Marisa R.

description:
Passion fruit cruffin topped with chocolate ganache was divine! It's basically like a slightly denser croissant shaped like a muffin....with passion fruit curd (AKA creme) pouring out from the center. Then with a bite of the chocolate ganache too it's like a quadruple threat!

The amelie amann is like a kouign amann but more dense and not as fluffy. Had a sweet, almost crunchy exterior from the sugar glaze. It's different. Worth a try!
author: Audrey L.

description:
I don't really get the hype. Some of the baked goods are interesting. Most have too much cream in them.

I don't think Mr. Holmes is worth a long wait, but if you happen to stop by when there is no line, you'll probably find something you'll enjoy.
author: Sara M.

description:
What a disappointment...

plain croissant $3.50
chocolate croissant $4
california croissant $5
donut $3.50

Spent $16+tax and still had to pay for a box (buy 6, get a box free). lame!

This shop has been on my bookmark forever!! I finally came on a weekday in July and there was surprisingly no line! Sadly, they didn't have any cruffins for sale. I've really wanted to try the matcha ones!

Overall,  I found this place to be super overhyped. The pastries are quite pricey for what you get. I thought the pastries all tasted mehhh; I've had better. The most interesting out of the four I got was the California Croissant. I advise you to save your $$$ and go somewhere else. There are so many other great bakeries in SF! Don't waste your time here...

2.5 stars
author: CeCe C.

description:
I was all about the hype and HAD to try a cruffin since my hotel was right around the corner.   We stood in line for about 45 min to wait for the cruffins.  Honestly I was not impressed.  They were o.k.  Malted chocolate was the flavor of the day.  I didn't care for the filling.  The outside was pretty good though.  They ended up  being too big, too messy and just o.k.  

NOW.  The better part of the purchase was the stuff you don't have to stand in the line and wait til 9am for.  I tried the Corn Bread Stuffing muffin.  It had lots of flavor.  Crazy tasty spices and pork sausage is deeeeeelightful.  Complete with gravy.  We also had a Kouign Amann.  Holy crap.  Those were soooooo good.  Flakey, sweet goodness. 

Go once if you feel you need to. I did.  I'd go again but not for the coveted cruffins.  

The employees were nice and helpful inside the store.  Outside in line was a bit different but I'm going to assume she's had to break up a fist fight or 2 over pastries.
author: Gigi M.

description:
We had several different items and all were exceptional.  The sausage roll is a great breakfast item to have before all the sweet ones.  The churro croissant was amazing, the cruffin was also amazing.  Go early as they do run out of things.  The cornflake cookie was also very tasty. 
The staff there was wonderful, very helpful in telling us what each item was and their personal favorites.
author: Marcia M.

description:
I navigated my way into the city from South Bay just to try some Mr Holmes pastries. I had really high hopes. While the pastries were delicious and flakey and sweet, they all tasted the EXACT same. The dough they use is awesome, but three of the four pastries I bought could have virtually been the same. Maybe I chose the wrong pastries? The only pastry that tasted different was their donut. I will say that the cream inside the donut wasn't anything special. Had lots of expectations that fell short. 

Despite the pastries being less than stellar, I will say that the customer service deserves FIVE stars. The ladies behind the counters were kind, more than willing to answer any of my silly questions, patient, and made you feel welcomed and comfortable in their tiny space. 

If I'm in the city again, I may give Mr Holmes another shot, but will not be making special trip up again.
author: Danielle D.

description:
i think i had le donut with orange-pineapple filing and it was AMAZING, i could've easily had seconds. i honestly wasn't paying attention when the girl was telling me what kind they were because i was too preoccupied from staring and almost drooling over the donut display in this small & cute bakery shop

my friend and i called them 10 minutes after they supposedly closed on a weekend and they told us they were still open, so we ubered there from our brunch place and got the orange-pineapple donuts, chocolate croissants, and a boysenberry danish - we devoured everything in silence because it was that good. 

the signature matcha cruffins usually sell out by 9am, but the other pastries certainly don't dissapoint. def call to check if they're still open after closing hours because chances are, they'll still have lots of goodies to sell
author: Ying Z.

description:
Came here a couple of times already and of course the cronut craze is real. They do officially sell them at 9am and yes there is usually a line. However, The times that I did line up, it wasn't as busy as other reviews. So it wasn't bad at all, just a few people in line, and even when I came a bit around 10am last time, I was still able to purchase 2 (the limit). They are delicious and the flavors change daily.
