They are a bit expensive but quite worth it, crispy deliciousness on both the outside and inside. They also sell other pastries and cookies, so make sure to grab something new to try.

 CC accepted here.
author: Hao B.

description:
I was finally able to try Mr Holmes Cruffins after a bunch of mistimed attempts. I have to say, it was worth the wait.

I've tried to get up early enough to get in line for these things, but always came a little to late to get a good spot (a place in line not near the end of the block). I would definitely suggest to try and get out there around 8:20-8:30. I arrived today around 8:25 and was maybe the 20th person in line. Which for a Sunday, wasn't bad at all.  Once the Cruffins came out (9:00 am every morning) the line moved pretty quickly and I was able to walk away with 2 Cruffins (the max for each person) and a few other pastries from the mainland counter. 

Today's flavor was white chocolate lemon ginger- also known as AMAZING. It was a great first experience with these hybrid breakfast sweets. And again, in my opinion, WELL WORTH THE WAIT.

I also ordered the strawberry jalapeño brioche bun (2nd time having it for a good reason) 2 Cal croissants, the cookie, and a blackberry covered bread that I'm still drooling about. Note: if you order 6 items or more, Mr Holmes supplies you with a box and a bag to carry out your sweets and savories)

Glad I was able to check off this foodie feat off my list! I'll be back for more soon!
author: Julian D.

description: If you want exceptional quality for pastries, this is the place ! Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is a small pastry shop in the Tenderloin that's been opened 3 years ago . How I know that???? Because , I was the few in line to get IN when it first opened ! Yay !!! It may a bit pricey , but your money's WORTH! Come over to be in Line to get some savory pastries today .
author: Gloria L.

description: Ok so we've known about Mr. holmes for  2 years now. And we know that the cruffins are the popular pastry to buy. Our first attempt was at 1pm. They said they ran out. Ok we said to ourselves. Its too late. 2nd attempt a couple months later around 10am, crazy long line. Just ran out. With the next year or so, 3rd and 4th attempts at around 9:30 10:30. Long lines still, Sold out still. So we just said maybe its the weekend or were just a little too late. So today we went before it opened and fell in line once again. Only to be told, we dont sell cruffins until 9am. W. T. F.! Probably our fault that we didn't know that. But we bought other pastries before, no mention of they only sell it an hour after opening. They just said they ran out. Plus, why? No logical sense. Til We realized its a B.S. marketing ploy. Never waiting in line there again. Nothing is that good!
author: Jb M.

description:
I can't believe I stood in line for an hour for this TWICE haha. Both times the cruffins were really good! I love that they change the flavors daily (and you can check what the flavors are on their IG).
This is such a cute bakery too, but you can not be in a rush if you want a cruffin. There are 2 lines so if you want a normal baked good (doughnuts, croissants, etc) the wait is much faster. 

Each person is also limited to two cruffins and they have this whole sticker process so you have to get there early to get in line to be guaranteed a cruffin!!! they serve the cruffins at 9am! on weekends I'd say get there at 8am!
author: Emma G.

description:
*** In Short ***

Tasty pastries. Get here early, unless you enjoy slim pickings. Try a cruffin, obviously. Better yet, try it after you've tossed it into a toaster oven!

*** In Depth ***

Cronuts? Never really got into them. I've had a wide range of them by now (albeit not the original), and while some were enjoyable, none ever blew my mind. But, a cruffin? Well. If you like flaky pastries, and you like custard or cream-fillings, then you'll probably like these little dough wrapped bundles of deliciousness.

Everything else? I'd argue the croissants at Neighbor Bakehouse are better, but the other fare that Mr Holmes has to offer is pretty solid. That said, expect cruffins to sell out bright and early, and their other popular pastries to sell out soon after. So, either come early, send out your peons for pastries instead of your morning coffee, or hope you have wonderful early bird friends that'll do it for you.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Small, but mostly accessible. The area in front of the counter forms a narrow space with the opposing wall, and when the place is crowded, you may have to say a few pardons to get through the doorway.

Bathroom - Not sure they even have one for customer use.
author: Johnny W.

description:
If you like baked goods and sweets, don't miss this place. Yes, it's probably slightly over-hyped and over-priced ($3.50 for a donut, $4.50 for a cruffin, and most other pastries), and you'll have to wait in line for an hour to get a cruffin. But it's delicious, and you should check it out at least once. I've now been 3-4 times and I love trying all the new flavors and different pastries that they make.

If you want the highly sought-after cruffins, be prepared to wait in line. The cruffins come out at 9 am, and they only have one flavor of cruffins per day. On the weekends, you'll need to get in line by around 8:15 - 8:30 am in order to get one - they hand out stickers to people around 8:45 to ensure that people aren't holding places in line for multiple people. On the weekdays (or at least on the Friday that I went) you'll need to get in line by around 9:15 or 9:30 to get a cruffin. On the weekends, the cruffin line is separate from the normal line to get the other donuts, so if you have multiple people in your group, you can send someone to get some other baked goods while you wait for the cruffins to come out.

I'm going to be blasphemous and actually admit that I like the donuts the best of everything that they have, even over the cruffins, which is good, because I don't have to fight with the rest of SF in the mornings to get one. 

Here is what I've tried and my thoughts:

- Cruffins ($4.50): This is probably like an 800 calorie bomb, but I suppose every now and again, you have to treat yourself. Imagine a croissant in a popover form, dusted with granulated sugar, and filled with a lot of flavored cream. I've only tried the matcha with dark chocolate cruffin, and it was delicious. Maybe because it was the first time I had ever had a cruffin, but I thought it was the best thing ever. The second cruffin I had was pumpkin spice, which I didn't care for as much -- I usually love everything pumpkin, but I found it to be too sweet and too much cream/filling for my liking.

- Donuts ($3.50) - These are expensive donuts but these are some of the best donuts I've had in SF, especially when you get a filling that is delicious. They are closer to a bomboloni (Italian donut), so it's fluffy and airy, generously stuffed with a cream flavored filling or a fruit jam-like filling. The passionfruit is one of my favorites, with a little bit of tartness to balance out the sweetness. I also really love the blueberry jam one - it wasn't overly sweet, and paired really well with the dough. I recently had the cranberry-orange one, and it was good, but not better than the other 2 I have had.

I've also tried their potato & leek danish, and one of their sweeter danishes, and I prefer the sweeter danishes better. At $4.50 a pop, they are pretty expensive, but nice for a treat once in a while. 

All in all, a bakery worth visiting if you're in the city. Just be prepared to wait in line if you go in the morning, and be prepared to wait around an hour for a cruffin if you go on the weekend. They post flavors once a week on Instagram, so you can see what is worth waiting in line for. They serve cruffins until they are gone, and the rest of the bakery is open until they run out of baked goods, which is usually around 2-3 pm.
author: Christina L.

description: If you love sweets you have to get to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse. I never got here because I always thought it was just a touristy spot for people to take pictures in front of a cool neon sign, but I stood completely corrected after finally getting there recently and trying their donut of the day which was funfetti. It was like a super quality better tasting krispy kreme donut. I have never had a better donut in my life, they are so good. Love the concept of changing the donut and cruffins flavors daily, very smart and keeps me coming. Also love the cruffins, which are croissant muffins. Can get really busy so be prepared to see a line, but don't worry it moves pretty quickly. Go follow @cass.eats on instagram for similar reviews and photos.
author: Cass.eats ..

description:
+ THE FOOD
I'M SO SAD THEY RAN OUT OF CRUFFINS RIGHT WHEN WE GOT INTO THE STORE. But nonetheless, I was able to snatch the last croissant and a cookie before they ran out of everything. The croissant was THE BEST croissant I've ever had. It was nice a flaky and had the perfect buttery taste. It was a bit sweet too as they sprinkled some sugar on top. My friend and I also shared the chocolate chip cookie, which was huge, and it was pretty tasty as well. I'm not usually a fan of chocolate chip but this cookie was worth it. 

- THE WAIT
You have to go super early!! My friend thought that getting there by 10 AM would be good enough, but nope. Everyone who goes early buys boxes and boxes of donuts and cruffins so it would be best to get there at 9 to ensure that you get what you want.
author: Cindy C.

description: Tried the matcha croissant and it was delicious. There was almost no line and staff was polite.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Baker's delight literally.
I wish they make a vegetarian version of the Californian Croissant.
Coz I love savoury Croissant and noone makes them anymore for some reason!
The doughnuts are to die for..And cookies are absolutely chewy they way it's supposed to be!
author: Auroshikha R.

description:
I give the neighborhood this bakery is in 2 stars and the bakery itself 5 stars for making decadent and irresistible pastries! 

It's the second time I've visited Mr. Holmes and it gets better every time with out regretting eating an entire box of pastries. 

Last year I called ahead, and the gentleman was kind enough to set aside a box for me. I prepaid over the phone, picked up the box hours later on - done deal. 

Sometimes it's hard to get up on an early weekend day to be in line, and so this time around I was in line at 8 and purchased Cruffins at 9. Due to the ever growing popularity, only 2 is limited per person to purchase. 

Maybe Mr. Holmes will come up with a similar purchase method like that of Dominique Ansel in the East, where you purchase 2 weeks in advance and can be picked up at the store without bracing the line. 

Anyways, I purchased: Cruffins - Strawberry Milkshake, Filled Donuts - Lemon Poppyseed & Vanilla, Kougin Aman, California Croissant - Salmon, Nori & Ginger, and Turkey Pesto Danish. I brought them to work and my coworkers said their mouths were in heaven. Next time I'll try their Ube Puff and Breadpudding. Their croissant anything are to die for! 

Love, Love, Love!
author: Alex C.

description:
My friend asked me to accompany her in line on a Saturday morning as she waited for Chocolate and Matcha Cruffins. Apparently the line was longer than usual because this cruffin flavor was popular. We waited in line for about 1.5 hours (remember to get into the correct line!) and I would say that although the cruffins themselves were not worth the wait, getting to spend time with my friend made up for this.

Next time, I would not wait for any cruffins and just go straight for the regular bakery line. I ended up ordering four things to fill the rest of the Mr. Holmes box I got with the two cruffins. The pastries were generally too sweet for me (so maybe I will get savory ones next time) but my favorite was probably the pear and blue cheese danish. The bread pudding was too dry, and the spiced bourbon donut was okay. I also got the ube pastry, which was pretty good. As for the cruffin, this was difficult to eat because of the shape of the pastry and the fact that there was so much filling inside.

Great service and delicious pastries. Experience the cruffin wait one time, but one time only... unless you have a lot of time on your hands. A box of pastries from Mr. Holmes would make the perfect present for a friend who has a sweet tooth, but this place is just not for me!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
*Scrolls through Instagram, comes across Mr Holmes "Flavor Updates", pause the world.

MATCHA FLAVORED CRUFFINS ON SATURDAY. Which began the most elaborate planning to make the most out of this cruffin trip. Let's just say, the cruffins did not disappoint.

The giant, crispy bundle of joy was everything I imagined it to be. To start off, the matcha marshmallow was delightful. Not too sweet, but jam packed with matcha. Yum. Then, the first bite. I was in awe. The mix of the matcha cream and the fluffy pastry together was perfect. Again, not too sweet but all around amazing. 

I honestly can not wait to try different flavors. I would get baked everyday if it wasn't so far from work!

P.S. Cruffins start selling at 9AM! They give you a sticker when you're in line to ensure you get your max of 2 cruffins!
author: Winnie I.

description: Cruffin is served daily at 9am. I got in on a Wednesday around 8.30am and waited but there was no line except for me and a group of girls. By 9am, a line about 10 people has formed. I suggest coming here on a weekday if you can if cruffin is what you're after. The cruffin was actually good. The filling for the day was apple and tamarind sauce which I enjoyed. The best part was the bread itself. The croissant dough was crispy and buttery. I suggest you get their croissant instead of falling in line for the cruffin. I particularly don't like jams or fillings. I also tried their donut and I thought it was awful. I ate two bites of it and threw it away. The donut was just lacking in taste. I'll probably just get their plain croissants when I come back. I definitely would not get the cruffin again unless there is no line for it.
author: Carol C.

description:
Not worth the hype/wait. 
I was super excited to visit this place and stock up on some baked goods. 15-20minute wait at 9am. Employees provide rushed service. Very limited bar seating. Most importantly, the cruffins tasted only average. Go to PATESSERIE B and get Quinn Aman instead. They have better service, seating, and baked goods.
author: Loe Y.

description:
YOU MUST COME HERE IF YOU ARE VISITING SAN FRANCISCO. 

Must. 

For the cruffin (croissant muffin), for the California croissant. For the love of humanity. 

Thank God my friends lined up at 8am for it to open (long lines out the door down the block) and gave me half of a cruffin with chocolate peanut butter cream filling -- it was enough for me to love this place. 

Then I had the California croissant! Amazing!!! A croissant with salmon and nori inside?! And dip this in soy sauce?! What is this sorcery. It actually works! The croissant part is not too buttery so it doesn't overpower the filling. It's kinda like a crunchy California roll. 

You can also get a box with your pastries (those boxes are so cute). 

Ube tart was just ok. Get the California croissant and CRUFFIN (if you're line up early enough)!
author: Elsie W.

description: Went for the cruffins which would've probably been perfect except for the filling. That day they had the lemon curd which was still good but for a lemon based filling, I felt it was too thick and rich. I personally like a lighter texture and a more delicate flavor for any lemon based custard/filling. However the croissant itself was amazing so will definitely come back for other flavors!
author: Tomoki T.

description:
Woke up exxxxxtra early this morning for their cruffins and I promise you, I was not disappointed. I had their mango cheesecake cruffin which was just as delicious as it sounds. O had to remove a bit of the custard filling because it felt slightly excessive but if you're into that then the cruffin is just for you! I also got the apple/pumpkin Danish which was just as good (although it tasted more apple-y than pumpkin-y)..

I went around 9 AM and there were about 20-25 people in front of me so I was one of the last people to get a cruffin. So for those of you who want their cruffins, I highly recommend going before then!
author: Marwa N.

description:
I didn't have the traditional Mr Holmes experience because for some (stupid) reason I didn't get a Cruffin. However, I got a basic chocolate croissant and it was SUPERB! I know it doesn't seem that exciting but I haven't had an amazing chocolate croissant since I went to Italy last year and I've been dreaming of eating on ever since I left. Well Mr Holmes does the basic chocolate croissant VERY well! Super flaky, slightly crisp on the outside and soft in the center, with what seemed like a mini chocolate bar inside - a good one!

Even though this place is small and doesn't really have seating it's worth a stop in! It's designed super well and the workers were friendly and quick. The line wasn't too long when I went (Sunday mid-morning.. granted it WAS raining) and it moved pretty quickly.

Coffee wasn't bad.. but it was no Four Barrel, Blue Bottle, etc. (it would be great if they served a local brand).

Next Time.... a Cruffin!
author: Kerry H.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday morning around 10am (when I should have been in at work) and there was still a huge line! You can actually cut the line if you are not about the cruffins, but you really should always be about them. 

That day, I had the chocolate earl grey cruffin, California roll, and chocolate croissant. I shared a little with my friend to feel less like a fatso. The earl grey cruffin was delicious. Good texture and fluff and literally melted in my mouth. I didn't realize the California roll has like actual fish and nori. It was rather strange for me and I think I'd prefer those ingredients with rice instead of buttery bread, but I'd probably eat it again.
author: Juliana P.

description:
Last summer my pal, Abby S, and I were chatting. I asked what she was going to do on a day off and her response was: 'crruuuufffffinnnnsss (with a photo.) I was drooling for 2.5 months until I met up with her and got to try one (or 2) for myself.

We trekked over at 9am on a Friday and only had to wait 10ish minutes. The staff seemed resilient to being always busy and were still kind and graceful when answering my questions. Inside the space was small but manageable for me to go through with my sweet chunky baby in his stroller. 

Now listen... I'm a cronut kind of girl (and still am!) Those close to me were skeptical if I could L-O-V-E a pastry as much. The cruffin held up to 'memorable/unique/iconic pastry' like the cronut. Beautifully crispy yet soft. Make sense? Not too sweet - but jjjuuussstttt right. Paired with their coffee... I was in baked heaven.
author: Sarah M.

description:
While on my trip to SF, I managed to get cruffins twice over a four-day span. 

WEEKEND CRUFFINS
* The flavors change almost daily, and they post flavor updates on Sunday afternoon/nights on Facebook and Instagram. 
* The line will start on the left hand side of the store entrance, and the line for regular pastries will be on the right.
We were able to snag four chocolate passion fruit cruffins (2 per person) on a Sunday morning, standing in line around 8:10 AM. If you arrive in line anytime before 8:30-8:45, you should be able to get some cruffins.
The hybrid of croissant and muffin is perfect. I have had Dominique Ansel's cronut, and I did not enjoy the filling as it was too sweet. I preferred the cruffin because it was crispy and crunchy throughout and the sweetness of the filling was just right. The best way to eat this? Sit down, have a lot of napkins ready to catch all of the sugar that will fall, and take pieces from the top in a roundabout fashion to eat this pastry efficiently!

WEEKDAY CRUFFINS
On a Tuesday morning, the flavor was carrot cake. It was probably not as popular of a flavor, so when we arrived around 8:15, there was literally no line. We returned around 9:00 and there were only ~10 people in front of us, lining up to the right hand side of the entrance.
The cinnamon flavors from the carrot cake were pretty strong, so after awhile we took some of the filling out of the pastry, enjoying the outside and dabbing it with the filling. 

pastries
+ AMELIE AMAN: This is similar to the DKA from Dominique Ansel, but crunchier and more dense. I am totally a fan! It is buttery, crunchy, and full of flavor without extra sugar or flavors! It is classic and perfect.
+ CALIFORNIA CROISSANT: This is my favorite savory croissant. The croissants here are literally perfect. It's airy, but so crunchy on the outside, and doesn't leave croissant flakes everywhere. It keeps its shape as you eat it, with large flakes that come off so that you can continue to eat it. Some think this is too salty with the salmon and nori, but I thought it was just right. There is only a little right in the middle of the croissant, but it is enough flavor to sustain the entire pastry. They also give you a soy sauce packet but you don't need it!
+ STRAWBERRY DONUT: The flavors of the donuts change daily, posted on their Instagram and Facebook along with the cronut flavors. The donut is like a cloud pillow in your mouth.  It's so soft!  Then, it comes with so much filling, but it's not overly sweet! I don't like jelly-filled donuts, but this was more like a subtly sweet, strawberry cream filled donut.
~ BREAD PUDDING: This is dense. I lifted it and it had to be a good 2 lbs. by itself. This is really moist and filled with too many raisin for my own taste.
~ CHOCOLATE COOKIE: This cookie is huge! It is loaded with chocolate on top and inside the cookie. Although we had this cold, I wouldn't say the cookie is something to come back for.
author: Sophie P.

description: The Cruffin is worth getting up and waiting in line for. One of the best pastries in SF!
author: Jocelyn E.

description:
I finally got my hands on a cruffin this past weekend. I arrived around 9 AM on a Saturday and there was already a long line outside. I was a bit worried I wouldn't be able to get a cruffin. However, someone comes out and passes out stickers to ensure that you'll be able to get some cruffins. I like that they have this sticker system because you know you'll get able to get a cruffin for sure. The maximum number of cruffins per person is 2.

The cruffin is truly worth the wait. It is not sweet at all so you won't get sick of it. It is super flaky and crispy on the outside with the perfect amount of sugar sprinkled on top. I tried the Snickers cruffin and it was perfect. The cream inside the cruffin was not overly sweet or overbearing. It tastes and feels like a crossiant and has the shape of a muffin.

I've tried their other pastries and haven't been disappointed yet. I like their cream-filled donuts, especially the pumpkin spice! Their bread pudding is also exceptional.

It is a small shop, but the line goes by quick. There is a lot of street parking available.
author: Gina H.

description: Good customer service. Knowledgeable staff. Short line on a rainy Saturday. The cruffin with peanut butter was not impressive at all. The croissants were not crispy and chewy soft inside. Just dense dough for me. The strawberry with jalapeno tart was interesting. Their pastry does not equal to mantras or Bouchon. Their pastry box is the best!
author: Kitty D.

description:
Late morning on a weekday there was a short line.

Weekends people line down the street to spend $50 on a box of pastries?

Well, right it must be good because everyone else is doing it. No?

No. No donut is worth $3.50. But, you know if it was the identical donut sold for $2.00 there would not be a line down the street in a crappy neighborhood.

The pastries are carefully made. And, they are nice. But, it's a fad. It is another four dollar toast.

Lemmings.
author: BigJohnS F.

description:
Got there half an hour before opening and saw people in line already. I was expecting to grab some cruffins and go within 40 minutes. Unfortunately I didn't realize they don't sell cruffins during the first hour. *annoyed*

Forty minutes go by and a worker comes out to notify the line that the daily flavor is lemon poppy. *disappointed as I was hoping for matcha or something else I'd prefer* 

Long story short, biting into that cruffins was a heavenly experience! I definitely enjoyed the lemon filling much more than I was expected! I also got some other baked goodies, which were great as well. 

It's on the pricey side IMO, but to be fair, I'm new to the Bay Area/city. I would definitely come back for the regular pastries. If I had to wait in that line again for the cruffins, I would definitely have to bring someone else along for some company, and also to snatch their cruffin virginity!
author: Eric N.

description:
are you a fan of pastries? then i think you'll love this place! my friends decided to wait in line for 2 hours to be the first ones to order cruffins haha. they also bought other pastries too. the cruffin flavor of the day was strawberry milkshake. it tasted really good, super sweet and filling. it would've been nice if they used a fresh strawberry instead of a dried strawberry.

the smoked salmon, gunger, wasabi, and nori croissant sounds really weird but it actually tasted okay. (i'm not a fan of wasabi or ginger) it was like eating sushi inside a croissant.

the ube puff and the brown ale onion danish were pretty good too.

i personally didn't like the strawberry japaleno brioche bread. i thought it was kind of disgusting. i don't understand why they would mix strawberry with something spicy?! it makes no sense to me.

i've also tried le donut (forgot which flavor) before. and i would say that my top picks are the cruffin and le donut. i personally wouldn't wait in line for more than an hour for pastries but i must admit that the pastries here are pretty good. they're definitely better than Tartine Bakery & Cafe.
author: Sylvia H.

description:
I had a stollen for $3.50 and it was pretty good. I definitely would've thought a stollen + cup of coffee would have been perfect. I was disappointed when I went around 10AM on a Thursday and there was no cruffins available. The entire experience was good though. Staff is super friendly and gave good suggestions and happy to answer any questions.

There's seating for only two-three people, but the place was clean and decorative plus good music in the background. 

My friend got a sweet onion danish and he thought it was just okay/tasted a little stale.
author: Mimi T.

description: One of the best and the wait isn't too bad. I question some of the donut flavors they come up with but hooray for creativity. Keep doing what you're doing!
author: Nasrin M.

description: Amazing pastries! The best one we had was the Cookie Dough pastry- it has a thin chocolate chip cookie baked on top of it and the most delicious pastry cream inside with nibs of chocolate. Their signature "cruffin" was also very good.
author: Marisa S.

description:
I came at 11 and everything was gone I purchased the last item! It was disgusting!!

I spend $5 on this piece of crap!!
I def would try to come again for the better pieces but they sell out so quick! 
The store was very cute 
Service was great but I was very disappointed in them and I drove all the way from Sacramento for these !
author: S T.

description:
Ok, so I finally tried Mr Holmes a couple months ago.  I was born a sweet tooth; therefore, you should take this review seriously. 

I tried the following: 

- Blood orange cruffins 
- Chocolate and Strawberry filled donuts 
- Strawberry Jalapeño Croissant

And some others but, cannot recall their names.. :/ 

LOVED their cruffins. HEAVEN ON EARTH. If they had more I would have gotten 3 cruffins and called it a day, unfortunately they only had one left when I got there at 9 am on a Thursday :( 

So, go early and go on a weekday if you don't want to stand in line. Call in sick from work if you have to! But, Mr. Holmes is a must try bakehouse.
author: Reet R.

description:
YOU HAVE TO STOP BY MR HOLMES NO MATTER HOW LONG THE WAIT IS!! 

While we were in San Fransisco my friend and I were walking out of our hotel to find some where to eat breakfast we walked by Mr Holmes and saw two ridiculous long lines from both sides of their door. We were so confused as to why there were so many people and what they were waiting for....we got the name of the place and left. After reading all the reviews we decided to head on over the next next day for breakfast.  

They opened at 9am however there were lines before that. On one side there is a cruffin line (which we didn't make it in time for they only make a certain amount and hand out stickers for the people that are getting some for sure that day) but that's okay because we just stood in the other line which is for pastries. 

We waited about an hour in line and finally made it into the store to order....at that point we said yolo and ordered everything that we thought looked good. For a box of pastries and two coffees we spent about $30. 

Man oh man was the wait and cost SOOOOO worth it. Honestly the best pastries we have ever had. Wish we could have tried the cruffins but we will for sure next time we are in town. 

We got two donuts one was strawberry filled and the other was like a key lime pie fill. I usually don't like filled donuts but these two changed my mind...you could tell that they had just made the filling so fresh and light.

You have to have to get a Choux Bomb oh. my. goodness. I never knew something could taste this great. Seriously this is a game changer for pastries. If I could eat this every single day of my life I would. 

Every single thing we had was so fresh and wonderful. This place meet and exceeded our expectations!  

They sure know what they are doing!! A must stop in San Francisco!! Can't wait to go back!
author: Batul A.

description:
I had a friend a couple of months ago who stood in line and got some cruffins. She had one left, so she dropped by after work and gave it to me.  The cruffin was good - kind of what I expected crossiant like texture in the shape of a muffin...which actually makes it kind of hard to eat. 

Then I was able to wake up early one morning and finally got a cruffin. Well two since I'm allowed to get 2.  To get the cool box, I needed to buy 4 more items so I ordered 2 donuts, a california croissant, and the bread pudding.  

Let's start with the thing everyone (or at least almost everyone) comes here for - the cruffins. They're what people will wait an hour in line for and there's so many pictures on instagram.  It's good, is it worth waiting an hour in line? Sure, why not. With a good friend and some great conversation it'll go by quickly.  The outside is crunchy and sugary and the inside has a great flavoring. I had the cookies and cream and I definitely enjoyed it.  Would love to try the matcha one though - probably will check their instagram for the flavors and try the matcha ones! 

The California croissant was interesting - salmon wrapped in seaweed in croissant. Delicious to say the least. Probably the most creative and croissant there. Would definitely go back to get those (since there really isn't line for the other baked goods). 

The donuts - well mine was filled with pomegranate and the other flavor was white chocolate. The donut was okay.  The filling (like someone else said) was very custard tasting. I didn't really taste the pomegranate - it was just all around sweet instead of a little tart like I would expect a pomegranate to taste. 

The bread pudding, I only ended up having half of it to share with my roommates, but it was pretty good. Filled with chocolate and dried cranberries, topped with powdered sugar and some caramel, it was dense sweet and like a bread pudding should be. 

Overall, I did get some delicious pastries. Would I stand back in line? Maybe with some friends if they wanted to get some. It's quite a difficult thing to eat and created a definite sugar overload for me, but an experience nonetheless. 

Protip: Get there early if you want a cruffin - probably at least half an hour early. I got there an hour early - just as they were opening the regular bakery and I was #5 in line! California croissant is unique and something people should try!
author: Nina Y.

description:
I am a fan of the cruffin! However I do believe this place can be over hyped. My boyfriend and I arrived around 8:40 am and the line was okay. They start serving cruffins at 9 am. We made it in at 9:20ish. The cruffins are pretty expensive and can get messy when youre eating it.

BE SURE to get napkins if you bought the cruffins! Its gonna get messy!
author: Karen T.

description:
The first time I tried Mr Holmes was when my sister picked up a box for our family. Unfortunately, they were sold out of cruffins that day! But she brought back a box of other baked goods. OMG- the Peanut Butter filled Donut!!! That is probably the best thing I've had at Mr Holmes Bakehouse!

I really made the effort one Friday morning to go to Mr Holmes for their famous cruffins and there was already a line out the door. Me & my brother got a little cray cray and might have gone overboard! We got our hands on a couple of their pumpkin cruffins, green tea donuts, and I think one of everything else they were serving that day LOL! Everything was really tasty!!! It adds up though money wise and cannot be good for this "diet" that I always claim to be on! 

I came here a another time on a Saturday w/ one of my girlfriends who has never been here. It was later on a Saturday afternoon.. I want to say around 2pm ish? There was no line and everything was nearly sold out which was a bummer! 

So definitely come early if you want the cruffins & check for their weekly flavor updates!
author: Michelle L.

description: I don't really understand the hype of this place. My chocolate croissant tasted the equivalent of one I get at Starbucks except at Starbucks mine comes out warm and it isn't a hassle. The famous sign was broken which was also a bummer. I don't see why anyone would go out of their way to come here because the food was mediocre and it is not located in a good or safe area.
author: Jasmyn F.

description: Yo. This place is BOMB. Everyone is talking about the cruffin but its MORE THAN THAT. Everything is freaking amazing!!! The croissants are crispy yet layered and also moist. The buttery taste is just uplifting. Their matcha is also superior, which is why I need a matcha cruffin. They change their menu everyday and I only tried the blueberry white chocolate and already it was just omg. Go here!!! Worth the wait!!!
author: Jasmina D.

description:
I know San Francisco loves itself some foodie hype. Every day another article comes out about the next best thing on the foodie scene. When my birthday rolled around my dear thoughtful husband went in the wee hours of the morning to secure himself/myself their famous cruffins. 

The rule states that you can only have two per person. The lines can be long. And there are only so many cruffins made per day. He won. He came home with two cruffins and an array of other treats. 

My verdict? The lemony cruffins were meh. Nothing to really write home about and certainly nothing to wait in lines for. The bread pudding and the ferrer roche tingy were the standouts and definitely in this fattys opinion worth more than the fancy cruffins.
author: Michelle I.

description:
This place rocks and is worth the wait!  Too bad you're only limited to 2 cruffins per person.  That day, the flavor was coconut pineapple which is delicious.  My only comment is to possibly incorporate the coconut into the pineapple filling.  Otherwise, it was just toasted coconut on top.  I can't wait to try their matcha filled cruffins!

Their other offerings are delicious as well.  The POG donut reminded me of Leonard's malasadas.  The Ube pastry was spot on and the prickly pear icing was a good juxtaposition to the filling.  That reminded me of an adult Pop tart!  Their bread pudding was ok, if a bit too dense though.
author: Gene D.

description:
Donuts are gross. NOT HERE! Omg I could not stop eating these fluffy donuts with light, airy chocolate stuff in the middle and crunchy sugar around the outside ughhhh so good. Can't believe I'm saying that. 

Unfortunately, sold out of cronut things by 10am so didn't get to enjoy those.
author: Lynne M.

description: Just stopped by their LA location too and it's beautiful! This place is so good
author: Avery D.

description: Delicious Croissants! (Certified by French friends!) The lines can be long on the weekends but worth the wait
author: Camille H.

description: So small, but so great. I often buy the croissants for the office and the shop is precious! Just wish they had more gluten-free options.
author: Kira G.

description:
I'm caught in between my review because I'm so happy I finally got come but then I'm slightly disappointed that I couldn't get what I wanted which is their famous cruffins :(

But it's fine because I bought an assortment of five: Salted Caramel Donut, Walnut Fig Tart, Bread Pudding muffin, Berry Cheesecake Tart, Apple Scone.

All five were amazing and freshly made when we arrived at the bakery which is even better. Prices were from $4-6 each which is great for what they are. My favorite was their walnut fig tart pastry because it wasn't too sweet and it's flavors were pronounced. The walnut gave texture while the fig gave an extra boost for the flavor. I suggest buying a box with an assortment rather than individual orders because it's totally worth trying a variety. 

The employees are friendly and helpful. No matter how stuck you get with trying to figure out what to get, they will help you decide and also explain a little about the pastry. They're organized, shop is clean and simple, and prices are great!

I will be coming back for their famous cruffins and will be writing a new update for them.
author: Allister D.

description:
Wanted a Cruffin because I heard so much smack about 'em only to find out that they had sold out - probably even before I stood in their 20 minute line. Note to self and anyone else that reads this review, pop you're head in if you really want a Cruffin. Then determine how many they have left. Ask everyone in line if they are getting one, two or if they plan to be a glutton and are gonna get a bakers dozen.  They have a stack of their to-go boxes covering their inventory from the street view. I'm convinced that if they had it exposed, people would walk on knowing they were out of Cruffins. 

Review of the 5 items I did get.  Best item, the Pastrami and sauerkraut croissant. Wasn't expecting this but if was really good. Not too overpowering with the kraut, tender pastrami, nice Russian dressing and cheese. 

Artichoke-feta croissant was good.  Although I would not order again. Just not that memorable for me. 

Gotta chocolate chip cookie that had a dusting with sugar and sea salt. Delicious. 

Bread pudding. Nicely done - moist with good flavor. 

Filled Cardamom donut or malasada. I forget what they called them. Pastry cream was good. But I was expecting a stronger cardamom flavor. It just tasted of vanilla to me.
author: Tony A.

description: I know everyone stands in line for the limited cruffins but when we went, the Lemon Cheesecake donut stole the show for us. We got the max 2 cruffins per person and filled out box with some other delicious pastries. The line was not too long on a Friday morning at 9 and we were happy to have a nice selection to choose from. The croissants were nice and flakey with a bit of sweetness that our daughter loved. The cruffins were delicious but by the time we were able to finish all four of them at the end of the day, they were a bit soggy. However, still delicious. I would say that everything is a bit on the sweet side!
author: Megan S.

description: Came here yesterday morning after an interview, to kill time and try the infamous cruffin. Waited in line maybe 20 minutes after getting there at 9am (but felt longer because it was freezing!) and met some people from Iowa in line who had heard about the place through Pinterest. Ended up getting the gingerbread donut, carrot cruffin and a chocolate donut. I'm not usually one for sweets or gluten, especially in the morning, but ended up taking a dive into the cruffin around lunch time and to my surprise it was actually not bad. It's not as buttery as a Costco croissant but nice and flakey on the outside and moist on the inside with the custard adding a nice touch to the overall experience of this tasty treat. It wasn't overly sweet, which I appreciated, and kept me satisfied well into dinnertime. Overall, aside from waiting in line, I'd say the visit was well worth it.
author: Massiel S.

description: Wow, Mr. Holmes did not  disappoint! Best bakery by far for custom sweets. You can tell they put a LOT  of thought and love into their amazing creations. If you have a sweet tooth hurry up and get down here- you will be very happy you did, and it will definitely get your day off to a SWEET start!
author: B A.

description:
MEH. I decided to finally give this place a try given all the hype around the "I got baked in SF." I heard that the lines were not so great, so decided to take advantage of a random Tuesday morning to buy goods. I'm also constantly amazed by how people in San Francisco have time to wait in line on the weekdays. Like why aren't they at work? These are the questions I ponder when I'm standing in a line alone at 8:50 waiting for the magical cruffins to be sold.

Given that it was a weekday morning, the wait really wasn't too bad at all -- I was in and out in probably 20 minutes from my initial arrival time. I got the Cruffin, amelie amann, strawberry jelly donut, and choux bomb as per what everyone has recommended on Yelp. My thoughts:

Cruffin -- meh. Overly sweet, not about it. Not sure what I was really expecting in terms of texture. Just tasted more croissant than muffin to me. 

Jelly donuts -- good, but also overly sweet. Donut texture was wonderful though.

Mama X took the amelie amann and choux bomb from me without letting me try a bite though -- she spoke highly of the amelie amann, but I think it's just because it was the only thing that I got her that was pretty minimalist and not filled to the brim with some sort of cream or anything. Apparently it was crystallized sugar and a slightly charred bottom and creamy croissant-buttery goodness. She highly recommends. Choux bomb was unmemorable.

A box here contains 6 pastries, fyi if you want it for your instagame. The people here were a bit sassy with me because I was trying to buy two separate things for two different people and I got sassed out for not filling one of the boxes with 6 pastries. oops. Sorry not sorry. Service could be a little more polite given that we're waiting in line for your not super delicious goods, but not a huge deal.

tl;dr overall, decent pastries and to be fair I can't think of any famous pastry place to rave about (maybe Tartine, but these two are playing in really different pastry markets) so it's unique -- I think it's creative and enjoy the ingenuity, but I found that most of the pastries here were of the creamy filled variety whereas I prefer more pure pastries that are less sweet
author: Jasmine X.

description: This stop was everything I could have hoped for. I tried the apple pie monkey bread (DELISH!) I was visiting the city and looking for a quick bite with full flavor; the bakeshop did not disappoint! Great friendly staff to boot!
author: Olivia D.

description:
I went here today (Thursday) and waited for about 20 minutes when I arrived at 8:45am. 

I was only planning to get a cruffin and a coffee, but waiting in line for places always makes me end up buying more than I planned. I bought a cruffin, chocolate croissant and savory pastry.

The cruffin was good (I believe it was mocha filling) like an extra crunchy croissant with a soft inside. I was overall pretty happy with It, but if I had to wait for longer than 30 minutes I probably would think it's not worth it.

The savory pastry was okay. It didn't taste that fresh but the flavor were pretty good. 

I haven't tried the chocolate croissant but it was the last one so I'm assuming it's pretty good.

I have to give this place props for their branding. The boxes, bags and decor of the bake house is sure to draw foodies in.
author: Rachel D.

description: Oooooooh baby this place did not disappoint. I found it on some fashion blogger's Instagram and it looked like something we couldn't pass up. We debated leaving once we saw the line however because we figured it would take over 30 minutes. The line moves quickly though and we were glad we endured because the food was worth the wait. My dad and I both got the churro croissant and it was so yummy. Perfectly flaky and mmm just delicious. The store is quite small and loud, but it's fun to get a picture in front of the "I got baked in San Francisco" sign. A must when visiting the city!!
author: Lauren S.

description:
"The hype was definitely there. Tons of elements played on it - the interior neon lights, the upbeat staff, stylish paper bags and boxes pastries were presented in. Our experience is so much more than just the taste; Mr. Homes Bakehouse capitalizes on the whole package."
"California Croissant had a curious combination of ginger and wasabi along with salmon. It was a bit spicy which was perfect to kick off the morning."
"Slowly peeling off the layers of goodness and licking off the jam was a delightful way to consume it. We thought, one cruffin was enough for two of us."

Just a few bites from our full experience review..
author: IS Palette S.

description:
This time my co-worker bought a whole box of goodies from this place. 2 weeks ago i bit into a cream filled donut and there was a long hair inside. Today my coworker wanted to share with me. I cut a little piece of her muffin and thought hey sometimes that does happen, so maybe this time there wouldnt be. Yes it was good, but nothing special about it. My little piece from the muffin didnt have hair and I ate it until I hear my co-worker goes, "Eww there's a hair in my muffin."

Im thinking shes kidding, then i see it and go wow WHAT THE!!!!

I could have sworn the owner replied to me saying they have made changes to ensure this doesnt happen again. 2weeks later it happens again! How would you feel to line up for a long time, buy these over hyped/over priced pastries and to find out there is a disgusting piece of hair threaded in the pastry, not once but twice! What is going on guys. The hair was threaded through the muffin again, so for sure it was during the process of baking. Sorry to be so harsh but its so disappointing and annoying to have it happened twice. Ok for sure i will not try this place again.
author: Ledam O.

description:
Insta-famous, slightly gooey, sweet pastries with an edge. This is one way to describe Mr. Holmes, though I expected a magnifying glass and trench coats al la Sherlock Holmes. 

Their cruffins, an exclusive experience, is nothing short of amazing. The rotating flavors of cruffins is what brings people back. It's an enjoyable feat, though not quite an experience because they lack tables and chairs. The store size is mediocre at best and coffee is not something they socialize in. But not all hope is gone! They do interact with their fans through social media, and post sporadic, mostly random thoughts with pictures of their perfect creations.

In actuality, I do think them serving cruffins at 9am when their bakery opens at 8am is a bit of overkill to make people wait in lines. A bit elitist if I must judge, because it's just pastries after all. And b. Pattiserie is absolute perfection already. Why must we wait for cruffins with the ridiculous stickers and quantity limit?
author: Jennifer N.

description:
This was truly an experience. Totally made my Saturday morning!!
-Bacon caramel morning bun: perfect sticky not too sweet glaze, loved this one.
-California Croissant: flaky croissant with a surprise in the center of smoked salmon wrapped in nori, also loved.
-Cruffin of the day: cookies&cream, again not too sweet and overall amazing texture with the crispy flaky shell and light cookie creme on the inside, liked this one lots.
-Brioche Bun with coconut thai toppings was good but all the excitement was on the top, otherwise a standard bun.
-Powder sugared pumpkin bread with squash: wasnt super thrilled with this compared to the other goodies but I have to give credit for the luxurious texture of this bread
author: Lisa K.

description:
They say the third time's the charm. I've ventured here three times to try their famous cruffins. The first time, I got in line at 8:45 am and was too late. The second time, their oven broke. And the third time, I was finally in luck. Because I've been here three times, I've tried a lot of their baked goods. I've tried the matcha doughnut, blood orange doughnut, lemon poppyseed doughnut, peanut butter and coconut doughnut (+ two other flavored doughnuts that I can't remember the name of), ham and cheese danish, mushroom danish, ferrero roche choux bombs, california sushi croissant, amelie amann, french toast grilled cheese, and finally, the chocolate cointreau cruffins.

My take on their pastries are that the dough here is REALLY good. The cruffins are perfectly doughy and flakey and the doughnuts are soft and chewy. However, what lacks for me is the flavor of the fillings. All of their fillings just taste like custard. I felt that way with their matcha flavor, their chocolate cointreau flavor, and peanut butter and coconut flavor. Being Japanese, I was especially upset about the how lacking their matcha flavor was! Whatever I ate was just custard dyed green. Their citrus-flavored items (blood orange and lemon poppyseed) were better. The tangy and the sourness shined through the sweet, which I liked. 

You can't go wrong with anything here. But with my track record, I would skip any of the flavors that is mixed with custard. For some reason none of them turned out flavorful.

Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is a great bakery, and such a fantastic addition to the neighborhood. Check their instagram for flavor updates of the week every Sunday. If you are going to wait in line for the cruffins, line up by 8:30 am.
author: Hana K.

description: good pastries, but overpriced and always a line.  Didn't get the cruffins as they ran out.  I guess that's supply and demand.  Cute box they pack 6 or more pastries into.
author: Lily L.

description: I'm a student here in SF and I went to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse last semester. The whole summer I spent out of town and on a no carbs diet. The whole summer all I could think about was the matcha croissant I had here. I'm back for the fall semester and tomorrow is cheat day. The pastries here are amazing. The peach cheesecake jelly doughnut is a show stopper. The line is too long but you will wait anyway and love it.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
I can't even..........

Came here Saturday morning still drunk from the night before and waited in line from 8am to 9:20am. Smart? No. Worth it? Absolutely!

What I ordered:
Dark Chocolate Matcha Cruffins - ho-ly-fuk. First bite was THE BEST! Not much of a pastry gal, but the flakiness + the sweetness + the creaminess of the filling make life just gravy :) I probably wouldn't wait in line again for these, but worth trying once in your life.
California Croissant - probably my FAVORITE thing here. Croissant filled with cooked smoked salmon wrapped in nori (seaweed). It sounds weird, but this savory bundle of joy works so well. I'd definitely go back again, and again for these alone.
Chocolate Chip Cookie - I LOVEE hard cookies! Buttery perfection I tell ya..

I also tried 3 different danishes that were just as good as everything described above. All in all, I'd say Mr Holmes really lives up to its hype. Yes, guys.. #HYPEISREAL

Tip: If you come with a group of people I highly recommend taking turn in getting your other pastries first in the shorter line instead of waiting until after you get the cruffin couz there's a rush to the other line after.
author: Anna M.

description:
I went to the bakery today (Aug,9th) around 10:30 am.  I was really excited to try the pastry but walked away disappointed by the service.  I am really surprised on how bad the service was given this is such a popular place.  The man behind the counter was extremely unhelpful and rude.

When I walked in, there were only a few customers in front of me.  When it was my turn, I walked up to the counter but the guy had a blank face, did not greet me or asked me what I wanted.  So I told him my order (two cheese and ham croissants), then he asked me "What do you want?" I repeated it again and he also again asked what do I want.  I then added two more Kouign Amann by pointing at the items.  I thought it was very clear because I told him what I wanted and pointed to the items.  He then again asked what do I want with a blank facial expression.

Finally, I had enough.  I said "never mind" and walked away.  It wasn't until I started to walk away that the man said "I am sorry".   By then it was too little too late.  I will not return in the future.
author: YK C.

description:
Cruffins, jelly donuts, chocolate croissants - all worth the wait. 

Granted, if you arrive right at 9 am when the infamous muffin/croissant hybrids go on sale, there's about a 10-15 minute queue. Compared to other long lines in San Francisco for sweet treats (I'm looking at you Bi-Rite!), this ain't so bad. 

Flaky, sweet dough. Ooey gooey jelly. Melt in your mouth chocolate. I'd go back right now if I could.

Is it safe to say that Mr Holmes' cruffins and the "I Got Baked in San Francisco" neon wall are one of the most commonly Instagrammed things and places right now? Does anyone have the analytics on that?
author: Abby S.

description:
AMAZING.

I know this place has been overly hyped and istagrammed but in my opinion, they absolutely live up to the hype. Their cruffins are seriously to die for, don't know about the wait though. Every time I tell others about their sweet buttery goodness, I feel like a drooling overweight child. 

Recently, they've also partnered with UberEATs to deliver donuts on Wednesdays. IMO, genius. Still waiting for the day we can get cruffins on demand...
author: Becky M.

description:
First things first: Each person is only allowed 2 cruffins. Cruffins are served at 9am and flavors change daily. If you go on a weekday get there by 8ish and on the weekend, before 8. Plan accordingly because they only make a certain amount of cruffins per day. If you snooze, you lose! Don't be that person. There is no limit on other pastries. 

On the the pastries! My first cruffin in life was the tirsmisu. I am not a big fan of tiramisu but it was good. Nice and cripsy on the outside and soft on the inside. It is pretty sweet since the cruffin is coated in sugar but when you mixed it with cruffin filling inside, it is phenomenal. On my second visit, I had the caramel popcorn cruffin and I liked it better than the tiramisu one due to my flavor preference. It makes me really sad that you can only get 2 at a time but I assume it's for quality purposes and I respect that! The filled donuts are pretty good too, however, they are super sweet as it is also coated in sugar. I also got the california roll croissant and that was delicious! It is seaweed, salmon, ginger(?), n a hint of wasabi inside of a croissant. They even give you soy sauce to eat it with. 

It's so easy to drop a good $20-$30 here but it's good and I don't mind at all! The line and wait is worth it!

Follow @mrholmesbakehouse on Instagram and Facebook for weekly flavor updates.
author: Brigitte M.

description: Relatively short wait on a Saturday morning, which was a plus! We got a selection of croissants, donuts, and a couple other pastries. I'm glad we tried the matcha croissants, but the donuts were absolutely amazing! Definitely will be back - and next time, we're trying the cruffins!
author: Priya B.

description: Oh I finally did it! Waiting in line for the most famous cruffins! Today's filling flavor is ginger and grapefruit, at first I thought it will be weird but it's not! It's different and I really digs how it's not overly sweet. It's worth the wait!
author: Gabriella S.

description:
Got there around 8:30 today and ordered a dozen of assorted pastries for our team at the hotel. BUT LOOK! A piece of hair in my muffin! It's still threaded through a piece of my muffin! 

I should have known better, my coworker already warned me of hair in her pastry last time..

Also, I don't see what the hype is all about, I just bit into a mouthful of butter. Brb, gonna throw up now..
author: Vanessa Y.

description: Rose champagne donut was delightful. I was lucky to be there at opening time but there was still a regular line.
author: Rocio H.

description: After 2 years I finally visited the bakery... In pictures the bakery looks really big but it's small and hidden on the side of the building. My boyfriend and I ordered 2 of almost everything. The total came out to almost $60 but we got 14 pieces of bread... We tried the croissants and it was really good. I especially like the matcha green tea one.
author: Monique T.

description:
Bought a Strawberry Rhubarb Donut, a Vanilla Toffee Donut, an Ube Puff, a Caramel Sticky Bun, a Kouign Amann, and 2 Lemon Meringue Cruffins. I spent around $30 for all the pastries listed above and I'd have to say, it wasn't worth it. In all honesty, if I could redo my order, I would only buy the Strawberry Rhubarb Donuts or just the donuts in general. Everything else was okay, so I wouldn't pay $2.50+ each for everything else. 

We went on a Thursday morning and the line for the cruffins started at around 8:30am. We were second ones in line. There is a limit of 2 cruffins per person. They started selling the cruffins at 9:00am. I believe they were $4.50 each.

From most favorite to least favorite it would be Strawberry Rhubarb Donut, Vanilla Toffee Donut, Kouign Amann, Caramel Sticky Bun, Lemon Meringue Cruffin, and Ube Puff. Their donuts are soft, which is probably why I enjoyed them so much. The Kouign Amann basically just tasted like a croissant with a hint of caramel to me, so nothing too exciting, but still good. The Caramel Sticky Bun was also good, but I liked the center of the bun more than the outside of the bun because the caramel made the outside a bit hard. I didn't really enjoy the Lemon Meringue Cruffin because of the flavor itself. It was a bit too sour for my taste, so I just ate around the filling. The Ube Puff was definitely my least favorite. There was some type of pink icing on top and I just thought it didn't taste good. My boyfriend thought the same thing, so we didn't finish this one. 

Overall, I probably wont be standing in line for another cruffin. If I want to cash out on some donuts i'd go here, but i'm sure a regular ol' donut shop would do.
author: Heather R.

description:
Waking up early on a weekend has never been so rewarding. 

Came here on a Sunday (after the cruffins were sold out) to pick up some of the regular pastries. We ended up getting a box; which is 6 or more pastries; and good thing we did! They definitely didn't last long. We got donuts, croissants, California croissant, sticky bun, and a danish. The donuts changed my life as I have never like donuts before. I wasn't a fan of the sticky bun but everything else was awesome. The prices are very reasonable for the quality of the pastries. I believe it was only $24 for a box of 6 pastries. 

I ended up coming back last weekend to try the cruffin and it was well worth the wait. We arrived at 8am to grab a box of regular pastries, then proceeded to get in line for the cruffins around 8:15am. There were not many people ahead of us so we knew we would get our cruffins. Around 8:50 an employee passed out the hot pink stickers ensuring we would get our cruffins. At 9am sharp, the cruffins were brought out. You get your cruffins and pay right there on an ipad. It was quick and simple. We went to a local coffee shop near by to sit down and enjoy our treats. The flavor that day was peach cheesecake and it did not disappoint. 

If you're big on pastries this is the place for you.
author: Lindsey L.

description:
So much hype. So much worth.

Shoutout to the Jamster for living so close Mr. Holmes, I didn't even have to wake up at 7am to try and get some cruffins. I think they got there at 9 and at first were told that they were out, but then they found like 5 more lying around somewhere so we got 2 without waking up super early!!! Pro-tip: be friends with Jammy. We also got a chocolate croissant, some Ube thing that I didn't get to try, and one other thing I forget.

The cruffins though. The star of the show. I think we had a mint chocolate flavor. There was cream on the top of the muffin with a giant square marshmallow. Biting into the cruffin, the layers were fluffy and dusted with sugar, just moist enough and so good. The best part, there was filling inside!! I didn't know that these cruffins had filling before so it was a really nice surprise. The cream was a light chocolatey cream with hints of mint, not overpowering in any way. Sooo good. Sooo down to go back and try more cruffins. Jime pls come thru.
author: Jenn L.

description:
Coming from New York, I've been to crazy places like Dominique Ansel for their famous cronuts so when visiting SF, I made sure I got a hold of these Cruffins... Oh man, it was heavenly good and well worth the wait! 

From reading the Yelp reviews, most ppl suggested going 30-45 min early to wait in line for the Cruffins that usually come out at 9am and there would be a separate line just for Cruffins. Apparently, the separate line thing applies to the weekend. 

I came on Friday and it was pretty disorganized where I waited on line outside and by the time it was ready to order, it was only 8:50 and the cruffins were not ready. The guy let me order the pastries and left enough room in the box for the two cruffins and said I could go back for it later. After paying, I asked where I should wait and they told me there should be a line for cruffins.... Do you mean the line that I've been waiting on for 20 min that is now a few stores down?? They said they don't make a separate line on the weekdays because it's not usually hectic. The lady then said she was going to form a separate line for cruffins only. When she had asked the line of ppl who here is getting cruffins, everyone raised their hands of course. So I was at the back of the line waiting.... Again! 

Overall, the cruffins and ube pastry was on point!  Definitely worth the wait. Minus one star for being disorganized
author: Jennifer Y.

description: It's fun when friends visit sf since I'm forced to check out overly hyped places such as Mr Holmes Bake House. Don't get me wrong the pastries taste good but not awesome enough to justify a long line and maybe they just arent my style. The croissants here are very dense and bready and have cream filling in them, but I prefer more traditional flaky and lighter croissants (like b patisserie or Bouchon). I will concede the chocolate chip seasalt cookie is pretty delish. I'm not sure what the hype is about the cruffin either. Once again I'm not sure why people would wait over 30 min for pastries..It's just bread, people!
author: Christine H.

description:
DO NOT ORDER DELIVERY FROM THIS PLACE

I ordered from DoorDash for this place. My order consisted of 7 different types of baked goods from this store. I was eventually told that they had only one of the 7 options I had selected. Why even offer delivery if you can't fulfill the vast majority of an order? Why was I able to place the order if you'd totally run out of everything? What a terrible experience. I ended up canceling my entire order and having to scramble to find a replacement.
author: Han Z.

description: I love this place! New flavors every day. Just go earlier in the day incase they sell out!
author: Lexi C.

description:
Out of the croissant, cookie, and doughnut that we got - I thought the cookie was the best. They have figured out how to make a crunchy outside and soft chewy inside. Good stuff. Don't let me mislead you though...everything I got tasted great!

I got there at 11am on a Friday and the cruffins were sold out. I'll definitely be back again to see if I can score a cruffin.
author: L. M.

description:
Great bakery! I came on a weekday around 1:30. There was no line and quite a few options. They had a chai donut (donut was really good, very generous with the filling, chai flavor was spot on!), 4 different savory pastries (I tried the artichoke feta and it was awesome!), cinnamon sticky buns, croissants, and a cali croissants (all the ingredients of a california roll!!).  

You do have to come first thing in the AM for cruffins. They said that during the week they sell out by about 10:30. On the weekends people line up before 8 and they sell out right away. 

They were super friendly and everything I tried was great! I can't wait to come back (on a weekday morning) for a cruffin!!
author: Jen G.

description:
When we picked up my sister from LAX, we saw her carrying this beautiful box filled with.. CRUFFINS! Yes, she flew a box of baked goodies from SF to LA. She picked them up that morning so they were fresh! She brought down a few of their danishes and kouign amann but the real winner was their S'mores Cruffin. I never imagined that they could taste so good! Their kouign amann was just okay but their cruffin was worth the wait. Their boxes are super cute too! 

Tip: go early before they open and bring friends! They have a limit of 2 cruffins per person and they're served at 9am daily. They run out quick! If you want a taste of these delicious cruffins, I would recommend going early.
author: Charlene L.

description:
We came in at 9:40 am on a Monday and the cruffin had already sold out at 9:25 am. I was so sad! Anyways, we ended up getting a berry brioche, california croissant, and an amelie amagn. Since there wasn't really a place to sit, we paid for our items, took a photo with the sign, and hopped back into the car. 

The berry brioche was decent; it was chewy and soft and had a berry filling in the middle. Not something I would order again though. The amelie amagn was amazing; the outside was crispy and flaky and the inside was light and airy. So good! I can't imagine how much better the cruffin would be.... The california croissant was also a winner. The croissant was more crispy and flaky than typical croissants which totally works out for this particular pastry as the inside has seaweed and salmon. The soft salmon adds a nice contrast to the croissant, and they even provide soy sauce to pair with the croissant! Really interesting take on a croissant, but it was done so well! 

Wish I had gotten the cruffin, but I guess that will have to wait until my next visit to SF! Don't know how long I can wait though.... These cruffins look amazing!
author: Celine L.

description:
Everytime I come here I wait about an hour to an hour and a half to get my cruffins and other pastries. And every single time, it is worth the wait
Their ever changing cruffin flavors are amazing, last time I went I had the coffee hazelnut one, and it was amazing! Not too sweet because I could really taste the bitter sweet chocolate. The flakiness of the cruffins is to die for.
Their Ferrero Rocher Chou Bomb are BOMB. They are so good because the cream isn't too creamy where it gives you a cavity. But is that perfect creaminess where it doesn't kill you with sugar but also gives you that sweetness you crave.
Their chocolate chip cookie is also really good. It is a huge cookie, chewy and warm. 
I am a sucker for a place with great pastries and this place is one of them. I do wish to try the Matcha Cruffins. 
I wish the wait was a little shorter as well.
author: Ariunaa B.

description:
Their baked goods ARE the bomb ! I tried the churro croissant, chocolate donut, raspberry rose lychee donut and the white chocolate blueberry cruffin. I would go back for the churro croissant and raspberry rose lychee donut. And of course to try other things. SO. FREAKIN'. GOOD. 

The cruffins are the star of the show here and I did wait in line for 45 minutes to try one. In my humble opinion they ARE really good but so is everything else. I'd rather get the other things I mentioned than wait for the cruffins to roll out (the bakery opens at 8 but the cruffins don't come out until 9).  I'm happy I tried them once though. 

All in all, it's a must visit to breakfast and well, any other meal. So buy extra
author: Michelle M.

description:
This is the cutest bakery in San Francisco (or at least as far as I have found). The baked goods are superb, but make sure you get there earlier in the day, as the selection tends to get smaller and smaller as the day goes on, just like with any other good bakery. 

The shop is easy to miss if you're not looking for it, so be careful. Parking is easy enough to find, especially if you're willing to pay. Be prepared with quarters, it is SF. 

Make sure to take a picture with the "I got baked in San Francisco" sign. I mean if you don't, did you even go?
author: Breena R.

description: Got there relatively close to opening. Waited about 10 - 15 minutes. Went in for two things. Left with a box of 6. Well worth the wait and price. Very nice people as well.
author: Norm C.

description: I didn't personally come inside this bakery but my friend managed to save me a cruffin. My goodness it's a lot larger than I thought it would be. Flavor of the day was pumpkin spice! Flakey muffin shaped pastry with the consistency of a croissant and a core of cream, sweet and tasty! Would love to try the other flavors some other time.
author: Wendy L.

description:
The food is definitely worth waiting in line for! Do not be intimidated by the massive hoard of people that builds down the block, especially if you're there early enough. Don't line up too late though, otherwise you run the risk of baked goods running out. When my girlfriend and I were fortunate to live around the block from Mr. Holmes, we would usually line up around 30 minutes after opening. But we were only interested in their regular baked goods, not their famous "cruffin."

We have not yet gotten to try the elusive "cruffin," which always has its own separate line and runs out quickly. But we are big fans of the "California croissant" and the "kouign amann." All of their pastries use the best dough I have ever tasted--light, crispy, and buttery. The "California croissant" is stuffed with seaweed, smoked salmon, ginger and wasabi, and it is served with a side of soy sauce. The "kouign amann" is a pistachio pastry that my girlfriend tells me is delicious, as I am allergic to nuts.

The only reason that I am not giving Mr. Holmes Bakehouse five stars is the inconsistent level of service. On a couple occasions, we were treated impolitely and met with snark, condescending replies from cashiers. Otherwise, Mr. Holmes is a must-try for any SF resident!
author: Ryan M.

description:
What can I possibly say about the cruffin that hasn't already been said? It's flaky, yummy and you should give it a try! Wait, that's all been said already. Oh well. 

We arrived at 8:00 on Friday and there was already a pretty solid line. About 40 minutes into the wait, one of the workers started to hand out stickers to people in line since they already know that there wouldn't enough cruffins to go round!

While Mr. Dubs waited in line, I dashed into their regular line to see what kind of deliciousness I can get my hands on. I ended up walking out with $27 worth of goodies -- two California croissants, a Ferrero Rocher tart, 3 custard filled donuts and a cup of coffee. $27 definitely didn't go a long way in Mr Holmes Bakehouse!

Cruffins were served promptly starting at 9 and we were at the front of the line within 10 minutes. We weren't given an option for which type of cruffin we'd like, we were just given 4 passionfruit flavored ones. The flaky cruffin paired with the perfectly flavored passionfruit custard is a killer combo. 

California Croissants - SO DELICIOUS! A croissant filled with baked salmon, nori and wasabi ginger dressing. The croissant also comes with soy sauce which i decided to forego. I dare say that I liked the California croissant just as much as the cruffin. 

Ferrero Rocher tart - Pass! It did taste exactly like a Ferrero Rocher, but there's just something about it that isn't satisfying. 

Donuts - Pass! The banana rum donut had way too much rum in it for my liking. 

My final verdict is that I'd happily devour another cruffin and/or California croissant, but I'm not sure that I'd spend another hour of my life waiting in line for them-- hence the 3-star rating.
author: Tiffany U.

description:
Can't believe I forgot to write a review for this place...

Decided to be smart and come on a weekday. Actually ended up not going super well anyway since instead of starting the cruffins at 9 AM, they delayed opening until almost 9:30 :( had to run to my parking spot and feed the meter more. But the pastries though. All the pastries though. If you're gonna come here, might as well broadcast the fact that you came here by either buying enough pastries for the box or just buy a box. I came on a lemon cruffin day? It was custard-y and delicious. Definitely not overhyped. I haven't had anything like it anywhere else and I've had my fair share of line-waiting at the doors of bakeries in NYC. The other highlights were the choux bomb and the amelie amann, similar to the more well-known kouign amann.

Can't speak for the other wait times but if you're free on a weekday morning, come by here around 8:30 and you'll definitely be among the first 10-15 people in line!
author: Lucy Z.

description:
When I discovered that my hotel was not far from this bakery, I decided to give it a go. 

Since I purchased a large, varied quantity of pastries from this shop and having tried them, albeit I am not a professional pastry chef myself, I have some misgivings regarding how the bakery runs its operations. 

I understand it's a private business and it is within the owner's right to act accordingly to his discretion. 

That being said, I find it perplexing that only one flavour is offered for the cruffins. There are a lot of people, including tourists, who do not live in the city to get these pastries (I find that they financially contribute more to MHBH than locals) and it is disappointing to wait for an inordinate amount of time on a weekend no less just to obtain a Cruffin that isn't even a flavour that you like. 

Out of all the pastries, aside from the cruffins, I thought the croissant was the best I've had outside of France. Everything else was lacklustre and I think it would be within the bakery's financial interest to solely concentrate on expanding the cruffin production to include additional flavours. I reckon it's a waste of time and resources to continue making other pastries that aren't even good---the cruffins are the best item anyway. 

Following the reviewers' advisements, I came at 07:45AM and did not receive my cruffins until 09:23AM. As I had somewhat of a walk up the hill, I asked for the box instead of the paper bag to carry my cruffins as I wanted something sturdier. 

In order to get that white box, I was asked to buy an extra 4 pastries because they won't give it to you unless you buy at least 6 baked goods in total. 

The cruffins are an interesting texture. It's extremely flaky, buttery, and the cream filling complements it very well. The sugar creates a sandy coating and honestly, this was very fun to eat. As soon as I bit into it, the cream exploded on the other end. 

I reckon if you have time on a weekend and are willing to wait a little for a pastry, go right ahead. It took me 90 minutes to get that sticker and I cannot blame others who would balk at waiting at an inordinate amount of time for a pastry---it's silly, right? 

One good thing however is that when you are in the queue, you have an opportunity to meet strangers and chat with them. It's a chance for a brief, human interaction and you might even be able to make a friend. 

But if you prefer not talking to anyone, then I suggest you bring a fully charged phone or some newspapers to read as you wait.
author: C. K.

description:
My first time in San Francisco ever was last Friday and I decided to start my day at Mr. Holmes Bakehouse to try the famous cruffin! However, here is my unfortunate story:

After getting off the airplane, I took BART to the Civic Center stop and proceeded to walk the 0.8 miles uphill to this well talked about place. Thankfully there was a short line (10am on a Friday) and all the pastries were still well in stock. I took the famous photo of the "I got baked in San Francisco" sign and ordered my cruffin. I was about to pay, but remembered I read great reviews about their donuts, so I added that to my order too. I proceeded to walk towards City Hall as the bike shop I planned to rent from was about a mile away in that direction. Right outside City Hall I decided "Hey my aunt was curious about a cruffin, why don't I send her a picture of it!" I proceeded to pull said cruffin out of the bag and took a pretty clear picture of it. Proud of myself, I was putting away my phone and with all the sugar around the cruffin combined with a waxy bag.....I dropped the cruffin. It didn't just hit once, it rolled around. I kinda just stared at it for a second, told myself not to think about it, picked it up, tossed it in the trash, pulled out the donut and held onto it for dear life as I stuffed my face. As I walked away I realized I should have taken a picture of my sad cruffin on the ground, but in the moment I was in such a high from the excitement of spending the day exploring San Francisco that I wanted it out of my mind and my stubbornness prevented me from walking the almost mile back uphill...again..for another one.

Needless to say, I cannot speak about the cruffin. It looked delicious as you can see in my photo! But sadly, another day. However, the staff was incredibly friendly and my second choice donut pulled me through the rough time because it was very delicious (thank goodness I bought 2 items!). I'm even one to usually avoid creme-filled donuts, but the chocolate hazelnut was perfect.

Worth the trip and always better on a week day to avoid long lines. Just watch out for that slippery sugar if you're holding up the pastries for a picture! Do it on a table.
author: Megan M.

description:
BAKED GOODS. CROISSANTS. MUFFINS. CRUFFINS.
Cruffins are sold out right when they open so you have to wait in line before open to get it.

Price: Look to spend about $3-4 per pastry.

Parking: Street? I think?

Service: Chill

Food:
Banana Foster Donut: Good.. different. Definitely taste the rum. Day drinking memories... but probably wouldn't get it again.

Chocolate croissant: flaky crust. Chocolatey. Super duper sweet.

Notes: May return to try the cruffin.
author: Krystle T.

description:
My new obsession.
