The location is bordering a not-so-great area but man does Mr. Holmes make up for it! Dropped in after seeing all these insta posts of a neon sign saying "I got baked in SF" and had to go. walked in to the little shop which was super trendy and clean. The gals working behind the counter were so cute and bubbly, they definitely enhanced the experience for me. 

Now let's talk about the pastries- they are absolutely delightful! I had one of the amalie aman (sp?) which I devoured in two seconds. I also tried the blue cheese and pear danish which was perfectly baked and exploding with flavor! 

my only regret is not buying their cute little totebag!
author: Nicole W.

description:
Me and my BF came here during our mini trip to San Francisco, it was recommended by my friend who lives here to try the Cruffins. We didn't rent a car so we decided to try and walk it there from my friend's apartment. I was warned about walking through Tenderloin since it can be a sketchy area. Walking through Tenderloin around 730-8ish AM was kinda still kinda scary. Anyway, when we got to Mr Holmes Bakehouse there was a little line formed outside the door. There were maybe 8 or 9 people standing in line. One of the workers came out and handed out pink stickers which seemed like the ticket to Cruffins. 

On this particular day they were selling the Matcha Green Tea cruffins. For some reason I thought they made more than one flavor so was slightly disappointed because I wanted to try a chocolate or caramel flavor. Anyway we bought a bunch just in case we liked them and also got an ube tart and a donut that my BF wanted to try. 

Me and the BF were excited and wanted to see what the hype was about. Ube tart was delicious! Just enough pastry to bite into. The cruffin on the other hand was not what I expected. To be a combo of a croissant/muffin i felt the consistency of the pastry was to thick and it was an overkill on the filling. It got real messy to eat and there was sugar all over my hands, my lips and the table. 

Hopefully next time I stop by SF there will be a different flavor.
author: Donna V.

description: Fun! Good if you are touristing/ looking for a special treat. Due to the long line and high prices is definitely isn't an 'all the time' kind of place.
author: Kiley S.

description: CRUFFINs. Who ever though croissant and muffins are such a wonder. They limit 2 per person so make sure you have your party there to get maximum because honestly you can easily eat 2 by yourself. It's nice and warm, soft, flakey, just perfect texture. The filling is different each day and are all nice flavor. The one we got to try was the pumpkin cheesecake and it was delicious. It was not too heavy on the pumpkin flavor, just right. Long wait, but totally worth the wait. I highly recommend it to people to try out. If they can't bare to wait, I recommend any pastry that they sell because all of them are just wonderful.
author: Adrian T.

description:
I came to this place with a friend around noon and the was told the cruffins had sold out at 9 am. I was disappointed but got a Danish Savory Pastrami ($4.50) and some type of sweet pastry. Both were good together - the Danish Savory would have been too salty if I didn't get something sweet. 

I will definitely be returning to experience the hype over the cruffin.
author: Christina G.

description:
Arrived around 9:15am on a Thursday and there was of course a line, about 2 buildings down.  I waited for about 25 minutes before I made it into the shop at which time there were still about 12 cruffins left. I grabbed 2 of them and a few other goodies and by the time I was checking out I heard "these are the last 2" a few people behind me.. so close call! The cruffin of the day was a peach custard .. was pretty sweet - good way to describe it was if beard papa and kouign amann had a baby.. 

I was so-so about the cruffin, but thought the seasonal tart (cherry!) was maybe, even better? I'm not as big on filled desserts so I think plain cronuts are more up my alley. Croissant was also good, but there are plenty of places to get a good croissant.
author: Melody T.

description:
Uh.. this place is so fckn hyped up..

AND GOOD REASON FOR IT! THEIR PASTRIES ARE gooooooodddddd!!

MUST TRY: ANY FLAVORED CRUFFIN THAT TICKLES YOUR SWEET TOOTH REALLY AND CHOUX BOMB! *Check out their website or instagram for flavor updates since they do change daily*

Note: No place to sit down and eat. Most people just point, pay, take pictures of their goods with the "I Got Baked in San Francisco" sign they put up and go.

Stayed over at a friend's place in the city for the weekend and walked over to Mr. Holmes' Bakehouse on LARKIN EARLY IN THE MORNING, WHICH IS WHAT YOU HAVE TO DO cause THEY SELL OUT QUICKLY and the WAIT IN LINE CAN TAKE AT LEAST an HOUR! There was already a short line at around 8 AM and the doors werent even open yet. They ask you to form TWO LINES to keep the purchasing system going.

1. For CRUFFINS. -  They hand out a sticker to EACH PERSON which entitles them to TWO CRUFFINS. Taste? THEY WERE DELECTABLE and really an INDULGENT dessert. Crisp and flaky on the outside with granules of sugar covering its exterior with caramelized crusts surrounding it. On the inside is the day's specialty flavors as its creamy light custardy filling. CHOCOLATE, MATCHA, GUAVA, PEANUTBUTTER, RASPERRY WHITE CHOCOLATE. All are pretty good but definitely something you can share. Note that they might not take being in the frige too well and are best eaten fresh/on the day. 

2. All other pastries - This line usually gets moving first. So you can get ahead of the pack but can only purchase everything but no. 1's line is for. Friends tried the guava flavored donuts and savory croissants. All were alright but not as special as the round morsels of dough filled with creamy goodness that you MUST HAVE: THE CHOUX BOMB.

Tip no. 1: WAIT FOR YOUR STICKER. This worked for me a my friends. We waited for them to give out the stickers so we each got one then those of use who wanted to buy something else went ahead and just got back in line where we originally were. Gets things going faster.

Tip no. 2: Besides Mr. Holmes' pastries, THEIR PACKAGING IS GLORIOUS and a thing to WATCH OUT FOR. Clean lines, GOLD  METALLIC font and design. Beautiful. Take note though, YOU CAN ONLY GET A BOX if you order 4 or more pieces. Tactics you say? 
      a. Buy at least 4 pastries,
      b. Share a box with a friend or two or more, or
      c. This one's a little sneaky. My friend went in the "for all others line" and purchased a few pastries and said that she'd be buying more cruffins so that they could give her a box. Let's just say she didnt get any more cruffins. Teehee! 

Tip. no. 3: Surely you'd like some company? Bring a friend or two you wouldn't mind waiting hours in line with. If you're on your own though and on a mission to have a bite, dont worry! Those dessert loving customers in line with you I'm sure are as sweet! I enjoyed talking with the people I was in line with! 

The pastries are good and definitely something you should try should you have the time and determination to try one of these goodies by lining up early in the morning. Without a doubt an indulgence but great box to bring over to a dinner/lunch at home or a party because it will surely impress!
author: Margaret G.

description:
Yes! I'm a fan! But more for their regular pastries than their cruffins, actually. We got in line at 8:30 on a Wednesday and it was already about 15-20 people deep, before the cruffin line even opened! I went in and bought all my other pastries and a coffee to drink while we waited. Once the line opened at 9am, it moved pretty quickly, and we were back in our car by 9:15 at the latest I'm sure.

The cruffin flavor of the day was caramel latte, and the flavor was present but subtle, which I liked. The cruffin is actually pretty huge and was soft and flaky but still held up with each bite. The one thing I didn't like about the cruffin was that it was covered in sugar so it was pretty sweet and messy. I would've liked it much better without the outer sugar layer. I don't think I'd go out of my way to wait for these again, but they are fun to get and a must try at least once.

We also got one each of their stuffed donuts (flavors of the day were a spicy chocolate and a berry jam), the California croissant, potato & leek savory pastry, Thai curry bun, cookie, and ube pop tart. I liked all of them except the Thai curry, which needed more filling and flavor throughout the entire bun. Favorites of the others were probably the California croissant and the pop tart - not too sweet, which works perfectly for me. The donuts were also covered in sugar and had quite a lot of filling - which are both good things, but for me, too sweet and too indulgent. I like the subtle flavors better :)

Would I come back? Definitely- but for their regular items! Both to avoid the crazy cruffin line and because I enjoyed them more.
author: Kathy L.

description:
This place is aaamazing!if you have the energy to wake up early and wait in like for the crud find you will not be disappointed.

I also love the"I got baked in sf" sign! Super cool...must visit.
author: Samantha S.

description:
If Mr. Holmes' service were as friendly as the place is hipster, the bakeshop would earn higher marks in my books. But maybe that's the point of being hipster? You're ltoo cool for school to show even a hint of a smile or thank your patrons for coming in?

The best goods Mr. Holmes offers is its variety of filled donuts, which very much resemble malasadas. I've tried several other treats, but was unimpressed. The cruffins are fine, but not worth the hype. I'm not one to get up early, schlep to the outskirts of the TL, stand in line for two pastries (yes, because there's a per person limit on cruffins), then stand in another line for the rest of the offerings. I'll just head over to B. Patisserie, thank you very much, and stuff my face with their endless supply of kouign ammans.
author: Mel T.

description: You cannot go wrong going here for breakfast! The cruffins are amazing! You better go early because they sell out quickly! Definitely a place to hit up if you are not from san francisco. The area in town isnt the best. Make sure to get a whole box of pastries because you will want to try them all!
author: Makenzi B.

description: Such good pastries! Usually a line unless you can manage to go on a weekday.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
The muffin/croissant is worth a try. My daughter liked the filling. 
The savoury bread pudding was a tiny potion but yummy:)
The donuts are forgettable. 
Worth a 10-15  minute wait for a "new" culinary experience. Perhaps not worth a 30 minute wait.
author: Robin M.

description:
I personally don't believe their other pastries are as good as the cruffin, so if you come too late and they're sold out of cruffins, then turn right around. There's not a whole lot else here that is worth the wait and will sorely disappoint you if you had your expectations set high.

Also know that not a lot of natives know about cruffins; it seems to me like a hyped up novelty item  by tourists and blogs.
author: Lee T.

description: Seriously the best pastries I've ever had in my life. Worth the stop. We got 3 of the Cruffins, the croissant with Carmel, and the Nutella and hazelnut donut and all were absolutely delicious. We will definitely be stopping back when we are in town.
author: Amber R.

description:
I had no idea donuts could be so good. Also Mr Holmes Bakehouse packaging is delightful.

I'll admit - I've never waited in line for these delightful cream filled wonders - because postmates! That being said - I would wait - and I try to get my roommates to make the trek with me almost every weekend but so far it's always out of the way from where our adventures happen to take us. 

I can't tell you what donut of the day flavors I've tried because they are never labeled in the box - but I can tell you that every last one has tasted like more! Donut cravings rarely hit me - but I could eat Mr. Holmes donuts every gosh darn day!
author: Shannon H.

description:
Ah their famous CRUFFINS. As if they need another review. Such a pain to get them but IMHO they're worth it!

What to do: line up EARLY. If you want to be on the extra safe side, at 8 am when they open. There are 2 lines, one for cruffins only and the other is any non-cruffin purchases (definitely the shorter one) so make sure you check before lining up! 

We got there around 8:30am on a Sunday and 15 minutes later someone from the shop started handing out the "golden tickets" - 1 per person and it will get you 2 cruffins each. There's only ONE flavour everyday and if you care to check prior, it's posted on their website the day before.

Minus 1 star for the rude and stuck-up employee that barked at us demanding to see all of our stickers, and proceeded to immediately ask for payment without cracking a smile.

Small space, therefore no seating. You should also sneak in an IG-worthy shot of the cool neon "I got baked" sign (WITH the cruffins! duh.) quickly before the employees start to give you angry looks signaling for you to get out of their way.
author: Kathleen S.

description: Visited SF and couldn't wait to go. However I was disappointed I was told they only have one flavored cruffin per day and the flavors are random. When I went, it was ginger and I didn't get it. I was so bummed! And then I couldn't decide what to get and the girl was SUPER rude cuhs it was busy. Uh, I'm sure everyone in here are all tourists just like me, chill. The wall decor thing that everyone wants to see is whatever, hard to take pics in such a small space and people staring at you
author: Esther P.

description:
Errrr not sure what happened with you today mr Holmes, you either bought croissants at Safeway and are selling them in your store or you have given me croissants from yesterday!!!! Very disappointed to travel all the way and have bought these either old/Safeway croissants!

WHERE IS THE FLUFFY, BUTTERY, FRESH ONES????
author: Zici L.

description:
Mr. Holmes Bakeshop, you reminded me of middle school/high school.  Why?  Because I've been semi stalking your Instagram, waiting for the perfect opportunity to "meet you" after crushing on you (your cruffins) for quite some time.  So, I've been wanting to get my hands on those damn cruffins for months and hubby always is skeptical of overhyped places like this but loves me so much that he'll go with me and wait with me.  We were close on one weekend but knew weekend waits even if we got there about an hour before the 9:00 cruffin time would be a lot worse.  So, we went on MDW Thursday with his cousin and stood in line while it was cold and slightly misty.  It was a little before 8:40 when we got in line and there were only about 10-12 people in front of us.  Of course there's no wait if you want to get non-cruffin goodies.  They kept coming out and making sure we knew of the "two separate lines."  I asked one of the workers if they would be able to tell us what the flavor was (fearing it may be the matcha one, as I don't like green tea).  She asked me first if I wanted to know or be surprised and I told her I wanted to know.  She then told me that the flavor was Almond Joy..phew!  Really wish they would let people know prior to that morning what the flavor is though. 

9:00 hits and we were super antsy, though it was about a couple minutes after when they let the first person go in.  We finally got in about 10 minutes after and if you get six items then they give you the box (less than 6 you can't even buy it you just get a paper bag).  I totally over ordered but because I thought to myself when am I actually going to be able to come back (& be patient)?  We got six cruffins (2 max per person allowed), 1 passion fruit filled donut, 1 Ferrero Roche choux bomb, and one coffee for his cousin.  There is really no room to eat here, just a small bench under the got baked in SF lighting sign and a small standing table by the entrance.  The verdict?  It's all about the flakey glorious cruffin.  The layers were flakey like a croissant that everyone would love, sugared like a morning bun, and custard filled like an eclair, and topped like a true SF creation with unheard of ingredients.  Though I expected this to be super sweet it wasn't, which is good.  I'm not that big on coconut but like an Almond Joy it had some shredded coconut and a piece of chocolate with diced up almonds.  It all worked so well and was pretty foodgasmic!  As for the other items, the passion fruit donut was way too sweet and messy.  It wasn't anything special that you couldn't find anywhere else (minus perhaps the passion fruit flavor).  The Ferrero Roche choux bomb I saved for later in the night, and I saw one Yelp buddy's disappointing review on it, but I decided to go for it.  It was a disappointment for sure.  It just had a very slight hint of Ferrero Roche taste, but the pastry part wasn't that pleasing nor the cream part.  If I'm going to ingest hella calories it better be worth it and this one wasn't..it was like eating just a bunch of whip cream out of the can.  His cousin has been living in Brooklyn for about four years and not only enjoyed the cruffin, but also said the coffee they serve here was really good, which apparently he hasn't good coffee as good in New York.  

The other pastries actually didn't look as appealing to me, some looked too dark as well.  I'm not going to lie, I was kinda hoping that I was going to like their other pastries and not so much their cruffins so I can just go back and skip the line to get the other pastries.  But honestly the hype is real on the cruffins.  The stalking does pay off for the cruffins.  Just like that boy I used to like in middle school/high school, sometimes the wait is worth it when you go ahead and make a move.  I just wished the other pastries were as good.  Would I come back?  Perhaps if I got another weekday off and was lucky to find parking like we did (saw others get dropped off via Uber)..but I wouldn't wait longer than 45 minutes or so for it.  We still love B. patisserie more, but thank goodness that Mr. Holmes wasn't a let down like Tartine was.
author: Cat C.

description: I bookmarked this spot because it sounded interesting.  I wanted to check out these "cruffins".  I made the mistake of getting a manicure after breakfast so I arrived at around 10:20 and the cruffins were gone.  I was already there, so I decided to get a blood orange filled donut.  That was AMAZING!  I have to confess, I actually bought two, one for the hubby, but he never saw it.  I hope he doesn't read this review.  The next day, I decided I was going to be there by 8:30 like they told me to start the line.  Indeed, I was the first one on the "cruffins line".  People kept asking if they needed to line up for other stuff; Nope, just for cruffins.  In the meantime, I got a Pear and blue cheese tart.  That was so delicious, I could have eaten a couple more.  Super delicate pastry and pear slices that are super thin, SO GOOD!  Nine o'clock came and I finally got my two (2) cruffins, yes there is a limit.  I think crack dealers should get a clue from the lines at this place.  Every day there is a different cruffins flavor.  The day I went it was honeycomb.  Hmm, I am not sure what to think of these cruffins.  They were good, but I don't think I will make the line again.  I loved the other items so much more.  I am not sure it if was the flavor or if all cruffins are like that.  It was more "croissanty" than muffin.  If they have some other flavor next time I am around there, I might taste it, but I will definitely knock somebody over for the blood orange donut.
author: Marisa S.

description: Really good morning treats, lots of variety that couldn't be found in a traditional bakery.  Expect a line but the wait is doable.  The staff was very friendly and efficient.  Worth a visit!
author: Jesus E.

description: Review is for the cruffin only. I had the s'mores flavor cruffin an hour after it was baked, procured after a 1.5 hour wait. The outer shell is crisp, dense and flaky with bits of raw sugar swirled in. Inside was filled with a chocolate cream and topped with a little marshmallow. Maybe it was just the s'mores flavor but it was too intensely sweet for my taste. I enjoyed the chocolate cream filling but everything else was drowned out by the overwhelming amount of sugar. Liked the softer, chewier bits of pastry dough closer to the chocolate cream and untouched by the sugar liberally applied to the outside and top swirl. I may be willing to give it a second go with a different, less sweet cruffin flavor.
author: Truc N.

description:
I actually realized after coming here one morning, that I don't really like pastries that much. But that didn't stop me from enjoying the pastries at Mr. Homes Bakehouse! Their baked goods are really as good as it gets. I really wanted one of their boxes, so I ended up buying 6+ pastries to fill the box. I tried a few of them and they were all so good. Everything I ate was so flavorful and had the perfect amount of crisp in each layer. 

I probably wouldn't come back and wait for an hour to get a cruffin again unless I'm really really craving them, but Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is really as good as it gets.
author: Estelle C.

description:
I've been waiting to "get baked" in San Francisco for a while. After trying the cronut in New York, I wanted to see if the cruffin could compete. Boy was I in for a treat! Sorry cronut, but you ain't got nothing on the cruffin. 

I woke up early on a Monday morning and drove over. There was plenty of street parking around the corner and I made it to the already growing line around 8:45AM. The cruffin come out at 9:00AM. There were maybe 30 people in front of me. The cruffin came out about 5 minutes late, but I managed to get my cruffin at 9:15AM. Remember, you can only buy 2 per person.  I also go the choux bomb and all the artichoke cheese danish.

The cruffin flavor was chocolate chip cookie. It was delicious! Now, it is VERY messy so I would sit down to eat it and have plenty of napkins on hand. Also, it is very sweet so be sure you have a sweet tooth like meee! My brother doesn't eat sweets so he thought it qas just a little too much for him. I didn't mind. I got to finish his! The chocolate chip filling was so creamy and smooth. Unfortunately, I lost some to the floor. I seriously ate it all up within a few minutes.

The choux bomb was also very good as well. Not as sweet as the cruffin but it was good. 

The savory danish with artichoke was so interesting. The first bite was kind of a shock to your taste buds, but keep munching away and you will like it. 

I've also gone back on a Saturday morning during the winter holidays. I got there around 8:30AM and waited in line. We got a sticker guaranteeing that we get a cruffin! While waiting, I jumped in the normal line and grabbed an eggnog doughnut and earl grey doughnut. Both were delicious. The flavors weren't too strong or overpowering. It was very light and fluffy.

Fast forward to the cruffin purchase. This day was the mint chocolate chip cruffin. I was expecting the generic mint chocolate chip flavor, but this was different! The mint was more like mint leaves! It was such an amazing and a tasty surprise! I think I liked this over the chocolate chip cookie. 

I will definitely be back to try more cruffin flavors... waiting for peanut butter! I'd also try their donuts as well. I plan on getting baked in San Francisco again and again in the not so distant future.
author: Jessica Y.

description:
Seriously, AMAZEBALLS!!! This place has thee most unique donuts I have ever had the pleasure of trying out. I have never liked donuts with fillings, "like EVER" (in the words of t. Swizzy) but so far, this awesome bakehouse is my ONLY, and I truly mean ONLYYY, exception. 

The donut filling is not overly sweet at all! Be careful once you munch down on it, all the wonderful goodness inside will overflow and you do not want to waste a single drip, believe me,  haha.

Very interesting flavors, e.g, today I saw strawberry lemonade (which is what I tried) and lemon poppyseed just to name a couple. I was told they have different options each day and make sure to follow them on insta to stay UTD. I cannot wait to try the at matcha green tea latte - I was told it is really rare when they have these so I'll make sure to keep checking! (;

Very cute little bakery! See ya next week! :)
author: Mischelle D.

description:
Overrated. As someone that has waited an hour at Dominique Ansel, I wouldn't wait 10 minutes for another cruffin. Eating a cruffin is awkward because my mouth doesn't open as tall as one and I don't like having sugar covering my entire face and neck.  

However, the place is really cute.
author: Kristina N.

description:
Apparently, they opened 6-9 months ago, and have had more organic success via the Instagram than Yelp platform. I agree, as I've seen their pictures on Instagram before stepping foot in the store. That said, I have mixed feelings about this place. Their pastries, both sweet and savory, are awesome and for the most part, unique...but their cruffins, which they are known for and which people line up out the door for, were not the main attraction for me. 

What I liked: 
-California croissant. Savory, unique combination of salmon and seaweed in a decent-sized croissant. Surprisingly a combo I've never seen before. Salty on its own and doesn't need the soy sauce it comes with. 
-Mushroom cheese danish. Solid solid danish. Reminded me of cream of mushroom and again, it was such a unique taste and mix of ingredients (whole mushrooms) on a danish, that I was pleasantly surprised. 
-Classic AKA basic (?) Instagram shot with the "I got baked in San Francisco" neon lights. #basicbetch 
-Branding. My friend and I were very impressed with their cheap but effective branding. They seem to buy bulk items, such as cups, and simply stamp their peace logo on it. With wax paper bags, they do the same but use a small circular sticker. Cheap, effective, and hipster all at the same time. 

Meh: 
-Chocolate croissant. My cousin liked it, but I've had better. The chocolate was minimal - too much croissant in contrast to chocolate. Good, but not impressed. 

What I didn't like:
-Strawberry cream cruffin was the flavor of the day. Filling was way too sweet. Just because you give a trendy new name to something you made up doesn't mean it's something I want. I don't see the hype and definitely do not understand why the line is out the door well before 9 am on a weekday. 

I do want to try the matcha cruffin though...perhaps that will change my stance on cruffins? Also, they don't take AMEX.
author: Phoebe C.

description:
I haven't tried the (in-)famous cruffin, but I can say with extreme confidence that Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is home to San Francisco's best chocolate chip cookie. I've tried all comers and MHBH is the hands-down winner. I'm going to go out and say it: it might be the best chocolate chip cookie you'll ever eat. It's that good.

Oh, and strawberry jalapeno bomb is pretty good too.
author: Andrew V.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place since they were name dropped on Shark Tank, by an entrepreneur/baker in the LA area trying to create the next big pastry. We came on a Saturday, and for some reason Yelp said it was closed, although if you call in it says they are open everyday except Christmas, so I'm glad we risked it and went anyways, and maybe that's how we got lucky to get a cruffin, as only so many people are guaranteed cruffins each day. The line for cruffins was very organized, and someone working at the bakery was very helpful and explained how the cruffins were distributed and that if you were not there for the cruffins there was a shorter line available. We got a chocolate flavor cruffin, I did not realize that the cruffins came with filling, but you don't have a choice with flavor. The chocolate filling reminded me of pudding, it was flavorful, but I wish it was a little more solid consistency like a chocolate croissant, because the pudding flavor was too runny and got everywhere. I would definitely preferred a cruffin with some type of berry filling. We got 3 cruffins, and if you want a box to hold your pastries you have to buy 3 more pastries for a total of 6, or pay 1.50. Since we were already there, we decided to get 3 additional pastries, which we ended up liking better than the cruffin. They made some "savory" danishes, one with artichoke heart filling, another with blue cheese and pear, and these were amazing! I l loved the flakiness of the danishes and the flavor combination was perfect. 
I thought it was helpful that everything in the display case is labeled, so you appropriately identify what you want to order, the problem being that I didn't recognize the name of most of the pastries, so I asked, but there was a long line behind me, so I felt like I had to make a decision and move forward. Everything here is at least $3-$4 so be prepared to spend a pretty penny.
author: Lisa H.

description: Best donut I've ever tasted on my life.  Worth a visit. No lines on a weekday morning.  They run out of cruffins, so plan accordingly if that's what you are after.
author: Mary C.

description:
The Bakery is very small, and is right outside of an apartment complex. Since there was already a line when we showed up it was easy to find. About 10 minutes before 9am, a worker will come out and hand you a hot pink sticker. If you get a sticker you can get a cruffin. The flavor that day was Rocky Road. I am not a fan of that flavor, but this was my only chance to taste a cruffin I bought 2 to share. For me the real stand out was the California croissant, their croissants are SO flaky and really are divine. The California is a great savory item

When I came back home. I wanted to share half a doughnut. So I cut it in half and a ton of filling squirted out! I was so surprised. I thought I had squished it all out! Turns out I didnt and there was plenty of filling still inside. The amount of filling they are able to SQUEEZE inside is crazy!! 

I really can't add to what everyone else is saying. Other then follow their instagram to get flavor updates
author: Christina C.

description:
Finally got up early enough to make my way here and try their infamous cruffins. Got here around 7:40 on a Saturday morning. The line was pretty long and I was worried my boyfriend and I wouldn't get to try those bad boys. 

We had time to kill so I decided to leave my boyfriend in the "cruffin only" line while I lined up in the other line to get my hands on their other goodies. Halfway through my wait I get a text from my boyfriend saying he received a sticker from one of the workers which meant he was guaranteed cruffin. I was ecstatic but worried that they wouldn't let me purchase a cruffin since I didn't receive a sticker. I figured they'll let me slide since I was in their other line purchasing other pastires from them. 

I get to the front of the line in the and I pick up 2 chocolate croissants (my weakness!), banana filled donut, strawberry filled donut, amelie amann, and a ferrero rocher choux bomb. 

Went back to the "cruffin only" line and rejoined my boyfriend who was holding our spot in line. We get to the front of the cruffin line and my boyfriend orders 2 (2 limit per person) and I try and order 1. That's when the worker said they were not able to sell me any since I didn't have a sticker. He explained to me that it's not fair for the other people behind me who may not receive one in the end. I explained to the worker that I was in their other line purchasing other pastires and even showed him the box to proe it. But he was still adamant about not selling me ONE CRUFFIN. So I let it go and we come away with 2 delicious tiramisu flavored cruffins!

On our way home, I continue to think about the situation and now believe it was unfair for me. Standing in line they hand out stickers to guarantee people a cruffin. However they also have a disclaimer to the people at the very end of the line telling them "There's no guarantee" that they will receive a cruffin. It was explained to those at the back of the line that its up their discretion if they want to continue waiting in line or not since there's no guarantee they would receive a cruffin. With that said, how is fair to me then?! It's not my fault the people behind me didn't wake up early enough, or get there early enough to receive a cruffin. It's not as if I was sleeping in bed and made my boyfriend line up for me. I was in the other line supporting their bakery! I even had the receipt and box filled with pastries to prove it, I expressed that to the worker but he wasn't having it. He was adamant about not selling me ONE cruffin. I wasn't even taking advantage and trying to get 2!  I only wanted to purchase 1 and yet they couldn't accommodate that for a customer who woke up early and waited in line for more than hour. The worker continued to say it's unfair to those at the back of the line. EXCUSE YOU, BUT I WOKE EARLIER AND LINED UP EARLIER THAN THE PEOPLE BEHIND ME. Yet, it's not fair to them? You've got to be kidding me. I didn't even want to purchase 2, I wanted to buy 1. I thought it was rude that they denied me selling me 1 cruffin when I waited longer than the people behind me and yet I'm punished for that? NOT COOL MAN. 

However, everything was delicious! Things I didn't like about this place is obviously how I was treated about not receiving a sticker. So I'm taking 1 star off. Also, I'm not sure if wait 1+ hours is worth the cruffins. It was good though, I just wish I could walk in order one and not have to wait for it, but don't we all wish that. Also the bakery is located in s pretty sketch area and the pastries are over-priced. They're delicious but a chocolate croissant for $4? Really though?
author: Mellani L.

description:
i call you definitely the cruffin nazi!   For i didn't get a cruffin and was left disappointed.  

I got in line at about 905am on a sunday.  These cruffins are suppose to come out at 9am and I wasn't able to get one! So sad.  

They have a limit of 2 cruffins per person so I would definitely recommend to bring more ppl if you want more than 2 cruffins!  I really didn't think it was fair that some people went into line twice 

So what is my review about? 
It's about the other baked goods that me and my boyfriend got to try.   

We tried the savory  mushroom which was oh so delicious and I wish i had gotten two.   Croissant Bostock which is like a play on french toast but still good.  
The cookie which was just okay, my boyfriend really hates salt on his cookies.  
We also got a donut filled with orange creme fraiche inside which was lightly sweetened. 

I guess we will have to try this CRUFFIN the next time we are in town
author: Jamie K.

description: Amazing!! Went to this place for the first time this morning no line and amazing pastries!! Will definitely be going back. Service is amazing and as always had to take a picture with the light up sign:) will definitely be going back very soon!
author: Lindsey P.

description: YUM! The cereal cookie is beyond a doubt the best and in my opinion the hidden gem since it isn't as "Instagram worthy" as some of the other baked goods
author: Paul J.

description:
The nice thing about living in a 49 square mile city is the ability to go from one end to the other in a relatively short amount of time, especially if it's for the purpose of heading to a bakery.

I had an appointment in JTown at 9:30am today.  I'm early.  It's 8:45am and I've just finished breakfast at Starbucks in the inner Sunset.

Where to go?  That's right.  I've been wanting to try Mr Holmes Bakeshop.  As I approached Larkin St. at around 9:00am, I don't see a line at the Bakeshop.  Maybe the hype is over.  I found a parking space nearby.  I entered the shop to ask about the cruffins.  Oh, sorry, our oven isn't working today.  No wonder there wasn't a line.

But we've got lemon custard filled donuts and sweet stuffed Texas style French toast and other items if you'd like to try them.

Great consolations.  I bought two lemon custard donuts and the French toast and tried them this afternoon and after dinner.  Yummy.  Somewhat pricey.  A slice of French toast $6.50.  Each donut was $3.50.

If they're any indication, I'm sure the cruffins are worth coming back to try.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Time to finally try Mr Holmes. The new hyped up bakery is Artsicault so I figure the lines will be shorter. :)

I was a little disappointed. I had a few things over the weekend and the plum cruffin today. I was hoping it be the "SHIET" but there are so many good bakeries in SF that it didn't hit the spot for me. The regular croissants seem a little dry. Actually most of their pastries we had seem to be on the dryer side (except their donut).

Cruffin: It's not as flakey and moist like a cronut or a regular croissant. The bottom area is dry and I assume it cooks more because of the shape of the pastry. There is a lot of sugar sprinkled around the whole pastry which made it a bit too sweet for my liking.

Cali Croissant: We just didn't like it... 

Chocolate Croissant: We had better. It's not as light and flaky as other pastry shops.

I would totally skip the cruffin craze and stick with the cronut. Cronuts are a lot more light and flaky. My favorite cronut place in the city is Fillmore Bakery. They usually have a couple of flavors and I believe they ask if you want sugar sprinkled on the it (it's nice to have that option). BTW, they have GREAT pie here too! This is my favorite place for pie. :)

For Croissants, my favorite place is La Boulangerie on Pine St. If you're lucky (which I was ONLY once), you get here right when the croissants come out of the oven. As I walked out of the bakery eating my croissant half way down the block I had to stop and turn back around to get another. This has only happened to me 2x in my life where I had to stop and go back into a store for seconds (the other time was a fish taco place in Newport Beach).

I haven't had the chance to try Artsicault yet. I hope I don't get disappointed. We'll see.....
author: Karen L.

description: I really love this place! I just don't love the line. I kind of wish no one else knew about it so I wouldn't have to wait. But they never seem to run out of my favorite, the chocolate chip cookie
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
How good is a cruffin??  Let's just ask the bicyclist who I saw slowly get hit by a car, get up and brush himself off, park his bike at the bike rack and then proceed to get in the cruffin line.  Yup, it's really that good!! Lol.

Cruffin:

While the other pastries are great the cruffin is definitely the shining star.  You can just tell the quality in the texture and the taste of the croissant.  Buttery, flakey....just perfect.  Now the varying fillings makes things interesting and keeps us coming back for more.  It is true that most of the time you don't know what filling you will be getting until you are already lined up.  I personally don't mind as I am not a picky eater and don't mind a repeat as they have all been delicious.

I do want to take a moment to comment on some people's sentiment on increasing the supply.  This seems completely logical for a patron as who wants to ever wait in line?  Don't get me wrong, I'm sure the limited supply is helping to keep the hype going. However, for a small business this isn't always an easy thing to do.  When you are just starting out you may have limited resources, e.g. funds, staff, space...also being careful not to compromise the quality of the product.  These beauties also take 3 days to make.  It's the technique that makes these amazing.  In other words, all good things are worth the wait.  

Other Pastries:

These are all excellent as well.  Their filled donuts are like malasadas and they always change up the fillings.  My faves are the sea salt chocolate chip cookies, white chocolate blueberry brioche bomb and the donuts.  The only thing I would change is to have more of a rotation in selection.  I've pretty much seen the same items the past few months and am itching to try something new.  

Strategy: 

On the weekends we usually try to get there between 7:45-8:00.  The wait really isn't that bad.  It goes by quickly especially when you're in good company.  There will be two lines.  The one to the left of the door will be for cruffins only, which go on sale at 9:00.  The one on the right is for the rest of the pastries, which go on sale at 8:00 on the weekends (7:00 on weekdays).  Come with a buddy if you can and split up so you can try more things.  Just make sure your buddy gets back in the cruffin line before they hand out the stickers though.  Usually 15 minutes or so before 9:00 one of the staff members will hand out the stickers guaranteeing you 2 cruffins.  And just like that...you're in! 

Shop/Staff:

It's a small shop in not one of the nicest of neighborhoods but it's not that bad during the day.  The shop itself has a cool/fun vibe to it and they have good taste in music.  There's not much room to eat your treats so you pretty much need to take them away to enjoy.  The staff is awesome... always so nice each time we've been there.

I highly recommend giving this place a try.  Everyone should try a cruffin at least once or 12 times. Lol

*4.5 Stars
author: Kim E.

description:
Two of my girlfriends and I decided it was time to wait in the frigid cold for a hour, just to taste one or two of their famous cruffins. Since it was a Saturday, they begin selling their cruffins at 9am but hand out stickers about 5 - 10 min before 9.  The other line sells their other pastries at 8am. So we devised a plan, so I waited in line for their other pastries, while my friends waited in the cruffin line. We got their Cali croissants, donuts, etc.  Then I made just it time to get a sticker.  That day, the cruffin flavor was chocolate walnut. Cruffins are the super star of the bakery, it's amazing, delectable, flakey, not super sweet.  I would definitely go back just for the cruffin. Hopefully, it's matcha the next time I visit! 

We divided up the other pastries and unanimously agreed, the cruffin is where it's at!
author: Jessica Z.

description: This is probably one of the best pastries i've ever had. This cute little store had some of the most amazing and unique pastries. Will deffinitely come her every time we come to San Fran.
author: Isabella G.

description:
I can't say I stood in line at 6AM, BUT.. I have a very good friend who loves to share and that is how I got to try one of the infamous CRUFFIN'S! 
Even at a day old, the cruffin was still flaky and buttery. The one I had was the berry filled one and it wasn't too sweet which I like in pastries. The filling had seeds so it felt like real berry filling. The cruffin itself is pretty big and I was able to share it with my parents and still got a good fix. Would love to try other flavors but don't want to stand in line lol.
author: Tiff C.

description:
Mr Holmes gets a slightly skeptical 4 from me, but I was not won over by the cruffin. I did, however, try one (how can you not, if you have the opportunity?!), because what else do you do when you find yourself in the TL at 8:30am?

Arrived at Mr Holmes close to 8:15am and hopped into the cruffin line. There are two lines - one to the left for cruffins ONLY, and one to the right of the storefront for all other goods. They start serving cruffins at 9am on the weekend, and there were maybe 10 people in front of me. My friend parked and by the time she scooted over to me about 10 mins later, the line had grown way past me and around the block. We waited patiently for the oh-so-coveted pink stickers / golden ticket, which entitles you to purchase 2 cruffins each. People brought their small children to grab a sticker each to also count for 2. Smart, wake them up and force them to stand in line for goodies (I'm totally doing this to my future kids). Stickers were handed out around 8:40am, and right after we got our stickers, my friend hopped to the other line, which moved pretty quickly, and returned about 15 mins later with a box full of pastries. Right at 9am they started collecting stickers and people were moving forward in the cruffin line. We were out of there by 9:10am, treats in hand!

Cruffin - flavors vary per day, but we forgot to ask the flavor and mistakenly thought we'd be able to tell. The cream was sort of nutty, but not exactly chocolatey... three of us could not distinguish exactly what it was. That being said, the cream was not impressive at all. In fact, I ended up ditching about half of it because the cream to croissant ratio was just off. The croissant part of the cruffin was really good - perfectly flaky, slightly crispy, powdered sugar all over - BUT about on par with some amazing croissants I've had in my time. Would I stand in line again for a cruffin? No. Especially now that I know it's just a croissant baked into the shape of a muffin, with some cream in the center. Meh. Underwhelmed.

Amelie Amann - now THIS was money. Maybe it helps that I had absolutely no expectations, but this was the cream of the crop out of the pastries we got. It was sweet, but the kind that is excellent for treating your tastebuds, with the right amount of sweetness. It was sticky, flaky, buttery, crispy... DROOL. I ate half and saved half for the next day and it was still very very good. 5 stars for this!

Donut filled w/ salted caramel filling - underwhelming. Donut itself was kind of dry, was nothing memorable.

Other things we got: Ferraro Rocher choux bomb, almond brioche toast. Both were decent, but nothing to rave about.

I'd come back for the amelie amann, and for other instagram worthy moments, but not likely to go out of my way.
author: Lily C.

description:
I started standing in line around 8:55am on a Saturday morning and I was already too late to get a sticker to be guaranteed cruffins! It's no joke that if you want to be sure to get a cruffin, stand in line no later than 8:45am! Around 15 mins into us standing in line, one of the employees came out and told us that we had a 5% chance of getting a cruffin even though we were only 3 parties behind the woman who got the last sticker! I was so sad but still determined to try these famous pastries so we braved the line for about an hour, hoping that there would be some left for us to try. We got to the front and there was indeed, another whole tray of cruffins for us and everyone in line behind us! I felt so bad for the few parties behind us who left halfway through because of the information we were given. 

Anyways, onto the review for these delicious pastries: 

The cruffin was AMAZING! The flavor we got was strawberry cheesecake with a balsamic reduction. It was SO good! Even though this place has so much hype and I had to stand in line for an hour, the cruffin did not disappoint! If you live in SF or just visiting, this is one place you MUST GO!

We also tried the stuffed donuts - raspberry lemon and chocolate. Definitely recommend these, especially if you have a huge sweet tooth because they are extremely sweet.

The chocolate croissant was pretty good, but it didn't taste much different to me than others I've tried at bakeries across the bay. 

To counteract all this sweetness, we also got the mushroom danish which was also just ok. Maybe it would be better if it was warm? But to me is just tasted like a flaky (kind of dry) danish with some very lightly seasoned mushroom topping - nothing too special or overwhelming.

Basically (TL;DR), GO HERE FOR THE CRUFFINS! 

Just a tip, if you want to get more pastries besides just the cruffin, send someone to stand in the pastries line while the rest of your party is waiting for cruffins. The other pastries also run out and most of the people go to them after they get their cruffins so the line is very short earlier in the morning!
author: Malika R.

description: I have been here twice. The first time I got the apple tamarind cruffin, nectarine apricot riesling jam donut and butterscotch donut. I didn't care for the apple tamarind cruffin and I expected to love the butterscotch flavor but the apricot was literally the best donut I've ever had. The second time I went I got the Thai cruffin, lemon curd hops donut and the gingerbread donut. I love the Thai filling in the cruffin, definitely made up for the last one. Although it's only my second time I believe that a cream filling goes best with the cruffin and jelly/jam go best with the donut. Lemon hops was better then gingerbread but the nectarine apricot is still the best donut I've ever had.
author: Louise M.

description: Criffins are excellent!  Not the best I've had (NYC better) but then again I bought the last dozen.  Friendly staff!
author: Betty Y.

description:
PRO TIP: Get into the cruffin line at the sweet spot of ~8:15a. No need to go earlier as you'll still get a cruffin and save that extra half hour of sleep!

With all the buzz lately about cruffins I had to try one. Went this saturday morning and ended up arriving at 8:15 and there were already about 20 people in line.. We thought we were doomed but turns out we were there at just the right time. The first people in line said they had gotten there at 7:15/7:30a but why bother going That early. People later in line still get the same cruffins. Hence, 8:15 is the sweet spot. However, be warned, you can't go too much later or they will run out.

General information:
2 Cruffin per person/sticker limit
Cruffin ONLY line to the left
All other pastries to the right. Cannot get Cruffins in this line.
Cruffin's are available at 9a.
Other pastries start at 8a on weekends.

Like other reviews say, you get into the cruffin line and around 8:45a they hand out stickers that help them identify that you were in the cruffin line. Note, just because you have a sticker does not reserve you a cruffin. If you aren't in the line, they'll sell the cruffins to the next person in line. So, if you are in the line to the right you won't be guaranteed a cruffin if you go back to the cruffin line later.

Everything smelled amazing and all the pastries were delicious. Honestly, the cruffin just tastes like a croissant but in the shape of a muffin. But it's really well done. The cruffin is extremely crisply and flaky and the matcha green tea flavor they had that day was on point. I also really liked the Amelie Amagn. Some people really like the donuts but I thought they were just ok. It was a bit too oily for me, but the passion fruit filling packed a really flavorful sweet punch.

Everything was about $3-$5. Weekend parking on nearby alleys are metered starting from 9a-6p. You can pre-pay a dollar and you'll be back to your car by 9:30ish.

So go and do the SF thing and wait hours in line for food haha. In this case, it'll definitely be worth it. Try everything!
author: Charlton Y.

description:
My little boy and I stopped here on a weekday so there were no lines whatsoever, but we did miss out on the cruffins.  I ordered a couple of doughnuts and my son and I devoured them.  He was giggling from the sugar high.  Before leaving, we also took pictures in front of the Baked in San Francisco sign.  

I spoke to one of the workers and she mentioned that I should stop by before 10 am on a weekday so I can make it in time for the cruffins.  I can't wait to return so I can try one of the cruffins.  Definitely a must visit when you're in SF. Don't forget to take a pic in front of the neon sign so you can post on Instagram and make all your followers jealous. :)
author: Christine P.

description: This place is all hype. I was really excited to come here after my co-workers raved about it but was so disappointed. I didn't think the pastries were that fresh and the cruffins weren't anything out of this world. However, I don't know if my expectations were set too high after everyone kept raving about it. Overall, I didn't think it was worth the wait. I'd rather go to a cheaper/fresher local doughnut joint.
author: Venessa T.

description:
Nice place, good for a quick bite.
good croissants ;) tasted fine, not overly exceptional. Would recommend.
author: Shubhra R.

description:
As I stood there shivering in line at 8:30 AM, I thought to myself: I have never put this much effort into obtaining food. 

Woke up at 6:45 AM. Got ready, left Oakland at 7:20 AM. Got to the city at 8:25. Stood in line. Received a sticker a few minutes later. Still did not receive cruffins until another half hour later. If patience is not your strong suit, you may want to send a friend to grab a cruffin for you, but heads up, they are limited to 2 per person! 

Does all this sound crazy and irrational? Yes. But with all the hype surrounding this place, I had to try it at least once. My friend has been there before so he showed me all the ropes. Get there super early to line up for a sticker, which allows you to get those cruffins. If you're too late, too bad. There's a separate line for their other pastries, which isn't as long as the cruffin line. Once I got my two cruffins, I went to the other line to fill up my box. Donuts, choux bombs, and a savory danish. I was on campus visiting friends and was like Santa, walking around with that gorgeous white and gold box, passing out baked goods to everyone I came across.

The cruffin is very good--but it's really just a croissant in the shape of a muffin. With all the hype and the cute name, I thought it was somehow a mix of a croissant and muffin, which drew my curiosity to the place. Still, the pastries are VERY good here. Flaky, light, and airy. The donuts are especially good, and my friend raved about the savory danish. Would I ever come back and wait in the cruffin line again? Probably not, because that was way too much effort. Definitely something to try at least once though, and the other pastries are worth coming back for.
author: Angela L.

description:
So I'm not allowed to give 1/2 stars, that's why I gave them 4, but it's really 4.5 stars. 

If you love flaky and buttery pastries this is definitely the place for you. Everything from their cookies to their croissants are amazing and the bakery itself is adorable. I especially enjoyed their California croissant, the smoked salmon and seaweed make this savory croissant unique and extremely flavorful. If I could have one for breakfast everyday I totally would. Their cookies and doughnuts are equally amazing and their salted caramel filling is to die for. 

My one complaint- the filling they use for their caramel/Apple cruffin was just not my cup of tea. The pastry to filling ratio was a little off. I'm all about biting into a ooey/gooey pastry, but this cruffin just had too much filling. I wish I had gone on a day they had their chocolate cruffins, but I definitely look forward to going back for more. Idk about pastry crazes, first there was the cronut and now the cruffin, but apart from the hype, the cruffin's dough was light, buttery, and apart from the filling very good. 

Can't wait to go back and trying more things on their menu. The staff was very friendly and they're reasonably priced.
author: Yasmeen G.

description:
A delightful treat for the sweet tooth. My team ordered pastries from here and absolutely loved their savory danish, chocolate croissants, le donuts, strawberry jalapeno brioche, and ube puffs!  My favorites were the strawberry danish and ube puffs. It was such an awesome way to kickoff a Friday morning and a birthday celebration. 

Side note: I'd like to visit the bakery and try their famous cruffin! I heard the line for this is insanely long but totally worth it.
author: Clarissa L.

description: The savory pastry was absolutely incredibly. Flaky pastry with a sweet salty combo of bacon bleu cheese and figs. The shop was small but we were in and out quicker than expected. Staff was very helpful and informative.
author: Amalee C.

description:
it is worthed after all, I may have to witness the longest Q in SF. the cruffins are so limited that I woke up early morning to get it, i waited for about two hours because the cruffins are ready on 9 am, there is someone who will give you a sticker for them, each day they make different flavor.

warning: You have to be patient when you come late because the line is doubled even when they just open for about 15 minutes.
author: Bryan T.

description: Mr Holmes Bakery is a delicacy like no other! The pastries are constantly made fresh everyday and always sell out by closing time. There are different concepts of a pastry which they are known like a cruffin or a cronut! All the flavors are very tasty and satisfying to not only to the stomach but the eyes as well!
author: Nate L.

description:
Definetely worth the wait. I can see why it's so hyped now. I went with two friends today and we already knew the flavor of the day was chai spice from their ig acct so we were pretty excited for this flavor. We got there around 8 and there were only 2 people in line. Next time i'll probably come a little later because there was still not that many people around 8:30 so dont rush to come early if you dont have to! You have to get 6 to get those cute boxes so I got one cruffin (although now i wish i got two), one strawberry filled donut, one white choco hazelnut filled donut, 2 ferrero rocher choux bombs, and one ham and cheese savory danish. 
Chai spice cruffin($4.50): SO GOOD, it was super flake and crusty but tasted buttery and sweet, they definitely were worth the wait 
Strawberry donut($3.5): it was pretty good and they are bery generous on the filling, the donut was pretty heavy! 
White choco hazelnut donut($3.5): TASTES LIKE NUTELLA!! Also a lot of filling and the outside was still fluffy, even 10 hours later! 
Ferrero rocher choux bomb($4):not really a fan of but my brother enjoyed it a lot. Also tastes like nutella, there was just way too much filling for me
Savory danish($4): highly recommend, i ate this after i tried all the other pastries because i just felt sick from eating too much sweets and this was perfect for that! Salty and buttery and super flaky as well. 
I will definitely be coming back for maybe a matcha cruffin or another flavor i like.
author: Celine C.

description: It was good, but It's definitely too expensive and not worth waiting in a line over 15 minutes for. Best thing was the pull apart monkey bread. Everything else was fine, but when considering we spent as much money and time as we did for pastries that were just "fine", makes me think I probably wouldn't return. I'd take Bobs Donuts with barely a line and much better price-wise any day.
author: I S.

description:
So, I woke up at 7 am just to come here, because I had heard that they run out of stuff pretty fast. And because my office is not really very close to where the bakery is. And I was thoroughly disappointed to find that cruffins are available only after 9 am. Sigh. The one thing everyone raves about, the one thing that I woke up and made a long trek for, was not even made yet. I resigned myself to settle for something else, mentally making a note to deduct an entire star from what could've been a perfect 5-star rating. I got the amelia aman, the raspberry danish, and the maple almond bostock.

The aman blew my mind: it was glazed, flaky, and just perfectly sweet. And the danish was excellent. But the bostock was the one that made me give them a 5-star rating. If the stuff that they say is the second-best is so good, I wonder how good the cruffins are. I'll let you guys know, I'm going there again next monday :-)
author: Avadhut P.

description: Yes this place is hyped up and all over Instagram. I totally understand why. We waited about 15-20 minutes at 9am. I recommend going as early as possible because they sell out. We got the cornbread muffin, it has spicy peppers and gravy on the side. OMG. SO GOOD. Also got the blood orange cruffin. I'm not a huge pastry fan, but the dough was not sweet the sweetness was from the sugar dusted on the outside. Perfect. Had the chicory and cherry donuts too, great. The only thing that was just okay was the matcha dipped croissant. I love matcha. It just tasted like white chocolate. I love their tag line. Got my mom a tote for Christmas. Will def go agin
author: Amy D.

description:
I got the cruffins, donuts, and the choux. To my surprise, the donuts were the BEST!! It is worth that much for a donut! The cruffins were still good. The flavor I got for the day was raspberry and lemon. It was a bit tarty for me, but the crispiness made up for it. I did not like the choux too much. It was so sweet compared to the other 2 pastries. 

I would definitely go back if I'm in the area!
author: Annie L.

description:
The line was 30 deep.  We waited and waited to occasionally get the fragrance of flour, butter and sugar baking in the distance.

We bought 6 items: Prickly Pear and Sticky Bun were the best.  My kids would probably say the cruffin.  

Would I wait in line of 30 deep again for these baked goods... No, 12 peeps tops.
author: Dawn E.

description: Found this place through Yelp while visiting San Francisco. Came here on a Monday morning around 9 AM. We waited in line for about 5-7 mins. The place itself is very tiny so don't expect to get a seat unless you're first in line! My friend and I both got the cruffin. The flavor of the day was cherry coconut. I'm not a huge fan of cherry flavored things so I was kind of expecting it to taste bad, but wow was I wrong. It was the best damn pastry I've ever had. If I lived in San Francisco I would definitely be here every morning! Must try if visiting.
author: Vanesa V.

description: I love love love pastries.  I will drive 2 hours for pastries.  That's how crazy I am about yummy buttery dough.  When I arrived, there was a line out the door.  It is a pretty small place with no seating area.  I wanted a chocolate croissant.  However, the people in front of me ordered the last croissant...:(  I had the peach donut.  My husband had the hazelnut cruffin and my daughter ordered the plain croissant.  My peach donut had way too much cream.  I had to toss the cream that oozed out of the donut.  My husband said the cruffin was a bit dry.  My daughter's croissant looked flaky and buttery.   She didn't complain about it.  Too bad the food didn't meet with my expectation.  Maybe I will need to give it another try at a future date.
author: Mei W.

description:
Had the day's Boston Creme Pie cruffin and it was pretty much worth the 1.5 hour wait. Also had the strawberry jam one which wasn't as yummy only because it was so sweet. I guess it depends on the flavor of the day so definitely check out the week's flavors on their social media every Sunday! 

Got their chocolate chip cookie and Amelie Amann which were both yummy too! Coffee was a bit too acidic for my taste tho.
author: Lisa L.
Jennifer C.

description: Holy diabetes!  This place is beyond decadent.  We received a beautiful white and gold box filled with Mr. Holmes goodies from a friend of ours as a gift.  Our super awesome friend chose for us a couple of donuts in a cup and 4 croissants (strawberry and green tea matcha).  The donuts were amazing--I definitely would not pass these up the next time I visit.  The croissants were pure buttery, flaky goodness.  The strawberry ones were my favorite.
author: Beth K.

description:
On some very good advice, my partner and I embarked on an early morning adventure to check out the much talked about Mr Holmes Bakehouse. And boy, did it not disappoint! Can't say that I've ever lined up for baked goods before, but I can see why.

We visited on a Monday morning. The bakery itself opens at 8am, but the infamous cruffins do not hit the shelf until 9am. We arrived roughly 40min prior to cruffin time. So we took some time to take an obligatory selfie infront of the fluoro lights, and bought some of the other goodies to keep us going before lining up for cruffin time.

For a Monday, the line grew pretty heftily so we were lucky we decided to still get in early.

We went overload on our sugar breakfast, but it was worth it. We tried the salted dark chocolate cruffin, pineapple mango and cherry doughnuts, the choux, and the Blueberry bostock. Everything was amazing. We were very impressed that the fillings were extremely generous. The custard was a delicious consistency and the salted chocolate in the cruffin was in particular TO DIE FOR. Perfect combination of salty and sweet. I never thought I was a fan of cronuts. And this may be because back home, I've not had a good one. This cruffin however was perfect. A pastry flakiness, soft and not hard or over cooked. Well covered with sugar. A lot of filling. Amazing. The cream choux was our second favourite. The thick cream was like a cream cheese. Delicious flavour and so fresh. Followed closely by the pineapple mango filled doughnut. A perfect dough consistency - soft, chewy and fresh with a lot of filling - delectable custard with great flavour.

The coffee was pre-made. It was ok, something to keep you going whilst waiting in the cruffin line. But nothing special. 

Service was the only thing that slightly let the whole picture down. Whilst the team were efficient and answered all questions, it would be a refreshing compliment to the amazing food if it was at least service with a smile. Nothing would suit the cool and chic air of the store like some bubbly, cheerful service. That and perhaps a coffee machine with some equally great coffee beans would see for an excellent overall experience here. 

All in all a good time had, and can't wait to return.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Believe the hype, Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is pretty darn amazing!  Is it worth driving to the TenderNob for? Is it worth standing in line for?  Is it worth spending $ on? Yes! Yes! and Yes!

Truth be told, I am a sucker for sweets and I am usually willing to wait in crazy long lines for the latest craze.  Heck, I made my husband take the subway w/ me on our last day in NY for some cronuts.  Thankfully, the line for Mr. Holmes is nothing compared to NY's and I like how my native hometown have much more selection too! :) I know they are here to stay!

While I prefer my kouign‑amann elsewhere over Holmes' amelie amagn, I come here for their other amazing goodies such as the infamous cruffins, CA rolls + savory fares, and donuts.  What's so special about a donut you may ask?  While something as simple as a donut can be easily over looked, Mr. Holmes makes them so onolicious that it reminds me of the yummy, fluffy malasadas I've had in Hawaii.  My very first Holmes donut was their Salted Caramel and I was immediately hooked the moment I took my first sugary bite - delicious and not too sweet with filling oozing out.  I've been a fan since and have gone back to also try out their Passion Fruit, Strawberries n Cream, and Vanilla donuts, all very tasty and bursting with fresh flavors as well.  My only disappointment was that my passion fruit donuts weren't as filled as the rest.  Not sure if it was because I came on a weekend for those but I bought a box to share with friends and they all had the same complaint, they were only able to get the filling in one or two bites and the rest was more like a plain malasada.  Other than that, the passion fruit flavor we were able to taste was still great.

Now onto the savories, I don't often go into a bake shop expecting them to master both their sweets and savories but Mr. Holmes does both so well!  I love how the CA roll pays homage to the Japanese culture and if that is not available, give either their mushroom or artichoke croissants a try, those will blow you away too!

Saving the best for last, how can I forget the cruffins?!?  The idea of a croissant + muffin hybrid is genius and in my honest opinion, way better than a cronut since it's not as oily.  Plus, the amazing fillings Mr. Holmes comes up with to stuff each of them, I'm in love!!  I've stood in the cruffin line 3 times so far and my current favorite is their Super Matcha Kruffin.  Anything matcha is always great, but when you top an already delicious cruffin with a matcha marshmallow, how the heck do you beat that?!?  While it sucks that I am only limited to 2 unless I bring an entourage with me, I think the system is fair in allowing everyone to try a piece of this heavenly sweet.  It's nice that they are consistent with the times too, they come out at 9am sharp every morning.  I do suggest that you get here earlier than 9am to stand (if not start) the line but if you get a chance to come on the weekdays, I have gotten pretty lucky with getting some even arriving shortly after 9.  Plus, it's great conversing with fellow sweets fans in line, I even met someone that came all the way from Seattle to check it out!

Thank you Baker X and his staff for constantly whipping up new flavors to keep all of us Holmies addictively excited!  :)
author: Janetto L.

description:
I've tried to get a cruffin on 3 occasions now but to no avail. I guess the only way to do it really is to get in line by 7am on the weekend. I doubt that will happen but we'll see.
They do offer a number of other delicious goodies that are overlooked bc they aren't as novel as the cruffin though.

Croissant - You know a croissant is well-made when you cut it open and see a perfect honeycomb crumb. It has a lightly sweet glaze on the outside, which made it that much better.

Amelie Amann - Their rendition of the kouign amann. Essentially croissant dough baked with an outer coating of sugar. It was buttery and delicious, but I personally still prefer b. patisserie's kouign amann.

Almond Bostock - Brioche topped with frangipane. I highly recommend this baby. It's very buttery and absolutely divine.

In order to get that cute Mr Holmes box, you need to buy 6+ items which really isn't hard considering how bomb everything looks. 

I came at 12 one time after brunch on a Saturday and there were literally only two items left. They close whenever they run out, so I recommend getting here at around 10 if you want to pick from a variety of pastries rather than whatever they have left.
author: Lucy N.

description:
California croissants (smoked salmon, nori, etc) are where it's at. The croissants are flaky, perfect, crunchy, everything. Some of the best ever.

Kouign amann is bomb for the sweet treat.

I've tried a bit of everything with various friends. I don't remember anything I didn't like (maybe the caramel one was a bit much, but that's a matter of personal preference). Twice-baked croissant too!

I haven't gone to wait for a cruffin or whatever is the hot thing nowadays. I don't think hype makes something taste better than any other thing. They've got the basic foundations down, and I like to enjoy that. Perfecting a craft that many do, but not everyone does so well.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Like a TL crackhead, I got myself up to the bando right as the sun was coming up for a fix. Avoided any lines or annoying/pushy tourists. Go Early. Go on a weekday. Be Swift about what you want and GTFO. 
I'm not into sweets, but good LAWD. Tasting Mr. Holmes baked goods while baked was a transcendental experience. Make your toes curl good.
author: Chelsey G.

description:
Cruffins got sold out when we came around 10.30am. Cruffins came at 9am and they recommend us to come at 8.45am. Sad. Need to come back.

Still got almond maple toast, passionfruit donut and blueberry brioche. Almond maple toast was bomb. Passionfruit donut is too sour and too much sugar on top. Blueberry brioche is simply too sweet.

+1 star for bathroom! Wash those hands people!
author: Inez J.

description: Awesome pastries! Definitely must checkout! The line is long in the mornings, and they tend to run out pretty quickly, so get there early.
author: Jay M.

description: My favorite Instagram account! So witty, so playful and creative. I HAD to try these beautiful pastries and get baked in San Francisco. Unfortunately the social media is better than the goods. The chocolate chunk cookie was so overly sweet I didn't eat more than a bite. For the sweets lover in me, that's saying a lot. I'd say go once to get your photo but that's the best part.
author: Marie M.

description:
Alright cronut part two...let's do this. Obviously if I endured the line for the cronut on the east coast, I will for sure be doing it for the cruffin on the west side. This review is if you are going on a weekday. I was going to attempt to do it on a weekend but when the opportunity arose where I didnt have to wait 1.5 hours with a "shorter" line, then I was all for it. I am a a crazy person and I was planning to spend all day in SF so I made the trek from San Jose to SF on a Thursday morning. I left at 7:30 and arrived a little before 9am.There is plenty of parking on a weekday that you have to pay for but you may have to go a block or two away. The whole process will take you less than an hour. I got in line and there were about 30-40 people ahead of me. Yes, it is true that there is a separate line for cruffins so if you want the other goodies, then you can skip the line. You are limited to 2 cruffins at a time. There are so many options to choose from and likely you will be purchasing the actual box for all your goods. I didnt get to the front of the line until 9:30 so much sure you give yourself enough time. I am so sad they ran out of the double baked croissant so if you have a friend, make sure they get it first and then they join you for the cruffin line. I spent $30 on 7 pastries. Jeez. There is a small area where you can stand at the counter or sit on those stools. It was a nice experience to have but I dont think I would endure the lines for pastries. I go for the hype...on to the next!

1) Cruffin- Yes this is why I came here. That day was matcha flavor. They do not tell you what the flavor will be that day but yolo. I am not the hugest fan of matcha so I just dealt with it. This is quite messy to eat and flakes will explode everywhere. To be honest, it is more of a croissant that is shaped like a cruffin. No crazy taste or anything but I respect the idea. Honestly, you cannot beat the cronut.
2) California Croissant- This is the salmon savory croissant which was nice to have in my mix of sweet stuff. This is good
3) Amelie amann- this is a tiny thing that is covered in pure sugar with more sugar inside. Meh
4) Caramel Donut- So much caramel in a basic donut
5) Choux Bomb- I had to get this because it was Ferrero Rocher flavor. The cream is exactly like that but since I didnt eat it until hours later, it was a bit soggy. Bloop
6) Brioche with blueberry & white chocolate- I liked the fresh blueberries. It was like something I had back in elementary school breakfast times. I think at this point I was all pastried out.
author: Amy H.

description:
Delicious creme filled pastry, but not sure if it will make "cruffin" a thing. Its more just like a pastry to me.

It tastes wonderful, but I definitely don't think its worth coming early in the morning to wait for. There are plenty of equally good bakeries in SF.
author: Cynthia X.

description:
So sad.  I tried (but traffic sucks) to get here in time for a cruffin.

Well at 10 am they sell out just about every day.  Get there at 8:300 or forget about...

So we got the Amiele Amann : damn good.  A compact croissant with a creme brûlée exterior.  And sweetness inside.  A must try.


The blueberry white chocolate brioche bomb meh.

Passable.

Anyway why don't they make more cruffins?  Clearly they're in demand!!! Like enough to sell through lunch perhaps!?!? Seriously why ration them, share the love!!! The poor tourist like myself can't always make it in time (8am??) for the beloved cruffin.

Maybe next time.
author: Crystal M.

description:
Really wanted to be a fan but...

waited in line about 7 people deep who were greeted with welcoming enthusiasm. After biking my butt up Larkin to finally check this hyped-up place out I get a blank "what can I get you?" Got the California Croissant to see what it was all about, ube-flavored anything intrigues me so I asked how the Ube Puff was and got a seemingly canned "it's delicious, like a unicorn something...blah blah blah" response (#millennials) ordered it anyway for curiosity sake, and got a white chocolate filled doughnut per the other worker's recommendation. 

- California Croissant - satisfies sweet/savory teeth...I wonder if anyone actually puts the soy sauce on their croissant
- Ube puff - only hint of ube was the purple coloring of the filling
- White chocolate doughnut - sugar bomb but not in a bad way
=$13

Hipster af, would probably kickass if they were located along the Embarcadero near In-n-Out, dig the innovative flavors.
author: eVa J.

description:
So hyped, but probably worthy of the hype. I'm not about that wait though. Especially not at 9 am.

Tip: I like the savory items more than the sweet.

Tip 2: Take a selfie!
author: Joe Z.

description: Great pastries nice atmosphere defintley a return
author: Nancy C.

description: Sadly didn't get what we came here for, must've forgotten somehow or didn't see it, but the Hong Kong milk tea donut and the sea salt chocolate chip cookie were yummy! Next time we're definitely coming back for the cruffin like we meant to!
author: Larissa L.

description: We got here around 10 am and they were already sold out of a lot of things. I got the chocolate chip cookie, and it was one of the best I've ever had.
author: Angela H.

description: Got there at 10AM on Saturday morning, and of course, the cruffins were sold out. We got donuts, California croissant, pan au chocolate, kougnigaman. The donuts were excellent, while the rest of the stuff we got were just alright. I would only recommend cruffins and donuts.
author: Deja V.

description: I hate that I love this place. I waited in line for over an hour to try the famous cruffin. My hope was that it wasn't worth the hype so I never have to wait in line again. Well, that delicious little thing has me dreaming about it.  The flavor of the day was strawberry lemonade and dang it was good!! This is a must try place. And yes folks, I'll wait in line over an hour again. I'll just make sure to bring a book or browse Amazon.
author: Katie W.

description:
Got there a little before 10am and they were already sold out of cruffins!  so bummed, but got a bunch of other treats. 
Got a SAUSAGE HAND PIE with rosemary, it was delicious. It was definitely in the precipice of too much salty, but still very good. The SAVORY DANISH HAM and CHEESE had mustard and mayo under layers of dived up ham with a blanket of melted cheese. The croissant part of it was the amazing! So fresh, flaky, and buttery. Everything I dream of when I bite into a croissant. I also got a box of other goodies to try. Will update this after I scarf them down!
author: Diana L.

description:
Overhyped and overpriced. I don't think I have ever paid 4$ for a croissant until I came here.
I had a matcha green tea croissant and the frosting was a bit too sweet for my taste.
author: Mei Z.

description:
This is only for the Salted Caramel Cruffin I got one Friday this year!!! 

Got there at 845am, line already hella long, BUT took our chances because many reviewers have said that when they open at 9am, it usually sells out by 9:20am so I figured we still had a chance.
