And we got one of the last ~20 cruffins so I was super excited! Then I learn the flavor of the day was SALTED CARAMEL I felt like I won the lottery!! 

The cruffin is everything that I imagined it to be - soft, crispy on the outside, croissant like texture, but it was super messy to eat !!! Sugar and flakes everywhere! You can't eat one wihtout a mess hahah The salted caramel pastry cream was heavy and delicious. But alas, this is a novelty thing that I will only eat once. But I am convinced their other pastries are just as good too - someday I will return!
author: Annie K.

description:
This was really just A-OK. hype didn't live up. I found the cruffin dry. Meh.
Attempted 3 times. First 2 were sold out. 
I did like the bread pudding.
author: Dee N.

description:
Everything is super yummy here but they are really pricey, all pastries range from $3.50 to $5 a pop. Bakery opens up shop at 7am, everything but the cruffins are out and cruffins come out at 9am with a limit of 2 cruffins per person.

For those who don't know what a cruffin is, it's a crossiant x muffin. Shaped like a muffin, filled with cream but has a flaky croissant exterior as opposed to your typical flour and egg muffin mixture. Very much like a churro too as it uses a cinnamon and sugar dusting! Flavors varies everyday, check their website or instagram for weekly flavor updates!

Pastries:
-Cruffin: Tastes like a churro in terms of flavoring but has the flakiness of a crossiant and the burst of sweetness like a jelly filled donut. Yummy but if you don't like super sweet stuff, you might not be able to finish the whole thing. Somewhat hard to eat too because the filling tends to leak out as you bite in, 
-California Croissant: A croissant filled with a sushi roll served with a packet of soy sauce on the side. I prefer to eat this without the soy sauce. A little bit odd but it works.
-Pesto Turkey Danish: OMG, it's so good, I've had a bite of the brown ale onion one and that was tasty too. I can only suspect that ALL of their savory danishes are super yummy. You can't ever go wrong with danishes. 
-Donuts: Donut flavors varies everyday, you can also check the daily donut flavor on their website or Instagram! Had the lychee donut and was surprised the filling wasn't tooth aching sweet, it was actually really yummy! BF had the Guinness chocolate donut, said it tastes like Guinness at first and then the chocolate sweetness kicks in and cancels out the bitterness of the beer! WOW!
Strawberry Jalapeno Brioche Bomb: Wow, this thing packs a tiny kick to it. Most jalapeno flavored stuff don't have a kick to it but this thing does! I really liked it, the bread was nice and chewy and filled with just the right amount of jam!

Verdict: 
Definitely grab some pastries from here, you'll find yourself inhaling the whole thing and suffering from food withdrawals once you realize you've devoured it all!

Tips:
-Get here early, preferably before noon.
-Get the cruffin if there are any left, if none, get anything else, everything is just as yummy!
-You need 6 or more items to get one of those fancy smancy boxes!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Finally made it out to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse and it has been hyped all over social media, all over town. I agree with the hype. 

I came here on a Saturday and made sure I was in the right line. There's one for just Cruffins and then a line for everything else. 

If you want to come, come with another person. They hold your spot in the Cruffins line while you can go get some other goodies. The regular stuff opens up earlier than the Cruffins. I must say it's SO smart of them to do this, sell out of most of their regular stuff and then when the cruffins are ready, they are sold out and can close shop for the day. Smart! 

Cruffins are one flavor each day (supposedly) and you are limited to two per person (drag some people with you if you want more than two). The day we were there it was a Torched Meringue Coffee Creme Cruffin. It was really good but for me, the meringue made it too sweet. The coffee creme wasn't super sweet so it was nice. It's super flaky, kinda hard to eat, but if you're at home and sitting with your coffee, no big deal. 

Also, I heard they aren't selling wholesale anymore so I think the bakery will have more goodies for everyone. 

Ok, I will be first to admit I am NOT a breakfast fan, nor a pastry fan at all. So when I say I didn't hate any of the items I got, it's saying a whole lot. 

Sushi Croissant: I was most intrigued by this. It comes with a side of soy sauce, which isn't needed because it borderlines a little too salty. BUT I loved this. It was delicious. I wish I was the one who woke up thinking... let's put sushi into a croissant, genius. 
Ham & Cheese Danish: Delicious, it comes with a dijon mustard sauce. 
Artichoke Danish: This was really yummy. Filled with artichoke and a gravy underneath. 
Passionfruit/Banana Donut: Ok, I'll admit it was kind of hard to tell the flavors of Banana but once you ate the passionfruit one, you knew which was which. It's kinda like a filled malasada. Delicious, but I'm not a super fan of the sweetness. 

I'd actually come for the regular stuff over the Cruffin. While it was good, I think my palate is just geared for the savory than the sweet. My mom, however, LOVED the flakiness of the Cruffin so I'll be back in that line to pick her up some. 

Yum!
author: Jeannie L.

description: This is an overrated trendy place with rude employees. I went early in the morning, there was no line, and the woman working behind the counter barely acknowledged us. We ordered a couple things because all the pictures on Instagram invited us. We were thoroughly disappointed. You would think that first thing in the morning your donut would taste fresh, but it was definitely old. There are far better bakeries in San Francisco. Don't waste your time here.
author: Ritza A.

description:
Updating my review to say mea culpa. The prices on the receipt reflect the pre-tax price, from which when you add 8.5 or whatever % to it, equates to the price displayed on the placards in front of the baked goods. Notwithstanding this admitted stupidity of mine, I would like to say that Mr. Holmes is still as delicious as ever, and that even though their pastries are slightly more pricy than the average baked good, it is well worth it. I don't know if it's worth standing in line for 1+ hours for, but it is definitely worth standing in line for up to half an hour.

Their savories are definitely not as good as their sweets. Whereas their sweet pastries are an amalgam of delicious flavors intermingling in a genius and pleasant manner, the savories that I tried only seemed to have one flavor, which was salty (not that it was too salty or anything, it's just out of all the flavors, it just tasted like salty toppings, on delicious fresh-baked bread)

From my old review, this still stands:
The pastries are delicious. Definitely something you'd want to enjoy on the same day you buy it as the crunchy crispy glaze on almost everything will be gone after a few hours. Nonetheless, it's still delicious next day, but definitely not the same.
author: Joshua L.

description:
Hear me out as to why Mr. Holmes was a 3. 

They've got the most important element down... The baking. Sadly the cruffins were long gone by the time I go there. The savory potato leek Danish was flavorful and so flaky it crunched with every bite. Apple honey bostock- comforting custard goodness. Strawberry jalapeño brioche bomb? Most interesting combination of flavors with a kung-fu kick, could be 15% moister though. Donuts and chocolate croissants were equally on point. 

What was seriously unfortunate were the unfriendly and snarky employees, who were impatient to our questions. How dare we ask them what flavors the donuts were and what were their favorites! 

If they were labeled individually with each flavor and not just generally labeled under "donuts" we wouldn't have to ask you. 

It was incredulous how two employees were yelling at the customers on a Saturday morning.  If you can't be joyful at a bomb pastry shop at 10:30am maybe this isn't your calling.
author: Sophie L.

description:
Didn't get to try the cruffin because I am clueless and dumb and didn't know they sold out upon being taken out of the oven at 9. I should have researched before driving up to sf from sj. Haha. BUT! BUT! BUT! Although I was unable to try the cruffin just yet, their other baked goodies were absolutely divine. Like wow! If the other "not as popular" pastries taste this great, I couldn't even imagine how amazeballs the cruffin tastes. Looking forward to a bite of that guy so badly. 

Anywho, there's street parking everywhere. I parked. Got out and ordered the vanilla creme donut, chocolate caramel donut and ferrero rocher thingymabob. All melted in my mouth with such delight!!! Ermergerd. I want some more right now. If I lived in sf, I'd be there every morning to start my day off right. Ugh. I'm drooling thinking about these baked goods. The service was accommodating since I seemed completely lost. So thank you for being patient with me although there was a line!

Thank you so much Mr. Holmes! I've been baked!!!!
author: Kim N.

description: Damn this is a dope bakery. Ube poptarts????? The items are not only fun but delicious. The boxes are so fancy. The line down the block. The famous sign " I got baked in San Francisco" is a must visit. They are famous for the Cruffin which is a croissant / muffin hybrid. New items in all the time and the food is just delicious!
author: Andy N.

description: The sweets are just ok to dry and last days baked and the service needs to learn how to work.  I'm always impressed by how the owners are not around and wonder why the business goes under.
author: luis j.

description:
My friend and I got up early to come here and get the popular cruffin. The flavor of the day was cookies and cream which I was excited about. There were two seperate lines. One for cruffins and one for the others items. I first decided to get the california crossiant and a white chocolate donut. Then we went in line for the cruffins. The wait wasn't too bad but it wasn't short. 

I thought the white chocolate donut wasn't that great. It just tasted like a regular donut that was filled with some type of custard. The california crossiant was actually really delicious. It's basically kind of like sushi in a croissant. I've never seen anything like it so it was cool to try. The cruffin was really good, but I actually expected more from it. I might have set too high standards for it but it did taste great but not spectacular. 

I think another thing besides the cruffins that drew me to this place was the I got baked in San Fransisco sign. It's a great place for a photo and kind of the focal point of the store. Overall, its a good place and I think it is worth coming to at least once.
author: Grace C.

description: The line was out the door when we came on a Sunday morning around 9am, as per other reviews - get there early. They were out of Cruffins but we were not disappointed in the least! They had plenty of amazing offerings. We ended up getting 6 items for the two of us to share. It was a rainy day and yes, we stood in the rain without an umbrella for about 20 minutes or more just for this goodness. Definitely a spot to see when you are in town.
author: Amy S.

description: Thanks to other helpers for letting me know to wake up early! Unfortunately I was still too late to get a Cruffin. I told the cashier I came all the way from Portland for one, and he said "hey girl I work here and I don't get any either" lol!!  I did appreciate the humor actually. The only thing I didn't like was the location. It's a little, umm, gritty for me, and I live in Portland where it's about as bad as the Tenderloin . But regardless, I'll be back to try again. The donuts had way too much filling for me. I want one of those sweet baby cruffins and won't stop till I get one!
author: Morgan J.

description:
Okay okay, after my third attempt, I finally was able to get myself out of bed at 7am and try this place. 

Okay, idk if we just got lucky or if people are exaggerating on their reviews but my friends and I went on a Sunday, got in line for the Cruffins around 8:10am and we were like a couple feet away from the beginning of the line. The line got longer around 8:30 and even still I feel like they didn't run out of Cruffins until like 9:30. 

The Cruffins does live up to its hype, but I honestly think it's one of those things that you just need to try at least once and you're good. 

We were able to grab some of the other pastries they had. Sucks that you have to fall in line again to get those.. But the Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb & the California Croissant were my favorites. I would definitely come back for those anyday.
author: Krystelle D.

description: Great donuts, cool location and friendly staff!  I went in around 9:30am on a Wednesday morning, only two other customers in the store so I was in and out.  Ordered one of each of the donuts, I think one was chocolate and the other a hazelnut filling....not really sure.  Wish they would of had a berry or fruit filled one but, just another reason to go back and try more flavors!
author: Reggie B.

description: Long line but the pastries are BOMB. especially the savory bread and danish. I would recommend going in the morning when they open to get the fresh batch.
author: Maggie H.

description: Came here with friends from out of town a few months back. The place is cute and in an area of the city where finding parking isn't too bad (definite plus!). I was glad to see that this wasn't your average overpriced basic donut flavor place. The prices were good and all of the pastries were different combinations you'd be hard pressed to find elsewhere. We ended up hitting this bakery twice in a weekend and was about to go a third time but I had to rush them to the airport. My favorite was the jalapeno strawberry(?) pastry that was enthusiastically recommended by the young and food loving staff. Glad they did because the flavors were intricate and smooth. Make sure to take the compulsory pic with the "I got Baked" neon sign. It can feel a little cheesy since everyone does it but it does make your Instagram look really good!
author: Erica L.

description:
I made it a mission to come here. I've been wanting to try this place for the longest time after seen countless mouth-watering photos of their pastries, especially their cruffins!!! Just dreaming about how they would taste... omg. Visiting this place has been on my list and I am so glad I got to finally try this place. A cruffin is basically a croissant + muffin, hence CRU-FFIN. Cool huh? Their cruffin flavors changes everyday so you will not know what cruffin you will get! This makes it more exciting and suspense, hahah! Definitely try to go on a weekday. I heard the lines on the weekends wrap around the corner! :O I made sure to set my alarm clock at 8am sharp.. didn't get up til 8:30.. IT'S OK, didn't matter, I got ready 10x faster. I needed to get those cruffins!

My boyfriend thought I was crazy waking up at 8am for pastries. BUT I had to do what I had to do, and of course, drag him along with me. Tag team duo. We left the house around 9am or so. The cruffin line starts at 9am. I was reading the past reviews as we were driving there and was afraid there wouldn't be any cruffins left! My heart sank and my anxiety went up. 

We got there around a little after 9:30am and quickly got out of the car! There was a line, however it was short to my surprise. ^___^ There were about 15 people in front of us. And as we got closer to the front of the line, I peeked through the window and was ecstatic to see about 40 cruffins left!! WHOO. OMG. Super duper relieved! I had to contain myself to not make a scene.. did not want to look like a crazy lady being overjoyed by pastries.. 

Each person is limited to just 2 cruffins. Today's flavor was flutternutter! This was a peanut butter + marshmallow cream inside topped with peanut butter fluff + chopped peanuts. Pretty good. I was really hoping for the matcha cruffin because I love matcha... but it's okay, because I will be back on the hunt for that flavor! I was happy with the flutternutter. It was flaky and yummy. The cream was not too sweet! However, I did not really taste the marshmallow mix, it definitely tasted more peanut buttery-- but I would come back to try the other several cruffin flavors. I also really wanted the box that comes with the pastries. If you order 6-7 pastries, you get the box. So of course, I had to get the box, duh. 

Along with the cruffins, we got the amelie amann, choux bomb, banana cream filled donut, coconut cream filled donut, and a negroni cream filled donut. The negroni was my least favorite. There is alcohol in this one. You can taste the alcohol in the cream so I was not too big of a fan... The banana and coconut cream filled donuts were pretty good. The banana was my favorite out of the three brioche donuts. The donuts just had the right amount of sweetness! The choux bomb had a slight taste of ferrero rocher. It was not very strong. Additionally, there was way too much cream in the middle and the cream was just eh. Overall, I just thought it was okay. The amelie amann was crispy, good, and flaky. However, I did not think it was anything spectacular. 

You have to come here at least once, to at least try their cruffins. It is pretty pricy... so beware... Don't be surprised when your box of pastries come out to be $$$... your wallet may be crying but you will be oh so happy that you got to try this place LOL.

Yay for Mr. Holmes!
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I was very determined to get some cruffins this past Sunday and it was a success! 

After 2 failed attempts prior, I had a game plan. We would sleep over our friend's place on Saturday night and wake up early to get some fresh pastries. Got to the bakery at 7:40am in my pajamas thinking we will just be in and out, but I was so wrong. There was a sign there that said the cruffins wouldn't arrive until 9am (should have read the Yelp reviews lol), so we waited in line. I watched the line for future visits and if you arrive around 8:30 (maybe it was a slow Sunday though) then you shouldn't have any trouble getting some cruffins. They usually sell out by 9:30-10am on the weekends, so be early.

We had the chocolate chip cruffin and it was good, but so much muffiny though. The custard is a flavorful without being too sweet and perfectly flaky as a croissant. I would like to try other cruffin flavors, but it wouldn't be the end of the world if they sold out. 

Other pastries worth trying: Sweet Onion Danish is a great savory pastry with a crunch, California Croissant is interesting but it doesn't taste awful, Ferrero Rocher choux bomb is flaky not too sweet deliciousness, and the filled donuts were light and fluffy. 

The only thing we would pass on is the coffee, maybe it was a bad batch but it tasted burnt.

I hate waiting for food, but its worth waiting in line at least once or maybe twice. :)
author: Mimi N.

description:
Mr Holmes Bakehouse is BY FAR my favorite bakery in the city. I've came here a few times after my workout (it's right around the corner from 24-hour fitness... yikes!) to pick up a few pastries and a cup of Sightglass coffee. I suggest to go early and on a weekday because it's less busy and there's still a fair amount of pastries around noon.
I've tried nearly everything on the menu (yes, including the infamous cruffin) and they are all top-notch. But my all-time favorite pastry at Mr Holmes is the plain croissant. Fluffy and light on the inside, flaky and buttery on the outside- I have no complaints. If you love a simple croissant with your cup of joe every morning, you MUST try the plain croissant. I promise you will not be disappointed!
author: Amelia C.

description: This place was awesome... two lines. One for cronuts one for everything else.. if you aren't there in time to get a ticket for the cronut line no cronut.. we all got an assortment.. monkey bread was amazing, the chocolate donut was a little heavy with the cream inside but still really Delicious.. strawberry jalapeño was delicious as well!!
author: Lindsay K.

description:
CRUFFINS specifically are only available starting at 9am everyday even though they open 7am weekdays and 8am weekends.

If you want to guarantee your chances of getting a cruffin, start lining up around 8:45am (on the weekday) right before they come out. Everyone is restricted to 2 cruffins per person. Be aware that the weekend will require you to line up even earlier.

So I came last Friday right at 8am which was nice because meters don't start charging until 9am. Cruffins weren't out yet but we got to buy some of their other popular items. By 8:35am there were 2 separate lines outside, one for cruffins and one for the general pastries. 

Now onto the pastries that I've had the chance to try the 4 times I've been here!
- Strawberry Milk Shake Cruffins: Cruffins taste very similar to cronuts, it's just their shape that resembles a muffin. The strawberry cream filling was so good! 
- Coffee Cruffins: Mr. Holmes usually changes his flavor daily now and only provides one flavor a day. The coffee cream filling and the visible flaky layers of this beautiful pastry really stole the show. I actually like this flavor more than the strawberry one.
- Matcha Strawberry Cruffins: really like this combo but the strawberry overpowered the matcha a bit.
- Chocolate Hazelnut Cruffins: this tasted like a Ferrero Rocher in every bite, pretty amazing!
- California/Sushi Croissant: Definitely recommend trying this if you like salmon! It's like a fun fusion between the French & the Japanese.
- Artichoke Croissant: I actually waited to go home to heat this up which made it taste way better. I wish they would have the option to heat these up for us here...
- Donuts: We had 1 vanilla cheesecake and 1 salted caramel donut. They were great donuts but I probably would skip on these next time in comparison to the other selections.


(NOTE: I GOT PLAYED! So right before I got into Mr. Holmes to redeem my cruffin, this girl appeared out of no where stating how she ONLY wanted to get the other pastries and NOT the cruffin. Since the line for no-cruffins disappeared, I felt bad. She even swore she wasn't trying to play me so the part of me that believed in humanity let her through. Behold she left with TWO cruffins...usually I hear Mr. Holmes gives out stickers to the cruffin line folks in the front but I think they might have forgot?)
author: Kathy L.

description:
pretty pricy... but really really good pastries! 
When you walk in you can see the back of the bakery where they make their pastries. Very small store and simple with the "got baked in san fransisco" light sign. Great location to take your girlfriends fir that IG pic... @instagramhusbands!
warning: hard to find parking.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Worth the wait and the hype! My boyfriend and I ordered everything, like the little piggies we are, and everything was delicious! There wasn't one pastry I did not like. 

PARKING: 
Street parking. Kind of hard to find. 

FOOD: 
My favorite pastries were the cruffin, of course, all 3 of the savory pastries, artichoke, bacon, and mushroom, the cookies, and the donuts. Everything was amazing, even after a couple of days. Of course we couldn't finish everything in one day, so whatever was leftover we stuck in the fridge and ate the next few days after popping them in the oven. The cruffin was crisp and flaky on the outside and soft and creamy on the inside. The flavor of the day was orange creamsicle. I really want to try to matcha flavor!! The savory pastries were so so so delicious. The pastry was flaky and the middle concoction was sinful. The doughnuts were on point, especially the banana flavored cream. 

My boyfriend and I came here around 8:40 AM on a Sunday and there was already a big line! We probably waited an hour to get all of our pastries, but I would be glad to do it again for these delightful pastries. XD
author: Stefanie K.

description: As good as you think it's going to be. Waited a few minutes and then got right in. Took the food to the Alcatraz docks and had three people ask where we got them because they looked amazing.
author: Brandon W.

description:
I guess you could say I'm famous. My lifelong dream of being on TV was fulfilled when I was interviewed at Mr. Holmes Bakehouse. I have this clip recorded if anyone's interested. But sorry, I don't have time to sign autographs right now. I must give my undivided attention to writing this review, because this place is DOPE. 

My friend stumbled upon it when it first opened, and urged me to try this amazing cruffin- a croissant muffin, not to be confused with the cronut. I started following Mr. Holmes on Instagram, and it was obvious they were really starting to gain traction. You can no longer stroll in to pick up some cruffins. It's an intense competition now.

IF YOU'RE READING THIS, IT'S NOT TOO LATE: The bakery opens at 8 AM, and I suggest you get there early. Two lines are formed- one exclusively for cruffins, the other for everything else. Cruffins come out at 9 AM, and they sell out within the first 30 minutes. You are limited to 2 per person. If your mission isn't the cruffin, you can sleep in- there are plenty of other baked goods.  

My friends and I snagged 6 cruffins, a Ferrero Rocher choux bomb, lemon poppy seed bread, vanilla custard donut, apple cinnamon scone, berry citrus tart, Amelie amann, and white chocolate blueberry brioche bomb. 65% of that was for me. They don't even like sweets that much, but hey, we got on TV, so everybody's happy.

The cruffin flavor of the day was honeycomb caramel. It's truly DIVINE and totally worth the wait. When asked to describe what it tasted like during my interview, I told the ABC news correspondent, "It tastes like a sugary croissant." I swear it was the editing that made me sound like an idiot. It looks like a muffin, but the similarities stop there. The dough is light and flaky with a cream filling, dusted with sugar and topped off with MORE cream. It is not easy to eat given how tall the pastry is, and it will leave a trail of crumbs on your face/hair/shirt. We were asked to take a bite on camera, and I'm so relieved that ended up on the cutting room floor. Really, NOBODY looks graceful while eating. 

If you can't get your lazy ass out there before cruffins sell out, don't leave disappointed. The vanilla custard donut, berry citrus tart, and Ferrero Rocher choux bomb are all marvelous! Or there's always TaskRabbit. The staff is exceedingly nice, especially the adorable co-owner who seemed both embarrassed and flattered when I asked him for a photo. 

I got baked in San Francisco, and now I'm hooked.
author: Karen S.

description:
Cruffins are overrated. When I came here, flavor of the day was peanut butter and jelly. Never a big fan of PB&J, but Mr Holmes can't yet change my opinion. I came around 9 am, the sunday of pride parade 2015. Waited in line over 30 mins when someone told us that my party of three is the last batch to get the cruffins (if everyone is buying two each) 

Since I was waiting to buy cruffin, my sister went over to the other side of the line to buy other baked goods (yes, there is a separated line for that!). The Salmon Croissant was a delicious, savory breakfast croissant that I would definitely come back for. 

The design of the shop is really cute, but really small and people have to wait outside. Unlike Dominique Ansel's boutique in NYC, you can't really sit inside and chat while eating your baked goods.

Will definitely come back to try the green tea cruffin cuz I am a believer. Lol.
author: Cindy M.

description:
This place is the bomb. The Cruffin is phenomenal in its crispiness and flakiness together with the cream filling. A must try but be prepared for the 8.00 am line to get a 2 max per person coupon to buy it.

Also try Tartine Bakery & Cafe for comparison.
author: Keo N.

description: Successful cruffin mission without a line at 9:50AM on a Tuesday and wanted to let eager foodies know that it doesn't justify the wait.  It's just a croissant with cream.  Scooping out the custard from one of the filled donuts to eat alongside the kouign amann is essentially a deconstructed cruffin.  It'll taste the same but double the price due to purchasing the filling and shell separately.  However, no wait and you can go play!
author: Amy J.

description:
I want to try them all. The cookie is very best. Sorry I have not had here. See you again 
Mr Holmes Bakehouse...
author: Hkc V.

description: Nice bakery with creative pastry flavors. I just don't understand the lines. It's good but not worth standing in line for a cruffin at 7am on a Saturday morning for an hour. I like that they release weekly flavor updates on instagram so I can swing by when I want to try a unique concoction they have whipped up. It is overpriced but that hasn't stopped me from visiting every now and again.
author: Diana A.

description: I managed to get in one day before the line, otherwise, I would never have stopped in. I don't recall what I had but the pastries were pretty and tasty.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Best advice: 
Go early. Weekdays will probably be your best bet. I can't imagine how the line would be on a weekend.

Cruffins:
They open at 8am however cruffins don't come out 'til 9am. Got here around 940ish Thursday morning and by the time I got to the front of the line around 10ish, there were only 8 cruffins left. Limit 2 cruffins per person! Felt bummed for the guy in front of us who brought his own container to fill with cruffins only to be told he could only have 2, lol. He was from Vegas, by the way. Anyways, they make 1 flavor cruffin a day. Hope to try the matcha green one day lol but this time it was the chocolate cherry cruffin. Pretty darn good but not something I'd go out of my way for numerous times.

Donut with filling:
Reminded me of malasadas from Leonard's Bakery in Oahu, Hawaii. I loved the passionfruit and banana fillings! 

Coffee: 
They serve sightglass coffee. $2.5

Overall:
If you have some patience, definitely worth a try!! Go for it!!
author: Crisgel B.

description:
It is easy to give this place 5 stars, because the food is SO delicious. I will give one caveat: the cruffin is VERY good and I'm glad I got to try it. (This past Friday, it was caramel creme.) But I don't think I'll wait an hour in line again for it. Their other stuff is just as good and there is no wait - generally - for that stuff.

On two visits, here's what I've had:
-Amelie amann - their version of the kouign amann, with rose pistachio filling, is divine. Crispy, flaky, and sweet. This is what a kouign amann should always be and rarely is.
-Butter (plain) croissant - so simple, in theory, but so hard to pull off. They rose to the challenge. One of my favorite croissants ever.
-Doughnut - clearly a brioche dough, and so much better for it. Puffy, soft and pillowy - yum! Went with salted caramel filling.
-California croissant - who would take a california (sushi) roll and replace the outer layer of rice with a croissant? These guys! And it's delicious.
-Cruffin - fantastic! Crispy, flaky croissant dough, coated in sugar and then filled with a flavored cream. How could you go wrong? You can't, with them.

For the future: want to try their chocolate chip cookie, the almond croissant, the chocolate croissant (pain au chocolat), and some of the danish.
author: David B.

description: The 'Cruffin's' are worth the wait in line......but everything else in the bakery is 'top of the line' also, so if you aren't in the mood for waiting, just go in and load up on some great bakery products.
author: Dave L.

description:
Cruffins: Croissant in a muffin shape, filled. The filling varies day-to-day. The particular day I went, it was PB&J.

We knew where the bakehouse was when we saw a line. They don't sell cruffins until 9am but the line forms prior to that and you're only allotted 2 per person. Bring a chair if you'd like. The line doesn't move until 9am. There's a line for purchasing cruffins and there's a separate line to purchase everything else. I don't like that you have to stand in line for a cruffin and get in another line if you want any other baked goods, coffee, or merchandise. But, it works. 

The baked goods are good. They're busy so you're not getting old, stale shit. Cruffins are messy and are good to try but I didn't stop and think I need to do this again tomorrow.. Although! it'll be a different filling.

And the shop is cute.
author: O M G.

description:
I didn't have any definite food/restaurant plans for my trip to California, except for Mr. Holmes!  I had discovered them on instagram and really wanted to go there.  Luckily I did on my second day!  

My friends and I got a later start to our morning than anticipated and decided to go to Mr. Holmes for breakfast. I had known about the cruffin from instagram, but I didn't know if there were rules or anything like getting a cronut (ie when they start selling them, if there is a limit, etc..) so we just showed up.  We got there around 8:30 and there was a small line formed outside the store.  The store itself is pretty tiny, and it was open up for customers to buy anything except the cruffin, which they start selling at 9:00. So we got in line, which wasn't too bad, although we went on a Thursday morning so it might be worse on the weekends.  I went in and got something to hold me over till 9:00. There were so many good looking options, but I went with the ham and cheese danish. It was really good, and had a nice flaky crust.  There was even some mustard in the middle, which I normally hate, but I didn't seem to mind too much and easily finished off the whole thing.  One of my friends got an interesting croissant. I think it was called the California croissant and had seaweed, wasabi and tuna inside.  It looked like it also had some seeds on the outside.  I didn't try it, but my friend enjoyed it. Another friend got a regular croissant which I had a bite of that was really good!  It was sweeter than I would normally think of a croissant being, and I really liked that.   

Then 9:00 rolled around and they started to serve their cruffins!  That day's flavor was creamsicle, and it was so good!  I just got one for myself, it didn't seem like they had a limit on how many you could buy.  I asked them how many they make each day and they said about 130-150, and they usually sell out in an hour.  So if you want a cruffin I'd say get there early. I think when we got there at 8:30 we were maybe 15th in line and more people kept coming after us.  

I really liked the cruffin.  It was nice and crispy, and flaky!  The filling was really good too, and not too much of it.  Go early to try a cruffin, but really just go anytime and try something!
author: Rachel W.

description:
I was headed to the city to play some tennis, so decided to get up alittle early and try this place out.  I got in line about 8:35 am on a Saturday and it was almost to the corner.  I was not sure if I would get their infamous cruffin or not.  Reading the reviews, I guess people line up about 7 am..WOW!!  Anyways, aboout 10 min til 9am, a worker comes around and passes the "golden sticker", which guarantees you to a minimum of 2 cruffin.  Note:  DO NOT LEAVE THE LINE!  There were people who left the line to line up on their non-cruffin line and realized when they got back to the cruffin line, they missed out.  I think the last person who got the last cruffin was in line at 8:50 am.  Maybe I was lucky to get a cruffin to come at 8:35.  It may be different depending on the weekend you go.

So, I got my cruffin and the flavor was chooclate carmel!  How did I like?  I liked it, I didn't love it, but I liked it.  Oh ya, I got to the front to get my cruffin at about 9:30 am, so not bad of a wait.  The cruffin was flakey and alittle messy since it is a crossiant shaped like a muffin with chocolate in the middle and carmel and chocoalte on top.  Once I got my cruffin at the cruffin line, I went to line-up in the non-cruffin line to try their other pastries - I was not going to leave after waiting in line for just a cruffin.  So I picked up amelie amann and a scone.  The amelie amann was nice, sticky and flakey and the scone moist.  Both were surprises and I would defitnitely come back and get them again.  

Overall, it was a good foodie experience.  Here are my final thoughts:
 - Cruffin:  It was good, not great,  I would come back if a friend wanted to pick one up.  It iis alittle gimcky / novelty to line up and try it out.
 -  The Box:  They have the nicest box to put your pastrries in!!  The best than any bakery I been to - seriously!!  The only issue with the box is that I wish they had a cruffin holder inside the box to hold up the cruffin.  One of my cruffin tilted and the filling would spill out..=(
- The employees - awesome.  Very friendly which made the experience even so much better.
 - The Other pastires - excellent and I would swing by again to pick them up again.
author: James L.

description:
Together with Tartine, the best places for fresh dessert or breakfast. For Mr Holmes, go before 10 am, for the best pastry, the cromuffin, both super moist croissant, crunchy and with deli filling that you can choose.  Fresh bakeries are hard to find with this level of freshness and taste.

Ps. A quien madruga, Dios le ayuda ;)
author: Natalia D.

description:
Moderately priced, but delicious!
Pro-tip: go earlier in the day or they'll run out of most items

The cruffins are definitely a novelty. I've only been once and may go back, but I wouldn't go there all the time. It's fun to try, but not worth the long lines. T

The place is small, but has great aesthetics for all your Instagram food pics! Very trendy and cute marketing tactics. 

Light-Up sign reads: I got baked in San Francisco ;)
author: Zahra H.

description:
SO worth the hype!

Thanks to the many suggestions and reviews on Yelp, I got the lay of the land before arriving last Friday morning on my quest for a cruffin.

Left line, for cruffins, right line, all the other pastries.

We got there around 8:15, and divided and conquered. On this morning, I was 7th in line for the cruffins. The pastry line moved pretty quickly and pretty soon we were able to enjoy some filled donuts and coffee while we waited. 

Bring a jacket, because it sure gets chilly standing there for an hour.

The cruffins come out at 9:00, and they start selling them about 9:15. Each person in the line gets a sticker, and each sticker allows you to purchase 2 cruffins.

Must have:
Filled donut - I had the banana one and the passionfruit one. YOM.
Apricot croissant pastry (danish)?? - SO GOOD. Not too sweet, crispy, flaky, just right.
author: Uyen D.

description:
You need to know they open at 8:00am but cruffins aren't available until 9am. They take credit cards.
About 25 people in line at 7:50am just for non-cruffin pastries.  Once they opened, that line moved SUPER slow as people tried to decide what to get. Another line formed to the left of the door just for cruffins.  A lot of people split their party to get in both lines. By 8:30ish the cruffin line was pretty long.  Once going, that line moved quick because they only make one flavor and you're limited to 2/person.
We tried the salted caramel roll, ube thing that's shaped like a pop tart, and the cruffin flavor-of-the-day: banana/coffee/toffee.  All were rich and buttery and tasty.  Glad we did it once but it was expensive, and with drive time, it was a two hour commit. Wouldn't do it again.
author: Yelp Y.

description:
I was incredibly blessed to receive a box of Mr. Holmes goodies from a friend during finals week. Maybe this isn't a totally fair review on account of the fact that I've never been into the store, but I felt a need to express my love and gratitude for the cruffin. It's a crispy, sugary croissant-muffin hybrid filled with ooey-gooey goodness. I am usually not a fan of fruity mystery custard, but it was excellent stuffed inside the cruffin. The other assorted pastries that filled the box were just as tasty and unique as the cruffin. 

Now here's the thing about Mr. Holmes, the early bird (and ONLY the early bird) catches the worm. The cruffin is usually sold out by 9 or 10 AM so you better set your alarm if you want one. You could also be waiting awhile to get your sugar-high, so bring a friend or spend some time catching Pokemon. Part of the hype about Mr. Holmes, if the hype itself. It's part of the experience to get up early, wait in line, and finally get your box of treats. If you're visiting SF, it's a must! Plus, once you get in, you can take a picture in front of their iconic "I got baked in San Francisco" neon sign. I promise, your Instagram followers will not be disappointed.
author: Nani S.

description: It can be relatively quite a few twist and turn to get to this situation.  It's like some of the nicest looking building  in a ghetto nearby.  The donuts had been great.  On a first seem normal the whole lot appears overly candy,  however, it wasn't.  The taste is very decadent. The wonder stage is just proper.   Nevertheless,  i would not go back again,  in view that it's relatively highly-priced.
author: Paige C.

description:
Probably the best bakery I have ever tried in the U.S.  Their signature pastry, cruffin, is the closest thing to what commonly is defined as an orgasm. Pardonnez-moi, I'm European, deal with that. 
The Ferrero Rocher choux-bomb is my guilty pleasure, and you should definitely try both of them at least once in your life. 
Last but not least, croissants are delicious as well. 

That said, you must be here early in the morning. The line is enjoyable since everybody is craving for this deliciousness. And it's absolutely worth it.
author: Marco B.

description: This place is amazing!! I've never been into the shop but I've ordered a bunch of things from them online for my company and it's soooooo yummy! I would definitely recommend them to anyone who has never gone into their store! Warning though, it is pretty pricy.
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
Amazing spot in the city with a great assortment of yummy pastries! 
I have been wanting to try this spot forever, and when me and my boyfriend finally visited San Francisco, I demanded we go here...and definitely glad I did! They make their items daily and have new items every day that are tasty and unique! We grabbed a peach-apricot donut and the ham & cheese croissant and OH MAH GAH they were soooo good! We brought these goodies to Dolores Park and enjoyed them in the afternoon sun. 

I would definitely recommend getting here early so that you get them extra fresh and so that they don't run out! They sell fast and have a limited number of items that they put out daily.
author: Jackie P.

description:
People can be so unreasonable sometimes. This place has the best cruffin in the city. I don't understand why people are whining about the wait and service? I know Yelp exist for review but dont you think you are taking it little bit too far? When place is busy, wait kinda expected and that's just the nature of San Francisco. The staff are super efficient and there are so many different flavors you can choose from when it comes to pastry. Coffee is not that great but Jane on Larkin is block away so you can head there to get some caffeine. 
For people who want to try to come and reading the review, check them out anyway. As i said people are whinny and look for perfection all the time. No ones perfect and so are you. If the food is great and service is efficient, what more do you want?
author: Solongo B.

description: Meh overrated. Just like the cronut in NYC this place is just instagram worthy. Though the dulce de leche churro crossaint was amazing. Thats the only thing I recommend getting. Their donuts were ok the mexican chocolate he recommended was nothing special. The actual cruffin was blackberry flavored this month. I was not a fan of the tart filling. Very sour. The box is 87cents if you dont buy over 6 pastries and the bag is 10cents. Waited in line for about 30 minutes they move fast. Cruffins dont come out till 9am.
author: Prima Z.

description:
Great croissants here, although I didn't get to try the cruffin.  I also kept with the dominant theme and got a ham and cheese croissant pie (don't know the exact name for it).  For taste alone, five stars.  For waiting in line and a high pricetag, minus one star.  Also I was disappointed with the selection, but that could be because I had come after peak hour (100+ people in the queue).  

I'll update this when I finally try the cruffin, but will it be worth a 30min wait?
author: Ben K.

description:
I did not get the cruffin.

Despite the strategic advice from the owner, I just couldn't make the early morning line. If the supply ever increases and/or demand decreases, I'll try again. In the meantime, there are equally amazing and creative pastries on offer, which incidentally also sell out before noon. 

I got the California croissant, which is a croissant sprinkled with Japanese rice seasoning on the outside and stuffed with salmon wrapped in nori, with pink ginger. It was not as weird as it sounds and not surprisingly, tasted amazing. The super flaky buttery croissant did not hurt either. I thought the $5 price tag was reasonable for the skill and fish.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Mr. Holmes had about a dozen baked items on display behind a plastic shield. all priced. huge cookies @3

brew: sightglass coffee(2.5)
-smooth but not silky, a little roughness, not sure why
3ish stars
eats: california croissant (5)
-looked dark brown, not sure why, overbaked? 
flaky but not buttery
-stuffing was baked salmon, wasabi, nori, ginger
insides tasted better than outside

crumbs:
-no seating available,
-friendly, fast service.
-pastries pricey, not sure which is their specialty.
author: Victor G.

description:
The cruffin was everything. 

My friends and I got super lucky on a Saturday morning. They arrived around 9:30ish, waited for 20 minutes or so, and there were 5 cruffins left for us!! The limit is 2 per person, but we decided to share one among the three of us so we could try more pastries. The cruffin of the day was filled with banana cream - so amazing. The texture and taste are very similar to a cronut - flaky, buttery, and covered in sugar. But it's even better than a cronut because of the delicious cream filling inside. The only "muffin" thing about it is its shape. 

We also tried the amelie amann (like a kouign amann with pistachio and rose) and a donut (their second most popular item) filled with banana cream or passion fruit that day. We opted for banana cream because of how good it was in the cruffin. The amelie amann was good, but doesn't compare to B. Patisserie's kouign amann, but the donut was almost as amazing as the cruffin! Can't wait to come back and try more pastries and cruffins!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
I just came from there and finished eating my Cruffi... Well, I had to write a review. It was the most worth it money I have ever spent in San Francisco. They cost $4,50 each, and you can get "only two", but literally, it was the best thing I ate around here.

I got there around 8:40am this Sunday, and I was the last one to receive a sticker ensuring that I would get a Cruffin. But after me there were still around 20 more left, so if you get there a little "late" (around 8:50am on a Sunday) you may get one. As I was the last one, I was able to put my hands on my Cruffin only at 9:30am, but no complains about that.

The Cruffin is delicious, it is made of a kind of croissant dough and it filled with a delicious cream inside that varies in flavor each day.

Please, don't miss it if you are in San Francisco.
author: Mateus N.

description: I love San Francisco,  I love this bakery. By far the one I have been in including Paris!
author: Lynn A A.

description: A must try in SF! Beautiful croissants and amazing berry cruffins. Walk in at 9 am on weekday and wait only for 5 minutes.
author: Hantien W.

description: The fact that this spot is now in the downtown area/financial district is AWESOME! While visiting we had to stop on by to beat the lines. As you come around the corner and close in on your destination you can smell the sweet scent coming from Mr. Holmes. This is your alternative to a sweet treat or breakfast. Their pastries are amazing. Of course we got half a dozen of different types. We tried a mango jalapeno filled, monkey bread, smores, & an apricot & jalapeno pastry. All of them were amazing. Line or not this is a spot you should def checkout when you come to San Fran!
author: Kevin Z.

description:
I'm an avid foodie adventurer so any food related endeavor that can acclimate new boundaries for taste naturally I will gravitate to. I am also writing this review hyped up on coffee as I wait in line.

I woke up at 7:20 after sleeping at 1 am grumpy with myself "you're fuxking dumb waking up hella early for a fucking pastry" yet there I was first in line for a cruffin at 9am with $30 worth of pastries hanging in a bag with two boxes off my arm. Frankly I don't even like pastries but the uniqueness and craft of the Cruffin is rather enticing, especially if you appreciate cooking (or baking) and I read that it is an extremely intricate process of cutting and layering the dough to master one (which is why they can't come out right at 7am). I was also excited to know that there was a hidden gem in the neighborhood that called for attention, as my brother tweeted me an article about it on CNN the day prior which prompted my decision to embark out in my pj's (http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/03/travel/cruffin-shop?sr=fb040715cruffin1aStorygallLink).

The wait:
On a weekday and esp if you live in the city, you can mosey on over between 7:40-8:00 and be one of the first in line (at least the day I went) or show up around 8:15-8:30 for a more moderate wait. I imagine showing up closer to 9 you'd still be okay, but on a Friday or weekend I hear it's much more difficult. There are two lines (the cruffin line and cruffin-free line) on the weekends but getting the other pastries or waiting in line for them if there is one goes by fairly quickly and the taste value is worth almost as much as a Cruffin in my opinion.

Post Cruffin:
Overall, if you're crazy enough to stand in line for one, you truly won't be disappointed. They were heavenly delicious to me in particular. It was a perfect, crisp, croissant on the outside with a delicious soft filling on the inside. The flavor of the day was Mandarin with Vanilla Custard. I think it's such a better binge than a Cronut, which I also stood in line for at Domnique Ansel's bakery in New York.

Other delicacies: 
The plus side is that the bakery opens at 7am and if you don't care to wait for a Cruffin, they still have so many delicious pastries to try. I would not pass up on the salted caramel donut (or any filled donut), the Amelie, and maybe the ferrero rocher brioche bomb. I was also a fan of the almond croissant.

Good luck getting baked!
author: Stefanie Rae A.

description:
So glad I heard about this place....it's the bomb! What can I say...out of this world delicious! If you've eaten a croissant in Paris any croissant outside of France usually disappoints...until you come to mr holmes!

Today's offering of cruffin was PB & marshmallow & I was a little disappointed as I didn't think I'd enjoy it that much...well I was outright wrong. It was SO DELICIOUS! First the croissant was phenomenal-fresh, crisp & perfect as a croissant should be...then comes the filling! Perfectly delicious without being sickly sweet & the filling didn't just stop at the 'muffin top' - it went all the way to the bottom. 

I also sampled the passion fruit donut which had a deliciously tasty real passion fruit filling.

This place is the real deal & we're so lucky to have it in SF. Credit cards taken, 2 cruffin limit per person.
author: Nicole E.

description:
I am not really sure what possessed us to go to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse one Saturday morning but we did and we waited almost an hour to get our goodies.  Not only do you have to wait in a ridiculous line in a seedy part of town but you need a sticker if you want to guarantee yourself a cruffin.  We didn't have the sticker but we got two cruffins anyways.  Also the staff seems friendly and nice and took the time to come out to graciously explain to everyone the process with the stickers.

We had two sightglass coffee cruffins, one blueberry brioche bomb, one amelie amann, one banana donut, and one passion fruit donut.  We finished them in two days.  

The pastries have flair and novelty.  They make baking innovative and fun.  The cruffin was definitely yummy. I prefer the banana donut over the tart passionfruit one.  If you like fun desserts that are posing as pastries then you will love this place. if you are more of a purist, then maybe not so much. I still like the kouign amann from b patisserie. I still prefer donuts from krispy kremes (i know i know) but where else can you get a cruffin? they are crispy, sweet, chewy on the outside, soft and filled with luxurious cream on the inside.
author: claudia y.

description:
I finally got to try this place as it's like russian roulette with the weekend flavors. The whole experience was great! you do have to get there early if you want a cruffin since they hand out stickers to those in line, which I didn't know. Another thing I didn't know was that you have a limit of 2 per sticker. While waiting in line, we decided to order some pastries (you can walk right in). My favorite would be the Turkey Pesto Danish. I would come back for this alone! Everything else I tried was good, but wouldn't make me crave for it. 

As for the star of the show! We got the Cookies and Cream Cruffin and it was amazing! I thought it would be too sweet with all the filling, but it wasn't at all! The cuffin itself was very light and airy. Since I didn't want to eat the whole thing, I wanted to see how it'd hold up over time. I ate it the next day and it was still good!  I will most definitely come back!
author: Linda H.

description:
Decor: 4/5
-Small bakery with limited room to eat

Service: 4/5
-Friendly and patient

Food: 4/5
-Box of six pastries for $26
-My favorites were the chocolate croissant and filled le donut 2 followed by the apple honey bostock
-The others I tried were California croissant (smoked salmon, wasabi, ginger, nori) is unique however not something I would purchase again. Turkey pesto danish was medicore in flavor. 
-I was unable to try the cruffin due to flight departure time. I will update the rating and review when I do
author: P H.

description: Had the donut with the pineapple filling. LIFE CHANGING. definitely worth the wait in line!!!
author: Nikki M.

description: They were good donuts that were light crispy.  The walk was a little long from the subway but all and all I would go again.
author: Katie B.

description:
Heaven in your mouth in the form of a strawberry cruffin. Literally. I can't. 

Time: 8:15am, Sunday. Raining. 
Players: Myself and best friend.
Action: Waited in the pastry line, friend hopped into the cruffin only line. Burn both ends of the candle if your smart. 
SCENE 1: pastries, if you want a box you have to get six. Not a problem. Nabbed two filled donuts, one vanilla one salted caramel chocolate. Nabbed a ham and cheese croissant, fab. +whatever they bring out. Approx $3 each. 
SCENE 2: joined the BFF in the cruffin line. Two per customer  (sharing is caring people. Limit the greed). Worked out perfectly, staff put on a great cruffin show. The pastry chefs came out, super awesome to see the hands of God's. 
SCENE 3: Instagram-Famous 

Grabbed philz coffee on the way home and paired with mimosas. I can't even move the food coma is glorious. Do it. The line is absolutely worth it. Even in the rain!!!
author: Melanie T.

description:
Woke up early to wait in line for an hour and a half for Mr. Holmes Bakehouse cruffins.  Verdict?  Wish I had stayed in bed.  So not worth the wait....cruffins are tasty enough but their operation is terrible.  They open at 8, but cruffins aren't available until 9.  So they constantly have 2 lines...1 for just cruffins and 1 for everything else.  I asked the person at the counter why that was and she said because it takes so long to prepare the dough that the cruffins are literally still in the oven when they open.  What?  That just makes no sense to me.  All your other croissant-like pastries are ready right at 8, why can't you just start earlier with the cruffins?  I'm not a baker so forgive me if I'm a bit ignorant about the process but it seems that they make it so much more difficult then it has to be.  

To make matters worse, their Square wasn't working properly, so they were taking so long to ring up people.  Maybe they should consider using a proper POS system rather than Square...you know since they're now global and all.

Pastries are fine but definitely not worth the long wait.  I'd pick b. patisserie instead for better quality pastries, better service and a better experience.
author: Tina P.

description:
As others have mentioned, Mr. Holmes only makes 1 flavor of cruffins each day. You wont know ahead of time what the daily flavor is. You just have to go early, wait in line, and hope it's a flavor you like.

The first time I went, the daily flavor was chocolate cherry. The second time, it was white chocolate blackberry. I'm not the hugest fan of chocolate in my pastries, but still enjoyed the chocolate cherry cruffin. However, I LOVED the white chocolate blackberry cruffin. Also amazing? The amelie amann. I will always pick up a few every time I make it to Mr. Holmes (especially since they limit you to only 2 cruffins per customer).
author: Cici A.

description:
I came here two weekends in a row! The first time, we came way too late (I think around 11:30 am?) and I foolishly asked if they still had cruffins. Then I realized that you have to get there at least by 8:30am to secure a spot for the elusive cruffin. So naive! My friends and I got a sausage roll, a banana donut, and a chocolate chip cookie. The sausage roll was a bit too salty, but the banana donut and cookie were delicious! The donut was the highlight.

The second time, I was determined to get the cruffin. My boyfriend and I ran up and down some hills before running over to Mr. Holmes so we could earn our treat. Thank god we did that because we ordered SO much for two people! We got a couple green tea cruffins, a California croissant, a ham and cheese croissant, a strawberry donut, a choux bomb, and an apple puff pastry.

Green tea cruffin - bomb. It was so incredibly flaky and the green tea filling wasn't too sweet at all. Definitely worth the hype.
California croissant - I was really excited about this, but it was way too salty. The croissant itself was extremely delicious, but the salmon filling was too much. They even provide soy sauce on the side, but that would've been sodium overkill!
Ham and cheese croissant - hard to screw this up, but it was good!
strawberry donut - good, but a bit too sweet. I preferred the banana donut.
Choux bomb - SO GOOD. I love Fererro Rocher, and they nailed the flavor. Wasn't too sweet.

I didn't get to try the apple pastry because we gave it to someone else. Overall, this is a great bakery, but there are some hits and misses. I feel like some of the fillings are too salty or too sweet. The pastry itself is delicious, but the filling can be too overwhelming. I wouldn't be able to finish the sausage roll or the California croissant by myself.

Also, everything was SO BEAUTIFUL. The pastries, the decor, the boxes...definitely picture-worthy.

I would come back for their cruffins, the choux bomb, and to try some of their plainer stuff!
author: Lisa N.

description:
An excellent example of when an excursion where the instagram ended up being the best part. 

I had a blueberry vanilla muffin and a cup of coffee. It was $6 for the 2 items. It was okkkkk? How often do you really get blown away by pastries in the US? 

Super cute shop but I wasn't wowed and I feel ridiculous for eating a muffin which took up most of my days calories. I understand the hype but it isn't for me. 

The staff was sweet!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
The cruffin was stellar. The fact that I got the last one made it that much better, I feel bad for the 40 people lined up behind me because they didn't have any more coming out soon. 

I also had the caramel filled donut, it was good but not anything I'd wait in line for again. It was fluffy but the caramel filing was rich and overpowering for myself. One of the bakers said she liked the passion fruit one, maybe next time? 

All and all it is a cruffin experience, as everyone on Yelp has already said.
author: Casey S.

description:
Mr. Holmes is an institution and "local tourist" spot. It is probably the most adorable bakery I've ever been to. They have and very instagramable neon sign that says I Got Baked in San Francisco. So cute and so appropriate. 

To get their famous cruffins, you need to be in line by 8:30 at least. They start serving their cruffins at 9 am and there is a whole separate line for a cruffin. You are allowed to buy 2 per person. I recommend going with someone who can stand I  line with you. That way one person can go ahead and get some of their other pastries for you to enjoy in line while you wait for the cruffins. We went on a Monday and the whole experience took us about an hour.

The 3 stars are for the instagram photos you will get, their big crunchy cookies, and their yummy homemade pop tarts. I didn't love the cruffins. They were nice and flaky but seemed a little dry to me, they were hard to eat, and you wait for an hour and only get one flavor choice. I'm pretty sure I'm the only one in SF who doesn't worship them, though. It's a cool experience,  I'm just not looking to go again.
author: Kari G.

description: Got here at 8:30am on a Th to get in line for cruffins. The line was about 10ppl deep, and that grew quickly as 9am approached. The cruffin of the day had a coffee-custard filling with blueberry topping-- definitely a surprising combo. Everyone in my group got blobs of sketchy looked goop on pants/shirt/face...guess that was an indicator of pleasure? I think I would have preferred a richer true custard on the inside though. The next time I go, I'm def going to skip the cruffin line before 9am and pick up their other equally tasty croissants and donuts.
author: Jean L.

description: I come to San Francisco for these baked goods its work the 5hour drive. The croissants are so flaky and buttery the place is well worth getting up in the morning...
author: Jordan R.

description:
I am a pastry lover, so I tend to be a little picky. I absolutely loved the pastries here. On the day I came, the speciality curffin (croissant+muffin) was passionfruit chocolate. Oh.My.Goodness it was amazing! The passionfruit filling was life changing! :) 

I would highly suggest coming here for a pastry if you are visiting or picking some up for your co-workers (they will love you for it!).

My next trip to SF will definitely include Mr Holmes Bakehouse
author: Alyssa K.

description:
Hmmm... I came here on a Monday morning at around 8.30am. No line, but I don't think there were any cruffins yet (not a problem as *shock horror* I did not go for them). 

I picked up a choux bomb, vanilla donut and an Amelie Amann. They were all quite delectable, but the choux bomb was definitely a little too rich for 9am; the donut perfect for a 4pm 'snack'; and the Amelie Amann good as a dessert the next day. The Amelie Amann was probably my favorite.
author: Kira G.

description: The donut creme filled donuts were worth the trip. Price is pretty accurate considering the amount of creme. There was no line at 10am on a weekday. High recommend going. One of my favorite donuts in SF.
author: Fernilla S.

description: Came early on a Sunday morning and left with a churro croissant, blackberry donut, chocolate peanut butter donut, California croissant, ferrero rocher croissant, chocolate croissant, and coffee creme cruffin. We went overboard, but we don't come around often so why not? The cruffin is basically a creme filled morning bun....delicious. Everything I had a bite of wasn't overly sweet. Make sure you come early or you'll miss out on the cruffin of the day.
author: Tara L.

description:
Mom made every effort to score some goods from Mr/ Holmes early in the morning (7:30), but only came out with a cranberry muffin for us to share that night at home. Mr. Holmes only makes a certain amount of goods everyday and once they sell out, then you'll just have to deal with it. Or if they don't have it yet because it's not made, then you're kind of out of luck too. The cronuts, which was on our radar, don't come out until around 9am according to the guy behind the counter.

That said, what we had was pretty delicious. The muffin had fresh cranberries and was incredibly moist and not too sweet. Is it worth a journey there? I don't know...there are many great artisan and pop-up bakeries in the city, but Mr. Holmes is definitely worth a stop by if I'm in the area.
author: Elaine Y.

description: This place is amazing! Worth every penny. Be sure to get here early because the line starts getting crazy even before they open. One complaint I have is they should stay open later for the tourists!
author: Felicia F.

description: Oh.  My.  God!  This is where the Sugar Plum Fairy has gone to die!  Got here at about 8:40 and waited in a short line for the much heralded Cruffins to make their entrance at 9:00.  In the meantime, enjoyed our coffee and tried to decide what else to fill our gorgeous boxes with.  Ended up with one each of the Strawberry and Coffee Cruffins (deliriously good), Amelie Amann (my favorite -- soooooo crisp and yummy), one each of the filled donuts (chocolate and salted caramel -- slurp!), and a California Croissant (Salmon, Nori, Wasabi, and Ginger -- a little scared at first, but oh so good!).  Staff is super friendly and helpful, very patient in dealing with customers trying hard to decide what to try while gazing frozen through glazed eyes.  Talk about a sugar high!
author: Lisa W.

description:
Never mind that Cruffin-they make many other items that will knock your socks off. Go in there and take ANYTHING with a criteria of either 'sweet' or 'savory' and be more than satisfied. The chocolate chip cookie with sea salt is simply amazing. 
The deal with the Cruffin: a lot of hype. You're just incapable of resisting the name, even though you have no idea what it is, or will taste like. They only make 200, there's a limit of 2 per order, so in theory 100 people a day take the lot. In mere minutes they could be gone. Don't worry about it. Have a Le Donut. Have that bread pudding. It's all really, really good. Every item they make is superior to the same named item ANYWHERE in the world. 
Tip: skip that line and use PostMates for delivery. You don't want to wait in line anyhow.
author: Richard V.

description:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9QKs1f7DN-w
@2:34 for my food porn shots of this place and the food! 

I never like waiting in lines, and most of the time it is not worth it - but in this case, it was worth it. 

This place is perfect for an insta photo (You instagrammers, you know what I'm talking about! Don't be ashamed to ask people to move out of the way to take that photo next to the "I got baked in San Francisco" sign. 

Food: 
We wanted to try the cruffins but came too late I guess (Yes, 11am is too late). 

Mango-Ginger & Blood orange donuts: (4/5) 
Love these donuts! I'm not a fan of filled donuts, but this had a very light custard that really tasted like fruit and not artificial crap. It really balanced out the soft, sugary outer layer of the donut. 

Bread Pudding (5/5) 
I love bread pudding. This was like portable bread pudding and I wish I could eat this everyday. 

Blueberry Brioche (5/5) 
Loved this too. It was amazing and soft and fruit dense. 

I just wish we didn't have to order 6 donuts in order to get a box, but whatever - we ordered 6 anyway just to get that cute packaging. 

Service: 
Friendly staff that were helpful in explaining what was what.

The wait: 15 minutes. Worth it. 

Parking: Street parking, hard to find. I ubered there.
author: Andrew L.

description:
This place is amazing.  All of these pastries are to die for.  Such great flavor and worth the wait if you have to wait in line. I think they lace there cookies with crack or something because I keep coming back for more.  I would def. recommend coming to this place for some good pastries!!

Thank you for making this Jew a happy Jew!
author: David F.

description:
Cruffins are delicious, but other baked goods are hit-or-miss.

First of all, their cruffins are definitely amazing, no matter what flavor! Filling is creamy and at the right sweetness level, and the pastry is baked perfectly. But I think the other baked goods are too expensive for what you get, which is a small-to-average sized pastry, with nowhere to sit and eat them. Some items are hyped up - I don't really get why their donuts are so popular, because they're not really that creative or sizable. Some of their pastries are definitely decent / pretty good, but I don't think they compare to B. Patisserie or Tartine.

Overall, I feel like this bakery succeeds off of its marketing gimmicks and the exclusivity/novelty of its cruffins. I'd recommend coming here for their cruffins only.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
Yummy cruffin, donut and salted chocolate chip cookie!
Had the strawberries and cream cruffin and it was yummy.  
I've tried many cronut wanna-bes before and this one is definitely one of the better ones although it doesn't really remind me of a muffin/croissant.

The cookie wasn't too salty and the donut had vanilla bean filling which was delicious.
author: Heejin L.

description: Loved their donuts! The environment is fun with their "I got baked in San Francisco" wall. This place has a fun personality.
author: Kremi A.

description: I actually like this bakery, but the relatively recent explosion in popularity it seems has made it a PITA to buy stuff here. Learned today that they have two lines now, one dedicated to cruffins and another for other stuff (don't think they did that a week or two ago). Wish they made that clearer to those of us who just got in line! Hopped in a long line ~9:15, the only one visible when walking south on Larkin, only to find out at ~9:40 that this line would stop being served after about 10 people in front of me says a staff member, and seeing a horde of 20 people behind me rush ahead to get to the other side of the door where a smaller line was hidden. I didn't even want a freaking cruffin. Probably could've had my baked goods in 10 min or less I'm guessing had this policy been actually communicated, rather than leaving empty-handed. Bah.
author: Linus W.

description: If you're going to eat a custard filled doughnut it should be from Mr. Holmes Bakehouse! Even after I swore off eating more delectables on this carb fueled vaca, I am really glad I kept my plan to visit. Mr Holmes does not disappoint! I had a mango custard doughnut that reigns in recent memory as the best filled doughnut I have ever had. It was perfect. My daughter thought the apple Danish with unpeeled apples, was a little rustic and dry for her enjoyment. My son demolished his Carmel roll so I'll assume he liked it. The chocolate croissant pastry was well cooked and the layers of pastry were crispy and sweet. I went at 7:20 on a Wednesday and it was already doing a brisk business with 4 people behind me. I'm glad I satisfied my curiosity!
author: Brenda G.

description:
My friend brought me here because he got a tip from a friend that the California Roll Croissant was the thing to try. I tried it and I can't say I like it. It is definitely creative and completely one of a kind. But that's it. I can make a banana-macadamia nut cheese pizza and it'll be special, but let's admit it; it'll be gross. My stomach also didn't sit too well afterward, and I'm guessing the salmon and the butter was all too rich and was sitting out in the cold.. My poor stomach didn't know how to digest it. I'd suggest anyone who is going to try the Calif Croissant to toast it up a bit before enjoying. Maybe you'll have better luck!

I also tried a bite of their Amalie Amann and it was really good.. Flaky with a lot of pistachio flavor but all I could eat was one bite because it was a bit sweet, and it was after that unsettling Calif Roll. 

I'd want to come back to give them another chance.. And try their other pastries but probably earlier in the morning when everything is still nice and warm.
author: Athena L.

description:
This review is based on my second visit here. The first time I came here it was a Saturday morning around 10 and the line wasn't too bad but their selection was slim. 

I tried again Friday morning around the same time and the Cruffins were sold out. Super sad. So if you want Cruffins... You better be there right when they open. 

I tried their croissant and apricot Dana and they were delicious. The dough the baker created was super fluffy and flakey, I enjoyed it. The croissant was different from most croissants I've tried. It had a sweet coating on top which set it apart from many others.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
Let's start off saying, the line for this place on a Saturday morning is intimidating. We got here around 8am. And there was already a pretty large line waiting. 
I repeat: THE LINE WILL BE LONG. 

But it is worth it! Be ready to gorge on delicious, flaky wonderful pastries that range from savory to sweet to cruffin-awesome. 

Word to the wise: There is a separate Cruffin line, which the shop owner puts a sign on the window to indicate. 

3 of us shared about...7 pastries. Don't judge, you'll do it, too. Make it an outing for not just yourself, because then you can only stand in one line, and while the cruffins are delicious and beautiful, my favorite was the artichoke heart tart. Freaking amazing. So, don't limit yourself, bring a friend, and be prepared to walk like 10 miles the next day to burn off the tremendous amount of calories you're going to ingest.
author: Ashley S.

description:
I noticed this place because of the huge line at 9am. I went at 9am on a Wednesday and waited about 30-40 minutes. Apparently, the cruffin is what everyone was waiting for and it's well worth the wait. The cruffin had a good crunch on the outside ,covered in sugar crystals and soft on the inside with a cream filling. They change the flavor of cruffin they have everyday. I had the honeycomb one which was delicious.

I also got the vanilla donut which was just okay. The savory danishes were very good as well with an herb cheese/meat filling. The pastries are kind of pricey (I got 6 pastries for $29), but it's good to at least try once and the pastry boxes are very cute!
author: Tanya Y.

description:
Whoa, just ubered 2 cookies on over from Mr Holmes Bakehouse and these sea salted chocolate chip crack cookies did not disappoint!  

Can't wait to visit the shop! Afraid of the damage that could be done there
author: Grace C.

description:
There is still a wait on Friday 30-40 min and lots of tourists. Choux Bomb $4 is very similar taste to Beard Papa but more pretty. I came in today 5/20/16 and planned to buy the cruffins but sold out at 10.15am as there is 200 cruffins per day.

2 staffs to help customers and 1 staff to stock the baked goods from the tray to display area. Not good enough for an expensive place charging $4-$5 per baked goods. The line moved very slow + only about 10 kinds of baked goods sold.

Worth to come here for the instagram pics only. I think :)
author: Jenni L.

description: If you want to try the good stuff you need to go when they first open because they sell out fast! We went an hour before closing and all they had left was butter croissants. We had originally just ordered two but since they were close to closing they gave us an extra one for free which was super nice of them. Can't wait to come back so I ca try their flavored croissants.
author: Danyelle P.

description: Yum, Yum, Yum! Worth the wait. You will need to get in line by 8:45 ish to get a cruffin. The staff was nice and friendly. They passed out stickers, 1 per person which allows you 2 cruffins. If you want a box you will need to purchase 6 items, which is easy to do.
author: Christina S.

description: Amazing is an understatement!!! The people were super friendly and has great recommendations.
author: Scott P.

description:
I have been living in the neighborhood for a couple of months and every morning I think of stopping by, but usually the queue dissuades me. Today as an earlybird I decided that it was the day, so I get some stuff with me.
I've only tried such a good plain croissant in that kind of cozy and always full french patisseries. The double baked almond croissant is crazy,  flaky on the outside and with a great combination of creamy strawberry on the inside. But Amelie Amann was perfect, as flaky as a croissant crunchier, maybe too sweet, but the soft inside without tons of sugar compensate the strong outside. 
The artichoke danish is also delicious. 
Now I'm not afraid of the line any more.
author: Inés E.

description: my friend got me the cruffin, and it was buttery, sugary, creamy deliciousness. i'd eat it again. i also ate some thing with salmon on the inside, which was only ok. the flavors were slightly off.
author: Xander C.

description: Great place! Cannot really sit in, but great for takeout treats!:) My friend and I split an elderberry/raspberry croissant and it was light, fluffy, and just the right amount of sweet. Very delicious :)
author: Cheyenne B.

description: Definitely worth going to this place. Would recommend going there again even though it might not be convenient to go there but their pastries are really good and they're really cute too!
author: Tiffany C.

description: Very rich, but a must have in SF.  Go with a lot of friends early in the day, and order a bunch of everything to share.
author: Maria J.

description:
So glad this place exists in the FIDI now! 
Like most SF jaded residents, I expected a huge line. However, this place was easy to get in and get out of. Delicious pastries (No cruffins) with a side of convenience. (I walked to the Larkin location a Saturday morning before. That is waiting in agony with a side of hand to hand crack deals.)
The guy behind the counter told me this morning that they won't actively advertise this location, but rather let the clientele grow organically. YES! A couple of more months of no frill delicious pastries!
author: Jessica D.

description:
Yummy. Croissant in a muffin. Croffin. It's an awful name that autocorrects to coffin. But... You might end up in one if you frequent this spot. Bwhahah.

Bon appetit!
author: Dejana B.

description:
Ok...I have had an amazing transformation as a NPC bikini body building athlete, but I still have some weaknesses.  My form of kryptonite = SWEETS.  So, of course, the moment that one of my bikini sisters told me about Mr. Holmes Bakehouse, I had to make the Saturday morning dash after my morning gym session (EARN THOSE SWEETS, FOLKS!).
