I totally did a face smash on a Strawberry Vanilla CRUFFIN after back and biceps.  OHHH EMM GEE!  So deliciously sinful that I had to share with my BFF and bikini sister, Sarah Chang.  

I also ordered an apple-cardamom scone (eh) and a banana cream filled do-nut.  Both of which I did end up sharing with other people.  They weren't half as tasty as that amazingly delcious and flakey CRUFFIN and I decided that moving forward, I would wisely invest any daily macros/calories in CRUFFINS.

There also were some savory goods that I wanted to try next time, which won't be for another month or so.

I read some reviews from nay-sayers and I have to admit, I don't see it.  This place is blessed by the sugar fairy!!!

Definitely recommend this as an occasional pastry treat splurge!
author: Hiromi N.

description: Seriously...mind blown!! Made it a point to go back multiple mornings during my last SF trip. Had everything from a savory truffle flavored breakfast tart to a fig filled sugary donut, and of course multiple cruffins. Also, had to buy the tote bag "I got baked in SF"...hands-down if you are in SF, add this to your itinerary. It's definitely worth the lines and getting up early for prime selection. P.S. Mr Homes- I want to die and come back as one of your cruffins.
author: Natalie F.

description:
I arrived on a Saturday morning at 7:40am, and to no surprise, there was already a line.  I was only about 20-ish people in so it wasn't too bad.  I assumed it was the line for cruffins since there was only 1 line, but based on other reviews, there usually are 2 lines.  My friend went to the front of the store to check if we were in the right line, then came back to tell me that the line for cruffins was on the other side.  Obviously, we split up and managed to be the 1st in lines for the infamous cruffins!  Either everyone else in line didn't care for cruffins, or they weren't aware there was a separate line.  Either case, my friend and I were guaranteed to get one!  Once the bakery opened at 8am, I waited for my turn to order and got enough pastries for my friend and I, which we ate while waiting for the cruffins to come out at 9am.  A sticker is handed out to everyone in the cruffin line around 8:50am, which guarantees that they would get one.  No sticker = no cruffin.

We went a little crazy and bought practically 75% of the pastries that were available that day, and I have to say that i loved everything!  We bought extra so we could eat the next day, and they are equally as good if you re-heat them in the toaster oven.  The reason why I gave this place 4 stars instead of 5 is because of the amount of sugar they add on all of the sweet pastries.  Had to rub off the sugar on the donuts and cruffin.

Notes:
*  2 cruffin limit per person
*  there are 2 different lines (be sure to read the signs on the windows) - one for cruffins, one for everything else
*  box of pastries:  minimum 6 items, or they will charge $1.50 for the box
*  Banana Chocolate Toffee Cruffin:  right amout of sweetness, banana flavor is not overpowering
*  Mango Ginger Donut:  mango ginger cream is light, and not too sweet.  ginger flavor is subtle
*  California Croissant:  crispy, flakey, and buttery.  can't ask for anything better
*  Kouign Aman:  croissant on crack
author: Melanie T.

description:
I've had better baked goods. But they do their croissant-like items very well. I don't know any of the names of the goods we got but we had 7 in a box. They mostly had a croissant consistency to them, except for the donuts. It's very good technique. Too bad they ran out of the cruffins at 10am on a Sunday (Bay to Breakers- I thought everyone would be there instead!).
The donuts were disappointing to me. The fillings were so-so. Other than that, there are better bakeries in SF but I'm glad this one is popular in the Tenderloin (my hood!). We'll try again for the cruffins another day.
author: Vol T.

description:
Came in for Fourth of July weekend and heard this was a must eat.

We definitely did not wake up in time on Sunday so we didn't get any cruffins :( they ran out around 9:50am. 

Super Yums:
*California croissant - like sushi in a croissant 
*Chocolate croissant - just a very good version of it 
*Strawberry jalapeño brioche - yummy muffin like texture with spicy sweet jam on the inside
*Chocolate and sea salt cookie - even delicious the next day 

Pass:
*ham and cheese croissant- just meh 

Overall, glad we went. Wouldn't wait more than an hour in line for the pastries but we had come late and only waited around 20 minutes since there were no more cruffins.
author: Jacqueline L.

description:
There's always a wait, even on a Tuesday morning, so if you want a cruffin go early around 8:30 on weekdays or 8am on the weekend! Cruffins come out at 9am and they are so worth it if you like sweets! Also it's 2 cruffins MAX per person...so don't send that one friend to get your group a whole set of cruffins. They won't give you more, i tried everything lol

You can get any of the other baked goods without waiting in line though! 

My personal favorite is the california croissant. It's a croissant with a salmon sushi roll inside, and it's FIREE!
author: Cheri K.

description: Delicious...a must try for everyone. You must go early and get in line, they don't begin selling the cruffins until 9am. I suggest getting there by 8:15am if you go on a weekday. They sell out of the cruffins FAST and they have a 2 Cruffin per person limit. Of course the other pastries and donuts are delicious too, but the Cruffin is unlike anything I've ever tasted!
author: Cathy G.

description:
Very popular spot! If you want to get one of the coveted "Cruffins" you have to line up early outside the store, apparently the first to line up around 7am for the big unveiling at 9am. But it is also only 2 Cruffins per person.

We went around 10am and all Cruffins were sold out, so we got an assorted box instead.

The sea salt chocolate chip cookie was amazing and definitely my favorite! Also had the traditional croissant, chocolate croissant, apple cinnamon scone, apple tart and ham and cheese tart. All delicious! Would go back again and want to try the donuts and maybe even wait in the big line for the cruffin!
author: Samantha B.

description:
I tried the strawberry and cream cruffin and it was just ok. I'm not sure what the hype is all about. Maybe I needed to eat it right after I bought it while it's fresh from their oven? I ate it 30 minutes later at work but found it to be a little too crispy on the outside for my taste
I did really like their donut with vanilla filling and would probably just stick to their other desserts if I came back.
author: Daniela J.

description: GO HERE. JUST DO IT. Get up early, bring a willingness to spend some big bucks, and buckle up because you will lose your mind over this place. If you aren't there before 8:15, fat chance of getting a cruffin. They open at 8 but cruffin a don't start until 9. So if you don't want a cruffin, show up at 8:45ish and you'll face no line for regular treats! But make a whole trip of it and splurge because it's worth it as every single thing I had here (tried 4 different things) rocked my world. It's about $5/pastry. Check on their Instagram for this weeks daily flavors for the donuts and cruffins! But you really can't go wrong! Definitely lives up to the hype
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Tucked away in a slightly sketch area of the Tendernob, Mr. Holmes Bakehouse is a pastry lover's dream. Fairly small (you can only sit on crates) and decorated like the most hipster cafe you can imagine, Mr Holmes offers the latest and the best of pastry creations. They offer daily and seasonal cruffins - croissant and muffin hybrid, amalie amanns - smaller kouign amanns, stuffed Vienna donuts with daily creams, and California croissants - savory croissants with salmon and other delicious fillings. 

I tried the caramelized banana donut - holy moly is it delicious. The sweet banana cream balanced the soft sugary donut outside. The chocolate cruffin with passionfruit cream inside was amazing as well. The picture below is worth a thousand words. Also, my friends immediately went and bought out the store, so Mr Holmes Bakehouse, I will be expecting some loyalty rewards program.
author: Kate M.

description:
Ladies and Gentlemen...the hype...the wait...is REAL.


Yes my foodie friends this is by far the best pastry shop of all time. Beats Portos franchise.  Try everything. Why? bc EVERYTHING is made with quality and care. They do not skimp. Reason why cruffins/pastries always change every week, is bc they dont want to keep doing the same thing over and over again. Which i love. It shows they want to keep progressing, keeping it up beat and ever changing. So just go and try everything. 

Since this place is bout it bout it, i will jus leave you with some tips you need to be aware of:

1. Go early - go 30min/1hr before opening. There will be a crowd.
2. There are 2 (two) separate lines!
2a. One line is for all pastries. Right when the store opens.
2b. Other line is for CRUFFINs only. (2 per person!) They release these an hour after regular store opening. (correct me if im wrong) Went there Sat, opened at 8am, released Cruffins at 9am.

*Teamwork is key!* I went with my fiance. She stood in the pastry line, i was in the Cruffin line. once she got the pastries, she then joined me to wait for the cruffins.

Enjoy!
author: Jordan J.

description:
Hype is real. 

Except, I found their other pastries just as good, if not even more satisfying than the cruffin

Got their at 8:30am, got the churro croissant, blackberry bostock and spiced pinapple donut. I then got back in line for flavor of the day cruffin(coffee caramel).  All were delicious and exceptionally well made. My favorite was the churro croissant stuffed with something that tasted like bavarian cream.
author: Trish M.

description:
Baked goods are always delicious and this place does not disappoint. Flavors are on point, but there are some things that are better than others.
I love the creamy custard-like filling in the Cruffins and Choux Bombs, however in my opinion the Choux Bomb is much better than the cruffin. Cruffins were delicious, don't get me wrong, but they're too flaky and quite messy----I feel like half my cruffin fell onto the street as I bit into it. (all the croissant dough is buttery flavored and delicious though). 

GET THERE EARLY IF YOU WANT TO TRY. 
It's the hype that gets these pastries out the door, I believe I've had better elsewhere. Solid 8/10 though!
author: Lisa Y.

description: Delicious pastries! I had the day off work so I stopped by and picked up a couple to try. No line! True, I got there right at 7am on a Monday, but I've seen the weekend lines there. Everything looked amazing! And then I checked out the prices. $4 for a small pastry? Pretty expensive. That's why I give this place 4 stars rather than 5. Maybe I should be grateful it costs so much, that will keep me from going there often.
author: Martha H.

description: We love this place!!  The line was quite long but worth the wait 100%.  It's a must visit when you come to San Fran
author: Michelle O.

description:
Sometimes visiting another bakery gives me an existentialist crisis as a baker, and this place definitely made me question myself the most (in a good way). If you live in SF, please support these guys, the pastries are amazing!! Super creative without being dogmatic (i.e. wayy better than Craftsman or Tartine's pastries, on par with b.patisserie). 

I was luckily invited to a tasting party, and the items that I tried were..

- twice baked croissants filled with strawberry jam & curd: jammy, fruity, dense aromatic goodness. It borders on being too sweet for me, but I'd stuff myself with it if it's within my vicinity. It was sort of a laminated, haute version of a pop tart 

- ferrero Roche choux pastries (think hazelnut praline):  this was my favorite. The texture was excellent; crunchy bits of craquelins and creamy, cold interior. And the hazelnut aroma lingers on your palate too. The sweetness was perfect except for the salted caramel cube; I would be fine without the cube. 

- muffin-shaped croissant filled with passion fruit curd and glazed with chocolate icing: Loved the curd. Slightly acidic, great body and consistency, not cloyingly sweet, and fantastic croissant dough. Wished it was dark chocolate instead of the icing. My second favorite!

- "sushi" croissant with salmon, wasabi, and furikake served with a packet of soy sauce: I was very skeptical of these type of eccentric pastries, but danggit it works. The wasabi cuts through the richness of the fish and croissant, and it leaves you wanting more. A really nice savory option

- amelie amann: this was their version of a kuignn amann but with a middle eastern twist--rosewater and cardamom. I'm a sucker for rosewater, and cardamom is my favorite spice, so this was an automatic winner too

- brioche with strawberry jam and creme pat: again, great jam and curd. Bread was just a-ok

- chocolate pop with some kind of filling: was too sweet and the only thing I wasn't enamored with. A dark chocolate coating would've balanced out the sweet filling imo

The people there were very friendly, the coffee was delicious (a lot of SF coffee are pretentiously under-roasted and acidic), and the space was quaint but modern & minimalistic. I would definitely be a regular even if it means possibly getting killed by the lovely residents of Tenderloin. 

I wish these guys great success!
author: Ray B.

description:
I've been a Mr. Holmes fan(atic) since I first tasted one of their pastries at (I believe it was) Fifty/Fifty Coffee & Tea in the Inner Richmond and of course at Saint Frank Coffee in Russian Hill. While many artisanal coffeeshops feature impressive local bakers, Mr. Holmes' goodies especially stood out. I often found myself asking baristas at Fifty/Fifty and Saint Frank, "Where was this baked? Who is your baker? I must know who is producing this devilish witchcraft of pastries!!" And they'd always tell me, "Oh, we have this awesome baker named Mr. Holmes." I was like, "Um who is this Mr. Holmes and can I meet him?!" (Of course, there is no actual Mr. Holmes. Apparently the bakery is in homage to a cat named Mr. Holmes.) 

I started to follow them on Instagram and Facebook and noticed they were establishing a stand-alone store this fall. Naturally, I beamed up with joy and have since awaited their grand opening. Voila! The day has come. On November 22, they opened up a shop in the Tenderloin. I planned to go around opening time at 7 AM, but found myself too sluggish and distracted by the rain. I got to Mr. Holmes around 10:15 and just within three hours, I was told most of their pastries were "SOLD OUT." Bummer. However, I did manage to snag a couple things: a raspberry pistachio brioche and an amelie amann (similar to a kouign-amann). The brioche was stunningly pillowy and light even though it looked dense. It was, thankfully, not too sweet and the raspberry flavor really shined through. The amelie amann was flaky, soft, buttery, sweet, and slightly sticky just like a proper kouign-amann. For the two, it came out to $7.50 -- probably the best seven dollars and fifty cents I've spent in a long time. They also sell coffee to accompany your sweet treat.

Keep in mind, this is a straight-up hole-in-the-wall. There isn't really a place to sit. There are some black crates you can temporarily rest on, but it's definitely not for lounging. The shop is minimally decorated. White hexagonal tiles, big counter, register: boom! That's the store. Oh, and then there's this cheeky little neon sign that says "I got baked in San Francisco." HA. 

Anyway, check this joint out. I honestly can't help but continue to spread the Mr. Holmes gospel.
author: James Z.

description:
Have you ever ate something and was speechless because it was THAT GOOD? Yup, that was a good handful of pastries that we got from Mr. Holmes Bakehouse.

My co-workers and I went this morning at 8:30 AM. Needless to say, there was a line-up already. However, all those people were waiting for the cruffins. We decided that we didn't need to have the cruffins (there were so many things that were available that we just wanted to check out). 

We ordered the following: choux bombs, plain croissants, donut (passion fruit and banana), brioche bomb, amelie amagn, chocolate croissant, artichoke danish, ham and cheese danish, almond cake, white chocolate blueberry brioche bomb.

Yup, we ordered a lot.

I had the following:
1) CHOUX BOMB: YOU MUST GET THIS. I probably had a foodgasm when eating this. If you like hazelnuts, then this is the thing to get. Everything about it was just amazing.
2) PASSION FRUIT DONUT: This was okay, IMO. It was good, but not amazing.
3) HAM & CHEESE DANISH: This is SO good (if you like ham and cheese, and mustard seeds). My co-workers and I were amazed by this.
3) PLAIN CROISSANT: It's great, but not as flaky as Tartine. Depends on what type of croissants you enjoy.
4) CHOCOLATE CROISSANT: Good as well -- but not THAT amazing.
5) AMELIA AMAGN: I've never heard of an amagn until today. BOY OH BOY, it was SO good. It's definitely full of buttery and sugary goodness.

I'm totally a Holmie now. I'm just glad it's close enough to me, but a little bit out of the way from where I live.
author: Joanne W.

description: Hands down, must visit when in San Fran. The cruffins are what dreams are made of. Also they have a bread pudding type thing, omg. So. Good. I don't even know names of what I got (from multiple visits), because I just picked up one of whatever was left that morning! Go early as everything sells out very quickly.
author: Carolina O.

description: Small bakery with a quaint theme, limited selection, but tasty, unique pastries. At least for the cruffins and donuts, they were well baked and had interesting fillings.
author: Eric F.

description:
Totally over rated, we walked 20 mind to get there for not a wide range of pastries. I got a croissant with ham & cheese which was cold, some bluberry thing and my hubby got a donut and some kind of sticky scone. Once we got them there is nowhere to sit not even a bench outside or a park nearby, so we just stood on the sidewalk. Fun.
The starbucks under our hotel is just as good and better at all the baked goods. The only cool thing is the sign that everyone gets a picture there ( i got baked in san fransisco) so unless you havr instagrtam photos u must take save your time.
author: Sharon B.

description:
The cruffin' is definitely real!! haha.
Pretty good but super messy... must drink with some M I L K!!
author: Criselle O.

description:
Freaking amazing place for my sweet tooth! 

Their flagship 'cruffin' (yeah that's right) was sold out but the items I tried were also great.

I got some savory Danish,brioche bomb,Ube puff(amazing) and a bottle of blue izzy.

Wonderful bakery.I might have to come way early morning (7am) to get some cruffins and the gals in the line told me there is quite a big line for cruffins.
author: Priyanka L.

description:
Good pastries. Prepare to stand in line if you're going on the weekend.

But cruffin game on point. And Instagram worthiness +200.
author: Natasha W.

description: This place is really popular! I found out why. I got there at around 9:08. There was already a line formed outside and I wondered if I would even get a cruffin. When I got there I was about 1 store away. Luckily when I got inside, there were around 10 cruffins left to be sold. They had passion fruit with little citrus cut pieces on top. I also got every kind of donut that they had: banana, passion fruit, and some sort of jam as well as the ferrero rocher pastry. The banana filling donut was my favorite out of the donuts. The ferrero rocher had a LOT of cream. It was okay. For the most part, all of the desserts were really yummy! I enjoyed everything and will be back someday. Maybe when they bring back the matcha flavor? ;)
author: Lyra C.

description:
Mar 30:  Went back for another chocolate croissant;  two regular/plain croissants;  and two mushroom pastries.  Unlike the previous experience the chocolate croissant this time was much flakier, suggesting that the one the week before was day old (don't they sell out and close?).  In other words, nothing like the previous one.  The regular croissants were very good as were the savory pastries (I still prefer Hearth, but these are still quite good).  This past week I stopped by at an old one time favorite on Fillmore at Bush, for a chocolate croissant---and an amazingly awful one at that---how can something made with butter and flour have so little butter flavor?  So, while I was disappointed in my soft and chewy chocolate croissant here, even as sad as it was, it was still miles above this other product--whose name will not be advertised by mention!  And, a week later, this bakery had improved/restored the quality.  (I did not identify myself to management, did not ask for refunds or credit or otherwise engage in any deceptive or self serving behavior, and paid for my purchase as one would).


Mr. Holmes is the place where there were two lines out the door---one to the North and one to the South---when it was new and hot.  It's still the place where you'll see out-of-towners at SFO with their easy-to-spot white and gold boxes.  There's still a line, 'round opening time, but if you're not working that day, the selection is still good a couple of hours later and without the wait, such is the nature of being trendy, and "In", and then, so suddenly, not.

Even at its best, it's pastries were still a shadow of those up on 17th, in the Castro, at Hearth (if you had the time to endure the abysmal service there).  A croissant is supposed to be a buttery, flaky, melt-in-your-mouth affair, an ethereal experience in finger food.  Lee's Sandwiches, further down Larkin in Little Saigon, has the exact opposite of a good croissant---the bread like crescent roll.  A croissant and a crescent roll are as different as rolls and pastry---as different as a macaron and a macaroon.  

Mr. Holme's used to have fairly flaky croissants---very nearly ethereal, which would describe Hearth's croissants (or Sand Box up on Bernal Heights).  I had a chocolate croissant today and while good, it was chewy, not flaky at all.  Not tough to chew, not gum---no nothing like that.  Instead of being flaky, melt in your mouth buttery, it was chewy.  I've had their donuts at different times. as well as their filled pastries.  All are good, the pastries being generally more flaky than today's chocolate croissant, but hardly the place to wait in line over, let alone fly home with.

I'll go back---it's on my way most everywhere on my day off--but I can't see standing in line.
author: Paul T.

description:
Cruffin. Limited daily supply, out at 9 AM and limit only 2 per person. 

Super Matcha Cruffin:  Filled with matcha creme and matcha marshmallow on top. The cruffin itself was flaky just like a croissant. Perfectly rolled with sugar. The matcha creme is just perfect! I love the matcha marshmallow on top! (You can easily make a mess since the sugar does fall off or stick to your mouth). Well worth the wait. Chef Ry Stephen will surprise you with different flavor fillings. Be prepared!

Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb:  Ferrero Rocher pastry version. The hazelnut creme and the salted caramel piece fits well together.

Assorted Donut:  Fluffy sugar donut.
Citrus - refreshing creamy citrus flavor. 
Salted Caramel - just as I liked. Perfect!

Apricot Danish:  Nice flaky texture on each bite.  Apricot and custard filling was delicious.

Blueberry White Chocolate Brioche Bomb:  Soft and fluffy brioche. The blueberry filling and some white chocolate bits makes a nice combination. Good amount of blueberry on each brioche. 

Artichoke Danish:  Flaky Danish. The artichoke is so good. Delicious.

California Croissant:  Croissant was flaky and crispy. A savory pastry sushi with no rice but inside a croissant with nori wrapped salmon, ginger and wasabi.

Amelie Amann:  Mr. Holmes Bakehouse version of the Kouign Amann. It is flaky and crispy, also slightly on the crunchy side. Still good.
author: Kei C.

description: We came here at 2p thinking we could get cruffins... But found out they usually sell out early in the morning. If you want them get there at 9a! Their chocolate chip sea salt cookie was alright tho....
author: Tessa C.

description:
This is not a casual place to pick up a croissant and walk away. It's a destination for out-of-towners, amateur instagrammers, and those enticed by the elusive cruffin.

Come early (aka 7am) on weekends to get a cruffin. Or settle for their other less-famous, less-instagrammable pastries.

Oh, and that pretty box costs $1.50 unless you buy at least 5 items. It's a business after all.

But man, their stuff is tasty. Just wish it was slightly cheaper and not a pain in the ass to pick up one thing.
author: Mira K.

description:
This bakery is located a little bit odd, I walk by it every morning to school and there was always this suuuuperlong line all the way out on the street so I figured we had to try it. 

I ordered the apple&cardamom scone and OMG it was so delicious. The scone was baked to perfection and you could taste all the spices, it had the perfect balance. I'm actually not a fan of cardamom but it was the best scone I've ever had. TRY IT!

I also tried the vanilla donut. Usually you get a donut with a very small amount of vanilla cream in the middle, but this had sooo much vanilla in it, almost too much. You get a lot for your money here and they use really good ingredients, real vanilla etc..
author: Jasmine A.

description:
13.02.22         First Visit

Cruffin ---------------------- 4.5 - 5
Pastries -------------------- 4.5 - 5

It lives up to the hype.
Well made and technically superiorly made.

Warning long line be there super early
Limit 2 per person 
   Cut down of friends cutting in line
Not the best area ... be alert ... especially cell phone
author: S.K. Y.

description:
Finally got to try the famous Mr.Holmes cruffins. on Saturday bf and I got to Mr. Holmes at 8:20 AM and the line was on the top of the block. Which also us just made it to the cut off for cuffins sticker. The stickers indicate much cruffins they have available and each person only allow 2 cruffins per sticker. Mr. Holmes starts selling their cruffins at 9am. 
After we got our cruffins, we needed to line up on their regular bake good line. The regular bake good line moved way much faster than the cruffin line (Thank goodness ). Overall, we spent over $50 for 2 boxes of pasties. 

The cruffins were very good definitely worth the wait. They were really flakey and the filings were just right. But I wish they didn't used cream on top because once I got home the cream was starting to melt :(  I didn't have a chance to try their regular bake goods. My parents finished them before I got around to them , I guess it's a good sign : )
author: Stacy L.

description:
- Cruffin: good but overrated
- Artichoke Danish: very tasty. Get it!
- Brown ale onion Danish: also tasty. Get it!
- California croissant: stuffed with salmon, ginger wasabi, and nori. They give you a soy sauce packet on the side which is unnecessary. Very interesting. Very tasty. If you like smoked salmon then definitely give this a try. 
- Sticky bun:  excellent. Get it. 
- donut: mine was filled with a peanut butter cream, and they're all covered in sugar.  good stuff.  check their instagram for the flavor(s) of the day.
- ube puff pop tart: meh. Pass.

If you want their famed cruffin, you have to show up early and wait in a separate line for them and you're limited to 2 per person.  I guess they're worth trying, but I'm not inclined to get one again.  Their other stuff is much better IMO.  My favorites were the savory stuff (california croissant, savory danishes) and the sticky bun.  But don't show up too late bc the pickings are slim later in the day (say, by lunch time?).

Also, they have some fancy boxes for their pastries, but you have to buy at least 6 to get a box; otherwise, they just put it in a paper bag.
author: Ed L.

description:
We did it.  We waited in line ALL MORNING for a Cruffin.

And they're OK.

I have to admit, I'm not super into sweets, but the Cruffins are yummy.  Worth waiting more than an hour in line?  Eh.  Maybe not.  Do it once, just for the experience.

I also got an Ube Puff from the regular pastry line.  THIS.  I liked it more than the Cruffin... don't hate me.

I can't say I'd do it again, but I'm glad I did it.   I don't think I'll ever do the Cruffin line again on my own free will, but I'll definitely be back for some pastries sometime.
author: Brian H.

description: Weeeeee, I love Mr. Holmes Bakehouse! Whenever I'm downtown in the morning I have to indulge in their donuts. I recommend this to everyone in the area. The line can get long because of the famous cruffin, but for first timers I think it is worth it. The inside is small, but very cute. Everyone loves to Instagram the lit sign in the wall (guilty of this). Will be back to satisfy my sweet tooth soon. They also have a California cruffin, some type of mix of sushi and cruffin? Will definitely come back to try that and re-review then!
author: Gina B.

description:
Turkey pesto danish is good.
Flavors on cruffin/donuts are hit/miss -- the chocolate flavors seem to be the worst and never "wows" me after trying multiple different one. The chocolate flavored donut/cruffin just taste like chocolate cream (that isn't really a deep chocolate flavor too) and is very underwhelming. The fruit flavors they have seem to be the best in terms of flavor (passion fruit, raspberry, strawberry coconut).
author: Melody L.

description: Came here sunday morning @ 8:30, there were 2 lines already, one for the cruffin and other for something else. cruffin line started moving @9:00am. The line moving pretty quick, only one flavor cruffin which was jasmine. Pretty delicious breads, spent $100 for 3 boxes and 4 cruffins. only 2 cruffins per person with sticker. Overall was a nice visit.
author: Henry P.

description: Loved the fact that the pastries were delicate, not overly sweet. The croissant texture was on point. Sure wish we lived closer to this tiny gem... but then perhaps it's a good thing we're over in the East Bay and stopping by here becomes a special treat.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
I hate that this is next door to my house.  I've been here two days in a row.  

Must get:
-banana caramel donut
-mushroom Danish 
-California croissant
-hazelnut Chou 

Did I mention the banana donut?

From what I was told, all of their donuts are a hit.  

Luckily 24 hr fitness is a block away!
author: Jacquelynne S.

description: the donuts here! im so so obsessed!  each is soft and fluffy and light, but has so much delicious filling (sometimes too much) but they all go great with coffee! NOMS.. i stalk their instagram for favor updates which are super helpful if you're craving a certain flavor of donut or cruffin. unfortunately ive never made it here early enough to actually BUY a cruffin but have had a [good] friend share! nomsies. also need to try to ferrero rocher choux-bomb! WAH! on a pricey side but they have a cult following so it's warranted i guess.  their savory pastries are pretty good too. small space, but service is fast n friendly.
author: Christina L.

description:
This is one of the few places on yelp that I never intended to walk into. Usually I have it looked up and we go there for a purpose or its so new its not even on yelp yet. This time around, as we walked by I was just instantly attracted by the decor from outside! And the rush of the fresh baked goodies from the kitchen out back instantly lured me inside as I got to the door. 

Menu isn't extensive - maybe 8 things to choose from but.... even two things would be too hard for me to choose from, they all looked SO GOOD. (Spoiler my friend and I got 4...hahhaha.)

So fresh, tasty, and unique desserts you dont get everywhere. Highly recommend this place! It's a little pricey so....4 stars!
author: Samson T.

description: Impressively creative flavors like strawberry-jalapeno!
author: Norma G.

description:
With 800+ reviews, it's safe to say this is worth dropping in.
I just want to weigh in and say YES to the Ube Puff forever.
You'll feel like a cartoon character having an SF morning opener.
author: Kiera R.

description: This place definitely lives up to it's hype. I had the matcha dipped croissant and oh my it was so good it melted in my mouth. It was nice a delicate and overall amazing. They ran out of the croffiant which was upsetting since I wanted to try them but that just means they must be really good! This place is definitely a must when visiting San Francisco it won't disappoint!
author: Valeria F.

description:
Pastries are amazing. But price is killer. Got 5 pastries and a coffee $26. 

I would come back but on special occasion. It's more gas than value.
author: Jim L.

description: Ummmm the hype is real. I made my hubby wake up early and trek from San Carlos to this bakery for a cruffin. It was worth it. It's in a super dicey area and there was syringes on the street as well as a few homeless folks hitting up the people in line for money. Don't block the door to the apartments while standing in line for your cruffin because there's a grumpy ass SF 49er's fan that will let you know how much he hates you and baked goods. Standing in line you get a sticker and then redeem that for your cruffin once they start slinging them at 9 am. We arrived about 8:30 and had 15 people in front of us. 2 per person limit. You can get anything from the regular bakery side whenever you want- no line. The fluorescent sign wasn't working when we came which was kind of a bummer. Check the instagram for Mr. Holmes for a weekly flavor breakdown. We had a coffee flavored cruffin and a raspberry passion fruit donut. Both amazing. I'd slap someone to get a matcha one- those look like green heavenly goodness wrapped in croissant deliciousness.
author: Lauren N.

description:
I wish I got to try a cruffin.

I wish I had gotten there at least 30 minutes earlier.

I wish they would give the last person that would receive a cruffin a sign saying that they would receive the last cruffin.

Unfortunately, none of those things happened. Luckily, I came with another person who was able to stand in the non-cruffin line, otherwise I would have been waiting for days.

Top Choice: Passion Fruit Donut (California croissant was sold out as well)
Other things tried: Banana cream donut, Strawberry cream donut, croissant, white chocolate blueberry brioche, Amelie amann, apple pie (stop judging!)

The donuts were all very tasty. Not oily, not super fried, super fluffy, definitely tasty. However, at $3.50 per, I'd suggest getting only the passion fruit. The banana cream and the strawberry cream were good, but nothing special. I've read lots about the white chocolate blueberry brioche but couldn't find the chocolate. Not sure what happened there. 

Amelie amann...is definitely not the Kouign Amann from B Patisserie. Smaller, more dense, and about the same price. Advantage: B Patisserie

Other quick tips:
1) There's two lines. One (probably the longer one), is the cruffin line
2) People continually get into the cruffin line, and people just wait and wait and wait until someone at the front signals that there's no more left. Said people are left having to move to the "regular" item line and waiting even more time to obtain other pastries
3) Got there at 8:30am on a Saturday morning. Line was super long. No cruffins were eaten.

As far as the rest of Mr. Holmes -- the staff was extremely friendly and they have an "I got baked in San Francisco" neon sign. Win.
author: Andrew C.

description: Lines out the door an hour after opening. It's a cute, small space. Very trendy with simple but picturesque branding decor. Their packaging is adorbs & high quality. It's glossy white with gold foil font. They have a selection of pastries. You need to buy 6 to order get the box. Worth the wait.
author: Ezra E.

description: 3.5. Pretty good, but too expensive. The cruffin flavor wasn't one I would choose, but I wanted to try one badly so I bought it. I ate the outside and left the custard in the center. It was a good croissant. I also tried the beer and onion Danish, which was also pretty good. What else can I say? I wouldn't wait in a long line for their pastries, but luckily I was there early in the morning and didn't have to wait. I would come back and try it again.
author: Jen B.

description: WOW. Amazing Croissants.  The California Croissant has a smoked salmon and seaweed in it and it goes SO well together.  The quality of the pastries here are top notch. Even on the second day they're still so fluffy and perfectly moist.  I also got their chocolate dipped croissant and whatever they put in their chocolate, has crack in it.  Even their chocolate chip cookie was amazing.  I'm definitely going to come back and try their cruffins and other pastries!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Absolutely delicious croissants and of course the cruffins :) They really know how to work with croissant dough and make it beautifully flaky. Unfortunately, there's no way to know what flavor cruffin they have beforehand (apparently you can check it out on social media!) so there's an element of luck in getting the flavor you want. In retrospect, we could have picked up some pastries while waiting in line for the cruffins so definitely going to do that next time. 

After waiting in line, it made sense to max out on the number of cruffins I could buy (max 2 per customer). In retrospect, DON'T unless you can eat it in the next few hours. The cruffins have a custard center which will make the pastry portion a little soggy and not as good as it could be if you wait too long. While the custard core was good (nothing too sugary/heavy), the true star is the actual croissant part. Again, so wonderfully flaky and crispy. It was coffee flavor that day so the bitterness really complemented the lightly sugared dough. 

Big fan of their more salty options though so you should definitely come even if they aren't selling cruffins. I tried the California croissants which had great smoked salmon flavor mixed with nori, but I didn't really get any taste of wasabi and ginger that's supposed to be in there. Still delicious though and would recommend. REALLY liked the reuben danish where the pickled sauerkrauts went so well with the saltiness of the pastrami. These pastries have a longer shelf life compared to the cruffins; just warm them up in a toaster oven and it will revive that wonderful flakiness of the croissant dough. Good as new!
author: Tiffany L.

description: You can only imagine what kind of crazy person would wait in a huge (going around the corner) line for one croissant but I swear I am not insane. The chocolate croissant front this bakery is amazing! Worth the 30-40 mins wait. The first time in San Francisco I was like "omg I can't wait any longer" but once I had gotten my bread I fell in love. Now there's one in LA in my community which I adore as well. But anyway it is great and definitely worth it!
author: Angelica H.

description: We absolutely loved this place. This is a quality bakery and a must if you are in the area. They have very fresh baked goods with a fun twist. We really enjoyed the croissants and donuts. The service was fantastic as well. Also, they have a great social media presence!
author: Han Y.

description:
PSA: Follow their Instagram page as they update their flavors for the week every Sunday so you can see the flavors in advance! 
I have heard and heard about this place and was suuuuper excited to give it a try. After reading many reviews we decided to show up quite early. It was a Saturday morning and we showed up right around 8:00 and we were the 4th couple in line(7th and 8th in line). I went and got donuts inside while my boyfriend stayed in line. 
DONUTS: The doughnuts were great, very much so like Leonard's malasadas in Hawaii maybe even better. They were raspberry cream flavored and I was quite surprised at how much I liked them. Very soft and just the right amount of filling.
CRUFFINS: To be honest I did like them. Sugary and crispy, yet fluffy and delicate all at the same time. However I do think they are overhyped. I am definitely going to give them another try because I do think the flavor was a huge aspect of that. It was hummingbird which was a spiced banana with pecans and pineapple. To be honest it was waaaaaaaaaay overspiced and had an extreme clove and nutmeg flavor. I really didn't taste the banana or pineapple at all which was quite disappointing. It was more so just a spiced cruffin. I really hope to try a more exciting flavor like the strawberry milkshake or matcha!
author: Alexis T.

description:
Does anything NOT taste good? Ferrero Rocher Choux Bombs. Mouth watering. Artichoke pastry. Amazing. Cruffin. Worth the wait.
I dare you to buy just one thing and not regret it.
author: Brituhknee S.

description:
mr. holmes, way to make croissant and muffin procreate with injected cream center (lol).  thanks to you the magical cruffin is born!  

mr. holmes bakehouse has been on my to eat list for some time and finally got to stop by over the weekend!

the rules of cruffin:  
1)  there is a limited amount of cruffins made per day
2)  they take the number of cruffins produced and divide it by 2 (cruffins are limit 2 per customer) and they will pass out a number card to guarantee the customers that got numbers.  the customers that didn't receive a card, well, may luck be with you.
3)  there is a separate line for cruffins ONLY, so if you're there for non-cruffins, you can line up at a separate line.  cruffin line moves relatively quick since it's cruffins only.  

we got to mr. holmes at 9:12 am (1 hour and 12 minutes after the bakery has been open) and yes, there was a long line for the cruffins.  the employee came out and announced that my friend and i may not have a chance to get a cruffin that day but we didn't give up.  turns out that we got the LAST two cruffins available for the day.  lucky us :)  but seriously, it was brutal having to watch the cruffins being purchased and wondering if you'd get some.  poor girl in line behind us was her second time back and she had just missed it by ONE cruffin...  so whatever you do, go as soon as the bakery opens.

verdict:  SO.  GOOD.  cruffin is a croissant shaped like a muffin with cream injected center.  the flavor of the day was caramel popcorn and it was divine!  i honestly wished i had 2!  i think between cruffin and cronuts, i like cruffins better :)  but for $4.50...  i'll have one maybe once/month...
author: Alice C.

description: Do not touch their pins they sell at the counter if you don't intend to buy it. I just got accused of stealing a pin from the counter by this rude cashier saying that he's gonna be cool about it if I take it out. He didn't even apologize after I overturned my pocket to prove my innocence and sarcastically said 'ok'. I'm extremely pissed I feel like my dignity just took a hard shot and needless to say my Saturday morning is ruined.
author: Jeanwei S.

description:
Judging by how popular this place is, and by word of mouth, I was expecting the line that I saw from around the corner. But I had nowhere to be, and I was excited about trying this place out for the first time, so it didn't bother me.

I came around 9:30am (much later than I wanted to), and I managed to snatch the last few S'mores cruffins of the day! Getting what I came for made the trip a bonus. But even if I couldn't get my hands on a cruffins (which were excellent and picture-worthy), i would still go for all the other pastries they have.

Their mandarin orange-curd donuts could possibly be one of the best donuts I've ever had in my life - but I'm not a big donut fan so I guess I haven't had much to begin with. Would love to come back & try their other stuff.

Cute shop, neon sign, & of course, boxes.
author: Stacey L.

description: Since I was visiting my old hometown of SF this Holiday Season, family wanted me to bring back #cruffins from #Holmesbakery which we discovered thru IG. I stood in line outside the store for 2 hrs despite the cold. They only allow you to buy a max of 2 per person. Ok deduct one point for that. I explained I came from out of state just to buy their cruffins and they explained no exceptions because they'll run out for all the other people waiting. Ok, I can understand that. But WHY DONT YOU ALLOW PEOPLE TO DO PREPAID PREORDERS?? ( minus 1 star) Makes no sense. Sorry but No, as good as the cruffins maybe, the long wait in freezing weather is not worth 2 cruffins at a time. #overhyped. I think this bakery does business this way only to continue the hype. Hope other bakeries start making cruffins but in the meantime I'll stick to good old fashion San Francisco Italian bakeries.
author: Judy M.

description:
Good bakery that's currently "trending". If you hate waiting in lines like me then try and get there early. I don't buy into food fads and over-hyping restaurants so I was genuinely only here to buy a donut and be on my way.
I live right down the street, and love picking up a donut every now and then. I love the donuts but they are very pricey, It's about $10 for 2 donuts and a coffee. Also, there is always a line, expect a 10-20 minute wait if you go at a peak time. Get there early to avoid the line and because they sell out of the good stuff fairly quickly. Also, Pro-tip, don't reach over the glass to point at what you want, just speak loudly.
author: Ernie B.

description:
Disappointed I missed out on their popular cruffins; they seemed, though, to still have most everything else.   Tried the chocolate croissant & their choux bomb...croissant: large, light, flaky, and not too sweet. Makes a perfect breakfast or snack pastry that hit the spot.  The choux bomb, imo,  makes a better dessert pastry as its chewy caramel thing (for lack of better description) & cream filling is definitely on the sweeter side.  The outside part of the choux bomb is a little cumbly and balances sweetness of the pastry.

Plan to arrive early as they can run out of pastries before noon.  If driving, parking isn't too bad; give yourself $.50-worth of meter time & you're set to go.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Wake up at 7AM X
Get in line by 8AM X 
Get my pastries X
Pig out X

Mr. Holmes was on the top of my food list for San Francisco! I've heard from all my friends how amaaaaaazing the cruffins are, so I decided that i needed to go and try them. 

I wake up pretty early, so getting there around 8-8:30 wasn't a problem for me. I went on a Friday and when I got there by 8, there wasn't a cruffin line so I just decided to look at all their pastries. They had some really interesting stuff such as cream filled donuts, ube toaster strudel things, bread pudding, and other sweet things. If your don't feel like waiting in line for a cruffin, don't, because the other things are just as good, if not better than the cruffin. My favorite item from this bakery was actually the bourbon vanilla donut, so try them!

When we finally got our dark chocolate matcha cruffins they were really amazing! I wouldn't say that waiting an hour for them in the cold was totally worth it but it was great to try it at least once. Everyone shows pictures of them lookin' all pretty BUT nobody tells you how messy it is when you eat it haha. 

Pros: Great variety of pastries overall, cute interior, really nice servers

Cons: Intentional limited number of pastries (cruffins), waiting in the cold, the price
author: Grace C.

description: Went on a monday morning and didn't get there terribly early. Got there around 8:30am and waited about 15-20 mins. I had the oatmeal cookie cruffins and the matcha coconut donuts. Both were delicious and a perfect way to start my morning! Tasty, fluffly, and a great sweet tooth pleaser.
author: Apoorva G.

description: Found the pastries to be as good as advertised.  It seems like there is always a line so get there when i opens so you can get out fast and have the most number of choices.  Definitely should try if you have a sweet tooth!
author: Clement C.

description: Tried the matcha croissant and a savory danish personally while my boyfriend ordered the churro croissant and strawberry lemongrass...something. Everything was delicious and actually kept me full longer than anticipated. Came on Friday around 11am and not busy although some popular pastries were likely sold out by then.
author: Sharon P.

description:
NOOO! I was next in line and THE GUY IN FRONT OF ME GRABBED THE LAST TWO CRUFFINS.

I got in line at 9:05 AM on a Wednesday, and there were probably about 20-25 people in front of me already. It was my turn around 9:55. 

Since I couldn't get the cruffins, I got one Nutella-filled donut, pineapple jelly-filled donut, two California croissants, and two Kouign amann. 

I tried the California croissant first because I was really hungry. I thought there would be more inside! The salmon was itty bitty, but it did taste yummy. The croissant itself was crispy and flaky, just the way I love my croissants! There's also some seaweed and wasabi in there. They also give packets of soy sauce for it which I thought was amusing. 

Next was the Kouign amann. It was alriiiiiiight. It's sweet and flaky but nothing completely stood out for me! 

The jelly filled donuts are more my style! I LOVE SWEETS and anything jelly filled, and these donuts have made my week. The jelly was creamy and delish! The donut itself was soft with sugary 

The workers there were really sweet as well! I can imagine how many customers they have to deal with AND so early in the morning, yet they manage to keep sincerely smiling and answer questions professionally. Thumbs up! 

Would I come back? YES, so I can get my hands on a cruffin! I would come back just to try the other pastries as well.
author: Priscilla T.

description:
The pastries? Delicious. The service? Meh.

I visited SF on Fourth of July weekend and waited about 40 minutes for these famed baked goods. And amazing they were-my favorite item was this toast with powdered sugar and blackberries on top (wish I could remember the name). However, I didn't love how the employees looked like they couldn't wait to get out of there. I don't think I saw one person smiling, which makes me sad because how could you be sad when working at a great place like this?! Anyways, go for the food but don't expect happy-go-lucky staff.
author: Audrey H.

description:
get: cruffin (too much sugar on the outside so dust it off), california croissant

skip: bread pudding (too dense), kouigan amann (caramelized shell was resulted in too much sugar) 

The desserts here are extremely buttery and DENSE. I had 2 and felt sick.

I got there at 9:45 am on a weekday, and there were 15 cruffins left. Although on weekends, you have to get there much earlier.
author: Jackie W.

description: Tried their famous cruffins, and they were just delicious! Best the day of - they are crisp he wait - at least once! While waiting, there is a separate line for other desserts and their other breakfast desserts actually look amazing too. Will be back to try the non-cruffin treats!
author: S S.

description:
Okay so I didn't know that he only served cruffins at 9am. I just happened to be awake extremely early and didn't have anywhere to go. So..I made my first stop Mr Holmes Bakery. I got here at 8:40am (luckily), paid for 1.5 hours worth of parking, and just stood in line basically. Everyone in line in front and behind me was sick though, which made standing in line not as pleasant....but I was visiting from SoCal and didn't really have anywhere to be at this time anyways so I was sorta okay with it. I finally got my cruffin at 9:30am. It was chocolate, with some coconut sheds inside it and I think some chopped hazelnuts. It was okay....it was really hard to eat. It was also really messy. I dont think it's really worth the wait for it. Maybe because my flavor wasn't that great? I saw some people from other days get matcha green tea flavor which sounds/looked very bomb. I think it's kind've a poor design. It falls apart pretty easily. It tastes like pudding with coconut sheds and a croissant dipped in cinnamon sugar. Idk I guess there are just better things out there.... 

But yeah he only makes one flavor a day. So get there before 9am and you should be fine. But be prepared to wait about an hour. $4.50 a pop btw. And make sure you grab napkins before you leave.
author: Ashley H.

description: I goted Baked here! And it was everything I wanted it to be! This is one of those hyped places that sometimes your worried it won't live up to it! Well for my experience I think it met my expectations. Visiting this spot I knew there was gonna be a line so I was prepared. We came here on a Saturday at about 8:30am and the line was not that bad at all, if you didn't want CRUFFINS then the line is fast and you can go right and and get other things, but if you want CRUFFINS you have wait in line that only took us about 15 minutes. I enjoyed that the people in line which was friendly and made the experience fun. When you get to enter you get to see the awesome neon lighting, and I've seen it in pictures already but seeing it in person it still very cool! The staff was friendly and the I enjoyed everything about this bakery. The the CRUFFINS was good! and worth a try because not many places make it, the other bakery goods were also very good! Definitely get a white box because it makes ur baked goods looks soo cool! Then remember to take a picture with the sign because it just make the experience fun! Another fun food exploration in SF!
author: James L.

description: This is too good to be true! The cruffins are AMAZING. We had chocolate and strawberry. They both are good, but I LOVE chocolate flavor more.
author: Ihsuan Y.

description:
Walked in on a weekday morning while vacationing and got a box of 1 of almost everything they had in the case. 

Standouts:
-Fererro Rocher Croissant: I need these back at home omg. The croissant itself is flaky and delicious, and the chocolate dipping is SO good, and not overly sweet either! I'm already craving more!
-California: Smoked salmon and seaweed in a croissant wut?! Very good savory pastry 
-Ham and cheese: Flaky pastry, yummy center! 

Also had a strawberry cruffin! It was ok--the strawberry jam was much too sweet and plentiful for my liking :c Would skip the chocolate filled pastry and just go with the ferrero rocher dipped croissant.
author: Jenny B.

description:
First time at this trendy bakery, even though it's a couple blocks away from me.  Mostly haven't been here because of the line, oh and because I work at another bakery in the city.  But had the day off and finally wanted to see what all the fuss is about.

I looked at their website before going and found they put out an Instagram every week of what the cruffin and donut flavors are going to be for the upcoming week.  That's nice of them.  

Did not like their flavor of cruffin today- caramel popcorn.  There were actually some left when I was being waited on at 9:30, which I hear is unusual.  Probably because it's the middle of the week.  Also, I get naming the cruffin that; it sells and it's catchy.  But really all it is is a oversized, overstuffed morning bun.  

I really enjoyed the guy up front; he made recommendations to people, was friendly but firm with customers, and I just knew he'd been doing this awhile and still liked his job, which is nice.  I actually didn't get helped by him, but it was fun to watch.

Anyways, I was torn between getting the Ferrero choux bomb and the donut.  Based on Yelp reviews, I was not wanting to pass up the choux bomb, even though I came there for a donut. But when I asked about the choux bomb (aka cream puff), they had changed the flavor to a white chocolate, coffee, chocolate concoction, which is good but not Ferrero good. 

So I got the chocolate/cherry custard filled donut.  It was good and I liked the surprise that on top of the donut, there were chocolate cereal puffs, and not chocolate chips which I was expecting.

They had a lot of great classic selections like caramel sticky buns and a large chocolate chip cookie (which the dude says is one of their best, most overlooked items), and then because they're a trendy place they had out there selections like the California croissant and the pear/blue cheese tart, etc.  

Overall, this place has gone to the tourists and the people who need to be trendy in the city.  I was chatting with the lady in line behind me and she said they used to sell wholesale to some place else and she used to get their pastries back then (so she's old school).  She doesn't come often because of the line. That does suck for her and others like her and I, but it's great for their business and I do like that they have their place in the city.
author: Becky N.

description:
Really great pastries. a little pricey, but oh so good! 
You have to be willing to be in a 30min long line around 9am to get the cruffins though. 
I was always just satisfied with the rest of their products. 

Big Big fan of their california croissant - salmon and nori in a croissant*!!! 

If it wasn't for the location (tenderloin= no parking) I would be willing to visit more often and maybe even get in line for the cruffin :). 

Worth all of it.
author: k k.

description:
I tried the basic chocolate croissant because that's what I always get at bakeries so it's easy for me to compare them. Mr. Holmes' chocolate croissant was on point. There were so many flakey layers, and they didn't mush up when I took at bite. There were two batons of chocolate, that seemed special. It was really an all-star croissant. 

So, I'll certainly be back for more. I'm happy to have this bake shop in the neighborhood.
author: Halley S.

description:
Rolled by around 2PM on a Sunday. Bought some croissants to go. Service was fast and pastries were delicious. Fun little shop!

+ Fast, friendly service
+ Tasty pastries
+ Fun environment
+ Dat croissant, yo

I recommend this place as everything I bought and my friend tasted amazeballs. I look forward to coming back!
author: Jack T.

description: I was so sad when I arrive to this place at 12pm because most of the pastries were sold out. I really wanted the cruffins. There was only the chocolate croissant, savory Danishes, and California croissant left. If you want the good stuff, you gotta come here early because most of the goods are sold out by 10am. I actually fell in love with the California Croissant because it is similar to a sushi hand roll and I love sushi. There was smoked salmon, nori seaweed, ginger and wasabi. It was so good that I bough two more. I hate wasabi but they added enough of it to this pastry for me to like it. The wasabi paired well with everything in it. I hope to try their other pastries but for now, the California croissant is my all time favorite!
author: Peter N.

description: I found out about this place because I always see pictures of their sign, "I got baked in SF". So on my next trip I looked them up and sought them out. We did out research so we knew that if you wanted a cruffin (the croissant muffin they're known for) you should get there a little before 9am. They open at 7am, but cruffins don't go on sale until 9am. We got there around 8:50am to find there was already a line of about 15 people. We got in line and an employee brought around cute peace sign stickers. She said that sticker gets you two cruffins and once she is out of stickers they are out of cruffins. After 9am the line moved pretty quickly, we probably waited 20 minutes in total. I got one cruffin and one passion fruit donut to go (and of course took a picture with the sign). I was hugely disappointed in the cruffin. All of the flavors I had seen online sounded delicious! Cherry tart, s'more, vanilla. The day that we went the flavor was grapefruit ginger marscapone. I like grapefruit and I love marscapone, and I have mixed feelings about ginger so I got one and hoped for the best. The ginger taste was hugely overpowering I could barely stand it. Aside from the filling the dough was good, and the passion fruit donut was great! I would like to return to try another flavor, but probably won't due to the line and high demand. Its fun for a one time visit when you are in the city.
author: Kelsey H.

description: Friday Morning, 8:45am, it's our first time visit here. We saw there's line in front of this breakfast place and we joined in the people, around 15mins, we got The chocolate cruffin. It's pretty good and full of chocolate through the entire cruffin.
author: Peizhi Z.

description: Seriously, skip this overhyped bakery.  They do a solid product, but it certainly isn't worth waiting in line.  There donuts and pastries are good, but not great.  Your neighborhood shop is probably just as good... with no line and lower prices!
author: George F.

description:
FIRST CUSTOMER OF 2016: I'm from SoCal and I stumbled upon this on Instagram one day. I saw the Cruffins that someone posted and thought " I NEED TO TASTE THAT!!" So when I went to SF during New Years, I did not pass this opportunity to go and check this out. 

First mistake, I should have called for their hours on New Year's Day. I ended up waiting a whole hour by the door before they opened since they opened later. 

Second mistake, Cruffins are sold later, so when they opened the loathed famous Cruffins was not even available! I was so disappointed in myself. I could have saved my time and went somewhere else. 

I asked if I can get a free donut as first customer of the year and the cashier lady said ok. So I overly got excited and picked whatever I wanted, but as I was paying and mentioned it again, I got REJECTED. So that's another bummer on my list. 

The cream puff like donut was soooo good!!!! Probably the only thing I would brag about worth trying here.
author: Jasmine C.

description: Their croissants are SO DELICIOUS! I am strongly recommending the orange blossom cherry croissant. The outer layer is crispy and sweet with the white chocolate dipped, and the filling is just the right amount. I love their donuts, but the filling in the donuts is a little too sweet for me.
author: Jenny L.

description: Found this place online (We're from OC) and we had to come check it out! Everything we had was SOOOO good! We tried the ferrero rocher croissant, the raspberry cream filled donut, churro croissant and a chocolate chip sea salt cookie. (Im not too sure of the exact name of these, i could be a little off) Anyway, they were all amazing. Couldn't even pick a favorite because they were all tasty and special in their own way! This bake shop is definitely a must! Can't wait to get baked again! haha
author: Polly P.

description:
3.5 stars

Retried to make sure my taste buds were intact.

The amann isn't flakey and buttery enough for my taste buds.

It's good but my first impressions were right on bat.  Still like T Bakery and B Patisserie more.
author: Dorothy L.

description: If you want to enjoy  a wonderful breakfast, this  is the place  to visit  just before 8:30.Most people  usually lined up for the so -called cruffins . The stuff around  is super fresh, though the price  of  the  croissant  -shaped pastries is way higher than other pastries. However you are  limited to only two cruffins.You can also order some coffee if you like.
author: Frank M.

description: Cruffins are insane! Worth the wait in the long line. Get there early! Only two cruffins per person.  Go with a friend or two and enjoy the rich buttery creamy goodness!
author: Pro S.

description: DROOL! We got there around 9 on a Sunday morning and barely got 1 cruffin each. They hand out stickers to the people in the front who get two cruffins guaranteed. The line on the left (when facing the building) is for cruffins and the right line is for other goodies. There is a small sign that says this but we didn't know until we got to the front of the line. We pretty much inhaled the cruffins as soon as we got them. They weren't hot out of the oven but were still amazing. 1 was enough for breakfast for each of us and I was only slightly crazy from all the sugar that morning. They were very messy to eat so you have been warned. I highly recommend it if you can get there in time!
author: Shelby J.

description: I'm so excited that I finally crossed this off my list! I made two attempts earlier in the week but kept arriving right when it closed. When they announced that the flavor of the cruffin today was chocolate peppermint I was kinda bummed. Not really a fan of mint and pastries at the same time. However I still bought the max amount to bring home because I waited over half an hour. It tasted better than I anticipated. Hoping to try a different flavor on my next visit!
author: Roxanne B.

description: Do yourself a favor and check out this amazing bakery. Nothing predictable and everything delicious. I had a tough time deciding but ended up with apple bourbon monkey bread and berry pastry which was insanely good. I wish I knew about it earlier in my trip - I would have come very day for breakfast. Don't miss it.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Came in time for cruffins, but it was chocolate cherry flavored, and I don't like cherries... I wish they could tell us at least 24 hours in advance what flavors they would have (pretty please?)

I had the STRAWBERRY MILKSHAKE FILLED DONUT. The dough was fluffy and the sweetness came from the sugar coating and the filling. Yum! It was perfect!

The CALIFORNIA CROISSANT was saltier than expected and does not need the soy sauce that they provide. It has salmon, wasabi and ginger wrapped in seaweed inside of it. Because it is so salty, I wouldn't recommend it. 

I had a bite of my friend's HAM AND CHEESE DANISH, which was SO GOOD! Best savory pastry! Get it and you'll see what I mean. They also have an artichoke version.
author: Liliana P.

description:
The best pastries in SF.I come here almost every week to get my fill of their highly addictive salty,crispy on the outside,chewy on the inside choc chip cookies and buttery,flaky kouign amann.The donuts and all the other items will also not disappoint.
I only tried the cruffin once and it is good but do not have the time nor desire to wait at least an hour to get cruffin ( cruffin line starts at 8, cruffin comes out at 9 and is usually gone by 10
MUST TRY ITEMS: everything esp the chocolate chip cookies and the kouign amann
author: aj s.

description:
After weeks of having to put a trip to this bakehouse off, I finally got to visit this past Tuesday 1/19 - the rainiest of all days!
However, the good thing about that was that there was plenty street parking and no line.

I read previous reviews about how a weekday like Tuesday would be your best bet in arriving a bit later and still being able to snag a cruffin, but even on an extremely windy and rainy day, I would not arrive in the bakehouse any later than 9:30. On a day with better weather... good luck.

We arrived around 9:30 and they had good amount of cruffins left. By the time I left, there was around 3-4 left that were probably about to be scooped up any minute.
So if you are dead set on getting a cruffin, arrive EARLY so you don't feel like you wasted a trip. However, they had plenty of donuts and other baked goods left.

The cruffin flavor of the day was White Hot Chocolate, which was quite good. The cruffin itself though is rolled in so much sugar that you can't avoid getting your fingers sticky and grainy. x.x It could use less sugar in my opinion, but overall glad I tried it and would get again if it was convenient.

I also picked up the last Ube Puff and I'm glad I did! At first, I wasn't too impressed, but take some time to really appreciate the glaze with the ube... it's really a good combination! I would come back for this.

And no shame on snapping a photo with the neon sign against the wall, because if you didn't take a picture.. did you even go?!

Tips:
- Arrive as early as possible
- Best bet, try a weekday morning
- Check instagram on Sundays for Weekly Flavor Updates - they list the week's flavors in donuts and cruffins.
- Must purchase 6+ items for a box, otherwise items come in a paper bag or pay $1.50 for the box.
- Other than the cruffin, try the Ube Puff
- Snap a picture!
author: Kieu-Kelly T.

description:
The cruffins were good and really messy to eat.  If you are wearing black cover up!  
I hated the greasy donut filled things closest to the cashier.  The dough was nothing to write home about, basically a great way to add oil to your diet.  I'll go back to try the other things since the cruffins were all that but will definitely keep away from the greasy donut wanna be.
author: Carb Q.

description:
I must say, the line may be worth it at this little spot. To our disappointment, we arrived about 10a and they were already completely sold out of their well-written up cruffins. Guess the early bird gets the worm - or the cruffin, in this case!

Despite no cruffins, everything we tasted was scrumptious! The chocolate croissant was flakey as anything I've tasted in Paris and we especially loved the brioche filled with strawberry-jalapeno jam! No words can really do that justice. They do sell their jam and I'm still kicking myself for not picking up a jar!
author: Carolyn D.

description: Best cruffin ever! Absolutely amazing and worth the waiting in line. Only 2 cruffin per customer and now I understand why. It keeps you coming back for more. I'm not from SF, was in town for vacation with 2 girlfriends from London and visiting my good friend James who told me about this place. The best best cruffin I have ever tried and would love to go back to SF just for cruffins!
author: Liza T.

description:
This is both a great bakery and a hype factory at the same time.

It's a great bakery because they create delicious pastries and serve really good coffee. It's a treat just to smell the different creations they offer.

It's a hype factory because they have mastered the art of SF hype:
- Looong line out the door
- Media mentions whenever I read about SF bakeries
- Cool neon sign that is irresistibly instagrammable
- The cruffin, a gimmick concoction that sells out in like 5 minutes in the morning. I mean cmooon

I haven't had a chance to bite into a cruffin yet, but I had a bread pudding that was decadent and rich--enough sugar in it to last me for three days.

If the line is manageable, I'd come here again.

---

Distinguishing factor: Birthplace of the cruffin, a croissant muffin that is an gimmicky and overhyped as it sounds.
author: Nick A.

description:
My sister and I arrived a couple minutes after 9:00am (the time they start selling cruffins) and waited in line for 40 minutes before we reached the door. The wait seemed almost worth it when we reached the counter and the employees were very friendly, very helpful and knowledgeable. My sister noted that the employees seemed like people who'd be fun to hang out with outside the bakery. The four items we decided to get were a mint/Oreo cruffin, bread pudding, an ube puff, and a chocolate chip cookie.
The croissant itself was a little bit dry, but the dusting of sugar was a good addition. The bite with the filling fixed the whole situation. The day's flavor was mint Oreo and the mint tasted incredibly fresh. The combination was awesome!
Bread pudding was the winner of the day. It was super moist and the texture of the caramel and powdered sugar was lovely. It was slightly crisp on top and moist throughout. Super wonderful. 
The ube flavor in the ube puff was overpowered by the lemon in the frosting. It still tasted good, but the ube was practically undetectable. Everything had a good texture to it, the only thing was that the ube didn't shine. The idea is great, but just needs some refinement. 
The chocolate chip cookie was nothing special and neither of us enjoyed it. It was huge, which would've been great had it tasted good. 
Though we didn't enjoy every item purchased, we had an overall great experience and would return!
author: Araba A.

description:
This place is such bs. I came here soooo many times trying to get a cruffin (1 cruffin!!) And i NEVER got the chance too. I always line up and by the time its my turn they sold out! Why dont they announce it to the line! Make me feel like an idiot waiting for nothing. They should give up numbers or tickets so at least people in line knows whether or not they can even get ONE CRUFFIN! 
The other pastries are creative with flavors and assortment but i didnt wait in line for that. I cant even prepay for one or place in a big order. They keep saying they are short in staff. Then hire more staff!

Btw i did go when they come out at 9am. (According to yelp they are sold at 9am)
author: Sophie L.

description: This bakery is off the hook. Next level donuts and pastries for reasonable prices. Lines are heavy on weekends, and they sell out of the good stuff by 8:30. They offer multiple flavors of their filled donuts which is delish!
author: Jack B.

description:
Want a cruffin? They make a limited number of them (100-200) and sell them at 9am. Then, THATS IT FOR THE REST OF THE DAY! There's a limit of 2 per person. So arrive before 9 to secure your cruffin! 

Otherwise they have lots of pastries and donuts. We arrived after 9am so there were no cruffins for us but there was still a line. We picked up six items and spent $22. They were good, but not something that I would go back for. Thanks for sharing but not every social-media craze is worth it. :-p
author: Lisa C.

description: A hidden gem in San Francisco. Known for their cruffins and cronuts however, I opted for one of the delicious donuts. I love how the Bakehouse plays with unique flavour combinations, always something new and exciting to try!
author: Christina M.

description: Went on a random Wed morning and even though the most popular items were sold out, the things I DID get to try were phenomenal (croissant and danish). Definitely going back again to try and get my hands on a cruffin' :)
author: Tiffany L.

description:
They make good pastries for sure and I really liked what I had ; croissants and ube puff

But it sucks cus they make limited amount of their well knwon pastry, cruffins.
I went there twice and came out with disappointment because they were out of it.

I was there by like 11 as well.

They need to start making more of the good stuff!!
author: Yoon M.

description:
I usually do not give bad reviews but this case warrant 3 min of my time.
I always wanted to taste the creations of Mr Holmes bakery, so after stopping by at 9 am on Sunday I was able to get 2 cream filled doughnuts and 2 caramel covered croissant type things.
Cream was not creamy at all, it was kind of chunky, may be people like it this way but not me.
Caramel covered things were kind of heavy and too sweet. Again, overrated and personnel is entitled and rude. I would not recommend this place to my friends.
author: Dmitri G.

description: Uh-amazing!! So delicous! The Crufin was dope, the Salted Caramel cookie was legit, the churro croissant was delightful and the White chocolate donut was hand down the best donut ever. If your in SF go here and get something. Get Baked
author: Tommy C.

description:
I've been here a couple times in the afternoon waaay after that opening wave. The bread pudding here is amazing and I had been wanting to try a cruffin since they're so famous for them. 

So during my midday visits I've gotten the bread pudding, bread pudding is my favorite so I'm a little partial. Other things I've added to my pretty white Bakehouse box are the donuts and ube pastry. They aiight. 

Woke up at 7AM to get in line for the cruffins cause it just had to be done. Gingerbread flavor that morning for the holidays. Good news is that you're there so early that there is an abundance of parking.

I got 4 Gingerbread cruffins, 2 CA croissants (smoked salmon, wasabi and seaweed) and the bread pudding of course.

- CRUFFINS. Not worth the hype. The garnish was a gingerbread cookie, moist and tasty. The actual cruffin was disappointing. Covered in sugar so it was way too sweet and messy. The shape of it left it with little soft, inner pastry texture what would contrast the crispy outer crust. The custard was ok. Not too much flavor which is odd with gingerbread because it's so distinct. 

- CA croissant, pretty goood. Shaped like a regular croissant so there was good fluff inside. Served with a pack of soy sauce which I found unnecessary. 

Wouldn't wait so early in the morning again.
author: Melanie L.

description:
Waited in line for an hour for the cruffins. They look very pretty, but unfortunately fall apart due to the disgusting filling inside. Got the cookies and cream kind (can't comment on other flavors...) had to throw it away because the inside literally tasted like a snack pack pudding with some crushed oreos in it. 

My roommate bought some of the other pastries, but they were definitely average and not worth the exorbitant prices they charge.
author: Jeniffer B.

description: Worth the walk up Larkin for their delicious baked goods! From cronuts to stuffed croissants to more elegant pastries such as the kouign amant - you're in for a treat. Don't mind the sketchy environment because like all good things: they are hidden in the rough. Items are sold out quick but the lines all re even quicker so don't expect to wait too long. However, don't expect those yummy goods to be waiting for you! As an out of towner, it was the perfect way to end our trip.
author: Catherine W.

description: The Meka of baked goods! I am yet to get there in time for a cruffin, you need to arrive before 9am. But the beauty of not queuing for a cruffin is the queue for all the other epic baked treats is very speedy... I would recommend the sea salt chocolate cookie, it will blow your mind, the peanut butter donut is unreal and if your after something more Savoury the California croissant is a winner!
author: Nicola T.

description: I get that if you're annoyed..you're annoyed. But if you work at a popular place where new people are going to come seldom knowing exactly what they want. Maybe some customer service would help in our choices. Not staring and saying "can I get you anything??!" Like?? Bitch?? Food was great, s/o to the bakers in the back y'all  were great and smiling.
author: Adrian T.

description:
I'm a fan of this place for the quality of their food and their overall operations. In short, this place is ran well and is consistent in their product and service. If you're a fan of traditional and simple recipes (chocolate croissants, donuts), then you'll find something to like here.  On the other hand, if you're a fan of forward-thinking and unique recipes, you'll also find something to like here...purple cabbage, passion fruit, artichoke, potato...just a few of the ingredients they often feature in their baked goods. 

I'd give them five stars if they offered more of a 50/50 split between their traditional and unique recipes that are available on any given day. Lastly, I haven't tried the Cruffin...largely due to the long line. On the weekends, I've seen people lining up as early as 6:30AM.
author: Nick R.

description: Just line up and wait for your turn to get those two cruffin! Yes... it will be worth it!
author: J W.
