description: Super cute, trendy spot. Very small location so it doesn't take many people for the line to swing out of the door and down the sidewalk, but it moves quickly. The pastry flavors are unique but there's not much of a variety to choose from. I had high hopes but I was a bit underwhelmed when I tried my selections. It's popular so it might be worth another try.
author: Krystal T.

description:
Gimmicky

That's the word we came up with to describe this experience. Muffins were uneventful and waiting in a big line for ill-timed mediocre food does not sit well by me.  Much better bakeries (some with lines others with none) that are INCREDIBLY more creative and varied in choices.  

Avoid a potential mugging and looking like a line standing d-bag by passing this by.
author: C K.

description: Delicious donuts! Get here early if you want a chance to taste these tasty pastries. Cruffins come out at 9:00AM. The line is long and moves at a steady slow pace. Space is a little tight, but there is a nice neon lit sign "I got baked in San Francisco." that everyone always takes a picture of. Also make sure to order at least 6 pastries if you want the cute box!
author: Elaine D.

description:
I haven't tried their cruffins because they run out of it pretty quickly. Their rest of the pastries are good but maybe not worth the 30 min wait. I will go there again someday and update my review if I dont have to wait long and if the pastry I try is better. 

Tip: Chocolate croissant is great, you should give it a try.
author: Ankit A.

description: Delicious strawberry jalapeño filled muffin, it did not disappoint! Friendly vibe and makes for a great insta shot of course!
author: Amy J.

description: 2 words - chocolate croissant!  Looked like there were lots of yummy things to choose from but when you put chocolate and croissant together in one bite - it's a bit of heaven in your mouth.
author: Brenda D.

description: The place is overrated. My experience was terrible: waiting in line wasn't bad but once ur able to look at the pastry the people behind the counter are very rude: just looking at you, not at all eager to explain what they have to offer and pressuring u to make a decision. Tried the sticky bun - nothing special but good caramel. Would not recommend - there are so many good places to go have breakfast in SF. No seating.
author: Tjark E.

description: After hearing so many things about Mr. Homes' infamous cruffins, we finally were able to try them out for ourselves at the original location. I scoured the reviews on Yelp the day before we decided to try, and most people recommended getting there half an hour before the cruffins go on sale at 9 AM to guarantee a cruffin.
author: Regina W.

description:
These cruffins are delicious! Messy to eat, but who cares! They also make a number of other delicious pastries. The croissants are heavenly, very buttery and flakey. California croissant was a bit salty, but I enjoyed this savory twist to the ordinary croissant. The Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb was delectable as well.

The staff is helpful and I didn't feel rushed. The wait is long for the cruffins (even on a Thursday morning when I went), which are available at 9am. But everything else is up for grabs as soon as they open, no lines.
author: Reena S.

description:
One early afternoon I stumbled across Mr Holmes. I was impressed that they were sold out of everything except for a couple of jam filled donuts. After reading so many hyped reviews, I became very curious (and hungry). So me being in the city early one morning I decided to give it a go. I arrived at 8:15 a.m. and there was already a line of about 40 people--curiosity peaked.

The store opens at 8 a.m. with all their products on sale except for the cruffin. The line is only for the cruffin and they don't sell it until 9 a.m. I wasn't sure whether to wait 40 minutes for a pastry but I already started a pleasant conversation with someone in line so why not? Those in line will be given a ticket that guarantees them a cruffin, if you don't have a ticket you cannot be guaranteed one. There's a limit of two cruffins per person. Luckily if you don't want the cruffin the line for the rest of the baked goods is pretty short, yet they do manage to sell out between 12-2pm.

Cruffin -- good or bad? Average. It's a croissant in the shape of a muffin with a lot of cream piped inside and some whipped cream on top. I did purchase one of their croissants and it tasted almost the same but the cruffin is in the shape of a muffin and is coated in granulated sugar. The cream is very good; however, the flavor of the day was ROOT BEER. Root flippin' Beer?! Ugh. I like root beer but not in my pastry. Even though the root beer flavor is faint and the quality of the cream is good, it'd still be better to provide at least two flavor options. One with maybe, errr, vanila? And the other as root beer, the one flavor people wouldn't wait 40 minutes in line for. As a life long muffin fan I don't see any resemblance in muffin flavor or texture. It's merely the shape. What bafoonery is this? What you're getting is an okay croissant with a lot of cream shot into it. You'd be better off at Beard Papa.

While in line for the cruffin I decided to buy some of their other stuff to see if it was any good. I bought a "strawberry milkshake" filled donut, a traditional chocolate croissant, and a california croissant. The strawberry milkshake donut was easily the best thing I had at Mr Holmes in terms of bake and filling. Although, the filling was a bit off because it had a strange lumpy consistency. The chocolate croissant was okay. It was airy and crispy but I've had better croissants (i'm looking for more buttery flakiness). The california croissant is a savory croissant filled with cooked salmon and seaweed served with a packed of soy sauce. It does kind of taste like a sushi roll when you eat it, but I was thinking why the hell am I not just eating a sushi roll. It's an okay idea but the flavor needs some work.

-----

An average bakeshop. DO NOT WAIT IN LINE FOR THE CRUFFIN. There are so many other fantastic bakeshops in SF with little to no line. The limited quantities are for marketing purposes.
author: Michael H.

description: This place is amazing. One of the best bakeries I've been to! Parking can be tricky if you're driving, and bring extra change just in case there is a long line because this place is popular and can sell out quickly! We bought several things and they were all amazing. They have different flavors everyday, so plan ahead and come early.
author: Angelina M.

description:
This was our 5th time visiting San Francisco as we have family in the area and were in town for a wedding this past weekend. The bake shop was near our hotel and we read a lot of good reviews of it on Yelp, so we stopped in to get some pastries before hitting up the SFMOMA. 
We spent $35.00 in various pastries and coffee and orange juice. The girl doling out the pastries was nice, but when I simply asked the girl behind the register if the orange juice was fresh squeezed she gave me a lot of attitude and acted like I was crazy for asking the question. She said, "If we did that, we wouldn't have enough time to even bake." The response was really rude and a simple "no we don't" would have been sufficient. She was fairly tall, had reddish/ strawberry blonde hair and was dressed in a punk style with multiple piercings and what looked like purple triangular makeup or tattoos under or around her eyes. 
My mom and I brushed off the rude comment. We stayed in the store to enjoy our pastries. Because we bought a lot it was put in one of the large boxes. We had about 1.5 pastries left when we were done eating. We were walking to and from our destinations and didn't want to have to carry a big box to the museum. So I went up to the same girl to ask if we could consolidate and put our pastries in individual bags. She did and said we could just throw away the box. I asked if she could please throw it away for us and she gave an extreme negative attitude once again that we were putting her out by having to throw away one of the boxes from her store. I figured the store recycled and would have a better disposable system rather than me trying to hunt down an industrial garbage bin in the city while 7 months pregnant!
After she threw away the box she came back to the register, rolled her eyes, and yelled out "Jesus Christ!" She really was put off by actually having to work and give her version of "customer service."
The pastries were good, but not good enough to be treated in such a way. There are plenty of other amazing bake shops in the city that we frequented on that trip and that we will come back to. For example, Tartine Bakery had out-of-this-world pastries and excellent customer service. But unfortunately because of the poor customer service from this one girl behind the register, I'm sorry to say we won't be back to Mr. Holmes. She completely put a bad taste in our mouth and now we associate her with this bake shop.
author: Tala M.

description:
The strawberry cruffin was amazing! It was melt in your mouth absolutely life changing amazing. The pastry was buttery and tender and flaky and the filling was so light and perfect. I was singing on the sidewalk! 

The salted caramel donut was also amazing but there was a little too much filling. I loved the donut part!!!
author: Marilynn L.

description: This was probably the best pastry I've ever had!! Do yourself a favor and get a cruffin. And take a picture with their awesome neon sign. I wish this place wasn't 6 hours away from home. Make sure you get there early, my boyfriend and I got there at 10:30 and got the last two cruffins. They sell out quick!
author: Sarah Y.

description:
Yum!

We came so late in the day such that there weren't many options - the bakery had sold out of a lot of things. We had a pumpkin doughnut, which was unique but enjoyable, and a potato leek quiche, which was delicious. Even with the limited selection, we feel that we got a good chance to test out Mr Holmes Bakehouse, and it lives up to the hype. Just make sure not to come during the last hour of operation like we did!
author: Cameron N.

description:
Mr Holmes Bakehouse is the hot-spot of San Francisco right now. You will find pictures of the infamous "I got baked in San Francisco" sign all over Instagram. Seeing all the hype I decided that I had to go and check it out for myself. I visited around 11AM on a Saturday morning and there was a line out the door. It does not take long to get to the front though, as they staff works quickly. 

Mr Holmes has a inventive variety of baked goods that they serve to patrons. Items range from cruffins, to pain au chocolate, to the smoked salmon croissant. The treats are baked fresh every day and are some of the most creative, yet delicious, combinations I have ever seen. All the hype was definitely accurate. Mr Holmes is a must try for anyone in the Bay Area.
author: Aletta B.

description: Iam really disappointed with the cruffins. Not what I expected it. The service is bad too.
author: Marishao F.

description: Probably my favorite bakery of all time! The passion fruit donut is a must (if it is available), as well as the matcha donut. White chocolate Cruffins, yes please!!! The location might not be ideal, but you will soon see why there is a line outside of the door.
author: Arianna N.

description: The best sweets, I liked the strawberry filled. This pace is a must when in San Fran. It's a little pricey like 3.50 per and you can only get a box when buying 6 or more. Otherwise you get an adorable little bag.
author: Marcella R.

description: I've gone twice and I've enjoyed every bite of that darn cruffin! It's a pastry that I had never tried before but Mann am I glad I tried them! If you have a sweet tooth and love pastries make sure to stop by. They really are one of a kind. They have different flavors every day make sure to check their website or social media pages to see what kind of donuts/cruffins are being sold. I strongly recommend this place. They're great and one of a kind.
author: Jovany M.

description: Ive had so many pastries before in San Francisco. But I fell in love with this place. First thing, you need to come early - right when it opens there will already be a line out the door. The pastries are THAT GOOD that people will wake up super early just to get some. I have tried the strawberry cruffin (flavors change) they are all delicious!!! There's so much to choose from-everything is tasty, but very sweet (covered in tons of sugar)
author: Adelisa L.

description: Went here when they are almost sold out. I got the only thing left which was the ginger bread donut, which was good. Didn't expect I would like it.
author: Angelica P.

description:
This place is definitely a place to check out when you are in the area. I came here twice but the second time I got more out of my experience since I got to try the cruffins and other pastries.
We got there around 8:40 on a Saturday morning, and the cruffins come out 9am. There was a really long line behind us; it went all the way down the block and to the corner. I recommend coming around 8:40-8:50 to try cruffins. 
The flavor of the day for cruffins were chocolate peanut butter and the donuts were orange creamsicle and pumpkin cheesecake. I didn't like the flavors that much, but they were good, so you should depend it on the flavor before buying donuts.
Other than cruffins, we bought the cream/choux bombs, a California croissant, and two donuts. Everything was fabulous, but they are not good for a long car ride nor they are good a day after, so make sure you don't go overboard with cruffins or the other cream stuff.
The only pastry I would buy multiple of next time is the California croissant. This would be the only thing I stand in a line for. This is a masterpiece, and everyone should praise this wonderful creation. Seriously. It's terrific and savory and sweet and flavorful. The croissant is moist and stays moist and the salmon and ginger and seaweed...it's heaven. 

Definitely check out this place, but in my opinion, cruffins are not worth the line.
author: Diana O.

description: Smoked Salmon, Nori, & wasabi baked into a croissant!!! That my friends is the California Croissant & the best croissant I've ever eaten outside of Paris! You need to get there about half an hour before they open to get a sticker to guarantee a cruffin! The cruffin I had was a strawberry shortcake & it was amazing! My friend & I got one of everything and they didn't disappoint. Drop whatever you are doing & get Baked today at Mr. Holmes!
author: Liam P.

description: This place is great but get there super early if you want a good selection to choose from. By noon they are pretty much sold out.
author: Richard P.

description: Lived up to the hype. Not a long line on a Thursday morning. Got a cruffin, doughnuts and croissants. Not a huge sweets person but if I'm gonna eat some it's gonna be delicious and it all was. Staff could be friendlier. They acted like it wasn't a big deal to be at Mr. Holmes bakery and get over it, hurry up and what the hell do you want. LAME.
author: Lauren B.

description: 9:30 am on a Saturday- too late for a cruffin  oh well. So theres 2 lines, the left one (usually the longest one) is for cruffins, the right one for everything else. Instead we got the chocolate donut, plain and chocolate croissants. And the california croissant which has smoked salmon inside, it was really good and sorta tasted like sushi. All the pastries were delicious. If you want the box u gotta get at least 6 pastries. My 6 pastries came out to $23. Overall I liked the place and it is perfect for IGers
author: Natalia P.

description:
I've been coming for cruffins since before the insane line. The last 4 times I've stood in line for an hour. Today will be the last time I wait for a cruffin. Sadly, I don't think they are the same. The dough tastes yeastier and is a bit denser than before. Oh man will I miss the light and crisp crust and chewy centers.

Staff here is great and everyone seems to love what they do. Overall I like the bakery and it's a nice addition to the neighborhood. Is it worth the line, a NO! But, if it's the experience and bragging rights you want, then go for it!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I've been a few times now, and each time, the treats become more and more lack-luster. 
I love how inventive they are with the flavors and the fillings of the cruffins and donuts cannot be beat. Almost every time, the exception of once, I've wanted to take a jar of the filling home and pair it with something I've made instead.

The items are, more often than not, cold and greasy, as if the grease was meant to stay on, in order to hold the dusted sugar to the item. Seriously? If I'm waiting outside in the cold for at-least 45 minutes, because it's not enough to be there as soon as they open you have to be outside at least a good 20 minutes before, dependent on the flavor of that day. I mean, heaven forbid I get something toasty and warm to scare away the chill that has nipped at my fingers in the misty overcast weather that is San Francisco. Nothing is as unappetizing as taking a bite into a cold greasy donuts and looking at your hands as if you had slathered them in a sugar scrub!

Although it can be noted that the store and decor are so very inviting once inside. 
I will also say that the updates that get sent out regarding that week's flavors can be very helpful.

Oh and this 2 cruffin limit and only before a certain time. If you're extremely keen to try and I believe that everyone should try them once. I would encourage you to bring a friend or 2. Once you see the number of people in each line, as there are 2, one for cruffins and another for general items, it's best to divide and conquer.
author: Shannan M.

description: I visited SanFrancisco and this place did not disappoint. All I have to say is...I'll be back!
author: Michelle C.

description: Only bc I am wont be in the city for a really long time...sign is broke 8/1/17. Also we came by at 2pm..pnly like 2 option to choose from. Pretty disappointed :(
author: K D.

description:
THIS PLACE LOOKS AMAZING. I've personally never been, but all my friends have been and they absolutely love it. 
I would deffinentley recommend it
author: Colette H.

description: Love most of their pastries here. I haven't tried to go early in the morning as i am not a morning person but i will definitely try one of this days! It's definitely one of the best bakery in SF.
author: Emily Ann F.

description:
Made it too late to grab some cruffins on a Saturday, so we opted to try their other baked goods.  I was really impressed with everything we tried, from the donuts to the sushi croissant.

They only have one type of cruffin a day.  Unfortunately it isn't always posted so it can be a bit of a crapshoot (because some of us are picky about flavors...).  My boyfriend stopped in on a weekday morning to get us cruffins and said there wasn't much of a line.  We tried the chocolate banana cruffins and they were scrumptious.

It is a bit pricey and the line can get quite long.  But definitely a sweet treat every once in a while.
author: Michelle K.

description:
We used to walk by Mr. Holmes everyday on the way to work and only realized it was what it was after seeing the lines out the door and finally going to check out what the fuss was all about. Have never managed to get a cruffin because they don't pull them out until 9:30am and we always walked by at 8:30 :( 

BUT, cruffins aside, the savory croissants and fruit danishes (i like the apricot) are wonderful! so is the apple cardamom scone. so if you happen to skirt the line and they're out of cruffins, don't fear! 

Don't forget to take a picture of their uber-instagrammable
author: Vivian C.

description: Ummm, I am addicted to this place!  Best place in San Francisco and I am not lying.  I go to San Francisco just for the croissant's and omg, the donuts! Did I say donuts?  Yes, they are cardiman, Indian flavor, fudge?  Thai ice coffee.  I know it sounds odd but trust me it is the most amazing treat place on the planet.  I go so they are fresh.  Everything is fresh.  This place is off the hook.  I am not lying!
author: Elisa B.

description:
These are best Pasteries in San Francisco. The whole experience makes for a great snapchat story or Instagram photo. 

I like there Savory Treats and the daily choice of Cruffins. Also in order to get a box there is a 6 order minimum but you can add more if you'd like.
author: David C.

description: I stumbled across this place while going for a walk. Wow! The caramel doughnut was stunning. Soooooooooo much caramel inside
author: Andrew S.

description: Ordered the California Croissant, Kouign Amann, and the Apple Danish. The California Croissant is definitely the way to go! The croissant itself is light and flaky (which is expected for well made croissants) but the addition of nori, salmon, ginger and wasabi really make this pastry standout.
author: Tasha B.

description: Came here because of the amazing reviews I saw on Yelp. I can attest to how incredible their cruffins are. Definitely worth the wait. Get there early before they run out! If they do run out, their donuts are definitely worth a try.
author: Jenny X.

description:
I had no idea what a cruffin was and I'm glad I waited over an hour to find out! White Chocolate Raspberry cruffin and Orange Cardamom Stuffed Doughnut were out of this world! I also enjoyed the California Croissant. The Strawberry Jalapeño Brioche Bomb was very tasty.
A+
author: Greg D.

description: I've heard of this place from a couple of friends and I've finally decided to check it out with some friends and I gotta say it's lived up to the hype. Very good pastries!
author: Lil Y.

description: Great stop for breakfast, friendly staff! Opened promptly at 7am, with about five people waiting outside. The ham and cheese croissants were delicious. Would definitely be back!
author: Savitri R.

description:
Have had Mr. Holmes a few times now, and every time it is a treat.  When skilled bakers do what they do, pretty much everything they make is going to taste pretty awesome.  

You better get your butt here early, or else you won't be as giddy b/c they won't have as much left.  Getting in early is part of the awesomeness.
author: Frederick L.

description:
So I had my first CRUFFIN EXPERIENCE yesterday, and Damn, it was AMAZING!
I was on my daily walk and noticed the bakery was open and there was no line, so I popped in and asked what the must have item was, the friendly young counter woman pointed at the last remaining caramelized banana CRUFFIN and I ordered it, thanking the universe for its kindness! The air in the shop was full of excitement and disappointment, the excitement of myself and another young woman enjoying her cruffin with coffee, and the disappointment was from the guy behind me in line, upon realizing I had just gotten the last CRUFFIN of the day!! I snapped my obligatory fun BAKED photo, and stepped outside into the beautiful SF morning, and was immediately accosted by a sexy young woman asking what flavor my cruffin was (I didn't know they had varying flavors!) and I told her so...but that I got lucky and got the days last cruffin... I thought she might cry, right then and there! She anxiously asked if she could at least have a bite (Sharing a cruffin with a perfect stranger in the Tenderloin is SOOOO San Francisco) and though shocked, I agreed and I gave her a bite... She made a loving sound, thanked me (& we lived happily ever after)!  I started devouring this buttery, custardy delight as I headed to the wharf. OMG!!! The mighty CRUFFIN exceeded my expectations, it was AMAZEBALLS delicious!!!
Peace, love and Yelp!!
author: Sean M.

description:
The cruffin line was no joke. At 830 am it was already reaching the corner! Friends and I decided we'd skip it even though they look delectable. Luckily there is a separate line for everything not cruffin. 
Before stepping in you can already get a hit of that good old fresh bakery smell. Walking in, we looked over the counter for of breakfast pastry of choice. We ended up getting flakey buttery croissants,  crunchy soft Amalie amagn, crusty soft scones, and so much more. Even by the afternoon of the next day, the baked goods were still soft and enjoyable.
author: Ani Y.

description: It was a cold and rainy day,.....seriously, and that's why there were only a few people in line at 9:30am on a Sunday.  The Cruffin was good, but the other pastries, including donuts, and cookies were outstanding and worth a return trip, and I don't think you have to wait in line to get those goodies.
author: Mike C.

description:
First experience there here on vacation I would have given a 5 because the passion fruit custard cruffins were that good. 

Second experience was probably touted because we walked forever and stood in the rain. Barely got there before the cruffins sold out and they were banana custard. Not bad, just the passion fruit was so much better and the custard stayed together better than the banana for easier eating.
author: DeAnn H.

description: Delicious pastries, too bad I didn't get to try the crud find, however I did try everything else. They have to be eaten fresh! A lot of people are always there with the i cameras to take a picture of their famous light sign.
author: Mandy Z.

description: The 1st time I heard about this place was on TV. Finally visited the bakery in SF and there was NO lines, which was great. Its a great little spot and the pastries are good. If you are not a HUGE fan of sweets, this place might not be for you.  It is worth trying it and crossing it off your bucket list.
author: Anali J.

description: Got some pastries to go and it was all yummy. I went on a random day around 10am and there wasn't too bad of a line. Their cruffins are worth the wait.
author: Rana K.

description: We got there at 8am and there was already a line up.  Once we got to the front of the line we noticed there was a separate line for the cruffins so we didn't get to try those.  We had the matcha croissant, two of the filled donuts, raspberry hibiscus kouign amann, and peach danish.  I highly recommend the raspberry hibiscus and the matcha croissant.
author: Vincent S.

description: Hybrid pastries are pretty hype right now. Ever since the cronut era, places have been trying to combine two different pastries into one to make something interesting. When I went to San Francisco, my friend suggested that we go to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse to try a cruffin? WHAT? THOSE EXIST? I have never heard of a cruffin until August of this year LOL. If y'all want to know what a cruffin is, it is a hybrid of a croissant and muffin. My friend and I got to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse at around 8AM in the morning, which is really early, and there was already a line! They do not serve cruffins until 9AM, but their other pastry area opens at 8AM. When we went there, we were served the vanilla bourbon cruffin, which was good! It was an interesting concept because it tasted like a cronut but looked like a muffin? LOL. I would definitely try this place at least once and make sure you get there early because they sell out fast!
author: Nicole B.

description: The cruffins were DELISH! Woke up at 6am & waited a whole 2hrs on the cold streets of San Francisco on the 4th of July just for these bad boys.
author: Jeree P.

description:
Got here on a Wednesday morning about 9:30am. The line was decently long and all the cruffins were sold for the day. I decided to try the California croissant and my other party tried the regular croissant and banana muffin. The food was decent. I wish the California croissant was heated though, I think it would have tasted better.

Next time I head out to SF I'm going to be in line early just to try their cruffins. I need to see if the hype is real. I know if you follow them on Instagram they have the flavored of the week! So that's helpful in deciding if you want to go that day or not. Until next time!
author: Christie N.

description:
What can I say about Mr. Holmes Bakehouse that hasn't been said already? Known for their iconic "I got baked in San Francisco" catchphrase and their even more popular "cruffin", Mr. Holmes Bakehouse quickly rose to the top of every San Franciscan's bucket list of treats to try. 

HOW TO "CRUFFIN":
-What is a cruffin you say? Well, it's a flaky croissant..shaped like a muffin..filled with a fluffy cream filling..and powdered in sugar all around the outside. Yes, please do contain your excitement.

-Okay, so you want a cruffin? So does everyone else. The bakery opens at 8:00 AM, but the cruffins don't come out until 9:00. But don't show up at 9:15 expecting to snag one. Expect to line up in the cruffin line (yes, there's a separate line specifically designated to cruffins) at 8:00 - 8:30 and wait until the line starts moving when they bring the cruffins in at 9:00. My friends and I got there around 8:30 and got our cruffins at 9:30. If you're starving, you can always send someone (always come with friends) to grab some goodies from the non-cruffin line so you may enjoy those while waiting for your main prize. 

-Only 2 cruffins per person (sad, I know)

-Only 1 flavor per day. Flavors I've seen range from Matcha Green Tea, to Strawberry Milkshake, to Chocolate Passionfruit

-Those cruffins are MESSY. Eat in your car at your own risk. Expect sugar to get caught in your hair, on your face, on your lap, in your beard, or just everywhere. 

-When you pick up your two cruffins, you can either get them scrunched together in a little pastry bag, or you can opt to buy a really pretty box for like $1.50 or something. The box is free with the purchase of 6 pastries. Each cruffin costs $4.00. 
-----------------------------------------------
I personally went in on a Sunday, which I think is ideal considering the parking game wasn't so much of a struggle and meters were free. If you go on a workday, I'd anticipate a bit of a headache. 

I didn't have the opportunity to try any of their other baked goods, so this is just based on my cruffin experience. Although the cruffins were absolutely delightful, I don't know how often I can drive out into town to wait an hour for one dessert. I will say it was a great experience though, and I'm glad to have crossed it off my list!
author: Cara O.

description:
Question we ask ourselves before waiting at least 30 mins in line for a highly raved particular item (the infamous cruffin in this case), "Is it worth the hype?"

So the cruffin itself is quite the unique invention, I mean a croissant + muffin? Nice! The idea itself already takes the expectation high. Which leads to the debate of what's the hype... discussing in terms of a what constitutes a high review of a baked good: the cruffin was flaky, taking after the croissant, and had good texture. Maintained its body while I was eating it like a muffin, which I like, instead of it falling all over the place. But toooo much filling in my opinion. The flavor of the day was chocolate cherry, which I was already indifferent about (wish I was there for a matcha green tea or blood orange day) so the flavor was already kinda made me meh to the cruffin itself.

Now would I wait 30+ mins in line in the morning again? Maaaybe. Possibly for a different flavor. & more likely too if the prices weren't as steep for $4.50 each. 

Other items: doughtnuts were ok, was expecting better to be honest. Although the texture was once again good, just the filling kinda killed it. And not really a fan of the topped sugar. What I did probably like the most was the Ferrero Roche choux. Flaky and not too sweet. The kouign amann was also good, simple and not too sweet. 

Overall, in the texture/base of the baked goods were great. I would say 4-4.5/5. It's comparable to other bake shops like Tartine and b. patisserie where you can find that same quality in other products. But I'm giving Mr. Holmes itself only a 3/5 because the filling ruined it lol.

But major props to the business aspect though. The marketing for Mr. Holmes Bakeshop is pretty awesome in my opinion. Their 6 item minimum to get the free box is a great marketing sales mechanism. They also have launched their products FAST, effectively, and upscaled their reputation well through social media and this is greatly demonstrated as you have people waiting in line DAILY for their products. And their creativity- only joint I know that's skyrocketing in their sales due to their infamous cruffin. & not to mention I'm sure everyone wants to "get baked in San Francisco". 

"FInal": 3.5-4/5. glad I was able to see what the hype was about, but not that outstanding for me to go back. There are lots of other specialty bakeries also worth checking out.
author: Shelby C.

description:
The food was great, the service was not.  It's my own fault for not realizing their hours, so I admit that I came in shortly before they closed, but when I asked if they had any coffee drinks for sale I was told: "Yea, but we'll be closing soon and I'd rather not make new coffee for you."  

Not the worst, not the best.
author: Melody J.

description: Honestly, what can I say that hasn't already been said? GET HERE EARLY. Ya, I think that's the most important piece of advice I can give. If you're in the business of getting a cruffin or 2, try to get there before they open so you can get a sticker. I did not show up early enough to get a sticker BUT I got lucky and was able to get 2 cruffins of my own. I really appreciated how organized and informative they were about the cruffins. You will not know the flavor of the cruffins until you get there, but chances are it'll be good anyways. They had a coffee custard/sea salt caramel cruffin the day I went, and it was ahhffreakingmazing. They count the cruffins they receive, divide that by 2, hand out that many stickers, and usually not everyone takes 2 (the limit per person) and they end up with around 15-20 cruffins after the stickers are gone, which offers good odds to at least 10 people without stickers. IMO, you only need one, but if it's your first time, go ahead and take 2 and maybe regret it the next time you're at the gym (or don't, yolo) Also, boxes are $1.50, but they are free if you buy at least 6 pastries.
author: Christine G.

description: Huge hype around the cronuts - love the creativity (new flavor everyday) but very, very sweet (sure to satisfy any sweet tooth for sure) and difficult to discern any other flavors. My favorite item is the bread pudding - rich, dense, sweet, tart, mmmmm
author: Catherine H.

description:
Mr. Holmes hit upon an awesome advertising idea: limited supply. "What?!? They don't make enough for everyone to get one? The scarcity makes me want it more!" 

After waiting 30-60 minutes for a cruffin, the customer feels obligated to love it. (Get here after 12 and you are out of luck). Why else would you go through the hassle of getting out the door early on a weekend just to stand in line and be told you *might* get one? Why else would you pay $4.50 to buy something that partially fills your tummy?

Come here because it is on your list. Otherwise, go somewhere else. You can find equally delicious pastries for a bit cheaper.
author: Lams L.

description: Go on a weekday morning if you can for less of a wait. Churro croissants are the truth.
author: Caroline K.

description: This place has really good pastries. The price isn't too bad as well. There was a line but the workers help everyone very quickly. They will explain which pastries are which and they don't seem to rush you.
author: Bernard Q.

description: I'm so happy to have discovered this bakery while staying at Hotel Vertigo.  I had a croissant and my husband had a cruffin, and both were amazing.  The people working there were all super friendly and kept the line moving.  Next time I'm in the Tendernob area I will make every effort to stop by and pick up some pastries.
author: G S.

description: Fortunately, we live just up the street from this place. Unfortunately, their service is the worst. Probably getting more worst as I write this. Their pastries are great, a bit on the pricey side, but still worth the wait in line from time to time. Not a big fan of their cruffins, but their passion fruit donuts are fantastic. However, if you work in a customer service industry of serving people, perhaps a bit of smile (or better yet, an attitude adjustment) should be useful tool to have. I have to say, the attitude of the ladies behind the glass is somewhat of a soup natzy, consistently. Also, thought when you order 6 or more items, you were supposed to get a box, not individually bagged (and left out an item you ordered and still pay for). It will be a while before we visit this place again. If we do visit. I think I will stick to Bob's Donut on Polk Street.
author: Dot K.

description:
I finally took the time to get in line to grab myself one of those "famous" cruffins. 
That the it was a "Strawberry Milkshake" Cruffin. 
Had to wait about an hour in a designated line because the deman is quite high and they only make 150 or so of them every day. Price wise I'd say they are ok. The Cruffin itself is a bit dry on the outside and I'd prefer it without all of the sugar crystals on the outside, but that's just my taste. The filling itself was quite good and I very much liked the attention to detail with the small dried strawberry on top. In the past if tried a lot of trend food like Cronuts, Cragels and even a Burger wrapped in a Langos, and I got to say the Cruffin is not quite in the top spot. Funnily enough, I got two and put the second one in the fridge and ate it the day after. I actually liked it more that way because it wasn't quite as crispy on the outside anymore.
As a side note, I also got myself a Poppy Seed Lemon Donut from the place and that one was superb and helped the rating to four stars.
author: Martin H.

description: My niece found the reviews for this place and wanted to go try it.  The first day, we got there at 10am and they sold out if everything. We were disappointed.  I got there early the next day and was able to get them.  Good baked
author: Russ M.

description: I would never wait if the line is long for this place. It's a super cute bakery and fun to take a photo of the wall that says "I got backed in San Fran", but the baked goods are not anything special. I was hoping they would be warm since there were still on the cooling rack but now luck. The sticky buns are amazing however!
author: Charlotte E.

description: Pretty good eats here for me and my ten children. Mom has to be a wise consumer. Some call me the old woman who lived in the shoe. At times I feel like a big broken down dirty shoe. Thank yuh Mr. Holmes.
author: Mary C.

description:
Finally got to come here and try their famous cruffins! Worth maybe a 30 minute wait (I waited 20); I'm not sure I'd wait more than that, but I'm also not very patient. 

Tip: come during the week (and not on the weekends!), but please don't all go the day that I choose to go :-).

Their special for the day that I went was the chocolate banana and the custard was delicious and not too heavy. The flakiness in their croissant tasted like heaven (though I could honestly do without the burnt sugar on it. I'd rather taste that butter! hah)

I also ordered their donut with salted caramel filling (I think I had vanilla or chocolate before and those flavors were surprisingly better than the salted caramel), and the amelie aman (my favorite on their menu!). All of their pastries look delicious and I can't wait till I go back. I want to try the California croissant (salmon inside a croissant with nori) and I also still have an artichoke waiting to be consumed later today :-).
author: Christina C.

description: Lives up to the hype for sure, creative mix of traditional pastries and their custom creations that are delicious.
author: Colin P.

description:
Pretty good desserts - but I'm not sure that the cruffin is my favorite of all the choices that this bakery offers.

We got the bread pudding, s'mores cruffin, ube puff, pumpkin donut, and the hazelnut choux puff. Ranked below in order of favorite to least. 

Bread pudding: I think this one was my favorite - it was pretty rich in taste, but I do think it could have been a little more crispy on the top edges. The texture was pretty soft overall.

Ube puff: I really liked the way the pastry was cooked on this one. The edges were crispy, but were balanced out well with the filling, which wasn't too sweet itself. 

S'mores cruffin: To be honest, didn't taste like anything special. I wasn't a huge fan of the flavor, but the cruffin itself was nice & flaky. It has a cream filling, but I ended up eating more of the pastry pieces without the cream. No complaints, but no wow factor either. 

Pumpkin donut & hazelnut chou puff: These both were a little too heavy on the cream and were both a little too sweet for my taste. Felt like the cream to pastry ratio was too unbalanced.
author: Jennie Z.

description:
I had been following this place on Instagram for the last 6 months. When I decided to vacation in SF, I made sure this was at the top of my food list. I arrived early as other posts recommended. I was second in line and when they opened the door it was complete chaos. The have about 6ft of counter space and about 4 workers trying to get customers in and out as fast as possible. Normally this would be okay, but there was no menu posted beforehand. After waiting in line for 30 minutes, they expect you to order blindly and act irritated when you are slow to order. Not to mention the music is blasting so loud you have to yell questions and it is near impossible to hear the workers response.

As for the pastries, they were definitely not worth the hype. I got a chocolate/orange filling  donut, which was oozing with way too much filling. had one apple scone which was delicious and moist on the inside. I also has a chocolate croissant that was comparable to Starbucks version. This place would be okay to stop by and pick up a sweet treat, but it in no way deserves the hype that it's getting.
author: Nadia V.

description: Had to check out this place when I was in SF. Crazy long lines but worth the wait. Some people were saying how these are over priced and over hyped pastries, but I honeslty think these were some of the best I've had in a while. The "cruffin" is their specialty which is a hybrid between a muffin and a cronut. Cute branding, too. Will be back for sure.
author: Andy J.

description:
I'm a first timer. 

Did the usual thing, waited in line. Maybe like 40 minutes.. whatevs whatevs.

But kinda bummed that I got the curry pastry-- it was really not that flavorful and I was expecting at least something in the middle. So I'd vote it as..... plain. 

The cruffin was the opposite, gushing out filling and lots of cinnamon, twas great.
author: Dede C.

description: Arrive at least an hour before opening on Sunday to get a cruffin! Which was utter heaven! All pastries were tasty, but the cruffin was positively perfect! I believe in Saturday's more than an hour is needed, so grab a coffee and imagine the tastiness that will explode in your mouth once you bite into a cruffin!
author: Kyan S.

description: AWESOME bakery! Didn't wait in line for the cromuffin(?!) but got the churro donut, sesame donut, chocolate chip cookie, ham and cheese croissant, and a savory danish! ALL delicious!!! I ate these days after they were bought! (On vacation) I would suggest skipping the line and try their other products!
author: Van N.

description: Pretty tasty place... Waited in line for the infamous cruffin and finally got to try it! I wasn't amazed by it .. It was good ... But maybe that has to do with the flavor of the day .. It was apple pie ( which I'm not much of a fan of) but it was tasty! I enjoyed their passion fruit doughnut better... All in all it was a great place for baked goods :)
author: Brianna L.

description: The donuts, cookies and croissants are amazing. A great place to visit for a quick snack. Very small and limited sitting but the continuous line out the door says it all. Make sure you try the cornflake cookies. A-M-A-Z-I-N-G.
author: Suzette A.

description:
The LoJam: Accidentally went here on 4/20, stoners made eyes at our box of goodies all day long. Moderately expensive sweets and savories with creative flavor profiles and daily specials. For us the savory items stole the show, especially the California Croissant, a buttery, flaky furikake-topped croissant featuring smoked salmon, red pickled ginger, and nori. Famous for the cruffin, but the chocolate-peanutbutter cruffin left us disappointed - wish they had had the super matcha cruffin! 

Highly recommended for any mouths willing to wait in a formidable line.
author: LoJam ..

description: Was really expecting to be blown away. Sadly today's flavor, peaches & cream, was lacking in flavor. The cruffin is flaky like a yummy croissant and covered in sugar BUT it didn't taste like peach at all!! Might come back to try a different flavor and then will update my review. I did enjoy their coffee custard filled donut, nothing amazing, but it was good.
author: J G.

description:
THE CRUFFINNSSS!!!!

I usually go about an hour or so before open. Based on reviews it sounds like if you don't go early you wait about an hour in line anyways. There's a line for cruffins and a line for all other pastries, so if you go with a group you can send one person to fetch some pastries for while you wait. They give everyone who is guaranteed a cruffin a sticker, which is nice because it would be a bummer to wait so long and not even get one, especially if they could have predicted and prevented it. 

The cruffins are always amazing. Fluffy and flakey with delicious creative fillings! I kind of wish you could choose but I think part of the fun is going and seeing what the flavor of the day is. 

Also good photo ops. Cruffins are highly photogenic and I'm sure yall have seen photos of the "I got baked in San Francisco *peace sign*" sign. You're guaranteed a minimum 40 likes on Instagram :P
author: Terra C.

description: The place lived up to the hype in taste and aesthetics, but the customer service was bad.
author: Isaac M.

description: Creative and edgy pastries. Definitely an SF institution these days!
author: Pete S.

description:
Walk past here in the morning and have always been tempted by the buttery-brown-sugary-amazingness wafting out into the street so I had to give it a try. 

Everything looked and smelled delicious. I had a ham and cheese croissant, go-to whenever I can find it. It was good, but nothing toospecial. I have a feeling their sweets are better than their savories

I would definitely go back but wouldn't go out of my way (or wait in the crazy-long line)
author: Anne M.

description: Had to try this place while in SF.  We came later in the day so they didn't have a ton of things left. We ordered three different pastries (don't even remember what they were anymore) but everything was ridiculously delicious. My taste buds were rejoicing.  Next time I'm in SF this will be my first stop.
author: Zoey D.

description:
Amazing! 
Its definitely worth the long wait in the morning. Have been recommending it to everyone and will continue to do so...
author: Taraneh G.

description: We showed up at Mr. Holmes bakery at 9 o'clock hoping for a cruffin. The line was crazy long. We decided to go elsewhere for breakfast. Thought we would let the line die down and come back. We came back around 10:15 and the line was still there. The guy two people ahead of us got the last two cruffins. We settled for the chocolate croissant. It was OK but similar to what we can get at home. Next time we will stick it out and try to be patient.
author: Ben B.

description:
We tried Mr Holmes today. One thing you need to know.. Get here early if you want to try their cruffins (croissant/muffin mix), they usually sell out an hour and a half into the morning. 

We got a plethora of other items besides the cruffin. California croissant = California roll ingredients inside a croissant, cheesecake, and other fine items. 

This is a good place for the great smells and to tickle your other senses too.

Awesome neon sign in the store too that reads, "I got baked in San Francisco".
author: Stephen L.

description: I tried a strawberry croissant. Meh. Well, it is decent, but I expected French quality for the croissant shell. The filling was good, though it had too much jam. I mean jam, not preserve. I reconsider going back for famous cruffins.
author: Charlie S.

description:
Holy cow. Just like homemade pie, except waaay better than a lot of homemade pie. Including mine, sigh. And mine's pretty dang good. 

This review is for a whole peach pie I purchased. I'm a bit of a pie snob, and really rarely like pie that's not homemade, but I've been known to make exceptions for verrry good pie (like that served at our wedding!). However, no time to make a pie left me schlepping to the nearest bakery. Thank God it was Fillmore! The pie was expensive ($30), and I kinda wish they'd told me about the $10 refundable pie-pan deposit policy when I called on the phone (only because I leave the city soon), but that's really no problem. Also the pie was TOTALLY WORTH $30, and I'm a cheapskate. Ultra fresh peaches and really on-point crust. Highly recommended! Would've taken a photo but it was gone way too fast.
author: Do M.

description:
I'm OBSESSED with these cruffins and their clever marketing. 

MUST get:
-Amelie Amann
-CRUFFIN (Duhh)

Not worth the calories:
-Caramel Donut
-Choux bomb
author: Jaime M.

description:
For how much this place was hyped up (in regards to cruffins), it was really only okay. It was hard to eat and honestly too sweet. This could be because I didn't get any of the custard filled ones and instead had the apple cinnamon flavor. For those looking for info on lines for cruffin: came on a Monday at ~8:50am and there was a short line already. Cruffins sold out by 9:15am from what I saw. 

Their pastry is delicious and buttery, so I'll give them that. Got a regular croissant and it was one of the better croissants I've had (apparently should have gotten the California croissant based on friend's recommendation!!). Also got a cranberry pecan danish where the pastry was also good and cranberry was tart. Overall though, it was average in comparison to what I was expecting. I wouldn't wait extremely long or anything for them, and pastries are all pretty pricey.
author: Jessica N.

description:
Mr. Holmes is so fucking delicious.  Their sweets are not too sweet, which is great for someone like me who does not have a big sweet tooth. 
The only thing that sucks about them is that there is almost always a line. And the line always goes out the door and up the block.
author: Lindsay L.

description: Best CRUFFINS & DONUTS ever!! And the box design is really nice. Everything sold out quick so be there early, especially if you want cruffins.
author: Nuntanat R.

description:
The pastries are excellent.  Wasn't a huge fan of the near-charred exterior of nearly everything they sell, and they've overdone it on a few of the amanns I've got, but I've been won over.  Donuts are inconsistent but sometimes clever.  Focus on the danishes, muffins, brioche.

I'm no retail genius, but I hope one will come along and improve the front of the shop.  I've never stood in the lines (what's a cruffin?), but even in the off-peak times it's kind of a hassle; as you ask the nice people working the counter what is in this donut or in that roll, you get the impression they've had to explain every pastry to every customer that has walked in.  Someone get Mr Holmes a chalkboard already!
author: Ryan O.

description:
Pastries are good.
Brioche donuts are especially good.
Coffee is decent. 
Tiny space and not very practical but instagram worthy.
Coffee station is hard to get to when there are people in. 
Customer service is lacking-- the girls behind the counter appear annoyed to answer questions (and many pastries are not labeled), I can never hear they are saying because the music is too loud and there's a glass barrier in between us. I'm not soft spoken but am seemingly never heard the first time I give my order because I get blank stares as they wait for me to repeat myself almost always. When there's a line, I feel especially rushed as if I was supposed to know what I wanted before I came in. Advice-- turn your music down so you can hear me the first time and smile a little. 

My boyfriend and I have gotten so frustrated with the tiny space, unfriendly attitudes and chaos that we've stopped coming in.
author: Sheena A.

description: So sad they ran out of cruffins :( I'll be back next time though! The other pastries are pretty yummy, so definitely worth the try!
author: Michelle C.

description:
hmmmmm 5 STARS for the cruffin itself but Mr Holmes only really deserve 3 STARS average counting all their other pastries.

Arrived 8:40am on a Friday and waited in line for approx 40-50 mins before getting my hands on 2 cruffins.

Salted Caramel Coffee Cruffins - First bite on the bottom was definitely the flakiest, tastiest pastry I've ever had. Coffee flavored filling was really good, but the salted caramel syrup/drizzle was waaaaay overly sweet. Had to scrape it off to eat the rest of the cruffin. Still a must try though.

Chocolate Pistachio Chocolate - Did not taste right, and I really couldn't put my finger on it. I couldn't eat the whole thing, and overall was too sweet.

Almond Bostock - 2nd favorite pastry after the cruffin. Good but still overly sweet for my personal taste

Amelie Aman - Got this because it was highly rated on yelp.... but it was just okay... and of course, it was too sweet 

If you haven't seen the pattern yet, I find everything overly sweet at Mr Holmes. I paired the pastries with black coffee and it still didn't help. Ill just put it out there that I don't prefer white people dessert because they're too sweet. (For reference, I like dessert places like Kowloon Tong. My Asian tastebuds can't handle the white people sweetness.) 

Overall, I would definitely come back, but just for cruffins next time. And maybe try the banana or passion fruit donut since they didn't have it the day I go. And I've been praying that the next to I go, they'd have either matcha cruffins or donuts. That is my dream.
author: Harriet W.

description: Came here on a beautiful fall morning just as they were putting the cruffins out. Although I had heard this place gets Disneyland-esque lines forming for their delectable sweets- there were only a few people ahead of me- which was perfect for those instagramable moments of patience and wait. While the cruffin did seem pretty appetizing, I opted for the thai tea donut instead and I have to say that it was pretty good but I couldn't imagine having more than one. The thai tea cream was sweet but not too sweet and the outside of the donut with sugar crystal was the right amount, but I still feel like I might've needed a tea or milk to go with it. Definitely, worth a visit back to pick some up for my friends and I.
author: Desiree C.

description: I love the packaging; coolest ever.  Love the plain croissant, best break fast. The cashiers are awesome; always paying great music...
author: Kirsten F.

description: I went here for their specialty pastry you are only allowed to have 2 of. I think it was called a Cruffin? The service was pretty quick. I had some sort of caramel popcorn Cruffin and it was pretty good. To be honest I really enjoyed their donuts more though. I am biased because I am not a true fan of caramel stuff. The people that work there were super friendly and very helpful at helping me pick out something tasty to share with other people. I shall return one day in order to try another type of Cruffin and other pastry stuff.
author: Sean R.

description:
I thought I wouldn't like the cruffin. I mean, it's just a croissant that's shaped like a muffin, rolled in some sugar, topped with some pop rocks, and filled with some kind of cream. Plus you can't even see the flavor of the day until you get there (at 8:30 am, if you wanna get a cruffin!)

But I was wrong. Forgive me, cruffin. You are pretty amazing. Unlike the cronut (which is disgusting, sorry) the cruffin doesn't taste like oil, and the sugary crust gives it a fantastic crunch which perfectly complements the silky smooth custardy filling (which is just lightly sweetened and heavenly). I had the privilege to try the chooclate brownie cruffin, and I hope to one day try the matcha cruffin.

Plan of attack: Get there by 8:15 am. Bring at least one other partner in crime. On the weekend there are two lines - the Cruffin Line and Everything Else Line (weekdays are easy - just one line). Your partner will go to the Everything Else Line, and you will make a beeline for the Cruffin Line. It would behoove the person in the Everything Else Line to get a box of six pastries (favorites: apple hand pie, almond croissant, almond bostock, kouign amann, California croissant with smoked salmon and wasabi...the list goes on! I loved the ferrero rocher cream puff thing for the creamy hazelnut filling, but not for the outer shell - way too crunchy such that when you bit into it the filling squished out - not architecturally sound but still worth trying!). 

When they get the goods, they should join you in the Cruffin Line (by this time you will likely have gotten a sticker guaranteeing you at most two cruffins) and the two of you should enjoy a few of the pastries while waiting for your cruffin. 

A note on cruffin line etiquette - if you joined someone in line, YOU DO NOT GET A CRUFFIN. They get max two, because they've been waiting. You are a bystander, just there to watch the show. Common sense right? Do you want to be killed by the people behind you? Didn't think so. So don't do it.

Now go wake up early and get your cruffin and other pastries!!
author: Connie W.

description:
I wanted to know what all the hype was about these cruffins so I made my boyfriend wakeup early with me as we trekked through the Tenderloin and over to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse. I was a little too eager as we showed up around 8:15 on a Tuesday morning. I knew that cruffins were not sold until 9 but I wanted to make sure my waking up early would be rewarded with a cruffin!

My boyfriend purchased a coffee while we waited outside of Mr. Holmes Bakehouse for cruffin time (theres a convenient countdown clock on their website, btw.) A line began to form around 8:40, which is probably a little later than normal considering this is a Tuesday morning. Once 9 o'clock rolled around, we were inside the quaint, yet trendy, bakeshop and decided to order 6 pastries. If you want a box, you have to order 6. The cruffin flavor that day was pear cobbler, and since that sounded so delicious, we decided to get 3 cruffins. (There are 2 cruffins allowed per person.) To complete our 6 pastry collection, we went with an ube puff, the California croissant, and a passionfruit donut. 

So now, the verdict: the cruffins were delicious!!! Layers of crispy croissant in a vertical format, covered with sugar, and complete with not overly-sweet filling. It was certainly messy but worth it. I was a little disappointed that we didn't order our allotted 4.
The ube puff was interesting. I had no idea what ube was but the pink prickly pear-based icing on top was intriguing. The puff was good, yes, but didn't taste like much. I would have traded it for that 4th cruffin.
The California croissant was excellent! Complete with a little package of soy sauce. If you're looking for a savory, rather than sweet, start to your day, go for this!
The donut flavor choices for the day were passionfruit or coconut. We chose passionfruit and gave the donut to my boyfriend's dad. He told us it was excellent! 

So overall, if you have some time to spare in your morning to wait in line, go get yourself a cruffin! I don't think you will be disappointed!
author: Bridget G.

description:
Cruffins are sold out at 9am, they say. Why are you not making more of great stuff?
Muhhhh! 
Alternatively other pastries are looking great, and cream filled donuts are lovely, made light and packed full. 
Still, I have to get here 8am? :-/
author: Chacha M.

description: This place was a top destination as it's an hour from my place and I'm a monster when it comes to all things baked goods and donuts. The location is fairly easy to find in the city - I came here over a month ago on a Wednesday with no line or rat race for cruffins. The pastries themselves are gorgeous and deserve the photogenic shots on social media. I wish I loved the cruffins, donuts, or bostock but thought everything was overly sweet. It was nice visiting Mr. Holmes Bakehouse but I won't be back for dessert.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Lemon curd donut - the lemon curd was good, but the dough was no different from any corner store donut, but you judge a bakery by the consistency of the dough. 

Salmon noori croissant - croissant was dry and hard,  not light and flaky, and too salty.  

    I haven't try their cruffin, but don't know if I want to judging from these two items, I'd say Mr. Holmes is overhyped. 

If you want to try a real croissant, go to Neighbor Bakehouse.
author: L V.

description:
It's a small and very hip bakery on the outskirts of the not-so-nice Tenderloin neighborhood. Take a picture with the "I got baked in San Francisco" sign! 

There wasn't a line when I went in the late morning on a Friday, but a lot of their pastries were sold out. I got a cheesecake-filled donut, and it was absolutely delicious. Very soft and sugary!

Their cruffin (love child of a croissant and a muffin) is apparently very famous, though, so I'll be back to try one!
author: Victoria C.

description: When I moved to San Francisco in December, this was one of the first bakeries I heard about. Everyone was talking about it so I knew I had to try it. I was definitely worried it was overhyped but my goodness they do donuts right! I'm a cream filled donut junkie and these are by far the best I've ever had. Usually you get 90% dough and 10% cream. It always leaves me a little disappointed. But not with Mr Holmes donuts! They're 80% cream and 20% dough. They taste incredible. I also purchased one of their chocolate chip and sea salt cookies for my husband and he absolutely loved it. Can't wait to try everything they have to offer! I did get there a bit late (around 12:30 or so) and a lot was sold out. So make sure you get there early to see everything they have to offer.
author: Charlene S.

description: Delicious, delicious simple delicious. The only downside of their "cruffins" is that they should sell them for a longer period time, they sell out before 11:00 am most of the time,  that is what I heard. I was lucky that only spent 30 minutes for the waiting since they start to sell them exactly at 9:00 am. I live in LA and I can't wait to them to open their new location. I've tried the Raspberry Pistachio cruffin since that was the flavor of the day. Check their Instagram for the flavor "of the day", they change every day. Nice culinary experience on my San Francisco vacation.
author: Erika A.

description: I dread long lines, but this place is worth it! Im yet to get there early enough to try the cruffins though.
author: Roy - Ocean IPhone Repair ..

description: Came here at 2plus on a Sunday and there was no queue! Ordered the sweet Danish and strawberry cream donuts. The strawberry cream is just absolutely yummy!! Totally got baked. The cranberry Danish tasted awesome even after being in the fridge for a day. Would totally buy more the next time!
author: Qianqi L.

description:
You've got to order Kougin Amann. It was crispy, buttery and absolutely wonderful. The cruffin was great as well. The flavor today was Chocolate Orange! 

Can't forget to mention the super cute decor inside! Great for foodie photos.
author: Kelli K.

description: While the baked goods at Mr. Holmes Bakehouse are quite good and inventive. To wait in a long line and have a clerk server who has a way too loud voice and a brusque, unfriendly and haughty demeanor, kind of ruins the experience. I had the salmon/wasabi croissant and it is excellent, but no matter how busy or popular, I still expect hospitality, which was not in evidence.
author: Neil K.

description: Pleasantly surprised by this place, even after waiting an hour and a half. It's annoying that this place doesn't open earlier in hopes of beating my fellow yelpers and tourist alike. So the DL- there will be 2 lines, one starts at 8 for the regular items( donuts, fritters,etc) the 2nd starts at 9 am for the cruffins which only come in one flavor (a flavor of the day) and are limited to 2 per person. On this particular day the flavor was cherry cheesecake and it was delicious. Youl'll line up, get a sticker proving you've been waiting and then one by one approach  the cruffins which will be doled out like communion. The cruffins are light, perfectly browned and flaky with just the right amount of sugar to incase a filling that is ample and throughout; you'll get some feeling in every bite just like with the jelly filled donuts. their donuts  are perfection too,most importantly not greasy and the fillings taste fresh and homemade.
author: Sabrina D.

description: YUM. Came here on a Sunday morning a little around 9:15am. There was already a big long line for cruffins! There's a shorter line for all the other bakery goodies too. Apparently just before 9am they hand out stickers, and if you have a sticker you're guaranteed 2 cruffins max. My boyfriend and I were only a couple people behind the last people with stickers, so we decided to take our chances since the lady said usually not everyone buys 2, so a handful of people without stickers end up getting cruffins! And we were one of those people!! I was sooo happy AND we came on a great day because they had cookies and cream which is one of my favorite flavors! It was the perfect flavor for my first cruffin ever :) These things are pretty expensive at $4.50 a piece, but they are worth the splurge once in awhile! The cruffin was SOO good. It was basically like a flaky, buttery croissant shaped like a muffin, filled with cookies and cream custard, dusted with sugar. Good thing I live an hour away or else I'd be here waaay too much...
author: Alyssa W.

description: The Choco cruffin was alright, it's like having pudding in the middle of a croissant pretty much sums it up (huge portion, was overstuffed with just one). The cookie that day was overbaked and not that moist. The lemon donut was too tart by the end of the last bite.
author: Sue N.

description: A must see if you're in san francisco. A bit pricey but worth it. Wish they had other cruffins but the bacon peanut butter cruffins still in the spot.
author: Ashley N.

description: I've only bought baked goods from Mr. Holmes a handful of times, but everything I've purchased from here is so ridiculously delicious. Totally worth waiting in line. Tips for avoiding the lines: 1) go before 8 am and 2) do some research and know what kind of baked goods you want beforehand. Honestly, whatever you do get, it won't disappoint. It's a little pricey (as in "more expensive than getting a doughnut at Bob's"), which makes this place great for occasional "treat yo'self" moments.
author: J L.

description:
Is it noob to expect Mr Holmes to have cruffins at 2pm on a Saturday? Lights out, sold out. I wish I had more to say but lesson learned. Early bird does get the worm.

One star for being sold out but promise to update if and when I roll out of bed early enough on a weekend...
author: Esther C.

description:
Mr. Holmes's employees are really nice and welcoming but i dont like the owner. We walked there at 1pm hoping its still open but they told us theyre sold out. We asked them if we could use their bathroom but the owner(or so i guessed) said theyre closed already and the bathroom was for customers only. He said theyre counting money right now and we couldnt be there. 
I mean, you could say it more nicely and we were your customer if you still had your cakes. We came there based on the great reviews but now, not so much
author: Kallista P.

description: If there's a line wait in it . Because what you are about to eat some of the best pastry money can buy. I don't care how busy you are it's worth it. Truly fantastic
author: Ginger S.

description: The hype is true and Mr. Holmes DID NOT disappoint. Came here on a Tuesday morning all the way from San Jose, so I made sure to get here extra early because one time I was by the area and Mr. Holmes had already sold out before their closing time. I was one of the first ones in line on this day and I didn't even have to wait long. I ordered two of their banana creme cruffins (Mr. Holmes has different flavored pastries everyday) which was one of the best pastries I have EVER HAD!! I also ordered a cupcake looking pastry which was also BOMB.COM. To add to my wonderful experience, their employees are super friendly and the shop is super cute! Usually when a place is hyped up, I end up being disappointed, but Mr. Holmes did not disappoint me whatsoever!
author: Jasmine S.

description:
Man, I was really hoping to like this place. 

We waited in line for about 20 minutes. The inside is very small. The boxes and minimal decorations are cute. Friendly workers. The pastries weren't that great tho. 

My bf got a caramel filled donut. It was oozing and he said it was overwhelmingly sweet. 

My brother got the cherry chocolate cruffin and two California croissants. The cherry chocolate cruffin was filled w chocolate cream and he ended up throwing it away. That was also very sweet. 

The California croissant is good but is a bit salty. I would've enjoyed it w wasabi on the side instead of smeared on the inside.
author: Jessica L.

description: First time I got pastries from then was about two years ago. Since then, they have been my favorite place in the city. Besides, their packaging is just awesome. Baked in SF. It couldn't be more appropriate. LOOOOOVE their pastries!!! Wish they can have a pop-up on the Mission =).
author: CLR A.

description:
I had the pleasure of going to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse twice in one week, which I was very happy about because I got to try different flavors. I got the matcha green tea, strawberry milkshake, praline, and salted caramel donut (Donuts are $3.50) , the blueberry brioche bomb ($4.00) , choux bomb ($3.50)  and the california crossiant  ($5.00) . The donuts were very fluffy and soft and there is enough filling to dough ratio which is very hard for me to find. The blueberry brioche bomb was delicious with fresh blueberries and the dough was soft. The choux bomb was sweet for my taste, but nonetheless definitely something I would get again if I have a sweet tooth that day. It is somewhat of a ferrero rocher flavor. And the infamous california crossiant. This is one that is worth trying. It is between a savory and sweet pastry considering that there is salmon, ginger, seaweed and wasabi inside the crossiant! It is ironically one of my favorites on their menu. I was not able to stay in line for the cruffin because they release them at 9am and I had an exam to take during that time. I heard that they are definitely worth it, but it is only two cruffins per person. 

I called the bakehouse around 6:30am though to check what kind of flavors they would have for the day so you can do that if you want to see what they are offering for that day. You have to purchase 6 or more pastries to receive the box, or pay $1.50 for it. I got one of their totes as well which is essential to carrying those boxes out the door!
author: Loree T.

description: I literally love every single thing I've eaten here. The filled donuts are a bit too sweet for me but they definitely do not skimp on the ingredients. The cruffin is just the right amount of flaky. The savory and sweet danishes are both so so so very delicious. The mushroom one may be my favorite. I waited in line for around an hour and a half for the cruffin on a Saturday morning but I would gladly do it again. I really want to try the matcha flavor. And the day my coworker brought in croissants, muffins, donuts, and danishes were maybe one of the happiest days in the office. Sure to be a crowd pleaser. Anyone could find something to eat here!
author: Michelle K.

description:
Doughnuts, chocolate croissant and cruffins  are good. But the surprising favorite was the croissant bostock. Flavor was blueberry the day I got it.

If you're at the door by 8:20 to get the cruffin, you should be set. I arrived 8:30 and I got the first cruffins from the third tray. (Only 3 trays a day are baked; two per person.)

I don't like Sightglass coffee at all; it's consistently bitter. I wish they brewed different beans.

Amelie Amagn $3.22
Donut $3.22
Muffin $3.22
Brioche bomb $3.68
Croissant bostock $4.14
Chocolate croissant 3.68
Sightglass coffee $2.29
author: Xteethx B.

description:
I went on the day they had the matcha filling cruffin.

Got three and ate them through the course of the day. They tasted like absolute heaven. If I wasn't crying before, I am now.

Get down there and empty their shop.
author: Jessie Q.

description: Came here for my birthday breakfast. Had a jalapeno and strawberry flaky pastry and chocolate something and the bread pudding I can't remember the names but everything was so delicious and perfectly baked. The bread pudding isn't too sweet, but it is super thick and heavy. I'm not the biggest fan of bread pudding in general, but it was relatively good; I really enjoyed the other pastries much more. If I lived closer, I'd gain so much weight! Haha.
author: Zara S.

description: I got an apricot danish that was really good but I was surprised with the lack of options.
author: Juliana B.

description: Awesome, got there around 9:30a on a Friday with only 7 people in line. I wish there was a way to know what the flavors of the day before I get there and wait. There might be I am just not aware of it. Other then that the Ubi Tart was my fave.
author: Desirae B.

description: Good pastries but the line for the cruffin was quite extreme. Interior was kinda cool, so I understand why Instagram basic betches like coming here.
author: Kay C.

description:
This really should be a 4 star review. It is a 4 star for the baked goods but I knocked one off for the young Asian woman that was rude and didn't listen to me and got my order completely wrong. There is a line in the morning at this place and I waited 15 min which wasn't too bad. But the wait then becomes an issue when you have a bad service experience. The woman missed 2 items and gave me attitude when I asked for a nicer looking pastry that was literally next to the one she smashed with her tongs. Then one of the other pastries I chose she flipped over and all of the delicious filling came out. Oh and she didn't explain the items well- maybe she didn't know what they were? Missed ingredients completely. The only way I knew what anything was, was because of the super cheery, happy other woman working there. I didn't realize she missed items I ordered until I got home of course. I get it's a Sunday morning and maybe you're cranky but then maybe you shouldn't be working a customer service job. 

Regarding the goodies- so far the churro croissant is amazing. Cornflake toffee cookie also yummy. Everything was the perfect amount of sweet. Likely I won't go back tho. So many other bakeries with great service to frequent like B patisserie and Tartine, craftsmen....
author: a g.

description:
Though I forgot to right a review the first time I came here.. I'm glad I didn't given the type of service I had today. Last time I was here (still not aware of any particular time frames of when cruffins are offered to be purchased), I wanted to try this 'Cruffin' hype. I got here the moment it opened to avoid a line.. But it was obviously no line. The lady told me I had to wait an hour because the cruffins aren't finished being made yet. Sure. Not an issue. I've seen photographs of how long the lines were so I asked if its possible if I could pay for it first and I'll be back in an hour to pick them up. She was fine with that and accommodated me. Awesome. Came back in an hour. Picked them up. Brought them back and shared with my family. It was delicious fresh. Different. Amazing.

Today however left a bitter taste in my mouth. Extremely disappointed. I just drove up from LA. Dropped my luggage off and headed straight over here. Arrived at 735am. There's a line and no parking close by since its street cleaning on some parts of the streets nearby. This time.. I got a really rude gentleman. Sorry.. Not sorry NOT gentleman.. More like a DOUCHE.. His response was extremely rude towards me. I asked when the cruffins were available. His response. "9am daily it has always been 9am and will only be available at 9am due to the high volume of people wanting this". Ok not a problem. I figured I could wait but realized I'm parked in a loading zone only. Any SF native knows those meter maids will be here 9am ON THE DOT. If you're lucky a few minutes later. So of course I lined up again to ask if its possible to accommodate me. I DID just come from LA to get some breakfast here and I AM going to wait outside. Since I'm here already and waited twice .. They did it before why can't you do it again? He didn't even apologize and told me rules changed or that it might have been a one time thing. Instead the response was rude. No. We can't do this for you otherwise we would have to do this for everybody. Ok well you did do this before? No. 9am. You are parked there and you'll be the first in line. Um.. Right.. First of many in line. So he pretty much said I had to wait in line like everyone else even if the line went down the block. Rude! Sorry guys but I won't be returning. If the service is inconsistent its not worth my time. I did however support one last time because I didnt drive out here to come home empty handed. It'll be my last three items I'm purchasing ever from this place. And here I wanted to buy boxes to share with my family. You just lost some business and I won't be recommending it to anyone else. Tough love!
author: Linda L.

description:
I really like their design and set up. Cute little place! We went around 10:30 and of course their infamous cruffins were sold out. The lady told us that they let out a bunch at 9:00am and they sell out usually around 9:30am. Should really make more!!! At least there isn't a huge line, which I appreciated. 

We tried the Chocolate (Nutella) and Lemon donuts (which are very similar to malasadas from Leonard's located in Hawaii-if you find yourself in the area). Similar taste and everything. Like a sugar donut with filling. I didn't care for the lemon one too much because it was more tart that I expected. If you miss out on their cruffins (cause you most likely will) their croissants look delicious! We got the chocolate one, wish the chocolate was more melted but the croissant itself was good! I think I would just do the normal croissant next time. Make sure to wash it down with coffee or milk (they only have coffee and sparkling water).
author: Lauren W.
