description: Line takes about an hour which would be fine if the pastries were worth it. After spending nearly $50 on an assortment of items including cruffins I found myself disappointed with most things besides the monkey bread and churro croissant.
author: Ty F.

description: Delicious, moist pastries.  Usually I'm disappointed by pastries.  This place was worth the wait.  The chocolate chip cookie was one of the best I've tried, and the chocolate filled cruffin was THE BOMB.
author: Wendy S.

description: When you get there, there are two separate lines. One for cruffins (usually long) and the other for everything else (doughnuts, danishes, etc.) they don't start selling cruffins until 9am. Check their Instagram for a list of what flavor cruffins and doughnuts are being sold each day. I arrived at 9:10am one Saturday morning to find the line wrapped around the building. Fortunately I was one of the last 10 individuals to get a cruffin by 9:45am. They were good but in my opinion, the doughnuts that day were even better!
author: Emily F.

description:
trendy trendy trendy... I have had clients walk in upset for having to wait in line so long to get yet another donut mashup.

The baked goods are decent, but you are gonna wait and pay for them (mostly the box they come in).
author: Kane M.

description:
Yes yes and yes! At first I was a little skeptical and thought this place was only famous because it was highly Instagrammed - but this place definitely lives up to its hype. There is a line outside to get in, but it moves extremely fast so I wouldn't be intimidated by it. 

Disclaimer: I'm only giving this place four stars for now because I didn't get there early enough to try the cruffins. I've heard you have to be there around 8am, but I could be wrong!

Moving on, I got there and I tried their savory artichoke danish, turkey pesto danish, raspberry danish, pineapple donut, and choux. The pastries are extremely sweet and I would recommend eating them from sweet to savory - mainly so you feel less guilty about eating all the sweets when the taste of saltiness is still in your mouth. The raspberry danish was a little too sweet for my liking - but I am also not the biggest fan of sweets. The savory danishes were really really good. The outside was the perfect amount of crumbliness - although I do wish there was a little bit more pesto in the pesto danish. The pineapple donut was amazing! It was filled with so much pineapple filling that actually tasted like pineapples. But I would say the donut outside was more of a mechanism to put pineapple filling into your mouth. The choux was okay - a little overrated and slightly tasteless, but everyone else seems to disagree, so I would still recommend trying at least once.
author: Alice Y.

description: Pastry heaven! It was a short walk from our hotel, we arrived around 8:30 am on a Sunday. Very short line, got through it in 5 min. B/t 2 of us we ordered 4 pastries(couldn't decide on 2, they all looked so good .) We were stuffed when we left, but already planning our next visit back!!
author: Ashton J.

description:
Came to Holmes Bakehouse,
mad lines homie fo' cruffins,
watch the crack on street
author: Roy C.

description: I didn't want to like it, let alone love it. It is gourmet, fancy, hipster, etc, and...excellent. The raised dough is yeasty and yielding, not overworked and chewey. Definitely a worthwhile vice.
author: Haroun S.

description:
Decided to go today because I found out they were going to be serving matcha flavor. Got there at around 8:10 am and had no more than 20 people in front of me in the cruffin line. Got and paid for my cruffin by around 9:15 am. A cruffin costs $4.50 a pop and it speeds things up if you have your money or credit card ready. 
The cruffin itself was delicious but very messy to eat so grab napkins before leaving the store if you plan to eat it on the go. I found the matcha cream to be creamy and a little sweeter than I usually that I like it. Other than that I enjoyed eating the cruffin and look forward coming back another day to try a different flavor.
author: Melanie P.

description:
CRUFFINS (croissant + muffins)

I did not even know about them until my friend told me about how she's been trying to get them for 2 saturdays in a row. They are flaky pastries (croissant shaped like a muffin basically) filled with generous amount of cream/whatever filling they have for the flavor of the day. Get in line at least by 8:30am. We got there around ~8:20am and we got the stickers that guarantee us cruffins and I think there were only 10-15 more people after us that got the stickers. 

In the middle of a semi dingy location, this bakery is such a cute hip place. cute stickers, cute box ($1.50 for less than 6 pastries, free for 6 pastries), and the famous "I got baked in SF" sign. 

Besides cruffins, I got amelie amann because it seemed like a house specialty. I think I can describe it as a denser, flakier croissant flattened out with caramelized surface. aesthetically, it doesn't really stand out but I really enjoyed this as well as the cruffins.

I wouldn't come here just to get some pastries but it's more like a weekend morning adventure with your friends.
author: Becky M.

description:
I just have to give this 5 stars, even though yes, it's one of those super hyphed up SF bakeries that everyone claims you HAVE to try. But really, you have to try this bakery ;) 

Got here around 8:30 am on a Saturday morning to stand in line (thank god we missed the rain) ...such dedication just to try the famous cruffins. We got to the front at around 8:55 or so, right before the cruffins get out which is 9 am. While we waited, we did what every customer/instagrammer there was doing. Instagrammed the "I got baked in SF" sign, deciding which other pastries we wanted, and checked yelp reviews to see which flavor cruffin they might be serving today - it was coffee! Yum. 

Here are the goodies we got: 
+2 coffee cruffins - totally worth every minute we waited that morning. The outside was flaky and crispy, as youd expect a croissant to be and inside had an out-of-this world coffee pudding. It was a messy and sinfully delicious pastry. 
+1 banana cream donut - Not a huge fan of the banana cream flavors but the donut was phenomenal. Soft and the banana pudding on the inside was a perfect consistency. 
+1 chocolate croissant - I would skip this and get an extra cruffin if you can. Not a bad croissant, just not their forte in my opinion. 
+1 blueberry brioche - did not try this so can't comment (a friend took it home for her bf who was still peacefully sleeping - lucky man) 
+1 mushroom croissant type pastry - a great savory addition to the mix! The mushroom filling was delicious and it was a great change in midst of all the sweet calories we were consuming. 

Tips:
+Cruffins only get out at 9 am - so either wait in the cruffin line, if that's all you want (We had no idea there were two lines), or stand in the regular line and if you happen to be paying around 8:55-9:00 am, like we were, they won't make you stand in the cruffin line and will just let you get those at the front. Weird policy I think? 
+You get pins while you are in line. Each pin let's you get 2 cruffins. 
+Skip the coffee (we though it tasted sort of burnt) and walk yourself to philz/another cafe in the area where you can enjoy your goodies
+ No seating 
+ You need to get 6 pastries to get one of the famous "I was baked in SF" boxes. If you don't get 6, you pay $1.50 for the box. Good business strategy to scam all us desperate instagrammers? 
+ Pastries get pricey - we spent over $30 on just pastries so watch what you're ordering as you fill up that box! 

Verdict: Yes, definitely go! And consider going to the gym after.
author: Anu P.

description: I've had Mr. Holmes multiple times, primarily their cruffins which are exactly as good as every days they are. A delightful muffin shaped croissant with filling in the middle. I've had flavors such a matcha green tea, chocolate peanut butter, and vanilla. It's worth the wait in line!
author: Christopher S.

description: Delicious pastries! Love the decor. The girl who helped us was very patient and knowing it was our first time there she helped us out with suggestion and explaining what each pastry consisted of. Will definitely be back here.
author: Lucy E.

description: I know everyone stands in line for the cruffins, but I go right to the front of the line and get their chocolate chip cookies, which are amazing. I have never had anything bad from this bakery and the coffee is great as well.
author: Kira P.

description: Honestly the best doughnut I've ever had in my life. Cruffin line gets ridiculous, but it's still on my bucket list to make it there for a cruffin! If you don't want to wait in line at 9AM, I highly recommend one of their daily doughnuts - you will not be disappointed!
author: Charlotte C.

description: Good, but did not exceed my high expectations. I would go for pictures of the sign. The flavor a are unusual yet interesting.
author: Emily C.

description: Despite how long lines get, it'll be worth it. Their cronuts are popular here and they usually have different flavors each day. I tried their jalapeño strawberry pastry and instantly fell in love with it. It's a small bakery and interior is cute! I'll come back again.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Damn holmes.... Alert my husband. I'm having a love affair with Mr. Holmes! 

Like most crushes, the affair started out innocent enough but quickly turned into a dangerous, calorie-laden liaison.... 

-2/3/15: 12:18p.m. After a 20 minute walk from my work in Union Square, my best friend and I arrived to find the bakery closed with a "sold out" sign. 

-2/3/15: 12:20p.m. Walked back to Union Square with my best friend and plotted our next-morning return.

-2/4/15: 3:00a.m. Lay awake in my bed with insomnia (unrelated to Mr. Holmes) and thought about Mr. Holmes. 

-2/4/15: 8:32a.m. Arrived at Mr. Holmes.No line! And my best friend is already awaiting with a box of every available pastry. THIS IS WHY WE ARE BEST FRIENDS. 

-2/4/15: 8:34a.m. Began methodically dissecting and sampling each pastry. My findings:

-Amelie Amann: mmm, flaky, buttery croissant dough baked with extra butter and a pistachio filling. Just a slight step below B Patisserie's Kouign Amann, but really, really good

-Brioche with Raspberry & Pistachios: my least favorite pastry, but only because I wasn't a fan of the tarte filling. If you like tarte flavors, this may be for you.The dough was light and flaky though. 

-Sea Salt Caramel Donut: Dough, fluffy pillow of goodness with an interesting salted caramel filling. It was less sweet, and more savory, with almost coffee, toasted almond notes.

-Apple Pie Turnover: my 2nd least favorite pastry, and same review as the Brioche above

-Mushroom & Sumac Croissant: Mmmmm, this was really good. The savory notes of the mushroom and sumac reminded me of a really good breakfast quiche. 

-Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb: SPOT-ON. This tasted exactly like Ferrero Rocher. The luscious Ferrero Rocher  cream is sandwiched between two cheeky halves of a flaky choux pastry. 

-Caramel Cruffin: my FAVE thing I tried. Flaky, buttery croissant dough baked into a whimsical muffin shape and then completely dusted in sugar and cinnamon. And inside, there is a luscious caramel custard that comes oozing out with each bite. With every bite you get the crunchy outer crust coated in sugar and cinnamon, the doughy inner crust, and the creamy luscious custard. A messy, get all over your mouth/face/fingers pastry that was worth the wait (when we arrived at 8:30a.m., the Cruffin didn't come out until 9:00a.m.). I'm sitting here, eating little by little, trying to extend this heaven as long as possible. Quite possibly the next "CRONUT" sensation!!! 

While slightly pricey, I thought the quality of pastries was worth it. As a plus, the aesthetic/decor of the shop is on-point: cheeky gold lettering across the front door, white honeycomb tiled floor, hip white minimalist interior, and of course, your catchy neon sign (sure to become an instagram phenomenon). 

In my opinion, way better than other over-priced bakeries (I'm looking at you, Craftsman & Wolves & Tartine) that were over-hyped and lackluster for me. Looking forward to return visits and trying all the different things you come up with!
author: Monelle A.

description: Pastries were amazing! I would have given 5 stars, but the employees were a bit standoffish and made us feel unwelcome.
author: Alison M.

description:
SIGH.

cruffins. it was really good but not worth the stupid wait. 

there are a few things to know. there are two lines. one is for cruffins only. they start selling the cruffins at 9am and they pass out stickers for the customers that are guaranteed a cruffin. you are limited to only 2 per person. the other line is for other baked goods. you cannot buy a cruffin in that line (and that line starts at 8am). 

california croissant is delish and doughnuts!!! i might like the dougnuts better than the cruffin. gasp!
author: Clara H.

description: Love this place. The cruffins are on point and too bad I have better things to do with my time than wait in line and find out what flavors they will make for the day. So yummy though. I've had a couple of these and when I do it makes me workout a little extra in the gym that day. The cream filled donuts are also delicious and you will not be disappointed. I love their tagline. I GOT BAKED IN SAN FRANCISCO. Awesome!
author: Ryan C.

description:
DONUTS ARE THE BOMB.COM - come arouns 10:30AM for their filled donuts, no line. cruffin, which is a take on dominique ansel's cronut is whateves. still 3 because they are controlling supply. 







The Beanie Baby of bake shops. 

The owner knows what they are doing - controlling supply to keep a high demand because once you've had one - will waiting in line, in the rain be worthwhile? 

All I wanted was absurd pastries for a brunch I was attending. 

It was good - I first tried a croffin because a colleague actually stood in line and brought them to work. He did mention a line- I hate lines of people for anything. I didn't expect a line one a rainy Sunday BUT When I drove on a Sunday- pouring rain, sick individuals were waiting out in the rain for pastries!!! What is wrong with us!??? No thank you. Now back to my favorite bakery B's
author: Dre X.

description:
Ive never had ice cream like this before, they have all kinds of new and unusual flavors. I personally go way out of my way just eat here. 

I also can't speak highly enough of the staff, kind and patience and are happy to answer all your questions.
author: Conor M.

description: wanted to check out the cruffins from mr holmes and got to try them in san francisco. there wasn't a long queue on a sunday at 11pm and a variety of pastries to choose from! the coffee wasn't so great and the donuts taste better than the cruffins. make sure to check out their instagram to see the different flavours available in stores!
author: Augustina L.

description: Staff was rude and did not greet anyone with a smile. I got the donut with blackberry filling and it was nothing special, I didn't even finish it. Would not go back due to the bad service. There are way better dessert options in SF.
author: Muoi T.

description:
food: cruffin. it would seem all the croissant mutants would all taste the same. however, this one is my favorite so far. it's thick enough on the top where it almost feels cake like, but the bottom part is thin enough to be more crispy. plus the custard. yum. it also has some candy pearls on there. not only good for the mouth, but good for the eyes too. ***5/5

service: yes the lines are long, but they go fairly quick. people are lost when the cruffins are out and they have to figure out what they can get as a second option. i waited longer in line for the place to open than to go through the ordering. what did you expect for a trendy location? ***3/5

value: typical pastry pricing. it was tasty. even if you dont like sweets, totally worth it for an IG pic. ***4/5
author: Andy Z.

description:
I kind of wish I didn't know about Mr. Holmes Bakehouse. 
I suspect it will be my undoing.
Seriously... everything I've had from here is TOO GOOD.
author: Carly A.

description:
Nope, I'm still giving this place two stars. Turns out that over baked is the "norm" for their pastries (I guess a lot of people like that). 

This place is still overpriced. A bad cup of coffee for $2.50? Just okay tasting. . . over baked pastries for around $4, $4.50, to $5? No thanks.

Haven't tried the Cruffins, and I don't want to wait hours to try one.
author: Audrey S.

description:
Just missed the cruffins but was able to snag a passion fruit filled donut, a sea salt carmel filled donut, and an aman.  These guys clearly know their craft. All three were absolutely fantastic and we scarfed them down in minutes (so quickly that I didn't even get a picture to post!) 

Weekday waits after cruffins run out are not too bad.
author: Amy L.

description:
Glorious. Absolutely glorious. Try a cruffin. Try a croissant. Try it all.

They know what good baking is.
author: Naseem K.

description: Delicious Lavender-Caramel donuts, friendly staff (attn: Dominique Ansel Bakery staff) and a bit annoying customers taking selfies wherever they feel like it (e.g. right in the middle of the place)
author: Sasha N.

description: Had their tiramisu cromuffins and they were delicious!!! Super sad that they only limit you to 2 at a time though. I wanted to bring at least a dozen home!  Even though they open at 8, you have to wait until 9 to get the cromuffins.  There are 2 separate lines! One specifically for cromuffins and one for their other delish baked goods!
author: Kim D.

description: The ferrero rocher choux bomb was my favorite! The line gets pretty long but I got here an hour before they opened on a Friday & was the only one in line for 30 mins.
author: Trisha G.

description: They really have a variety of selection fresh baked goods but if you want the most popular items you would have to wake up early and make line because they do sell out before they open
author: Henry L.

description: Our boss had a good day and brought us a bunch of different pastries from Mr. Holmes. A coupe were weird--super tall(we had to cut them in 4!) with some strange green cream on top, but everything was yummy--we were fighting over them in the kitchen.
author: Kitty_Kattus A.

description: I did not have a chance to try the cruffin, so I will have to come back for that! But I did come around noon, and they had a large variety of baked goods to choose from. I got 4 of them that were available, and they were all fresh and good, but nothing too special. Maybe I will be more enamored when I try the cruffin.
author: Nikita K.

description:
Awesome creations. Great staff and really fun baked goods. Mr Holmes can make any morning that much better.

Highly recommend- especially if you have time to wait in line!
author: Josh C.

description: Worth the hype. Unfortunately, I've never had the cruffins...but the filled doughnuts are amazing! I normally hate filled doughnuts but the fillings are unique (lychee and peanut butter chocolate are two of my favorites) and taste a bit like pudding. The outside is flakey and sweet without being overly sugary. Highly recommend! We live nearby and  pick up doughnuts whenever we walk by and see that the line isn't too long. Waits aren't too crazy if you go at an off-peak hour after the cruffins have sold out.
author: Ana D.

description:
The pastries here are pretty good. I really like the savory danishes. Everything here is REALLY good if you can catch it right out of the oven, but I think it kind of depends on the day that you go what kind of quality you'll catch. The people who were here are generally really sweet, and the drip coffee is nice. 

I'm really happy I asked exactly what the California Croissant was before buying it because I don't care what anyone says it does not sound like something I would want to eat for early breakfast. Their chocolate croissants are good though.

The interior is cute but hey it's a little city bakery so it will be a bit cramped and there will be a line early weekend mornings for the cruffins.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
It's GOOD. We arrived at 8:30am on Saturday and it took us about an hour to get our pastries. Pro Tip: cruffins come out at 9am. It's not about being the first in line, you just need to get your hands on the pin or sticker that guarantees you two cruffins. They take it back after you order. Is definitely stop by on weekday to grab some pastries, but wouldn't wait in line for it again. But hey, I don't even wait for Tartine anymore ;) I go on off days.

The wait was not bad because one of the servers (he may have been an owner? British accent though don't think it was Aussie?) came out from time to time to update us and keep spirits up. I wouldn't agree with anyone that says its overhyped - service and taste were top notch. 

California roll - salmon, nori and pickled ginger wrapped in a croissant and served with soy sauce. Unique and really feeling good for sushi lovers. Try to eat it separate from all the sweets though!

Mushroom Danish - so good! Mushrooms were perfect and loved the crispy cheese on top. I would go back in line for this. 

Coffee Creme Cruffins - really good! They only have one selection a day so you have to hope you get a flavor you like! Not a muffin, more like a tall sugared croissant but I loved the texture.

Filled Donuts - I am not a fan of custard donuts but my boyfriend enjoyed the banana and passion fruit varieties they had today. He even like it more than the cruffins! The dough was good :)

Everyone should give it a try once and once the news dies down you can call it a regular place to grab a quick and crunchy bite. Enjoy!
author: Angela R.

description:
amazing pastries..a little pricey.
I live across the street and as happy as I am to see a business with lines out the door

my one complaint is I wish they would maintain the lines a little better...its annoying having to push through a crowd of people as I am trying to get to work
author: Ripley B.

description: Geez, delicious almond thingamajigie...!  I don't know the exact name of it, but I dream about it.  I bring extra home and they get devoured.
author: Emy B.

description: Everything about this place is amazing. So amazing that I bought the bag to show off that I got baked in SanFran. The most perfect donuts. The only thing I would complain about is the overabundance of filling, but hey, I'm being picky now. Go there or regret not going!
author: Anna H.

description:
Weekdays they are sold out of almost everything by 10:30 am, no later than 11:00 am. "Cruffins" are typically gone by 10:15 am. I am not sure if this is an everyday occurrence, but on weekends you have to get in line to pay for "Cruffins". They come out at 9:00 am. Then you have to get into another line to actually get them. The nice girl at the counter always has the same line: "Right now we are only doing one bake, but we are looking into hiring more staff." 
The slice of almond cake was moist and tasty but lacked almond taste. 

The pastries are good, but personally I do not like their strategy!
author: Bogee B.

description:
I had a great experience at Mr. Holmes Bakehouse this morning. I arrived just before it opened (6:45am) and was first in line. I was sad to hear that the Cruffins don't come out till 9am, but was still excited to get a box of pastries to take to my coworkers. The boxes have a minimum of 6 pastries, and they're beautiful white and gold cardboard. 

California Croissant (the sushi one) - this was delicious! Very hard to split with my coworkers, as it flaked all over the place when I tried to cut it. It was a little hard on the outside for a couple of the flakes, but overall I loved it. The buttery light flavor mixed with the salmon was light and savory, and a pleasant savory surprise. The soy sauce was a cute addition, but I didn't pair it with the pastry for fear of getting it everywhere. My coworkers were skeptical, but loved it after trying it. 

Strawberry Croissant - The filling proportion was great, and it was very sweet, though not overly strawberry flavored. This croissant was perfect, this one wasn't as flaky as the sushi one. Tough to eat gracefully (lots of powered sugar and almonds on top), but worth it. 

Salted Caramel Filled Donut - The filling was extremely rich and dark, but the proportion in the donut was perfect. The consistency of the chocolate salted caramel filling was excellent, and you could taste the deep caramel flavor with the chocolate. I would have wanted perhaps some salt flakes on the donut exterior, but otherwise it was delicious and extremely soft. Pro tip: they sell the filling at the counter in cute little jars! They also sell coffee and granola. 

I will definitely be back with guests and fellow pastry lovers.
author: Claire S.

description: In San Francisco, you have your "must do" or "bucket" list. If you like baked goods, this is one place that needs to be toward the top of your list. Yes, expect a line. Yes, it's small - I've seen master bathrooms that were bigger. Be prepared because when you get to the front counter, there will be a display of baked goodness that you need to choose from and they like to get you through quickly. It's not cheap either, these aren't big chain grocery store donuts. But it's all most definitely all worth it.
author: Davin C.

description: I'm really glad I made this an essential in SF. My boyfriend and I stopped here for breakfast before venturing out in the city. The line went outside the door, which I expected since I heard great things from the bakery. The line wasn't too long though, we waited probably 15-20 minutes before we started ordering. Everything from the window looks amazing, we wanted to try everything! The decor was modern and cute, I was a bit sad to see that the famous baked sign they have wasn't lit lol, but that's because I wanted a nice picture. My boyfriend got the choux bomb and he loved it, and he isn't a big fan of sweets. I got the strawberry and jalapeño brioche bomb which was AMAZING. It was a little odd at first but it got better with every bite. We also got the bread pudding to share and 10/10 from us. I am definitely going to come back here and get a box full of goodies to take home. The coffee there was also good and had their cute logo stamped on the cup. So worth the drive and wait, this place deserves every star.
author: Daphne M.

description: Delicious pastries. The inside is super small, so even though the line is out the door, the wait goes by somewhat fast (less if you're hungry). No espresso bar, so they only sell coffee. We had the Ham and Cheese croissant and it was amazing!
author: Kelsey G.

description: For the price, the pastries do not meet expectations. The pastries were okay, but not really worth the price (in my opinion). I was so excited to drive up to the city and try the infamous cruffins. Unfortunately the cruffins had run out by the time I got to the bakery, which is understandable, I know how popular they are, that is not something I am holding against them. What is not understandable is how they can hire someone so rude to run the front of the shop. Seriously, if your job revolves around customer care and having to interact with people, you would think you would make more an effort to be approachable and friendly. I was just simply asking what was in one of the pastries and she huffed an sighed and acted like I was asking the dumbest question in the world. I don' t think what I received was worth the drive.
author: Crystal F.

description:
Croissant dough in creative forms, this take out bakery is known for its "cruffins" which go on sale at 9:00 am. We started the queue this morning at about 8:35 (they run out). Today's flavor was chocolate brownie, a flakey-crispy muffin shaped croissant filled with chocolate pastry cream with a brownie bite on top. Yes, delicious, even though it was a bit too much cream for my taste, the croissant dough was spot on. 

I also had a savory pastry with caramelized onions, brown ale, and béchamel sauce, which was also delicious. My niece had their new ham and cheese croissant, complete with béchamel sauce like a Croque Monsieur - yum!  

They had a lot of other delicious looking options, all of which looked devour-worthy, but we managed some self-control. 

We got a $20 day pass on MUNI public transit and took the California cable car to Larkin for a 3 block walk. We then hopped back on the cable car to the park by Grace Cathedral to savor our goodies. Great way to start a day of hanging in the city before tonight's Giants game.
author: Janet A.

description: We heard the hype of this place and just had to try out the famous chuffing before heading home. We heard you needing to get in line early and saw some people mention getting in line 30-60 min ahead of time. Well first off their instagram says cruffins at 9- but when we went to their website it showed us it opens at 7am weekdays and 8am weekends. We got there at 7am thinking cruffins were at 8. Nope. We were obviously confused that the main shop opens at a different time than when cruffins are there. So... we waited around 2 hours. We learned while waiting- that an hour is probably too early unless you want to be at the front of the line. We likely could have come 15 min before 9 and still gotten a cruffin and other baked goodies. And as for the cruffin- definitely something I recommend trying at least once. Great flaky texture and so soft and yummy. But in my group- we all preferred the crime filled donut of the day better (it was pumpkin spice). Which we could have gotten at 8 when the shop opened. Anyway- cute shop- definitely worth checking out at least once if your a visitor!
author: Amanda H.

description:
Love their bakery here, great selection and high quality pastries. Cruffins are great but other pastries are great as well.

Waited in line for 30 mins one time but worth the wait.
author: Felicia S.

description: Okay now if you wish you where in Paris right now having a croissant with real butter and supper flakey then you need to go to Mr Holmes right away . This place is super dangerous because it is really that good. Oh carbs I am in love with Mr Holmes croissant it is superb.
author: P C.

description: Had to check out the hype for this place. I love the boxes tho. The pastry as good to look at. It's a bit pricey for me.
author: Marie V.

description: Hands down the best bakery I've ever been to! From the cruffins to donuts, anything really, you can't go wrong! Worth the wait in line! Loved everything we got
author: Brooke K.

description:
They only have cruffins starting at 9AM! I got in line a little after 7AM on a Fri and the line was already out the door! It's just pastries so the line moves quickly. i ordered the apricot danish and IT WAS BOMB DOT COM. it was topped with a piece of real fruit and it was just delicious against the flakly crust of the danish. NOMS.

i had coffee as well but it is a definite skip.

cant wait to come back and try the other pastries!
author: Lisa N.

description: My husband and i ordered 6 pastries because i wanted the cute box it came in. I attacked the coconut cream malasada like donut which was pretty heavenly. My husband has a turkey and cheese tart which he said was good. To that, there was also a sticky bun, chocolate croissant and a cheese and artichoke tart and a cookie i believe, all of which were not mind blowing. We actually gave it to the homeless in union. Its an odd setup having one line for cruffins and one line for everything else its borderlining snotty especially if you dont have time to designate waiting in line since 6am. Havent been back there since though but maybe when i visit again i'll brave it in line.
author: Ella A.

description: Oh my goodness, this place had all kids of goodies.  Was it worth the wait....the answer is yes.  I wish I can remember what I had there since it has been awhile, but I do remember that the pastries were fresh and flaky, and the creams were delicious.
author: Bryan H.

description:
Great baked goods! No seating though!
Had the apple blue cheese Danish which was awesome.
author: Yasser A.

description:
With only two days to spare in the city, I saw this on a blogger's instagram (shoutout to ohhappyday here!) and decided instantly that I had to have this at least one of the mornings that I was there. I noted from the yelp reviews that cruffins is THE THING to have, so I hauled ass to get myself there before 9am. 

The line wasn't too bad for a Wednesday morning, and I managed to get my cruffins and some other goodies within the hour. So here's the verdict (whoops my bad but I don't know all the names of everything) - 

Cruffin - Mixed feels on this one because the flavor of the day that I got was the pina colada, which actually had a mini tube of alcohol on it. The creme and cruffin was alright without the tube (the outer shell was very sugary and flaky, while the center was pretty soft), but once the alcohol was in, it was a no go for me. But some of the other flavors sound like they were way better - namely, the Strawberry Milkshake, which I wish I could have had instead.

Apple Scone - This was pretty good! I think generally everything at this bakery is a bit heavy in flavor (heavy compared to asian bakeries), but it worked for this one. A nice touch with actual apple bits.

That ferrero rocher(sp?) choux creme - This was definitely the crown jewel of the set for me. I actually ate this one days later...but it was still incredibly good! The creme really does taste like the chocolate, albeit a lightweight version of it, and the pastry bits were delicious. I would definitely eat this again, and I think it was honestly a lot better than the cruffin.

Banana-filling doughnut - This was alright. I wasn't in love with it, but again, nice touch with the banana bits in it. I was expecting the creme to sort of taste like banana pudding (which I think would taste really good too!), but it's got more of a natural taste to it. It was decent, but nothing I would write home about. 

Overall, pretty decent. I'm a bit unsure about the cruffin, but hey, the bakery is kinda cute in this hipster dive kind of way and some of their other things are really good. Plus, their boxes are really cool and you can actually just buy the box for $1.50. I would say definitely worth a shot especially if you're a local because you've got nothing to lose but the time you wait in line (and probably that $4.50 you have to shell out but you get my point).
author: Doris K.

description: The pastries are delicious (specifically the chocolate cherry donut and the artichoke cheese Danish. The Cruffins are worth the long wait in line. Yes, it's best to arrive early as they will run out.
author: Anna C.

description:
The hype is real.
Everything I've tried in their shop is so delicious, but I don't understand why they don't simply make more items for their high demand. 
They usually close up shop when they sell out of cruffins which is 9am to basically 10:30am.

If you're coming on a weekend, be sure to be in line by 8am :/
author: Jacqueline N.

description: Worth it! There is a line but the orange bourbon cream filled donut is great! We also had the sticky bun which was just as good. Perfect morning stop!
author: Vanessa P.

description: I really don't understand what the hype is about with the cruffin. If I was blindfolded, and I try both cruffin vs croissant with same filling, I wouldn't know which is which since the only difference would be the shape. I also tried the ube puff but I thought the icing didn't go well with the pastry. It was too sweet that it overpowered the actual ube filling. I've tried the california croissant as well and maybe this was the only one that I liked. It had smoked salmon, nori, ginger and wasabi in it. Overall, this bakery is expensive for what you get and not worth my time. I'd rather go to La Boulangerie or Thorough Bread for better croissants and pastries.
author: Dianne P.

description: This place is seriously as good as the pictures look! My boyfriend and I got super lucky and only had to wait in a 5 minute line when I heard the lines wrap around the block sometimes! We came around 10 AM and a lot of the items were already sold out but still so much to choose from. We had the ham and cheese croissant and the white chocolate donut and they were both the best things we have ever tasted! YUM. Worth the wait for sure! Staff is super friendly as well!
author: Evelyn A.

description:
CRUFFIN:
I came here at around 10am on a Monday and thank God there were still cruffins left!!! I didn't know that they started selling them at 9am everyday and apparently they usually sell out in around an hour so I got really lucky. 

So let's talk about this cruffin...I already LOVE croissants so I knew I was going to love it. The flavor of the day was mint chocolate chip and at first I was disappointed since I'm not a fan of mint chocolate but I gave it the benefit of the doubt because I knew I HAD to try a cruffin. It was also my last day in SF. I'm so glad I did because it was glorious. The cruffin was crispy and flaky outside with soft buttery layers inside. It was filled with this mild mint chocolate custard. I liked that the custard was not too sweet because the whole cruffin is covered in sugar. 

Delicious! I felt so guilty after eating it but it was so worth it...Oh yeah and they have really good coffee as well. I wish they made this into a cafe with a seating area and everything!

Service:
Super helpful and friendly staff!
author: Nadine U.

description: Sigh, I hate/love this place. They definitely have their marketing strategy down. They purposely make a VERY limited batch of cruffins (that sell out in 2-3 hours) everyday, which adds to the hype and sends the line all the way down the street. Free advertising for them. I came here around 10 am on a Friday morning, waited in line for at least 40 min, only to find an empty space on their baked goods counter where the cruffins are supposed to be. I was pretty bummed...since I'm like never in the city. But of course after waiting so long, I couldn't leave without a box of baked goods. You need to buy 6 or more pastries to get a box, so I got a good variety. Can't remember the names of everything that I got, but all of them were SO delicious! The texture of their pastries is perfect, and I didn't find any of them to be overly sweet. The strawberry jalapeno brioche was hands down my favorite--I loved the spicy kick and warmth that the jalapeno flavor added to the strawberry filling. Will definitely be buying more of these next time. And hopefully next time I'll get there early enough for the cruffins. Ugh. Why do you guys do this to us.
author: Ashley Y.

description: Smells sooooo good walking by, can't wait to go back and try whatever the new special of the day is, it's sure to be amazing and unique.
author: Peter H.

description:
I live in the neighborhood, and I cannot tell you how happy I am to have a new bakery so close by. This part of town has shuttered up storefronts, block after block. It's great to see folks moving in and clearing away the plywood.

Our first visit to Mr. Holmes Bakehouse was the Sunday the time changed. I was hoping that the time change was going to mess everyone up and I'd get there and there would be no line. Stupid smart phones. They automatically adjust and now everyone knows what time it is. I miss the good old days when people would forget to set their clocks and you could get an advantage. Oh well. The line wasn't that bad. We showed up around 8:20 and waited about 20 minutes in the general pastry line.

Oh, the baked goodness! Lets start with the savory items. The California Roll was delicious. I only got one, and I had to share with my husband. I won't be making that mistake next time. The ham and cheese tartlets were great too. I got two of those, so thankfully didn't have to share.

Sweet items: Cream puffs. Wow! Best ever. I also picked up some brioche cookie things with cherries and apricots that were really, really good. Last on the list..some kind of almond thing. I can't remember the name. It wasn't bad. It was just last on the list of my box of awesome.

Here's a tip: If you're not too picky about what you get, because, let's face it, it's all pretty good. Go later in the day to get a box of scrumptious. I stopped by on Friday around 1:30 and there was still plenty to choose from (no cruffins, duh), and they were all tasty.

The folks who work there are also very friendly. Be nice to them. They know you waited in line forever and you're hangry for pastries. You don't have to be a jerk.
author: Wendy G.

description: Finally got to try the Famous Cruffin! Came from Modesto just to try this place! It was amazing. Definitely worth the wait and the long drive. The Rocher ferrero is really tasty to!
author: Tanya R.

description:
Delicious! I came and waited in line with the other excited foodies to get my Cruffins! I tried a chocolate cream cruffin, I was happily suprosed by the filling and the top.
The very first time I cam here they were broken into and someone stole their recipes. 
I will be back, and I continue to bring new friends!
author: Jackie R.

description:
One of the best pastry experiences i've had.  Cruffins are amazingly wonderful.

We waited for over an hour - i left the line to get our kids one of their doughnuts.  Got back in line where bff was holding my spot and the cruffin police decided i was not allowed to get my two cruffin quota - after waiting for over and HOUR.  Still a fabulous concept.
author: Laura M.

description: This place rules. Ate a bostock the size of my face. It was warm and moist and delicious. No regrets.
author: Lauren A.

description: In my worldly pursuit for the perfect carb, I decided to try Mr. Holmes this morning.  I am now sitting back on my sofa with a huge smile after the most ridiculously amazing foodgasm.  It started with the carmelized donut...perfectly fluffy donut with just the right amount of sugar coating and an amazing carmelized banana filling...beats anything at Bob's by a mile.  I then moved on to the Bostok...a brioche with custard and a litchi filling, sprinkled with almonds.  This is when I knew that I was in trouble...I quickly finished with the chocolate caramel twice baked croissant...done...yep, DONE! No Mas! Absolutely amazing on every level...I have already scouted out the coconut rum raisin cruffin for next time, but the menu changes daily....run, don't walk to this place, it is beyond amazing and is why I love and live in SF!
author: Alan A.

description:
This place made me want to write my first review on Yelp.

First off, I had the hot chocolate marshmallow cruffin and the chocolate donut. I thought the flavors for the cruffin were overwhelming and the donut was just meh. It tasted like a regular chocolate filled donut to me. However, I did like the chocolate chips on the outside of it because they were crunchy, I wish they were on the inside as well. Don't get me wrong, the cruffin was baked to perfection but I thought it was overly sweet in my opinion and I love sweets! You should eat the pastries right when you get them, I ate them hours after and they were kind of soggy, oops. 

The thing that bugged me the most was the lady who was putting my order in. I felt rushed and I felt like she wasn't really paying attention to what I was saying. I asked for 2 Ferrero Rocher choux bomb but I realized when I got home that I never received any. I wanted to try this the most got home without it. I asked for 2 chocolate donuts and she gave me 2 chocolate and 2 lemon donuts. Maybe she heard the word "donuts" and gave me 4, which is why I felt like I didn't have her undivided attention. She also put them into the box carelessly so the filling on top of my donut fell on the box and stuck there and so did the marshmellows on top of my cruffins. 

As for the wait, I was first in line for the cruffins because I arrived at 8 am on a Thursday. People only started arriving around 8:30-8:45 to line up for the cruffins. At around 9, however, when the cruffins come out, there was an extremely long line down the block. 

Since this bakery is in the Tenderloin, parking is very limited. While waiting in line, I saw maybe 1 or 2 spaces open. Meters start at 9 am so if you want to stand in line for cruffins, you're gonna have to start feeding the meter by the time you get there to ensure when the clock hits 9 am, that you don't receive a ticket, or you can bring a friend and have them stand in line with you so you can go and feed your meter when 9 o clock hits.
author: Marlene H.

description: Croissant muffin smush that words cannot describe. Try the mocha flavor to pair with your coffee and justify the calories. Ha!
author: Regina D.

description: So I wanted to go to this restaurant because of the cute sign and I heard the food was good. The food was mediocre at best. It wasn't the best thing I've ever had but it was a cute little bakery and I got a good picture out of it. I haven't found a good bakery here yet so I'd go back to it.
author: Amanda N.

description: Wonderful selection of baked goods.  Very different, but delicious!  Cronut and the muffins are a must to try.  No place to sit and enjoy, so we we walked about 4 blocks and ate at the foot of Grace Cathedral on Nob Hill.  Very hard to walk and not dig in our box!
author: Kathy M.

description: This place is definitely worth a stop, although you will most likely be waiting in line for a bit. The Danishes are pretty delicious, and if you get there in the morning they have a good variety. My girlfriend and I got a chocolate croissant, two cheese and apple Danishes, and one cheese and apricot Danish. They were all excellent, but a little over priced in my opinion. Drop the price of each item maybe 50 cents and I would probably say that's what it should be. But considering its in SF, can't blame them too much. Check it out if you can. It's a treat worth having.
author: Michael Z.

description:
The struggle is real to get your hands on the all illusive "cruffin" (croissant muffin), but Mr. Holmes Bakehouse does not dissapoint! It is well worth waking up early to get in line and patiently wait 30+ minutes to get your 2 Cruffins (limit 2/person) and other scrumptious baked goodies.

Tips: Go early and if you want one of the pretty Bakehouse boxes, you need to get 6+ items (trust me it's easy to do!).

What I've tried:
The Strawberry Milkshake Cruffin brings back childhood memories of yummy strawberry milk to the liking of Sheldon Cooper. Sweet, flaky, moist croissant dough, filled with excellent strawberry custard with pieces of freeze-dried strawberries. 

The Crème Caramel Cruffin is the perfect sweet treat to accompany a nice cup of coffee in the morning! It isn't too sweet like some caramel pastries tend to be, but the perfect caramel-y custard gooey goodness inside the delectably buttery croissant dough.  

Ferrero Rocher Choux Bomb: BEST THING EVER! Hazelnutty, chocolatey, creamy goodness inside a nice moist, light, cream puffy dough. This little guy celebrates Mr.Rocher's chocolates perfectly,  he'd be happy!

Banana Custard Filled Donut: Might sound a bit strange, but it's actually really good! It was like a banana cream pie masked as a tiny little sugary donut ball! 

Vanilla Custard Filled Donut: It might sound mundane compared to all the other choices, but it is simple yet super satisfying! Vanilla bean-y custard goes perfect with the soft donut dough.
author: Sharon L.

description: I found this place through someone I follow on instagram and I was planning on going to sf, so I decided to make it a point to go here (mainly for the insta pics). Let me just start by saying it's a little small. If you want to get a picture of the infamous "I got baked in San Francisco" sign, you may have to strategically place yourself/wait a couple minutes for people to leave from taking their own pictures. ANYWAY, the food: amazing. The first day I came here, I got the churro croissant, California croissant and matcha green tea croissant. The only one I wasn't a huge fan of was the churro one, but that is the safe option if you're not a very adventurous eater. The free tea one reminds me of the matcha green tea latte from Starbucks. And the California croissant is my absolutely my favorite. It is stuffed with salmon and ginger wrapped in seaweed on the inside, so not for people who don't like sushi/seafood. Fair warning: these croissants are very flaky so don't eat them in your car or on your bed because you will be finding crumbs for DAYS. The prices are pretty decent in my opinion. And the staff were very friendly. Would recommend and so glad they opened one in la
author: Kristen M.

description:
My S.O. waited in the cruffin line, and was told that there was only 50/50 chance we would get a cruffin.  Then about an hour later, it was still a "good chance"...then 30 minutes later, it was a 90/10% chance...then about 15 mins after that...sold out.  There were at least 8 people in front of us, and one lady had the sticker.  Lame.

I waited over 1 hour in the "non-cruffin" line to order pastries.  Got a coffeecake, a couple varieties of croissants, hazelnut cream puffs, and pear tart, and honestly, my  favorite part was the box that held the pastries.  There are so many other great (tasting) bakeries around that it's a one and done deal for me.
author: Thao D.

description: I love the custard filled donuts. It is like heaven in your mouth. Very high quality ingredients. I wish that their donuts were sold at cafe's still. I miss having them in my neighborhood.
author: Blake S.

description:
This place is a bit hit and miss. I've been here maybe four five times, and unfortunately it seems to be getting worse with time. Maybe this is because I'm choosing the wrong baked goods?

Anyway yesterday I had a toffee apple donut and a "ferrero" cake. The donut was an ok donut, but had way too much toffee inside, making it super sweet. It didn't feel very special considering the $4 price! For $1 it would have been ok, now it was just an overpriced bad-to-mediocre donut. The ferrero cake was also a disappointment. The cream was in this case not very flavourful, it felt very buttery. And the choux pastry was also nothing special. So I wouldn't recommend either of these!

I remember from previous visits I had an almond cake and a few others things, some of which were extremely good! So choose wisely! In general the stuff with fillings of some kind seems much worse than the stuff with no fillings.

Also the service is hit and miss. Once the lady at the register couldn't calculate my change. She literally couldn't deduct two from three, so the guy packing the pastries has to intervene saying she was "overworked". Maybe they should put someone who knows numbers by the register... 

So all in all, there are a dozen better bakeries to load up on calories around in SF.
author: A D.

description:
Ok ok it can be added to my last meal on earth ..

let me explain ...if i was to die today ..what would be my last meal of life 
what is my must have !what would i in joy the most ! what would send me to a food orgasmic..coma  where your eye roll round to back of your head...that great 
As i Travel the world i will add to this Meal..
author: Vincent J.

description:
Mr Holmes is known for their cruffins but there's definitely more than that.  I arrived about 30 minutes before the store opened.   I saw about 3-4 people already waiting in line.  Luckily there are two lines.  One for cruffins and one for everything else in the bakery.  My girlfriend got in line for the regular pastries while I stood in line for the cruffins.  The cruffins don't get served until 9am so if you wanted to get something from the other line and then get back in line for the cruffins, if is possible.  If you do however, the line will probably be a lot longer.  It's best to come with two people so one person can wait in each line.

The doughnuts were delicious.   I don't remember which one I had but it was one of the filling doughnuts and you can tell it was freshly baked and prepared very well.

The cruffins however was a little disappointing for me.  I waited in line for about over an hour and found out that they only had one flavor.  The flavor of the day was coffee.  I like drinking coffee every now and then but the taste of coffee in a morning pastry for me was not working.

I would go again only if I knew what they were having that day or if I was craving doughnuts.  It was a fun experience and the workers were really nice as well.  Mr Holmes himself came out to let people know that cruffins were on their way and he made the crowd happier staying in line.
author: Alan B.

description: The hype is real! The cruffins are delicious. Flakey on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside. Nom nom nom. I really want to come back and try their green tea flavored one. Until next time!
author: Kristen T.

description: Great baked goods! Had their sugar doughnut filled with blood orange and guava flavored Creme and their strawberry jalapeño pastry. The staff was kind enough to allow my friends and I to split a box and pay separately which saved us money. I will most definitely be back. Only bummer is the lack of space so this is a great spot to pick up your treats and run.
author: Andrea D.

description: I may be a fan but I don't know for how long ... Suggestion... If u don't want to repeat urself ... Then put up a sign ... Yes ... Last week .. The limit was 4 cruffins per customer ... This week, it's 2 cruffins ... Next week it will be 0 b/c maybe u r sick & tired of just making cruffins ... Anyways ... That seems to be the attitude ... Cheer up ... Life is good ... U r selling tons of fatty food ... We may become the next obese capital !
author: Jay S.

description:
I had absolutely no idea what amazing treats were at Mr Holmes! I'll review what I had!

Strawberry jalapeño croissant: 
Rating 5/5 
Wow! This was probably the best tasting out of everything we purchased. It was so different and unique. The croissant itself was pretty good but the cream cheese filling was divine! It was almost a cross between a jalapeño cream cheese filling and a strawberry buttercream. Not too heavy or too much off "anything", simply perfect and refreshing.  
Savory Bread: 
Rating 4/5 
I choose this bread because it stuck out on the display and I've never tried anything like this before. It was really dense and full of flavor, but it definitely had a lot going on. Overall, I really enjoyed it and would definitely but this item again along with the croissant; I probably wouldn't finish the entire piece in one sitting though. 
Chocolate Chip cookie: 
Rating 5/5
Both me and my cousin enjoyed this cookie very much. You could taste the quality of every ingredient in the cookie. As an avid cookie connoisseur, I would confidentially agree that this is the probably the best chocolate chip cookie I've ever had and I highly doubt I'll ever be able to make something as delicious as this. I don't mind though, I plan on visiting Mr. Holmes again on another cheat day.
author: Miquela B.

description: I try to come every weekend now to get my wife some weekend goodies. I get in line for cruffins by 7:45am and probably see the cutoff line by 8:15. If you want these goodies you better wake up early! Ive seen people line up and walk to the pastry side and miss out on the guarantee sticker. When they come back and realized that they should have wait for the sticker before leaving, their mood gets ruined. So think twice before leaving the line. Friends cant get you 2 stickers so stop complaining!
author: Kevin N.

description:
Ok, I was one of those crazies in line to see if the cruffin and other pastries were worth the hype. I got in the left cruffin line around 8:30am and was able to score a cruffin-enabled sticker. The line shuffled sloooooowly but I was able to get my two caramel/praline cruffins. I jumped in the other pastry line and snagged a Ferrero Rocher choux bomb, California croissant, regular croissant, artichoke cheese danish, passionfruit donut, and caramelized banana donut.

Were the cruffins hype-worthy? IMO, yes. The laminated pastry was very light and flaky and the filling was creamy but not overly sweet.  My other favorites were the hazelnut-ty Ferrero Rocher choux bomb, tart and fragrant passionfruit donut, and the savory California croissant. The generous smoked salmon, ginger, and nori contrasted with the buttery and flaky exterior.

Would I go back? Sure. Maybe not when some dude was busy vomiting near my car.
author: Manda W.

description:
Can't believe I haven't rated this place yet, have been following mr Holmes since they popped up over in coffee shops around sf and was excited for their b&m to open.

Thing is, while the donuts are good (so so good) and the cruffins are unique to them.. It's not worth the wait that has occurred.

Unless, they tweet the flavor of the day around the time they start baking em' (early am) so we wouldn't feel a bit let down when we buy the cruffin even though the flavor isn't exactly what we wanted but because we arrived already, we wait in line and since we wait in line..

And delivery, I would give hundreds more than I already have if you deliver.
author: Whitne Y.

description: I've been lucky enough to sample various wares from Mr Holmes, thanks to a generous coworker who picks them up to share. When I heard about the creations, I didn't think I would like them - I generally don't like stuffed donuts, but these are amazing. I'm not normally a big fan of banana but the roasted banana stuffing is incredible. The brioche with blueberry was definitely a step down to me. I'd like to try a cruffin but am not sure I want to deal with all the ridiculousness involved in such an endeavor...
author: Lisa K.

description:
I'm sorry, I'm not a hipster. I used to be. Back in the 80's I had a shaved head, listened to punk rock, wore black exclusively. These days, I'm almost 50 years old. Back then we thought 30 was old ...now it's 50? HUH?

In any case, Mr. Holmes is 2/3rds of a block away from me. Part of this gentrification that I now seek, after living in SF since 1989 (yeah, I was here for the Big Quake -- that's another story for another time...). I'm a little tired of looking at everyone pissing themselves and yeah, I enjoy a place where they have good food & greet me nicely.

I go into the Bakeshop and -- believe you me, I'm not a sugar fiend -- but their stuff still looks good. And, of course, the food porn draws me in. Every time I leave, I've spent another $20 -- what the...?

I've a savory person. And I have to say Holmes has some savory savories -- as I'm walking down Larkin, I'm mowing down on a Ham & Cheese croissant -- it's not called a CrufHaChe or a HamCheCroi or anything else like that. But it is a "danish-type" Ham and Cheese Croissant: the ham is all crispy burnt, Gruyere cheese hard melted on top -- but the real gem is the grain mustard on the bottom of the croissant. 

Anyway, back to walking down Larkin this morning: the old Asian dude was disgusted by my ChompChompChomp on the ham&cheese croissant, that was crumbling all over the front of me. I carefully maneuvered it so that I wouldn't lose the ham or the cheese or the mustard. 

I sidestepped this that & the other but I didn't avoid food all over my clothes. Holmies know how to make a croissant. A crumbly, crusty, crunchy croissant.
author: Yasi S.

description: What can I say about this place that hasn't been already said. Amazing baked goods all the way around! The staff is helpful and still happy after working through a line of 100's of hungry people. I always check out the new Cruffin flavor, that is of course if any are left. But other than that treat they have many, many more amazing goods to try. Their donuts are flavorful and the perfect texture.
author: johnny G.

description:
Pretty small bakery, but packs great flavors into their yummy, sugary pastries. 

I have yet to try their more well known filled donuts, but on this particular trip, I got to try their Amalie Amann and their snickerdoodle cookie. 
+The amalie amann was really nice and flaky. I appreciate the well-done glaze that surrounded the pastry.
+The snickerdoodle cookie was also really good! It's not super chewy, for those who prefer those kinds of cookies, but I think it was pretty soft. 
For these two pastries, it was about seven dollars.


Only wish I came early enough to have a better selection (AKA before 01 PM on a Saturday).

Cashier guy was very nice =)
They brew Sightglass Coffee!
Not many places to sit, so I wouldn't count on hanging out and eating pastries here with your friends. And you might need to pray the cool sign in their shop isn't blocked by strangers if you want to snap a picture for yourself :P (Talk about great marketing designing)
Parking depends on what you can find on the streets.
Another downside is that it's in the Tenderloin-ish area, and a small girl like me doesn't dare often to walk to path alone.

Here's to convincing friends to try this place with me every time I want to get baked!
author: Ashley N.

description: The first time I went to Mr. Holmes I got myself a sampler box and I enjoyed it all. My favorites right now though are the mushroom tart and the plain croissant. There are still quite a few I need to try but from what I've "sampled" so far, all have been yummy. It's a breath of fresh air for this neighborhood and I enjoy good pastries. The place is simple with the retro tile and pink neon sign but it doesn't need much because the pastries sell themselves in the clean, immaculate glass case.
author: Kim L.

description: If you wanna stand in line for a mediocre pastry, go ahead.  Perhaps san franciscans like standing in line as it draws out the experience... but i think lines are a waste of time. Furthermore, when you have the actual pastry in your hand, eating it in the tenderloin with the stench of piss in the air, its just average. Like coffee shop average, not high end bakery average.  Mr Hype Bakehouse is a better name
author: Love U.

description:
Cute, small bakery. Most things were sold out by ~11am on a Wednesday...I was looking forward to getting an accidental cruffin. Came here to try out some donuts for my new years resolution of finding the best donut-ery in my vicinity. Donuts-wise, this place was okay. The donut itself was good, the cream was good, but somehow, it wasn't enough to make me go, "Wow, yes, this is tasty, and it must be tasty because I paid $3.50 for it, right?" Don't get me wrong. It was tasty. It just wasn't $3.50 tasty. For $3.50, I'd rather go to the farmer's market and pick up a Bacano Bakery donut.

The amann was nice; it was the first time I had it so it wasn't what I was expecting. Crunchy, honey-caramel-amazingness on the outside, decent croissantiness on the inside. I think I may have just hyped myself up a bit too much for this place.
author: Robbin A.

description: Finally had this bad boy.  Salted caramel donut.  This is THE BEST donut.  Right out the oven goodness.  The texture of this donuts is soft.  Once you have your second bite into it, the caramel will attack your tastebuds.  The combo of the salt and sweet is perfect.  I know this may offend donut aficionados, but please try this.  Forget your Rolling  Pin, anak.  If you have time in the hood, check out this place, SON
author: Chris P.

description:
OMG donuts.

The banana creme filled donut-like thing was by far the best donut I ever had. It was light, hot, crusty, crunchy sugared, chewy inside, and had the most intensely strong fresh tasting banana custard filling ever, how in heck do they do that? It is more banana than a banana.

It is also four dollars, so not exactly a daily occurrence. But OMG, the donuts. It is the Muhammad Ali of donuts, the best there ever was, don't even ask.

They could dump everything else on the menu in my opinion (although I haven't tried it) and this could be the Cafe du Monde of San Francisco. 24 hour donuts, 365 days a year.

FWIW they have some savory items too, rosemary cheese puffs, and unlike most pastry shops the sweet and the savory items are the same price -- so for the savory things it's not expensive at all to pay $4 or so.
author: Gil S.

description: They did not have the Cruffin when I went there on a recent trip to San Francisco.  Maybe I was too EARLY?? was afraid that I would miss it.  the line was manageable at 9am but no Cruffins in sight.  I did get an assortment of their baked goods which were good but where is this mythological cruffin that everyone was raving about??
author: Sherry W.

description: The best baked goods in SF. Unfortunately I wasn't able to get a cruffin in time. :/ but I opted for a cookie and a chocolate croissant instead and they did not disappoint! The cookie has caramelized edges that were my favorite. Must try the cruffin my next visit!
author: Melissa C.

description: Here they hand make their own pastries and cookies and they are really good at it.  I will definitely be back.
author: Michael M.

description:
I was in town for a conference and my colleague mentioned this bakery in passing. We agreed to check it out if we were up early enough, since they sell out quickly. Luckily, we were up and at em in the morning and joined the line around 8:50. The anticipation continued to grow as we waited and heard people talking in line. The flavor of the day for the cruffins was strawberry milkshake...ohhh ahhh. As the line moved we saw the adorable interior of the bakery. They have a really cool little spot. The boxes are adorned in gold and piled high in front of the window. Their branding is on point. They have a fun neon sign on the wall inside and some crates converted into seats, although it's far too small to sit inside. The counter has about a dozen gorgeous baked goods on display and you can't help but to salivate and want to jump the display window and eat all the things! Of course you stop yourself because there's a long line of witnesses and there's no way to talk your way out of that. Instead, you ask for a box, which you can only have if you order 6 or more pastries, no problem! There is a cruffin limit, 2 per person, so you'll have 2 of those and then 1 of everything else. I ended up with a delicious tart with a beautiful merengue on top, a donut, an Amelie Amann, and a brioche with fruit in the middle.  

The cruffin was out of this world delicious. It's flaky with a doughy center and the strawberry milkshake filling was like a strawberries and creme cloud. I scarfed it down while trying my best to relish the deliciousness. I moved on to the Amelie Amann, I just wanted a bite. It was flaky and buttery and everything I ever wanted. I had to walk away...

When I returned to my hotel room I had to eat the tart because the merengue was losing its life. The crust was thick, which was annoying at first, but once I got to the filling it really helped to balance the sweetness. Initially there was a just a yellow filling but when I got to the center I found a citrus filling within the filling, filling ception! The tart was so delicious, I ate the entire thing and immediately felt sick, I recommend splitting it with a friend. 

This bakery lives up the hype, it's on a whole 'nother level! Seriously, get up, wait in the giant line, and sent me a pastry as a thanks!
author: Jessica P.

description: This place is seriously addictive. Hesitant to give it another five star rating as it will only make more people to come. But want to make sure they will be around for a long time.  What isn't good here? Even if we don't need it, I make sure to buy enough to fill a box.  Try everything. It's seriously good.
author: WeR5 L.

description: Pretty dang good bakery. My friends and I got there around 8:15 and we were within the first 10 in line for the cruffins. The flavor of the day was strawberry, banana and white chocolate. I think it was very good and pretty easy to eat (bite off don't rip)! It wasn't too sweet but was just right. The size was also larger than expected but the price reflected that ($4.50), regardless it was still worth. My friend also got the donut and she said it was even better than the cruffin. The only downfall was the ladies who worked there were not the nicest. However, the cruffin spirit boy (who's name after reading a couple reviews I think is Jeremy?) was super energetic and made the experience significantly better. Was it worth going once? Yep. Would I go a second time? Yeh if I could get myself to wake up so early and haul ass from the South Bay hahaha.
author: Monsi M.

description: I was really excited to try this place when I first looked it up! Everything I expected and more. Such friendly staff and amazing fresh out the oven pastries. I loved it, my next trip to San Fran I'll definitely stop by again!
author: Jessica L.

description:
Superb. The closes you can get to Paris, France.
High quality.
Be there early, or don't go at all :-)
author: Rachel O.

description: I saw this bakery on Instagram and had to give it a try. I loved all the options. I was sad that I got there at 11am and all the cruffins had sold out. I didn't realize you had to be there within the first 30min of opening to get your hands on one. That was a little disappointing, but I will be back to try one!
author: Katie E.

description:
I don't get all the hype or why one would stand in a line more than 10 min. for this.....but OK, people do it.  Yes, the food is good...high quality .... But not in a unique way.   There are equal or better places all over the city. 

As for the cruffin, it's good but not to die for.  Think of a croissant merely cooked with the bottom half inserted in and molded by a muffin pan/cup with a flavored cream filling squirted in the top end.  So, it's just a cream filled croissant of a slightly different shape.  Not sure why people are so fascinated by that but they are.  

The service is efficient and very friendly, accommodating.  Hell, even very patient with people as they hunt and change their minds while selecting their treats from the display case. 

My only complaint is the price.  I bought a box and selected 6 pastries.  The total was approximate $30! I get it.  It's good.  It's trendy.  There's high demand.  But come on.....as much as I enjoyed the treats I could not get rid of the bitter taste of having been taken advantage of on the price.  The same level of quality can be had for 20 to 30 % less at many other places. 

Will I go back? Yes.....it's good and I live close.  Will I go back often....no way.  So long as the tourists and wannabe trendy 20 somethings indiscriminately throw their last dime at them driving up the prices, I'll make this a place to get a single treat a few times a year if there is no line.
author: John B.

description: great pastries, plus the cute sign on the wall is a great sf photo op. Not much parking, but its what you'd expect for San Fransisco. The shop is also very small and the line gets long so you can end up waiting outside, but its worth the long line.
author: Sophia C.

description:
Very tasty!
The day I went the flavor of the day was Key Lime Pie for their cruffin and it was tasty.i went in the morning so line wasn't to bad . Would def want to try their other baked goods as well. Everyone else I picked up goods for like their cruffins too.
author: Cecilia B.

description: Their pastries are like crack, seriously. I got hooked on these fuckers HARD. I love the cruffins [I better for getting up at 8AM on a Sunday!!], but my favorite so far is their Bostok pieces. I tried one the other day with blueberries and it was amazing. The staff is hella cool, too.
author: Kat S.

description:
Came 45 minutes early before opening and there was a very long line already. Of course, it was on a weekend. :p

There are 2 separate lines, one for cruffins and one for other baked items. Best to go with some friends if you want to try a bunch of pastries. People in the cruffin line will get stickers while in line, and eventually this will be your ticket to purchase a limit of 2 cruffins that day. Depending on the day, they either have 1 or 2 flavors of cruffin. I had the green tea and it was delicious. 

Texture of the cruffin is awesome! Crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. Beware, it was difficult to eat neatly. Hahaha

Pretty pricy for a cruffin, but good to try! Wayyy better than the cronuts.
author: Angela G.

description:
I've had the Kouign Amann at Dominique Ansel's bakery in NYC (the Cronut was sold out by the time I got there).

Judging by the Amalie Amagn, the Vanilla Custard Donut and the Apricot Pastry, the croissant dough here is second to none.   

Definitely worth the wait in line.
author: Fred X.

description:
Awesome! If your craving a delicious treat that's unique Mr. Holmes is for you 
Get their early and come with an empty tummy it's one of the best donuts I've ever experienced !!
author: Layla L.

description: Delicious donuts if you're willing to wade through the crowd of tourists. Overall there was good coffee and cream filled donuts, a bit overpriced but worth the penny. Orders the brown butter caramel donut and was impressed. 4/5 will revisit when hours are not at their peak.
author: Elizabeth R.

description: So sad I never got to try the cruffin, but Mr. Holmes' Bakehouse has got some other awesome pastries and baked goods as well. The stuffed donuts and other croissant based concoctions were excellent. Looks like there are only crazy lines in the early morning for the cruffin, and that once those are sold out the lines die down.
author: Tunaidi A.

description: I'm in love....Can't wait to go back! Everything was amazing and I literally got 1 of almost everything. My only critique was the young man running the cruffin line was taking a lot of time with every customer which is good in a way, but everybody was in that line way longer than necessary. Also witnessed him allowing customers to purchase more than the allotted 2, when their was till a line up the block of ppl waiting to purchase them. This was the day before Easter Sunday 2016. Sorry for the late post. Bottom line I will go back.
author: Brittney M.

description: Amazing concept! Pastries just delicious! The French toast with blackberries! OMG! Just delicious! Very clean and neat! Nice services, very friendly! I will back anytime I can for sure!
author: Jessica M.

description: Best donut I have ever had in my life. It is hard to choose, since everything looks & smells so good. Get there early, the do sell out.
author: Laura A.

description:
#1. The California Croissant
      Nothing in life has made more sense. Perfectly done. Thank you for this Mr Holmes. I love you dearly.

#2. Ze Cruffin
      Flavors: dark choco cherry & matcha. 
      Both were unreal. Matcha is my favorite drink/flavor on this planet so obviously I have nothing but rave reviews. Not too sweet, and again, done perfectly. I wasn't super pumped about the dark choco cherry but they killed it. I would get it again and again.

Note: Donuts are my favorite treat and I'm not even mentioning them here. Salted caramel is yum and all but I don't want to take away from the two above. Get them both, they will change your life.
author: Britt M.

description: I've tried the pastries but always looked forward to the chance to try the "cruffins" when I could actually come by after 9am. So I took a weekday off for my birthday and thought, now is the time! It is my fault that I was lazy enough to stroll in at 10:30am, but I couldn't believe they "sold out" by 10am and I had missed my chance by 30 minutes. Yes, I would have liked to the these cruffins, but after living in SF for 15yrs, I can walk away saying this is a one trick pony. Of course they could make more cruffins and sell them all day. You only do this when you want to create a mystery behind your product. The reality is that B. Patisserie and bakehouse can sell outstanding pastries all day long and remain huge hits. So if you miss the cutoff for this mystery, don't fret, and don't buy the back up pastries, find a place you love w *seating* and enjoy the perks of SF.
author: Tanya W.

description: Amazing donuts! Fresh--would recommend to anyone craving a sweet treat!
author: Amrita V.

description: This place has been on my bookmarked list for awhile. The banana cream filled cruffin was something I really wanted to try but they were sold out by the time I had arrived, which was about 11 AM. So plan to arrive early! A must try are the blueberry brioche and chocolate croissant!
author: Larry C.

description: If you want to eat their breads, you need go earlier as possible...
author: Sayaka D.

description:
So many delicious goodies - thank you to my friends who woke early to get in line for the yummy:
- tiramisu cruffins
- blueberry muffins (do those have cardamom in them?)
- apple cardamom scones - fluffy and soft
- plain croissant

The chocolate chip cookie was too salty - weird.
author: Vena V.

description:
Mr Holmes Bakehouse is worth the hype and then some. We arrived a little past 10:30am on a Tuesday and we were told that all the cruffins were sold out by 10am (which was considered late). The cashier was the sweetest and was the most accommodating for my friend that is allergic to nuts. She recommended to get in line by 8:30-9 to ensure yourself a cruffin! As we were munching away at their other lovely, perfectly flakey pastries, out comes Ry Stephen and the cashier with a single cruffin from the back room. They were nice enough to offer us this last majestic Choc Pop Rock Chip Tiger Drip Cruffin. We were simply ecstatic, totally made the hour commute from the east bay all the more worth it! Thank you based cruffin, I will never forget you. 

Who cares about the cronut, it's all about the cruffin!!! Holmes sweet Holmes
author: Laura N.

description: Followed the hype to wait at 8am on a weekend for my strawberry rhubarb cruffin. Devoured in seconds in the car with friends. Some of their other pastries, which rotate in availability, run a little on the diabetes-inducing sweet side but that cruffin was perfect! Too bad there's the 2 per person max...
author: Tina K.

description:
Went to Mr Holmes Bakehouse to try the much talked about cruffins.  I arrived at 8:55am to a pretty long line.  I was hoping that going on a weekday would make my trip quick and speedy, but I still got stuck with a wait.  

When I finally made it to the front of the line I was greeted by the cafe and cream cruffin which was being served today.  It was beautiful and truly a work of baked art.  The rest of the baked goods all looked spectacular as well.  I ended up getting my allotment of 2 cruffins and a few other items.  The cruffins were amazing!  Croissant texture with a delightful filling and lots of sugar!  All if the other items I tried were also delicious!

While all of the items I tasted were truly amazing, I don't think it was worth my 40 minute wait.  I'm glad I went once to check out SF's newest food craze, but I don't think I'll be back anytime soon unless there is a secret way I can avoid waiting in line!
author: Lisa M.

description: Obviously because of its popularity on social media I had to try this place while visiting SF. I was surprised at how tiny it was inside!
